We ordered the bucket of fried chicken since we were in the mood for hearty, southern/soul food. There was a lot of chicken to split among three of us and plenty left over that were taken home. We had the mash, creamed corn, and mac for sides. My favorite was the creamed corn. There was obvious truffle flavor, which I love. For dessert, we had to go with the beignets. They were big, but I've had better. It looked fluffy, but could be softer like actual beignets if they weren't overcooked. I normally have my beignets with a side of raspberry or chocolate sauce for dipping but this restaurant didn't have that option.
author: Mintz L.

description:
Contrary to popular opinion, I found my experience at The Front Porch to be completely underwhelming. I know, I know...I'm not sorry! My best friend fights me about this ALL. THE. TIME. I swear she loves this place so much, so I've told her I will still go back with her sometime in the future because she swears I must have had a bad batch or something. 

Anyway, upon arrival the first thing to catch my eye was the cute porch with rocking chairs! I was down to sit in the cold, but my girlfriend was not feeling the wind and chilly weather. We headed on inside and geez this place is tinyyyyy. Thank goodness I had made reservations! Dimly lit, super cozy, and adorable, I loved the vibe of this place! You're served some complimentary cornbread and it comes with a luscious herby butter. We ordered some garlic mashed potatoes and deviled eggs and these were our favorite part of our dinner. Such flavorful little deviled eggs! 

Finally, here comes the chicken, the star of the night, the reason why people say FUCKET get a bucket. Well, due to my bestfriend's love for this place and my hardcore love for fried chicken, I too found myself saying fucket, get a bucket. So much regret because we only ate a couple pieces since we weren't that fond of the chicken. It was tasteless, which I wouldn't complain too much about because they have an awesome selection of different hot sauces, but the thing that I couldn't shrug off was how extremely dry it all was! And where was the crunch from frying up and having a bath in hot oil? The skin was rather soggy and mehh. I will not fucket, I will not get the bucket.
author: Maleah M.

description:
"Fuck it get a BUCKET" is their T-shirt motto and if you're with a party of 3 or more it's a must! Fried chicken is crunchy, flavorful, and just perfect. After watching the fried chicken episode on Ugly Delicious (Netflix, look it up) my bf and I were jonsing for delicious chicken and this more than hit the spot! You can't go wrong with any of the sides, but my stepdaughter (who is a mac & cheese aficionado) said it's the best and could have had that on its own. 

So in short, go after you watch UD and "Fuck it get a BUCKET".
author: Karla N.

description:
This food was mostly trash. Honestly, they charge you like $18 for food that your cousin might make you when you're high at 2 am in his trailer. Their po'boy sandwich used low grade tomatoes and lettuce, on like a hotdog bun with some shrimp that had clearly been frozen at some point. The beans and rice was a huge let down, closer to bar-food-quality than Caribbean-restaurant-quality. My friend got the chicken and waffles and the chicken was super dry, and just not a good piece of meat.
It's like $15-$20 for food from your grandma's house...if your grandma hated you.
author: Jordan T.

description: Omg. I just ordered onions and mushrooms on my burger and it was SOOOO good. Ty for making it happen
author: Darryl V.

description: Chicken was extremely bitter and over cooked, and the gravy was the worst I've ever had.  Don't waste your money
author: George O.

description:
Was excited to try this place - southern home cooking with a focus on fried chicken. Overall didn't disappoint and glad we were able to get in without much of a wait.

Made a reservation (big family sometimes has its perks) and wound up sitting at the big booth just inside the door. A bit chilly...  would have loved a bit more temperature management or at least then using the curtain that was hanging there.

Enjoyed the deviled eggs and hush puppies as appetizers. More hush puppies...  seriously, they were great. Kids loved the Mac and cheese and the fried chicken was really delicious. Also really liked the short ribs and the burgers were really good as well.

Would go back, a Bernal Heights classic.
author: Bob K.

description: Well I have been here before and times have changed:  The burger was off.  I think they used ground short rib but when you do that you should mix it with some prime ground chuck.  It was really hard to eat and it had so much char from the grill I could taste it for a whole day later.  Hubby had the Dr Pepper short ribs way to sweet.  You need insulin after eating that.  Service was slow and lack lustre.  They had lights turned down way low.  The front porch needs a scrub down and a little mini renovation.  I know that is a kind of hipster place but at least try not to look so left over including the kitchen staff SMH!!
author: Pam P.

description:
Great spot!

We really enjoyed front porch's food. I had the chicken po boy, which i didn't know was a thing, but I liked it very much. Only challenge was that what seemed like 90% the mayo-sauce was all on one half of the sandwich -- so i really felt it was lacking for the first 50% of the meal, and was making a real mess once I hit the sauce for the second 50% of the meal. Husband had the burger, which he thoroughly enjoyed. 

The place is pretty grungy, and feels very much like a dive bar -- may or may not be your scene. We were the yuppiest folks in there for sure.
author: Stephanie M.

description: I liked the Front Porch, but didn't love it. The food felt like a California version of southern food and not authentic southern food. Our server was friendly and efficient, but the kitchen was very slow. We had to check on the status of our entrees a couple of times after waiting a very long time between courses. The cocktails were good. I would give it another shot, and definitely want to try it for brunch.
author: Peter O.

description:
I came to The Front Porch a few years ago and vowed to return back for more fried chicken.Years passed by, I finally got the chance to come back and I think my experience fell a little flat. I came for brunch this time and the service was extremely slow. I had the chicken fried steak- which I found to be way too salty. What a bummer!

I'm still giving them 3-stars thought because I remember their fried chicken was to die for! With all the options to eat in SF, I don't see myself heading back to the Front Porch anytime soon. Whomp Whomp.
author: Tiffany U.

description:
Amazing fried chicken and collard greens! Probably the best I've ever tasted. I've never liked collard greens before until I came here. Great atmosphere, wonderful people, and a long history of fantastic service and food. The people are down to earth. Feels like a second home.

I can't wait to try everything else on the menu.

Go Westlake!
author: Jacob J.

description: We came for a family dinner to try a different place in San Fran.  Our order contained blackened catfish, burgers, fried chicken meal, shrimp and grits, and kids mac and cheese.  Everything could have used a little more flavor.  The bbq shrimp from the Happy Hour menu was probably the best item.  The service was pretty good as we made a reservation around 7:30 for an 8:45 dinner time.  Our server was attentive.  If you like an eclectic, trendy place, this spot is for you.
author: Alejandro Y.

description:
We were excited to try this place...appeared to be a little hole in the wall with what appeared to be really authentic style of decor, etc. How much better would their food be. We ordered the gumbo as an appetizer.  I ordered the 4 pc fried chicken with garlic mashed potatoes and greens. The bf ordered the 1/2 rack of beef ribs which came with a side of beans and coleslaw. 
We were served 2 tiny cornbread muffins along with some herbed butter. Not sure if this came with our gumbo or always comes to the table at the beginning of your meal. Either way, it was good. 
The gumbo was so good but we should have ordered two appetizers. I definitely wanted more food once we were done sharing the cornbread and gumbo. I thought that this was OK though so we would have room for what was to come. 
Our food arrived and the breading on my fried chicken was...well no other way to describe it than burnt. I had read reviews about the golden breading of the fried chicken so I was really looking forward to this. I had to peel mine off because I'm not into burnt breading. It really turned me off but I proceeded in eating some plain chicken. I went after the greens as I was looking forward to those as well but they was so much vinegar in them that I just couldn't. The mashed potatoes and gravy were the best part of my dinner... though they didn't taste like they had much garlic in them. 
The BF's ribs that he ordered were cooked nicely but had a lot of dry rub on them for sure. Beans that came with the plate were very rich. We ordered some red beans and rice also and they were very good. 
They have a full bar and I ordered a basic margarita which had way too much triple sec or something of the like in it. Unfortunately I ended up leaving more than half of it there (this is so unlike me). 
I really wanted to like this place....we might try it again but just not sure.
author: Michelle F.

description:
My bf has this ritual where he has to get southern food to celebrate Martin Luther King Jr. We went for dinner time and boy was it dark inside. So this place is the bottom floor on a house, the concept is super cute. Its small and dark inside with candle light but it feels very homey. You should make a reservation for this place because it can get crowded. I had a good time but wondering why our food was taking so long to come out. Once we got out food, the waiter told the people next to us that the fried chicken takes about 25 mins to make which would've been nice to know for us when we ordered.

Blue Crab Hushpuppies were sooo good! It did look a little burnt on the outside but it was delicious! It's sweet with a little saltiness. Plus that remoulade is sooo good! The explosion of flavor mixed so well together 

4pc Fried Chicken has bread like crush and was very juicy. I was a little sad the breading got soft from the gravy on the mash potatoes tho. The mash potatoes were very creamy and flavorful. The greens were sweet and sour which was interesting but still good. 

The Mac n Cheese was pretty good. At first I thought it needed more flavor but when you eat the browned top and edges with the middle part of the mac n cheese, it's a good amount of flavor. The pasta is super soft and are made with the shells which makes it very easy to eat as well
author: Ada N.

description:
Awesome place for brunch! I recommend reservations as this eatery is relatively small and there can be a line during popular brunch hours. We had a big party of 10, so we had reservations. We were seated in this corner booth with additional chairs. It was kinda tight, but we made it work.

PARKING: Only street parking (mostly metered). There is one residential street where parking is free for 2 hours - but you gotta get lucky!

FOOD: Think Southern style brunch food. Appetizers were great too! Biscuits & gravy and the FRIED OKRA with jalapeno aioli. Yum! 

Their fried chicken is probably the most popular (takes 25 mins approx.). If you know you want it, order it fast so you don't have to wait long for it. Comes with huge pieces of chicken and a bacon waffle.

I ordered the benedict with andouille sausage - yum! Served with choice of cheese grits or tater tots (got the grits, but it was sooo much. Probably should've gotten the tots).

Overheard the coffee wasn't all that great - with some kind of spice to it?

SERVICE & AMBIANCE: Mood lighting and pretty dark in there. Don't count on getting a good picture of your food in the dark - just enjoy it! Service was decent and food came out relatively quickly.
author: Wing L.

description:
This place is amazing. Not only is the fried chicken some of the best you'll find in the city, but the service is very good. In fact, it stands out because it's so much better than it needs to be, as they're certainly not hurting for business. I've been here a couple of times and it's always at least an hour wait for a table.
We ordered a bucket of chicken. It was tender and juicy through and through. The most variable and differentiating factor with fried chicken is the batter. The batter is relatively thick but not bready. It is golden brown and crispy throughout. It's well spiced and they provide two kinds of house hot sauce. Seriously delicious. I often am tempted to peel off the breading when I have fried chicken. Never here! 
We also got collard greens, which were perfectly cooked and not light on the ham, as well as rice and beans, which were great, heavy on the tomatoes and peppers. They come vegetarian but you can choose to add sausage. We opted for veggie and it was great. There's other stuff on the menu, but I find it hard to imagine getting anything other than chicken. 
Here's why I'm really writing this review. I want to give a huge shout out to host Kevin. We came on a Tuesday night and put our name on the list for a 45 minute wait. The group of people I was with had some catching up to do, so it was no big deal. We went to rock bar and had some manhattans while we waited. (Owned by the same folks, check it out.)
Sometimes wait estimates go wrong. We ended up waiting for maybe an hour and a half, but you know what, shit happens. Servers can't control how long tables stay occupied. We were deep in conversation and not worried about it at all. Kevin seemed so distressed to have our wait extended, and he more than made up for it. He hooked us up with free appetizers, and was absurdly grateful when we were cool about the whole thing. The point is he really cared about our experience. I wish I knew our server's name because she was great, too. We had a lovely evening despite the wait! 
TLDR: food is great, rare good service in SF, don't miss it
author: Anna P.

description: Best brunch ever. Do be warned that corn bread is a night time dish not a day time one. Must eat: the sausage biscuit gravy, and the fried chicken.
author: Peter T.

description: Love this place! Great food. Owner was extremely nice. It is a busy place, so make reservations!
author: Elaine M.

description:
my friend & i came here and had a FEAST. the free cornbread was warm and delicious. the fried
Okra was appetizing. a tad salty. we ordered the fried chicken and it came with mashed taters and collard greens and sprinkled random popcorn on the side.  chicken  and side was aight 3/5. the shrimp & grits was great. tasty big shrimp. Friend ordered the chicken liver which i had never tried before. he digged it because he enjoys that stuff but i was gucci off of trying the slightest bit (not for me because hella tastes like iron). then we topped it off with some beignets and an assortment of sauces (chocolate, caramel, and shrawberry). They were good but not like amazing because i wished they were softer in texture. oh yeah, the lemonade was FIRE.
author: Ying Ci H.

description: I was there for dinner last night with my husband and two kids. My son was entertained with the pay phone  The food overall was  tasty! For appetizers we had the devil eggs which I would say they were just okay... it needed more flavor. The fried pickle were yummy. For dinner we ordered the bucket of chicken  with a side of Mac n cheese to die for and fries. The fried chicken was delicious and the house sauce waamazing! The server and service was overall good. I made reservations for 8:15 and was seated on time.
author: Mariela S.

description: Found this place randomly while driving by and decided to wait till they opened. Thank god we did! There were already several people waiting to be seated as well. My bf and I sat at the bar, and the bartender Rafael was awesome! Overall we enjoyed our food and more importantly the service! We will def be coming back to try more!
author: Deborah J.

description: I won't consider myself hard to please but this place did not meet my expectations. The decor and ambiance of the place was nice, customer service was also good but the food was a bit of a disappointment. We ordered the fried chicken and baked Mac and cheese. (Side note: I came in pretty hungry) the Mac and cheese was tasty but it was way too oily. The fried chicken was a bit bland and the breading wasn't as crispy as I'd thought it'd be. I wouldn't come back here for the food but I will come back for the decor and hang at the bar!
author: Wendy E.

description: I've been here twice, incidentally for my boyfriend's birthday both times. I really like that it's easy to get reservations for large parties- something rare for sf. The downside, however, is that the service was pretty slow. It could be because we had a large group, but I felt like the time it took between us ordering and actually getting our food was a little unreasonably long- especially for a weeknight (the restaurant was probably 50-75% full?). As for the food itself, I thought the burger that I got was pretty good although not particularly memorable. The entrees are all fairly expensive as well ($15+). All in all, I don't think the food is bad but there isn't much about it that would make me want to go back.
author: Stephany L.

description: Ordered the shrimp and grits. Lemme tell y'all something...I've eaten shrimp and grits all throughout the south and the dish served at the Front Porch is right up there with them.  The shrimps, juicy. The grits, creamy. The gravy with the andouille sausage, a hint of spicy and plenty savory.  This dish was great.  My wife ordered the 4-piece fried chicken plate and the batter they used for the fried chicken was packed with flavor.  Eating the collard greens took me back to Alabama or South Carolina the way they kept it authentic.  They also had red pinot noir from the Mosel region of Germany, which is my favorite wine so far. The mac and cheese should be renamed to cheese and mac the way it was so creamy.  Service was great too!  Michelle took care of my baby girl and was accommodating​ to my pregnant wife when she wanted to change her order.
author: Angelo L.

description: Good southern cooking & fun drinks.  Cozy atmosphere, decent waitstaff.  You order your food, then wait for it to be cooked.  I thought the food to be authentic (southern cooking) but nothing outstanding.  Luckily we shared quite a few items.
author: Molly M.

description:
Had a cheat day and had a small bite of my friends burger. Quality meat! Juicy & tender. Like how its deconstructed so you can do what you want with your burger. Creole fries were decent but nothing to write home about. 
My friend kept asking for more ketchup cuz they give you a tiny saucecup. Finally our server got the point and gave our table the whole bottle.

We came in here for dinner and it was so dimly lit. We had to use our phones to read the menu.. Then they came by halfway thru our meal to light the candle at our table..

Service was courteous but a bit slow. Slightly expensive but worth it if you enjoy the food. 

Skip the sparkling lemonade. Tasted like lemonade with club soda. They also add alot of ice to their drinks so ask for no ice or less.
author: Angela C.

description: Great brunch spot. Excellent fried okra as an appetizer. Good coffee. I had the pork and sweet potato hash. It was tasty but a little bland. I hear the fried chicken is good. Excellent service. Dark ambiance. I would eat here again.
author: Charles N.

description: This place was sooo delicious! It was definitely on the pricey end but it was totally worth it. I would highly recommend getting a reservation because that seems to cut down on the wait time. The place is small but also adorable. Will definitely be going there again.
author: Bree Y.

description: I love front porch  I've been for brunch and dinner and it's all delicious. Everyone who works there is so nice and I want to eat here every day.
author: Molly S.

description:
This place wow what can I say...sure didn't disappoint. We got here a little bit earlier than our reservation time and the owner was super nice to let us know when they would be ready for us and to go across the street and grab drinks while we wait. They own the bar by the way cant remember the name so this is s review for both spots.

1. Bar across the street- Nice cool local vibe feel drinks are well poured. I think I saw a pool table could be wrong.

2. Now back to this place- OMG order the shrimp n grits super bomb and flavorful. Fried chicken was crispy and moist with it would of been a bit more seasoned with herbs but it deffinatenly doesnt stop me from ordering it again. Mac and cheese was nice and gooey cant complain.

 I will deffinatenly  come back to that bar and front porch  again. I advise you make reservations I heard the owner tell one couple the wait was going to be almost 2 hours.
author: Stina N.

description: If you haven't been to Front Porch you are missing a big part of your life. Their Chicken Fried Steak is the  bomb. A little bit thin on the steak but the breading is delicious. Crisped to perfection. But lets not forget the best part of the meal was the sausage gravy. Not too thick and not too thin. I just don't know how else to describe it but its just overly delicious. Can't get over it. Pair it with the freshly baked biscuit it will just make your day. This meal is a must. Worth your $16. The meal also includes 2 eggs and a choice between tater-tots or the cheese grits. I also tried one of their special sandwich, the fried oyster po'boy and its just yummy. Perfectly portioned fried oyster plus a side of fries. This place is a must. Highly recommended. A+++ for they deliver too. Will keep coming back. Authentic country food.
author: Kristina A.

description:
Wow! This was so unexpected. Booked as a last minute brunch, but definitely somewhere we will return to. I had the pulled pork hash (delicious & good value) & my husband had the fried chicken which - although not Brenda's (his standard setter) - went down pretty well! 

The place itself is pretty & cozy. Most importantly it was super super busy (great sign)! Can't wait for our next visit.
author: Fi M.

description: It's so good.  That's it's good.  Lol. Oh man. Gumbo on point mac and cheese is mind-blowing chicken was good and tender. Dinky little place to eat but awesome food worth it
author: Nancy X.

description: I have brought two different friend groups here for their birthday parties and we always have a great time! It might be a little pricey, but that is why it is a birthday treat- the drinks and service make up for it. They are super accommodating and the host is always so nice. It is only four stars because the food is ok but thank you to the servers, host, cooks and bartenders for making this restaurant run as smoothly as it does.
author: Aili P.

description: When my order arrived the fries were hard and cold, as if they were old. Garlic mashed potatoes had way too much garlic in them. The portions were very small e.g. vegan red beans and rice, to be so expensive. I've heard and read good things about the front porch; however, this was my first and last time trying them.
author: Tyree R.

description: Incredible food and service. Cute spot with moody decorations that make the restaurant feel homey. Delicious food! Tried the Mac and cheese, short ribs and shrimp with grits. Highly recommend
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Bread pudding, fried chicken and waffles, baked eggs, Mac n cheese and a half dozen Roman Holidays was just what I needed to settle a rum-induced hangover 12 hours prior. 

Food: we started with the mains--great fried chicken, not saying the best but certainly hits the spot. My friend ordered the three piece on a waffle but was kind enough to share a little of his wrong with me. I'm a hot sauce on chicken gal but friend's addition of syrup was actually pretty dinner licking good. I had the baked eggs because every ingredient in there ranked to 10 on my fav foods list. Creamy cheesy (goat cheese) grits, sauteed mushrooms and baby spinach, egg and some sweet sweet crack bacon. It was the first time I ordered it and they got all the ratios of food just to my liking. Whole lotta grits w small dabbles of goat cheese, one egg, sprinkling of mushroom and spinach, and two strips of bacon cut in bite sized pieces so that every spoonful of heaven had some pork angel on it. 

Bread pudding cake next. It was beautiful but aside from the real whipped cream on top, I would have preferred hobies (sry). 

I needed a little extra calories Fromm just having the baked egg and decided to get a side of Mac n cheese. Cheesy lava came and went. It's was like an out of body experience because before I knew it, I had finished it. Two mains at 1030am Saturday! Boom. Drop the mic. I didn't have to eat for the rest of the day. 

One deduction bc of the bread pudding and our waitress. She was nice when she first sat us down with but she tried to take my menu away when I knew I was gonna order more - and I told her that! She also didn't come back to check if we've busted a button on our shirts with all that food but the other staff made up for it :). 

I'm hoping to avoid her the next time I go!
author: anja l.

description:
I had a craving for fried chicken and creole food, so I chose this restaurant for date night. 

We had a fantastic meal. The chicken was on point, and since I know how to fry and make amazing chicken, this was the real deal. It was definitely soaked in buttermilk before hand(secret of juicy, moist chicken). The skin was full of flavour and spices...yes! I got a side of baked macaroni and cheese, which I paid extra for, greens, and hushpuppies. I was not impressed by the Mac and Cheese, but I'm picky in that regards. I also got a cocktail that was delicious, and my husband got standard martinis and the white wine that was recommended to go with the chicken.  We also got the crawfish hushpuppies, which I'd give a pass on because they don't taste like what I know to be hushpuppies (they were also a mite overpriced at $11..That's a $7-8 item).

However, I came to leave a review for the greens!!! These are REAL Southern greens, cooked just like the ones I grew up eating in the South. The secret to good greens is you need to add a little sugar, or honey, to cut the bitterness, when you cook them. It brings out the delicious flavour, and these greens had some vinegar in them, too.  I genuinely raved about them to the people working there...y'all just don't know! Real greens cooked the right way are nearly impossible to find in a restaurant, so I always end up making them if I crave them.  However, it's awesome and surprising that I could find these in San Francisco!!

I use a walker to ambulate, so when I made a reservation on Yelp, I mentioned that in my comments. They actually read it, and sat us at a table that was easy for us to get to, and store my walker. They have a portable ramp they can pull out to use for the bathrooms, since they are up a step, FYI.  The space is definitely cozy..I kind of felt like I was eating in someone's living room.  My husband felt a tad claustrophobic,initially, but after a drink he was fine!

The service was awesome, and I especially appreciate the hostess/manager who was working in the front and around the restaurant. Great service and treatment definitely makes the experience of going out a treat.

We'll definitely be back...if just for the greens and chicken!
author: Robin W.

description: Food and Service was excellent. I love the small quaint feel of this place while dining with family. They could have fried a few of the chicken pieces harder but, overall I have no complaints and will definitely return to try their brunch.
author: DeAndrea S.

description:
Made rsvp here through Yelp. It's a good thing to do before hand cuz this place can get busy. My husband and I ate on their "front porch" and there were others eating outside as well. They have cute rocking chairs to sit on to make you feel at home, I didn't sit on one while I ate though. The hubby did. They also have cute decorations hanging above you for shade. Super cute. 

I ordered a drink but I didn't like it. I think it was with cranberry and champagne? Or something like that. 

My husband ordered the steak and eggs which was bomb and I ordered the shrimp and grits which was also very delicious. 

I wish I remembered our waiters name cuz he was really friendly and helpful with the menu. The food came out at a good time. I would def come back here and taste their dinner menu cuz we came here more for a brunch time. 

Parking is a pain, but thats SF for you. Small cute little restaurant. 

Can't wait to come back.
author: Chan T.

description:
Went to this place because it was featured on Diners, Drive-in and Dives, and was not disappointed. If you can handle chilly SF weather, the seating outside with rocking chairs is pretty cute. But the inside has a dark, romantic sort of feel to it that makes it great for a date. 

The food was excellent. Highly recommend their Dr. Pepper braised short ribs - the meat is so tender and juicy and the gravy is delicious! And of course, the fried chicken is great. I tend to like my fried chicken on the spicier side, so on its own theirs is a little plain for me, but they offer different levels of hot sauce to compensate. And OMG their mac 'n cheese is fantastic! 

We'll definitely be returning to try more stuff!
author: Livia E.

description:
The Front Porch wildly surpassed my expectations for Brunch this past Sunday. I was expecting some greasy spoon food that would leave me feeling gross for the whole day but instead was met with DELICIOUS comfort food that I cannot wait to eat again.

We made a brunch reservation for 10:15AM at the last minute and were glad we did. Within 15 minutes of us arriving, every table on the inside was taken and people had to be sat on the outside deck or at the bar. Seriously, most places don't take reservations for Brunch so its awesome that a place as popular as The Front Porch does. The space on the inside, as pointed out by other reviews, is definitely dark. Even in the morning the restaurant felt like a divey bar. This isn't necessarily a negative, just unique for sure. I could definitely see coming here for some late night drinks based on their drink list, the space and the prices.

Anyways, onto the food! The two of us ordered:

-Coffee ($3): I usually hate Chicory Coffee but this was delicious and the taste of the chicory wasn't overwhelming. Refills were frequent which I appreciated

-Beignets ($5): SO GOOD. The right size, fluffy and warm. These were served in half of a paper bag which was cute. I honestly could have eaten these by itself for breakfast. MUST ORDER. 

-Spicy Shrimp & Grits ($18)-This was my order and I am so glad I got it. While there were only 4 piece of Shrimp, the portion was really filling and I couldn't even finish my plate. The flavors were delicious and rich. I would kill to order this again

-Chicken and Waffles ($17)-This was A's order and it was HUGE. 3 massive pieces of fried chicken over a belgian waffle. Holy shit. Let me just say that the fried chicken was AMAZING. A said it was the best he has ever had and I tend to agree. I cannot wait to come for dinner and get the plate of this. The waffle under it was okay, nothing special. A also couldn't finish his so we luckily got to eat leftovers after.

Overall, this was a very reasonably priced brunch given the quality of food, size of the portion and attentive service. Neither of us expected to like this place that much and honestly, I think it is better than Brenda's across town. I cannot wait to come back and get dinner or drinks. Seriously, if you are in Bernal, you have got to come here.
author: Carrie W.

description: I love this place tucked away in the outer Mission in a converted basement/garage.  This only adds to the charm and lends itself to the southern, New Orleans-y feel.  Two words: Fried Okra! Yes, please! Can't get enough of this! Okra is a finicky vegetable that can be divine or disgusting. The Front Porch successfully achieves divine every time.  I have tried a number of items on the brunch menu and have yet to find anything I was disappointed with.  The fried chicken po-boy is awesome! The pulled pork & sweet potato hash is amazing as well.   The servers are all friendly and very accommodating.  Ashley works the front of the house with reservations and being the perfect hostess with the mostest!  Kenny's always a fave server and it's great to see his smile when we sit.  I still need to hit them up for dinner and look forward to an equally delicious experience.
author: Dana E.

description:
I just want to start off by saying Kevin had amazing hospitality! This place is listed as "not kid friendly" but that is quite the contrary. This restaurant has a kids menu and high chairs. My husband and I visited this location with our three children and our youngest happened to be quite the handful that evening. The reason why I bring this up is because they brought a toy to try to settle him down which i truly appreciated and was unexpected. 


Now down to the food. My husband and I were impressed with the cornbread, fried chicken, mashed potatoes and gravy, mac & cheese.  However we felt the hush puppies were over done and extremely tiny. The greens had  to much of like a vinger taste an almost no hammock in it. The short ribs were good but not what we expected. 


Anyways overall it was pretty good my husband and I will definitely be back to try brunch and probably without our children lol
author: Brittany G.

description: How can I not like a place where u can order a deep fried pickle?  Combine that with amazing fried chicken (in a bucket), Mac and cheese, creamed corn, fluffy biscuits with rosemary butter...all washed down with an aperol spritz.  Great way to celebrate the 4th!!!  Oh and of course salad with feta, arugula and sliced fruit so that we were not complete gluttons!  Yum yum gimme some!!
author: lisa w.

description: This place is amazing! Awesome food, great people and the ambiance is second to none! The bartender and owner Josie are THE BOMB! I love this place and I come all the way from Michigan to EAT IT!
author: Mary B.

description: Best fried chicken! Absolutely love the food here. And the fact you can order from Rock Bar and have it brought over.
author: Brian S.

description:
After running the San Francisco marathon, I ended up here with a friend on a whim to break the 9 hour hunger spree. The wait was about an hour or so with 6 parties in front of us, take that as you will whether or not that's a victory.

First off was the gumbo. Perhaps it was me being famished but I wolfed down my half pretty quick. My only note that I can remember about the gumbo was that it tasted like it's a slightly elevated version of something I'd find in a can. I'd skip this should I ever come back.

To make up for that lackluster appetizer, we followed it up with the fried okra. This is the complete opposite reaction to the gumbo because these were fried to some kind of transcendent perfection. The batter was amazing and the jalapeno aioli gave it that perfect tip to make it over the top. Highly recommend!

I had the chicken fried steak as my entree. The steak itself was a little tough, the tater tots weren't fried to being as crispy as I'd like, but the over easy eggs were done correctly. Still, I ate it all anyways because #hungry.

My friend ordered the shrimp poboy and it was pretty tasty the few bites I had. The fries that came with it (and my tots) had a cajun seasoning on it which was rather pleasant.

All in all; cool little place where you should order the fried okra.
author: Jonathan N.

description: LOVE this place! There wasn't too long of a wait for four people and the customer service was fun and helpful. The drinks were yummy and my friend and I ordered the seasonal risotto (excellent!) and apparently the pulled pork ribs were good too. Will definitely come back when I visit SF again!
author: Alicia M.

description: The place is a hidden charm. We made a reservation for 6 people and we got seated outside in the back. The atmosphere is great . I don't recall exactly what I ordered. I remembered it was delicious:) the service is very good too.
author: Tracy D.

description:
How is this place not 5 stars?!  I've never had better fried chicken in my life. My girlfriend and I are so disgustingly full right now, and my wallet is happy too.

If you're craving biscuits, gravy, mac n cheese, collard greens, and/or fried chicken, you have to go here. It's a must for any people close to SF.

We didn't try anything else. Other reviews mention bad ribs. Don't eat ribs in California. If you want BBQ go to Dallas.
author: Matt H.

description:
Obie is the man, the myth, the legend. Under the Yodaesque instruction of Ashley Miller, he has really begun to spread his wings and grow into a starring role behind the bar. Sitting at his bar, you can't help but feel like you're familia.

His discerning use of Chareau in a Rye Sour was absolutely blissful and complimented the spicy notes of the whiskey like butter on bread.

Furthermore, this place also has the best Fried Chicken in the city, and quite possibly the entire west coast.
author: Zachary T.

description:
There are so many reasons to come here.
But, if you like fried chicken. Then you NEED to come here. And it is so good leftover. And the collard greens. And the service. And the drinks. And the casual vibe. 
Make a reservation. And take home your leftover chicken. My lunch the following day was just as good with cold fried chicken.
author: Amy O.

description:
Fire fire fire. This place gets lots of praise from locals, food blogs, and Guy Fieri alike - and all for good reason. I've only had brunch here but tried a bunch of different items, some of which are offered at brunch and dinner time. Many people have already written tons about this great spot so I'll keep it to the highlights. 

-The chicken fried steak with gravy and cheesy grits was one of the best I've had and best value to quality to quantity ratio dishes I've had in San Francisco. The gravy had an amazing smoky rich flavor and the cheese grits were succulent, rich, and addictive. The steak was big and hearty and not so pounded out that the breading becomes the star of the show. For $13 I can't think of a better way to get filled up and satisfied in SF. 

-The blueberry cornbread bread pudding is completely ridic. Delicious, rich, moist, decadent, it was the perfect way to end brunch as a shared dessert. The texture is drier than your average bread pudding but moister than the typical cornbread. Fusion at its finest. 

-They take reservations for brunch. (Through Yelp! Wooo!)

-Cons that almost made this a 4 star review: chicory coffee isn't really my thing, even though I still drank 4 cups of it. The eggs Benedict was a bit of a let down - not enough hollandaise and not enough Cajun flavor to really differentiate it from any other that I've had. Many many better benedicts in the Bay Area, but TBH that's probably not why you would come here.
author: Sean S.

description: I made reservations for Mother's Day and my party had one more than expected. The staff were super friendly and accommodating. Food was fast and delicious! I highly recommend the hush puppies and the bucket of fried chicken, the best Southern food I've ever had!
author: Jenny J.

description: Awesome! I like such cousine now. Thank yiu so much for a great time and nice atmosphere.
author: Odeya S.

description:
Wanted to try this after I saw it on Check Please Bay Area. As a Southerner living in San Francisco, this place really fell short.  
Boiled peanuts, fried chicken, and collards were a no. Cornmeal on fried chicken is just not something I can do. 
Biscuits and Mac and cheese were good but that's about it.
It was absolutely freezing inside if you are seated anywhere near the front door.
author: Jean G.

description:
Came here for brunch on a Sunday. Ordered chicken and waffles. It's the worst chicken and waffles I've had. Worse than Brenda's, worse than Farmer Brown's. Chicken was dry and very salty. Waffles is nothing special. Overall, it tastes like something you can buy frozen from a grocery store and bake at home. No special flavoring or seasoning, or any uniqueness at all. 

Tried my friend's tater tot. I normally love tater tots. They're pretty salty and weird-tasting here. I would say it tastes worse than the frozen ones from grocery stores. I did not want a second one. 

Had a beignet. It was decent but not as good as Brenda's or beignets in New Orleans. The skin was tough. 

Atmosphere is awful. Extremely dark in here (think: bar) even though it's brunch time. Very noisy, loud music, and service is slow. Not a good place to talk. 

Parking is easy but that's about the only pro. 

I wouldn't recommend this place. I found this place via Yelp and this is one of those places where Yelp ratings are way off.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The Front Porch is quickly becoming a favorite weekday date night spot. Along with the juiciest fried chicken I've had in the city and some killer seafood bouillabaisse, the restaurant has the most old school New Orleans / East Village NYC bar vibe, with tin-tiled ceilings, worn in couches, and a great candle-lit rustic ambiance. The cocktails are no slouches either.

In the future, I see myself bringing out of town visitors here to show them what a perfect neighborhood restaurant in Bernal/Mission looks like.
author: Ken H.

description:
Had a great meal at The Front Porch last night.  The have a Southern/Creole menu and everything looked tempting.  I went for the Baby-back Ribs and my guest chose the Root Beer Short Ribs.  We started with a side of fried pickles and added some Mac & Cheese to top it all off.

The service was friendly.  The first thing the bring you, after your drink order, is cornbread muffins.  This was the only, for lack of a better word, disappointment of the meal.  The cornbread muffins were the tiniest I have ever seen and we each got one, along with some butter. I guess it was a teaser as they sell the cornbread muffins as a starter.

The Fried Pickles were excellent. They were sliced, as opposed to spears, which made for nice tasty bites! 

The Baby-back Ribs were awesome.  They were mouth watering and had a great taste to them.  I am not a fan of beans, but ate all of my root beer baked beans.

Although my guest wouldn't share any with me, he raved about the Short-ribs all night.

The side of Mac&Cheese was a meal in itself.  It came in a hot skillet and we shared it. The sides were nice and crusty and the cheese was melted throughout and baked on top.

This Front Porch has been added to my list of San Francisco restaurant stops!
author: Pj D.

description: After reading fellow reviewers I was excited to try this restaurant. I came for lunch and was surprised no one was there but possibly found out why. Server was awesome ran through the menu and highlighted favorites. I decided on the fried chicken and shrimp po'boy which I'd take home to eat later. The chicken arrived looked good, skin was crispy but something did smell right I'm an armature cook.  I cut the chicken at the bone sure enough it was undercooked after checking the second piece it was the same. After informing the waiter who spoke with who I assume is the manager I was told it's the bloodline and not undercooked.  I've cooked plenty of chicken to know this was not the case. Undercooked chicken could be dangerous but to not acknowledge and insult me is worse. But to make me feel better they gave me a friends and family discount of $3 I was shocked but give the lack of customers realized they need every penny they can make. Overall good wait staff horrible management and hope no one gets sick!
author: Los C.

description: Great food, great service. We came for dinner and got the cornbread, catfish, and Dr. Pepper ribs! Delicious :)
author: Mingming C.

description:
The food is really good. Favorites: fried okra, fried chicken, bbq pork ribs, Mac and cheese...get the picture, all so good! 
Not sure why Yelp says "not good for kids." We brought our son, the owner and staff are very welcoming to children! He loved the Mac and cheese from the KIDS menu. Bring the whole family, great place to share a meal.
author: Melanie H.

description: It's quaint, has a homey feel. You have to try their Gumbo, Shrimp&gritS...... Amazeballs !!! The vegan dish is tasty, fresh, and filling will come back
author: Lala B.

description:
It was our first time at The Front Porch and we had pretty high expectations from the great reviews. It lived up to those expectations for the most part. 

The fried chicken was incredible - both flavorful inside and out, cooked to perfection, and the breading was traditionally seasoned to its Southern flavors. The pork belly sliders are definitely a must get. The mac 'n cheese, while cooked wonderfully, was a bit on the bland side when it came to both texture and taste. The beignets we ordered were a bit too hard, we were expecting the insides to be more doughy and donut-like, but it tasted more like hardened bread. 

Overall, the atmosphere as well as service was phenomenal. Some of the dishes could've been better but we would definitely come back again.
author: My N.

description: I took my boyfriend here a few months ago and it's the cutest coziest place. It literally feels like you're in the south on someone's porch :)
author: Shannon S.

description: I went here for my birthday in September. I had a great time. The staff was friendly. The service was great and so was the food. We ended up getting the bucket o chicken and it was crispy and delicious. I split it with my friend. The drinks were also great. I'm not really sure what other items they have to offer but I definitely want to go back.
author: Kim D.

description:
I always tend to mix up Front Porch with Portland's Screen Door. 
If Front Porch had a screen door, or if Screen Door had a front porch, I would be really confused.

The Front Porch is a rather popular southern place in SF, and it's been on my list to try after acquiring a taste for Southern food (I used to hate fried food, but southern/cajun/creole is such a foodie genre, I jumped onto the fried chicken bandwagon.

The restaurant itself is a bit odd; the inside is very dark, and the tables are very high up compared to the seats. Unless you love eating in extremely poorly lit places, I suggest requesting the front porch tables, though it's limited. If I ran the place, I would either light up the inside better or turn more of the restaurant into front porch seating à la Foreign Cinema outdoors seating with an invisible tarpe. Anyways, I shall proceed with the food review (and a warning about poor quality food pictures in the dim lighting.)

(+) Corn bread with herb butter (complimentary): Bite-size corn bread that's indulgently buttery, made even tastier with the herb butter. I really liked how it was in small pieces because it was surprisingly filling, and you get a lot of crust (similar to the muffin top concept). One of the more memorable bites of the visit.

(+/-) Fried corn on the cob with creole crema & cotija cheese ($6.50): The menu description sounded more exciting than it tasted, unfortunately. Basically buttery grilled corn with some melted cheese and chopped garlic. Interesting take that reminded me of Mexican food, but not particularly memorable.

(++) Fried pickles with Tabasco aioli ($7): This was my favorite! Similar to fried zucchini, except the sourness of the pickle is magical with the panko batter. Although I couldn't taste much Tabasco in the aioli, the creaminess added a nice contrast.

(+/-) Baked mac n cheese ($8): I liked the noodles, which were thick and shaped like something like elongated shells. (Difficult to tell in the dark lighting) The rich creaminess was satisfying, but it could do without the extra thick layer of cheddar cheese on top. Also, their selection of cheese seemed to ooze out a lot of oil.

(+/-) 10-piece bucket of fried chicken ($29): Maybe it was the anticipation that this is one of their signature items, along with the fact that it was the longest wait, but the fried chicken failed to meet my expectations. The batter did have an overtone of a caramelized taste, but I found it too thick, greasy, and not crispy enough. I also think I prefer a more savory approach on fried chicken with ample black pepper, rather than Front Porch's more bland version with a hint of sweet. I hate to say this, but I honestly think I prefer KFC for the composition. On the plus side, Front Porch's comes in a cute bucket and popcorn.

Overall, Front Porch is not bad but their style of heavy creaminess and greasiness just isn't for me. It's funny that I was initially disappointed since many plates seemed to look small, but turned out to be super filling due to all the lipids. I much prefer Buttermilk Kitchen for southern food, which has bolder, spicier flavors and is less greasy in my opinion. 

On the plus side, Front Porch has rocking chairs, a mini rocking horse, and our server spoke with a southern accent.
author: Edna C.

description: Came here for brunch. My pulled pork hash was so bad I barely touched it. Not once during the whole meal did the server ask me if my meal was ok. At the end, she took my plate away and asked me if I needed a to go box. I said no, but was still charged for food I never ate... definitely never going back here again. Basic food and exceptionally poor service. Consider this a PSA.
author: Martin K.

description: Great food, staff super nice and fast service! Cutest little hole in the wall I've been to in a long time. Highly recommend!
author: Ashley A.

description: Not very family friendly... my kids were literally walking up to the front of the restaurant and the host gave away our table because "we weren't all there". What a big jerk! My only guess for such rotten behavior is that he really didn't want kids in the restaurant. At 5:30... not like we were taking prime time seats.
author: AMIE L.

description: Loved this place for brunch. Comfort food with a southern flair! Fried okra as an appetizer and then max cheese with spicy beef and an egg on top - delicious and decadent! Wonderful atmosphere sitting outside on a beautiful San Francisco day!
author: Mike H.

description:
The Front Porch had been on my bookmarks for about as long as I had been in SF, but hadn't been out to Bernal enough. Also with a place like The Front Porch, you want to go with friends, especially friends from the south. So for my last dinner as an SF resident I recruited my friends and we got to enjoy a wonderful last meal.

As people have mentioned, it is a bit tight inside - As you walk past the cute little front porch (which does have heat lamps for those cold, winter nights) you enter into a small - I would barely call it a foyer by the door. There is a curtain, and I unfortunately learned that that curtain is there to protect the two patrons sitting at the bar from the cold. I had bumped into them and I apologize. If you don't have a reservation or good timing you may have to wait a bit to get a seat but we got the last table right in front of the kitche and by the restrooms (also protected by a curtain) and got to look at the menu.

Our waitress quickly came and was delightful - she really made an effort to do all that she could. To start we wanted some drinks and the two men at the table got "smoke gets in your eyes", we're both mezcal fans and this sounded and tasted great. I ended up getting a second. The woman got a bottle of white wine which her man ended up getting a glass as well.

For the food we started with the following:
-Blue Crab Hush Puppies with spicy remoulade - all of us are fans of hush puppies and you could really taste the crab. You had to dip it in the remoulade for the full flavor experience.
-New Orleans style Beignets with powdered sugar - While usually for brunch or dessert, we started early. Well one of us did, I saved mine for dessert when you factor in the hush puppies.
-Fried Okra with jalapeno aioli - So I'm a huge fan of okra, but my woman friend wasn't and she made that very clear. Whether out of irony or spite, our waitress gave us an order of these on the house. I thought they were great, esepcially with that aioli.
-Biscuits - We're from the south, how could we not order these? Holy crap were they good, a buttery, flaky square of heaven.

As for the main meal, the restaurant currently had a special Beer Week menu, and while EVERY item sounded great, for simplicity's sake we went with the Bucket o' Chicken. They weren't kidding when they say bucket, and I really enjoyed the random bits of popcorn. They let us know ahead of time our bucket was missing two pieces, which they delivered shortly (with more popcorn!). The fried chicken was hot, moist, and spiced perfectly and I also introduced my friends to the wonder that is honey on fried chicken. Stuck with the white meat and got a breast and a wing. Both were great.

As for the side, I know we got baked mac & cheese and it went fast, regardless of the steaming hotness. I love mac & cheese and these were solid.

So as my last meal in town, I was more than content, I was southern fried full. And I even had a beignet for dessert!

Notes:
-Hot Sauces: they have a chile and a habanero. That Habanero will kick your ass, but it is worth it on okra, or chicken, or whatever.
-Honey: Seriously, if you've never had honey on fried chicken (channel your inner mcnuggets and honey memories) you are missing out. Even better with the above hot sauces for a sweat and spicy combo!
author: Michael C.

description:
Came here on Fat Tuesday and this place was packed! We had a reservation right when it opened so it wasn't too bad but it was super busy by the time we finished. They also gave us beads which was festive. 

Can't go wrong with the bucket of fried chicken which was great for the whole table. I've had the Mac and cheese before and it was ok but THIS time it was bubbling hot and crispy on the bottom of the cast iron dish it came in. The secret is to keep it cooking for a few minutes then dig into it. It was so delicious we ordered another! We also ordered the mashed potatoes which was good and the fried okra was ok. 

The iced tea was average and wanted a punch so they added some bourbon to sweeten it. 

King cake was a little dry but my friend found the baby in the cake so she was thrilled! 

The front of the house staff and waiter were all very friendly. It was a great time. Thanks Front Porch!
author: Cindy A.

description:
We scoured Yelp for a last minute, in the city, Friday night reservation for 10 that at least looked semi kid-friendly from Yelp photos and ended up choosing The Front Porch for a bevy of reasons, inclusive of Bernal Heights location and parking convenience via a drive from South Bay, the 2k+ reviews, and the general deliciousness of Cajun and/or Southern food.

The dinner ended up being more successful than I figured, lugging an infant and a toddler in either hand. We got to the City in just under an hour and found parking around the corner (and walked past a dispensary, natch) with no problems. The front area and bar is small, but it's an elongated space and we squeezed into a round booth which would have better sat 8 but provided a cozy, raucous atmosphere.

After dining here, I still can't figure if this place's roots are Cajun or Southern. Drink-wise, I started with a draft Abita something-or-another (natch, again), probably the standard Amber or Purple Haze, and followed that up with a Fieldwork IPA (one of their many). We picked up some starters, too. The fried pickles were good (hard to ever go wrong there) but the blue crab hush puppies were the hit.

For mains, the wife and I went with the fried chicken and the shrimp and grits. In that battle, the Southern side clearly came out the victor. The shrimp and grits were fine; Brenda's is better. The fried chicken, though, was fairly fantastic. As opposed to my younger days, I don't get the fried chicken much in the Bay Area (and even then, it's usually Popeyes Tuesdays, because you never go wrong there), but Front Porch's chicken plate is huge, tasty, and worth the cash outlay.

Between the plethora of food, availability of kids menus, and last minute large party availability, I'm counting this as a successful dining experience.
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
Brunch = yummmm
Definitely the best biscuits that I have had in SF. The fried Okra was delicious and so was the mac and cheese. All the food that our group ordered was amazing! The service was great. All in all a really fun brunch experience. Going back to get those amazing biscuits again for sure!!!
author: Bhavya K.

description:
Not too into the fried chicken, it was just so-so. Maybe I'm just not a foodie and prefer KFC...

I enjoyed the shrimp and grits more than the fried chicken. The shrimp was fresh and there was enough butter in the grits to make it taste awesome. 

Otherwise, not somewhere I would come back for a second time.
author: J I.

description: This is my favorite place in the city for those times that I am missing home.  The shrimp and grits are incredible, the fried chicken is to die for and the bloody Mary's are out of this world good!  I've had everything on the menu and have not been disappointed yet.
author: Dirk N.

description:
The hubs and I happened to find a table for dinner on a quiet weekend during the holidays in December. We loved the ambiance and the laid back feel of this place. What we ate -
Apps:
shrimp etoufee special - 5*, fried okra - 3*
Mains:
short ribs - 4*, beets side - 4*
Dessert:
beignets - 4*, pecan pie to go - 5* 
Their cocktails were pretty good as well. We totally loved their hot sauce, so I ended up buying a bottle. Next time, I would love to sit outside in their cute patio on a warm night.
author: Raquel D.

description: Incredible neighborhood gem. Cozy and delicious. Amazing food and staff. They were out of Pecan pie the day we visited which was a bummer, but the shrimp and grits was top notch. Fried chicken was very nice. The sausage is on another level. Strongly recommend!
author: Justin Y.

description: Bloody Mary Review - Calling upon the bloody mary gods, The Front Porch uses a magical method of culinary sorcery to turn regular bacon into a salty, sugary rim coating insanity called Bacon Crack. Combined with salami-infused vodka, creole spices, tomato water, a top secret house hot sauce,and house pickled veg, I can only assume the dark day-drinking forces themselves were tapped to create such a work of meaty perfection. Why go? Bacon crack. | Price: $10
author: Shelley B.

description: I loved it all!!!! Great service, everybody there is very nice! Atmosphere was awesome! I had the Blackened wild gulf flounder. I was not sure about it when I ordered since I had no clue on how it was going to be. Man! I wanted to lick that plate. Sooo good! We had a great time!
author: Paula V.

description: Fried chicken, collard greens, mac and cheese and biscuits. Can't go wrong.
author: Linus C.

description: Always Tip My To Go's they were pretty busy. Remember this Local I pretty much on a regular spend $85 on my orders here. My family loves this place. Take it from an SF Native, you wanna eat here. Fried chicken Dr Piper ribs Mac n cheese. It's worth it! Thank me later with a LIKE
author: Sasha M.

description:
Corina and I went for brunch on last Saturday as it is just around the corner from the family place we stay at when in San Francisco. I know this is a well known and popular place, but we had never been there before. It was pretty good, but had expected it to knock our socks off and it just didn't do that. 

Corina had the Baked Egg & Grits with wild mushrooms, spinach, goat cheese and bacon. It was OK, but she would have been happier with a side of ham and eggs. I had the Biscuits and Sausage Gravy with a side of sausage. The side sausage was spicy and while good didn't go with the rest of my breakfast well.

I got to tell ya it is pretty dark in this place. We had to use the lights on our phones to see the menu. We will leave it 4 stars and will go back.
author: Bruce S.

description: Friendly employees. Their fried chicken is the best! The Mac and cheese is piping hot and yummy. Great service and the desserts are delicious too. Looking forward to going back again soon. It's our go to place in SF we know we won't leave disappointed.
author: N. S.

description: Chicken was on point. Shrimp and grits killed it. The pork belly was pretty unreal, order it, you won't be disappointed. Drinks are solid.
author: A. K.

description: In a city full of an unnecessary amount of "high-end" restaurants, The Front Porch is a breath of laid back fresh air. There's nothing confusing about the menu and there's nothing pretentious about the place. You can expect to have a delicious relaxing meal, which for me, takes me back to dinner on my parents front porch in the Midwest. On my first trip, I enjoyed the fried chicken - it was tender, crispy, salty, and delicious. On my second trip, I wanted to get back to my burger roots so I tried the Porch Burger with Pt. Reyes Blue and Bacon + cajun fries. This meal hit the spot while being highlighted by their amazing house made hot sauce, buy a bottle! All in all, it's a great spot in a city lacking the laid back creative food explosion LA is currently experiencing - that I personally wish SF could mimic.
author: Ryan M.

description:
I love occasional rich and heavy southern comfort-style food, but I have to crave it to really enjoy it. Anything from fried chicken to mac and cheese to gumbo will do. The Front Porch carries that southern charm, with quaint rocking chairs for the front patio seating, chill booth seating inside, laid back yet friendly service, and an open kitchen if you're seated near the back of the darkly-lit restaurant.

Of course I had to try The Front Porch's fried chicken and waffle during this past weekend's brunch. The estimated prep and cook time for this dish is 25 minutes, but we received ours shortly after 15 minutes (the restaurant wasn't filled with diners though).

The fried chicken was delicious, with crispy, crunchy battered skin and moist, though borderline overcooked/ dry white breast meat. However, the cornmeal bacon infused waffle was divine - both the crispy edges and fluffy center were perfect. The medium-course cornmeal batter added a bit of crunch, and the bacon bits shined through with a hint of savoriness. Dousing the waffle in maple syrup and butter was optional.

We had New Orleans style powdered sugar beignets and fried okra as starters to nibble on prior to our chicken and waffles. The beignets were crispy on the outside and chewy on the inside, and sprinkled generously with powdered sugar that after taking a bite, you'll have a fluffy white mustache. The fried okra was decent, the batter crunchy and not too thick. On the side was jalapeño aioli, which was not spicy at all. But if you love a bit of spicy, give their homemade hot sauce a try. The spicy, vinegary sauce packs a punch, without a lingering burning sensation.

Probably the best fried chicken I've eaten is from The Screen Door in Portland, Oregon. Pair their fried chicken breast with The Front Porch's cornmeal bacon waffle and we've got the perfect combination I'd be willing to wait in a 30+ minute line to eat!
author: Priscilla W.

description: This place is cute yet fairly small. The food is pretty good and nicely portioned. The spicy shrimp and grits was tasteful, I enjoyed the deviled eggs with bacon bourbon jam. (The bacon was light cold and fluffy) the fried pickles was pretty interesting for it being my first time trying it they came out hot. I also tried the fried okra which were decent. I gave this establishment a 3 star rating based on the hostess who was rude to my mom and very unaccommodating while our waiter was very friendly and able to do everything our hostess was unwilling to do.
author: Kam G.

description: Excellent staff, good for families, and an interesting menu. The food didn't blow me away, but the variety of the menu was exciting and the overall experience was positive.
author: Haley M.

description: Happen to be in-town for brunch. I got the shrimp grits and my friends got the chicken and waffle. Both dishes were amazing. Warning the chicken waffle is HUGE! The chicken was tender with just the right amount of spice that can transfer over to the waffle a bit. The only thing i wish they had more is outdoor sitting. The indoor is a bit too dark for a brunch
author: Penny C.

description:
I came here on a Wednesday night with my family to celebrate my dad's birthday. We were all looking forward to some Southern food so we were excited to try this place!

They start you off with these tiny cornbread muffins which are actually pretty good. Too bad they're super small!

We ended up ordering to share:
- Fried chicken ($18.50): Hot and crunchy!! The chicken was moist and the fried outer coating was good. Collard greens and mashed potatoes with it were okay. Also came with a side of popcorn that was sort of drenched in the fried chicken oil..... not sure what the popcorn's purpose was
- Fried pickles ($7): I don't even like pickles but these were pretty good. Tabasco aioli was tasty! Portion size was a small bowl for $7
- Dr. Pepper braised short ribs ($25): Probably my favorite entree--the beef was really tender and it went well with the mashed potatoes!
- Spicy shrimp and grits ($24): Needed a bigger portion of grits... Wasn't spicy either. Shrimp was good though, and I liked the andouille sausage
- Baked mac and cheese ($7.50): Yummy!!! Came on a hot plate and was ooey, gooey, and cheeeezy

Overall the prices were a little higher than usual. I'd rather wait in line for Brenda's or Hard Knox because A) the food is cheaper, B) the food tastes better, and lastly C) the portions there are huge!! Portion sizes here were definitely small for their big price tags.
author: Tara A.

description:
From the lit candles on each table to the "Fucket Just Get A Bucket" glass water jar to the vintage curtains along the walls this cozy little restaurant definitely delivered the whole experience of a relaxing, casual but modern atmosphere with a great selection of quality food in large portions. 

The complimentary cornbread and butter were a perfect appetizer for the table as they came in small bite sized pieces and a tasty herb butter. We ordered a bucket of chicken which came with 10 hearty pieces of fried chicken and mashed potatoes with gravy. The chicken was perfectly seasoned as it was not oversalted at all as a lot of fried chicken can be. The meat was soft and juicy and the skin was dark and crispy. The mashed potatoes and gravy complemented the chicken well but nothing about it stood out. This a great place for millenials looking for a pre late night bar that serves quality food.
author: Kirsten E.

description:
Decent- not bad for brunch. The chicken and waffles literally takes at least 25 min (noted on the menu). Unfortunately my dining partner didn't enjoy the chicken and I was starving when my shrimp and grits came out and still slightly hungry after finishing off the plate. 

I don't recommend sitting at the bar as it takes forever to get the bartender's attention. We were in a hurry and it took forever to get the receipt and to go boxes. They take reservations for brunch which I would recommend if you plan on coming here.
author: Leily P.

description: The fried chicken and Mac & cheese is bomb!! I've already been twice and I plan on keep going :-)
author: Nick D.

description:
This place is a super SF, really cool hidden gem in the middle of the Mission District. 

I have a vegetarian diet, so I tried the Josey's Vegan and it was delicious! The black eyed peas, collard greens and other veggies in it were cooked to perfection. I would definitely have this dish again and I also want to try their other vegetarian options. My waiter, who was extremely helpful to my two friends and I said that the Mac & Cheese there is very popular and scrumptious, so I'll be going back to try that soon!

Overall this place deserves more than 5 stars, but since that's all I can give here it goes..hehe, thanks for the great service and food Front Porch!
author: Erin W.

description: Celebrated a friend's birthday here. Variety of food menu selections from the New Orleans, Cajun, creole style dishes, some with a little Cali twist. Food was overall great! Had the souved tritip with rootbeer baked beans and onion rings,fried okra, cornbread, fried chicken, cocktails were stiff! I'm not complaining tho. Service was great from our server Michelle. Very friendly environment. By also very loud place. We had to yell to have a conversation. It gets poppin for dinner on fridays. My pics are not as good because of low lighting. I recommend this place!
author: Mel G.

description:
Excited for my trip to Nola, we decided to try this place to give me a taste of that southern soul food flare.

We ordered the following:

Deviled eggs = with bacon and bourbon jam. Yum!

Crawfish hush puppies = came out dry, doughy, and chewy. I had better hush puppies elsewhere. 

Fried chicken = 4 pieces of fried chicken with mashed potatoes, gravy, and green collards. It was way too salty for my taste and I was not impressed with the fried chicken. KFC mashed potatoes with gravy taste way better than this. 

Flounder = the only dish that night that was decent. Fish was cooked perfectly.

While the food was mediocre, I did enjoy the casual ambiance and the chill staff. 

Tip: Make reservation or come early to secure a spot. It can get crowded.
author: Owie N.

description: Came here on Sunday night looking forward to come comfort food. The venue is cute. The inside is decorated in a throw back to your grandma's kitchen in the 70s. I had the shrimp and grits which were so flavorful and cooked to the perfect texture, really fantastic. My boyfriend had the fried chicken which was quite frankly overdone, and not salty enough. I loved my dish, however, was disappointed by the chicken. The waitstaff was friendly and brought everything out pretty quickly. The price was reasonable. I liked it but perhaps this is a place that has been around long enough they are stopping to pay attention to their clientele. Maybe worth checking out once if you are in the neighborhood. Probably not worth going back to visit.
author: Anne S.

description:
Came here with a group of 10 people and we tried a bunch of different things. The lighting is pretty dim but the decor is cute and super homey. I liked the free corn bread and butter! The butter was some sort of herb flavoured and it was so good.

Most of the dishes we had were very so-so. In particular, the braised short ribs were very dry and not good to eat. The hush puppies were okay, and so was the flounder and the shrimp and grits. Honestly I felt like nothing stood out to me as very good to eat, but nothing was terrible either. Their fried chicken was cute because it came in a bucket and also had popcorn in it, but the actual fried chicken wasn't anything to write home about. 

Overall, I like the vibe and ambiance of this place, but the food wasn't amazing especially considering the prices.
author: Theresa L.

description:
Just a splendid evening. Had just returned from New Orleans and needed a fix. And my lovely partner had never had creole cuisine so over to the Porch. Still think it's as close to being a block off Bourbon as u can get in SF. 
Four piece fried chicken, spicy shrimp and grits and side of telephone pole size asparagus. Everything fantastic. But coolest thing was, FP owner Kevin comes over to say hi and I invite him to enlighten us. He pulls up a chair and tells us a bit of the history of Cajun creole culture and food. My date was delighted and learning a bit more about the sublime chow made a great evening truly memorable. Oh, strawberry shortcake and pecan pie were excellent and old fashioned seriously strong....Bueno. 
Christine did a great job taking care of us. This place has been consistently on the boil for a decade. Nice job, Kevin and staff.
author: Timothy S.

description: Even though we had to wait for our drinks for quite a bit the overall food experience was awesome! Hush puppies were perfectly fried. Pate was very tasty. Though the star of our dinner was the shrimp and grits. It is true comfort food. Especially after a cold San Francisco day it warms you right up! I've never had shrimp that were so juicy. Absolutely amazing. Thank you Front Porch!  We'll definitely be back :)
author: Anna C.

description: Cozy retro atmosphere. Loved the dark lighting and decor, felt like modern mixed with the 80s. My food wasn't the best however everyone else I was with loved their food...slightly limited choices for vegetarians, but that's not their fault. I would go back. I enjoyed the vibe, very attentive service and food overall
author: Valerie T.

description: An impromptu dinner at this little gem. I've never been here nor have I heard about it but my friend heard positive things. We realized quickly there was a Mardi Gras celebration happening and walked in without reservations. The hostess was so accommodating and sat us down with 15 minutes. The ambience was lively and just loud enough to feel the energy amongst the patrons but still able to communicate without shouting. The drinks were delicious and strong enough to leave me feeling pretty tipsy off the first one! The food was rustic, tasty and really fulfilling. I had the lobster bisque with the homemade biscuits...Yum! Service was a little slow but I guess that's to be expected for the occasion. Perfecting fitting restaurant for this Fat Tuesday. Highly recommend this place.
author: Kimberly M.

description:
The food is worth 5 stars which is why it had been on our date night rotation, until our last visit.  My husband and I each had 2 drinks, an appetizer, main course and dessert, with a bill of $200 with tip. So we are not cheapskates.

When ordering our main course I asked the server if I could not have the potatoes that came with my dish but rather the mashed potatoes that came with another main dish. He said yes, but with a $3 "Convenience charge."   Whaaaaa?  We eat out at least once a week in SF and NEVER have we come across a policy like this.  "no substitutions" on a prix fixe, ok that is one thing. But a $3 upcharge for switching out a potato for another potato? It feels really icky.  We felt bad for the server as he kept saying "it is the kitchen's policy, i'm so sorry."  

Well, Front Porch. We're sorry too. We like your food. But we also eat out for the experience. And we're going to take our average $100/pp date nights somewhere else where we don't feel like we are being nickled and dimed. I hope the management reads this and reconsiders this ridiculous policy.
author: Lester L.

description:
Wow. Still can't believe it's been the first time I've been to this place. Kind of surprising considering how often I hang out in the Mission neighborhood. 

Came here for a lazy Sunday brunch 30 min before closing time. Managed to find a seat outside. The servers were really warm and explained to us about the Porch Classics of Shrimp& Grits and Chicken Waffles. So we decided to get them. Although it took a while ( we were warned ), it was absolutely delicious and cooked to perfection. Having never been to New Orleans, I imagine this is the kind of quality Cajun food that should be served everywhere. 

Special mention to the interesting cocktail menu. I got the California Cactus which was a Jalapeño chili vodka drink. This was pretty strong and got me quite buzzed .

This place is a definite recommend from my end and is true to its motto : "Souther food with Mission hospitality "
author: Pranav B.

description: Best fried chicken I've ever had. I tried the Alligator and I was pleasantly surprised by how good it tasted.  The texture and flavor was unique which made for a more interesting experience. The service was excellent.  If your in the mood for great southern food and want a new experience or can't get enough fabulous fried chicken head over to the Mission and stop in at the Front Porch.
author: Richard C.

description: The never-ending hunt for the paragon of brunch in San Francisco brought us to the Front Porch one sunny afternoon. I never really get out this far into the mission, so this was my first time trying this spot for brunch. I had the Shrimp and grits - which was out of this world - the shrimp weren't exactly "shrimp-sized" and and the sauce was perfectly spicy, and with a strong paprika flavor if you like that. We also ordered fried okra and bread pudding for the table to share. The fried okra was to be honest disappointing - now don't get me wrong I LOVE okra in all forms (that's the south asian in me) but here it was a bit too dry and the batter it was fried in was pretty bland. The bread pudding I think was legit a dessert and I'm not really sure why we went for it as an app (but that's the "fun" of hangovers I suppose). Too sweet for my taste, though I do remember really loving it in the moment, but I don't think I would order again. Basically the food is pretty fucking great, but it was SO damn dark inside that you could barely see what you were eating - okay I know I sound dramatic, but it's that dark inside. To top it off there are fake window frames on the walls which makes it kinda depressing with the ye olde time jail vibes. Am I still gonna go back for the food though? Oh yeah for sureeeee.
author: Farrah N.

description: Love the ambience here. It's great for date night or dinner with a friend. I recommend the fried chicken, if it's your first time. The breading on the chicken pairs well with their house hot sauce. I also ordered the Dr. Pepper short ribs; the meat was tender, but not as sweet as I hoped. The super nice employees checked on us every 5 minutes. Restaurants like this sets apart SF restaurants from the others.
author: Rochelle B.

description:
We went to the restaurant yesterday. Had heard it was pretty good. Overall, the food was generally okay, so not writing about that.

However, the hostess needs training. We arrived prior to them opening. There were 2 parties ahead of us who had checked in, our party (we checked in), and 1 after us who did not check in. We all waited outside. Then, another party arrived and went to the door. The hostess was seated at the bar - did not stand up to greet them. After greetings were exchanged, she immediately sat their party, leaving the rest of us standing outside to fend for ourselves.

Then, that party, the 2 ahead of us and the 1 behind us were seated in the front part of the restaurant. However, we were seated at the back near the kitchen - the only ones back there with plenty of tables near the front. Since we were the only African-American party, something just didn't feel right. Therefore, I asked if we could move. Our waiter was very accommodating.
