Later, a party of 5 people came in. At that point, the restaurant was pretty full. The hostess squeezed them into the table we vacated rather than asking them to wait. You could tell it was very uncomfortable, especially since it was a table for 4. What took the cake was her comment, "I'm sorry about this but someone asked to be moved (condescendingly) and this is all we have." She wasn't tactful in the volume or inflection of her comment. Therefore, I assumed she was referring to us since we were the ones who asked to be moved.

As I said initially, the food was generally ok. Would try it again for comparison purposes, but please train your hostess to be more professional.
author: Beverly B.

description:
Being a Southern girl, I'll always always have a sweet spot for boiled peanuts and fried chicken. This place really hit the spot for me.

We ordered a bucket of chicken (gluten free style), mashed potatoes, fried okra, and boiled peanuts. Cornbread with chives butter comes with the table. Rootbeer float for dessert.

Everything was delicious. Even though we got gluten free fried chicken, we didn't miss the gluten at all. Heck, we probably wouldn't even have guessed it was gluten free.

The chicken is incredibly juicy -- cooked just right. The skin is crunchy, crispy, and packed full of flavorful spices. Though flavorful, it is on the blander side, perhaps because they intended us to use the hot sauces provided. Two sauces are available, one spicier than the other. 

It's a great place to let loose and eat as if you were in a diner in the south in the 70s. Something about the food and atmosphere here (it's probably the root beer float) that just felt very nostalgic to me.

I will definitely be coming back if I'm craving more chicken.
author: Chia L.

description: Visited the Front Porch today for the first time. My food was ok but my friend didn't like his at all. He didn't touch it at all after the first bite. We had assumed his would be taken off the bill but it wasn't. Definitely ruined our Sunday brunch experience. Nothing worse than leaving brunch hungry and paying for something you didn't consume.
author: Daman K.

description:
I first drove right past this place as the storefront isn't very big or flamboyant as other eateries. 

Getting here at 5:30pm, there was a small crowd of people right outside the place. We didn't have reservations, but we went in right as it opened and got seated right away. It's a pretty cozy restaurant and by cozy I mean the spacing is tight. So if you're sitting in the booth seat you have to wiggle and suck in your way into that back seat while trying to to knock over the next table's candle (I'm a petite Asian and it was hard for me!). 

Now onto the food. My friend and I decided to split the 4 piece fried chicken and the shrimp and grits. Let's start with the Shrimp and Grits since it was the first dish since the fried chicken takes 20 minutes to prepare. The shrimp was plump, well seasoned, and perfectly cooked. The only thing I would change is that I wish we got more than FIVE shrimp, that's right FIVE shrimp! The sausage was nothing special, but the grits and gravy was magical. The hints of shallots added greater depth in flavor. It was so flavorful that I wanted to lick the bowl. It wasn't very spicy, but when I added the mild hot sauce it was so good. I mean SOOOO GOOD!

The fried chicken came about 15 minutes later. The mashed potatoes and collard greens isn't anything special. The fried chicken was crispy, well seasoned, and most importantly not dry or too oily. When cutting into the chicken the inside meat was surprisingly moist and tender. IT wasn't as finger licking good as the Shrimp and Grits, but satisfiying.

Overall, good experience and I would definitely come back for the shrimp and grits. Which was bomb dot com :)
author: Melissa N.

description:
I came here for my birthday for lunch on a Saturday because I absolutely love Creole/Cajun food and wanted to fill my craving for fried chicken and waffles and beignets. 

I made a reservation the night before so getting a table was easy. Parking is on the street so we had to walk a little bit but it was totally doable.

The restaurant lights were dim and everything had an certain charm to it which I loved. The fried chicken was crispy and juicy. The waffle was fluffy. It was just the right amount. You get 3 pieces of chicken and a giant waffle. Perfect combination. The beignets so soft and were just right. 

Definitely met expectations!
author: Kelly N.

description:
This used to be really good. Stuck to classic Cajun food. Haven't been back for a while and decided to come back because my step dad was in town wanting some Cajun food. He's from New Orleans and has some high standards. Boy has it been a big disappointment. It's like they hipstered it up and tried to get creative. Too creative where it's just too much. Also ettouffee is always served with crawfish. I get they have a vegan option but the shellfish add on was shrimp.......shrimp. Not crawfish although they do HAVE crawfish in their hush puppies but not in their ettouffee. Maybe I missed this las time as I had the chicken. Also ordered collard greens with ham hocks. There were no ham hocks in the greens. They were also vinegary. Something way too acidic was made with these greens. What in the flying world. Bill came out to be $170 and it was not good. If you like it you're a hipster. Just admit you're a hipster.

The next day when looking at the leftovers we took home because being Asian I wasn't going to let $170 worth of food just go to the trash...
OH MY JESUS. We didn't even touch the sides at the restaurant and we had the guy pack them up. These are large portions for sides mind you. Why the f--k are the take home portions of sides half of what was served on the table?! Where the hell are my sides? I know you ain't serving them to other people. Right?! Did you just jip me on my TAKE HOME LEFTOVERS?! 

Recollecting on our experience this morning with my boyfriend and we also recall the people behind us complaining. Like did we hear they put pickles in their martini's? C'mon bro. WHAT ARE THOSE?!
author: Noelle C.

description: So...walked in and found my reservations and was seated immediately even though I was almost 30 minutes early.  It wasn't because they weren't busy.  It was a full house from the time we sat until the time we left...and for good reason.   Crawfish Hush Puppies!  Boudin Balls!  OMG....Da Bomb!  Had to pass on the fried chicken but the Dr Pepper Braised  Short Rib was amazingly tender and the Pork Chop were to die for.  Top that off with super friendly folks made me feel like it was the happiest place on earth to work and eat and I was fat and happy at the finish.  The food was hot when served and the drinks were tasty.  Next time I'll have the Okra
author: chucky B.

description: I would call myself a fried chicken connoisseur, and I came to front porch with high expectation, and was slightly let down. They are known for their fried chicken, which led to my high expectations. But honestly, the chicken doesn't stand up to Popeyes down the street. With that being said, the rest of the meal was solid. The biscuits were awesome and they also have a great variety of drinks. Besides falling short on the fried chicken, I have nothing but positive things to say about Front Porch
author: Ross S.

description: Simply put.  Amazing Food, Excellent Staff and Awesome Drinks!!!  Will be back... next week!!!
author: KEN S.

description: This place is really good. Lived in sf for over 5 years and never had the chance to try it. Would def recommend it to friends and family . I'll def be back for few more things on the menu.
author: Andy P.

description:
The food was great, service was great, everything was great. This would be a 5 star review if it hadn't ended up being $150 not including drinks, for only 3 people. 

The Front Porch was really one of the better dining experiences I've had in San Francisco. We ordered a wide selection of food, which all represented a taste of New Orleans, or in general southern cuisine. With low ceilings and a richly decorated interior, and a cute illuminated outer seating area, The Front Porch is a hole-in-the-wall restaurant, or rather the bottom floor of a residential house that was converted into a restaurant. 

We started off with Hush Puppies and Fried Pickles, both of which were excellent appetizers. The puppies were delicious crab meat fried wonders and were pretty large in size. It came with 4, plus dipping sauce, for $11, which is probably a little expensive for what it was. The fried pickles were a better value at $7 and were actually worth every penny, being wonderfully cooked and breaded with way more pickle than other attempts I've had. The ratio was perfect!

We then moved on to the entree. Two orders of the shrimp and grits and an order of the 4 piece fried chicken. The shrimp and grits were far better than the version I had in New Orleans itself, with perfectly cooked seafood, a spicy but juicy sausage, and incredibly prepared grits full of flavor. Those were 24 dollar dishes, and while it was delectable, I don't think it is worth quite that much. Maybe 19 or 20 dollars, max. I ordered the fried chicken, and it was hands down the best fried chicken I have ever tasted. First off, the plating and the sides were beautiful, with a wilted kale salad ordeal (delicious!) and a big old pile of mashed potatoes with gravy in the middle, volcano style. Then there were also little pieces of popcorn on the plate which was a nice touch and an even better snack, as they were seasoned! But back to the chicken. As moist and juicy as can be imagined, with a very crisp but not disproportionate breading. I can't even get over how good it was. And at 18.50, it was well worth the price, considering the size of the chicken and the amount I left for home with.

After our entrees, we figured we would shoot par for the course and order dessert. The Sorbet of the Day was strawberry and it was definitely the best sorbet I've had, with little seeds in it, and flavor that could completely knock you back. Seriously, it would have been good to pair it with crackers or some other neutral flavor to tame the flavor a bit. So good, but at 6.50 for a bowl it probably wasn't worth half that. The second dessert was classic New Orleans beignets (pronounced benn-yays), a puffy pastry drenched in powdered sugar. Seemingly fresh out of the oven, these were incredible, and as good as the ones we got in Louisiana. Finally, the sundae was ordered, and it was perfect. Chocolate ice cream on top of a brownie, topped with whipped cream and chocolate syrup. Couldn't have been better, apart from the 8 dollar price. Yikes. 

Also, Kenny, our server, was awesome. He chatted with us and told us about the hot sauces that were on the table and was in general quite helpful. 

With all that in mind, it seems like a super great experience, and one that I would not hesitate to recommend. I can't wait to go back myself, so long as I can face the priciness of the place. Yes, it was good. However, I think I just feel bad when I pay that much for a single meal. I can't stress enough how good it was though! Highly recommend.
author: John B.

description:
Bf and I came here for dinner, waited about 15 min before we were seated. Initially, I wanted a booth inside but they only had a table outside available. Come to think of it, it was actually a lot nicer since it was very crowded, loud and stuffy inside. 

Corn bread was yummy and you get as much as you want. Ordered the Fried Okras, Grits and shared a 4 Piece Chicken meal, which came with mashed potatoes and collard greens. Plenty of food, we would've had leftovers if we got 2 entrees. Chicken itself was savory, evenly breaded and fried. Flavors were enhanced by their house-made hot sauces! The gravy was to die forrr!

Servers were all very nice and polite. Food was very good. Overall great experience! Parking is very limited tho, but we got lucky
author: Natasha S.

description:
Surprisingly (I think) 5 of us were able to get a table at 730 on a Friday night without a reservation. It was busy. I guess we got lucky. 

Inside was pretty dark, but cozy. They had some tables outside that looked like they would be nice to sit at. 

They bring mini corn muffins with herb butter to the table instead of bread. Those were tasty. 

One of our party was allergic to celery and our waitress was great about checking to make sure there was no celery

Our party got:
The ahi tuna Wellington special. It was good. Tasted kinda like beef Wellington. Sauce and filo dough were tasty. 

The fried chicken was excellent. Very crispy and the chicken was moist and flavorful but still cooked through. Might have been a little too salty for my liking. Still, 5 stars. 

The shrimp gumbo polenta was a little bland. This could have been because we got the sauce on the side (it had celery) but when I added the sauce back it just didn't quite have that richness I wanted. 

The beef short ribs looked good, but I didn't actually try them. 

Would like to try the jambalaya risotto. I saw it on another table and it looked good. 

On the spendier side- easily 40 per person with a drink - and they have lots of special cocktails and a selection of beer and wine.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I love this place.  We are repeat customers, though we moved out of the city recently.  Saturday we had a  re-visit.  Heirloom tomato salad, green goddes dressing, pickled onions, and house made Ricotta.  Hands down, this was the best salad I have ever had.  

We also had the deviled eggs with a bacon jam dollop, exquisite!

Well worth a trip to visit this gem, be sure to make reservations and sit outside if the weather permits!
author: Patrick H.

description:
So I have very mixed reviews about this spot.  

Let's break it down...dish by dish!  Haha.

Deviled eggs with bacon and bourbon jam:  3 stars.  The name of the item sounds so much better than it actually tastes.  I felt that it was a little too sweet for my liking but it was decent.  

Fried chicken, 4 pieces:  3 stars.  The chicken was crispy and tender...but the sides were meh.  The collard greens were way too large and chewy.  No seasoning whatsoever.  Mashed potatoes?  Definitely not a highlight.  Also served with popcorn which was soggy.  I'd order a bucket of chicken and leave the sides behind instead.

Burger with house made American:  5000 stars.  Wowza.  Now, that's what I call a burger!  The meat was cooked perfectly to my requested medium rare.  The cheese was absolutely ridonkulous and melted perfectly.  The fries were also the perfect balance between chewy and crispy.  Fantastic.

Our bourbon and ginger was stiff.  Perfect on a warm, sunny day.  

Our food took a very long to come out.  There was a huge gap between the appetizer and the main courses.  We're talking a sitting uncomfortably twiddling our thumbs kinda gap.  

Service was friendly though and we weren't ignored at the bar.  I'd come back for the burger alone.  3 stars.  

Our bill came out to around $60?
author: Jen W.

description: We had a po boy and spicy shrimp and grits both were really good, po boy is exactly what you would get in New Orleans. Ambiance is very casual it's basically a dark whole in the wall bar with really good food. I would go back again just for the po boy. The only reason 4 not 5 stars is it seems a little grunge not a place I would bring friends that could not over look the old run down look and feel.
author: Victoria K.

description: Very nice staff. I ordered and ate at the bar to avoid the line. The drinks were very well made. For lunch I ordered fried chicken on waffle and fried okra. Both were very good. Not too oily or salty and up to the mark.
author: Ash M.

description: We went here because we were celebrating a birthday weekend in San Fran and saw this place on Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives. The food looked amazing and I love Southern inspired food. So we made a reservation and went. The place was definitely a Dive. :) Didn't bother me, I wasn't expecting a five star entrance. The service was fabulous. Very attentive and precise. Great personalities. Drinks were fabulous. I wanted everything. So we ordered, shrimp and grits, deviled eggs, baked mac and cheese, fried chicken 4 piece meal, and the short ribs dinner. I have 3 stars because the eggs literally had no taste to it, the fried chicken was overdone and the  garlic mash seemed old, and the short ribs had the look as if they'd been sitting out all day. Very dry on the outside but it was amazingly tender. It just lacked the look of freshness and the taste I was after was missing. However, the baked Mac was pretty good and the shrimp and grits were amazing. I was bummed because I really was looking forward to eating and enjoying every fork of food I had based on the reviews and episode. Genuinely disappointed.
author: Deborah L.

description:
We heard about this place from an acquaintance, so we were very excite to get some yummy food here. What we found was a cute outside decor, lovely outdoor seating, and dark interior. The inside extended long-way towards the back of the building, and they only have windows at the front of the restaurant. 

The menu seemed like, but we were shocked by the high price tags. I don't really put the Southern food with high price together... The food was ok, the hush puppies were large and tasty, and the fried chicken was nice. The baked mac & cheese were melt-y and gooey. But none them were that special, it was good but not amazing. Maybe we had too high of an expectation...
author: June S.

description: A hidden gem... if you're a foodie and love to try new places, this should be on your list! You can either enjoy the outside patio or go inside. I'd definitely recommend the patio as you'll enjoy your meal while rocking away in your rocking chair... order the bucket of chicken (which is the best deal) and some delicious sides (FYI - they come in small portions) and quick fact, the bill quickly adds up but great little place to try nonetheless... "fu** it get the bucket* their slogan, lol...
author: Dee G.

description:
We loved it here!  Great ambiance! dimly lit and clean!
We had the fried okra appetizer and the vegan entree with collard greens, beans and grits cake was excellent! The chicory coffee was good as well.
The corn bread pudding was ok not that good. Altogether a very good place to check out  y'all! ;)
author: Raja K.

description: Amazing place for good southern cooked food- been here a few times for brunch and loved it each time. The coffee with chicory is a must try, as is the chicken and waffles. If you're a fan of okra, the fried okra is great too. Highly recommend
author: Camden P.

description: The chicken was very crispy but very tender inside, you can eat it with some great hot sauce. Delicious cocktails at the old fashion wooden bar are tasty.
author: Yosef R.

description:
Wasn't a fan.. I had just a regular breakfast, grits were suppose to be "cheesy", their not.. eggs over cooked.. I wanted to add onions and peppers to my eggs but was told they couldn't.. when I asked why, I was told the normally have some all cut up but was out of the precut ones & the cooks were to busy to chop up some........ like, seriously..... ok. It also came with a dry cold biscuit and bacon. I told my server I didn't eat meat and he suggested some kind of veggie mix instead but said it would a extra $6.50 for the substitution.. I then ask to sub it for fruit then.. also extra but I went ahead and did it.
Overall, it just wasn't a good experience for me. We had to wait 30mins an was told we'd be sat at the bar but instead was put outside in the cold, without even being asked was it ok. My friend also didn't care for her food neither. It was honestly not worth the wait, money, or us freezing. Maybe it's popular for the chicken and waffles, i'll never know though.
author: Qushandia H.

description: This place is too small but the food is so good we can easily overlook this bit of a challenge.  My favorite is the macaroni and cheese, my husband (he is from the south) loves the gumbo.  My girls love the fried chicken.  The people are very nice and make you feel right at home.  I would recommend making a reservation because walking in can make you wait a very long time.  If you like southern food you need to come here and try the food, it will remind you of the south.
author: Kyra S.

description: Came in here on a Friday night. It was our first time so we didn't make a reservation. The host recommended that we do so next and for any given day.  It seems like they place you on the patio for non-reservation (don't worry it's heated) and there's about 4 tables outside with rocking chairs! . Luckily we came early and only had to wait 20min, because they got really busy later on. There's also a bar across the street if you want to grab a drink while you wait. It's nice that they text you when your table is ready. We opt to wait right outside and the smell of food was so gooood. We ordered spicy shrimp and grits and fried chicken. Grits was super flavorful and creamy. Chicken was tender and juicy. The waiter recommended midnight sun cocktail. The drink was really pretty, but unfortunately it did not taste as good as it looked. Service was good and everyone was friendly.
author: Victoria T.

description: I have to get this place five stars. The atmosphere was downright homie, and you felt like you were stepping into your Mom's Kitchen. You could sit outside on the front porch if you liked but we chose not to since it's Ted chili tonight in San Francisco. We both ordered different foods my brother and I. I ordered the fried chicken and bacon filled waffle, which was a amazing! The Fried Chicken had a tad spice on it but nothing too harsh and was delicious. My brother had, the bourbon brined pork chop (I think that's what it was called). The pork chop probably was 3" thick, sitting on a bed of mashed potatoes and onions it was amazing. He had a glass of wine which enjoyed and I stuck with my iced tea. The staff was really considerate and worked really hard to make sure we had everything we needed. The door seem to open and close so much that it was cooling down the place they offered a blanket, lol. It might look like a hole in the wall, but it's well worth the five stars.
author: The R.

description: It's a great place for fried chicken and the side dishes.  Some unusual items on the menu like fried pickles.   It's a very cozy restaurant.  There is some outside seating,  nice bar, and relaxing atmosphere.  It is a popular place so reservations are recommended at dinner time on weekends.
author: Marco J.

description: Omg me and my guy saw this place on diners and dives months ago and finally made it here. We had Chicken and fries also blue cheese burger and fries soooooooo good the Owner was VERY nice and helpful.We suggested to him to put pictures on the menu.So many good choices went for lunch WiLL return for Dinner
author: Rose U.

description:
Came here to celebrate a friend's birthday and we were not disappointed. We started with the Fried Green Tomatoes with Crab and the fried okras, which were both delicious. Dinner did not disappoint. Our table ordered the fried chicken, shrimp and grits, short ribs and the creamed corn. The shrimp and grit and fried chicken received better reviews than the short ribs.

The staff was super friendly and went above an beyond to make sure our friend had a great time. Will definitely return.
author: Jette A.

description: Lets just start off by saying... I WILL NEVER forget how delicious this place was. Best southern food hands down. The restaurants vibe was super cool as well. I came here with a group of people and we all got different dishes. Definitely cannot wait to come back
author: Navita S.

description: I thought the fried chicken was good but small portions and fried csra was good but again small portions and it's to overpriced for what you get, for 3 pieces of chicken and a side of ochre it was $25.00' and a long wait for takeout, the place was dark and hard to see what you are eating, will not go there again!!
author: Frank V.

description: Wait was not a problem when reserving on open table, efficient and everything has a vegetarian option
author: Renee L.

description: Good place for Southern comfort cuisine. I went here for dinner & enjoyed my meal. Decent cocktails-try the Porch Swing (strong & tasty). Super tiny cornbread. Will try to catch HH next time.
author: Thatcher C.

description: I'm from the south, so here's my food purchase. Fried okra and green tomatoes are delicious with a San Francisco kick. The chicken was delicious with the same kick. Collard greens, almost as good as mine. All in all very good.
author: Susan j.

description: I've always had a good experience coming here. The food is always good and the service is never bad. I do wish they would switch up the menu a little bit.
author: Susan T.

description:
This time, the fried chicken, served bucket style was disappointing. The exterior tasted slightly burnt and lacked proper seasoning but still retained a moist interior 

Mac and Cheese was even better this time around! 
Pork chop was delicious, great portion and super moist 
Braised Beef Short Ribs - super tender, very straightforward representation 

I thoroughly enjoyed the Bay Area Garden Party drink, a well balanced gin drink 

Overall Thoughts

Chicken can be hit or miss so I hope you have it on a good day
author: Eddie W.

description:
I can't be happier when yelp comes through. It wasn't even me yelping this time around. It was my not so yelper of a significant other. He converted for me! Anyway we were looking to cheat hard on our diets when the front porch appeared on our radar. It was serendipitous, I am convinced. We meant to go for ice cream rather than food but saw The Front Porch wondered what it was. Only the smallest restaurant with the biggest personality. 
We got sat right away and ordered right away as well. We got fried pickles, fried chicken, the burger, braised beef and a salad but holly cow was that food great. I can easily say it was probably in the top 5 for me. 
The service is phenomenal, the place is cool, and the food is great. What's not to love?
author: Kristina G.

description: This place is always packed especially on weekends so I would highly recommend to make a reservation. Outdoor sitting arrangement is as nice as the indoor ones. It's a very cool San Francisco styled place. darker inside. I ordered their Fried Okra, it was literally the best weird sounding dish i have ever ordered and taste amazing. it comes with a sauce and totally goes with it. So definitely give it a try. Then I ordered their Bucket o' chicken. Apparently this place is famous for it. The portion is huge. 10 pieces of Mary's chicken in a bucket that 4 people can easily share. if you're single i would recommend to get chicken and waffle. Nice people, nice staff and tons of parking space.
author: Kashif F.

description:
I can't start this review without mentioning how absolutely perfect the service was! The host and hostess were friendly, polite and accommodating. Since this was my first visit to San Francisco, I didn't have a good handle on parking and was -- yikes --15 minutes late for my reservation, which I hear are hard to come by because of the popularity of this spot. Nevertheless, the host welcomed me and gave me the option of a seat at the bar or outdoor seating under the heat lamp. After starting at the bar, I ultimately ended outdoors and oh..what a great experience!

The timing between courses was on point. To begin, they started with complimentary little corn muffins, which were just ok, but taken to the next level with some amazing Rosemary butter.

I also started with one of the yummiest, most beautiful salads ever -- a fall arugula mix with Fuji apples, pomegranates, pecans and delicious persimmons, which added a great tasty element. It was topped with a nice light balsamic vinaigrette. Very good salad and definitely shareable.

And as a show of their extreme southern hospitality to a visiting southern girl, the chef let me sample one of the best versions of fried okra I've ever tried. Instead of the little slices I'm used to, these were larger pieces and salted perfectly. The jalapeño dipping aioli was a perfect accompaniment.

I'm also a sucker for trying out fried chicken and Front Porch didn't disappoint. It was fried very well and reminded me of the cast iron fried chicken my grandmother used to fry. I would give it an 8.5 out of 10 because I tend to prefer a wet battered chicken recipe with just a tad more salt, but it was still very very good. The house made hot sauce completed it. They served four huge seasoned pieces with collard greens, popcorn ( this was different) and although it usually comes with garlic mashed potatoes, I subbed for the "new" moms twice baked potatoes with crispy potato skins. Definitely worth the $2 upgrade! 

I had the pleasure of visiting with two locals as they finished their drinks outside. They were lovely and shared they they visit often, mostly for the fried chicken.

I was very pleased with my visit and look forward to coming back during my next visit to the Bay Area next year!
author: Danielle M.

description:
It's been a few years since we have been here.  Really because we live too far away for this place to be a regular spot for us.  We got the favorites tonight
- started with Ceasar salad light on the dressing.  Loved it. They serve the lettuce with long pieces which was great.   Lots of  fresh Parmesan cheese 
- we shared spicy shrimp and grits.  The spiciness comes from the sausage slices.  It was only slight perfect for us.  This was a solid dish but not my favorite as the grit sauce was a little on the salty side.  
- 4 piece chicken with mash and collard.  I wished we could order all dark meat.  It was delicious.  The corn meal coating is the secret with a slight spicy kick that made this dish simply awesome. 

We sat at the bar as we didn't have reservation. All in all a very nice early dinner.
author: Lei H.

description:
Tried this Cajun restaurant the first day we got in and loved how cozy and relaxing the ambience was and definitely very hipster, with interesting art and decor.

Everything we ordered was delicious. This includes the hush puppies, fried chicken, baked mac and cheese, deviled eggs and more. 

The cocktails are also very delicious and festive. I got the eggnog cocktail while I was there and it was a good choice.

Consider coming with a larger group so you can taste more on the food menu!
author: Lesley Y.

description: After seeing all of the great reviews on yelp and by a coworker's recommendation, I really wanted to love this place. But it did nmot live up to the hype. The fried chicken batter was a little over cooked and dark (as in burnt). While I could taste the seasoning on the batter (and boy, does it smell delicious!), the actual chicken was bland...very bland. It tastes as if they boil the chicken first, then season it, finishing it off with a final fry. The meat itself is not flavorful at all. For the price, my husband and I were very disappointed. The greens, mac-n-cheese and fried pickles were good. Service was good, and atmosphere is nice. Just not worth the hype, nor price, for the actual fried chicken.
author: Mimi L.

description:
Like Front Porch says, "Fucket, get a bucket"...

And that's what we do...we order a bucket of their famous fried chicken ($29).  It comes as a 10 pieces assortment served in a popcorn bucket and sprinkled with popcorn.  We usually add $4 more to have all dark meat.  The fried chicken is crispy and not greasy.  Be sure to make use of their homemade hot sauces (which they also sell for $8).

Don't forget your sides or appetizers.  I feel their appetizers and sides are a bit inconsistent.  Sometimes they're amazing, sometimes they fall short.  The bf loves the crawfish hushpuppies ($9, 4 pieces) here.  Once the crawfish was a nice creamy filling inside the cornmeal ball which I loved, another time it was mixed in which made it dry.  The mac and cheese is a hit or miss as well.  I've had where it was creamy, cheesy and cooked perfectly and then another time the dish was overcooked.  It's also a small portion for $8.  The mashed potatoes and gravy ($6.50) is good.  The mashed potatoes are pretty thick.  You might want to ask for extra gravy because they sometimes skimp on it.  If you're a fan of pickles, my bf loved the fried pickles. 

Service is friendly.  My only complaint is timing with food.  The last time we went, it took about 30-35 minutes for our food to start coming.  

WHAT TO KNOW:
*They're busy, so make a reservation.  We waited 30 minutes at 8pm on a Wednesday for our party of 2.  
*Complimentary corn muffins to start your meal.
*3% SF health fee is added to your bill.
*Street parking which can be difficult to find.
*Brunch is served on the weekends.
author: Nicole S.

description: Beignets and fried chicken  I'll definitely be back for the shrimp and grits and drinks!
author: Andrea T.

description: Love eating here, the food is always fantastic.  The staff are always friendly and helpful. There is outdoor seating if you want to dine with your four legged companion. The wait is long so I suggest making a reservation, they are usually packed and there is a line so plan ahead. I am a big fan of their eggs Benedict, mac and cheese, jambalaya, and grits. The area is shaded so you don't have to worry about baking in the sun during your wait and there are rocking chairs and a bench for those who wait.
author: Jinnie L.

description: We ordered almost every appetizer on the menu and shared. The Red Beans with sausage was delicious. Okra and a side of grits (with bacon crack ) was wonderful. The Mac and Cheese was even better the next day when we had leftovers. The beignets were the least favorite but still good. Highly recommend this place.
author: Marvena M.

description:
This is definitely the place to be if you're looking for some southern charm. My friends and I came here for brunch. Everyone ordered the chicken & waffles except for me (Mac & cheese for this gal!).  Drinks were delicious, atmosphere was quaint (though a bit too noisy for my preference), and service was quite attentive. 

Highly recommended!
author: Saline J.

description:
I came across Front Porch through yelp. It was easy to make a reservation through Yelp for a party of 3 for a Saturday lunch. 

Street parking is easy and the staff is very friendly. 

I personally felt like the restaurant has a bit of a European feel to it. They have outdoor tables, but space is limited. Inside is really dark and gloomy. That's the only thing I didn't like. 

The menu is pretty big. They have chicory coffee which I wanted to try but didn't get to. 

They do have a good drinks menu as well. A small list of cocktails with champagne. 

Here's what we tried:

1. Mimosa - pretty standard
2. I can't remember the name of this cocktail with champagne and passion fruit but it has a long name with the word "Adult". It was good. Very tangy. 
3. Blueberry Cornbread - we had this as a starter and it is a bit sweet and a hint of salt too. Interesting item. Must try!
4. Chicken and Waffle - 4 pieces of chicken. Must try!
5. Josey's Vegan - this was a delicious entree. Very flavorful and filling. Must try! 

All together, our total was $68 with tax and tip for the above items. 

Highly recommend trying it!
author: Hiral P.

description:
Dr pepper braised pork is not as sweet as you think nor is it as bland as some forms of grilled  pork. It comes with veggies and mash potatoes which actually makes it a simple but filling dish.

The beignets , sweet tea are items i hope never come off the menu...but the hush puppies sometimes are over done and taste like deep fried hockey pucks.. but other days they are as good as it can get.

My only gripe with this place is that its in a area where parking is dam near impossible..makes me consider taking lyft line here more than anything else...

The place can get cramped so travel light when coming here.
author: Eric C.

description:
After a long day my family of 4 and I were too tired to cook and didn't want to go out. We found The Front Porch through Yelp and were so glad to see they delivered (through Eater 38)! 

We ordered the bucket of chicken, 2 sides of mashed potatoes, and 1 side of macaroni and cheese. We were all so impressed with the taste and quality! Every piece of chicken was juicy and the coating they use has the right amount of spices...very flavorful. The sides were delicious as well! Did not disappoint.
author: Megan P.

description: The food is great and the service is incredible. I lived very close to this brewery and would go here often. The happy hour menu was a great deal and the house made beers were always delicious. Love this place and always recommend it!!
author: Hayley C.

description: The food is sooooo good here. I only come here on special occasions, as it is located SF, so expect SF prices. I love the ambiance, food, and the cocktails are spectacular.
author: MG H.

description:
Great food and decor, the long wait is well worth it. 

I went for the shrimp and grits which hit a variety of flavorful notes from the perfectly cooked shrimp to the well-seasoned coarse grits. I would certainly come back to try other menu items.
author: Ryan S.

description: A great friendly place. Amazing food. Wonderful customer service. I would definitely recommend this place for a Sunday brunch. PS brunch stops at 2:30 on Sundays.
author: Erica Y.

description: Walking into front porch was like walking into the swamps of Savannah. The red checkered floors were like a disco dream I won't forget. Every drink option was tempting but I went with a classic beer. From the macaroni to the chicken fried steak, this place does not disappoint. The gravy was spread in the best way keeping every bite the perfect amount of crispy. I will be back, and I will eat more.
author: Storm S.

description:
Great service, super friendly and patient servers.

 The fried chicken is everything! The shortribs were OK- I'd definitely come back only for the fried chicken. =)  Dessert (lemon cake) was meh should've gotten the beignets- oh well, next time for sure.
author: I LOVE ME SOME G.

description:
Ok, look, the place is a cute little spot to have dinner but the food was ariteeeeee.

Chicken and Waffles (3 stars): Boring, so boring. I was completely underwhelmed. The description on the menu made it sound like the chicken would be bursting with flavor....it wasn't.

Baked Mac N Cheese (4 stars): BOMB. It was so rich and creamy!

I WOULD come back again and just replace the chicken and waffle with another menu item.
author: Zohra A.

description: Head shrimp and grits the macaroni and cheese and homemade biscuits in the gumbo and don't forget the chicken breast everything was on point in the vibe there is like a movie its lit!
author: Terrance M.

description:
The Front Porch is a divey/homey Southern place in the way southern parts of the Mission. I met a friend here for a dinner on Monday night. Seating was busier than I expected for a Monday night (we had reservations).

The food and drinks were delicious. We each enjoyed our cocktails, and hungrily split appetizers of fried pickles and the blue crab hush puppies. The fried chicken was great - juicy, crisp skin, not (that) greasy. We also somehow magically had room for beignets. There was an obscene amount of powdered sugar thrown into the beignet bag, it was hard not to leave a mess on the table.

Service was prompt and friendly. The atmosphere of the place is pretty warm and comfortable. The prices are fair, not cheap.

I'd recommend going if you were in the area and looking for comfort food.
author: Bill H.

description:
Brunch review 

French toast sticks - 4/5
Beignets - 3/5
Stoner stack - 3/5
Chicken and waffles - 4/5

Overall, "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description:
The service was excellent. We ordered the fried okra,chicken and waffles,baked mac n cheese and the shrimp po boy. 

The fried okra was good, as was the mac n cheese. The chicken was juicy but a little bland the waffle was ok as well. The Po boy was a little dry but alright as well. The waiter was very attentive and really nice. It's a nice small spot but I probrably won't go back.
author: Teresa B.

description: Came with a large group for a graduation dinner. It's cozy and dark inside. The food was amazing. The only dishes we weren't that impressed with were the fried chicken and the gumbo. Service was awesome and parking in the area wasn't too bad. Now I really want to come back to try their brunch.
author: Susan G.

description:
Decided to come here for dinner because of the rave reviews on Yelp but honestly I was kind of disappointed. I thought the food was decent/good, but it wasn't mind blowing like all these reviews on Yelp. 

Ambiance: I thought the outside was pretty cute and unique. I want to say the restaurant is like literally in a basement of a house/apartment. The lighting on the inside was a little dark so it was kind of hard to read the menu but i didn't mind. 

Service: I thought my server was nice. Not super attentive but enough for me. 

Food: 
Hush puppies: 4 small pieces for $8. Nothing special. 
Mac n cheese: I would have to say the mac n cheese was pretty good. Just the right amount of cheese to pasta ratio. 
Creamed corn: it was okay but again nothing special.
Fried chicken: don't know if it was an off day tonight but I was pretty disappointed! There was too much batter and it was pretty salty. I'm a fried chicken connoisseur and I was really looking forward to this dish. Sadly it fell way below my expectations. 
Shrimp and Grits: I thought this was a nice dish. The shrimp had a lot of taste. The grits were okay. The andouille sausage adds in a nice flavor though. 
Beignets: fried dough with sugar! What can go wrong?
Bourbon pecan pie: portion was so small for $8. It was good but I would pass if I were to go eat there again. I do have to say the 'whupped' cream was pretty darn tasty. 

Overall considering the price and taste of the food, I probably would not go back in the near future.
author: Vickiiieee V.

description:
Made reservations for this place for Sunday Brunch. The outside of this place really looked like a front porch. When we walked in, it was pretty dark. The inside was quite small, maybe like 15 tables and a bar area. 

We definitely had to try the chicken and waffles! We also ordered the macaroni and cheese (and we added bacon). And had the beignets as a dessert. 

The macaroni came out first on a hot skillet. I thought it was really good, partly because we added bacon to it. It did seem quite oily. 

Then the chicken and waffles came out. I really liked that the chicken was still juicy and not dry like most other places. The waffles had little pieces of bacon bits in it as well. Everything paired very well together.

We requested that the beignets come out at the end, just in case we wanted to take them to go. But we ended up eating it there since they wouldn't taste as good when they get cold. Beignets tasted dry to me. 

Would probably come back if I'm ever in the area.
author: Michelle S.

description: Good gator. Spicy. Not cheap. "Cozy". Dark. Fried stuff. Decent cocktail (Porch Swing) came promptly but service is a bit weird as the folks had to reach all across us to take care of the teeny table. The fried chicken was, well, fried chicken, but the gator was a little more interesting. I dunno how so many stars for the number of reviews but it's prob ok for the crowd, just average for me. No offense. Wish I tried the fish
author: Kevin F.

description: Come here for comfort food! They have the best fried chicken. We came in on a Wednesday night and didn't need reservations for 5. Portions are large and enough to share. The chicken liver pate is rich, but good.  Hush puppies and deviled eggs are good, but nothing to write home about.
author: Ha D.

description: Came here with some friends who live in the neighborhood and after living the better part of the last year in New Orleans, was curious to see how Cajun/Creole/Southern fare in SF tasted.  Overall, very solid - the beignets were quite good as was the breakfast sandwich.   As can be expected with most Southern meals, it was heavy and greasy, but that's not necessarily a vice all the time.
author: Jeff A.

description:
I'll tell you why I ate here... because after being around San Francisco and craving Mitchell's ice cream I knew I had to eat something first! Little did I know, fried chicken was going to be on that menu, I would have been better prepared. The place itself is a very unique place it doesn't really look like much. But they have these unique iconic rocking chair outside of a small little patio that reminds you but you're in for an adventure on the tasting end!

Mind you must really love southern food to come to a place like this. It is southern comfort food! Myself and a group of friends end up coming without any reservation mind you(you need a reservation!) 

The place on the inside is small dimly lit and almost Western spooky. But the wait staff is kind, friendly, and very very pretty. One of the hosts look like a better-looking Nicole Kidman! She is very nice, letting us know because we didn't come with the reservation the table that was available had to be emptied had a certain time. And that they will try to accommodate us.

THANK YOU!

They had a variety of different drinks, I can't really remember what I ordered but I did order the patent Jack and Coke. Far as food I do remember that we ordered some delicious sliders, some okra, greens, macaroni and cheese, and a bucket of fried chicken so that four of us can split. 

The Fried Chicken was delicious! The pieces that they gave were juicy its chicken was crispy. This itself cannot go without an order of grits, to complete the meal. 

The place has a delicious sauce that you can also buy and take home, but while you're at it make sure you enjoy some of that delicious mini corn bread.

This isn't the last time you've seen me! (Shakes fist)
author: Michael R.

description:
A wonderful dinner spent at the front porch for my husband's birthday dinner:

Suggested items to try:
1. Fried chicken meal w/ mashed potatoes and collard greens
2. Fried okra
3. Gumbo 
4. Beignets for dessert

Complimentary cornbread! Soo delicious! 

We were stuffed after eating all of that. We were going to get a 2nd meal entree, but we figured the the fried chicken meal with our items would fill us up. There were definitely no left overs to bring home but I consider that a very good thing!

A must try for a cajun flavor experience!
author: Marian V.

description:
This place was a big disappointment as a whole.
We came here with 4 other people and we all felt the same way :( yup, pretty sad, especially when you want to justify the pricing.

Let me start by what I liked, I did enjoy the Mac and cheese, collard greens, and hush puppies (even though they served them with ranch instead of honey butter).

Now off to the things I didn't like, their fried chicken was the biggest disappointment (we ordered 2 buckets, so it wasn't a fluke) the batter was not crunchy, mostly flaky, by far some of the worst fried chicken I had.  The gumbo was mediocre, the flavors didn't pop.  The cheese balls should be called meatballs due to the fact that it was a meatball not a cheese ball smh. We ended the meal with beignets and thought how bad can they be, big mistake, it was dense and not beignet like consistency.  Perhaps the places ive been to previously set the bar too high for this place.

Would I come back ? I would, only for their Mac and cheese, to be honest that's what earned them the 2 stars, do not be deceived by the 4 star rating.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
Came here with my sister as both first timers. Reservation through Yelp was pretty convenient as it got pretty crowded about 20 mins into eating our food. I ordered the famous Chicken n' Waffles while my sister ordered their Shrimp with Cheesy Grits. My food wasn't too bad as the waffle had REAL BACON bits and cornmeal baked inside. **cue Homer Simpson drool**

Chicken was pretty juicy with a great kick to it especially by drizzling their homemade hot sauce all over. Definitely enough to fill you up! This place had a divey-hispster country feel to it. Different, but cool décor overall. 

I wouldn't mind coming back to try their Crawfish Hushpuppies which I was told are only available during dinner. Until next time, Front Porch! :-D
author: Bria S.

description:
Came here on a date and this spot is great for sharing food. We didn't have to wait to be seated since there were two open spots in a cozy corner at the bar.

We got the 4 piece fried chicken with hush puppies and a biscuit; it ended up being enough food for two separate entrees if split. Our biscuit was taking a while so we called our waiter over and were treated with an extra one for the wait. Yum! 

The wine list is also marked with options that pair well with the fried chicken so be sure to check those out. 

Will definitely be coming back here for a full bucket next time! :D
author: Bonnie L.

description: Awesome pick for my company's holiday dinner! I'm a big fan of southern food and The Front Porch didn't disappoint me. My company ordered a preset dinner - fried chicken, beignets, shrimp and grits, etc. Everything was yummy and fresh! Sucks that they didn't order ribs as I was really looking forward to trying the ribs. This restaurant was featured on Food Network's Guy Richie's show "Diners, Dives..." so it is usually very popular. Glad my company made a reservation so we didn't have to wait. Atmosphere is interesting as it's pretty dark in there.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Reservation: quick online note it was a Tuesday
Decor: eclectic and kind of dark
Service: very good
Price: standard 
Drinks:
- porch swing: feminine old fashion
- Chantilly lace: herbal him cocktail
Food:
- fried okra: good to try but couldn't finish it 
- deviled eggs: ok solid recipe 
- (craveable) 4 piece fried chicken: amazing moist and the sides were also memorable
author: Cameron M.

description: I am already plotting when to return! We showed up early-evening without a reservation and were sitting at the bar about 40 minutes later. There were two of us an we ordered fried okra, mac and cheese, and the 4-piece chicken with sides and I loved it. It's greasy, down home, southern food.
author: Bianca E.

description:
The most important part of The Front Porch: BEIGNETS.

If you've gone to New Orleans before and you're craving Cafe du Monde, do not expect these to be JUST like that...but it's damn close. I'd definitely take these beignets over Brenda's any day.

This place is literally someone's front porch. I mean, it's attached to a house, okay, so keep that in mind. I went here with my best friends and we called in to reserve a table. We had to wait for about 10-15 minutes since that table was just taking their sweet time sitting around (patrons of restaurants: do remember that while it's okay to mingle, try to remember that other people want to enjoy the food too!), and the waitress was very gracious about it.

It's a pretty cool place. Really dark, so don't expect your Instagram photos to show up properly. The food there is all sorts of things you'll want to say, "Yes. Yes. Today...today is a treat yo'self day" to. I had some sort of breakfast food that was delicious but nowhere near as important to me as the beignets. I don't mean to say the food was bad...I just wanted the beignets way, way, way more than anything else that was on my plate. I got the chicken fried steak, which was not what I was expecting. It was really like a thinly cut steak, which is fancy, but I prefer mine to just be a hamburger, fried, because I am not classy.

Anyway, beignets. I think you get four for $5, which isn't bad. Next time, I'm just getting two bags for myself and calling that breakfast. Done.
author: Robbin A.

description:
4.5 ( but I will round up to 5 ) 

  Great food and great sevice. The fried chicken is tasty - milk battered with a sense of herbs, but I wish they would brine the meat more. 

  The fried okra is pretty good and the biscuits and gravy were soft and a delight to eat. 

  The decor really reminded me of New Orleans and it was fun sitting on my car seat turned dining chair. 

  They take reservations which is a plus.
author: Anthony N.

description:
We had the special crab cakes, really moist and full of crab.  We also had the Deviled eggs and chicken liver pate, we needed extra bread for the pate; both were very taste.

The bucket of chicken is really good, 5 people and we are still taking some home.  The mac-n-cheese is so good, a great melty and crispy cheese topping.

For dessert, pineapple upsidedown cake and butterscotch pudding;  the cake is ok, the pudding is great, not overly sweet.

Very good service.
author: Tina D.

description:
The place we had planned to eat at was closed and we just so happened to walk past The Front Porch while we were waiting for another friend. One of us had heard good things about the restaurant and so we decided to check it out for dinner. When we walked in they asked if we had a reservation, which we did not, but luckily they still had an available table. We ordered a smorgasboard of food, which was all delicious, but for me the Mac n Cheese was the star. I could not stop eating it. They are also known for their fried chicken, which was finger-lickin good, crispy skin. Cocktails were on point, and the service was friendly and homey. 

For 4 people: 

Apps: 
Deviled Eggs
Arugula Salad

Mains:
Shrimp n Grits
Friend chicken 4 piece with garlic mashers and ham hock collards
Dr. Pepper braised short ribs
Baked Mac n Cheese

The only ones I probably wouldnt get again were the short ribs and the deviled eggs. They weren't bad, just didn't wow me as much. With that being said, I was a happily satisfied customer at the end of the meal.
author: Cynthia T.

description: Great food, cocktails and service. The food is really great, but there aren't any healthy options so save your calories for this meal.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Wonderful cozy atmosphere, perfect for date night or a catch-up with a good (and hungry) friend. All the food was delicious and so so satisfying. The mixed drinks were also quite. On. Point. 

Blue crab hush puppies with spicy remoulade ($11)- four little fried balls of blue crab that were crispy on the outside, soft on the inside, delicious throughout. 5/5. 

Fried chicken 4-piece ($18.5)- served with garlic mashers and gravy, ham hook collards. This chicken was divine. So rich and tender and perfectly crispy on the outside. The mashed potatoes were also perfectly seasoned and so delicious! The collards balanced things out nicely but were a little on the salty side. 5/5. No wonder this is their trademark dish. 

Porch swing ($10)- Bourbon, Curacao, orange, lime, sugar rim. Both light and flavorful and perfectly balanced. 5/5. 

Smoke gets in your eyes ($12)- mezcal, aperol, yellow chartreuse, lime, grapefruit bitters. Again, perfectly balanced even taking into account the smoky mezcal. Loved. 5/5.
author: Sophie C.

description:
First of all the front porch literally the front of the restaurant is adorable! There's a few tables outside to enjoy San Francisco's beautiful weather surrounded by sparkly lights, green plants and a cute rocking horse. 
My boyfriend and I walk in and notice it's very small which is completely fine as I love small restaurants, to me there's better food and service. Inside is dark and cozy with an awesome bar! This is around 840pm so it's a completely different atmosphere than the day time hours. 
Before we were sat I didn't know we needed reservations (not required but recommended) because it gets crazy busy as told by the hostess and our waitress ( I'll put her name once I find it out). Anyway luckily for us they had open tables so we were sat right away, we had an option to sit at the table in the middle of the restaurant which is noisier or at the bar which is more intimate. We chose the table because we don't mind the noise.
Right away I notice the service is on point! Everyone who works there, bartender, hostess, waitresses, manager, bus boy, etc all helped out. They were all very nice and made sure everyone was taken care of.  
Literally right when we sat down a man brought us complimentary mini corn bread which was delicious then seconds later our waitress brings our water which was in a cool glass bottle. 
Our waitress was super cool and friendly! She went over the menu with us and recommended her favorites. 
My boyfriend ordered the burger with fries and a side of mac and cheese and I ordered the Dr Pepper braised shorts ribs with a side of mashed potatoes :) Everything was delicious! The mac and cheese was cheesy and saucy! 
Oh and my drink I ordered was on another level I had the Midnight Sun-ll and one of the ingredients was butterfly flower infused rum!  It was interesting in a good way :) 
Overall my experience was 10/10! Thank you for everyone's great service  I can't wait to come back and try the spicy shrimp and grits!
author: Brandi R.

description:
#tl;dr Some of their appetizers are among my favorites in SF, entrees not so much. Till I find a rockin main dish here, it's a drinks & apps kinda place.

If I were a lesbian Waffle or a gay Chicken, I'd just stay in the closet for #prideweekend bc I was *not* proud of the Chicken & Waffle I had. But if I were bi Okra or trans Peanuts... woopWOOOP I'd be dancing half nekkid on a float IN the parade mzafzas. #atethisway

(^_^) Fried Okra #amongfavesinsf
(^_^) Boiled Peanuts #amongfavesinsf
(^_^) Crawfish Hush Puppies #ateemall
(^_^) Iced Tea #mealstaple
(-_^) Biscuits & Gravy #wishmoresavory #twss
(-_-) Short Rib #toughmeat #twss
(v_v) Chicken & Waffle #liketheclothes #superdry

Perhaps I got the wrong entrees. But if it's a Southern restaurant and Fried Chicken is a wrong entree? #thingsthatdontmakeyougommmm *Rounding up* to 3 stars bc polite service.
author: Dan B.

description: Wonderful experience from service to food.  Thank you for being a great bartendar.....
author: Mary V.

description:
One of the best restaurants I've been to. Truly delicious and wonderful service. 

Got the Wild Arugula Salad to start followed by their fried chicken. Absolutely to die for. Definitely recommend this place!
author: Kay P.

description:
We were looking to try someplace new. Living in the East Bay, we're making an effort to try out neighborhood restaurants in San Francisco. Being fans of Cajun/Creole, we decided to try the Front Porch. 

We were greeted and given several seating options. We liked the hipster vibe of the restaurant. Upon being seated, we were presented with a pair of very small Corn Muffins. How small? Two bites each. 

The menu is pretty basic. Everything short of dessert fits on one page. I asked if the size of the Gumbo (appetizer) was appropriate for sharing. I was told that if I ordered the Dr. Pepper Beef Short Rib and she ordered the Fried Chicken Dinner, that the Gumbo would fill us up just fine, as the Gumbo came in a medium sized bowl. 

The gumbo was served with three bottles of hot sauce. A mild, a medium and a spicy habanero. The mild was bland. The medium had a nice little kick to it. We didn't dare try the habanero. The gumbo itself was very bland and needed the hot sauce. 

My Beef Short Rib was boneless and sitting on top of a pile of Smashed Potatoes. There was also some Broccolini keeping the Short Rib company. Flavorwise, it was good. Portionwise, it was adequate. Tenderwise, the fat was cooked out so the meat was a tad drier than I would have preferred. I didn't realize until after the meal was over that I hadn't received any horseradish (or if I had, it had no heat!).

The Fried Chicken was flavorful. The Garlic Mashed Potatoes were good but needed a bit more gravy as she ran out before finishing the potatoes. The Ham Hock Collard Greens were tender but lacked any smoky flavor.

All in all, an okay restaurant with very good service but not enough bang for the buck to bring us back.
author: Dexter D.

description: Cute place for a date, but there's also bar spots and tables that are a bit more well lit for everything else. The staff is amazing, and the ambience is just perfect for lean-in conversation. Definitely a warm, late night type of place.
author: Joy Y.

description:
We are going back! This is not a diet place! Chicken fried steak=excellent. My husband NEVER finishes a meal but he finished this plate. Grits were solid. Corn dog special was delicious. Only disappointment were the beignets. The dough was tough. My children are 1/2 and left them on the table. Brenda's still has the corner on best beignets. 

I'm going back today for a bucket of chicken for a party.
author: Rebecca M.

description: This place was great. The atmosphere was totally 80s! An era that I can truly appreciate. The food was great, service was excellent. I loved the décor and the intimate setting. Reminiscent of my childhood. Very chic and a dedication to the hipster generation. I will definitely return.
author: Tennille R.

description:
Small cozy restaurant with very good tasting Cajun food.

Started. With the deep fried alligator bites. They were cooked perfectly and came out piping hot. Served with a tasty tartar sauce. 

There were three of us so we shared the fried chicken, seafood stew, and shrimp and grits. All three dinners were very very tasty. 

Usually not a big collard greens fan, but the greens served with the chicken were very tasty. I guess they made me a fan. 

We ended the meal with an order of hot beignets. 

Make sure to make a reservation as they were very busy on this rainy Wednesday night.
author: Bill H.

description: This place continues to rock even two years later. We had dinner at the Front Porch last night and everything I wrote in a review two years ago, still stands. Food, service and ambience were all outstanding. Go check it out yourself, affordable, friendly and casual. All the right things for a good time when going out to eat.
author: Patricia M.

description: I loved all of the appetizers. The fried okra was really good and I don't usually like okra but I really liked this appetizer most. I had a burger with American cheese, bacon, and a fried egg. Honestly it was really good i was sad I couldn't finish it because I was so full. Now the chicken was good it was crispy but the flavor was ok. We found some parts of chicken that were a little under cooked. The mashed potatoes were really good (I love mashed potatoes).  The braised short ribs were very soft which allowed it to kind of melt in your mouth with the mashed potatoes. Besides the chicken everything was amazing. I would definitely come here again.
author: Denice Arielle M.

description: Yes! Worth the hype. Fried chicken, mash potatoes and their GREENs! All on point. Hush puppies are must have with their shrimp and grits. I orders almost everything on the menu. All served on point.
author: mui d.

description: I really like this neighborhood place and it seems the owners are trying hard to be welcoming and helpful but the food is inconsistent. I get the sense that there's a different chef every 3 months. In the beginning their fried chicken was amazing. Today it had way too much garlic and was borderline burnt. I couldn't eat it. I saw the tater tots being delivered in a box. Seriously? The cocktails are awesome and the staff works hard but the kitchen is the weak link.
author: Rude G.

description:
We were well pleased with the experience at the front porch. The fried chicken was a real hit! The creamed corn with bacon and troffle oil deserves a five star! And the mac and cheese is highly recommended. 

Our table ordered a lot of varieties to taste the menu, fried pickles was a 3 star, hush puppies were over fried, pork belly was very delicious, flounder a bit too much dough, shrimp and grits was very comforting but the collard greens was too salty.

We loved the selection of tequilas and beer, and service was excellent!
author: SJ L.

description:
If there's fried chicken on the menu, I'm probably gonna order it...

Food: Fried chicken. Made a reservation for an 11 AM brunch on Saturday and the place was surprisingly only half full. Yay. Ordered the Stoner Stack ($13) and omg, as the boyfriend can attest, I still talk about that sandwich months later. The combination of fried chicken, bacon, cheese, and sausage gravy together on a biscuit is just too much, in the best way possible. It was so good that I don't remember what anyone else ordered... the Hangover Helper? Eggs Benedict? Also on the plus side, the sandwich is really filling, especially since there's also a side of potatoes or grits. I got box to go, but if you're manly enough, you can definitely devour it.

Service: Not bad for brunch but it does take a while and then some for the food to come out. ~25 mins after ordering? But our waitress was nice and since we were all happy with the order, we didn't need to ask her for much.

Ambiance: Boyfriend lives around the corner, so I can't comment much on the parking. But also knowing this neighborhood, parking ain't easy. Pretty much always a group waiting outside anytime you walk by though. Their hype is real. Lighting is relatively dim inside though, so food pictures are rough.
author: Lucy Z.

description:
Here with husband unit on a Monday night at 9:30pm. Place is probably half full still. The service is super relaxed and chill but friendly... Like you're hanging out at a friend's house. There's a full bar and it's a bit loud even though it's not too crowded; seems like a good bar scene, but we were for fried chicken. Street parking which seemed like it'd be difficult at times (but in San Francisco, what can you really expect). 

Two complimentary sweet corn bread muffins with an herb butter. They weren't hot (not sure if they should be?) but they were still very tasty. Small like mini muffins... We asked for two more and that wasn't a problem.

Fried green tomatoes were tasty. Three slices topped with a pimento sauce were good. Not a huge portion or anything. 

Mac and cheese was quite delicious! It came out in a small skillet. Creamy shells and good flavors; not bland like some can be. It was probably my favorite part of the meal. 

We came for the fried chicken though, and it wasn't our favorite. The skin was kind of chewy/soft in spots, and the meat had a very plain-chicken taste... And almost bitter in a way. It was juicy though. It was difficult to bite into a clean spot though, also. So the chicken was probably my husband and my least favorite part, unfortunately. Everything else was delicious though, and the service was good. Collard greens are fair but a bit tough; good flavor though. Mashed potatoes were tasty. Biscuits came with an herb butter and apricot jam, which was very good. Everything was hot and good sized portions.... Neither of us could touch the 4th piece of chicken. 

Cokes were by-the-can, so I doubt the refills were free. 

We'd probably go back, but try something other than the fried chicken. Seems like a good bar though, and good food in general on top of that.
author: Kat B.

description: Enjoyable place with great food and one amazing waitress. I could see going here more.
author: Craig F.

description:
Review is for brunch:

You can make reservations for brunch which is really nice. The lighting was so dark though - are they trying to save on the energy bill?

I got the baked egg and grits. This was delicious - buttery grits and lots of flavor from mushrooms goat cheese. The runny egg was perfect. My only complaint was that between the goat cheese and bacon, the dish was VERY salty. I felt dehydrated after eating it! But I appreciated the uniqueness of the dish. 

The beignets were pretty good. They were totally hollow which I wasn't expecting, usually beignets have a little more substance.
author: Tasha H.

description:
I just came back from brunch. The food was really good and my party was very pleased initially. However, there was an incident that I felt could have been handled much better by staff and management of the restaurant. 

Towards the end of our meal, we noticed a bee was swarming around our table in the outdoor dining area and was attracted to our food. We had tried to move our food away hoping the bee would leave. It did not. After at least 5 minutes, I informed our server and he told me that there was nothing he could do and so I went back to my table with my party helpless trying to protect the food and themselves from getting stung. 

Our server eventually came back outside hoping to trap the bee with a cup but after multiple failed attempts, the manager/host came outside and with an annoyed tone of voice expressed how we could not continue to stand around the table and expect their staff to kill a bee for us, esp. since bees are beneficial for the environment. After hearing this, I was in disbelief and anger as my intention and expectation as a customer was only to be provided with a safe environment to consume my meal. Being made aware of the situation, staff and management did not immediately move us to another table but watched as we struggled along with two other tables next to us. 

We eventually moved to the bar area after the manager/host told us that we could not continue to struggle with the bee outside the dining area. We hesitantly finished the rest of the food we were able to salvage and left.
 
I had brought my aunt here to introduce her to a different type of cuisine that she had never had before. We were all so excited but left absolutely disappointed in how staff/management handled the situation and treated us.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
Complimentary corn bread muffins were quite tasty, but could have been hotter (or even hot lol). 

Fried green tomatoes were delicious. 

Biscuits were good. 

Wife unit thought the mac and cheese was very good. 

Fried chicken was good but not quite as good as we were hoping. We both thought it had a certain taste in it that was just...something we would have preferred not be there. Not like terrible or particularly dominant, but just enough to remind us that our main dish was like the only thing that wasn't quite...highly satisfying.

$2 cokes by the can were fairly priced compared to typical fountain sodas at most places, and the canned cokes were good cokes (coke varies to me, especially in fountain format, but also in can format). 

Service was friendly and efficient.
author: Zach C.

description: One of my top favs in the city! We always have a great meal: food super yummy (oh man, the fried chicken...), cocktails are interesting and tasty, and service consistently is nice and attentive (but not too attentive, ya know what I mean)! Highly recommend 'em!
author: Aimee M.

description: The most delicious baked beans in life. The beignets were better than those at Café Du Monde in New Orleans. Service was lovely and the atmosphere was overall lively and chill simultaneously. I found nothing wrong at The Front Porch.
author: Victoria ..

description:
When you go into a place that sells a t-shirt that says fucket get the bucket, you got to go ahead and order the fried chicken to see what the noise is all about. The menu was unique and if I hadn't seen the t-shirt, I would of gotten something else, but I was happy that I went with the chicken.

As itself, the meat was juicy and not dry. My guess is that it is brined and then battered/fried, and it makes a world of a difference. The fried batter was good with flavor. This ain't your kentucky fried chicken mess. This has unique spices that go well all around and the crisp is dark in color and not light. The hock hammed collared greens were the first I've ever enjoyed collared greens. It was soft and solid with a little tang but not too over powering. The mashed potatoes were creamy and could totally be used on the chicken to become biscuit and gravyish.

I definitely would recommend sharing majority of the entrees unless you can eat a lot. The 4 piece fried chicken were good enough for 2 people.

The vibe is like you walked into a home with the porch outside. Totally unique, small, comfy, and fits the neighborhood well. Dare I say it's San Franciscoish as a LA native? Perhaps. Did I also mention a full on bar with mixed drinks?

Come and get it!
author: Jason F.

description: Perfect spot for a nice cozy dinner. Had mulled wine with Vegan Jambalaya and they were both just perfect. A bit on the pricey side but food and service is totally worth it. Definitely recommend:)
author: Suprita K.

description:
Solid brunch option if you are ever in the neighborhood. It's often pretty packed and a wait on the weekends, so be sure to get their early. Make sure to come hungry, because this is not a place to eat if you are looking for a light bite. 

IMO, I think their Spicy Shrimp and Grits is their best dish (and I don't even like grits). Generous sized shrimp and the cheesy grits will make you wanting more. 

Hangover Mac dish is another favorite, but again it's a heavy bite. Also, go wrong with their eggs Benedict. 

Beignets are nothing special, but easy and nice to share. The baileys shot in your morning is a nice touch to starting your weekend too!
author: Christy C.

description:
Wasn't really sure what to expect here but all the food ended up being really delicious! This place sure knows how to fry food. We ordered a bunch of food and ate it family style

Hot boiled peanuts. Although this is an American joint, it sure did remind me of age my parents would boil peanuts and snack on them. The peanuts came out piping hot and had a slight kick to them

Fried pickles were great. Thinly sliced pickles with a good coating of batter was just the perfect ratio

Biscuits were hefty but surprisingly light and fluffy inside. They came with a side of tasty jam and herbed butter

Pork rillete was meaty, creamy and went well with the accompanied biscuits

Garlic fries were served thick, fresh cut and perfectly crisp. A yuzu based dipping sauce elevated the dish even more. 

By the time the bucket of chicken came out, we sure were stuffed but we all are one piece. For a chicken breast, it was seasoned well throughout the entire piece I had. 

Mashed potatoes came with a beef gravy and was delicious

Service was really attentive
author: Ed H.

description:
This was a late night vacation dinner but one well worth the wait. Our reservation was for nine o'clock and while we were on time we ended up being plus one, upon arrival. Probably not a big deal, but this is a small place; only worth mentioning because it resulted in a lengthy wait outside (probably to the tune of 30-45 minutes). They tried to make it right, with a free app, and bringing us drinks; the app however was slightly different (boiled peanuts) drinks were basically okay, sans the wine, which had turned (tasting of vinegar). They promptly replaced the wine with an appropriate substitution that was on par. 

In any event, we were eventually seated and this place was busy! I mentioned it was late but still it was loud (at this hour on a weekday I believe that's a testament to a well enjoyed restaurant). It is also a bit eclectic and bohemian but definitely in line with the City and what I've come to expect (in a good way). In any event let me close this portion by saying they were all very polite, eager to please, and happy to go the extra mile in homage to their customers. 

I ordered the spicy shrimp and grits. First bite, grits, buttery, decadent, perfect consistency, almost mashed potato like and oh so savory. It came with a sauce that was very complimentary and offered incredible layers of appeal. The spicy was absent but that is typical for me, that said the sausage offered significant flavor to the dish and the shrimp was perfectly cooked. They served a bread snack small muffin, as a warmup, but it was a little disjointed for me; not as sweet as cornbread and tasted of sourdough without that consistency. The spread offered with the bread was okay, but did little to enhance the flavor of the bread, or stand on its own. 

As for our other diners and guests: our younger son had the Dr. Pepper ham, which I didn't taste, but those that did raved. Our elder son, had the burger (he was polite enough to accept it, he'd ordered the flank steak but it became confused somehow) he ate 3/4 of it and was done; he also ate three fries and was equally over the fries too. My wife is a lover of mac 'n cheese and yet most of it remained in her dish; she described it as simply a cheddar sauce and a lot dry. I'd have went with a creamier cheese; though I love cheddar, it doesn't typically make a great sauce as it gets grainy when melting. 

Hey, we often joke I do better at ordering, so perhaps I should've ordered for my lovely wife. Overall, I was happy with the dining experience, but I think she had the lesser experience, as did the elder son. I'd still come back, especially were I local.

On a brief side note: we could've easily passed by this place and missed it so know the address or destination, but it's worth the trip.
author: Drew R.

description: Today was our first time there. I went with my wife and daughter. The food was great and this may sound a little funny but the french fries were wonderful. I found plenty of street parking. But the shining star of this restaurant is an employee by the name of the Felix. She is a server and her hospitality and generosity are better than any five-star restaurant. She was very friendly and went above and beyond to help us and she even shared a personal story. I do not know what her hourly pay is, but I think management should double it. Because of her, we would definitely be back!
author: M C.

description: My wife and I heard about this restaurant and we decided to visit. We had a great time and are booking our second reservation. The food was excellent especially the shrimp.
author: Ron U.

description:
This is definitely a Local Dive. So far, as I await the arrival of my perpetually late daughter, I have enjoyed the cornbread muffins and blue crab hush puppies.  The jalapeño aioli is spot on. Perfect with my Speakeasy CASK IPA!  Probably have a couple more before she arrives!  My pics are lost in the plethora of pics - #2998 & #2999, but of course I think they are the best. 

Noisy conversation and good beer seem to amplify each other! Hope she comes soon!
author: David H.

description:
This was our second visit to The Front Porch.  Knowing that there could be a long wait on a Sunday I opted to use Yelps reserve a table option. Once there we were greeted by a friendly and smiling hostess and our table was ready in five minutes, much better than the 45 minutes they were quoting walk-in guests. 

There were three in our party and we were seated in the five minutes range. Water was quickly poured and menus handed out. They offer a nice variety of brunch and lunch items as well as some interesting cocktails. We stuck with lemonade and iced tea however. I asked for a piece of lemon for the tea and they brought us a cup full of lemon wedges right away.
