description:
So sad I have had this place bookmarked for awhile after ready glowing reviews and sadly me and my Husband rate this place 3 Stars!

1 Star for friendly customer service
1 Star for ambiance 
1 Star being able to make reservations online

I ordered the Shrimp Po' Boy that was $16 and my Husband ordered the Chicken & Waffles for $16.  And we tried the beignets as well.

Let's start with my Shrimp Po' Boy Booooy it sure was poor as it was more bread than anything hardly any shrimp that they were only in the middle of the sandwich only with excess bread around them.  You can see in my picture I posted.  I have to say Brenda's is way better.  Also the beignets were ok but we love Just For You Cafe's better as they are bigger, lighter & fluffier texture.  My Husband got the Chicken and Waffles for $16 you would think they would be better than average.  He said they were just OK.  The ambiance was decorated really cutesy and the staff was very friendly.  I'm glad we gave them a chance but on to the next.
author: oNEloVE C.

description:
Before ordering I like to read some negative reviews, just to reduce the hype I have heard about any restaurant. I just want to say that Front Porch was a true delight.

Being on somewhat of a comfort food kick, I ordered up the baked mac 'n cheese and the bucket o' chicken (10 pcs) for my roommate's birthday. Went to pick up as our house is fighting a cold and couldn't make it out, but the ambiance was adorable. There is outdoor seating where a family with their little kids were sitting; twinkly lights and knick knacks in the front, not sure about the back (didn't get that far), inside was dimly lit and cozy, looks like a nice date spot. Full bar and plenty of tables. An obvious regular followed close behind me and we were both greeted by the bartender with true enthusiasm, like she was happy to see her friends. The waitress who helped me called me "honey" (nice people rule).

Having ordered to go, I was immediately approached by a waitress who went to check on the order in the kitchen. Order was ready, about $40 for it all (which is a bit pricey considering it was chicken and pasta...). We got home and dished out the steaming, cheesy mac and I couldn't help but take the first bite, mid-scoop. It was really good! We sat down and dug into giant morsels of golden brown fried chicken. So moist and full of flavor, no one used hot sauce at all, which we normally would do. 

Good portion sizes and really hit the spot for just what we wanted. I might be a little addicted to the mac 'n cheese, but hey, it's hard to find a good, tasty mac 'n cheese in the city, and trust me, I've looked. Enjoy, people!
author: Crystal C.

description:
Awhile ago, we hopped on the healthy bandwagon and started eating clean (which is a really hard thing for a foodie to do) and hit the gym/run more regularly. We reward ourselves with a cheat meal and somehow their Fried Chicken started calling my name after a visit up to Point Reyes for oysters.

They were nice enough to squeeze a party of 4 in at the last minute and we ordered a good variety of dishes to try.

Mac and Cheese - Pretty damn good for restaurant mac and cheese. Eat hot.... there was a crispy crunchy layer of toasted cheese on top while the mac was bathed in creamy goodness. When I bit down on the mac, it squirted out a dollop of butter in my mouth. Definitely a high caloric splurge side!!

Gumbo - It was well flavored and I could taste the butter and rich fat that was emulsified in. I dread to even THINK about how many calories it was but it was one of the better gumbo's I've had in the Bay Area.

Fried Chicken - Definitely delicious! Yelp did not lead us wrong! We ordered the entree for four of us to share. The garlic mashed was delicious and I don't think I'll ever grow to like collard greens but that's just a personal preference issue. The chicken was well brined and well fried. It didn't taste like a grease bomb like the Addendum version I had a few months ago. 

Dr. Pepper Short RIbs - Interesting tangy sweet sauce, short ribs were well braised so they were falling off tender. I loved the celery root mash!!

Porch Chop - Delicious!! Good porky flavor, served medium. Creamed corn left little to be desired. It tasted slightly sour and seemed like they added some sort of alcohol that needed to be cooked out. 

Flounder w/ Jambalaya - DELICIOUS!!! Texture of the fish was perfectly crunchy and the jambalaya was delicious. Found nice large chunks of blue crab meet.

Shrimp and Grits - YELP YOU FAILED ME!!!! *CRIES* this was my entree... after FALLING IN LOVE with the shrimp and grits at Petite Toulouse in Seattle. The shrimp here wasn't large and plump... and the grits were pretty flavorless. Gravy left little to the imagination. It wasn't the worse shrimp and grits I've ever had, but it didn't come close to the Seattle Version. 

Overall only the shrimp and grits was a miss... Service was great and they make their own ghost pepper sauce!
author: Vicky L.

description:
I love that a lot of families bring their young kids to eat dinner here and that the servers are so warm towards them.  

I made a reservation on Saturday night for 5:30pm, right when they open, and the restaurant filled up shortly after we were seated.  

The fried chicken really is the bomb diggity.  I don't know what exactly is in the seasoning but it the right balance.  You have to ask for their two hot sauces on the side--the orange bottle (habanero) is so darn tasty you'll want to drizzle it on everything.  Sides for this dish are collard greens (good) and mashed potatoes (good but not special).

I also tried the burger which was properly cooked to order, medium rare, but I wouldn't say it's a must get item here.  The fries that come with it are thick and seasoned spicy, just the way I like it!!  

Great service.  Our server came by to fill up our water TONS of times even though we had a bottle at our table, which I usually assume means its our responsibility.  I would definitely come back for an intimate dinner with 1-3 people; it's not big enough for groups.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Had to check this place out after finding they were featured on Guy's Triple D. 
The place is very small, very busy, so you gotta make reservations. 

I went with a group of 7 people and we ordered:
Hush puppies (YUMMMMMM!)
Shrimp n Grits (My friend loved it!)
Bucket of Fried chicken (Tasty)
Porkchop (My friend really liked it)
Braised short ribs (Good)

We felt their portions were big, no one was able to finish their plate so come hungry!

My order was forgotten so I had to sit with food envy for a bit. Our server, I guess she seemed nice enough? I felt she was annoyed by us at times... 

Parking is horrible! You'll probably have to circle the area a few times to find parking.
author: T P.

description:
Ignore the fact that I came here during my son's naptime and he was being hella crabby. Ignore the fact that I had a hunger migraine by the time we arrived. Ignore the fact that my mom couldn't decide what she wanted and then when she did, she changed her order soon after ordering.

Despite these circumstances, the food was good and it arrived with impeccable timing. The sweet potato fries were crispy, delicious and came with this aioli dip that was really yummy. The beignets were very hot and kept my son quiet for a few minutes. I wasn't in the mood for sweets, so it made no difference to me.

I didn't know what to order because my migraine was getting in the way of my appetite, so I let the server choose for me. He said I would enjoy the pulled pork sandwich. Did I? I don't know, my migraine wouldn't let me truly enjoy it.

I want to base my review on everyone else who finished their plates, especially my stepdaughter who eats like a bird. She and my husband ordered the chicken fried steak and enjoyed it very much. My dad and my brother enjoyed their fried chicken with waffles. My mom and my sister in law enjoyed their dishes as well, so I guess that's a great thing.

I gotta come here again. No kids, no headache. Just my appetite.
author: Sharon B.

description:
Let me just start by saying I'm not from the South.  Went with some friends of mine who grew up in Alabama and they had a hankering for some Southern cooking.  They loved the place and everything they consumed - they said it was the best Southern food they've had in SF by far. 

I had the fried chicken, which was very tasty.  We had the boiled peanuts to start (I just don't understand these, not a fan) and the fried pickles (these were delicious).  

If you're looking for some tasty fried food, this place is great.  I think one thing that would make it better is if they offered some non-fried options as well to help balance out the menu.
author: Rachael S.

description: I remember coming here when they first opened after hearing all the hype on The Food Network. I remembered it being so great that I wanted to come back and try it again. Unfortunately my visit yesterday did not go so well. Not sure if the chef or management changed, but the food tastes different. For example the biscuits are different and they didn't have the jam that was so amazing. My boyfriend ordered the country plate with bacon and he was initially given completely overdone bacon. Then when he asked for more they were under done. I ordered the shrimp po' boy which was good. I did like what I ordered. But The service was slow as well and took about an extra thirty minutes to get our check. Something was just off, I'll see if I come back again in the future.
author: Michelle P.

description:
First time here with my girlfriend. Ordered the chicken and waffle for myself, and gf got the pulled pork hash. Also started with the fried okra with jalapeño aioli. 

The okra was fried perfectly. Not too oily. Doesn't leave a puddle of oil at the bottom  like most places with fried veges. The aioli sauce was also on point. Didn't leave a single drop. 

The pulled pork hash was good. Not super amazing, nonetheless, still appetizing. 

Now let's get to the pinnacle of this whole experience. The fried chicken and waffle. There's a 25 minute wait for this dish, but it is worth it! The outer layer of the chicken (skin?) was fried to perfection. The chicken meat itself was surprisingly moist and tender. This is the best fried chicken I've ever had! The waffle was good too. Not on par with the chicken, but still good. Try not to drench it with syrup before hand like we did. It got soggy after a few minutes. Dip it in the syrup instead. 

Overall, this place is definitely worth visiting. Brunch is only on weekends.
author: Michael C.

description:
I saw this place featured on a tv show and had to try it for myself. We went for brunch on a Sunday. No line, got seated fast. Staff was so nice and helpful. 

The food was amazing! I had the Chicken Fried Steak. By far, best chicken fried steak I've ever had. Not to mention the potatoes. My boyfriend got the country breakfast and he also loved his food. 

Definitely found my new favorite spot in San Francisco!!
author: Leslie A.

description:
Came here on a date yesterday and thought this place was really good! As a native Texan, glad to find such quality Southern food.

To start, we both got jalapeno margaritas. These were really good - mind was very spicy, which I love. 

Then we ordered fried okra for an appetizer and shared the 4-piece fried chicken. The fried okra was almost to hot to eat initially but was really good. Next up: the fried chicken, which I very rarely order anywhere. So glad that i did here. It was both crispy and juicy and we both loved it.

There are a few other things on the menu which I'd wanna try, so def will be back here!
author: Dan T.

description: I'm not a big brunch person but we came here on a Sunday afternoon since we were in the area. Wait was at least 30 minutes at 11:45am (surprise) but the bar was surprisingly empty so we snagged 2 seats. I swore I'd get the beignets but I totally forgot! We split the baked mac n cheese appetizer and the stoner stack. Both were average; mac n cheese seemed a little dry and the hot plate it was served on was way too large for the small portion, stoner stack was a bit of a disappointment and the side of cheesy grits didn't taste cheesy at all. Cocktails (Bloody Mary, get the bacon rim!) and swinging porch (?) were fabulous along with the bartender. Might come back but will try the dishes they're "known for" as well as the beignets
author: Jamie B.

description: Best fried chicken. Ever. Anywhere. And every other dish is amazing too. Seasonal menu changes from time to time. But everything is always solid. One of my favorite places in SF.
author: Stephen D.

description:
Birthday brunch has kind of become a tradition as I've gotten older so I was definitely on the look out a few weeks prior looking for a cool spot out in the city. I've heard good things about this place from family and co-workers so this place was a must!

I started out with an amazing mimosa that got the day off on the right foot! For starters, we ordered the fried okra. I've never really been a fan of okra growing up, but our super cool server recommended it. She was definitely right because it was cooked a perfect golden brown and was paired with some sort of delicious aioli type sauce. I also ordered the beignets. The beignets were nice and pillowy soft in the middle but had ridiculously good crunchy corners. For the main dish, I ordered the shrimp and grits. I thought this dish was good but it could have been better. The shrimp was slightly overcooked and the grits could have used a bit more butter. (Brenda's French Soul has a much better shrimp and grits dish!) I also ordered a side of the mac and cheese. This side dish was amazing!! The pasta cooked just right and it was also super cheesy with a nice little crust on top. I tried my sisters order of the chicken and waffles. The chicken was perfectly cooked, nice and juicy. The waffle also nice and crispy. 

I don't remember our servers name, but she was super cool! She was great at providing menu suggestions and really friendly. The vibe inside is chilled and relaxed. The decor inside reminded me of that old school, 80's biker bar that Whoopi Goldberg's character in Sister Act escapes to in the middle of the movie. Two thumbs up for The Front Porch!
author: Paul C.

description: Love this place for brunch! Everything I've had has been great, and sitting outside on rocking chairs with blankets and a hot beverage is definitely the best way for me to work off my hangover.
author: Josh H.

description:
Service: 5 stars
-Our food was going to take longer than expected, but before we could even notice the wait we were given free beignets to hold us over. Also, we brought our 3 year old, and they were so accommodating with giving her crayons, coloring paper, and plastic utensils (despite Yelp saying that this place is not good for kids). 

Food: 4.5 stars
The fried chicken was crispy, juicy, and full of flavor. It was just a tad too salty for my liking but my husband thought it was perfect. The pulled pork hash was tasty and cooked well. The fried okra was also good, but some pieces were a little tough and fibrous ( I know they probably don't grow their own okra, but maybe this could have been avoided this with smaller pieces of okra?). The beignets were light, fluffy, warm, and covered in powdered sugar. What more could you ask for? My daughter loved her Mac n cheese, it was a huge portion that would have fed an adult. I admit I stole a few extra bites after I tasted it to see if it was too hot, and we still had to ask for a to go box. 

Overall, this place is great and well deserving of a 5 star review. My critiques are super minor, and I would definitely come here again.
author: Ciana D.

description:
Hands down one of my favorite, if not my most favorite, Cajun restaurants in the city. I've been here a couple of times (birthday dinners, date night, just because.. Etc) and it has never disappointed. 

I don't think I've tried anything bad from their menu. But the fried chicken, mac and cheese, and gumbo stand out the most to me. Those are my three favorite Cajun comfort food, and I'm a hard critic on my Mac & cheese, so for theirs to stand out means a lot. Also, their bucket of fried chicken comes with popcorn. 

I've also tried their appetizers and my favorite is their fried okra. Sounds gross at first because okra is typically a gooey-textured vegetables but when fried, it's not slimy at all! Most fried okras I've tried are usually soggy but here at The Front Porch, it was crunchy fried goodness.

There can be a wait but I love that they take reservations from Open Table, so I definitely avail of that service so I won't have to wait long for my bucket of fried chicken.

Parking around the area is always tough. I mean it's the Mission, so even if you have a reservation, give ample time to look for parking if you're gonna drive.
author: Liezel D.

description:
Came here with my family on Christmas Eve for brunch.  This place is absolutely amazing. Simple food done perfectly. Gumbo and red beans and rice as good as New Orleans. Fried chicken as good as anywhere in the south. 
I'm so thankful to find great down home cooking in the heart of a quaint part of San Francisco. 
Don't miss the bloody mary's!!!!!!
author: Dwayne G.

description: two stars for the horrible service. I am disabled and was seated at the bar. HELLO!!!! I can barely walk and you sit me at a bar. The hostess finally gave a hoot to reseat use at a table. The service was still less than desirable. The FOOD was amazingly delicious. The collard greens was haut like big mamas and the mash potatoes too. The fried chicken cook could take a lesson again with the chicken. It was dry and over cooked burnt. Overall. I would not recommend.
author: Shar I.

description:
I love love the beignets here for for the first round at brunch. Second, the chicken and waffles. Always include a mimosa followed by chickory coffee. I've never had to wait more than 20 minutes and the seating outside is perfect on those lovely SF days.

This place is one of my favorite brunch places in the city because of it's location (we always find parking) and I like dark lighting inside. I love that it's not super duper bright and blinding. Sometimes I like bright, sometimes I don't. Ok..tangent.
author: Carina M.

description:
Two stars for the food. 

Service was terrible. A 30-minute wait that started with a name placed on the wait list and a phone number taken turned into a 90-minute wait. It was as if they kept forgetting we had spoken to them and were reminded every time we came back to check-in with them. People listed further down had been seated every time we checked back in. Lastly, it came off as an inconvenience every time we came up to them (at the time we were told to come back!) and asked about our wait time.
author: Erika J.

description:
After reading many wonderful reviews about how good the fried chicken was, I had to try it out for myself. 

Had reservations, but ended up arriving way earlier than expected, but luckily there was only one or two tables filled up. We got seated promptly.. the host/waitress was welcoming. Got seated in one of their booths and took a minute to decide what we were gonna order.

The interior feels very down south, homey feeling... which is nice and comforting since I was about to indulge in a bunch of comfort food!

We Decided on a bucket of fried chicken, that comes with a side of mashed and collard greens.. and also got a side of baked mac n cheese.

NOTE: the chicken and mac n cheese takes a while to come out, so if you're absolutely starving, I'd definitely suggest getting a starter.

Prior to everything coming out, we got two pieces of corn bread with jalapeno butter spread.. the corn bread was warm... oddly shaped, as I have never seen it in that form/shape.. the butter was good but a bit flavorless and didn't help much with the cornbread. 

So, in my honest opinion... I did not like the chicken very much... first off, I wasn't a fan on how they fried it... it wasn't too crispy and quite greasy.. it wasn't even juicy... I would have rather ate at Popeye's for the price of The Front Porch's bucket..  

The collard greens were SOOOOO sour... made it hard to swallow..

The mashed were good.... flavorful.... and creamy..

The mac n cheese was truthfully the only other thing that was okay.... and that would be sad to have been messed up..

As usual... I am always on the look out for good customer service... it was sad to see that I was never asked how we were doing after we took our order.. I eventually had to flag the girl down for some ketchup. 

Mediocre food... and mediocre service.. MEHHHH......
author: Tiff C.

description: Great place, great service the bartender is extremely nice and very informative. Can't wait to return again. We tried The fried chicken, Mac Cheese, and garlic mashed potatoes and all three were bomb.
author: Samineh H.

description:
I came here last Saturday 9/12 and made a reservation through Yelp SeatMe.  I was so surprised to find that I was able to make a reservation just two hours before, which was nice. The reservation was set for 12:00 pm for a party of 2.  We got there 5 mins early, but actually didn't get seated till around 15/20 mins later. I noticed a couple folks (who didn't have reservations) arrive around the same time & the wait time, even with a reservation, was pretty even. No big deal, but I probably could've used those extra minutes to even out my wing liner instead of rushing to make our reservation. (Enter palm face here.)

The bf and I were seated outside. First off, the setting/theme is so cute.  The fact that its literally a front porch is amazing & I really enjoyed the homey vibes.  There are a bunch of mismatch benches/chairs (rocking & static) and even a little rocking horse for those waiting to be seated. I thought it was cute how they had a sign out front in which invited guests to take advantage of the surrounding business while waiting to get seated.  Oh, and brownie points because about 4/6 of the tables out front had their pups with them. As I ALWAYS immediately fall in love with every dog I see, this was a plus for me. I'll be returning with my schnauzer next time. Anyways, we split everything--the beignets, the Stoner Stack, and the Chicken and Waffles. The beignets were good. Super light and not too sweet. I would get them again, but am I wrong for saying they're ain't thattttt special? The Stoner Shack, I really enjoyed.  The chicken & bacon was nice and crisp, as were the potatoes. The onions with the potatoes were BOMB.  I just really wish there was more gravy though. By the time the chicken & waffles came out, I was pretty full at this point. I ate a quarter of the waffle and a piece of chicken. The waffle had bacon pieces in it! I could've done without, but still good.

The only reason that this isn't a 5 star review is because service was a little EH. Don't get me wrong, everyone was super friendly, just felt a little short handed.  All in all, for brunch the food was great. Not anything out of this world, but what makes this place  special are the vibes and setting. I'll definitely have to try dessert next time.
author: Julie Ann B.

description:
Heard about this place many times and finally made it over. Reservations are strongly recommended. If you can't get a table there, walk across the street to The Rock Bar and you can have your food delivered there, while enjoying tasty tap beer or, my favorite, sparkling wine in a lovely old school glass. 
Now, about that bucket of chicken....yummy!  Don't be afraid to use your hands either.  Tasty sides like Mac n cheese and biscuits with gravy complete your need for comfort food.  My brothers ordered their fried pickles and enjoyed it with the creole dipping sauce.  Is your mouth watering yet?
author: Michelle P.

description:
Came here after trying for a long time, it's best to plan ahead and make a reservation. It's a small restaurant, as with most restaurants I'm San Francisco you want to eat at the ones that have the longest wait. As a tourist this is a hard concept, but as a local you know people will wait for good food.

This is no exception. Good food all around, fun quirky menu to throw you a chuckle. The shrimp and grits were spot on as were the hash (even though the menu said "sweet potatoes" they were not sweet potatoes (but still a very tasty treat).  A good variety of beers are available, I did enjoy the decor of the restaurant. 

It is a little on the dark side (perfect for hangovers), the music was a little interesting I would have thought the music would have been more jazz themed? The beignets were not what I've had in he past in New Orleans, but the portions are so generous that you don't really need desert.

Someone took my friends chair when he was in the bathroom. The rest of us didn't notice because we were to busy sharing food.


Food is good.. Will be back!
author: Chris L.

description:
Another disappointment. The chicken and waffles were not quite what I expected. 
-The fried chicken I felt was not golden at all but dark brown from not changing the oil they used to fry it in. 
-The biscuits were downright delicious along with their homemade strawberry jam. 
-D/f okras were ok nothing outstanding. The sauce to dip it in was good tho
-Spicy shrimp and grits overly salty and nowhere near spicy 
-Sweet ice tea, refreshing
-Seafood gumbo made me sad because it just did not taste like gumbo at all

Verdict: I would only come back here to munch on there nummy biscuits and homemade jam with their refreshing sweet ice tea

PS they have the ghost pepper hot sauce but you have to ask for it.
author: Mary Ann B.

description:
When I asked everyone that I was with what their biggest complaint about this place was, one of my friends answered "that it's not closer to my house" and I couldn't agree more. The atmosphere is really chill and our waitress was very sweet and very helpful. I got the burger and it was quite perfect. It was perfectly cooked, juicy and flavorful. The fries were made fresh and even the pickles and ketchup seemed to have been made in house as they had a unique, different flavor to them. Everyone I was with loved their meals as well and most importantly we all left absolutely stuffed. I really wish I could've gone here for brunch because the brunch menu looks even better the dinner menu. I'm not from San Francisco but I might have to make the trip back just to come back to here. Yes, it was that good. No brainer 5 star review. 


The front porch rocks, for sure.
author: Waldo M.

description:
This place is amazing!  I went here last night with a few friends,  my second time, and I had to take the time to write a review this morning.  Go here.  You will NOT be disappointed.

Food/Drinks
Our evening started off by presenting them a very nice bottle of Pinot we brought to have them open for us.  No fuss, no hassle, like so many SF restaurants with attitude give you.  We also ordered glasses of white wine to start off and the deviled eggs as an appetizer.  The eggs, slightly smoky, were unbelievable....who'd of thought, something that simple could be so delicious. 

For dinner, we each got something different (pork chop, braised short rib, fried chicken) so we could share things.  The pork and short ribs were "spoon tender", perfectly cooked (not over cooked) and melted in your mouth with very different layers of flavor; simple food made complex.  As a fried chicken aficionado, this place cannot be beat and I've eaten it ALL over the USA.  The chicken is very crispy, a very nice heat (spice) to it, not a bit of grease, and the meat is as tender as it gets.  The portions are huge, but with some arm twisting, we did a good job finishing everything.  : )

For dessert, we ordered the beignets were more than we needed, but what the heck.  I had a cognac, very good price for a very good vsop.  One other in our party had a beer/coffee liquer drink suggested by the waitress ("The Best Part of Waking Up").  It was good.  Very different.  (see more under service).

Service
Perfect.  I do a lot of cooking and, while I really appreciate great food, service is what makes it for me.  I can't say enough.  She was helpful.  Honest.  And, as I mentioned up above, when my friend didn't completely enjoy the "coffee/beer" drink, she took it off the bill without us even asking.

Go here!
author: John S.

description:
The Front Porch won my heart today.

I had heard of it, but never been, and the boyfriend had mentioned chicken fried steak on Thursday and we couldn't get it out of our heads ever since. I poked around on the internet looking for the best, and we decided to finally try The Front Porch.

First, the style is exactly to our tastes, as is the music. It's sort of like a old timey dive bar hybrid southern comfort diner with kitsch so classy it ain't kitsch no mo'. The ambiance and comfort is top notch IMO.

We had a reservation for the opening time of 10 on Sunday (today). Our waitress came right away, but the meal took a while to get to us - some kitchen issues, but seriously.. don't you dare ding them for a stall. The food was orgasmic.

Surprisingly light for such an often heavy and greasy fare. I mean, it was indulgent for sure, but we felt great after we cleaned our plates - a rarity in southern cooking. Usually the eating is great and afterwards you're kind of ashamed of what you just did to yourself. 

The boyfriend had the Stoner Stack with potatoes. It was divine. We had the fried egg on top; It's a stack of fried chicken bacon cheese and country sausage gravy on a biscuit. INSANELY GOOD.

I ordered the chicken fried steak with two eggs over easy and cheesy grits. It was amazing. At first, I agreed his was the winner of the two, but after continuing to eat these items in the same bite and had the flavors developing and harmonizing - It's dead heat. This place is our new favorite breakfast place.

Since my boyfriend makes killer breakfast, we rarely ever go out and pay for it. But this place can expect to see us there on the regular.

Seriously. I love The Front Porch so much - I'd fight someone over it.
author: Jane H.

description:
Came for brunch after the Giant Race with my mom. The atmosphere and food are phenomenal!!! We were starved after the 10k and decided to pretty much order enough food for like 5 people. Started with the beignets and fried okra, then chicken & waffles and the shrimp po'boy. Enjoyed a bloody mary and a schlitz-alada to quench our thirst. We sat outside so I don't have any impression of the inside other than it's dark and small.

Beignets - Warm pillows of sweet dough camouflaged under a thick layer of powdered sugar. No dips or sauces (which is how I prefer them) and they come in a cute brown paper bag. They were the perfect start to this meal!!

Fried okra - honestly the real reason why we decided to get these was because of the jalapeno aioli. The okra was cut into large pieces then fried in a thin batter so you could really taste the (somewhat) slimy texture. The jalapeno aioli was a beautiful combo of creamy and spicy. It was definitely worth getting this dish for the dip but I don't think I'll be ordering them again, maybe just a side of the aioli for my fries!

Chicken & waffle - best decision I made all day! I'd never had chicken and waffles before so I wasn't sure what to expect. Based on other reviews and recommendations, I think I was just hoping for something filling, comforting, and savory. It absolutely delivered!! It comes with 3 pieces of hearty chicken that are battered in a creole spiced concoction and fried until deep brown. The waffle was thin but if it was thicker, you wouldn't be able to taste the chunks of bacon hidden in the mix. I didn't even put butter on the dish and used less than a spoonful of the maple syrup. It was just too good to not enjoy it in it's naked state. I couldn't even finish the dish which is literally unheard of me. Must have been the second beignet I consumed!

Shrimp po'boy - I didn't get to try this dish since we were so full (see above!). It looked delicious and my mom said it was pretty good but dry. The bread looked like a toasted baguette and it was pretty hard. The shrimp were HUGE - so big that they looked like pieces of white fish more than shrimp. The french fries were sprinkled with a healthy dose of some creole seasoning but again, had so much to eat that they were barely touched. I'd love to try this dish the next time and get a better idea of the flavors all together.

Drinks - their bloody mary mix is damn good! Not too spicy but has an amazing flavor and tastes very fresh (not even sure if they make their own or not but it's fantastic!). I had the schlitz-alada/michelada (i.e. bloody mary mix with a pacifico). It was a match made in heaven with my chicken and waffle.

The reason why it doesn't get 5 stars is because of our waitress. She seemed a bit annoyed that we were there and wasn't attentive at all. The food runners had so much more personality and communication skills than she did so it was sort of a blessing that she only came around to take our order and drop off the check. After we ordered our food, she rudely grabbed the menus and we had to stop her to place our drink order before she ran inside and disappeared. She also didn't come by to see how everything was so her attitude didn't give off the comforting southern hospitality vibe that they want to have going for them. 

Moral of the story - Food is really, really good!! Go try it for yourself! I'd definitely like to come back and be able to hang a bit longer. I'll probably not order quite as much food so I could actually enjoy my full meal but I'm glad we were gluttonous the first time around!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Not the healthiest food, but very rich and delicious.  We shared the Spicy Shrimp with Grits, a salad, some crawfish hush puppies and the bread pudding.  The grits is creamy smooth and buttery with a very french tasting sauce + a little spice.  It was outstanding and very filling.  The hush puppies were also really good.  T

It's a bit over priced for the biker bar-like decor, and somewhat rustic home cooking. But then again, it's probably the best southern food I've had anywhere outside of the South.... so I guess it's worth it!
author: Paul K.

description:
We came on a Monday evening arriving just after 6:15 and were asked if we had reservations. "Oh no!" I thought to my self but our host said he just likes to always ask. There was no issue because there were at least two open tables. I highly suggest you make reservations on any day of the week or time because within 15 minutes there was a wait.

Food here is five stars and in case you missed it the fried chicken is excellent, superb and wonderfully tasty. On the inside it's juicy and tender and on the outside crispy and crunchy. Definitely top five in the city, no question.  I'm not going to get into the complexity of a thin exterior crust that pulls off the skin but it's marvelous. My dinner came on a prison lunch tray with popcorn, greens (excellent), mash potatoes with gravy and the most amazing fried chicken I've had in a long time. I was told when I placed the order there may be up to a 20+ minute wait. If I was in a hurry I'd go to KFC so this isn't an issue for me. In fact it gave me time to enjoy my Racer 5.

She had some fish thing on rice with water. I wasn't about to mess up the happy little flavor party going on inside my mouth for fish.

There is a 92% chance we will return for the fried chicken although please do be aware that where this is a very cute little spot with lots of charm it is a dive bar and smells as such.
author: Justin S.

description:
In short, the dining room was very dimly lit, table was wobbly, restroom had graffiti everywhere and just disgusting and food was extremely overpriced for what it was; spent $90 (no alcohol) with tip for 2. The highlight was that our waitress was very friendly and attentive.

We ordered the hushpuppies and tiger shrimp appetizer; these were pretty decent.  The mashed potatoes were nothing spectacular.  I did not like the collard greens at all.  The bucket of chicken was moist but extremely overpriced at $30. 

I wouldve been happy eating at my neighborhood Popeyes for a fraction of the price.
author: Raymond S.

description: The food was fantastic!  Fried chicken, shrimp and grits, deviled eggs with bacon jam, blue crab hushpuppies and baked mac and cheese.  Ran into a friend and it felt like home.  We were there on the fundraising night for the victims of the Mission/29th St. fire.  It was great to see the number of vendors that donated goods to the evening.  The special chocolate ice cream with orange olive oil and Himalayan salt was absolute heaven.  That should be a regular on the menu!
author: Shannon K.

description: Cute little place... love the out door patio.. definitely don't agree on my bill but hey... the shrimp and grits had a weird taste and not worth $24 dollars... greens didn't have enough seasoning. Mac and cheese was a little too cheesy.
author: Kaylie P.

description:
A great, reliable purveyor of southern food. 

I've only dined in the restaurant once but have had takeout multiple times (for dinner only). My go-to order is fried chicken; their fried chicken is great - crunchy fry on the outside and juicy and tender on the inside. The mashed potatoes and gravy that come with the fried chicken are good also. My next favorite order is ordering sides - gumbo and mac and cheese - because very few people want to order entrees and sides, Those two sides make for a hearty meal, and I really enjoy the gumbo - lots of great flavor, a hint of smoke and spicy richness. 

Of course, they carry Abita beer which is a must.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Very upset with my experience here! 

1st I ordered the shrimp and grits. It had marinara sauce all over it, eww..nothing like the pictures here on yelp! 

 2nd I ordered the greens. They were ok the best thing that i ordered here. But for some reason they brought out the greens before the rest of the food like why would you do that I like to eat my greens with my food.

3rd I ordered the chicken and waffles. The chicken was whatever I wouldn't recommend it and the waffles were good would have been better if they weren't cold 

4th the Mac and cheese. Where do I start... It came out cold, and the texture wasn't the best I just over all didn't like it only took maybe 3 bites at the most.

Overall it was a waist of my time and money over prices and all my food had something wrong with it... 4 out of 5 items I ordered were cold I will never be coming back and I will be telling all my friends as well
author: Vanessa R.

description: This place was amazing! The menu had classic soul food and chill staff. I split the deviled eggs and fried pickles for an appetizer ( the fried pickles are a must) and the fried chicken and the pork roast entrees. So yummy, flavors were perfect. Cocktails were delicious too!
author: Alyssa M.

description:
My husband is a big Triple D fan, so when we travel we try and check out some of the spots, Front Porch being one of them. I made a reservation on a Friday night for us and 2 of our friends.  Even with a reservation we had to wait a bit for our table, but were seated within 15 minutes. Once we were seated inside, we were ready to grub! We ordered the fried okra to start, a side of the mac n'cheese, side of collards, biscuits, dr. pepper braised short ribs, and a bucket of fried chicken. Our favorites of the night were the biscuits and the mac n'cheese. The fried okra was good but didn't have too much flavor, same with the fried chicken. Also the food took 45 minutes to be served, which seems like an awful long time.  The bill for the 4 of us ended up being over $150 (including 1 beer each), so for that price, wished the food was a bit more memorable. 

Food - * * *
Price - * *
Ambiance - * * *
Service - * * *
author: Jess K.

description:
While sitting on The Front Porch in the movie Friday...

Pastor Clever (Bernie Mac) [at Smokey] Excuse me brother, what we call drugs at the 74th Street Baptist Church we call sinny sin sins. 

Smokey (Chris Tucker): Well round here, between Normandie and Western, we call this here a little twenty twen twen... 

Craig Jones (Ice Cube): Right... Here's a clip:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pkpGBiSck20&feature=youtube_gdata_player

(The Front Porch)
Excuse me Brother, but what we call The Front Porch right here on 29th Street is a Diny Din Din..

I ate here the other night with my Frienny Frien Friend.  Walking in, I liked the theme/idea.  Many times I have wished to live in an area like the south or east coast where I could sit in the front porch of the house for hours playing cards, messing with everybody who passes by, and having dinner.  

But when coming to eat at The Front Porch the other evening, unfortunately it was too cold to eat outside so we had to go inside to eat.

I really liked the simple options of southern style dishes.  Fried Green Tomatoes, Blue Crab Fritters, and Fried Okra all sounded great.  But here's what I ordered:

Fried Chicken Bucket with collard greens and mashed potatoes:  Some of the best fried chicken I've had in a long time.  Moist on the inside, crisp on the outside, and seasoned nice.  Delicious and perfect left over food to take home.  Mashed potatoes were creamy and buttery.


Blacken Salmon with a hush puppy and jambalaya:  I like blacken fish but I'm not sure if it's the style of cooking or just here but it was a little dry.  Still good combined with the moist jambalaya. But this entree didn't blow me away or anything.

The service was decent and really friendly.  Average hipster style crowd.  
Ambience is definitely on the dark side (Anakin).
(In Lil Wayne-ish style).  The Front Porch gets four stars with ease.  Serving that food from where that quarterback play. (Drew Brees).
author: Michael L.

description:
Interesting place.

Was recommended by a coworker to come here for their fried chicken. 
Fried chicken was good, juicy and flavor was all the way through. I didn't like their collard greens though, not sure why but it was not my thing. 

Also tried the fried pickels which were good, but after so many they get too sour. Probably better shared with more than 2 people.

The crawfish etouffee was good too.

I had a 'lovely day' and really liked it. well balanced drink.

Service was good. They get pretty busy, but we walked in and they tried to accomodate us by giving us a table for an hour. Which they (i think) rushed the food out for us. Which I didn't mind because i was HUNGRY! lol so yay.
author: Erica L.

description:
I hate when people say "let me preface this review by saying....", but let me preface this review by saying I was born and raised in South Carolina, my dad grew up on a farm, and my grandma would fry the hell out of some chicken and okra.  So, I'm not teling you that I am an expert in the field of southern cookin' (but I'm an expert in the field of southern cookin').

1.The mac and cheese is the closest thing to real southern mac n' cheese that I have found (aside from the dinner table during thanksgiving)
2. The fried okra is DELICIOUS (it just happens to be my favorite food).
3.  I don't order a meal, just the mac n cheese and fried okra, because who wouldn't want just that???
4. I have tried the fried chicken, the greens, the holy shit burger (or whatever it's called), the french fries, the bacon-wrapped dates, and probably 8 other things- all yummy
5. Portions are big...you will leave full.
6. The decor is really cozy, but the place is small, so make reservations
7. Staff is friendly
8.  While you're being fat, Mithcell's ice cream is conveniently a block away, and still tasty enough to enjoy after stuffing your face at the Front Porch

Enjoy!
author: Brooke M.

description: So good! The shrimp and grits is amazing! Boyfriend had the fried chicken and we shared the Mac n cheese. Everything was delicious!! Yummmm!
author: Nawal W.

description: Low key hole in the wall great spot. Food was great, drinks were good. Brunch was top shelf. If you're looking for a brunch spot look no longer...
author: Nathan R.

description:
The food wasn't bad, but I definitely was not blown away. As a college student, this was also overpriced. 

My friends and I stuck with some basics for our main meal (Bucket of Fried Chicken, Fried Corn, Baked Mac and Cheese, Biscuits). We also got friend okra and friend green tomatoes; yeah, a lot of fried. The stand out was the fried green tomatoes, definitely down with those, and followed by the fried corn. The Fried Chicken and biscuits were basic. The mac and cheese was so greasy though that may be expected, but it was really under-seasoned.

The ambiance is chill and the waiters/waitresses were ok, but not good enough to make the food better.

Honestly, unless I was making a decent income, I wouldn't be drawn to come back. I expected much more.
author: Valerie Z.

description: Truly an amazing place. Food, ambiance, service. it has everything PLUS a great selection of premium brews and a slamming blood mary! Get there early, relax and loosen the belt buckle kids!
author: A. H.

description:
Good fried chicken, possibly the best I've had in the SF Bay Area.  It is juicy and crunchy with a marinade that gives the chicken a nice flavor.

The sides are pretty good, too.  The Beans and rice have a bit of a spiciness.  The mashed potatoes are ok, not very flavorful but they are made from actual potatoes as evidenced by a few lumps in the finished product.

The biscuits are just ok, my Oklahoma grandmother would definitely not serve these biscuits from her kitchen.  They are a bit dry and dense instead of airy and moist like a good biscuit should be.

The 4 stars is graded on a curve against other Bay Area chicken purveyors.  When graded against true southern cooking from a chicken shack in a place like Georgia or Texas, The Front Porch would be lucky to get 3 stars.
author: Lance W.

description: Delicious chicken wings and fried okras!! Very authentic and most fried chicken. Excellent alternative to Brenda's French Soul Food (if you really crave good fried chicken but don't want to wait 45+ minutes).
author: Betty T.

description:
I was craving fried chicken and was excited to try this place with all the awesome reviews. The chicken came out super oily and when i took a bite out of it, the batter fell right off to reveal boiled chicken skin with a lot of little feathers sticking out - I think that this chicken is boiled or steamed beforehand and then deep-fried later to make it seem fresh - it looked fresh and delicious but it wasn't. There was also a lot of batter and it wasn't fully cooked at the bottom so it proved my theory even further. 

The extra star is for the ambiance of the place - really cute and the rocking chairs are a plus but none of the food we ordered was worth coming back for.
author: Alex M.

description:
I can drink booze on a front porch with a blanket, eating beignets and watching people pass on the street? Why had I never been here before?!

The cocktails are absolutely awesome. We ordered small plates and everything we ate was great! The service was excellent despite being busy: the owner was even walking around greeting people and taking drink orders.

I'd recommend this place to anyone!
author: Lauren A.

description:
The Front Porch is a no-frills, super casual comfort food restaurant. That casual nature translates in both great and not-so-great ways.

We arrived a bit early for an 8pm reservation. Our party was in full attendance (five of us in total), but we didn't sit until about 8:20pm. The staff at the front was courteous but seemed a bit detached while we waited. 

When we did sit, they put us at a four-person booth with a chair shoehorned onto the end of the table. Not a cozy set up, so I'd be wary of comfort if you're thinking about dining here with a five-person party. The service was attentive but not particularly personable. Others referenced "southern charm" with their dining experiences; for us... meh, not so much.

The food was quite good. We ordered the Fried Okra and Crawfish Hush Puppies as apps, and I had the Shrimp and Grits for a main. The apps were good, but nothing to write home about. I really enjoyed the Shrimp and Grits, and would recommend that to folks dining here. I also tried my SO's Farmer's Vegan entree, which was quite delicious, too.

Price-wise, I think The Front Porch offers good value for what you get. Multiple bottles of wine, cocktails, appetizers, entrees, and a couple desserts set us back $60 per person with tip. Not too shabby for a Friday night in SF, if you ask me.
author: Matt T.

description:
Have the Fried Chicken, they are so good! crunchy on the outside and moist and seasoned on the inside. It takes longer as they battered and fried on order. 

We share the Chicken Gumbo; warm spicy with habernero peppers and loads of okra and sausage, the base is a nice consistency and not water down like some other places. 

Chicken Plate dinner comes with 4 pieces of chicken, mashed potatoes with gravy and sauté bacon collard greens. 

We also ordered a side of baked Mac n cheese, nice crunchy cheesy  top but they did not have any flavor on the elbow macaroni once you eat all the cheesy goodness on top.

We finished up with the Banana Foster Upside Down Cake with brown Butter Caramel and Mitchell's Vanilla Ice cream.  It is very dense but not overly sweet.

Decor is ecletic with several rocking chairs if you choose to sit outside.

Bathroom is one stall for ladies and one for gents, right pass the kitchen.

We parked on Delores street around the corner and there are also metered parking in front, it also is closed to the driveway up to Safeway but not sure if it's safe for your car if you park there.
author: Sarah W.

description:
We really like this place. They are totally militant about what time the kitchen opens though, like, to the minute!

The ambiance is what we like. We usually sit outside. The rocking chairs are nice but not the most comfortable. The heaters are good. The cocktails are also good. The tables are teeny tiny. They sell bottles of hot sauce for $8. 

The fried okra is okay. The mashed potatoes are delish and the fried chicken is really good. We sometimes get a bucket and bring it home. We have not yet tried the dessert because we are always stuffed. I'm not a fan of the collard greens.
author: Chanel B.

description: Sunday brunch was amazing. Don't forget to make reservations or you'll have quite a wait, but it's worth it.
author: Mari L.

description:
You know what I love most about San Francisco, it's the people! Every where you go, they're just friendly and down to earth. 

My boyfriend's cousin lives in SF, so we were lucky to have him take us around all the good eats! And this was one of the spots. 

I ordered the mac n cheese and boyyyyy was it the best I've EVER had. As for my main course, I had the grilled hanger steak! OMG, it was filling, but I finished EVERYTHING. 

I have never had Cajun/Creole food, and let me tell you, I'm glad I had it here! :)
author: Sheree Y.

description:
Dark inside, but super cute place in Bernal Heights overflowing with people waiting on the weekends for brunch. Great menu ("Beer-unch") with starters for brunch (fried okra, but they ran out of gumbo!), favorites and main courses (although the difference has stymied me a little), and of course, drinks.  

Sweet tea is deliciously refreshing, made with simple syrup, and served in a classic cheapo Chinese teapot for my friend who is addicted to sweat tea, and needs the free refills.  Bloody mary is ok -- could have used more flavor, although the optional bacon bits rimmed around the edge of the glass is a nice touch.  

The fried okra was crisply fried and served with a mysterious but yummy sauce.  It was ok.  Shrimp and grits was ok.  Country fried steak was ok, although a little chewy, and a little tough.  All in all, it was *ok.*  It wasn't memorable, and probably not worth my trek across town (which I was super late for, but that is another story).  If you want memorable shrimp and grits, go to Brenda's in the TL, and if you want memorable country fried steak, go to Hard Knox.  

BUT, they did serve *perfect* sunny side up eggs.  Perfectly round, perfectly intact yolk, perfectly cooked.  Did I mention perfect?  I was duly impressed.  It's difficult to make perfect eggs!
author: Shirley Y.

description:
$18 for 3 pieces of fried chiggen? No thanks.

FUCKET IT, GET A BUCKET

and that's what us 4 ladies did. 

Get a bucket of fried chicken, it's more bang for your buck and you'll be thankful you did. Perfectly crispy and juicy, finger lookin good - the way fried chicken is supposed to be.

If you're a veggie lover (like me) DO order a side of collard greens - great zing from the balsamic vinegar. DO order the fried okra because it's tasty as hell. Crispy and lightly salted. 

DO NOT get the Frito Pie. This you can skip. It was lacking in all departments.

DO get the mac n cheese if you're a cheesy laden carb lover. 

And then do go across the street and grab some Mitchell's.
author: Susy C.

description: This place gets one star simply because of that fact that it will not let me leave ZERO. The service at this establishment was absolutely horrible. Never in my life have I received such bad service. From start to finish this place was pitiful. We waited about an hour before getting seated while other parties, who showed up after us, made their way in. As we were seated we were crammed in a tiny booth and were only attended to once our whole visit. The food was mediocre and if you're used to the traditional chicken and waffles then I suggest you stay away from theirs, it's for better words GROSS. Avoid the tall blonde waitress she was totally unprofessional and extremely rude. This place gets an absolute ZERO. I will never go back and if you value good service and food to match, stay away from this place.
author: Andrew F.

description:
Overall not a bad experience.   

Food was decent but not something i would get excited about or recommend as a must try.   Chicken was cooked perfectly, but the crust was not as crisp as I had hoped.  It was very garlicy and too the point it changed the flavor of the chicken to a bit sour tasting.  Very odd.   The greens were also a bit sour tasting but decent.   I prefer a little sweeter and buttery southern style greens.  

Cornbread was ok. Too small portions.  It's cornbread.  They should offer big piping hot pieces. Not literally one bite samples.  

Mashed potatoes and gravy were meh.  Nothing special here.  Gravy was greasy and bland.  Should have had a bit more salt to add pop to the potatoes.  Instead both were bland and i didn't finish eating it. 

Oxtail fries were good. Except they put only one piece of oxtail in the fries.  The rest was gravy covered fries.   

Service was excellent.  Offered bar seating and was fine with that.  Weekends you better reserve or expect to wait.  Was asked multiple times how were doing and how was the food.  

Value is good.  Price is right on point on what you get.  

It's a decent place.   If you are in the area, give it a try.
author: Tim F.

description: OMG, if I lived in S.F. I might come here every week or  damn near. Everything we had was remarkable with soul oozing out of the pores . . . the fried chicken was everything I've ever dreamed of: crispy but not greasy, not too dark or scorched, golden brown with those collard greens I could eat by the bucketful--tangy and smoky. The mashed potatoes with a ladle of gravy I could a trough of easily. And gravy is an iffy thing with so many people not knowing how to get the texture thick but not clumpy, but these people have the talent of gravy I shall say. The biscuits I all but inhaled; even my husband who's not a biscuit fan (I know, who doesn't love biscuits, right?), loved them. We got a bunch of sides and also the meatloaf which is my weakness. Such a charming place, a little house, a ton of attitude and a vibe of hippie rockster. It was packed, even though we showed up at the opening dinner hour, and it was deafening. I mean loud beyond anything, to the point we couldn't hear anything. It was literally an eat an run expedition for us. Though I love this place so much, it'll be a while before we go back, only for the noise level. Did I mention the service was outstanding--super casual and friendly and the prices awesomely reasonable. If you can handle noise and love soul food/fried chicken, you won't regret it.
author: Ranjan P.

description:
I've been here before and always had a good experience - tasty food, unique ambience. But I came for brunch with a friend a few weeks ago and won't be going back again. 

We'd made a reservation about a week in advance, but when we arrived on time, we were told we would have to wait for the other people who had reservations who arrived before us. Okay, fine. The wait didn't end up being that long and we got an outside table. 

I ordered some kind of egg platter, and asked if I could make a substitution for the meat since I'm vegetarian. The server said I could sub fruit, so I did. She didn't mention there would be an up-charge; that was just a surprise I got when the bill arrived. 

For the most part the food was very good. But the main part of the dish, the scrambled eggs, arrived in a literal pool of oil. They were swimming in grease. I tried a few bites but they were just too greasy to eat. So I ate everything else but had barely touched the eggs. When another server came to collect our dishes, he didn't ask if anything was wrong despite the fact that most of my meal was still on my plate. 

We got the check, and as we were signing our bills, a string of lights fell down on me, with one of the bulbs smacking the back of my head. It hurt a bit, but mostly was just very startling. The waitress was just coming out, and we explained what happened (with the string of lights still dangling in between us) and she went back in to get the owner. He came out and sort of halfheartedly apologized. (It turned out the lights were very haphazardly attached to the fence with twist ties, which was clearly no match for a windy Bernal morning.) As he re-attached the lights to the twist tie, he offered us a round of free drinks, but we were already paid and planning to leave. He did not offer to comp any part of our meal, or even offer a free meal in the future. Not that it would have mattered, as I won't be returning.
author: K M.

description:
It's rare to find a Southern/Cajun restaurant in the city that takes reservations and doesn't require building in a lengthy wait time to your experience. The staff at The Front Porch were very accommodating when I called, and even changed my reservation time when I couldn't make the original time.

The place itself is super cozy and well-decorated, and the wait staff made us feel right at home as soon as we got inside.

And of course the most important part - the food. The shrimp and grits were absolutely amazing. Big, juicy shrimp, perfectly seasoned pieces of sausage. I'm usually not a fan of grits; don't enjoy the texture, but they were perfect here. Definitely my favorite part of the meal. We also got the crawfish hush puppies, which were quite tasty. My friend and I shared the four piece fried chicken as well. It was pretty good, but I will say the chicken was a bit dry. We were pretty stuffed at this point, but decided on an order of beignets as well. These were a bit disappointing, unfortunately. They weren't bad, but I've definitely had better elsewhere.

Overall though, I definitely enjoyed my experience. Tasty food, good service, and a fun atmosphere. Would recommend to anyone, and definitely try the shrimp and grits!
author: Nune M.

description:
They really try to emulate a homely front porch. They pretty much pull it off with their inviting exterior and fun interior design/decor. Our server was very knowledgeable about everything on the menu and she did that thing all servers do at soul food restaurants, memorize your order no matter how many people are at the table. When did that become a thing?

Anyway, to note, 2 things you should definitely order here are:
1) bucket o' chicken 10 piece
2) baked mac & cheese
The mashed potatoes were also pretty dang good. You really can't go wrong with anything here since everything is cooked/ried to perfection.

I might come back here after I try a bunch of other soul food places in SF like Farmerbrown in downtown. However, if you are in this part of the city, it's a great choice for dinner and you can go to the famous Mitchell's for ice cream afterwards since it's about a walkable block away.
author: Marlon T.

description:
Amazing staff and you definitely get a front porch feel (of Auntie's house in the South) with a louder crowd and oldies playing in the background!  While the menu and restaurant is small it is full of big taste and character. Plus, the water is served in 40 ounce bottles. When was the last time you had a 40 ;) 

Friends and I gathered here for a birthday. They take reservations which is seemingly becoming a rarity for small popular restaurants. Not all of us arrived at the same time but they allowed us to check in then go "outside" (actually, across the street to the bar) while we waited for the rest of our party. Considering the petite size of the restaurant I thought that was kind. There were 10 of us so we had the pleasure of sitting in a corner booth with a huge round table, perfect considering all the food we ordered and tabletop space we needed! 

Consensus was 2 thumbs up on the drinks ordered (Porch swing, jalapeno margarita, porch light, lovely day). I ordered the Porch light: Texas vodka, luxardo maraschino, Campari, pineapple - delicious! If I hadn't been driving back to the East Bay after dinner I would have had more than one of this delight. 

My friends raved about their entrees and appetizers. I tasted the following: 
-Winter wedge salad: It was a nice crispy salad made up of 2 good sized wedges. 
-Baked Mac n cheese: MUST TRY! Cheesy mac served hot in a skillet and crusted on top! 
-Jalapeno deviled eggs cost: Humorously cost 6.66 . So good my friends and I are attempting them at our next function!
-Gumbo: More spicy than salty (as described perfectly by my friend) and even though it is listed an appetizer it's actually a good size for an entree. 

Desserts! KICK ASS GOOD! 
Apple crisp: Served like a pot pie with ice cream on top. Sweet, spicy, hot, good texture! 
Butterscotch cheesecake: I didn't try this but a friend at the table apparently "made love to it"
Chocolate trifle: Served in a larger shot glass. Layers of chocolate and cake. 
Brioche bread pudding: My favorite! A large portion served. 

By the end of the night as we were handling the cash and cards at our table, the server came to us and said unsolicited "Let me know what you guys want to do... I can do anything" Again smaller places usually aren't so accommodating and I know how annoying it is for large parties and splitting bills... she was very sweet and flexible. 

I would have rated this place 5 stars except the only chicken they offer is fried. I am not a friend chicken person ... but for being a fried chicken restaurant I had no problems enjoying everything else the restaurant offered!
author: Krystal A.

description: Last minute out of town guests wanting to go to dinner in SF.. the pressure to impress!    Three days later they are still talking about the food!
author: J C.

description: The place is cute, food is mediocre, and i came home with 3 huge bug bites!! So gross!! That's all I have to say about this place. #fumigate - I would not even put one star if Yelp would let me.
author: Melissa C.

description:
A friend of mine has been raving about this place and I finally decided to drag my foodie companion to give it a try. 

Parking was pretty easy on a Thursday evening. 

We didn't have a reservation, the place was packed, but they managed to fit us in as long as we were done in about an hour as they had full reservations for that time.

The decor was interesting, nothing jumped out at me too much.

Wine and Beer only despite the rather large bar taking up a lot of room in the establishment. 

Blue Grab Fritters were YUM, soft, stuffed full of crab.

Shrimp w/ Grits had great flavor and spice, we really enjoyed the many textures that came along with this dish. 

Jambalaya was interesting, normally it is served chopped up and mixed together, but this was more constructed, the fish and sausage where served whole on a bed of yummy rice with a Crawfish Hushpuppy. It tasted really good but I felt it was lacking spice. 

Over all, yea, I would totally go here again to try some of their foods!

Service was friendly, attentive and polite.
author: Meghan L.

description: I've heard good things about this place so I had to try it. Made a reservation through Yelp. Small but quaint playing some 90's jams. Hostess was nice. We waited a few minutes then was seated inside. Menu options were good, server wasn't the friendliest, file gumbo is okra based so it's not very good. However the main dishes are delicious!!!
author: Shawna J.

description:
My wife and I heard about this place and just had to go and get some fried chicken.  We weren't disappointed.  They had a little wait, but we got there around 5pm on a warm Saturday and we ate at the bar.  Service was great, but the food and drinks here really shined.  We had the ham hock collard greens, mac and cheese, and the bucket of fried chicken, 10 glorious pieces of goodness.

First time here, we will be back.  And two drinks recommended that we never tried, Tobermory Whiskey 10yr and Baba Black Lager.  Excellent!  Street parking only, but it wasn't too bad at all on San Jose Avenue.  And for dessert, wander down the block to Mitchell's ice cream.
author: Gerry T.

description:
I really did not like much of ANYTHING about The Front Porch and neither did the rest of my party, although one of them ordered the burger and said it was pretty good.  And the jalapeno aioli that came with the fried okra was good, not the fried okra though.  OK so let me start at the beginning.  

We show up on Sunday afternoon around 12:45.  I tell the host that we had 3 and he asked me in a semi-horrified manner if we had a reservation.  I told him no and he said "Ok well I'll be able to get you in in about 20-30 minutes.  *looks around* actually probably sooner, is your whole party here?"  (I was totally confused as to why he acted like I was inside for showing up with no reservation then said it would be 20 minutes, I digress) I told him yes and went out front to wait with my girlfriends.  About 30-40 minutes later I checked in with him and he looked at me like it had been 30 seconds and shrugged and said "uhh Idunno maybe like 20 minutes or so?" um. what?  20 minutes later my pregnant friend (hungry, uncomfortable, swollen feet, read: watch out) went in to ask again and he told her with a great deal of snide attitude that we were next and it would be a few minutes.  About 10 minutes later we were called in.  Note that everybody waiting for a table was extremely pissed off and were in the same boat as us, INCLUDING people who had made reservations.     

We sat down and you know that kind of server who comes over and doesn't introduce themselves and just like puts waters down and just kind of acts like you come in 3 times a day and no greeting is even necessary?  i don't know if I described that correctly but its not like a familiar friendly attitude its like an obnoxious lazy can't be bothered way too cool attitude.  So she does that.  I don't know her name but I think she had an English accent.  Hard to say since she barely talked to us.  She barely ever came to the table and when she did she rushed us and was not friendly.  I ordered a Bloody Mary and it was the worst one I have ever had, it just had a really strange flavor I can't even really describe what it was, it was bitter and just strange.  Later I got a Lovely Day cocktail and it was pretty gross too, really cheap gin and really abrasive other flavors, do not recommend.  My girlfriend ordered a lemonade and she had to add sugar to it at the table, I totally didn't think I would agree but I tasted it pre-sugar and it was just lemon water (and they charge $3.50 each with no refills, really steep for lemon water).  

The fried okra tasted like it used those breadcrumbs from a canister and a lot of seasoning packet.  The jalapeño aioli was awesome and I'd eat a shoe dipped in that.  If I were to go again I would get an order of fries and a side of that aioli and call it a day.  The chicken and waffles was gross- the chicken was overly salty and I assume it is brined and whatever was in the brine just made the meat taste really strange, again I'm sorry that is not descriptive, it was just weird.  The worst part was the waffle, it was soggy and had gross chewy pieces of bacon studded in it just creating more saltiness.  It was a quite small portion and I hardly finished half.  Oh and its $18!! Where do these people get off?!?!?! The prices are INSANE!!! $50 per person for brunch.  

My friend got the shrimp and grits and it was OFF THE HOOK,  I only had one bite and maybe I was extremely hungry and disappointed by my own food but my memory is that it was awesome.  Recommend.  BUT, then again, shrimp and grits is sorta hard to fuck up.  Well maybe its not hard to fuck up but its also easy to get right.  

The server never came by to see how we were or ask if we wanted anything else, which we did, we wanted more cocktails the whole time.  She finally came by and put the check on the table and I had to ask if we could add to it and get more drinks.  Find a new line of work lady.  

If you want mediocre at best food, a rude host who is either lying to keep business or is just also really bad at his job, overpriced bad drinks using cheap well liquor all served to you by a person who is bothered by you and took cool for serving tables, come to Front Porch.  You can listed to gangster rap and use mismatched mugs, AKA hipster heaven.
author: Emma H.

description: My 1st time here and I have to say I'll be back whenever I'm in the city. Wonderful food and great service along with an unexpected location and eclectic decor. I highly recommend this place. Amazing craft cocktails and and extensive wine and beer lists make this a must visit if you are in SF's Mission District.
author: Linda R.

description:
The Front Porch is this quaint hole in the wall near 29th and Mission St in the City.  The facade has rocking chairs and a tacky hillbilliesque like decor that looks like something out of an early John Waters movie. The inside, dark, refreshing and retro looking almost as if it had once been a night club back in the day.

The food here is pretty good, but it needs a little bit of improvement.  I mean, given the cost, which'll have yah hung at the gallows at around $30/person,  you better get some southern food that tastes of Southern Lovin'.  I have to admit, "expensive southern cuisine" seemed a bit of an oxymoron to me.  I guess, in terms of SF money, $30/head is considered cheap.

And the service should have that Southern lovin' vibe too.  But that wasn't the case.

Warning: A rant: and a bit of an anti-social SF editorial (keep in mind I came to this place with high expectations and had a strong craving for both southern cuisine and Southern Hospitality):

Service was typical "cool" "avante garde" SF.  I hate to ding this place, but when I go to the south, there's a special feeling that I'm welcome home.  In SF, there's always a feeling in establishments that one is a) not good enough; b) below their standards...you know that snob, uptight vibe.  That's just how San Franciscans are.  If you get that typical SF service in a restaurant that purports to be a Southern Restaurant, it completely ruins the vibe, and quite honestly, shits on the spirit of Southern Hospitality.

Also, when I go into a "southern establishment" I expect something more than just cliches.  I expect music and references to be true south.  I didn't get that here.  Case in point, the music played was Guns'n'Roses and AC DC.  That's not southern music.  I expect bands to be obscure country bands from the Appalachian Mountains or something other than "Sweet Child 'o Mine."

Now that I vented my frustrations about the culturally wreckifcation of the south, I think I can go more on the quality of the food.

It was good but not rootin' tootin' good.

For starters, there was a complimentary appetizer, albeit, a joke of one at that: a tiny serving of a miniature corn bread muffin about the size of my thumb.  At first, I thought it was a joke and was looking for cameras.  It was like a crumb.  When you have two 200lb men sitting down at an establishment purported to be Southern Cooking, you don't give nothing less than a pound of corn bread.  I was flabbergasted by how small the serving size was.

After that, we had something that was fries and a crawfish sauce or something like that.  It was pretty tasty.  For add'l appetizers, I stumbled upon a perfect example of the bastardization of a culture: fried pickles and.......get this: aioli sauce?  WTF?  In the south?  Aioli is some snobby San Franciscan sauce made because it ain't cool to say ketchup and mayo with a dash of cayenne pepper and herbs.

I guarantee that in the South, Aioli ain't even a word.

Still, although I liked it, it tarnished my perception of what this place was trying to do.  What next? Apple Pie with nonfat soy ice cream a la mode?

Annoying.  All in all, the fried pickles were good, but not in a "thanks for the nostalgia and taking me back to Nashville sense.

For the final dish, I had fried chicken, potatos, and collard greens.  The fried chicken dish, four excellent pieces, was very good.  BUT, I am suspicious that they simply drove to a Church's Chicken on Geneva Ave. bought a bucket for 8 pieces for $10, and drove right back, placed on a plat and charged us $18/head for the meal.

I mean, it's scientifically not possible to muck up fried chicken.

As for the collard greens, I had deep psychological issues. For they tasted papery.  Not enough love was put in putting 'em together.

All in all, if you're from the Bay Area, and you want true Southern Cuisine, don't come here.  If you come without that expectation, this place can get a bump up to 4 stars.  There is some quality here.  But if you're looking for a southern experience,  you'll be disappointed.

The place is good.  But not a home run.  I'm giving this 3 stars because if I had a desperate craving for fried chicken, and I was driving by here, I'd probably come in and take a seat.  So, if you're not too high strung, like I am, about what a restaurant experience should be, do not worry about what I've written here, you'll probably have a good time.
author: Tony U.

description:
Really, really yummy!! Love these kinds of places!  Fried chicken was the best !  Eggs were amazing!  Desserts were fantastic !  Got seated right away too. Why 4 stars?  Service was a little spotty but still very nice. Rating should be 4.5 stars. 

Looking forward to going back here and trying new things. Except those eggs, I gotta have those eggs!!
author: Debi S.

description:
It's a small place but full of character.
We had a party of 10 but we had good service and were placed in a comfortable spot.
The Mac and Cheese, served in a hot skillet, is really good.
We also had the 10 piece chicken as a main course.  Along with the mac and cheese, our sides were mashed potatoes, biscuits, cornbread, and collared greens.  
For us, this was enough. 
Parking isn't that bad since this place isn't located in a touristy area which makes it EVEN BETTER!
author: Marie T.

description:
Me Likie!  Delicious Southern comfort food with an adorable atmosphere.  Fried chicken was crispy and flavorful on the outside and ridiculously juicy and delicious on the inside, the fried okra was tasty, shrimp and grits were also awesome and the fish! Mmmmmmmmm has me dreaming of San Francisco for sure!

Reasonably priced too, can't wait to come back!
author: Annie H.

description:
making reservation via Yelp was easy.  the service (host&servers) friendly.  food and drinks delish.  forgot my cell phone there after dinner.  came back for it and the host saved it.  remembered who and where I sat.  handed me the phone.

genuinely good service.

thanks
author: m t.

description: Really enjoyed our dinner at the Front Porch! I have spent some time in the South and I have to say that the food at Front Porch is seriously legit! I had the Fried Chicken with collard greens and it was cooked to perfection with a flavorful spice (without being too spicy). The atmosphere is very cozy, casual, romantic and warm. We were a bigger group with kids and the wait staff was very attentive. I could also see this place as a good date night as well. They have a full bar too!
author: Dylan K.

description: Great restaurant! Vibe, food taste, the only thing I'd say could improve is the cornbread size. But that's me nitpicking.
author: Heron R.

description: Don't get the hype.  Soggy collard greens (how dare they), burnt fried chicken, mushy mash.  And they had a jerk chicken on the menu that would offend a Jamaican...
author: Kamael S.

description: The Chicken is pricey- but oh so worth it! Mash potatoes and gravy and a new take to the classes margarita just makes me too happy. The lovely waitress Christine help my group out and made great recommendations. Will be here again!
author: Jane D.

description:
I dropped the leftovers right when I reached my car and it was literally a travesty. Yes literally. I saw my dates eyes and saw a look I'd never want to see again... Just utter pain and remorse. She must've asked herself "wtf why am I here? Why did I let this useless fried chicken wing dropping sob take me out to dinner." I can't even comment on the food because it just brings back terrible flashbacks. I think I have ptsd.


Ps. Rip chicken wing and macaroni and cheese I dropped.
author: William L.

description:
I love the Front Porch, I haven't been there for couple of years.
The "Soul Food" OMG!!!! Everything very delicious, you will over eat.
My fav side dish is the Deep Fried Okra ( in batter )
The owner is so friendly and she will come to your table and greet you!!!
Customer service is great too
author: Rosangela B.

description: As others have mentioned, it's dark in there. The decor is consciously low brow. Seats along the wall in back are from a passenger van, complete with seat belts. The fried chicken is very good and the collard greens side is just plain awesome.  It is not at all chopped into tiny fragments, which is nice.
author: Herb L.

description:
Intrigued to try this place because of all the hype. Maybe we should have tried their brunch as most of the reviews I've read rave about it. We went on a Friday night and I was disappointed that they have a different menu for dinner (craving for chicken and waffles). Nevertheless, we shared a 4-pc chicken order ($18.50), which came with mashed potato and collard greens. Added the $8 mac and cheese.
Chicken and mashed potato-2/5; Collard greens-0/5
Mac and cheese 3.5/5

Service and bar was good but the food was just okay.
author: Michaella A.

description:
