Here's the thing: I don't eat mac & cheese that often, but when I do, every single tryst of this Southern comfort food always leaves a memorable mark in my cranial nerves.  In this dinner, oh my YUM...cheesy without being too sharp or reticent, with some strings attached *hint hint* from the baked pasta, I'd give it a peerless 5.0 if the elbows were less soft.  Deng, now I gotta find an emulation of this in So Cal! x/

...And the most prominent display of the porch was...

-Bucket of Fried Chicken, Garlic Mashers w/ Gravy & Collard Greens w/ Bacon ($34)-
Ummm, $34 for 10 of those cluckers?!  Popcorn--err, Rocky Jr.--Chicken 50x the size of normal, this fried meatiness was relevantly executed in a theatre popcorn bucket.  I generally prefer burgers to fried chicken, but no matter if it's drumstick or thigh, the consistently succulent meat & crispy skin were enigmatically delicious for using seemingly simple ingredients to build this edible masterpiece.  With the very creamy, slightly mushy yet tasty mashed potatoes & appetizing, baconized leaves alongside, the chicken has half a point, out of 5, taken off due to that price label (Think twice if you're actually considering getting 3 pieces for $17 ^_^).

All said & done, b/c of my unforeseen Yelp Bookmark I must come back to chill at The Front Porch for either brunch or for the noteworthy Beignets.  From the wow-inducing food, the required but appropriate 18% gratuity for our party of 8, & the bow-down patient & hospitable service from the redheaded Kidman doppelganger (i.e. Marcelle), it's 4 stars and nothing less, friends, and I wish you all a magnificent & fun-filled 2012 =D.
author: Fia R.

description:
Came here for a very special occasion. They had a specific menu for the holidays and everything we tried was absolutely delicious. The shrimp and grits was AMAAAAZING. I tried to replicate the recipe at home because it was so good, but it's nice when someone else makes it for you and serves it up piping hot. Also had their herb rolls which were better than your standard bread and butter. The mac n cheese was also scrumptious. I think I am obsessed with mac n cheese in general and I've tried many versions, but this one is up there in the top 5. 

The location BTW is great for going out for drinks if you like those hole in the wall bars. Bernal Heights is a neighborhood where you really get a sense of the niches of San Fran. I hope to be back in the neighborhood soon.
author: Manisha S.

description: Fried pickles and chicken is what makes this place sing.  It is a tough spot for groups - the largest I've ever been with is 11 and that was really tight.
author: Kimberly C.

description:
This place was a hoot. I felt like a grownup eating from an elementary school cafeteria tray. While drinking cocktails. Bit surreal, but totally delicious. 

We got a mess of fried chicken and peas and mashed potatoes and porch swings (cocktails). Only complaint was the 'taters were kind of cold. The chicken was scalding hot. Well done, cooks!

We had 6 folks and fit comfortably at our booth table. 

The good: legit food.
The bad: food was a bit slow, but chicken takes a while, so this is probably a positive.
author: Amanda B.

description: As a serious chicken & waffles addict, when I saw this place on DDD I knew I had to go. Booked a reservation for brunch yesterday and the only negative thing I can say is that I'm super bummed I hadn't heard of it years ago! The ambience is hella cute and homey, the coffee cups are a mish mash of cute quips, which I loved. The menu...where do I start... I love southern comfort food, so my family & I thought ordering a few things & splitting it all family style would be best. We started out with beignets, which were hot and chewy, and covered in powdered sugar - to the point where if i exhaled while taking a bite....POOF sugar everywhere! Next, the biscuits & gravy - de-LISH! there was a hint of garlic, and the biscuits were crispy, yet soft, and not doughy. We ordered shrimp & grits, with an extra side of grits, cuz my 9 year old daughter can put away some grits... the flavor of the shrimp was amazing, with just the right amount of spice. Last out was the chicken & waffles and i swear the plate was glowing while angels sang 'Hallelujah' The chicken was cooked perfectly, moist and delicious inside, and the perfect exterior crunchiness with an awesome cajun kick. The waffle had chunks of bacon in it and was also perfectly cooked. I highly recommend The Front Porch for a delicious brunch and/or dinner. We perused the dinner menu, and are very excited to go back and try more of the foods!
author: Amy B.

description: Great! I wanted to say just how accommodating the service is. I had some last minute additions to my reservations and they made it happen so we could be seated near each other, for which I was very grateful. Food was great - Mac and Cheese was delicious. Mashed Potatoes and Gravy Especially. Burger was A+, very minimal "plain" burger - but that was what made it great, you could just taste the quality of the meat so well without any disguise. Fried Chicken was a on the salty side, but moist.
author: Trini L.

description:
I went to the Front Porch on Saturday morning for brunch.  We canned to make a reservation and they pretty much just told us to come in at a certain time.  So basically you are calling to find out when they can fit you in.  Be prepared to wait a little bit even with a reservation.  But it is worth it and the serving sizes are great!

First we ordered the beignets. They were piping hot and delicious! Then for main courses we ordered the chicken and waffles,  the pork scramble and the stack.  Everything was awesome.  The fried chicken was so crispy on the outside but juicy on the inside.  The grits were amazing and not to cheesy.  We finished everything.  I regret not ordering the mac and cheese.  I will definitely have to go back to try it!  

The service was great as well considering that they are always crazy busy.
author: Nia R.

description:
I was watching Eye on the Bay about a week ago or so and they had a show about chicken.  The show featured several restaurants, one of which was The Front Porch and their fried chicken.  I was very intrigued.  I quickly grabbed my laptop and went on Yelp to search for it.  Once  found, I sent the link to my hubby.  I was expecting some type of comment like "Oh that sounds good" or something of the sort.  Instead, he totally surprised me by saying there was a 6P opening for dinner on Valentine's day.  Wow. I guess he really wanted to try it out, so glad we did!

We came in early and there were only 2 tables seated when we got in.  I was a bit bummed that we were seated in the booth directly across from the kitchen door. Each time the door opened I kept feeling a cold draft.  I knew I'd have to order a glass of wine to warm up.  As the restaurant filed up, I didn't notice the draft as much (or may be it was the wine?) I do have to point out that  I loved the welcoming feel and ambiance.  I love restaurants like this one!

I ordered the fried chicken and it did not disappoint!   It really lived up to the hype.  It was super yummy delicious. I couldn't stop eating it.   I would order it again and again. Best fried chicken dish I've ever ordered so far.   I did like the collard greens but I could take it or leave it on the mashed potatoes. A lot of it was left on my plate.  We totally loved the brussel sprouts! So glad the hubby ordered it. His entree was the shrimp and grits.  He polished the plate so I thought he really liked it, but he just told me the shrimp was a little over cooked.  At first we hesitated on ordering biscuits, but we decided to order it after we got our cornbread (we thought the cornbread portion would be bigger).  For dessert, we had the bread pudding, which was delightful.

All in all, we're definitely going back.  I think the food took a little longer than expected to come out, so we thought it was a little slow.  Other than that, we had a great time!
author: Dawn D.

description:
The front porch is like stepping into the comfort of someone's house. The mugs are mismatched, the lighting is low, the curtains are custom and the food taste like you're in New Orleans. The fried chicken was delicious, I didn't  know they sold buckets of it until we left. The gumbo was spicy, wooo wee. I was sweating for sure (spice level 6). 

Definitely going for the fried chicken!
author: Vicky H.

description:
Eh, it's ok. Pretty standard. The fried chicken, their signature item, was decent, but again, I think you can get the same quality at any decent restaurant that serves fried chicken. I wish it had more of a spicy kick to it, more flavor. 

Same with the Mac and cheese. It's decent, but nothing amazing.

I had the pineapple upside down cake with caramel and vanilla bean ice cream. Sounds good doesn't it. I usually love dessert, but only had a few bites of this one. 

They server Mitchell's ice cream product, but Mitchell's is literally across the street and open late. Why pay more when up could take a nice stroll in the pleasant evening weather to grab some Mitchell's across the street.
author: Ahmed A.

description:
This is my second visit and I don't recall having a memorable experience the first time I came here. My review is on my most recent visit.

We ordered: 

*Baked Mac & Cheese
*Fried Corn on the Cob with Lime-Chile Butter & Cotija
*Farmers Vegan
*Bucket O' Chicken 10 Piece
*Dr. Pepper Braised Beef Short Ribs - Celery root puree, grilled broccoli rabe,horseradish.
* Crawfish cakes

I enjoyed the mac & cheese, fried corn and the fried chicken. The other dishes were good but were missing something. I would come back for the dishes I enjoyed and possibly try other menu items. 

I found the prices to be a little steep for southern food. But with great company the price can be overlooked.
author: Kristina S.

description:
Firstly, the kind people at front porch were able to accompany my late reservation. Super cool of them!

The front porch is located on a block in bernal heights in a house like conversion. I've been dying to try soul food/Cajun so this seemed like the perfect spot. 

If you're going to order the four piece fried chicken, it'll be enough for two. Trust me!

The spicy shrimp and grits were the highlight of our meal. 

Definitely a cool unique date spot in sf.
author: Rachel T.

description:
On Saturday, 4/19/14, my girlfriend and I ate at The Front Porch for dinner. We had very high expectations after reading the majority of the positive reviews on yelp.

Atmosphere/Decor: 

The restaurant is pretty small. It's located by a Safeway shopping center. I can see how someone could literally drive by The Front Porch and not even know it exists. When we walked up to the restaurant, there were a few dining tables located in front of the main entrance. Having outside dining is definitely a good idea especially in the summer or on a nice sunny day. 

It's very dark inside the restaurant. There's a bar and enough seating for about 8 to 12 people. There were a few tables in the middle of the restaurant and dining booths. The restaurant is so small you can literally see the location of the kitchen and the bathrooms. Watch your step when you go to use the restroom. I almost tripped once I opened up the curtains to enter the restroom. You can easily stump your foot when you enter the restroom because there is a little curb that rises above the ground level. I felt like the Southern concept was off to me. I'm not from the South but the atmosphere/decor is kind of tacky. 

Food:

We started off with the baked mac and cheese. The mac and cheese was pretty good. My girlfriend liked it a lot. She said it was one of the better mac and cheeses shes had. I like it a lot as well but there was a little too much pepper. In my opinion mac and cheese isn't supposed to taste like pepper. 

I ordered the fried chicken for my main entree. I really didn't understand the red plastic eating tray. I mean who serves fried chicken, collard ham hog greens, mashed potatoes & gravy along with popcorn on a plastic eating tray? It reminded my of an elementary school eating tray. It was hard to eat the chicken because the tray spaces weren't that big. There was literally no room. The fried chicken was decent. I don't think it's one of the best fried chickens. The mashed potatoes and gravy were really good. The ham hog collard greens weren't good at all. And where the heck was the ham hogs? I didn't have a single piece of ham in my collard greens. I wonder why?  Maybe they forgot? Oh yeah, and what the heck is up with the popcorn? We're not at a carnival. This is a restaurant. I feel like the popcorn has no business being on that tray. Now if it were little deep fried chicken nuggets or little pieces of deep fried chicken shaped into a small ball, that would work. 

My girlfriend ordered the Dr. Pepper Short ribs. I got excited when I heard about a short rib being infused with Dr. Pepper! But it wasn't that good! Dang it!!! The taste was different. It was more like a pot roast then a short rib. Good short ribs are supposed to be super tender. The Dr. Pepper Short ribs were tender but not melt in your mouth tender. I couldn't really taste the Dr. Pepper either. My girlfriend pointed out that the whole meal tasted like collard greens. The collard greens were placed directly on top of the mashed potatoes then the Short rib was placed on top of the collard greens. My girlfriend was right, everything tasted like collard greens which wasn't a good thing. 

Service:

The service was good. What stood out to me the most about the service was every waiter and waitress seemed like a team player. There were a few times when our waiter was busy waiting on other tables and a waitress came by and filled up our water. She even took my credit card from me once our waiter dropped off the bill. 

Overall:

The Front Porch is a decent restaurant. If you want better fried chicken visit Wayfare Tavern. Tyler Florence definitely knows what he is doing when it comes to fried chicken. At Wayfare Tavern you also have the option of ordering all white meat chicken or mixed with dark meat. If you think these short ribs are good you should visit Lark Creek Steak and order the pre-fix pot roast dinner or go to Paragon. Paragon's pot roast blows The Front Porch's Dr. Pepper Short ribs out the water as well. It's very good! I don't see myself coming back to The Front Porch anytime soon, probably never again.
author: David R.

description:
It's been two days and still haven't finished digesting the chicken! 

On the other hand the deep fried okra and mac and cheese were superb.

If I was to go again I think I would stock with a selection of samples rather than have a main.
author: Aaron D.

description:
I HIGHLY recommend Front Porch! What a Southern delight.

My friends and I went here last night and we were in a serious food coma when we left! The vibe in this place is awesome - it's dark, loud, and a whole lotta fun! Ressos are highly suggested! 

Our waiter wasn't the friendliest, but the food definitely made up for it.  I loved the fact that there were only two cooks in the kitchen! We were sitting right next to the kitch and it was easy to peek in. 

I have a new found love for pickles, so we ordered the fried pickles appetizer. Holy hell, they were SO good! I could probably eat them everyday for the rest of my life, no problemo! For the main dish, we ordered the fried chicken plate (shared amongst three of us). It came with 4 pieces of chicken, mashed potatoes & gravy, and collard greens.  We also ordered of a side of mac 'n' cheese, which I highly suggest.  Their hot sauces are amazing. Everything was super delicious, it left us full and happy! The dessert was also yummy - beignets and bourbon root beer float (there was a lot of bourbon in it). SO GOOD! 

Great atmosphere, food, drinks, desserts, and prices! Five stars!
author: Suki B.

description:
I wanted to like this place, I really did. Had been wanting to come here for some time.

We came for brunch-maybe brunch doesn't showcase the best of The Front Porch?

There was a long wait so we ended up sitting at the bar to eat. The bartender was great about serving us-very nice guy. We ordered some baked mac and cheese to start with. It was pretty amazing.

What made me sad was my brunch entree. The Stoner Stack is fried chicken, bacon, cheddar, & sausage gravy on a biscuit. Dude. World's smallest freakin biscuit. If I were indeed stoned I either would have laughed myself right off the barstool or wept inconsolably. Flavor was not great-it was bland and dry.  I got "cheesy grits" on the side. They were watery, I didn't taste cheese and the texture was reminding me of something unspeakable. This is my punishment for hating eggs, as most breakfast/brunch plates manage to insert them in some form or other..it's hard to find a good dish that doesn't contain them. This, my friends was not that dish.

Mr Q had the baked eggs and grits. He was also not bowled over by the flavors or portion size. I had a cocktail and he had a soda so I believe we spent around $50 with tax and tip. 

Meh.
author: Fancypants J.

description:
Amazing chicken, biscuits, and also the bacon wrapped dates appetizer.
 First time trying and will be going back to try more in the near future. Staff was friendly and really enjoyed the casual ambiance.
author: Dawn C.

description:
Great service and great food. Got the bucket of chicken with some sides with a group of 4. More than enough for everyone. 

The garlic mash potatoes were perfect   Mac n cheese was nice and hot. Roasted corn was better than expected. 

The fried chicken was really well done. Plenty of skin and meat with low bone ratio when it came to the chicken breast itself. Nice and tender while juicy as well. 

Definitely a must go for anyone visiting the Bay Area. 

Beware of long wait times though. Can get really busy.
author: Aaron F.

description:
Yummy yummy in my tummy!

Mac n cheese is awesome!  Shrimp n grits is awesome!  Went at 10:15 am on a Saturday and had no line.  Good service, good food, no line=win!  Only bad thing is it's a little small.
author: Michael L.

description: From a southern~ this food is amazing bit of southern/ Cajun culture!! Love the rockin chairs at the tables!  Stoner stack is where it's at!
author: Madelyn J.

description:
I was really excited about The Front Porch because whenever my brother and I get together, we love to eat fried chicken. 

When we saw that there was a 25 minute wait for the Fried Chicken and Waffles, we thought it had to be worth the time. Sadly we were wrong. The food was hot, the waffle was good but the fried chicken was tasteless.

It was so strange because the meat was tender and the fried coating was crispy but the chicken was really lacking seasoning. I didn't even taste salt. 

The atmosphere is pretty funky and fun. The signs in the place are also very clever and funny. 

The service was bizarre. The waitress who took our order was great. She was nice and friendly and helpful. But the waitress that finished up our visit was rude and a little on the mean side. My brother complimented her singing because she was singing to the song over the sound system. He started to sing along with her and she stopped singing, ignored him and gave him a nasty look. She also seemed annoyed that we were happy. After that... we paid our bill and left as quickly as possible. 

I might have to try this place again in the future but for now... sorry... two stars.
author: Joyce H.

description:
So lets start with the good.  The joint is very cool.  Got a front porch that can seat 10 (5 groups of 2) and some seats are Rocking Chairs!! Awesome!!  My water was served to me in a 40 oz bottle, which I thought was very cool.

We ordered the Fried Pickles, the Bacon Wrapped Fried Dates, Mac & Cheese, and we each had the 4 piece Fried Chicken.  The batter on the fried pickles were great; fried crips, and light, not overly battered.  The pickles however, were not as dill as I like them to be. I like my pickles sour...like slap me on the face sour.  The Bacon Wrapped Dates (my friend ordered) were not my thing.  It was too sweet for me.  The Mac & Cheese, while having a nice toasty crust, were bland.

Then came the chicken.  That's really what I came for.  I can forgive all the appetizers if I like the chicken.  Once again, the batter and fry technique were spot on.  Thin and crisp, and amazingly not greasy! I didn't feel like I was going to have a heart attack when eating this.  However, the flavor was lacking.  I felt it was way under-seasoned.  I found myself constantly adding salt and hot sauce trying to get some more flavor into my chicken, but it just didn't cut it.

I have to say this is yet another soul food restaurant, that although has excellent cooking technique, is missing some soul.

2 stars seems kind of rough, but as the description says "Meh, I've experienced better".  I'd give 2.5 if I could.
author: m k.

description:
Yum!

Came here today for brunch after having this place bookmarked for so long. I was able to make a reservation through yelp so that was a plus. The restaurant is rather small and cramped, and the space fills up quick with other patrons waiting outside. 

I had a glass of mimosa and the country fried steak with over easy eggs and the cheese grits. It was delicious! Really heavy meal so I couldn't quite finish but it was so good. The gravy topped it all off and the grits were a great accompaniment because it acted as the mash potato that I usually have with my country fried steak. The grits here were much much on the greater tasting end. I usually don't like it but here and Brenda's French Soul Food has the absolute best. 

My boyfriend also had the stoner stack. He loved it! I thought it was good, but the biscuits were a bit dense. And like I said before, the gravy sealed the deal. 

I would definitely come back, but next time, hopefully for dinner!
author: Kelly T.

description: Cute ambiance - dark and cozy, but bustling. This place reminded me of  NYC concept restaurant. Short rib w Dr. Pepper sauce and celery root was great. All of it was yummy.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I love Cajun food and I've also been on a fried chicken addiction as of late, so this place was the perfect dinner choice for me.

It's a really cute place with rocking chairs for its outdoor seating. 

My favorites were the jambalaya risotto balls and fried chicken. Our party of three ordered a bunch of appetizers to share and split the bucket of chicken, which was more than enough food to fill our stomachs up. The chicken is magically tender throughout and so juicy. The skin is not particularly crispy, but crispy enough. And the seasoning is perfection. More on the herbal side though: you can definitely taste the thyme. (The chicken comes with a little popcorn, which was a bit salty for my taste.)

The biscuits were also pretty amazing though a bit on the harder side, and the jam and butter tasted delicious with the biscuits (we ordered the side version). The gumbo was okay, I've had gumbo with more meat, but this was flavored pretty well.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
WINNER WINNER CHICKEN DINNER!

Come here for the fried chicken, you won't be disappointed!  This place is always packed on the weekends, so make sure you make a reservation if you don't want to wait.  It's a pretty obscure location in the Mission and the décor is kind of rustic, southern style, and they have approx. 7 or 8 tables and a bar area.

What we tried:

Crawfish Hushpuppies - the dough was fluffy and flavorful and they didn't skimp on the crawfish.  They were really delicious when they were fresh out of the fryer.

Baked Mac n Cheese - not your typical velveeta cheese, they layer different types of cheese for some stringy ooey gooey goodness

Shrimp n Grits - great texture on the grits, large shrimp with tail on, but I wasn't a fan of the Andouille sausage because I felt like it was on the dry side

Mashed Potatoes w Gravy - nothing out of the ordinary, just your typical smooth mashed potatoes

Fried Chicken Bucket - The star of the night: it's not your typical KFC junk, and at $36 for 10 pieces, it ain't cheap either!  It comes served in a popcorn bucket surrounded by popcorn.  Now here's my theory, the popcorn soaks up all the oils, thus leaving the chicken batter with the crispiest skin I've ever had!  I cannot rave enough about this chicken and have referred several of my friends to try it as well.

Cornbread- medallion sized mini cornbread was served on the house along with a Cajun flavored butter, quite good

Fucket get a Bucket - habanero hot sauce, the best thing ever! It's so spicy and super addicting.   It's also great with the cornbread and chicken.

Our server was attentive and refilled our water several times.  Overall, I'd have to say this place has the best Southern food in SF.
author: Michelle W.

description: I recall having the fried chicken before and also recall it being amazingly juicy, flavorful throughout the fried batter and the meat itself.  But from my recent visit, the chicken was underwhelming.  All I could taste was crunchy cornmeal, the chicken wasn't dry but was not how I remembered it.  Maybe my memory made it taste better than reality.  My friend asked if we thought the mashed potatoes tasted like the powder mashed potatoes that came out of a box - I didn't think so till she pointed it out, they pretty much did.  That said, the cocktail I had was awesome, as were the blue crab hush puppies and fried okra appetizers.  You can sit outside on a cold night because there are heaters, and it's rather fun being right on the street.  For the last few items I mentioned, that's why I'm rating 3 stars and not 2.  My search for the best fried chicken continues.
author: Mirba E.

description: The order patio is adorable with the cute rocking chairs and decor. The food was only average, which was disappointing. The best part was the free cornbread with rosemary butter. The vegan risotto was not great, and the only vegetarian option under entrees. Macaroni and cheese is better at most other places. The cocktails are heavenly.
author: Leela R.

description: Great as always. If you get the bucket of chicken they warn you it takes a while. It really does but is worth the wait. Hua puppies and mac and cheese are great aps to nibble on while you wait
author: katie r.

description:
saw a feature of this place on TV... don't remember which show.
I also found this place thru Yelp when I was bored in St. Lukes hospital one afternoon.
So, my sis, a friend and I are planning to have a girls' night, I had to plan a dinner here.
With no reservations, we came here right when they opened.
Parking is quite hard to find since they only have street parking.

We ordered cocktails.
shared the  bucket of fried chicken, mac n cheese, hush puppies, and the citrus salad.
they were all great!  fried chicken was tasty, not dry.
hush puppies were good but I've had better.  salad and mac n cheese were good too!

hubby was upset that I didn't bring him here so I will have to come back!
author: Learnee L.

description: Great southern food. Fried chicken okra, pickles crab hush puppies, and really smooth grits. Seasonal heirloom tomato salad.  Friendly owners, chef, wait staff.
author: David B.

description:
3.5 stars. Good Southern eats are alive in SF thanks to The Front Porch (which Rocks BTW). We had a great sampling of their bucket of chicken, collards, mashed potatoes and gravy, boiled peanuts, and fried okra and fried pickles.

We walked past a few rocking chairs on the front porch into the previously mentioned rather dark interiors of this restaurant. We were promptly seated (thanks Open Table for the highly recommended reservations) and were promptly served from there on out by a very friendly and efficient waitress.

The verdict: the food ranged from just OK to excellent.

Boiled Peanuts: a large appetizer that you really have to like in order to appreciate. Boiled peanuts are not particularly attractive, rather dark and grey served steaming hot in a paper bag. If you can't get past the look or texture, then this is not for you. I liked them OK, but this was not something I'll re-order.

Fried Okra: I think these were too overdone to be perfect. They got stringy at the ends and there was not a great contrast between the insides and the crunchy outsides. I did like the dipping sauce that was provided.

Fried Pickles: Interesting and overall successful with the dipping sauce. Not soggy or particularly flavored one way or another. 

THE Fried Chicken: A set of very juicy pieces thickly breaded with a very crunchy corn meal coating. Not particularly spicy (OK not spicy at all) and some may fault the chicken for being bland, but I really enjoyed it. This is not Popeye's style spicy chicken; if that's what you expecting, go elsewhere. But (Front Porch) that would be a really nice idea to provide a spicy version of this already great chicken.

The mashed potatoes were perfection but not many of the our table liked the collards, which was judged to be too sour.

Deserts were off the hook. The brioche bread pudding was like tiramisu meets carrot cake meets cinnamon bread pudding. The banana cream pie was cleverly presented and very delicious. "Just like homemade" was often heard.

This came out to about $40 per couple, so this was moderate to high for this style of food. I did very much like the service and the food. But the darkness and the rather high prices for the food (which was uneven in quality) brought the value down some.
author: Glenn H.

description: Excellent food and excellent service! I brought a large party with me from another country and we got phenomenal recommendations and service! Everyone loved the food and the experience!
author: Erica H.

description: Ok the four of us were in for sharing tonight.  Ended up with several appetisers, sausage balls; oh yeah' Fried Pickles excellent, Crab Hush Puppies just needed to be left in the fryer a few minutes less.  The we finished with the fried chicken along with Mac and cheese.  No complaints with timely follow up from the wait staff.
author: Robert B.

description:
I liked this place just a little...lol I was expecting this fabulous meal but just got "Ehh". We had a part of like 10 people and they sat us in the very back in a corner table. We were not comfortable at all. When booking the reservation they should of warned me about the space (C'mon Carla, really??...They want business). The fried chicken was definitely good but not the best ever...The greens was ok, a bit bitter for my taste not sure what they add to it to make it soo bitter?

The corn bread was my highlight and grand finale of my meal!! It was warm buttery and all so scrumptious! Can I take a bag to go?? Oh  yeah Don't forget the butter cause I don't think I will be coming back.
author: Carla F.

description:
went here for our anniversary dinner a few months ago. we didn't have any reservations but we were seated right away (it was a weeknight though). 
The service was impeccable and all our questions were all answered. I'm not very picky when it comes to eating out. I expect to get a nice hostess that will answer my questions and good food that's on time. Great eats!
author: Niko B.

description:
The fried chicken here is so freaking good! Perfectly cooked, juicy, and tasty! I first had it during dinner, which runs north of $30 for a bucket. It feels kind of weird to be paying $30+ for a bucket of fried chicken, but if you're a fried chicken glutton like me, it's worth the price. A great alternative I do to get my fried chicken fix for cheaper is to come during weekend brunch, where they serve chicken and waffles for $14. As an FYI, it takes 25 minutes for them to prepare it, but that's because they make it to order. Having freshly fried chicken brought straight to your table... so good!

I've also tried a few other things on their menu. The beignets are fresh, and I would recommend those as well. I would actually recommend AGAINST getting the chicken fried steak and mac and cheese, which I'd actually rate below average. The fried chicken I rate a solid 5 stars, which brings me to my 4 star rating for this place.
author: Morris C.

description:
I came here one random night with a good friend because we both wanted to try this place out.

CORNBREAD is always good. May ask for extra! =)

So, we shared a plate of the bacon wrapped fried dates, the 4 piece fried chicken, and a cup of mulled wine.

The bacon wrapped dates were something new to us. It seems like a great idea but we did not really like it. There was no distinct taste to it. Not sure if it should taste sweet, salty, or gamy of goat...even when there was a drizzle of balsamic glaze to it, no distinct taste.

The fried chicken was bomb-diggity because the batter was oh so crisp and the chicken meat was so juicy. Once we cut open a part of the breast piece...mmm...the juice came out. This is what all fried chicken should look like! =D

The mulled wine was pretty good. It tasted like hot apple cider. You do not taste the wine at all. Well, I'm not sure if I am suppose to because this was my first time trying it.

The cozy home ambiance is the best here!
author: Annie H.

description:
Ordered the bucket of fried chicken and a side of mac and cheese and felt the price was a little high for the quality. Don't get me wrong the fried chicken was delicious. Very flavorful and crunchy but I felt the mac and cheese was a little bleh and not as good as everyone had been raving about. I was also turned off by how loud it was when we came in for dinner. We stopped in around 8:30PM on a Saturday night and were sat right near the bar. It was super loud and I could barely hear myself talk. I wasn't expecting a super fancy quiet dinner but I wasn't expecting a rowdy bar crowd while I'm trying to eat dinner either. 

Overall the establishment was cute but I felt like it was a little 'cave-like' inside and the tables were too small. After we ordered all our food there was barely any room to even put my wine glass down after I taking a sip. I don't know if I would come back if I'm in the area again. I think I'd opt to try the other comfort food/southern cuisine restaurants that SF has to offer.
author: Brandon H.

description:
Nice experience, nothing really stood out. Always wanted to come here, because of the reviews and triple D's recommendation.
Because we don't come here often on this side of the town, we ordered a variety. We had shrimp and grits, my granddaughter liked the shrimp, popcorn chicken, nothing that stood out, braised ribs, it
Was okay too. We had appetizer eggs and jalapeño, that was nice.
Appreciated the experience, difficult to find parking
author: Doris U.

description: Drinks, food and service is a plus plus plus! The fried chicken is to die for! And the crab cakes are amazing!
author: Katheryne G.

description:
Disappointed.

I was hungry for some chicken and waffles... Had the craving for something sweet and salty... We pass by this place all the time so I figured might as well try it. It looks chill and the price has two dollar signs- so average, right? Wrong. This place is too pricey for the actual food. I guess if you're a hipster and like the thrifty look for a high price, then go ahead, it's your scene. The place looks small and dingy from the outside and inside was a normal small restaurant with a bar. Our baby carseat couldn't fit in the booth so we put it in the high chair and hoped it wouldn't get in anyone's way.

So I guess you have to make reservations here bc it's usually packed. Why? As my bf put it, "I don't understand the hype." we got here at exactly 5:30 right when they opened for dinner so we were lucky to be seated. The waitress asked if we could stay only up till 7pm bc the tables are all reserved already. Whatever, that's fine. I guess we couldn't sit and relax after dinner if we wanted to. But I didn't want to anyway bc the food wasn't even that enjoyable. You know when you're hungry, everything is usually really good??? Not here. I ordered the chicken and mashed potatoes with the side of mac and cheese. Per the waitress, "The chicken is what they are famous for." why? When it came, there were 4 small to average size pieces and I only ate one and gave the rest to my bf. he said they were just okay, but didn't want to waste it bc it was 15 bucks. The greens and mashed potatoes weren't anything special. I feel like I would have enjoyed this at KFC more bc it's cheaper but at least KFC has that buttery taste to their mashed potatoes. Anyway, the Mac and cheese wasn't bad. It was super cheesy, and really hot. I filled up on that only bc I was hungry and it was decent. My boyfriend got the shrimp and grits. He said it was ok but for it to be 23 bucks or so, not worth it AT ALL. Dude, the bill came out to be 65 bucks (with tip) oh and I ordered a coke (no refills on that bc it came in a can). What a rip off! I don't know how it came to be so much with just 3 average items and all I wanted was chicken and waffles, and couldn't even get that. 

The only reason why I gave it a 2 star and not 1 was because the waitress was pretty nice. She was sweet and accommodated us without a reservation. Other than that, please go somewhere else if you are craving comfort food.
author: Jamie B.

description:
To be fair this place wasn't terrible or anything, it just wasn't good for me. Food is very expensive here and I didn't enjoy any of it. The fried chicken was alright, on the dry side. The gumbo was par. 

One star for the ambiance though. Very true to it's name. 

I just wouldn't come back here.
author: Anthony T.

description:
Everything about this place is excellent.

My roommate and I love the bacon-wrapped, goat cheese-stuffed dates. The fried chicken, of course, is amazing. The staff has always been courteous, prompt, and welcoming

Highly recommended; I encourage all of my friends to come here.
author: Sev G.

description:
This place was delicious, but you have to leave your diet at the door. I had never heard of this restaurant until my friend recommended it for her bday and as a warm up to our New Orleans trip. I was pleasantly surprised- great drinks, yummy food and a cozy atmosphere. 

Some highlights- My gin and St Germain cocktail (can't remember the name, but it was well balanced and not too sweet), Mac n Cheese and the Sweet Potato Gratin.

Needless to say I'll be running this off for a week... but it was worth it.
author: Carla R.

description:
The food here is pretty good for what it is but I would not return because the service is both inadequate (which I can usually excuse) but also mean and snarly (which I cannot excuse). It's supposed to be a southern restaurant and southern hospitality is a thing, no? I think it's kind of a kitsch hipster idea of a southern restaurant--the fried chicken served in a bucket, the mismatched furniture, the rocking chairs. Underneath these stylistic flourishes is just like a very cold, SF, hipster place with a punk edge. That's ok in a dive bar, but not really what I want from a restaurant where my entree was $25. 

I was in the neighborhood and called to see if they had tables for in 10-20 minutes, and the hostess said yes there were open tables and to walk on over. But she also confusingly said, when you get here, you can put your name on the list. When I got there, there were no tables, and we were given the option to sit at the bar, which we did (why didn't she reserve us a table when I called if she knew how busy they generally are?). The place I was seated was at the very end of the bar directly in front of where the drink orders are placed on a rubber mat--not a place to sit and eat anything more than bar snacks. The restaurant acoustics are also designed for roaring din. Since I wanted to have a quieter conversation with my friend, we asked if we could just have drinks and apps at the bar and be moved to an outdoor table when one opened up. The hostess was visibly annoyed by the request, though she did honor it. Yes, I understand it was an annoying request, but I would have appreciated the eye roll coming AFTER I turned my back. I could see the restaurant was really slammed and all the staff were working super hard, but that meant things happened like...no silverware or napkins til 10 minutes after we got our food, requests for water that was never delivered. Most of the service we did get was not from our waitress, it was from a very hard working guy who I suppose might be called a busser? He brought the bread, he brought the water, he cleared the dishes, he asked if we were doing ok. I hope he gets a good cut of the tips because he seems to carry the show! I think I only saw the waitress twice-once when she took the order and once with the bill. And honestly, she seemed snarly and I would have felt very uncomfortable asking her for anything. The whole experience made my normally laid-back friend super tense and unhappy, which is kind of the opposite feeling you want from a restaurant. 

As far as the food, I got the Dr. Pepper braised beef short ribs and they were dry and tough, but the sides were great.  My friend had the fried chicken tray and it was good. The bartender was great.
author: Cat M.

description:
I swung by for Sunday brunch. Safe to say, it was a good time for all. 

TFP is what was a garage/ground level duplex turned restaurant. This makes for a relatively low ceiling and a very homey feel. Cozy. Crowded ... But not too crowded with tables and chairs and all. Very easy to navigate inside the place without knocking into people's chairs and tables. As far as ambiance goes, I'd say the music was just a tad too loud for my taste. I had trouble hearing the person sitting two chairs to my side. That said, they were playing some hip tunes. 

Service was quick and friendly. They take reservations which is a plus. Needless to say, if you're planning on going during peak operating hours, consider making a reservation to minimize or eliminate wait time. 

The fare is priced a bit more than I would have expected, but I suppose it's justified given their rent is probably close to astronomical. I'd say $11-15 gets you a nice plate. I got the 2 egg/biscuit/bacon/grits combo. Everything was pretty solid. Not mind blowing, but above average (in my opinion of course). I especially enjoyed the biscuit and the grits; just the right flakiness level, and just the right amount of cheese respectively. 

Was it good? Certainly. 
Would I go back? Maybe if I was in the neighborhood. 
The best? Probably not ... Gets a bit more hype than I would deem worthy. 

I am not saying I wouldn't recommend. It's ok. 
If you have ever been to Hard Knox cafe in the Richmond -I'd say TFP trumps it.  

All in all, a good experience.
author: Anthony L.

description: This was certainly one of the best meal I've ever had. We had the shrimp n'grits and the beef. Everything was PERFECT! It will be one of the reason we will go back to the bay area!
author: Emma T.

description:
Fantastic southern/creole food and drink! You cannot beat the fried chicken at this place. 

My wife and I both started with one of their signature cocktails, both of which were bourbon/citrus creations that were both delicious. The fried chicken takes 15-20 minutes (WORTH IT) so you need a little somethin' to sip on while you wait! 

The fried chicken is freaking unbelievable. The skin is the perfect thickness and crunchiness, and the breading has some spicy cajun style spices in it that give it a nice little kick. The flavor of the seasoning is present all throughout the juicy meat of the chicken too, so they must be brining their birds. bravo. I was literally searching my plate for leftover scraps of skin. 

Time for you to get out to the mission district and get your chicken on. 

Heads up: we've seen it get REALLY busy in the past, so consider making a reservation. They have an open table, so that's simple enough!
author: Sam W.

description:
We had a reservation and was seated right away.  Oh yea parking can be a challenge but we found one right away.  

Came here with my girlfriends so we decided to share the food.  

fried chicken - It was dry.  They're known for this but eh.  I prefer Blue Plate (a block away).  Bucket good enough for 5 of us.  
mac and cheese - creamy, but okay.  nothing special.  Again I prefer Blue Plate's
fried corn - different, never had it before.  it was good.  
asparagus - good
biscuit - good with the butter and yam
corn bread- good with the butter

They have homemade hot sauce - habanero is really spicy, the other other one is good. 

It's a cute place but was not impressed with the food.
author: Claire J.

description:
Oh, you want fried chicken? grits? Sure. Just head over to Front Porch (right behind Safeway in Bernal)! 

I had the fried chicken ($18) along with some Mac & cheese ($7.5) and bacon wrapped/cheese filled dates! 

The fried chicken comes with 4 pieces of white or dark meat, garlic "mashers", collard greens, and a bit of popcorn for good measure. Chicken was good, not dry. Everything else was great. 

Great wine selection as well as a comfy environment. 

If you're craving some southern food, this is not a bad option.
author: Carlos M.

description: I'd heard amazing things about this place and needed to check it out. I was greeted right away. Friendly staff. Nice. It's a bit dark inside but I do like the decor and feel of the restaurant. For brunch they have a great beverage selection. Hard to make a choice. Then we got to the food menu and it was even harder to make a choice. We shared beignets. They were light and not overly sweet. The Mac n cheese is like crack. Oh man, it was so good! I had the egg, grits, spinach, mushroom, goat cheese and bacon crack skillet. I wanted to love this but I realized I'm not a grits girl. There just wasn't enough flavor in the dish and the texture wasn't to my liking. I was definitely covering the chicken and waffles at the table next to me... Oh well, next time as I do plan to go back.
author: Tera K.

description:
Finally tried this place after passing by so many times on our way to Mitchell's ice cream. Bestie and I luckily scored a seat outdoors in the "front porch". We had the crawfish hush puppies with some sort of dip. These 4 balls were fried with batter and had pieces of crawfish. These were just okay but they were not amazing. I thought it was dried and too bread-y. I guess that's how a hush puppy is suppose to taste? I guess I'm not a fan. Maybe I've been too spoiled by Brenda's crawfish beignet so I just imagined there would be a creamy crawfish sauce in the middle. Nope. Dried. Moving along, we shared the 4 piece fried chicken plate with mashed potatoes w/ gravy and collard greens. Chicken was good! But it wasn't mind-blowing. Then we had the shrimp n' grits. Again, maybe we're just too spoiled from Brenda's that we just had high expectations for this place. The shrimp 'n grits was good but not as amazing as Brenda's. It was definitely missing the cheese. And the "sauce" or was it soup? It was too watery. Nonetheless, it was still delicious. However, the shrimps seemed a little overcooked. We skipped dessert because we wanted Mitchell's. I'm glad I finally got to try this place but I wouldn't come back. 

I have a feeling I'm making a trip to Brenda's French Soul-food soon.
author: Laura T.

description:
I usually never give 5 stars to restaurants and this time I will.

This hidden gem in the outer mission is by far one of the best restaurants I've given the pleasure to eat at and they'll have me back for more. From the decor to the mixology this place has it all, and where else can you eat a bucket of fried chicken with a spicy margarita? 

The customer service is outstanding and your food is made fresh just for you with a wait time of about 20 minutes (if you order the fried chicken, which you should.) 

Please don't forget to grab some sides for that crispy chicken like the Fried Okra, Mac and Cheese, or the delicious biscuits and cornbread! 

If you're ever feeling a bit under the weather after a long night out in the waterhole make sure to grab a bacon rimmed Bloody Mary that'll keep your head and taste buds in a cure unlike any other!

So please do check out this joint, it truly is a special place in this city!
author: Gabe G.

description: Had a good first visit to The Front Porch last night.  Great staff, fun menu.  We ordered several different cocktails, all nicely crafted.  Hush Puppies with crab were disappointing, overcooked - did not appear even close to photo on web site.  Tiny corn bread muffins with herb butter - fantastic.  Shrimp and grits with gravy - devine.  The bucket of fried chicken was fun, flavorful and the smell was addictive.  The short ribs and deviled eggs also got high praise from the table.  We ordered three desserts, the beignets were hot and perfect and the pecan pie decadent. The brownie sundae with cherries was good but underwhelmed. Totally enjoyed our visit - great staff, great food, appreciated the fresh flower arrangement in the ladies room - we'll recommend and be back.  Thanks.
author: Debbie D.

description:
This place usually has a line out the door on saturday night. I guess they take reservations now. Also it was raining badly which maybe helped. 

There were 3 of us, and we got the large bucket of fried chicken. Mac n Cheese, Sweet potato fries. For an app we ordered the special shrimp fritter, and a bread pudding for desert.... 

The Fritter was no very great. It was overly fried and slightly burnt. Ive had better at red lobster :( 

The Mac n cheese was no bueno. I love crunchiness on top of that mac, and this was more like a kraft box at home. 
The Potato fries were slightly burnt as well and were just OK. 

The Fried chicken definitely saved the day for me. I heard so many great things about this place and thank goodness the Chicken was good. A little overly bready but super juicy and tender meat. Very well done. I like the home made hot sauces as well. Good draft beer, and the desert was tasty. 

The place it self sits under apartments and is small cozy and neighborhood like. The staff was awesome as well. But for almost 100 bucks... meh. 3 stars
author: Benjamin B.

description: We first seen this place on Triple D and decided we wanted to check it out. We made a reservation from the Yelp page and we were off. The wait staff was really attentive but very rushed as its a small place with a lot of business. The food was good but a little expensive for the portion size. all in all it was a good experience and ide recommend it to someone that wanted to try a new spot!
author: Richard M.

description:
I must truly know how to "walk around the block," as we did exactly that recently as full-time pedestrians to meet up with a group here locally for brunch.

Once arriving at Front Porch, I was soon to learn what all of the "chicken and waffle" craze was all about, as that is apparently their specialty.

Our group of 4 started with New Orleans Style Beignets with Powdered Sugar, and throw in some Mimosas to boot. Appetizer or not, they were both yummy and a time absorber -- our upcoming meal, the Chicken & Waffle dish, requires 25 minutes of preparation, and our server informed us of this up front.

I guarantee that it is worth the wait! 
Three juicy tender chicken pieces upon some Jalapeño-Bacon Waffles, doused in maple syrup... I never would have expected chicken and syrup to combine well, but at least here at Front Porch, they do splendidly!

This was my second time ever trying a Chicken & Waffles dish somewhere. Here was the first place to get it right.
author: Garett T.

description:
Now this is my type of joint!  Came here for brunch on a Sunday and boy it was well worth the wait.   IS sipping on delicious Mimosa's really waiting????

First, the ambiance.  I love places that are not afraid to be realxed and chill, with 90's hip hop blasting.  Very laid back atmosphere and the staff is really great.  You can tell they are great to their customers:  you have a range of people in there, from toddlers to senior citizens, all just busy devouring their food.  Just by peeking in and checking the facial reactions of everyone, you know they are doing something right.

Second, the food!  How can we not talk about the food????
1.  Baked Mac and cheese: effin delcious.  Nice char on top, hot and creamy inside.  Perfection.
2.  Fried Okra:  WOW.  perfectly crispy abtter, and the inside is not as slimey as you would expect.  The jalapeno aioli is CRACK!  I would smear that on anything and everything!
3.  Fried Chicken and bacon waffles:  Damn good!  The fried chicken is nice and crispy and so moist and hot inside.  They sure know how to fry things!  The bacon waffle was a great accompaniment.
4.  Spicy shrmip and grits:  Damn, this palte was licked clean.  Perfect flavor and texture on all apsects.  The shrimptasted so fresh, and teh grits were delicious.   That andouille sausage gravy was again CRACK!

Overall, I cannot wait to return.  30 minute wait is perfect, Mimosa's can be had!
author: Raymund S.

description:
I made a reservation for 4 people at 7:45 pm. I came in early because I really needed to use the restroom, so I told the hostess about my reservation and asked if I can have access to the restroom beforehand. She said absolutely! And told me that when everyone arrives, she can seat us early. This was the start of my 5 stars.

We ordered the seasonal storm as the alcoholic beverage of choice, and man were they delicious. For food, we ordered the fried pickles, the bacon wrapped dates, the blue crab hush puppies, and the main entrée of the four piece chicken with a side of mashed potatoes and gravy and collards. The appetizers were soooo bomb. The pickles and the hush puppies were fried goodness, but surprisingly my favorite was the bacon wrapped dates. The bacon was thick and crunchy, while the dates were adequately soft and sweet. Not to forget that the dates had cheese stuffed in them, so the combination of flavors made my taste buds really freak out with amused excitement. The mash was a not too thick or too thin and the gravy wasn't slathered excessively over it, so I could taste the butter and the potatoes with a few tiny chucks, which I appreciated. The greens had the hit of tangy sweetness, which one of my friends didn't really like, but I thought was a good balance with the mash. The fried chicken was just ok. The skin tasted a little over cooked and I kept biting into the chicken thinking that some kind of seasoning was missing. My friend said the same thing after she tried hers. My other friends really liked theirs, so I just added some hot sauce on mine and it was good to go.

By the end, we were completely stuffed and wanted to cry a little because they handed us the dessert menu and we really wanted to try them, but we just had no more room.

The staff was courteous and came to check on us a good amount of times. They didn't take long to take our orders and told us the chicken would take 20 minutes to fry. We left happy and satisfied, which is why they get 5 stars.
author: Pamela B.

description: Pretty solid southern food for SF but having eaten a lot of genuine southern food, none of the food here is a home run. Pretty good if you have a craving for some comfort food. The crab hush puppies are recommended as well as their mash potatoes. They have really good choice of cocktails and beers. I really like the chill environment.
author: Jin N.

description:
Been for dinner twice in the last month.

Kept things pretty simple - bucket of fried chicken plus a couple of sides.  Fried Green Tomatoes and Ribs as appetizers on last visit.

Food is of very high quality.  You get a sense that the (tiny) kitchen puts some heart & soul into the food.

Drinks are hearty, well priced, and a good selection of beers.  

Service always spot-on - cute as a button guys n'gals who ply their trade with aplomb.
author: David P.

description:
I really enjoyed everything about this place. From the minute we walked in good service was in the air. Soon enough our server busted out the menus including the kids menus. 

Our little ones just couldn't get enough of the complimentary cornbread. It was so good that we ordered seconds and I had a chance to sneak a couple down the hatchet. 

Next up were the Fried Green Tomatoes with Shrimp Remoulade. This was the first time I've tried this dish and I liked it a lot. The crunch and crispness of the green tomatoes went perfectly well with the shrimp remoulade sauce. 

It took a little while for the Biscuits a' la bama baked to order, but it was dam well worth the wait in my book delicious! 

The girls killed their Mac n' Cheese and I emptied my plate of Fried Chicken (single) with rocky jr. garlic mashers & gravy with collard greens with bacon. The chicken was not the best I've had but overall it was pretty good along with the fixings. 

My wife however, didn't care much for her Spicy Shrimp and Grits. The "spice" factor was almost nonexistent. In her words it was okay. 

After all was said and done, we're definitely looking forward to hanging out at The Front Porch again...
author: Gary E.

description:
Had 6 pm reservations with the hubby and scored a space right outside the restaurant. After the blonde hostess/server sat us in a smaller 2 top table, I practically had to beg for a bigger table. I don't understand the attitude I received for wanting a bigger table especially if it was early and there were plenty of tables open. This is my biggest pet peeve. I'm not paying $60 to sit in a tiny table.  

On to the good stuff. The bucket of fried chicken is a must because you will want left overs late at night. Probably the best fried chicken in the city. Mashed potatoes were so good. Salad with pomegranate and nectarines was refreshing. 
I recommend going early to avoid the heavy crowds
author: Livia K.

description: Another overrated yelp place. The cornbread was the best part. Excellent. The fried chicken was so so. The collards were just ok. The mac and cheese was bland and overall not good. Wont be going back.
author: Yaneke B.

description:
You know that place you go to when you need some comfort food that hits the spot, just so perfectly? This is it. Best place ever. All the details that are outlined in their menu - from the special buns that are ordered to the sauce that they put into their food - it's absolutely spectacular. And that's an understatement. 

A review really can't do this justice. If anything, I'll say without any reservation - best burger I have had on the west coast. That's a tall order in itself.

The servers are amazing and so friendly. 

I will be coming back here... a lot. Also, let your diet rest for a day... or two. You can burn it off later. 

:)
author: Jane E.

description: I'm new to anything barbecue and this was a very pleasant encounter. I had the salad and we shared 3 pieces of fried chicken (which were huge) and all of it was really tasty. The candied pecans in my salad & the slice of ripe peach are definitely gonna be copied at home :) Service is friendly but busy, and the overall atmosphere is really nice, intimate and warm.
author: Hanna G.

description: Food was good, limited menu as it was New Year's Day but nonetheless the fried chicken was pretty good and also the collard greens. Downside was that the service was a little ehh and it wasn't even busy. People at the bar/ bar tender seemed to be drunk and cursing kind of loud too. Probably should've been a little more professional.
author: Natalie M.

description: I don't understand the hype.  My girlfriend and I ordered the 4 piece, the shrimp and grits, and a side of the baked mac and cheese. The chicken was highly recommended by the waitress as was the shrimp and grits. Maybe it was because it was a Tuesday when we came in and all I could think was I could have had a better 4 piece for the weekly special at Popeyes. And the shrimp and grits were ok I actually didn't like the sausage that it comes with. But then again maybe my tongue isn't as sophisticated as most. Surprisingly the gf did enjoy the mac and cheese, her love for the blue boxed stuff usually trumps everything else. All in all this is just going to be a place I drive past on my way to mitchell's.
author: Michael S.

description: Yum! My friend and I ordered the fried chicken with mashed potatoes, collard greens, and popcorn, the spicy shrimp and grits, and deep fried okra with jalapeño aioli. Everything was really tasty, especially the shrimp and grits! However, the fried chicken was just ok. Good crunch from the batter, nice and moist, but I felt like it was missing something. I guess I was expecting it to be better because of all the hype I heard about it in the past. Will definitely be back! Maybe for brunch if I have a couple hours to spare on a Sunday morning :)
author: Krizia M.

description:
This place definitely has a divey, hipster atmosphere. We came here for dinner and ordered the fried pickles, fried okra, and the vegan option. None of us were vegan (I'm ovolactarian), but after hearing about it, we had to get it.

It was a pumpkin soup served in a pumpkin shell and hushpuppies and collard greens. Everything tasted reaaaally good. The hushpuppies, however, were made out of another substance (eggplant?) so that threw me for a loop, but it was tasty nonetheless. 

Would definitely come back and I'm sure the bucket of chicken is tasty too.
author: Christina K.

description: The food was delicious! We had the chicken and waffles and chicken fried steak and they were both incredible! The beignets are also awesome! Definitely a great brunch spot and we were seated immediately.
author: Jason S.

description:
There's good friend chicken here! If you're on the search for some southern fried chicken, then you should probably check this place out. 

I've been on the hunt for quite some time. I grew up in the south and occasionally crave southern comfort foods. After hearing decent things about this cozy little spot, I decided to give it a try. 

Here's what we ordered: Beers (they've got a small but very nice selection), friend okra, friend chicken, Dr. Pepper beef short ribs and the mac n cheese.  The fried okra was perfectly crispy and came with a spicy aioli for dipping. I'd recommend starting with this. The fried chicken was also cooked perfectly with a flavorful crispy outside. Finally found a place that does it right. The Dr. Pepper short ribs were fine but nothing too memorable and the mac and cheese the same. 

Overall, I only gave this spot 3 stars because the menu was over priced and the service was a little lacking. It's not a spot that I would frequent but would suggest to my friends that were looking for some decent chicken.
author: Sheena A.

description:
Good place. Small for sure. Kinda pricey.

Best bets:
Mac-n-cheese
Fried chicken
Greens
Mashed potatoes

I'd skip:
shrimp-n-grits (did not like the sauce)
author: ANGEL R.

description: Food's fine, crazy expensive, and about as Southern as a Paula Deen chain restaurant. There are so many dishes with (fried) meat inexplicably tucked in that it's more of a sarcastic Southern parody. The rice and beans are the dullest of the dullards, but the vegan gumbo's actually worth the price. Everything else falls somewhere in between. Not much stands out from the schtick food-wise, but the place has an enjoyable space so you can have a good time with your dining party, taste everything they order, and judge for yourself how the experience holds up against the bill you get at the end.
author: Jeff B.

description:
Eh, don't know the hype about this place. I had the shrimp and grits and thought it was gross. I finished it just because I didn't want to waste food. Their mimosa wasn't that great either.  Just tastes like store bought orange juice with cheap champagne. 

I also tried their beignets. That was okay...nothing really special. 

Tried a bite if their chicken and waffles and wasn't a fan.  Their waffle has bacon and jalapeños in it. It just tasted weird to me. Won't be back.
author: Kathy N.

description:
Pretty much everything that it's cracked up to be. It's expensive for comfort food but I've never left feeling disappointed and I've been frequenting this place for about 5 years now. 

The fried chicken is one of the best in the city, with a nice crispy batter and juicy meat without feeling greasy.  Everything else I've had there is also solid, with particular high marks for their mac n cheese, grits and burger.

The rocking chairs outside are a lot of fun if the weather permits and if there's a long wait, I recommend spending your time getting a drink at either the rock bar across the street or the 3300 club at the corner (it's not quite as scary as it would appear from the outside).
author: Baron C.

description: Awesome spot for cozy dinners. We were seated outside on a cold night and stayed warm with restaurant-provided blankets and ample heaters. This comfort food really hits the spot. Go for the bucket of fried chicken, mac & cheese, and hush puppies.
author: Lana H.

description:
Weekend trip back to Nor-Cal and I had bought a SF Gate Daily Deal for this place. I came here with my sister for Saturday Brunch.

We both got iced coffees. She got the huevos rancheros. I got the blue crab benedict. Beignets to start of course!! The beignets were a bit doughy but WAYYY better than Brenda's French Soul Food. They had lots of powdered sugar on them. YUM! The blue crab benedict was yummy! English muffin, ham, poached egg, and blue crab on top (I got the hollandaise sauce on the side). The ham was so good- meaty and hearty! The blue crab was buttery. I thought that the portions were kind of small for the prices. I wasn't super full when I left but it was good.

Overall, I give this place 4 stars. I will have to try this place again for dinner.
author: Angela D.

description:
Ate here a couple of times with friends.

Decent food, decent atmosphere and decent service.

This place is usually pretty busy, so plan ahead.
author: Anthony D.

description:
I'm updating my review based on my latest visit. I would give 3.5 stars.

Cornbread mini muffins: Always a great idea. So are seconds.

Fucket Bucket: I think my palette for fried chicken in general has gone down, so I didn't think it was amazing. The chicken breast felt a little dry, but the chicken itself was soft. 

Mac n cheese: It was yummy at the time, but haven't had Fat Angel's Mac n cheese, Fat Angel wins for being cheesier. At FP the Mac n cheese is baked, so the cheese is harder. Still one of my gm favorite things here.

Braised rib: Another favorite. Huge portions and enough to share with 8 people. It was tender and fell off the bone.

Biscuits: Where is the biscuit gravy? It tasted a little different here... maybe because I had Pine State in Portland and it's forever changed my palette on what a biscuit should be. Also, it was a little hard.

Cream of corn: Expected soup, and it came out like an entree. There should have been more liquid, and I think that's what everyone was expecting... to eat with a spoon, but you only needed a fork.

Deviled eggs: Delicious at any juncture. I love deviled eggs. That bacon on top made it good!

Pork chop: Also huge portions, so good to share. It was a great pork chop, and if you normally like pork chop you will probably like it. Pork chop meat is a little too tough for me, but I'll still eat it. 

The dessert we got was in a mason jar with chocolate mousse, marshmallow, etc. It was unique and flavorful, and great to share!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
We came here because of all of the rave reviews about this place. We came in without a reservation when it first opened, so we were lucky to be able to grab a table. Looking over the menu, we decided to try a few things other yelpers recommended.

Lets go over the items that I didn't like so much...

Mac and cheese is OK. If it was crispier on the edges, I feel it could have tasted better.

For all the rave reviews we read about the fried chicken, we were hoping for more. Roscoes has better fried chicken in my opinion. For the price that they were charging to make fried chicken, I expected the meat to be more moist and flavorful.

The biscuits they served were really dry. I took a bite, and put it down.

The burger was OK as well. Pearls burger is a lot better for cheaper price. 

The two dishes that I really did like was the devil eggs and the shrimp and grits. The devil eggs had the right amount of seasoning to make it taste really good. The shrimp and grits was also quite delicious.

This place really suffers from overhype. The food is fine, but for the price that we wer charged, I really expected better food.
author: Paul V.

description:
I was reflecting on this today, the day after I ate at The Front Porch, and I'm fairly certain it's the best fried chicken I've ever had.  I'm not going to do the whole Costanza thing and use sex words to describe the taste of this chicken, but as someone who has neither been in the South nor had a home cooked Southern meal, I feel fully qualified as a pretentious Bay Area individual to say that this fried chicken was legit.

What I do regret is going in on a bucket of chicken with some mewling coward who gave up after two pieces because they couldn't admit that what they really wanted was mac and cheese.  I mean, I guess I wasn't really going to use those last few moments of my now suddenly shorter life, but I like to think I would have said something profound.
author: Norman S.

description:
Having bookmarked for several months, we finally made it over.  Also been holding on to a $40 worth of food and drinks defunct Town Hog  coupon which I paid $20 for.

Made a reservation via open table earlier in the day and got 6pm.  We arrived behind a party of ten. Walked in and immediately liked it.  Dark and funky with attitude.  We were promptly seated in one of the several booths alongside the wall.

Knew we wanted the fried chicken, but perused the menu.  Asked our server about the fried pickles, and she said "don't be afraid".  Said beer battered dill, so we ordered for our starter.  They also give you cornbread shaped like a finger with a spicy sauce.

Practically everything on the menu is deep fried with the exception of two salads.  Having never been to the South, I assume this is par for the course.

Got the bucket of nine piece fried chicken which comes with mashed potatoes and collard greens.  As with many restaurants serving fried chicken, it's cooked once ordered so the wait is like 20+ minutes.  

Came to the table in a popcorn bucket with a few popped kernels.  Chicken was piping hot, and nice crispy skin and flavor.  Got two thighs, two wings, two drumsticks, and three double breasts.  Had two breasts leftovered.

Other items ordered  included three beers, cup of coffee, and four powdered sugar beignets in a brown paper bag for dessert.  Each beignet was the size of a two inch square and hot to the touch.

Tab inc tax&tip $71.00.  We enjoyed our entire meal.

Metered parking in a very busy area.
author: Shirley N.

description: Bad fatty pork chop. It seems like a very popular place locally but we will not go back. The service was very good but the food was poor in our experiences.
author: Jack O.

description: I'm usually not a big fan of fried chicken but they really know how to make it delicious here. For appetizers, you can't go wrong with the gumbo and crawfish hush puppies. For a party of 2-4, I would suggest getting the bucket of chicken (super moist and flavourful) and a few sides. I had the steak frites my first time here and that was also really good. Overall great ambience and would definitely come back!
author: Katarina D.

description: Had the beignets, chicken & waffles, grits, and some pork thing.  It was all very good.  Beignets were a little on the crispy side, but still tasty.  Wait staff was friendly.  Ambiance felt very "New Orleans."
author: Brian B.

description:
I've been wanting to try The Front Porch for a while now.

3 of us split a bucket of fried chicken, 2 other people got the burger & the steak. we all loved our food. The bucket of fried chicken consists of 9 pieces and popcorn (i know, random...). The order of fried chicken also comes with mashed potatoes & collard greens. Both of the sides were really good. The skin of the fried chicken was crispy and not oily, the meat was tender and juicy, even the big pieces of white meat. 

We also ordered a side of the mac & cheese and it was good. The mac & cheese was topped of with a layer of cheesiness. I liked it, but i wish they'd add a cheese that has a a more unique taste like pepper jack or goat cheese.

Front Porch has 2 special hot sauces and they were great with the fried chicken and sides. They also have a full liquor license now, the rose sangria was nice & refreshing.
author: Terry C.

description:
Hmm, maybe it is the neighborhood attraction, but as someone from the South now transplanted to the North, the North is beating the West on the Southern fare food.

First of all, the fried chicken was not that great.  I have had better fried chicken in Minnesota and in Tennessee.  The chicken here is more like greasy breaded chicken.  The seasonings were very lackluster and I am really surprised at the mac and cheese - this wasn't well done.

The atmosphere was really awesome, which is why I gave it two stars, but some of the appetizers were just not well done.  

All in all, things seemed really overpriced, lacking flavor ( and I mean SEASONINGS - not salt), and missing the boat on that Southern charm.  I won't be back and people that have had real southern cooking, I suggest you don't go at all.
author: Susan L.

description:
Best fried chicken (and mac and cheese!) in San Francisco. I would know because I went on a fried chicken bender not too long ago that included Front Porch along with 2 other famous for their fried chicken restaurants and this was the clear winner. The clear loser of that weekend being my waistline, not to mention my heart.

Also - you can check out their giant art prints of record players and classic records on the walls, drink amazing dark and stormys, and jam to the sweet sounds of the smooth Philly soul playing in the background. You could even do all this rocking out on their porch outside basking in the sun. It's basically my dream come true.
author: Teresa T.

description: The Front Porch is always a great overall experience.  Everything was fantastic.  Drinks are amazing.  Friend chicken to die for.  Wish I could order some of the other things on their menu but the fried pickles and chicken keep calling me back.
author: Lisa R.

description: yes please! fried chicken is good for the heart and soul. If I could eat here every day I would!!!!
author: Adam L.

description:
I don't know what the rave is all about with this place.. Came on a Friday night during dinner rush and I knew my boyfriend and I were going to have to wait based on how full it looked.. So we waited an hour.. 

When we got seated, ordered our food.. It took approximately 20 minutes for our appetizer to come out.. I get it, it was busy.. But our main courses took another half an hour! The side we ordered (which was Mac n Cheese) got to our table first.. 

The Food: 
- Way too under seasoned.. This is supposed to be Cajun and Creole?.. I felt like they didn't even bother to salt the food. 
- We ordered the 4 piece fried chicken with collard greens and mashers.. So disappointing.. I had to drown my chicken with the mashed potatoes because to be honest, that was the only thing that actually had salt. 

All in all, the food was oily, under seasoned and just plain boring.. I've had better southern food that didn't cost me $50.. 

I didn't quite get the decor.. It was so dark that I could barely read the menu.. Southern food, fancy and grungy decor do not go together.. I want to eat my fried chicken with my hands without having to look too hard on where my food is at. 

I hate to rant about restaurants because I know how hard it must be to keep it running.. But I feel like The Front Porch needs to rethink their strategy on how they can better their place.. Get the food out faster, season it, and modify the decor..
author: Kat P.

description:
The food way okay, but just sorta disappointing. 
A for the Ambiance
B for the menu
D for service ... just not good
D for food too...

The place looks great and we were there last night for what had to be their final seating of the night and we were pretty much being rushed through our meal from start to finish. Still eating appetizers when they took my plate. That was only one example... the main thing I remember is being rushed through the meal and the place was still half full. 

Gotta say my hamburger was good but the fries tasted weird. Most of the party had the fish that looked good. The shrimp and grits looked like soup. The fried chicken was cooked to death. 

I probably would not go back again. Not a friendly place. Rush rush rush... guess they had a party to get to.
author: Scott K.

description:
This place was delicious! A hidden gem in the outer mission. Very fun and quirky atmosphere. 
*Try the Jalapeno deviled eggs and the mac and cheese for apps.

 It is a little small but the service is great and the food is impressive.

I was so full I wasnt able to eat my main course. My friend and I will be going back next wekend to explore more of the menu.

If you want some delicious southern comfort food with a fun twist- GO HERE!!!!
author: Angela I.

description:
Sauteed Wild Gulf Flounder!!!!!!!!

I had to loop around the area for more than an hour to find parking on a Saturday night and I didn't have a reservation. Bad idea and I just wanted to go home but I finally made it. I sat at the bar to eat which I didn't mind because the service was still very satisfying. I ordered two appetizer, two mains, and two drinks. They were ALL great but the flounder dish was SUPERB!  I just couldn't believe there's only one review about this amazing dish. I WILL BE BACK FRONT PORCH.
author: Naomi L.

description:
With its homey feel, great southern comfort food, and friendly service, this neighborhood gem is worth making the trip from anywhere!

Our table started off with hush puppies -- full of crawfish and just the right amount of breading -- wonderfully rich tomato soup and a warm salad, all delish. We devoured a  mix of fried chicken and pork loin plates, oh so savory. We left stuffed and with bug smiles on our faces.
author: Daniel S.

description:
We came around lunch time on Saturday and to our surprise, there was no wait for a table. Service was quick and friendly, food was absolutely delicious. 

We have a pretty healthy appetite and shared the Stoner Stack and the Cajun Sausage Eggs Benedict. We scarfed those both down and left completely satisfied at that full but not so full that you hate yourself level. The biscuit and fried chicken in the Stoner Stack were moist. The hollandaise on the benedict was perfect and tasted great with the spicy sausage. 

I definitely want to come back for dinner and then walk over to Mitchell's for some dessert. Sounds like a terrible night for my arteries; can't wait!
author: Diana N.

description:
three stars due to parking:

Was craving fried chicken, heard about The Front Porch, drove around for way too long gave up and called in a to-go order for their fried chicken. Order came with the following:
