description: I had a horrible experience at this place. My sister made a reservation for 5:30 for a group of friends celebrating her going Away party. They said that we could only have the table till 7 so we were already stressed about being rushed when we got there. Upon arrival, we had to wait outside IN THE RAIN for them to open. There must have been at least 4-5 paying customers waiting outside in the rain to be let in to the restaurant. You would think they would have at least allowed us to come inside and wait by the hostess stand, but no, outside in the rain. Once inside, we were seated and actually had a nice waitress (who should not be discredited for this bad review) The bad review is a reflection of the owner and management who expected us to be out by 7 pm, harassed us by telling us to wrap it up many, many times, when they only served us our food at 6:45! Even though we ordered at 6! Our bill was over $150 dollars and they still rushed us out of there and blamed us for not eating fast enough when they only left us 15 minutes to eat! We were flabbergasted and the way the owner handled it. The owner was EXTREMELY rude and everyone at our table left feeling harassed and poorly treated. None of us have any interest in returning to this establishment, and any good manager knows that you don't ever wanna lose customers ! Especially for something as correctable and petty as mistreatment!
author: Julia ..

description:
I'm a big fan of Southern food and this place offered some pretty tasty southern cookin. The chicken was spectacular, very crunchy and just the right amount of spices. The fried pickles, whoa! So good and paired with a wonderful spicy dipping sauce. We also has the Mac & cheese which was pretty amazing too. Served in a hot plate, we added the habanero sauce to it (salivating!). 

I'd give this place a full 5 stars but we thought it was a tad over priced and bad lighting. We had to breakout our flashlight app to see the menu.
author: Martita S.

description:
We came here after the Candlestick Tour.  It wasn't busy, and we got seated right away.  I ordered a lemonade, Sandra got a beer, then water came.  The waitress returned for our orders, and asked at the end if we'd like something besides water to drink, so we reminded her that we ordered drinks from her about 10 minutes ago.  Maybe she was just having a bad day, but that was slightly annoying.  

We got the beignets because beignets rock!  Sandra got the baked eggs and grits, mostly for the "bacon crack," and I got the fried chicken po boy (because I'm boring).  The beignets were ok.  I really like the ones at Disneyland a lot better than most, and these were incomparable to them.  Robert didn't even like it!  It's a sugar covered donut!  He loves the ones from Disneyland and Devils Teeth, though.  Her dish came in a small skillet, and much to her surprise, even though she was sold on the dish through the "bacon crack," it was probably one slice of bacon, crumbled over the dish.  :-/  That was pretty mediocre.  My sandwich was nothing special.  Robert thought the sauce on it was too spicy, but he kept eating it, so it got the approval of a toddler!  I doubt we'd come back here.
author: ROB L.

description: So far starters have been excellent the gumbo was nothing but delicious jambalaya was as well just enough to keep u wanting more chicken I had as a main dish Mac & cheese were a little plain but Greens were ok hope u guys enjoy this little hidden gem right off of mission
author: Chi G.

description: Stop reading this and go there and eat the fried chicken. Now!  No. Seriously. I travel all over the country for my job and I'm a sicker for fried chicken. This is the best fried chicken I have ever had. You need this in your mouth, now.
author: Lisa D.

description: Small, friendly restaurant. Played great 80s music in the background. Tried the Shrimp & Grits (substituted grits with garlic masher)...mmm soooo good!! Dish came out hot and it was very tasty! Bucket of chicken was tasty & moist! Mac & cheese & crab hush puppies were delightful! Ham hock collard greens had a bit too much citrus/vinegar and the complimentary corn muffins were just okay... Would definitely go back and try other items on the menu!
author: Wendy Y.

description:
So first off. The fried chicken in terms of juiciness and texture, is textbook.  However, the Salted Caramel I had at Bi-Rite later that night was higher on the savory scale - the chicken my friends and I ordered was disappointingly bland.  Tabasco and salt were not enough to rescue it.

Okay, the starters weren't as bad.  I especially liked the fried okra (which WAS plenty salty actually).  I also tried some Spicy Shrimp and Grits which I liked, but wasn't great.  Maybe it was just an off batch (like I said, the juiciness was great), but I'll probably look toward the East Bay for my next fried chicken fix.
author: Alan W.

description:
Listen, I don't hate "The Front Porch" just because I gave it 3 stars. I simply don't see why this place gets the rave reviews it gets. It's fried chicken. In a dingy, dark, creepy (but kinda cool) spot. I mean, I guess if your'e in to the whole "swampy, damp, humid" feel of the South- this place nails it. 

The porch area reminds me of the Pirates of the Caribbean ride at Disneyland. The old seats turned chairs/benches are kinda cool. I mean, i can dig it. (I also loved the stickers...catchy, creative...)

I had a Bloomspot that was going to expire, so I invited a girlfriend to meet me here for dinner. Since the chicken got all the rave reviews, we both went with this dish. DON'T GET ME WRONG- it's good- but I absolutely felt my arteries begin to clog. I've certainly had fried chicken I like better too. Found everything to be super, super greasy. 

We also giggled at the pieces of cornbread that came before our meal. They were 2 bites and gone! Yummy, but not exactly generous in size.

Was it a bad meal? No. Would I come back and/or recommend it? No.
author: Annalise F.

description:
Came here with a bloomspot and left a happy camper.  The bf and I ordered the crawfish beignets and the 9-piece bucket of fried chicken.  Both were delicious.  My only gripe was that the chicken took super long.  The waiter told us it would take about 20-25 minutes to make which we had no problem with.  But we ended up waiting for almost 40-45.  After bringing it up to the waiter, he repeated the 20-25 minute speal and left...It would have been awesome if they gave us some more cornbread to tide us over from waiting but oh well.  

All in all a great restaurant with delicious food.  Very pricey for the chicken but definitely worth it with the bloomspot!
author: Connie C.

description: I'm not sure what all the hype is about with this place. I thought the food sucked. I ordered the fried chicken with collard greens and mash potatoes and my boyfriend order the Dr. Pepper rib. Urgh...my fried chicken was uneven as far as taste some bites had burst of flavor and some where tasteless and I truly believe that the mash potatoes were instant and I HATE instant mash potatoes. The collard greens were super salty and the cornbread was tasteless. My boyfriend said his food was alright but that he wouldnt go back for this. Also, the service was lacking long periods of time to refill water, ask about service. I wouldnt go back. The place is super cute looking but thats it.
author: Christine M.

description:
This is a 4.5 star review. My bf and I ate here and it was amazing! We started with drinks recommended by our server, the porch swing and the donkey d's hot ass margarita with jalapeños.
For food we shared everything. 1) lolla rosa mixed greens salad with strawberries. 2) fried pickles with Tabasco aioli 3) fried chicken single with mashed potatoes/gravy and collard greens 4) baked mac and cheese. 5) bread pudding for dessert! 
Everything was homemade with great flavor and the wait staff was very nice.
author: Lee J.

description: Went there on a warm evening so we sat in  outside in the rocking chairs. Loved it. Have to be honest and say that I do not think I would have like sitting inside - it was a little too dark. To me, dark restaurants should be reserved to fine dining. The fried chicken and the biscuits are great, the service was excellent and overall it was a fantastic Sunday night meal. It is a real restaurant with real people that have conversation with you.
author: Ina D.

description:
French toast replaced by peach waffle (you get one waffle). Fried chicken still good.

Pleasant service.
author: Inigo M.

description: The food was great. The prices were very reasonable. The fried Chicken, Greens, Mac n Cheese, and Shrimp n Grits were amazing! Also try the fried okra!
author: Miz L.

description:
Finally made a last minute reservation here after remembering my hairdresser once recommending this place (don't snicker, he was a regular at La Ciccia long before it gained recognition on Check Please, 7x7, or was listed on Open Table) and the hostess was nice enough to fit me into the only remaining table that evening. 

1) Atmosphere (3.5/5) - Dim lighting, booth and small table seating, has a converted dive-bar vibe.
2) Drinks (3/5) - Sazerac and Front Porch Swing; not cocktails to rave about but both were fine.
4) Fried Chicken (3.5/5) - Ordered a bucket and proceeded to devour 3.5 pieces. While the thigh pieces were expectedly moister and (in my opinion) tastier than the breast pieces, I wasn't blown away by this dish. Perhaps my expectations are too high after years of lusting after the perfect fried chicken; Simply by the nature of fried chicken (laden w/ fat and sodium), doesn't it automatically default to the "delicious" category even when it's not great? For $5/piece, I wasn't thrilled to find a couple pieces of wimpy wings in the bucket :(

Other items ordered which I finished despite having better elsewhere - mac & cheese (no crispy top?), collard greens w/ bacon, crawfish hush puppies, and tiny cornmeal muffins (dry but made better w/ the accompanying butter).
author: Ida C.

description: The fried chicken was pretty good.. Overall, I didn't like the service and thought it could have been way better. I liked the the homey feel of it as well and literally the "porch" ;)
author: Kevin D.

description:
The Front Porch ROCKS! 

Good quality food, fair prices, and great service! Excellent wine list. They have a good selection from Argentina and Chile. They also have a lot of really good draft beers. They have an awesome happy hour, aaand they're doing lunch, AND brunch now. 

I grew up in this neighborhood, and I have to say this is one of THE BEST restaurant additions ever. I love everything about the Front Porch. Most definitely my favorite hangout in the hood.
author: Michelle W.

description: The Front Porch proudly serves grits, collard greens, okra among other favorites in a dimly lit, eclectically styled environment. Art crowded the walls, deep colors showed through their spacing, and all came together for a comforting southern-kitsch feel. Outside seating was minimal and tables went quickly, but no matter as the restaurant had a fair selection inside. My friends and I came during a busy brunch hour, and from what I hear, the lines tend to lengthen the later it gets. Gumbo, Fried Chicken, Crab, Shrimp and Chicken Fried Steak inspired our mouths and the grits were worth another order. Put on that eatin' smock and venture here for some heavy southern fare.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Wow that fried chicken is SO HYPED UP FOR NOTHING! While it was "cooked" perfectly (crispy and tender/juicy meat), it was quite bland. Very average at best. 

Other things we ordered:
- Mac & Cheese. Nothing special.
- Jambalaya Risotto Balls: Comes with 4 balls that were very tasteful
- Steamed Clams: They ran out of mussels so they replaced it with steamed clams in a tomato broth. Not bad.

Service wise, no complaints. Everyone was very welcoming. My only complaint was that some random lady slipped in the restaurant and went to my table asking for money. At first, I really thought she was there to take my order as she was holding those black note pads. That always steers the dining experience in a different direction.
author: Ken N.

description: Nice cozy place. We went for dinner and it was hard find the place. But food is very good and atmosphere is great. It took a little arm twisting to get them give us some warm milk for the kid. First we were told they can't heat it up but agreed to after asking for it a second time. Good sauces and reasonably priced. Highly recommend. Better than Brenda's Meat and Three.
author: Gulshan I.

description:
The fried chicken was delicious and they played 
Awesome soul music, reminded my of parents.
author: Michele T.

description:
My beau and I arrived as they were opening for dinner time and so we were seated immediately. Apparently reservations are highly recommended, but we were fine since we arrived early. The restaurant was small, as it was located in what appeared to be a house--hence The Front Porch name. The menu was brief, with a few starters, main dishes, and sides. Their menu was a little frustrating, because they only had two offerings of chicken--their four piece combo and a nine piece bucket; nothing in between. We went with an order of the jalapeño and bacon deviled eggs, gumbo, and an order of their four piece chicken combo, which included mashed potatoes and collard greens. I thought the food overall was just average. The gumbo was flavorful and authentic; however, the fried chicken was not as special as I had anticipated. It was extra crispy and juicy, but extremely bland--I guess that's where their house hot sauces come in handy. 

Customer service was friendly and attentive and prices were fair. It was good to try, but I wouldn't go out of my way for it again.
author: Lien T.

description:
Encountered The Front Porch over the weekend while visiting from Los Angeles.   Went on Yelp while on the road, trying to decide what to have for dinner.  My fiancé then said, "I wish they had a Roscoe's out here."   So I searched for "Fried Chicken," and after reading reviews on many locations we ended up here.  So, I will start off by saying Roscoe's Chicken and Waffles has nothing on The Front Porch.  The Front Porch over exceeds in all aspects, food, service, and drinks.   We did not have a reservation and therefore encountered a wait, but were kindly told we could go across the street to the bar and have a drink, and they would call us once our table was ready.  They did exactly that.  
Ambiance: We were seated on the porch which was such a warm experience.  Although it was past 7 p.m. and quite chilly, they had over-head heat lamps which were at perfect setting.  We had beautiful plants and garden accessories around us, while we sat on rocking chairs, listening to the blues. 
Drinks:   We started off with water.  It came in a nice glass 42 oz bottle.   I ordered an alcoholic beverage, but for the life of me, I cannot remember the name, other than it had rum, orange juice, and other splashes.   It was delicious and I had enough with just one. 
Food:  We ordered fried chicken, ham hock collards, garlic mashed potatoes/gravy, and the mac and cheese.   The chicken is to die for.  It is nice and crispy on the outside and amazingly moist on the inside.  The batter is on the thick side but not overwhelming with amazing spices.  By far, the best fried chicken I have had.   My fiancé ordered the ham hock collards.  Sadly, I didn't get to taste them because he ate them all before I could try them!  Therefore, I assume they were good.  The garlic mash and gravy were delicious.  They were nice and creamy with the perfect amount of garlic.  The gravy was a great compliment and not too thin or thick.    My favorite side was the mac and cheese.......Oh my, it was bomb!  It was brought out in the baking skillet and was perfectly baked, thick, and cheesy (I hate water-downed mac and cheese).
Dessert:  We ordered the beignets.  Although everything was amazing, the beignets were the least of my favorite.  They were not bad, but I like my beignets soft and with syrup.  These beignets were very powdery and crunchy. 
Overall, we had an awesome experience.   The portions to the mains are quite big and sharable if you order extra sides.  We will definitely return; next time for brunch!
author: Ms. Z.

description:
I've only been once, but it was such a bad experience I will not be going back.

Things started off well - the atmosphere is dark and cool and the fried okra was yummy. But my catfish was not cooked. Seriously. I think the cook forgot to flip it. The cooked half was fine, the other side was raw, and catfish is not something you want to eat raw. The person I was eating with was horrified. It was cold, mushy and gross. 

I showed the server, and she took it back and then returned to the table to tell me that "this is the way it's supposed to be served"... as if it's ahi or something. I eat a lot of fish and sushi, and have had lots of catfish in my life, and this was not right. 

When we asked for the check, they sent over a dessert. It was complimentary to make up for the fish, but we had no appetite at this point, so didn't touch it. The waitress brattily asked if something was wrong with it, and my dining partner said "we didn't order it and we aren't hungry at all anymore".

They actually charged us for the inedible catfish. Customer service 101. Total fail.
author: K L.

description:
Oh hell yes.  This place was SOOOO good. I love some great Southern and/or Cajun food, and this place does not disappoint.  First of all, they have Abita beer (delicious).  Second of all, their mussels are really good!  Third of all, their baked macaroni and cheese was so delicious that I was about to stab fools with my fork if they got to close.  Fourth of all, that fried chicken was some of the best I've had outside of the South.  

My husband had the shrimp and grits (which I tried, and were pretty good), other people in our party enjoyed the flounder, the short ribs and the duck.  Everyone was super satisfied with their food and cleaned their plates.  So damn good, I'd definitely go back.
author: Jackee K.

description:
This place is good. Just good.

I have had my ups and downs with this joint over the years. It's weird- the service is either perfect or terrible. I have no idea why it changes. It sort of feels like there was a good idea here, but no one's checked on it in a while. Kinda like a garden that was awesome until your forgot to water it all month in July. 

They are *right* around the corner from my house so that's a plus.

As a dinner place they, as everyone will tell you, do fried chicken very well. Even in a world where fried chicken has somehow made it onto every menu, they are still in the top 10th percentile. 

Their shrimp and grits is not bad- but sometimes the shrimp are over done. 

Everything else is mix and match. I have absolutely no idea why there's a line around the corner for brunch there every weekend. We had brunch there and it was okay- nothing I would wait an hour for. 

If there's no line- go- order the fried chicken- you'll enjoy it. If you have to wait- skip it- there's great stuff all around you.
author: David C.

description:
This spot totally took me by surprise as I was not expecting it to be at street level below a residence.  It is also much smaller inside than I had expected.  Though, what the restaurant lacks in space and size they make up in the flavor of their dishes, warranting a short wait in case you didn't make a reservation.

The cornbread they started us with resembled elongated madeleines, but were fantastic.  I ordered the single order of fried chicken with an extra side of mac n' cheese.  The mac n' cheese was the beez neez, it was really good!  My single order of fried chicken came with three pieces of fried chicken, collard greens with bacon and garlic mashed potatoes with gravy.  Tasty and filling.  Two of the three pieces of fried chicken were very good, one for some reason wasn't all that great.  The breading of the fried chicken wasn't very thick which wasn't a bad thing at all and you could actually barely tell if there was any skin between the breading and the meat.

At sixteen dollars and change for The FP's fried chicken meal it's about three times more expensive than KFC's three piece meal with mashed potatoes and coleslaw, but then again The FP's three piece meal is certainly at least three times more delicious.
author: Erich D.

description:
I had the vegan entree, which turned out to be a piece of dry corn bread on a small pile of overcooked beans.  

$17 for essentially two side dishes.  No lube was supplied.
author: Chris W.

description: After hearing about this place from some co workers and checking out the yelp reviews, I knew I needed to satisfy my craving for southern food at The Front Porch. Made a reservation and got right in on a Friday night. Small place, dimly lit, louder atmosphere - but maybe that was because it was the weekend? The portions are pretty large, so consider sharing if you aren't starving. As far as the food - it was good, best part being the flavorful crispy fried chicken. Everything else was just ok. I don't think I will be rushing back to this place for a couple reasons. First, the waiting on the food. We had drinks and good convo so it wasn't something that occurred to us until we realized we had been there about an hour and half with no food yet. Just a longer than expected dining experience. Then the price. Maybe since I've grown up on southern food (and southern prices) I'm a little biased, but for what we paid and what we got - I didn't think it was worth it.
author: Casey B.

description:
I went here for brunch one day, and, like all brunch places, there was an annoying wait, with nowhere really to wait as the bar was packed and claustrophobic and outside was cold and we were pretty much just standing on the corner. Luckily, I had a bloody mary to ease my woes. The bloody mary was pretty good. I liked the bacon and maple syrup rim, though my glass only had a few pieces, so I kept stealing the bacon bits from my boyfriend's glass. A friend that was with us, on the other hand, had some coffee that she dumped like five sugars in to make palatable. 

Luckily the wait wasn't too bad for a brunch place, under half an hour, and we got a big booth to sit in instead of one of the cramped tables. Once seated, everything got better. The food was great! At least I liked mine. I got the gumbo, which was unlike most gumbo I've had, but was so delicious. then I had the shrimp and grits with the mushrooms and the shrimp stock they used, easily tied with Brenda's for my favorite shrimp and grits. Completely different, but delicious, especially if you like that porcini mushroom kind of flavor, which I love. My bf go the chicken and waffles, which he said were good, but not as good as Gussies. 

The wait was annoying, but it's brunch, so you deal. I will likely come back for the food if I'm in the area.
author: Charlene D.

description:
I wish I lived closer to this place. I love the staff. I love the ambiance, I love the food.

I would be here at least once a week if only it was within walking distance. 

Southern comfort food at good prices, with good beer.

I usually order the mac & cheese as a entree, and ask them to cook it a little longer. This will make it a little bit more baked, which is more comforting to me :)

My wife likes the chicken a lot. 

We also get the boiled peanuts. These are best when they're boiled long, so the peanuts are runny with the oil of the nuts inside. It's kinda messy, but worth it.

Staff is friendly and welcoming.
author: Shawn S.

description:
http://www.dinersdriveinsdiveslocations.com/the-front-porch-california.html

SF Foodies -- a must try place.

Party of 6 split all the dishes - winter wedge salad, warm spinach salad, farmer's vegan, fried chicken, vegan beans and rice, baked mac & cheese, biscuits.

Corn bread and butter, finished the night with the beignets.
author: Rae Ann D.

description: Yes!!! But too high!!! Will not be going back unless you paying!!!
author: Toia A.

description: Rude workers!!!!!  I picked up my after ordering on the phone came 5 mins prior the time given for the food to be ready and encountered terrible customer service food was okay nothing special
author: Erika E.

description: Wonderful little spot! Delicious food - recommend family style so you can try a bunch of the sides and mains. Charming decor and ambience.
author: Nisha R.

description:
Bucket of fried chicken, fried okra, mac and cheese and the veggie dish.  Yep, good ol' American food.  I do enjoy.

The fried chicken is lightly battered.  Its not as great as Popeye's or Hard Knox, but its still meaty and decent.  The collard greens doesn't blow me away though either.  Taste a bit bitter, but still good.

Fried Okra is delicious, the jalapeno was the bomb.  A must taste.

Mac and cheese, they definitely use good cheddar, but wish it has some toasted bread crumbs on top.

Veggie was decent and the Pimm's cup drink was quite refreshing.  I still would go to this place cuz its got a nice atmosphere.  The lighting is great and the service was good from our waitress.  Though the other staffers are not as smiley, so it kind of brings the mood down.  Cheer up butter cups.  So I have to rate it as an ok.  I still dig a location, so check it out for sure.
author: Janice F.

description: Had Dinner there saturday night and had the Dr. Pepper Braised Short Ribs!  OMG Amazing!! There is nothing on their menu that is not FANTASTIC!!
author: Carl H.

description: The BEST fried pickles!! They come with a spicy sauce that puts them in a world all their own.  The vibe in this place is cooler than cool.  Make sure you wear your "I'm not trying effortless hipster outfit" and you'll fit right in. Also, if you've ever wanted to try alligator go out to the front porch. You'll love this place!!
author: Maisha T.

description: Love the vibe and the food. Been a bunch of times; food occasionally inconsistent so only reason not giving 5 stars. Brunch isn't bad either.
author: F G.

description:
Get the fried chicken!!! I'm not a huge fan of fried chicken, but I am a huge fan of the fried chicken at the front porch.  The biscuits are delicious as well! Definitely get those as a side!

The mashed potatoes and mac and cheese were good, but weren't my focal point of the meal.

Pretty good beer list as well, and the atmosphere / decorations made it a fun experience!
author: Sandeep K.

description: This review is only for the fried pickles. Get them. They're good. There is a great neighborhood vibe too. The cocktails are pretty good and the fried chicken won't disappoint you.
author: Lauren A.

description: Really solid southern food with a California twist. A reliable place to get reservations on Friday and Saturday, too.
author: David S.

description:
Everything I had was amazing. The fried pickles, fired okra, cornbread, fired chicken and the benyas for desert. Amazing. Great service, great atmosphere. I can't wait to go back.

BTW, the fried chicken WAS that good! I think most of these people who didn't like the chicken think KFC is good fried chicken.
author: Biggie V.

description:
Loved everything about this place! The food, ambience, and service was just what I look for when I go out to eat.
I recommend splitting entrees if there are two of you. We shared the smaller fried chicken plate and shrimp and grits; does not get more southern cuisine than that. When we could not decide between one of the dinners or another our server was so helpful and friendly with telling us more about the dishes.
author: Josh S.

description:
So I'm on a search for the best fried chicken in SF.  Well this isn't it. I guess I just can't get my hipster vibe on enough to give this place over 2 stars. 

I had the fig stuffed appetizers C- at best the cheese was bland which then throws the whole balance of this dish off. It is about the sour of the cheese against saltiness of the bacon with sweet date.  If the cheese isn't just filler.  Also the cheese was cold  it should be warm & gooey.  

The chicken was a C at best I have had better in SF. If you factor for the price it isn't even close to the best.  The meat was moist but no real flavor same with the crust. I like my crust to have a little flavor this was bland.

Sides mash potatoes were flavorless and stiff.   Greens were ok chunks of bacon or pork belly always help.  

In the WTF / Why bother category.  They put popcorn on the side of the plate. I'm guessing as a garish. Why they do this I will never know total waste of popcorn & time. At the top of the meal they give you ONE MINI corn muffin it actually looked like they gave me more butter in the little metal container then muffin to spread it on.  In contrast a different fried chicken place in SF gives you 2 full size muffins  now that is what I'm talking about. Also I didn't have much to go on since the muffin was so small but it actually wasn't all that good.

Not worth the trip, the trouble parking and most of all not worth the price!!
author: Kevin C.

description:
I thought this place was ok.  Not great, but it was decent.  Is it the best creole food I have had?  Well, it doesn't compare to Louisiana/New Orleans, I will tell you that, but comeon now, we're in California.  I wasn't expecting to be transported to New Orleans.  

The people there were nice and funny, the atmosphere and decor were casual/cool/chill.  There was a live jazz band that took up a lot of the walking space, but it was cool to see some little kids dancing by them.

So my friend and I decided to share a bunch of things.  they have 5 inch poboys, so we decided to get 3: oyster. pulled pork, and catfish.  I was disappointed when they told me the 5 inch could not be cut in half because it was too small and would fall apart.  I know it would have looked messier than they would have liked, but we had a hell of a time with that butter knife and it was a pain in the butt.  So taste wise, the oyster was the best and was fried really well.  The catfish came in second, fried well, but a little dry.  The pork one  i wasn't really feeling.  I just ate it coz we got it.

We also got fried okra (same batter as the oysters and catfish), red beans and rice (sadly I like popeyes more), and the beignets (very disappointing because they were heavy and not light and fluffy like  i was expecting).

Overall, I am glad I tried it.  If  I were in the area again, I might consider it, but for the price (and it was a bit pricey), I think I would try something else.
author: vanessa t.

description:
Front Porch was one of my first restaurant recommendations in San Francisco, and certainly has the cult following to back it up. It's a southern-fried cajun themed place that serves primarily meat, fried chicken and pork dishes, though there are some deep-friend veggie options if you'd prefer. 

I opted for the pulled pork sandwich, which was tasty, although I expected a little softer bread. (Any southern cooking I've ever had has a lot of love for their buns.)

Points to them for some seriously good thick fries, too many places opt solely for the thinner ones, and Front Porch seasoned theirs just right.

I left feeling satisfied, but not totally blown away. The bartender was decent, and the food was above-average, but I felt like they could have stepped up a bit in a few areas.
author: Kevin B.

description: Cozy hipster spot with lots of charm. The food was good but not memorable for me. I shared the crawfish hush puppies and shrimp and grits and found it to be perfect for 2. The hot sauce was awesome! Definitely recommend resies since seating is very limited.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Would I come back to this place?? Absolutely!! The outside of this restaurant is charming! SO cute! There's a terrace above the main door along with their menu and a couple tables as well. There's even a baby rocking horse! Cute!

Anyways, my boyfriend and I came here for his 28th birthday (7/16/12) to celebrate and have a feast! We were greeted with the seating hostess and she directed us to our table. My first impression as we walked inside the restaurant was that it was very dim-lighted... I mean, very dim-lighted. The bar lighted up the restaurant but not completely. And this place is quite small... The maximum capacity could only probably fit 40-50 people. But I guess that's what makes the restaurant unique and intimate! 

We were seated in a booth and we could see the chefs cook in the kitchen! Our waitress was really nice. Our waitress didn't rush us with our order and made sure that we were taken care of. 

I ordered a Donkey D's Hot Ass Margarita which was smooth and pretty good! It had slices of Jalepeno's and jalepeno juice as well. My bf ordered a "Chilled" Mulled wine which was good too. For our appetizer, we shared the fried pickles with a creamy, spicy aioli sauce! OMG those fried pickles were amazing, My mouth is watering just thinking about them! So crunchy, so juicy. So full of flavor. Our waitress told us that the chef de cuisine pickles their own cucumbers at the restaurant! And the pickles are deep-fried in a beer batter. YUM! 

For our entree, my bf and I both ordered 3 pieces of fried chicken which came with a side of garlic mashed potatoes and collard greens. The chicken was juicy and tender, and the crunchy skin was crunchy, but not greasy. My bf and I thought that there could have been more season though... The garlic mashed potatoes were good, but not great. I did enjoy the collard greens. In fact, that was my first time having collard greens! My bf ordered a side of baked Mac & Cheese and it was good too! It came in a little skillet that was piping hot! Oh yeah, all of our food was piping hot! Great indicator!!!! The Mac & Cheese was flavorful and had a nice creaminess too. I ordered a side of fried corn on the cob with chili lime butter. The corn was tasty and had a little crunch too! The chili lime butter wasn't overwhelming.

Everything was great! Our service was great! The only thing though that was a little iffy was the lighting in the restaurant. I had to use the light on my phone to read the menu... But other than that, I would definitely come back here and experience more of the menu items! This food is definitely "Stick-to-your-ribs" kind of food. :)
author: Francesca H.

description:
Born in SF, raised in Nashville. Try country cuisine in my favorite city? Hell yes! Four of us sat down to eat at 8:30pm on a Thursday night.

We each ordered a cocktail. Each.cocktail.was.brought.to.the.table.one.at.a.time.By.the.time.the.fourth.drink.was.brought... WTH?? Four drinks are ordered so deliver four drinks in one serving. The Porch Swing cocktail was forgettable.

 Bread basket of corn muffins were yummy. Aioli was what? Cheese? Neither spicy or cheesy.. what was in it?

Entree service: Again what's with the serving dishes one at a time??

Shrimp and grits: Don't order. Soupy, fishy grits? Sound appetizing to anyone? They weren't. Shrimp had a "fishy" flavor and the broth was unnecessary. 

Fried chicken: Fucket I'll have a bucket. $17 for 3 pieces, so 2 of us ordered $34 for 9 pieces.  Delicious, crispy chicken with mashed potatoes and gravy. Too many bad reviews about collard greens, so we paid $4 extra for mac and cheese. Pricey, but creamy, cheesy carb-loaded goodness! The 2 others in our party shared in the bucket of chicken, and we still had 2 pieces to take home.

The female server left the check on the table while we were eating. Then she came back and said she could go home early if we paid her now.  Our water glasses were empty, but I guess when you want to go home, then you have other more important things on your mind. Well, by all means, we wouldn't want you to have to stay and wait on us, so we asked for more water and paid the check.

One star for the chicken, one star for the mac and cheese. Y'all come back now, ya hear? Uh, no.
author: Merrilee S.

description:
I had been here and been SUPER impressed for dinner.

Today I tried their brunch and I am happy to report that it was as good, if not even better, than their dinner menu!

My husband got the Hangover Helper and loved it.  I got the baked eggs and grits and it was delicious.

Great food, great service.  You must try it!
author: Amy N.

description:
Yummy chicken and waffles for lunch.  The waffle was a large piece that was fluffy and did not deflate...like some others. The chicken was juicy and moist, though I ate it sans the best part, the breading.   Have it with the Speakeasy red ale and your day is set.  

One good surprise was that I didn't expect the place to be a bar. When I asked the server if they served beer at this time, he responded, " we serve everything." Duh!!!  (Lightbulb and Homer Simpson "D'oh")
author: Marck N.

description: I've been here numerous times,  but for dinner,  and it was great! Service,  food everything, and I wish I made a review wheneverci had a good experience,  although today just left a bad taste... I walked in for brunch,  I was greeted by this woman who looked like the trunchbull (watch Matilda), she sat me at the bar,  after saying it was only me for my party, which is fine I don't mind.  I sat down at the end of the bar,  and this is where my poor experience begins. I have 6 inches of space to place my plate when I get it,  and I have a server stabbing receipts into the receipt holder which will impede on my eating space.  I decided to move to a seat that opened up ( still at the bar). After asking the trunchbull,  Ashley,  if I could sit in a more spacious area,  she made it sound like I was inconveniencing her, but said yes, I took the seat, she began to violently wipe the bar from the previous guests,  and carelessly flung food onto me. I kept my cool,  wiped it off (she never apologized) sat the next guests down, as I was sipping my Bloody Mary,  she decided to bump her chest into my chair to hand menus to the new group..   Bloody Mary on my chin... Oh and even better,  no napkin,  no utensils! The food arrives and it looks like something from ja Rules' cookbook from jail. I am really disappointed in the service over anything.  The hostess just made it that bad.
author: Anonymous T.

description:
Their lunch menu is absolutely FANTASTIC. There was a ton of food and the flavors on everything were outstanding.

My husband lived in Louisiana for a few years and he said it was the best gumbo he's had anywhere outside New Orleans. Now that is saying something.
author: Vanessa J.

description: We were so confused after reading so many reviews that this is a dog-friendly place. We showed up with a friend's dog that we were dog sitting, and had an icy reception from the hostess who said "Oh. You have a dog." We then were lectured about letting them know we had a dog, which we'll remember for next time, if we decide we ever want to come back. The food was all right, great fried chicken but in my opinion, I've had better.
author: Steph S.

description: The coffee was watered down. The biscuits and gravy was possibly low fat if that's possible and were slightly sweet which was a little strange. The beignets were too dense. The fried chicken was good but no better than a chicken chain. The waffle tasted like any batter mix. The highlight was the waitress. She was very good and genuine. The food was also all made fresh. I also liked the used China dishes they use. I usually judge a restaurant on whether I'd want to bring others there to try it. I wouldn't bring people here, but I'm glad I tried it. It's a neighborhood place I kept meaning to try.
author: David H.

description: I went to this place for brunch on a Saturday.  I made reservations, so there wasn't much of a wait.  There were a few groups waiting on the sidewalk, but no worse than most brunch places in SF.  I ordered the chicken and waffles, and my date ordered the shrimp and grits.  We both agreed agreed the food was just okay.  The waffle was heavy and cold, the chicken was so so.  I didn't like the flavor of his shrimp and grits.  They do give pretty hefty portions, but if you don't like the food, it doesn't matter.  We left a good bit of the food on the plate, the host noticed and ended up taking 25% off of our bill, which was nice of him.  The service was good but I wouldn't go back, I wasn't impressed with the food at all.
author: Trenicia W.

description: The power actually went out while we were eating here, which made it a super fun dinner experience! The cornbread muffins are SO GOOD, and the fried chicken is yummy. Drinks were great, as well. Wasn't a huge fan of the vegetarian gumbo.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Our visit was inspired by a voucher I had bought on Bloomspot, but I only bought the voucher after receiving a recommendation from a good friend and fellow foodie.

Everything about the experience was fantastic! Awesome setting - it was as if we had left San Francisco for the night and arrived in the Southeast. Our waitress was super friendly and took good care of us. We had:

-crawfish etoufee (highly reccommend!)
-fried okra (average)
-spicy crab & grits (mostly consumed by my husband but I'm pretty sure he enjoyed it)
-fried chicken (supposedly the best in SF! but I haven't tried enough to make that conclusion. still pretty darn good)
-banana chocolate chip cheesecake (this was possibly the highlight of my night - the best darn cheesecake I have ever had, puts any cheesecake at The Cheesecake Factory to shame!)

We brought our own bottle of wine and thoroughly enjoyed our Friday night at The Front Porch.
author: Jigna P.

description: Very cool little place built out of a residential garage.  Wife took me there for date night and we loved it.  We ordered and shared fried pickles, french fries crawfish etoufe, and 4pc fried chicken, and finished with peanut butter mouse pie.  Everything was delicious!  All of this for two of us to share plus a drink for $55.  This is a great place if you like good southern cooking.  We made reservations for next month before we even finished dinner.
author: Steven B.

description:
So I read alot of reviews before going here and I have to say that I'm so glad I went!!
It was my husband's  birthday and I wanted to try something new. 
First you walk up and it's kinda crazy how little it looks and is.. if I was just driving by I would have thought nothing of it and definitely never noticed it was a restaurant. 
We had great service from beginning to end and never had to wait for anything so maybe some of those reviews of bad service were just random incidents. 
Now to the best part... the food...
DELICIOUS DELICIOUS DELICIOUS and oh wait did I say DELICIOUS...
We had the beignets with powder sugar.. yummoooo
Then we had an order of shrimp and grits which was one of the yummiest things I've ever had. There  were 4 of us so we had a country breakfast, chicken fried steak, chicken and waffels and a shrimp po boy. Nothing was shy of excellent and I was nothing less of a food coma when we rolled out of there stuffed and 100% satisfied!!!!
I highly recommend this place and will definitely be back.
My only tip is too wear a jacket. The front door is open and it's a little place so it was super cold.
author: Angela H.

description: Cannot go wrong with their okra, shrimp and grits, jambalaya, and fried chicken
author: Siddhartha G.

description: Chicken was under cooked, meal was blah and served on plastic. No idea why everyone is so bonkers about this place. Seems over rated to me.
author: Marsh M.

description:
This place is certainly worth a visit if you're in the area. It's got an easy atmosphere and the service is fantastic.

The food, though unique, isn't mindblowing or especially memorable. It's a good place for friends to go and have good conversation over dinner, but the food won't be the main topic. 

Nonetheless, I'll say again that it's certainly worth a visit, because some of the things on their menu I simply have never had or heard of previously. Good beers, too.
author: Pat P.

description:
This place was recommended to me highly after some friends raved about the brunch (which I may still try.) Let's break this down shall we:

1) Service - Not bad. Friendly staff. Being asked if we have a reservation on a Wednesday night while there are tables open is always like a big FUCK YOU, though.

2) Drinks - We ordered a couple Front Porches. I think after the kind of dot com day we all sometimes have, I need stiff drink. This didn't do it for me. I should have known better and just ordered straight bourbon. Meh.

3) Food - For the price of dinner, we should have probably gone to cancun for a better meal. The Prawn Hush Puppies came out first. Meh. They were fine, since we were starving. Dense, not salted enough to even taste what we were eating and requiring hot sauce to enjoy. We ordered the Fried Chicken 3 piece. The chicken was just OK. Not sure if it was the time of night that we rolled in (9pm) but honestly overalll the food was blah. Mashed potatoes were crap. Like really  not buttery fluffy and fabulous like I was looking forward too. Bland from a box type of garbage. 

C'est la vie. Live and learn. Don't go here. Go to Cancun and have fun.
author: Rich_kids_of_yelp Z.

description:
Probably should be 2 1/2 stars, but not possible. I was looking around for some southern comfort food, and this place looked appealing. Supposedly the fried chicken was the best around the city.  
First of all, it's just a little too cramped inside for me. They have  crammed as many tables as they could into this little place. (I can't really fault them for that, I just don't like being able to hear everything other customers are talking about, and people bumping into your table as they pass by). Very claustrophobic feeling. The food is OK, the service is OK. I didn't find that the chicken, although good, was anything special. I expected a lot more for what they were charging. Way overpriced for what you get. I don't mind paying for a great meal, but this isn't it. Also, so not worth the pain in the ass it is to find a parking space. You have to really get lucky to find a place to park in the vicinity of this restaurant. Overall, pretty good waste of money. Would be worth it if the prices were cut in half. Too many choices in the city to have this many concerns.
author: William L.

description: I went here with my grandparents and the customer service was nowhere near that "southern hospitality". The restaurant is southern him style cooked food meets San Francisco hipster. We had a white young lady as a waitress and as soon as my grandparents spoke some Spanish they switched to a Spanish speaking waiter which was alright but I was a little offended because my grandparents speak close to perfect English. The food was not as great as I thought. The fried chicken was pretty great. I can understand why it's rated so high maybe because the rest of their food is absolutely terrible. Their homemade mac n cheese was oily and burned. Their hamburgers tasted like they haven't cleaned the grill in weeks. I was really offended how the waiters treated my family and I. They took forever and tended to the other guests it was just really rude and a little bit racist.
author: Marc H.

description: Made Reservations and came for dinner. We had the Okra, bacon wrapped dates, short ribs and fried chicken. Flavors were bland, the mashed potatoes were horrible and I wish we had gone to KFC.
author: Bill M.

description:
I impressed a hot ass Southern boy by taking him here, so +1 million for that. Those soft biscuits with honey are no joke!

However, their booze is way over priced, and that is a cardinal sin in my book.

Aside from that though, really cool vibe, sassy waitresses and good down homey food.
author: Serena Q.

description: Eh. Went here for my sisters birthday. I think I was expecting more and should have did more research.  We shared a bucket of chicken which was just OK, fried okra with the aioli sauce was nothing to rave about. The dish that stood out the most to me was the shrimp grits. Definitely not a place to go if you're looking to soothe your palate. But if you are in the neighborhood and want to drown your sorrows in overly exaggerated foods, then this is the place to go.
author: Karen A.

description:
This place is totally in the middle of nowheresville, Bernal Heights. Okay fine, not exactly nowheresville since it's just down the block from Mitchell's... but there is almost nothing else around it save for a cramped Safeway round the corner. Came here with some friends for dinner and they allowed us to expand our reservation from 4 to 5 people, which was great, but the service throughout the night was a little spotty. I didn't really like that everyone's dish came out at different times (Asian restaurant-style) and it was really hard to flag someone down for help! This place is so tiny, don't think I can't see you ignoring me! 

I ordered the Farmer's Vegan (a risotto dish) that seemed very promising, but extremely pricey for what it was. I didn't find it to be particularly amazing. It was honestly quite standard and nowhere near as good as the risotto I've had at Nob Hill Grille (they didn't make mine vegan here, in case you were wondering). Disappointment abounds! The fried chicken is of course the star of the show, but I don't expect that I would've had a better experience here had I actually ordered it. Everything was quite pricey for the portions and none of the dishes really jumped out at me as creative or particularly exciting... :( 

If you're looking for a really fabulous restaurant around this area, go to Noeteca instead! Or better yet, fill up at Mitchell's ;)
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Just had brunch here - it was so delightful and amazing. 

French Toast sticks - must have, so good
Baked Egg + Grits - everything about it was so hot and delicious
Fried Chicken + waffles - chicken was flavorful and juicy

The brunch really exceeded my expectations. Need to come back soon!
author: Jenny L.

description: First time I'd ever been here. Seen it packed tons of times so thought it must be good. Took a look at the menu and tried the shrimp & grits also the Stoner which was a take on Croque Monsieur but fell flat. The Stoner had a dry biscuit, little gravy, over easy was over hard on the egg and the potatoes were over cooked. The grits were watery and looked nothing like the Yelp pic. Sad really as I had high hopes, alas I won't be returning. Nice service though.
author: Victor G.

description:
Finally, after years of hearing about the fried chicken, I came here with a few friends for a celebratory dinner and had a fantastic time.  Some of us enjoyed drinks such as the Georgia Peach made with Pimm's no 1, lemon, Bunderberg peach soda with Fee Bros. peach bitters and the Jake & Ginger made with Ketel 1 & moonshine, handmade ginger/lemon syrup.  

The table shared the lolla rosa mixed green salad with heirloom tomatoes, avocado, lemon cucumbers, buttermilk-herb dressing & brioche croutons, shrimp & grits with wild gulf shrimp, garlic, shallots, bacon & wild mushroom truffle ragout, a bucket of fried chicken starring rocky jr. chicken with garlic mashers & gravy, collard greens & bacon, grilled sweet tea brined porch chop with corn bacon hash, green tomato relish & crispy vidalia onions and the baked mac & cheese.  Everything was delicious.  The chicken was as good as everyone told me it was and we loved the popcorn that was thrown into the bucket also.  The pork chop was thick and juicy.  The mac & cheese was off the hook.  The cute little corn muffins were tasty with the butter.  I haven't a clue what the butter was mixed with but it was good.

The only problem was the extremely loud table behind us.  One person in their party was a bit shrill for about 80% of our meal.  We could barely hear the table on the other side of us.  The acoustics in the place was just bizarre.

Oh, and the place DOES have a TV so I was able to sporadically keep an eye on the Giants during the NLCS.
author: J. P.

description: Excellent vibes, great service and delicious food. Definitely coming back for more. I love shrimp & grits!
author: Harold C.

description:
We found this gem the other night cruising around for some fried chicken.  I must say we were blown away.  Fried chicken had a great crust, skin was crispy and fat rendered down correctly.  The meat was tender, juicy, and seasoned perfectly.  Hands down one of my new favorites.  The greens that came with the dish are tender and seasoned, but still had a little bite to them, not the overcooked mush you get from other Southern kitchens.  

Hushpuppies came out fresh from the fryer, packed with crawfish.  Only disappointing thing we had were the deviled eggs which  were a little salty and had too much mustard IMO.  Service was casual and super friendly.  They put us at ease immediately and were on point.  i love when the front of the house knows their business - makes the mea -l and these guys were great.

Drinks were great, food was awesome, and staff helpful and friendly.  Coming back for sure.
author: Tom T.

description:
I suppose if you've never had legit creole food, this place is good.I had the chicken and waffles. the waffles had jalapeño and bacon which was pleasantly different. Chicken was burned, I suggest turning the fire down before frying, and seasoning with some Tony's. I'm not a professional chef, but I lived in New Orleans for some years so I suppose I have some merit. 

I scolded a customer who was sitting next to me that did not finish her salad when she was on a date. I figured it was pretty rude that she ordered food and wasted it, especially if her significant other paid for it. But then my sister ordered the salad. Do not order the salad. I don't know how someone could mess up salad, but this place did. 

2 stars for the sweet tea.
author: Tyla B.

description: We've been to this place so many times already. This review is past due :-) We order their fried chicken, with mash potatoes, and collard greens. It is mouth watering good. Its crispy, juicy, tender inside, and soooo flavorful. Their garlic masher are soooo yummm...their collard green are such a good addition to go with the fried chicken.  We are never disappointed, and it is consistently good every single time. We have tried their hush puppies, hmmm sooooo good. Their fried okra, beyond belief good, and their mac and cheese also very very good. The best customer service, and the best food. We ALWAYS enjoy our time there. I wish they open a branch next to where I live :-) If you're craving for fried chicken, its your place to go!
author: Fatimah Q.

description:
A little taste of heaven. 


So cute from the outside, and crazy crowded on the in. 

Their Mac n cheese will make you want to sin, and thei mashed potatoes are just as deadly. 

Now considering I'm a pescatarian, this review is not going to be helpful to all you meat-eaters of the world. 

But I did have their sauteed wild gulf flounder with spring succotash, potato croquettes, fava beans and a green garlic beurre blanc, and MAN was it tasty. So tasty I didn't want to leave the place, I just wanted to keep on trying everything that I could on the menu. 


And love that they serve old school root beer out of the bottle.
author: Renae B.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place for a long time now.  I've heard nothing but good things about their fried chicken.  I came here with Lester W. during MLK weekend for dinner.  We called ahead to make sure they had tables available, and it was a good thing we did because the place started filling up once we sat down.

We started out with the Gumbo with Andouille Sausage, Okra and Seafood.  And then of course we had to get the Fried Chicken.  We also ordered a side of the Mac & Cheese.

I usually don't order gumbo, so I don't have much to compare this to.  But I think this was the best gumbo I've had so far.  They put a good amount of ingredients in it, so you're not digging around to find the sausage or seafood.  It was so good, we practically licked the bowl clean.

The fried chicken is to die for!  This was by far the best fried chicken I've had.  The meat was super juicy and the skin was crispy and well seasoned.  The greens and mashed taters were a great compliment to the dish.  The mac & cheese was just ok.  I have had better elsewhere.  But I can overlook that tid bit because the fried chicken made up for it.

The service was very good and parking was pretty easy to find.  I will definitely be back to try more dishes...and the fried chicken!
author: Patra I.

description:
I love the atmosphere of this cave-like spot. The southern inspired menu is good, although lately I've gotten into scrutinizing fried chicken and the version here is good, but not the best I've experienced. Miss Ollie's in Oakland (whose owner started out at The Front Porch) is hands down better. 

Great cocktail program and atmosphere will bring me back for a drink.
author: Lee H.

description:
I was looking for a brunch spot in the Bernal area and happened to come across this place via yelp. It was a little tricky to spot because the building looked like a house but we figured it out quickly enough. 

Out front it definitely feels like a front porch, which is quaint, and when we walked inside, it was super dark and felt more like a bar that serves food rather than a restaurant with a bar. Overall though I really liked the aesthetic and once my eyes adjusted to the low light I grew to like the ambiance.

My girlfriend and I both ordered the chicken and sweet potato waffles, which seems to be our test of a brunch spot that has that on the menu.  The waffle was pretty spot on and the chicken was really moist but the breading was a little lackluster.  All together it was an excellent meal and we will definitely go back and try other items.
author: sergio a.

description: It was pretty cool but guy ferrari made it look extra delicious but it wasnt. But overall really nice atmosphere and very kid friendly!
author: Nae F.

description: The place rocks! We found this place on Yelp and made a reservation (good idea). We got a seat in the rocking chairs outside on the 'front porch' area.  The weather was nice too.  Great local vibe.  The food is amazing.  We had the braised short ribs and the fried chicken with collards and mashed potatoes.  Try the biscuits too, they have this awesome butter (sweet with rosemary i believe).  The chicken took a while but it's worth the wait.  It probably the best i've had (don't tell my friend that).  It has a little kick and the crunchiness it the best. They offer hot sauce, but I didn't need it.  We were pleasantly surprised.  The customer service was very good too.
author: Vince A.

description: Fried chicken is bomb. Thats really the main staple I thought upon sampling most dishes. Decor and attitude are legit
author: Lenny K.

description: The best chicken and waffles ever! Great service' ! Will be back for sure. Never wanted for anything! Friend had a delicious Bloody Mary and a Bacon, Cheddar, Chicken and Egg on a fabulous housemade biscuit. Really enjoyed the day
author: Jane M.

description:
Re: the fried chicken - It makes me want to take off my shirt and rub my breasts with my grease-coated hands.
Re: the mac and cheese - It makes me want to do something similar to the above with cheese grease, with the caveat that the hottest lumberjack in the room eat it off me.
Re: the fried pickles - Well, we don't have to go there.

Who knew I took food porn so literally? This is beginning to feel like that sad episode of The Drew Carey Show about the refrigerator.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
Cocktails: modern, bright flavors
Fried okra: yum.
Fried Pickles: next time
Ribs: falling-apart, tender
Fried Chicken - crunchy, juicy, home-style
Ambiance: cozy, casual, relaxed.
Service: friendly

I'll be back...
author: Miz J.

description:
Discovered this through TripleD. The food was amazing! We had the dr. Pepper beef braised short ribs, Mac and cheese, red beans and rice, fried chicken and corn bread. 
The Dr. Pepper braised short ribs melts in your mouth. The beef pulled apart so gently and the collard greens with the mashed potatoes were a great pairing.
The Mac and cheese was the best I'd ever had. I loved the crispy top. I loved the cheesiness of how when you pulled the noodles apart the cheese spread into this oooey gooey ness! 
The fried chicken was so crispy and moist. Definitely the best I'd ever had! We got the 4 piece meal and substituted the collared greens for the Mac and cheese and it was a 2 dollar difference and it was the full side if Mac and cheese. So instead of spending 8 dollars I spent 2 dollars! 
The complimentary corn bread and herbed butter was moist and the perfect size!
The red beans and rice with andouille was okay. I would of been fine with out it.
I will definitely be back again the next time I visit SF from LA! 
Thank you Guy Fieri  for coming here!
author: Cathy D.

description:
We really wanted to like this place after seeing Guy Fieri's glowing review of the Front Porch on DDD. What we encountered was a series of "misses" that added up to a disappointing and mediocre experience. 

First of all, we had a 9PM reservation on a Saturday night. We waited about half an hour for our table. I recognize that a restaurant can't predict how long a group will keep a table, so I cut them some slack on this one. The host was very polite and kept us apprised of the status of our table. 

Next, the space itself resembles a dark, windowless cave with sound bouncing off every wall. Hardly a Southern comfortable atmosphere. 

Next, the server took our drink orders. I asked for a mojito and was informed that the restaurant doesn't stock fresh mint. Really? A Southern comfort restaurant with a full liquor license doesn't have fresh mint for Mint Juleps & Mojitos? I found this particularly odd given that one of the menu items was a salad CONTAINING mint. Do they use dried mint? I don't blame the server. It just seems like a dickish policy on the part of the management. 

Next, the server brought cornbread. Only they were itsy bitsy mini cornbread muffins - more like cornbread bites than muffins. They were not only dried out but actually stale - as in not fresh. The sage butter wasn't of much help. 

Wanting to avoid a lot of deep fried food, we ordered the $9 chopped salad with Green Goddess dressing & a side of biscuits, which we asked to be brought out with the salad. The salad was fresh and crisp but had almost no flavor and none of the savory goodness of good house made Green Goddess dressing. The biscuits weren't brought out until after we had finished the salad. I saw the server nudge the kitchen staff several times but it did no good. The biscuits themselves were quite decent & were served with sage butter & a tasty strawberry syrup. Probably the best food of the evening. 

Taking Guy Fieri's recommendation, we ordered two of the Front Porch's signature dishes: the Dr. Pepper braised beef short ribs & the spicy shrimp with grits. The 5 medium sized shrimp sitting in a puddle of grits & mildly spicy sauce were acceptable but nothing special. For $23.50 I expect better. The braised short ribs were dry, stringy, and flavorless. Even dipping the meat in the sauce didn't relieve the meat's dry stringiness. The short ribs were simply cooked to death. Or as my friend exclaimed, practically hurt, "I can't believe they killed the meat". Definitely overpriced at $24.

Now I know that restaurants can have off nights. But botching both of the signature dishes? And on a Saturday night? Not a good sign. I guess that's why the servers were trying to steer everyone towards the fried chicken. I guess they knew something. 

I give the restaurant two stars because the service was efficient and attentive. But I won't return to the Front Porch. Brenda's on Polk sets a high bar for Southern comfort/Soul food in this city and this place just doesn't stack up.
author: moncho b.

description:
Front Porch fans, be warned:  I just didn't get it.

Maybe it was all the hype that I'd built up in my mind from reading stellar Yelp reviews, but I wasn't as impressed with TFP as I'd thought I would be.

I'm not a fried chicken fan, but I've had excellent fried chicken before (Blue Plate dished up THE BEST I've ever had).  Sadly, it wasn't at TFP.  The meat was very moist, but it severely lacked flavor.  Maybe it was an off night?

I've grown to like collard greens Southern-style, but I didn't like the way they served theirs.  It was overpowered by a very strong sour taste.

I ordered the Farmer's Market, which I think changes every so often; it's usually seasonal vegetables in some form.  Last night, it was chopped root veggies and rice cooked in a tomato broth, then served with some cabbage slaw on top.  The best way I can describe this is a really dense vegetable-and-rice stew.. pureed.  It was good, but since it was the only thing on my plate, became too one-note for me.  I would've preferred a plate of veggies in that delicious broth, with a side of rice.

The only things I absolutely loved about TFP were the service, the ginger beer, and BF's mashed potatoes from his fried chicken.  If parking had been harder, I would've probably deducted a star from this place.
author: Tori S.

description:
The only fried food I like is fried chicken. It's a shame really b/c there are so many good fried foods out there but as I get old the greasier the food the harder it is to digest. Growing up in Michigan I had my fair share of fried chicken and remember ordering buckets of it for family picnics. This little Cajun style restaurant makes you feel like you are going over to a friend of a friend's house that has weird decor and lay out of their house. The booth I sat in was an old van seat equipped with a seat belt in case my eating got out of control and I needed to be buckled in.

We luckily beat the rush and I'm finding I'm eating dinner the same time my grandma does to be an hour long wait sometimes.

We had the side of macaroni and cheese - multiple oozing cheeses. I also had the fried chicken in a bucket. Not just any bucket but a popcorn bucket mixed with actual popcorn. I also had garlic mashers or mashed potatoes and gravy with collard greens. I had to wash everything down with a sweet tea. The seasoning on the food was good with a Cajun, southern flavor - savory but not spicy (must add your own Tabasco). 

A serious clog to the arteries but I enjoyed every bite I took. Sometimes I wish I had more than one stomach, like a cow...
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Considering all the hip brunch spots in SF that require standing in line for like 1.5 hours just to be seated (as you do in SF for some reason), why not come here??? They take reservations! (What a novel brunch idea in this town!)

Plus, you can get some really tasty dishes! My only complaint was that the inside (the outside was full, but gets nice am sunshine!) was a bit dark and cold for brunch, but whatever-- the food delivered.

Chicken and waffles was excellent. I didn't not find the waffle flavorless like other yelpers did. It had a really great and complementary wheaty thing going on that suits the savory nature of the fried chicken. I also really liked the pork belly with sweet potato and eggs. It is not a HUGE portion, but so rich that it is completely enough. Salty... but in a good way.

Need brunch without the wait???? Come here! I think you'll be pleasantly surprised. 

(They could use freshly squeezed OJ, however).
author: Katie B.

description:
Oh yeah honey, you gotta get in here and get you some fried chicken...it's damn tasty!

Totally unassuming spot - I've strolled past it on more than one occasion on my way up the street for 'Good Frickin Chicken' - now I'm mad that I wasted my chicken dollahs up the street when I could have been having this!

Came for an early dinner (make reservations, this place gets super packed!) and sat at the booth in the front. The space is small and narrow, but they managed to fit a bar and plenty of seating. The decor reminds me of a down-home country home, complete with a tin ceiling!

Their motto should be followed, "Fu@k it, get a bucket." Seriously, get the bucket! For $34 bux, you get a ton of their amazingly delicious fried chicken, and a dish of greens and garlicky mashed potatoes and gravy. This fed three of us with no problem (waitress said the meal was more for two people - must be some pretty hungry people!).

MUST get the bread pudding - yeah...so tasty! 

Service was great and our waitress was super friendly. Gotta go back for shrimp and grits and hushpuppies...must. exercise. moderation!
author: Christy L.

description: I really wanted to love this place, after coming here 3 times I can honestly say that I don't. For the price you are paying for a bucket of fried chicken and popcorn I was expecting to be blown away; I wasn't. Their mac and cheese was alright, the only thing I really loved was the collared greens, they were actually pretty good. Everything else was just... Ok. The ambiance is cool and laid back, the service was pretty good as well. Hopefully they can add some new entrees to the menu in the future, but until then I don't think we'll be coming back.
author: michelle t.

description:
Rocking chairs on the porch, hospitality & charm that would make the south proud, and no separation between bar & eating area. This place gets my vote.

A waiter led me to our table for two by taking me by the hand & pulling out my chair. Chivalrous, much? The Front porch knows what they're doing: a Bob Marley track was playing, there are multiple window frames on the Tiffany blue walls & the waitstaff are super laid back. My senses were thanking me & we hadn't even ordered yet.

* sweet tea- the perfect way to wash down...
* their complimentary corn bread in the shape of corn on the cob (flavorful, a little dense) & fried okra appetizer (the okra flavor was fresh & came through because the batter was so light & crispy)
* small plate: gumbo with seafood (spicy & thick, but the dark color reminded me of "champorrado," filipino chocolate rice; i guess i'm used to gumbo being reddish brown, not blackish-brown, but the flavor was still spot-on good)
* the best friend & I both opted for their special: filet mignon with crispy potatoes (bernaise sauce was amazing, steak was unbelievably tender)

Everything about TFP appeals to me & makes me excited for a second visit sometime in the very near future. I loved that the restaurant is so dim & quirky. Their prices are very reasonable (I believe our entire dinner was under $100) & our waitress, Carrie, was a doll.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Without a doubt, one of the best places in the city for fried chicken. But the surprise really lies in the oh-so-amazing pecan pie.  Any half decent pie lover in the city has to absolutely make the pilgrimage to The Front Porch for some of their pecan pie topped with Mitchell's vanilla ice-cream and cry tears of joy for the existence of such magnificence!  I'm grateful for the Pi Day for introducing me to this deliciousness!
author: Jyotshna K.

description: My last night in San Francisco some of my family members and friends met here for dinner. We made reservations. We had a few appetizers, although for the life of me, I can't remember them all. Frito pie (got a lil spice to it), étouffée (pretty tasty), and bacon wrapped dates with goat cheese (sweet and salty and very cheesy). 4 people had chicken, my friend had the holy shit burger, and I had the crab and andouille sausage. For dessert, we had the beignets, apple cobbler, brioche bread pudding, and pecan pie. No complaints there. :) All the food was good and we had a great time.
author: Melissa A.

description: The fried chicken was overrated. Not bad, but overrated.
author: Jess C.

description:
This place wasn't that bad. I like the area and I didn't have to wait that long to be seated. They had their own style of the restaurant and the decor made you really feel like you're sitting at "The Front Porch"...
 The food I ordered was Chicken and Waffles which I automatically ordered right when I was seated, because it specifically said on the menu that it will take about 25mins to be served. The chicken was good but the waffles need more work. If you're going to have a "Chicken and Waffle" in your menu at least try to compete with all the other restaurants. the FAMOUS dish called ChIcken & Waffle is in its own class. You have to make them delicious especially if you have it on the top of your main entree on the menu. The waffle was dry and just tasted like bread. I also ordered the beignets which was nowhere close to the other biegnets Ive had in those "soul food" restaurants. Step your game up! 
 Unique location and decor but the most important is the dish. Make sure they are really delicious. I just give it 50/50. Taste somewhat good, but ehhh..
author: Jon R.

description:
Had dinner here on a Monday night. Good fried chicken, though I liked what I'd had at Range (about two weeks prior) much better. Baked mac & cheese and bacon-wrapped dates made up the full meal. 

Good portions, good quality, good scene. Just didn't think it was stellar. Would I go back?...I might, though there are so many good options in the city. I'll be sampling other places before a return trip here.
author: A M.

description:
So sad to say, this place does not live up to expectation. 

The good:  ok, the Mac n cheese was very tasty, hot and bubbly.  The coffee was hot and the service was great.

The bad: Fried okra was very slimy on the inside.  I couldn't eat it- made my stomach turn.  

The ugly: Fried chicken was not crunchy at all and very fatty: the skin was sort of mushy and slid off the chicken.  Honestly, one bite into the drumstick and I could barely swallow it down.
author: R D.

description: Can't say anything but good about their fried chicken. Really awesome. However the rest of experiences would prevent me from coming back to this place. We got an appetizer of chips and dips and it felt like a rip off when chips arrived in the bag like from the 7/11 with 2 ounces of 3 "special" dips for over $10. WTH? Is it a joke? We were also seated at the table separated by a cutrain from bathrooms. Really? Really. Those observations did not sink in till later on, after we ordered. I would suggest to look at pictures of menu before you order and demand to switch tables if seated next to the facilities. Personally, I am not coming back. Many more places to visit.
author: Natalya O.

description:
Brunch at the Front Porch in Bernal Heights was simply outstanding. We stopped in on a rainy Saturday morning, took a couple of seats at the bar and put down a pint of Anchor IPA while we perused the menu.  Everything sounded so good we ordered practically one of everything...

By far the best dish was the fried chicken and waffles. Juicy and brined fried chicken, the thigh was my favorite and the waffles were so soft and melt-in-your-mouth good.  We loved the dish so much we ordered a second order of waffles!

The  fried okra was excellent, it was lightly battered and fried crispy, the sauce it was served with added a nice creamy dimension to the dish.

My friend Dan ordered the shrimp and grits, which were excellent.  It was served in a dark, brown gravy like sauce, kind of like a grits meets etouffee recipe.

The muffaletta sandwich was good, but not quite what I'm accustomed to from New Orleans.  Although the ham and cured meats were great and their homemade giardiniera was awesome, the bread was too light and flaky to absorb the vinegar and oils from the pickled vegetables and melted cheese.  If they served it on a thicker bread, this sandwich would be amazing.
 
The only dish we didn't particularly care for was the red beans and rice, which I thought lacked flavor and contained a lot of red kidney beans, where I prefer pinto beans.  

The other great part about our meal was the southern band playing.  Band playing southern. Ghost pepper hot sauce was amazing...nice 

Finally, a good tip for the non-tasters/hot sauce fiends out there...they have a secret super hot sauce that they serve only upon request called the "Ghost Pepper Sauce."  This sauce was potent, but the flavor and complexity in it are rare. If you are glutten for punishment, but want a special treat, then this sauce is for you.
author: Pete V.

description: The Front Porch literally has a front porch! The decor consists of a lot of antique rocking chairs that one of my friends used to own. Great service. So many eye catching, mouth watering things on the menu. My boyfriend and I got the bacon wrapped dates for our app. We shared the 4 piece fried chicken with collard greens and mashed potatoes. Added a side of Mac n cheese and we were set for the night. It looked like less food than we normally have but we were stuffed! If you are in the Bernal Heights area and want delicious, perfectly crispy fried chicken drop by the Front Porch.
author: Trina C.

description: I loved this place! I ordered the four- piece fried chicken. Wow. So good. Good sized portions and reasonably priced. I also tried the bacon and jalapeño deviled eggs. Also a fan! The atmosphere is cute, quirky, and eclectic. My recommendation is to make a reservation, because it's pretty busy and small. Because of that, it's a bit loud, but a fun atmosphere. There's a cute porch you can sit on also. There's a full bar. Drinks came a bit slow. I got the watermelon ricky. It was ok. I also tried the white wine pairing for the fried chicken. It was very good. I would definitely go back to this place!
author: Cynthia C.

description: Family went by for a quick bite before heading to the airport.  Best pit stop ever.  We started with the gumbo and the bacon wrapped deep fried dates. The dates were like little drops of warm kisses.  I had the infamous pork chop dish.  It was so tender and packed with so much flavor.  My wife had the shrimp and grits which were fantastic as well.   My daughter order the mac and cheese.  She's not much of an eater at 2 but she enjoyed the few bites.  Daddy and mommy happily finished her leftovers.  Delicious all around.  Wish we were able to drink as they had an amazing beer list.  We'll be back for sure. Lived up to the hype.  No hype, just plain ol good.
author: Edison S.

description:
A lot of times when we are feeling down, the first thing a lot of us thing about consuming is comfort food. Comfort food can be different from person to person, usually my favorite comfort foods are a nice piping hawt bowl of nuuuudos or some yummy dessert! However cravings emerge for fried chicken, collard greens and mashed potatoes.

Front Porch is a combination of a bar and and old school diner with booths and a porch outside that would be perfect to eat on when the sun is outside. Ive been here twice now and what has drawn me back and will continue to draw me back again will be the fried chicken. 

Front Porch's fried chicken is amazing, the best way to get the full experience is 
 to take a bite and let the swirl of flavors but i shall try and describe it. . The skin is very crunchy  and the batter is pure perfection, not too much and not too little. The chicken itself is very flavorful and tender. Its a guaranteed that there won't be any leftover chicken anytime soon.
