The chicken comes with a nice side plate of their baked mac n cheese is another popular fav, this is probably my first time having mac n cheese baked! Mac n Cheese might be simple for some people but sometimes simple is better! The blend of cheese they use are great and the elbows are not overcooked. 

On to more fried items, this is the first place i have had Fried Pickles and Fried Okra. These lil fried goodies went great with the aioli sauces that came with them. I would skip the merlitons, they weren't anything spectacular. Other than that everything else i have tried here is really scrumptious. 

Recently i came back bringing with me two of my fav LA yelpers Ms. Fia R and Daniel L and they thoroughly enjoyed the food here at Front Porch! Awesome food with Awesome company, can't ask for anything better than that. 

On a side note i will be back for Brunch sometime! :D
author: Jonathan W.

description:
On Saturday night a friend told us about this incredible burger he had from The Front Porch. He showed us pictures and described it in detail. My mouth watered, CP drooled on me and I knew we had to stop here on our way out of town Sunday afternoon. The place is so cute and I love the rocking chairs out front. It's a little dark inside but we managed. 

Sunday means brunch so it's a whole different menu. I realized this after we sat down. No burger for us. But don't worry about me. I was dedicated to having a huge freaking meal here. CP had the breakfast sandwich. I had the fried chicken and waffle. We shared some sausage and grits. We drank the coffee as fast as it was coming.

The food took a little while but they had given us a proper heads up in the menu (fried chicken is at least 25 minutes). Everything was very tasty. CP's sandwich was so good. The biscuit holding it together was saturated with the eggy goodness and falling apart. It was mostly a fork and knife situation. The sausage was less breakfast sausage and more kielbasa or something but it was very good. Grits are one of my favorite foods and these were winners. I just poured the whole bowl into my mouth (not really true). Fried chicken and waffles is a great meal. And I've had some great versions at many awesome restaurants. This one was pretty good but I've definitely had better. I think the sticking point was the waffle. It was missing something. Still great! Don't get me wrong. Just not the best. 

This place is groovy and it looks like it becomes quite the spot at night. I can see the draw for sure and I hope I can try that heart attack inducing burger sometime!
author: Tai F.

description:
Finally made it out for a solid 3.5 star experience. We arrived at 7:30 on a Weds night and had a 20 min wait (they said - it ended up being 35-40 min) for a table of 3. We killed time at the bar, rapidly losing precious degrees of body temperature as the front door to the front porch didn't really close as people continually walked in and out. The cocktails were a little heavy on the herbs for me - I found the lillita too minty, but liked the lana lee sweet tea, although it was a little weak.

I was pretty disappointed to find that the complimentary cornbread seems to be a thing of the past. We shared the fried chicken, catfish (fried), and the short ribs. The short ribs were the worst of the bunch - they were overly fatty and still tough rather than tender. We subbed in fries instead of mashed potatoes, and they were excellent - one of the highlights of the meal, although the aioli with them was spicier than I would have liked. 

The catfish was a pretty good chunk of meat. I'm no hush puppy expert, but I found these to be tasty, although overly dense. The coleslaw was bland but inoffensive - similar to the sweet potato fries. I liked the chicken - a single order came with a small but meaty breast, wing, drum, and thigh. I thought the breast was well cooked, but the thigh was overdone. I quite enjoyed the vinegary greens with the rich mashed potatoes, although I wished the latter had had more texture.

The trio of sorbets from mitchell's were outstanding. We also had the ginger bread pudding with pumpkin ice cream for dessert. While the concoction was denser than I was expecting, it wasn't overly gingerly. The texture was reminiscent of fruitcake, which was unusual.

One thing that was nice was that all of the dishes seemed to be appropriately sized - I thought we'd have tons of food leftover for three people, but it actually turned out pretty well. Overall I enjoyed the experience but wouldn't particularly come back.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Man, where should I start. So we made reservations at 9 pm on Friday, March 7th, 2014 and were seated at 9:20. No problem, it was a Friday night and pretty crowded. We are very nice and laid back people. We were seated and immediately we knew there would be an issue b/c our waitress (tall lady with a british accent, dark hair and miniskirt) obviously DID NOT want to be there. She took our order and brough the first two appetizers. Pretty good. Then came the waiting game. A half an hour went by and no one, but another very nice girl who was helping around with the tables, came by to see how we were doing. 10 pm no food, no drinks. Our waitress finally shows up again and is obviously under the influence of something, maybe that's where she was for the last half hour. She had those high/drunk sleepy eyes and seemed a lot less stressed out about having to serve humans. I know those eyes! Well, she finally brough the food and disappeared for another half an hour :/

We signaled the other very nice lady to come help us and she brought us the check and apologized for our waitress' lack of service/courtesy. Our waitress pops up to collect payment...

The bill was $192.00 and we gave her 3 credit cards for $55 each and one $100 bill. She comes back with $28 effing dollars change and disappears again. We never told her to keep any tip b/c we were going to leave that with the change from the $100. We had some time to ponder on why she would do this.
15 minutes goes by and she dissapeared again!!!! She finally shows back up, we tell her that she owes us about $50 and she says, and I quote, " Oh! I know what happened. The change got mixed up with." No face of confusion at all, just an immediate "oh damn I got caught and here is the excuise that I pre-fabricated in case I GET CAUGHT!" 

WTF?!!
EFFING SERIOUSLY???? SHE TRIED TO ROB US WITHOUT A MASK.

I will NEVER EVER EVER EVER go to this restaurant again. The "service" was probably the worst I've ever experienced in SF and it was incredibly unpleasant.

Sad, because we loved the ambiance of the place and the food was pretty good. BUT even the most delicious meal in the world accompanied with a side of "Slap in the face" and attempted robbery doesn't warrant an applause in the least.
author: Themane D.

description: The brunswick stew. Jesus. So good. I don't know if they always have it on their menu, but if they do... get it.
author: Jessie L.

description: Atmosphere is great and I want so bad to like the food, but I just don't- sorry. Maybe I'm just used to fresher and lighter food and so the richness of southern cooking is too much for my stomach but I just can't say it's for me. Super cute spot tho- get a drink and app and then maybe move along!
author: Merritt K.

description:
Oh my heart attack, this is the place for it AND it's worth it!  Our Sunday reservation was at 6pm and we pushed it back to 6:30pm. Upon arrival, we ordered the fried okra, the devils on horseback, and a bucket of fried chicken.

The okra was good, but nothing that knocked my socks off. The devils on horseback, well, bacon and oysters. Even bad, it's good. Last, the fried chicken. One bite and I was in pure ecstasy. There was collective silence as we crunched our way through the bucket. Sigh...finger licking goodness, but consume in moderation!

Overall, good service, friendly staff, and fried chicken that is to "die for." On the other hand, the cocktails need improvement as well as the disappointing beer selection.
author: Sophie C.

description: 3.5 for food. 2 stars for service. Had a reservation for 7 at 130. Got there at 115, seated at 155. Ordered at 2. Food arrived at 250. I get that our party was big but they easily could have seated us outside. Instead, they gave it to a party that just walked up. Free beignets for us upon being seated but they weren't that good. Not coming back.
author: Lauren C.

description:
Simple and straight forward

For brunch,

Biscuits were dense. 
Cornbread was okay 
Fried pickles were fun to eat (I never had them before)
Fried chicken bucket and mac & cheese are the way to go. (the popcorn in the bucket was meant for show; i'm assuming because they were stale)

My friends order the shrimp&grits and gumbo, each looked appetizing. Overall it was relaxing and a good experience.
author: John K.

description: Everything is good here and I'm so glad we discovered it. You'll start with a cornbread app to tie you over while waiting for bacon wrapped dates, perfectly fried corn on the cobb, and tender collared greens to match a bucket of fried chicken. Don't forget the hot sauce! Not too spicy, but full of flavor.
author: Calvin W.

description: Best damn fried chicken ever. Service was great and everything was super tasty. Parking there is awful, so plan ahead. Plus the drinks are very very good, but damn they add up fast.
author: Da V.

description: The food here was worth 4 stars but the lower rating is due to the practices of one of the cooks. We sat in the back section of the Front Porch after getting seated quickly. We went around 11am today (Saturday) for brunch. My hubby ordered the country breakfast which he was happy with except for the consistency of how the bacon was cooked. I ordered the very yummy and satisfying Sweet Potato and Pulled pork hash. Much to our dismay, after our delicious meal, my husband noticed that the one cook in the kitchen repeatedly was touching his hair in between touching food/cooking. Gross! My husband reported it to the server who said she mentioned it to the cook. Disappointed and grossed out, we left after paying our bill.
author: Keri M.

description:
I've been here twice in a span of about three years and the food has great overall. The most recent trip a few weeks back I had the gumbo - a quite spicy one at that!  The other time before, I had the fried chicken and although it was very good, it didn't quite hit the bar I was expecting.

The service has been excellent on each occasion but for some reason this place always seem cold on the inside. Maybe it's because both visits were during the winter but it'd be nice if it was a bit warmer during the meal.
author: Art O.

description: Awesome gumbo!  A real southern joint with a pretty waitstaff.  Usually busy cause its so good!
author: Mike K.

description: Wow , lthe Front Porch is homey , delicious and friendly . Great food , pretty and yummy deserts. Not greasy , but super moist fried chicken . The servers are genuinely friendly without being intrusive , they are fun , but also so professional , and helpful . Everything I've tried here is wonderful
author: kim h.

description:
34 bucks for a 9 piece bucket of chicken. You're thinking, WTF!!!

I was thinking the same thing but based on the reviews and b/c it's in San Francisco (one of the best cities for dining), I decided to give this place a go. Actually, my fiancee set this up for an early bday dinner so who am I to say no to a free meal?? lol

With this 9 piece bucket meal, it came with mashed potatoes and collard greens.The sides were pretty good. The greens had a lot of vinegar, which I don't mind too much b/c that's the style but some people may not like it that way. The mashed potatoes had good texture and was pretty good.

But it's all about the chicken. There are a few types of dishes that I hold a pretty high standard for b/c I have eaten a lot of it at various places throughout the country. This list includes steak, jambalaya and of course fried chicken.

You get 2 pieces per body part (2 breasts, 2 wings, 2 thighs, 2 legs). For the 9th piece, you just roll the dice to see what part they give (no place gives breasts). I used to work at Popeye's fyi =) 

However, upon tackling my last piece, I noticed an extra breast!!! They hooked it up with 3 breasts. I am a "breast man" ahem so I was happy.

I did ask the waiter how many breasts came in the bucket and she said  "usuallly two". I worried a bit b/c I wanted to make sure I had at least 2 in there but the extra one made me burst out with tears of joy!! Okay that's exagerrating but you get the point.

Since one from the bay area cannot go to New Orleans for the best fried chicken, this place doesn't take a back seat. It takes 25 minutes to make since they make it "to order", which is fine by me. All the more delicious.
author: James K.

description: I wanted to try this restaurant after seeing the episode of Drive-in, Diners and Dives.   When we got there, you can see there isn't a lot of seating.  That's why we were told the wait would be an hour or more.  ***Special Tip = we found out they take reservations.   I would definitely recommend making a reservation instead of being a walk-in like we were.****   Luckily,  we got there as the next meal shift was happening and we were the first ones on the waiting list.  We were finally sat after about a 40 min wait.  We immediately ordered the beignets to start as well as their fried okra.  Both were very good, especially the beignets.   For our meal, our kids shared an order of the chicken fried steak,  my wife had the shrimp and grits, and I had the chicken and bacon-infused waffles.   We all really enjoyed our meals.  When we make another trip to SF, this will definitely be one of our go to locations, .... as long as I have the foresight to make a reservation.
author: Jimmy W.

description:
Heirloom and watermelon salad was perfect. Burger was great. Fried chicken on other tables looked good enough to steal. And there's Bourbon Pecan Pie.

I love it here.
author: Jaime M.

description: From the looks of the previous reviews, the country fried steak with eggs and potatoes is usually a hit or miss. Luckily mine was a hit for a first timer. Great with mimosa too.
author: Cheryl P.

description:
Damn, that chicken is good.  Thanks to Jonathan W. and Daniel L. I got to experience a restaurant in a part of town I have never been.  Bernal Heights, I'll be seeing more of you.

The chicken, the chicken, the chicken.  It's all about the chicken!  It comes out piping hot and is super moist.  The batter is crunchy and so flavorful without weighing down the chicken.  The spices are abundant and so fragrant that when we brought home the remaining chicken, our car smelled so delicious after only a minute.  Even warmed up in the oven 2 days later the chicken was still fantastic and moist.

The problem with the chicken is that you can either order 3 pieces for $17 or 9 pieces for $34.  3 is not enough for 2 people but 9 is too much.  I wish there was an in between range.  I'm obviously going to go for the nine piece because my asian mathematical brain and lean wallet tells me so.  The chicken comes with a side of mashed potatoes and collard greens.  Both are wonderful with the collards having a hint of vinegar.  They also have 2 hot sauces, one being habanero that are both spicy and good.

The sides are also very good but my main complaint is that the serving size of the sweet potato fries, fried pickles, and fried okra are smaller than my fist.  It is served in cones on a little wooden platter and you really can't get much in there.  And they want to charge me $6??  Yeah, I don't think so.  I enjoyed the fried okra the most as it wasn't slimy at all but my stomach was still empty and so was my wallet.  For the same price you can get mac and cheese and brussels sprouts which is substantially more food than the fried finger foods.  The mac and cheese was creamy and full of cheese.  I really enjoyed it but wished that they  had used a sharper cheese.

I'll definitely be back for the chicken!
author: Mylinh M.

description:
There are things I really like about Front Porch and things that just aren't quite right. 


Let's start with the food! 

The mediocre:

The pear salad and the creamed spinach are just OK in my opinion. Maybe it's just personal preference but I don't care for sweet salads and Creamed spinach shouldn't be chewy. The French Fries are nothing special.

The Good:

The fried Okra was everything it should be. The Burger is pricey but good (I still make a better burger than anyone). I had the Ox tail dish on my first visit. It was decent but I barely remember it so it couldn't have been that exciting.

The mouth wateringly good:

The shrimp and grits dish was so good it almost made me cry because my friend ordered it and all I got was a taste. I will definitely order this the next time I go in.

The things I don't like about Front Porch:

It's way too dark. This is a casual restaurant not a romantic one. people come here for a social meal, not to get close in a dark booth. The lights were so low that I had to turn on my phone flashlight to see my food and then they turned them down lower.

On my last visit the waitress was a little too surly for my taste. I think we won her over in the end but to be honest that just isn't good enough. Even though the atmosphere is extremely homey Front Porch is not a cheap restaurant. If they want my hard earned money I'd like friendly and helpful service; I don't expect to be treated like I ordered a cosmo at a dive bar.
author: Manny F.

description: I heard about this place on DDD on the food network and I have to say my experience here was HORRIBLE. First we came in and no one came to take our orders till maybe 15 minutes later. Then, the waitress was rude and walked away from us while still giving her our orders. The food we ordered was nasty and the portions where way too small for the price they charged. They took another 15 min to bring us the rest of our order and by that time we were already done with our food. So to sum it up the food and service was HORRIBLE and way to over priced. I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE. TRUST ME ITS A TOTAL WASTE OF MONEY AND TIME.
author: Jon D.

description:
The front porch is a nice little place located close to the heart of Mission, I must say that I was a bit dissapointed with the food, It was OK but ok as in good but not for that price.  Staff was very friendly and parking was not an issue (after 6pm). Our total bill was over 50 and the quality was not worth that much.  Don't get me wrong it was tasty and a good amount of food just too pricey. 

Food: 2/5

Service: 5/5

Scenery: feels like a bar that serves food.
author: John B.

description:
This is such a fun place!

My boyfriend and I went here at about 5-6pm on a Friday night. Parking was a bit difficult because there are so many popular restaurants nearby. My first impression? The outside definitely looks like a front porch lol. It was really dark and cozy with all the candelit tables going on. They played really good music and the service was good. Our waiter made sure our waters were filled. Cute milk jug idea by the way!

We didn't make a reservation and it seemed pretty empty, so we asked the host if we needed to make a reservation beforehand. She advised us to make reservations on Friday nights since it does get a bit packed, and it would be an hour and a half wait and then proceeded to lead us to our table. I didn't know if I should've felt bad for her since we didn't get her sarcasm or felt bad for us since we didn't get her sarcasm. Lol anyways!

The menus are just plain paper which added a nice laid back feel to the restaurant. Our waiter told us the specials for that night. He brought out complimentary corn bread which resembled long pieces of madelines accompanied with their yummy buttercream spread. We ended up getting a bucket of chicken which came with mashed potatoes, collared greens and a side of macaroni and cheese. Like my boyfriend said, the bucket of chicken really comes in a bucket! A popcorn bucket, with pieces of popcorn in the bucket adding a nice touch. Of course I was the one who munched on the popcorn. They give you a good amount of mashed potatoes and collared greens for 2 people and the macaroni and cheese was enough to share for 2 people as well. The total came out to about $40 something. A majority of that was the $34 bucket of chicken, though!

The chicken was so tender and juicy. Sweet Baby Jesus! My boyfriend and I were comparing the chicken to several restaurants and The Front Porch's chicken is hands down, my favorite. Almost no bone, all meat, and the batter is tasty! The mashed potatoes were a bit watery for me. I like my mashed potatoes creamy and buttery but these were just eh. The collared greens were soaked in vinegar which I absolutely hated! The macaroni and cheese? Let's just say if I could have one last meal before I die, this would be it. The macaroni and cheese is the best! It's not too creamy, not too strong on the cheese flavor and just perfect! I sort of didn't want to share with my boyfriend after I took that first bite.

Love this place! I will be back for the chicken and macaroni and cheese!
author: Joyce E.

description:
The Front Porch is exactly what Yelp suggests for 3 stars: A-OK; it's fine but nothing special.  And certainly NOT Creole food like they advertise.  Cajun maybe, but you'll have had better Southern food at any number of spots in Louisiana (or the Bay Area, actually...) for much cheaper.

PROS:
Fun, chill hipster-esque atmosphere (but again, that's not Southern)
Awesome service all around-- our server was great
Nice wedge salad
Great cornbread and butter "whip"
Food came out both quickly and hot
Hot sauces rock
Extensive wine and gourmet cocktail lists
Seated sans reservation on a Friday evening

CONS:
An unimpressive "house white" is 9 bucks
Fried chicken crispy and juicy... and underseasoned and forgettable
Mac and cheese is really basic and rather bland
Mashed potatoes have too much butter
Too casual to be in this price point ($80 for 2 with a shared appetizer and no dessert)

Probably 3.5 stars if I'm being fair.  I'm just kind of over the hefty prices for food I'm not stoked about.  So I'm rounding down (which I don't normally do) to 3 stars for The Front Porch.  I'd choose Oakland's Pican with a similar menu 9 times out of 10.  Or the Hard Knox Cafe.  Or 1300 on Fillmore. Or Brenda's.  Or...you get the point.
author: Brendan S.

description:
We were visiting a friend and was looking for a place for brunch. We actually parked up on Church when I found The Front Porch on Yelp. It was about a 7 min walk from there and when we got there we didn't see a huge long line as we did with other places. But for us that was a good thing. At first I thought it was just a bar because from the outside looking in, that's all you see! But we walked in and saw other families in booths just to the right.

We got seated and looked over the menu. Everything looked good! We started with fried okra, I got the pulled pork hash with sweet potato and egg, my husband got the shrimp and grits, and my friend got the fried oysters with a scallion scramble, and our little one got the chicken and fries.

Overall it was yummy. My portion was actually pretty small so I had to taste the shrimp and grits and that was way more yummier. My friend didn't care for the oysters though. I would go there again and get something else like the chicken and waffles :) but be prepared because it's a 25 minute wait!

The little rocking horse in the front porch was a hit with my son. He kept asking to go out there. 

I'd love to try it out again :)
author: Mochi L.

description: Deep fried pickles.... while not a revelation, certainly appreciated!
author: Shawn C.

description: Very good meal.  Had reservations and our table was ready for us.  We had the crawfish hush puppies with remoulade sauce that were excellent.  I had the shrimp and grits that had just the right amount of heat.  My BF had the fried chicken which was also excellent and very moist.  Service was spot on.  Looking forward to returning again soon !
author: Katherine B.

description: Came here on Valentine's Day after a long delayed flight from snowy Ohio. They allowed us to push our reservation back due to my delays and were so accommodating once we got there. I ordered the Mac & cheese and shrimp & grits and loved every bite!! I will definitely recommend this place to all of my family & friends who live in the Bay Area.
author: Simone B.

description: Partied hard, woke up with a hangover and now you need Jesus? Call the Front Porch, make a reservation and hoppity hop over. Do not go here on the weekend without a reservation or you're going to have a bad time (forrealz you might have a 2 hour wait). They have delicious cocktails, and their brunch is out of this world. Can I just say STONER STACK? Go and nom nom nom nom away!
author: Gladys M.

description:
The Giants fan fest drove us out of SOMA, and YELP helped us identify the Front Porch. What a find!

The waffle and chicken dish was phenomenal, and the shrimp and grits sent my wife back to her Alabama roots.

Great time. Great place. Great food.
author: Vincent V.

description: Every time I go I enjoy this place more and more. Took a friend from LA who swears they have better food then we do. Umm what your chicken is amazing and you love the okra. hmm maybe it's time to admit that while we have place like The Front Porch up here you have no chance.  :) +the staff is awesome!
author: Jessie V.

description:
I went here with a group of 4 on a Saturday night.  Parking was a nightmare, but that's to be expected on a Saturday night in SF so just be prepared to arrive early if you have reservations.  We had 8:30 reservations and got there early at 8:15.  Although we were told it would be a 5-10 minute wait, we were seated by 9.  Thanks for the 30 minute wait for our reservations, Front Porch :P

I didn't really have any expectations coming in just because my friends picked out the place.  The Front Porch serves southern/Creole food and had a cool, slightly hipster vibe.  It did have a front porch/outdoor seating area of course and a nondescript door.  It was super dark inside but lit with candles.  I liked the dark wooden bar that ran the length of the restaurant, the wooden chairs, leather booths -- just an overall, cool prohibition-y type vibe.  

I thought the cocktails and drinks selection was also pretty interesting -- a lot of prohibition style/southern drinks were available.  We had the complimentary corn bread appetizers which came with a yummy flavored butter (was it sun dried tomato? i don't know!) and the fried pickles.  The fried pickles were what you'd expect and nothing to write home about.  The service was pretty good.  The server came by pretty often to refill our waters and check in on us.  It was annoying that after we ordered, they told us the chicken would be a 20-25 minute wait.  It was actually a 45 minute wait for our entrees to come out.  Why can't they just give a realistic time frame for the wait? Ugh.

For our entrees, we had the catfish + salty funnel cake, large fried chicken bucket, and shrimp + grits.  The chicken was pretty good. I liked the flavor of the batter they used and the chicken was pretty tender with only a few bones.  It was $34 for 9 pieces of chicken and a small side of garlic mashed potatoes and collard greens and $18-20 for the other two entrees each.  The chicken was pretty good, but not worth the price to me.  The mashed potatoes were mediocre.  Not very flavorful and a little runny.  I've had better at Safeway!  I've never had collard greens before but they were pretty gross.  They were really sour tasting, mushy and had an awful after taste.  Yuck.  The bf had the shrimp and grits, which were a pretty small serving.  The grits were pretty bland, but the sauce was good.  Savory and slightly sweet.  The shrimp was decent.

Going to a restaurant in SF, you expect a few things: overpriced menu, terrible parking and a long wait.  The Front Porch delivered on all those things.  Besides that, the ambiance was pretty cool but the food was mediocre.  Come for the ambiance, the Prohibition/southern vibe and bar if that's what you're into, but the Front Porch delivers pretty average soul food.  IMy review would probably be closer to a 2.5ish.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Eh. I've wanted to like this place but I'm always done after appetizers. The fried pickles are amazing and I can't get enough of the tangy goodness. Little cornbread poppers are tasty. Downhill from there. Gumbo is a thick slimy mess, while tasteless. Fried chicken super battered and way salty. I don't even remember what I ate the other two times I visited, which is a bad sign. Service is actually nice, but that doesn't make up for the food. And it's pricy. I doubt I'll give it a fourth try, which I think is pretty fair.
author: Samia K.

description: I sort of love this place.  Maybe because it's called Front Porch and that is just such a feel good name.  Oh, and the food is super Southern yum.
author: Sarah P.

description: I really liked the atmosphere of this place, very laid back. First time being in the Bernal Heights neighborhood. Wanted to see the views from Bernal Hill.. and also try this place among others. It was Sunday so ordered bellinis.. why not? They were ok. Started out with the mac and cheese.. yummy gooey! Then we both had the chicken and waffles. So good! Not the best fried chicken but it is very good. I prefer mine super crunchy. I think this place is worth a visit.
author: Vol T.

description:
Went for Sunday brunch.
Fried chicken -- great, maybe even best in sf
Shrimp and grits -- pretty good
Chicken fried steak -- not bad but I wouldn't order it again here
Bloody Mary's -- great!  They 'salt' the rim with bacon bits!!
Service -- pretty good
author: j k.

description:
My girlfriend and I tried this place out this past weekend and as soon as we walked in, I felt like I teleported from Bernal to the French Quarter. While virtually all Cajun places try to emulate the experience and feel of being in NOLA, this is the first one I can say truly nailed it.

Most importantly, so did the food and the service.

We started with a few beers and the fried okra appetizer. They had a solid tap lineup which is always a plus; not huge, but some great selections including Abita (for good measure), a Speakeasy specialty brew on cask, and a local Bay Area brew. The fried okra was delicious and came with a jalapeno aioli that had just a very mild kick to it. We also got complimentary mini cornbread with rosemary butter which was amazing. Never thought to combine rosemary in butter but will definitely start doing it now. 

Deciding on an entree was difficult since it all looked pretty awesome. I went with the fried chicken, mashed potatoes, and ham hock collard greens while my girlfriend did the shrimp and grits. We shared between the two and it was difficult to decide which was best since they were both so damn good.

The fried chicken is possibly the best I've ever had; definitely the best in SF thus far (beating out Brenda's and The Street's). It managed to be moist and flavorful without having a lot of grease at all--just the right amount. The collard greens were salty and went great with the mashed potatoes.

As great as the fried chicken was, the shrimp and grits were the winner of the day. I've never had grits so flavorful. The andouille sausage added some spice and bite and the shrimp were cooked perfectly. I won't even attempt to guess what kind of cajun creole voodoo magic they used to make that sauce, but whatever it was, it was fantastic. 

I could go on and on but bottom line is that this place is a home run.
author: Steve B.

description: Came here for lunch with my sisters and we were lucky enough to get a seat at the bar at around noon. We ordered the bloody Mary with bacon sugar for drinks. Too spicy for my liking! I got the fried chicken poboy with a side of Mac and cheese and their country slaw. My sister got the shrimp poboy with a side of country slaw and collard greens, and my other sister got the fried chicken with beans and rice. Service is great here, they are super friendly and energetic. Only thing I would have to complain about was how cold it was inside the place!!!! It was freezing and not sure why. Overall, I had a great experience here and the food is great!! I would definitely come back here to try their other items on the menu.
author: Cat L.

description: Don't be put off by the outside. It looks kinda scary and run down but it's great food, fun atmosphere/decor and the wait staff is awesome. I went with 4 carnivores (I'm a vegetarian) and we all had really good stuff to eat and drink. They loved the fried chicken, beef short ribs and I had a vegan gumbo and a biscuit. I also had a watermelon, goat cheese and tomato salad that was awesome.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Restaurant looks a little grimy and run down. Food was decent tho. Enjoyed my porboy but it think Brenda's is better
author: Carrie T.

description:
I came here the other day with some family from out of town. I recommended it based on what I'd heard of it, so I was reallyyyyyy hoping it would impress.

Parking in the neighborhood was really difficult, so we ended up being a bit late for our reservation. It was no problem though, they seated us right away. Everyone I was with ordered drinks, and they all really enjoyed the mixed drinks.

We ordered:
Fried Pickles
Baked Mac & Cheese
and dates wrapped in bacon filled with goat cheese.

I ordered the burger for myself and tried some of the pulled pork sandwiches. All the food was really good-- the standouts were the fried pickles and the mac & cheese. My burger was good as well, but nothing special.

I just looked on their website at the updated menu, and I will DEFINITELY be back to try the soft pretzels, french onion soup, and lobster mac & cheese.

Other than the parking and the noise level being a little too high for my taste, it was a great experience. Good food, good ambience, and overall a restaurant I will definitely be back to again.
author: Erica W.

description:
The host and waitress were not very friendly and helpful. We made a dinner reservation and got there 10min early. They sat us down at the middle table right by the door. As we were waiting to order our food, we noticed that there are two other tables available close to the end of the bar. We asked them if it is possible for us to switch seat because it was freezing by the door. But the host rejected us and told us that both of the tables have reservation already but they are just running late. uh...we also made the reservation and we arrived already, AND we are sitting here freezing! They switched us at the end...whew!

Fried chicken was great, we ordered a couple other dishes but I already forgot what they were. I just remember every dish they brought out of the kitchen looked delicious!
author: Jenn M.

description: I have recently been here for brunch twice within the last month. I would suggest making a reservation because the wait can be 45-hour plus. Regardless, it is definitely worth the wait. While you're waiting, you can order a drink from the bar and drink it right outside. I ordered the "lovely day" and my boyfriend ordered the "shand job". It was a lovely day for a shand job! *cues comedy punchline rimshot* The decor here is definitely unforgettable and unique with the hanging utensils and eccentric wall art. Not to mention the "fucket get a bucket" stickers on the water bottles (love it). My favorite dish is the stoner stack because it's a more elaborate biscuits and gravy with bacon and fried chicken in between the biscuits, yum. I have had it both times during my recent visit and will continue to keep ordering it. My boyfriend ordered the chicken and waffle and I wanted to cry because it was so good! The chicken was crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside. The waffle was soft and fluffy and had bacon bits mixed in. YES YOU GET A BACON INFUSED WAFFLE. Best idea ever. I also had the hangover helper and it was okay. The fried okra was really tasty but beware. You might end up eating the whole thing and get full before your main dish comes out. This is one of my favorite brunch spots and can't wait to go back!
author: Brigitte M.

description:
Great southern food in SF. Fun to come with a group if you love to do family style. I came in a group of five on a Friday and got seated immediately at our reservation time. 

Appetizers: I love their gumbo with chicken, andouille sausage and okra. Fried green tomatoes and white corn salsa are a great to share as well. Fried pickles are nice and crispy and comes with tabasco aioli (a bit light on the hotness for me). 

Entrees: Bucket of fried chicken (9 pieces) is a must here. It comes with a side of collard greens and mashed potatoes (most of us seem to ignore those side dishes since we were too full to devour anything else). Shrimps are grits are just standard to me. There's nothing much to talk about. Mac and Cheese is smooth and creamy although I find the macaroni too soggy. 

I love the local scene of Bernal Heights here. The service is super friendly and attentive. I'd love to come here at some other time.
author: Saran R.

description:
I've been here several times since my first review and will continue to keep coming in for 1) seriously good burgers that are juicy and taste like the best backyard bbq burger from a hot summer evening, 2) well-seasoned fried chicken that seems to have gotten the hint, 3) velvety mac n cheese that I'd like to marry and have mac babies with and 4) more celebrity sightings!

That's right, folks. I saw John Waters here last week, enjoying a meal with a table full of friends.

If it's good enough for John Waters, well then it's good enough for me.
author: Amanda R.

description: The reason why I'm giving this place 5 stars is because of the great service, delicious fried chicken, and cute outside eating area. I came here on a date with my boyfriend and we sat outside, it was so cute. After being greeted by our blonde waitress with a cute European accent, I decided to get the fried chicken, and my boyfriend got a bacon cheeseburger. He loved his burger and the fries were perfectly seasoned. My chicken was to die for, it was fried but didn't taste heavy or greasy, it was seriously so good. The habanero hot sauce was also great. I would definitely come back :)
author: Homa K.

description: My party of four arrived on time and we were told we would be seated in a few minutes because the table they had for us had just paid.  Well, 30 minutes later they said we are still waiting for them to leave.  WTF:  Tell them we have people waiting for this table.  Secondly, the food was overpriced for what was basically KFC style chicken.
author: Justin E.

description: Food was really good and we just plain ol' had a blast!
author: tory m.

description: The front porch is awesome sauce. I loved everything about it. My boyfriend and I decided to give it a try because it had a lot of reviews also we were up the street on Cortland listening to bluegrass before here. We ordered hush puppies craw fish. Those were great. The cornbread was amazing with a different kind of butter. Him and I order the 4 piece chicken fried chicken which came with a side of popcorn, mash potatoes with gravy, and collard greens. Everything on the platter was amazingly delicious. I loved it. The drinks were good as well. The environment was amazing. Everything was just so good. The only thing is it gets really packed, we didn't have reservations so I suggest getting reservations. That's all I'll be coming back here though.
author: Rhoddavie M.

description: awesome fried chicken steak as well as chicken and waffles. I will definitely be back again. Having a reservation was a good call because this place was packed! The portion is very generous - don't forget to get a side of bacon though. The bacon is fantastic also!
author: Emily Y.

description:
The Front Porch is a must for good southern food. I've never been disappointed by the food, although the service is occasionally slow, and although I've never made a reservation, I've never waited longer than 15 minutes for a table or a spot at the bar. 

The food is great. The fried chicken, and the shrimp and grits are delicious, but I usually go because the appetizers are both cheap and delicious. The boiled peanuts are always boiled to perfection, the fried pickles are so yummy, they have rotating appetizers that are always delicious usually involving crawfish. I would definitely recommend it.
author: Angela O.

description:
Lets be honest. Soul food is not the healthiest option but if you had to splurge, the Front Porch is the place to be.

Quite possibly the best fried chicken amongst all of the soul food restaurants in the bay area. Everything just worked here. The service, food, the rustic "front porch" vibe just flows.

We shared the fried chicken which was awesome. The chicken was juicy, hot, seasoned very well throughout. The baby back ribs (I have honestly had better) but the bbq sauce was good. The house made hot sauces were great additions to add that extra kick you need if you like it spicy. The corn dog was surprisingly good. The corn bread was light and the sausage was spicy. The tater tots that came with it was a little too doughy.

For dessert, we shared the beignets. I think it could have been a bit lighter but the dessert came out hot and fresh!!!!

Overall, a great place for some fantastic soul food, specifically, the fried chicken!!!!
author: jason g.

description:
How this place has 4 stars, I have no clue. 

I've been to the Front Porch 3 times and it has consistently gone down hill. 

The gumbo is absolutely horrible. The 1st time I had it, it was ok. A few weeks ago I tried it again and it was barely edible. Maybe someone burned the roux? 

I used to love the chicken and waffles but the last time I ordered it, the dish was just ok. 

The po boys are decent. The beignets are enjoyable. The service is nice but I do not like the food. 

Recently, I found myself with an expiring daily deal and I just gave it away to a friend...but with a warning. 

There are better places in SF for southern food.
author: Kiristen R.

description: Love this place. It is a bit on the pricey side for some fried chicken, but it is perfect for a fun date .
author: Orlando B.

description:
Parking: 5
Service: 4.5
Food: 4.5
Company: 5+

Shoutout to dai lo Mike (DLM) and dai lo Dea (DLD).  Told you I'd do it.

DLM picked me up from work to head over to the Front Porch.  I was very excited given that it's been over a year since I last ate here.

Happy hour M-F, 5-7.  Also, I think it's cute that they call it Blues Hour instead of happy hour.  It's the little things...

We started with two cups of gumbo and the spicy popcorn, along with the comp corn bread.  They were all amazing, and the popcorn was astoundingly good.  I mean, the concept is so simple: Tabasco and popcorn.  It's the simple things...

FYI, they don't make the spicy crab and grits anymore, because that was the creation of an old chef.  They're now offering the spicy shrimp and grits, which is the most remarkable thing I've tasted on the menu, hands down.  Now I see why everyone raves about it.

And of course, we got a big bucket of chicken.  Yes, the one that spills out of a movie popcorn bucket.  It's really cute.  See, it is the little things...
author: Jenny L.

description: Had carry-out from The Front Porch on my visit last weekend. I was in heaven!! Fried chicken, Mac and cheese, mashed potato & greens.  Everything was so good!!! The greens had a hint of vinegar which I love!! Will be back!!!
author: lisa y.

description: Boiled peanuts were very tasty and so was the fried chicken.  I ordered the shrimp and grits but they let me order an extra piece of chicken off my friends order, which was nice.  The shrimp and grits were disappointing.  Sooo bland.  I think they forgot to season it.  I doused it with the habanero sauce which helped, but I was really disappointed.  The fried okra was also inedible.  Stringy and I couldn't even eat it!  So weird... Maybe a bad batch of okra?  Who knows.... But I wouldn't bother coming again.  On the bright side,  our waitress was sweet and always kept our water glasses full.
author: Debbie L.

description:
Wowsers, that is some GOOOOD fried chicken!!!  Infused with soo much flavor, definitely itching to go back for some more!

We ordered the bucket of fried chicken - Good punch of flavor, fried to perfection
mashers - unmemorable
collard greens - ok
mac & cheese - poor
Apple Pie - YUM YUM YUM YUM YUM!

Def loud when we went and the lighting is way too dark for me...I started to get a headache.  Decor was ok.  Layout felt a little squished if I remember correctly. 

Would def recommend coming here for their fried chicken and apple pie!
author: C A.

description:
I kind of went on a bender here.  I heard good things about the sangria (all true) and ended up having 3 while waiting for a table, ordering and then eating.  I know that's not much of a bender, but I'm a lightweight now.

We were half an hour early because we had no problems finding parking.  The staff at Front Porch were really accomodating.  After 15 minutes and my first drink, we had a table.  We had the crab fritters, fried green tomatoes, salmon with jamalaya and the bbq shrimp and grits.  Everything was tasty although I probably wouldn't get 2 fried starters again. 

The place is cozy and the service was great so I'd happily come back.  Maybe just one glass of sangria next time.
author: Seong P.

description: Hushpuppies and shortribs were amazing.  Great sitting on the patio with the rocking chairs...rocked the night away
author: Wendy W.

description: TFP was a fantastic find! It is now one of my top 2 favorite brunch spots in San Francisco. I had the king of all brunch dishes...the EGGS BENEDICT. Yum! The hollandaise sauce was warm and comforting, not overpowering. The ham beneath the pillow of perfectly poached egg made me think of Christmas. The cheese grits were the perfect gooey and so delicious. Sooo good! I thoroughly enjoyed my meal while Nate Dogg serenaded us over the house speakers. How delightful. When I go back, I am trying the chicken and waffle! "Regulattooors, mount up!"
author: Kara L.

description:
Ate here a few days later.  Wasn't too hard to get someone to go with me after I mentioned good fried chicken.  The crowd was once again relaxed and happy, well-fed, and in the case of a big table near the front, well-served too.  We ate at the bar and enjoyed it.  A table hadn't opened for our reservation yet and we were 5-10 minutes late anyway.

We ordered a bottle of wine with boudin balls, shrimp and grits, fried chicken, mac and cheese, biscuits, boubon pecan pie and beignets.  I'm getting full again just reading the list.

The boudin balls were out pretty quick and were better than anticipated.  This was important since the mac and biscuits are cooked to order, meaning a 15min wait on each.  

They use real milled grits.  No matter how much butter you throw at instant grits, they'll never be as good as milled grits.  Add in spicy shrimp, plus some bacon and mushrooms, and you have a delicious entree.  This and fried chicken are two southern staples that I can't ever get enough of.  And once again, the fried chicken was great.  I ate the heck out of it.  Mashed potatoes too, of course.

Somehow, the kitchen ran out of mac and cheese.  Normally I'd be crushed but given the volume of quality food in front of us, it seemed to be no big deal.  The biscuits were nice and we had two desserts coming....

....make that three.  We got a apple tart as well.  Nice touch on their part.  Overall the meal and environment were great.  Can't wait to eat brunch there during a weekend.
author: Mike H.

description:
Everything about Front Porch is great, except for the food.

I was absolutely enjoying the dark, slightly shabby interior, the friendly service, the cool neighborhood vibe, the fantastic-looking menu...I really couldn't wait to dig in.

Then our cocktails arrived. The best of the lot was a boozy but otherwise undistinguished Sazarac, and the less said about the rest, the better.

Boudin balls were tasty (it is very hard to mess up fried meat), but a duck confit gumbo was missing all signs of duck, and the shrimp and grits were drowned in a generic hot/sour sauce. I would call this a criminal offense against shrimp and grits, but the shrimp weren't very fresh at all once I scraped off the sauce, so really the entire dish was doomed from the start.

The fried chicken and garlic mashed potatoes were tasty, and if I'd come with a group to split a bucket would also have been good value. But reasonably tasty fried chicken and mashed potatoes? About as remarkable as reasonably enjoyable oral sex.

If you're looking for a hipster KFC, don't mind the hipster prices, and avoid the cocktails, you could do ok. If you're looking for real soul food, keep looking.
author: Amy L.

description:
We had the mac n cheese, burger with fries, and 3 pcs of chicken (with mashed potatoes and some greens). 

The mac and cheese was okay, a couple blocks from the place is a great mac and cheese place. 

Burger also was okay, nothing special with the taste, but the burger patty was pretty big!

But the chicken, it's juicy inside and crispy on the outside. order their chicken! the gravy was okay too, I'd prefer to eat their chicken with some gravy from Popeye's tho.

They serve dinner menu on the bar, but the bar is not really ideal for eating because, for me, the top was too high, maybe they could get higher chairs?

The place is close to Mitchell's Ice cream, so that's a good thing when you want to get some ice cream after, but I was stuffed with what we had.

Parking is a challenge in the area.
author: V B.

description:
Great place if you like Southern comfort food.
Try the beef short ribs, the fried chicken, biscuits, and ice cream apple cobbler.
The mac and cheese was decent but not amazing.
author: Soorenikus S.

description: Went to The Front Porch this morning for brunch. Everything was wonderful. The staff was excellent. Had the country fried steak with the works! Great Bloody Mary's.
author: Rebecca N.

description:
bring it on!
Ribs.....quite yummy 
Prawns & grits....must try. 
 Pretty good cornbread - not too rich & dense as you'd expect.

*** Do Make Reservations!  ;)

Yelp states ambience is hipster which is not accurate.  It's SF - a mix of locals, definitely seemed more yuppie than hipster. What really matters * the food is solid. And service was pretty damn good.
author: Athena S.

description:
Shut the Front Porch. What a disappointment. 

I bookmarked this place just based on the sheer number of positive reviews I've read (as well as its close proximity to Mitchell's). Being a huge fan of Brenda's, I had ultra high hopes this could be the Bernal Heights alternative. Sadly, it was not.

I ordered the fried chicken and waffles, at the recommendation of my fellow yelpers, as well as the egg, bacon, and grits, because I love Brenda's grits.  These items took longer than the others to prepare, I like that the menu told us that. The fried chicken and waffles were pretty good, chicken was moist and cooked to perfection. Although, the waffles tasted sour! Like they were made by the sea, or sourdough. It was unappetizing. 

Worse, was the grits dish, which was so bland, I had to add salt, pepper, AND hot sauce just to make it slightly less disgusting. I think Brenda's really spoiled me because the grits I've had at other places don't compare by a milestone. The grits dish I got here from the Front Porch was also topped with feta cheese, which made for an unlikely and unappealing pairing. Sadly, with far better options out there, I won't be coming back.
author: Ray W.

description:
I'm on the fence about this place being a-ok, or a fan. I've been here several times, and really enjoy the ambiance, service and menu choices. Unfortunately, the last time I went I had the shrimp and grits and had some issues from all the butter they use there.

That said, this place is great for big groups. We were a party of 6/8 with reservations,and the booth seating is perfect. I've also been here for brunch, dinner and late night snacks which all was delicious. I do love the fried chicken though, and how they serve it in a bucket with popcorn. 

The ocra is eh - and recommend picking a different side when ordering. That said, I would definitely considering coming back here, and just avoiding the shrimp and grits.
author: Laura H.

description:
I just loved this restaurant! The ambiance was incredibly charming - the drinks menu was creative, and the fried chicken was to die for. 

Please note - almost everything on the menu is friend -- even the pickles! Just accept it, don't think about health for one night, and enjoy :)
author: Michelle T.

description:
What a cute, fun place.  I loved the feel of it!!  The couple next to us had a cute baby that started to get a little fussy.  They packed up everything and ended up taking all the food to go.  That was awfully nice of them, but not entirely necessary.  The kid wasn't  really that bad.  It was kind of entertaining.  

I've been on a diet for the last few weeks and this is the first meal I've had where I felt I was being naughty!!  I had the burger and fries.  The burger was good and juicy and perfectly charred.  The "ketchup" was kind of weird (maybe homemade??)~ a little too runny and kind of just disappeared into the bun.  It tasted okay though.  He housemade hot sauce was yummy!  I really like the habanero one!!  

My friend had the fried chicken, mashed potatoes and a side of mac and cheese all of which she let me sample!  She's a good friend.  The fried chicken was really good.  In general, neither one of us likes white meat, but it was juicy and delicious.   The $17 price tag is a bit much, but this is San Francisco.   I think we've gotten used to it!  The mac and cheese was tasty.  My friend commented that it had a slightly burned taste.  I don't know ~ I kinda liked it.  I will say, however, that the place where I work has the best mac and cheese I've EVER HAD!!!  I love our lunch lady!!!
author: S. Y.

description: oh boy! what a feast. died and went to heaven.
author: Thomas P.

description:
ugh. the owner's comment responding to my review? 

totally for show.

that same day i did exactly as they asked. i emailed and i also messaged him via yelp. no response.

do not go here. the chicken is good, but is not worth the attitude and the negative experience that i had and clearly continue to have.

also, open table didn't lose my reservation. a man there did. when i made it, i used the phone and spoke to someone personally.
author: Tara T.

description:
Bloody Mary was alright that I started with. 
But then we ordered  the fried okra that was spicy and well-breaded which ridded it of any of the slimy texture that usually happens with any preparation of okra. 
After the okra, I had the fried chicken and biscuit sandwich (stoner stack?) and it was delicious. Salty, rich and slightly spicy. The cheese grits were flavorful as well (I didn't  regret not getting hashbrowns). 
We also got the chicken and waffle, which also had flavorful chicken and a nice cornmeal waffle. It was spicy, salty and everything one needs to cure a hangover.
author: Nichole V.

description:
Oh my goodness so yummy! My husband and I had an early lunch here yesterday and it was fantastic.  We both order a po boy sandwich (chicken for him and catfish for me) and we split an order of beignets. I am not sure how the chicken po boy was because my husband devoured it before I got a bite but the catfish was so flaky and delicious - it had a nice light batter and it was a fairly decent size fillet.  The fries were cooked to perfection - not crunchy but not soggy either with a nice bit of seasoning.  The way they serve their beignets is very creative - they serve them in a small brown paper bag which keeps them warm and also keeps the powdered sugar from getting everywhere. Plus if you can't finish them you can just close up the bag - no need for a doggy bag.

We will definitely be coming to The Front Porch again and soon!
author: Kayla H.

description: I was recently here for a birthday brunch and we essentially ordered everything: Stoner Stack, Baked Eggs, Shrimp and Grits, Hangover Helper, Chicken and Waffles, Apple Waffles, beignets, fried okra and probably some other stuff too.  I was most impressed with the Shrimp and Grits (I am not a huge grits fan and this convinced me otherwise) and Hangover Helper (the inclusion of the chili made the mac less insufferably cheesy).  I had but one piece of fried chicken and found it pretty perfect, but was less impressed by the waffles.  Yet, the best part of the meal was the beignets that we had to start off with.  I've had them at Cafe du Monde and I actually prefer the ones from Front Porch.  They were like tender pillows of dough.  I'd be curious to come back for dinner and see how a meal works here when you don't eat bits and pieces of eight different dishes.
author: Jeremy G.

description: Pretty good southern food. We got the bucket of chicken which came in a unique popcorn bucket and the baked mac and cheese. The chicken was good but our eyes were def bigger than our stomach when we ordered because we had a lot left over. Baked mac and cheese was okay. Tastes almost just as good as leftovers.
author: Queena T.

description:
We were there on a Saturday night with a large group consisting of both grown ups and kids.  Having a kiddie menu was key.  Kudos to The Front Porch for getting us in and making our tummies full.  The drinks were good and food tasty.  Just as importantly, the service was also quite fine althought they could have been slightly more attentive.  At the table was all sorts of vittles:  
Cornbread
Fried Pickles:  yumy
Boiled Peanuts:  better than at the ballpark
Fish n CHips:  fair but kid friendly
Mac n Cheese:  decent but not for the ones that think blue box is the bombFried Chicken:  for the money, i'll just go to kfc
Collard Greens:  yummy
Tatoes n gravy:  a hint of garlic and quite enjoyable
Crab w/ grits:  tasty and different

We enjoyed, but for what it was, felt a bit overpriced.  Glad to have gone there but not really on the list of places to go back to.
author: Jeff G.

description: My cousin and I wanted to try a restaurant in San Francisco that had been on The Food Network and thats how we found this place. I loved the unique setting that you walk into. Everyone there really went above and beyond to show they appreciated our business. We had the gator, bucket of chicken,  mac and cheese, along with a side of greens. Everything tasted so delicious! Seriously southern hospitality in Cali.
author: Ka'Desh C.

description:
I am actually from the South, so maybe my standards for Southern comfort food is higher than most. After seeing hot boiled peanuts and fried pickles on the starters menu, I was super excited. We got the fried pickles which were amazing, so I was really looking forward to my shrimp and grits for dinner. When it came, it looked unlike any other shrimp and grits I've gotten (which isn't necessarily bad), but it also didn't taste very good. Waaay over seasoned shrimp with mushrooms, onions, bacon, etc. with a bowl full of brown sauce over grits. Can you say heartburn? Less is definitely more, and they put everything but the kitchen sink on those grits. Furthermore, my husband's fried chicken was bland and his collard greens had a vinegary flavor that missed the mark.  

And could you guys turn on a light or two? I usually like to see my food.

Not eager to head back despite an excellent starter.
author: Emille L.

description:
Not Gonna Lie...I saw this place on some Tv special they have on SF food spots on a day and an hour when I'm pretty sure people are actually enjoying the city verses watching Television. 

So naturally I was like Giant Bucket of Fried Chicken served inside a popcorn container....SCORE, hmmmm so then the mission to try this shindig out began. 

I came at night, it was that stereotypical grungy place you come across in Indy flicks or better yet pretend your in a Dive in New Orleans. Lights are dim, ceiling are low (mostly because I'm pretty sure this is the basement, and dim lights are always better for hiding uninvited predators from outside AKA bugs). The waiter is nice, the mirror is tripping me out because it make the place bigger, and the entire atmosphere is really making me want to order Wine. I order my Fried Chicken yeehaaaa, however to my dismay  it came in a porcelain plate =(. However the chicken was o
author: Lannette G.

description: Had breakfast here with my husband and kids. Very good food. Don't be deceived by the appearance of this place. The food was good- especially the potatoes and my husband had a really good looking (and huge) omelet. Service was good as well. We will be back.
author: Deanna C.

description:
This place is hipster for sure, so just know that right away. The food is fine, but not world rocking. You'll need to make a reservation or wait awhile if you don't. I've been dining and drinking in SF for 20+ years and don't mind that some of our restaurants are going hipster, but what I DO mind is as we were finishing up, a manager (?) came to our table and told us "someone is waiting for your table". We were appalled and let him know. Our group of four had fried chicken, mac 'n' cheese, and pork chops, along with a few drinks, so they certainly got their money's worth out of us! I can count on one hand the number of times I've been "rushed out" of a restaurant and I never go back after that happens. There are PLENTY of delicious mid-range restaurants in the city, so who needs the drama? The sad thing is, the wait staff had been perfectly cordial up until this guy stepped in and ruins the experience. 

If you're looking for a similar food experience that is actually better, go to Hard Knox Cafe. The fried chicken is awesome, the atmosphere is laid back, and the owners and staff are extremely sweet and accommodating. The Front Porch really tried to be "too cool for school", but ended up just being flat out rude.
author: Sal C.

description: If you want the best fried chicken in town? This is the place. All I ca say is WOW, the chicken is so goooood almost eat the whole bucket myself.
author: John A.

description:
Total Trendy Southern Charm equipped with rocking chairs on the floor as well as a mini chair hanging from the outside porch ceiling. There is just the right amount of light in the evening and there are a few large tables to accomidate parties of 5 or 6. (Good to know for families as most places in SF are tiny)
  -The Sweet Tea was one of the best sweet teas that I've had - like ever!!!
 - The complimentary cornbread sticks sprinkled with rock salt (soft  butter as well) were so yummy that we asked for another order...
 - The Spicy Shrimp with Grits were so hit the spot yummers with just the right amount of spiceiness....
 - The Cheeseburgers were yummy as well- The onions for your burger were pickled and you can order a jar of their homemade pickles.
 - The fries were seasoned good and the ketchup tasted homemade as well.
 They staff was attentive and the atmoshpere was laid back until a very loud group of dudes came in then I started to feel like I was in a bar - at least were were headed out.
**Parking sucked though - we ended up parking at Safeway even though you aren't supposed to (you'll get towed) but there was no parking and we were hungry**
Yup another yummy place in the city - On my next visit I'll be back to try other stuff....
author: Ursula U.

description:
Front Porch. Feb  7, 2010

Josey, my waitress, is a redheaded charmer who could be my niece. Sat near the back. Super Bowl on but no sound. Nice touch. Get to watch the kitchen. Meet the staff. Great people.  

Beer week going on; had a nice Belgian Ale, then a superb local IPA. Spiced nuts start the meal, and then corn sticks, bringing back memories of Campton Place, though they would never have served the scrumptious spicy butter with it. Sprinkled with kosher salt. Yum!

Gumbo was as good as I've had at a restaurant. I learned how to make gumbo from my great grandmother, and I make a damn good one, if I do say so myself. Roux was dark, layered, sophisticated--you can see why some might not like it. A meat fest! I did not want it to end. 

Fried okra w/ jalapeño aioli. Thin crust, not overfried. Excellent.

Then the fried chicken. Perfectly fried, seasoned under the skin with a  garlic mixture. Not overly spicy. Three pieces: a drumstick and two breast quarters. Rocky chickens. Served with perfectly cooked collards and mashed potatoes. 

Another beer. A stout.

Can't have desert, but the traditional offerings are here: bourbon pecan pie, beignets, bread pudding, etc. 

A really good place, with a funky New Orleans joint vibe. It gets crowded during peak hours. Highly recommended!
author: Walter M.

description: I am usually not a fan of southern cuisine but this place is pretty awesome. Friendly staff and excellent food. My date loved her short ribs and the grits are just so creamy and tasty. Make sure you make a reservation otherwise you will have to wait til Obama leaves office...
author: Kevin W.

description: This. Place. Was. Amazing. Everything exceeded our expectations! Through word of mouth, I had high hopes for this place and I couldn't have been happier! Everything that was ordered was amazing... Cute place and cute neighborhood. Number one recommendation: Blue Crab Hushpuppies. !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Would go again and again, as the menu changes seasonally. Tip: make a reservation, this place is hoppin!
author: William F.

description:
I have been wanting to come here for awhile and I was very excited to finally try it. The place is a very cosy restaurant  with a bar. I was impressed with the food and they have lots of interesting mixed drinks at the bar. 

Food:
Crawfish beignets- two good sized beignets with good flavor and filling
Cornbread- tasty complementary cornbread with some interesting butter
Mac and cheese- Cheesy goodness on a hot skillet
Brussel Sprouts- pretty good with bacon and apple, interesting mix
Shrimp and Grits- Grits were amazing and the shrimp and mushrooms complemented it very well
Fried Chicken with Mash Potatoes and Collard Greens- Chicken was super moist and crunchy very delicious
Butterscotch Pudding- SO SO SO Good and great way to end the meal.  

Mullied Wine- Warm wine that taste like winter, it also had a Game of Thrones reference on the description so it won me over. 

Great place for food, I would come back again!
author: Elliot T.

description:
While my normal diet is completely different from heavy Southern cooking, occasionally I let myself indulge.  Last night was one of those occasions, plus I wanted to impress my guy and take him out for his birthday to a place I knew he would enjoy, so off to the Front Porch we went.  I heard many good things about this place from coworkers and it has been on my to-try list for quite some time.

We really enjoyed our meal here, starting with the trendy, yet homey and warm atmospere.  We started with glasses of Pino and Zin and shrimp hushpuppies.  For dinner we ordered fried chicken with mashers and collard greens and spicy shrimp grits.  I had the grits.  They were very flavorful, with truffles providing just the right touch.  I managed to snag one piece of fried chicken, and it was everything that I would want in fried chicken, crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside.  Judging by my date's reaction, he was in personal heaven.  Score!!!  We finished everything on our plates and had to have another glass of wine each to finish our meal.  I highly recommend Zinfandel for the red wine lovers, I could have sipped on it all night long.  Service was great.

The only downside were the hushpuppies, so I had to subtract one star.  They were fine, as far as hushpuppies go...but absolutely nothing to write home about.  In addition, when it says shrimp hushpuppies, I expected some shrimp.  It didn't seem like there were any shrimp inside, and if there was one, the shrimp was so small that it went unnoticed by the both of us, twice.  That was disappointing.  So, I will definitely bypass the appetizer next time and just focus on the main dishes.  Can't wait to try this place for brunch.
author: Marina S.

description:
"After literature (William Faulkner) and music (Elvis Presley), the South's greatest contribution to American culture has been its food."

I read that once, and it stuck with me.  I love all three of those gifts.

Walking into the Front Porch is like walking into a bayou.  Dark, cavernous, delightful.

I met up with three of my favorite foodies (and people) last night for a much overdue reunion.  We ordered almost every appetizer, and I have to say I was floored by the food. It's darn delicious!

Once we ordered drinks (mmm Electric Marmalade) and settled on the food order, we were in seventh heaven.  Steak Tartare, Grilled Oysters, Asparagus with Hollandaise and Prosciutto, BBQ Shrimp, Fried Okra, Fried Chicken with collard greens, the flatiron steak.  Y'all need to order these!  Not one of those dishes is expendable.  If I were forced to choose a favorite, I would rather die.  Since I'm from a big half-Southern family, I'm used to sharing my food. If you don't, Front Porch will convert you with its Southern hospitality.

Apparently the chef chose all of the wines to go with fried chicken.  Well, if he says so!  The Moon Mountain did the trick for me!

Eat.here.now. Diet later. It's the Southern way.
author: Joanna M.

description:
Came here with a friend before a show. Res for 5:30, finished by 7:15. Overall not a bad experience, but felt like a few kinks needed to be worked out. The service in unobtrusive, yet once the place was full, it was harder to get someone's attention.

The fried pickles were good, as was the fried chicken, yet for some reason i could not wrap my head around the grits. I've had good southern style grits before (Lois the Pie Queen? Brown Sugar Kitchen?) but these, for a lack of a better word, were gritty. Maybe they were a little undercooked  - no matter, i wont order them again. The chicken, however, was juicy and well seasoned. The shrimp? good, but small. The mashed potatoes were just 'ok', the greens were good, but not 'wow'. Overall not a bad experience, but i felt like i've had better elsewhere. 

I'll have to come back for pickles and to try the burger. Oh, and to have more drinks. BTW the unpretentiousness of it all is very refreshing, especially cool were the old car seats, complete with seat-belts, disguised as a booth. Cheers!
author: Vittorio L.

description:
While it's true that the fried chicken here is really great, we weren't too wowed by anything else. Maybe this is a better brunch spot.

We were a party of 3 on a pretty busy Saturday night. The host was very friendly and welcoming, however the rest of the service was sort of lackluster. While nothing went wrong during our meal, it wouldn't have hurt if the server cracked a smile once. 

Aside from the fried chicken--the rest of the food we had wasn't too amazing. The collard greens, mashed potatoes, fried pickles, and poutine weren't anything to write home about. I'd just recommend that you stick with the chicken alone when coming here for dinner.

It was $62 for 3 drinks, 2 appetizers, and 1 entree so the price point wasn't too impressive either. The ambiance is quirky and warm so it's definitely worth a visit.
author: Tina G.

description: Went on a whim, and a The Front Porch did not disappoint. The short ribs were tender, the biscuits were perfect, the fried okra was just right! I wish I lived here so I could go back again.
author: Nicole N.

description: When I walked in, the waitress walked passed me and my bf so I thought she was a regular customer until she returned and sat us down minutes later. We ordered the Shrimp and grits, 4-piece fried chicken and the Mac n Cheese. The chicken was too dry and overcooked because the outside tasted a little burnt, the Mac n cheese was too bland and the Shrimp and grit was not worth the price it was listed for. My bf enjoyed the spicy popcorn that was included with the fried chicken the most.
author: Deanna L.

description:
I took the bf here for his last birthday.  We had both wanted to try the Front Porch out, so it seemed like a good opportunity.

The bf loves fried chicken, so I hoped it would live up to the hype.  I have to say that it was good, but not the best.  We ordered the bucket, which is fun and all.  It's a lot of food, but for the price I'm not so sure.

Highlights of the meal were the fried green tomatoes and the hush puppies.  They did them proud!  The mac n' cheese was decent, but nothing to write home about.

I guess perhaps my expectations were too high going into the meal.  The reviews on Yelp were really stellar.  I'd have to say it was a good meal, just not great.
author: Greg S.

description: This place has a great brunch selection. Went with a group of 5, and there was not a compaint in the world. At the table we had shrimp and grits, french toast, chicken and waffles, eggs benedict, biscuits and gravy, fruit bowls and fried okra. Everything came out hot, and fresh! I had the shrimp and grits, they were both cooked perfectly, and the sauce they put over it with the mushrooms was simply amazing! Everyone left full and happy, as the portions are not skimping either!
author: John G.

description:
I absolutely love this place. It's my favorite kind of food, after all I am from the south. They make the best fried chicken in the city, hands down. Everything else on the menu is terrific, the ambiance is charming, the staff is friendly and assertive. I brought my girlfriend here for our anniversary, it was a great night. 

I hear from the grapevine that they will soon be opening up across the street (29th) in the old Club International dive. It's going to be called Rock Bar, and serve classic prohibition style drinks, southern drinks, and will most likely cater appetizers from across the street! Can't wait! my hood needs a decent bar that isn't the Knockout.

Cheers!
author: Jevir G.

description:
I've tried this place twice within the past couple weeks... I liked it, I thought the decor was cute, but I wasn't "wowed." I never really go to Bernal.. Not my thing. Im always downtown (shopping addiction) or in Hayes (food addiction) or North Beach (Dessert addiction. And I love the wharf.) The staff were very friendly, and service was a-ok.. Not amazing, but nothing to complain about either. I noticed that most of the other patrons were hipsters.. Not my ideal crowd, but whatever, Im not there for them.. I came for the food. Which brings me to the next part of my review. 

I wanted to try their georgia peach drink, which they were unfortunately out of that day. Went for the "front porch" instead, i believe. It was small, but yummy and strong. I would get it again, and recommend it to others who dont mind the extra booze. But who does mind, eh?

Fried pickles- Holy moly yummy. I never had a fried pickle before, and boy was I missing out. I dont even like pickles, on anything, all the time.. I tried these out of curiosity and felt like i struck gold. Or green. Or both, since the batter was a beautiful golden brown. RECOMMEND.

Grilled little gem salad with feta cheese, peaches, pecans, topped with a bacon shallot vinaigrette- this was probably one of the better salads ive had in a restaurant. I dont usually order salads actually, but the description sounded enticing. I must say it was quite delicious. Grilling the leaves added just a touch of smokiness, and all of the other components balanced nicely. Plus it had bacon. Nuff said. 

Fried green tomatoes- I thought they were okay. My sister loved em. Personally I just dont like pimento cheese.

Gumbo- It was average. Ive had better, and Ive had worse. I wish it was a bit spicier or something though.. I felt it was a touch bland. 

Fried corn on the cob- I never thought of frying corn on the cob, but something magical happens when you do. This isnt something I would want to eat a lot of, but its pretty good for sharing. It was less messy than I thought it would be. I dont know if the frying causes this, but it comes off of the cob a lot easier than expected, and nothing annoying stuck in my teeth.

Fried chicken- Sadly, I wasnt really a fan of the fried chicken. I thought it was overpriced and rather bland. I wasnt a huge fan of the collard greens either, which I usually love. Ill continue to make trips to Hard Knox for my chicken cravings. 

Grilled hanger steak- it was good. I had the steak done rare. I liked everything that came with it too. The creamed corn was good, the broccolini was nicely flavored, and you cant go wrong with onion rings.

No, I did not finish everything by myself. Yes, I would return to this restaurant. :)
author: Alison A.

description:
For all us city folk that call our 4'x1' stair a "porch," The Front Porch is just what the doctor ordered. Colorful food, colorful people, notably helpful staff, squeaky swinging chairs surrounded by ivy climbing the lattice, Speckled Hen on tap, makes a long wait, not a wait at all.  I enjoyed being in line as much as I enjoyed the food; it was such a pleasure.

I prefer my oysters snotty raw and straight up, possibly with a light spray of lemon, so I wasn't prepared to like the pickled spring onions that accompanied ours. But they did not overwhelm and delicately balanced the oyster. I would definitely order them again. Note: do not eat the colorful items below the shells, those are salt granules.  

The spicy shrimp and grits were wonderful. Not that I have a lot of experience, but I have never had a better grit. I would go back soon to ensure I have that the shrimp again before they change their menu.

The chicken was a little peppery for me. Certainly enjoyable, but I think it was unnecessarily seasoned. Just as I wouldn't ever think to use a pepper shaker on my fried chicken, I don't think I wanted it baked in there. It wasn't bad, but just a bit distracting.  

The steak was perfectly prepared and the tomatoes and bordelaise were fantastic. I loved it.

The reason to dock the Porch a star is due to the desserts. Just don't bother with the strawberry shortcake or the donut bread pudding. In a nutshell, they were not very good. Stick with the main entrees and finish it off with a King Cobra... I still can't believe they have that on the menu. 

Tip your mariachi players please.
author: Hayley W.

description:
This place reminds me of one of those trendy southern places that the hipster kids always review on Check Please Bay Area haha. 

That said, it's a cool place. I like the armosphere, it's really dark and cozy, and it's usually pretty crowded, although I've never been here on a weekend, when I assume it can get even more crowded.

They offer some cool sides and starters, like fried okra and boiled peanuts, both of which are delicious. You can also get Cracker Jacks with bacon on them. I've never gotten those, but it seems like one of those "let's add bacon to old - fashioned stuff" trend items that actually sounds good.
