I really like this place, but to be quite honest, I don't go to a southern restaurant to spend as much money as I do here. I mean, it's great food, but it tastes a lot better when someone else is paying for it.
author: Angela S.

description: Real Life Amazing Food.  The fired chicken is a must and grit that were better than my aunt's. That a big deal!!
author: Rayannah S.

description: Over priced and food was blah! Cracker Barrel was even way better! I have heart burn and my tummy hurt after! Not worth waiting and driving into San Fran for!
author: Judy L.

description:
This place is small, watch your head with the ceiling.....and it's as dark as an open grave on a moonless night.
I wish they gave us candles to carry. 
I was scared going to the bathroom.

I've been to New Orleans, and the decor here (that I could see) didn't evoke Louisiana for me.

More like a tomb.
They do have those above-ground crypts in N'awlins, but I didn't actually go inside one. 
I guess now I have.

There are cushier coffins than the little wood chairs they offer.
If Morticia ushers you to a table past an open casket-I mean booth; take a stand, my friend. 
You're not here to prove your powers of submission.
Get the booth.
(Unlike me-I got the chair.)

The garlicky fried chicken was excellent. 
I got the 3 piece size ($17) and they were SMALL pieces. 
Those are some cute little birds they kill.

Go for the 9 pieces ($34)
It's expensive, but you have to counter the crappy chairs, Tales from The Crypt ambiance and painful noise level.
Eat a lot of chicken.

The mashed potatoes were excellent.
The collard greens were very astringent; mmmm......astringency.
Those weren't good.

We liked the food, but physically, I'm not ready for interment.
There's good fried chicken when you're dead, though.

2nd visit:  
There was light! 
I asked the server and she said it's the bartender's call. 
So this guy likes to see. 
Okay, there IS some swampy decor evocative of the French Quarter and the floor is dirty.
The chicken was exactly the same, (oh-the pieces were bigger), rully, rully good.

If you like dates, the hot bacon-wrapped dates were incredible.

It costs lotsa money.  Lots.

P.S. They've changed their pricing and # of pieces of fried chicken.
author: Lame Lake Meese Z.

description: What!? Fried pickles you say!? I'm there (never square). Yes, my furry friends, the front porch has fried pickles. Get that with their amazing fried chicken and you got a fried match made in heaven. So what if I was obese in another life (or maybe in a few years)?
author: Josie A.

description:
Started off at the bar with awesome selection of drafts : Try the Abita! Great start and went well with my meal.

Yummy complimentary corn bread bites with delicious chipotle spread? (we asked for these a few times :D )

We ordered the baked mac n cheese as an app which was some of the best mac' ive had out. 

I had the shrimp n grits and my friends ordered a bucket of chicken. Everything was tasty!

Will come back :)
author: Elsa C.

description:
Usually if I don't like a place, I don't review it highly. This place really sounded like it would appeal to me. The menu looks great, the bar is cool, and the atmosphere is awesome. Been here twice now, and have tried a lot of the dishes. The fried chicken wasn't my deal, but that doesn't mean it wasn't well executed. Tried a fish special on the trip before last, and it was perfectly cooked, well seasoned, but just not my bag. The sweet potatoes with coconut milk, were however, beyond belief. 

While I wouldn't regularly come here, I could be seduced back. The service is great, and the chef smiles. Even the line cooks smile. It's obvious that something special is going on in this kitchen. Maybe I'm missing it, but that doesn't mean they need to be slammed. The experience here is a lot of fun. Friendly service that makes you feel like you're right at home. Sorry I can't give five stars, but I feel like they know what's up.
author: Evan C.

description:
The two of us went around 11am on a Saturday and it was packed! Maybe the cold weather had something to do with it since no one was sitting outside. We waited for 20 minutes or so and by the time we were seated in the back we were ready to order. 

The chicken and waffle came out first surprisingly, (they warned us of a 30 min cooking time) and the chicken was delicious. Juicy, flavorful, crunchy on the outside. The waffle was nothing extraordinary. 

I ordered the baked egg and grits with mushroom goat cheese and bacon, and it was delicious! But I don't regularly eat grits, hence not familiar with the classic grits. If that is what you're looking for this may not be for you. I think the goat cheese complimented the grits and maitake mushrooms very well. Ask for their house hot sauce to top it off if your taste buds starts to get a little bored. 

A lot of people around us were ordering the bloody Mary, and if I wasn't so intolerant of alcohol I would have ordered one. But the coffee was good and they give you a nice big cup :) definitely a big breakfast. Overall our dining experience was great, but just by looking at the menu it looks like some dishes could be hit and miss.
author: Nat Y.

description: Front Porch never disappoints, great food and even better service. Thanks Bre!
author: Nicole A.

description: The reason why we went there is because it show this place on the food network show!~ Everything look so good on TV so we decide to give it a try!~ But we will never go back there anymore!! I ordered the "Shrimp and Grits" I found one of the shrimp was not devein and some of the shrimp was not fresh.......and the mac & cheese was plan and too oily. The service was bad and really slow we don't like our waitress. We feel like everyone that works there they don't care.
author: Suki C.

description: Didn't realize how long ago this original review was written. Definitely a favorite restaurant for the family.  Favs of ours are shrimp and grits, pork chop, fried chicken, flounder, hush puppies and our must have: fried okra.
author: Amy O.

description: I got a vegan quinoa extravaganza and my buddies got burgers. Both were delicious and well executed. Now that's talent!
author: Beth N.

description:
My first time and it didn't hurt, i wasn't nervous, and i didn't leave thinking, "that's it?!?"  it was the COMPLETE opposite! ;)

We tried and LOVED the:

*SPICY SHRIMP & GRITS- took the first bite and it was like an explosion in my mouth (not always the best thing, but this was an exception)!  it wasn't as spicy as i'd like, but it tasted soooo friggin good.  at first i thought, maybe I'm just really hungry which is why i'm enjoying it so much, but when the other two I was with had the same reaction-  you know, eyes rolling back, toes twitching, little moans and grunts with every taste- i knew, for sure, it wasn't just me!  

*FRIED CHICKEN- crispy, juicy, and all that good stuff.  the batter wasn't too thick and the spice was just right.  you could actually taste the chicken which is a major plus!

*FRIED PICKLES with some kind of aioli sauce... YUM!
*BISCUITS A' LA' BAMA- biscuits not as soft as I'd like, but the dipping sauce is friggin delish.  butter & honey with a kick of spice.  FUCK. YES.
*BAKED MAC & CHEESE = HELLA cheese = HELLA good.


*BEIGNETS- took a bite and it was good, but we also had the...
*CHERRY COBBLER  topped w/ GOAT CHEESE ICE CREAM- so i pretty much forgot about the beignets and got down and dirty with this one.  the cobbler was amazing!  

overall, GREAT food, GREAT service, GREAT ambience.  would do it again... and again... and.... again.
author: Kat D.

description: DRY-AS-THE-DROUGHT FRIED CHICKEN!! "Mashed" potatoes with zero lumps that my grandma knows only comes from a machine mixer because somebody was too LAZY or TIGHT-FISTED to hand-mash them. Unfriendly arrogant (beautiful people) staff. Cramped and questionable fire-safety: as you enter, imagine everyone exiting suddenly through that one and only 36-inch wide doorway. No parking. I'm actually from the South and have wanted to love this place again and again- but every time I go back, I leave more disappointed. Please don't waste your time and money supporting the Front Porch that is so DONE already like it's DRIED chicken.
author: Chris R.

description:
I think this just might be my favorite restaurant in the city. Bold claim, i know. The fried chicken is delish. I occasionally branch out, but always find myself missing the chicken. Also, (being from Texas) I have frequently lamented that nowhere in California could I find my favorite side dish: fried okra. Not only did I find it at the Front Porch, but it is hands down the best fried okra I've ever had. The spicy crab & grits are also a fave. And the corn shaped corn bread - whats not to love? 

The wait is long on a weekend night, but if you can find a seat on the front porch it is a good time. They also let you head down to the 300 Club and will call you there when your table is ready.
author: Meagan C.

description:
I liked the Front Porch quite a bit. Some very good and innovative cocktails and an interesting menu. Nice dining experience as well, with good service.

We had Devils on Horseback - bacon wrapped fried oysters on top of savory bread pudding with a tomato based sauce. I thought the sauce was a bit underwhelming and would have liked something with a bit more spice. I added hot sauce.

Hoppin' John - delicious melange of black eyed peas, onions etc

the burger - which was quite good

the pork chop - this was a slight disappointment, a little too much meat without enough sauce to flavor things. The mashed sweet potatoes and greens with it were great though.

desserts were very good - bread pudding to die for and a root beer float

I'd go back and skip the pork chop and try other things on the menu.
author: Sam P.

description: The food simply delicious! I can't wait to go back I had the shrimp and grits. One word: Amazing! But don't believe me check it out yourself.
author: Sonya W.

description:
I took the boyfriend here for dinner this week. 

It wasn't too bad finding parking on a Tuesday night. We didn't have reservations but they were able to seat us right away. They were busy. The wait staff was friendly and attentive (and tolerant of the weirdo at the next table who insisted on getting a steamed milk even though it's not on the menu). 

The food was amazing. I ate WAY too much. Boyfriend got the fried chicken which was delicious. I got the pork chop. We started with the salad with goat cheese. Boyfriend was not excited about the salad to start with but the goat cheese was fried. We finished up with creme brule. 

The meal was amazing. Can't wait until they get a full liquor license. I will be back either way.
author: Kristin G.

description:
I really want to like the Front Porch, I do. I hadn't been there in a while, so when someone suggested brunch there for an out of town guest today we said "sure!"

Again, I was disappointed. I probably should've just gone with the flow and ordered the chicken and waffles, but it seemed like a lot of food for brunch.

I ordered the sweet potato and pork belly hash with eggs. Imagine my surprise when there was very little of anything in it. There was hardly any pork belly in the dish and what was there was under seasoned (salt and pepper for god's sake!). There were no onions or peppers or anything else, it was just sweet potatoes and a tiny amount of pork belly under two eggs. 

Which don't come with toast? I guess I wouldn't have minded paying extra for toast if the bread hadn't been the crappiest white bread possible. Bad toast isn't something you notice until you're paying extra for it, and it's terrible. How can restaurants continue to use shitty bread in this town? Good bread is everywhere, and yet they choose to buy the cheapest, worst possible bread.
author: Mike F.

description: Had a group reservation on Saturday night for 10 people. The place was packed, but we were seated right away on time and had great, quick service. Highly recommend making a reservation. The interior and exterior decor is really well done and gives a great ambiance. We loved the mac-n-cheese, pomegranate apple salad, and shrimp/grits. Cornbread rosemary butter was unique. We had their famous fried chicken that my in-laws raved about, but it was so-so; the chicken was just so salty I couldn't taste much else and wouldn't get again.
author: Paulina B.

description: Like others, I wanted to like it. But can't really recommend. Fried chicken has so much garlic it is not edible. Fried pickles, on the other hand, are super yummy. Can be a hassle getting a table with or without a reservation.
author: Antonia T.

description: love the gumbo good place good service im a fan
author: Leigh G.

description:
I had a family dinner there yesterday, we have a large group of around 30 so we ended up buying out the restaurant for the night. I was in talks with one of the owners, Kevin, who was an extremely friendly and gracious host, in the week leading up to our dinner and found that the restaurant was very accommodating. They drew up a great menu for our dinner and worked with me closely to make sure I was happy.

The night of, the prepared a cocktail reception with small appetizers. Their deep fried chicken sushi comes to mind... it was unforgettable! The staff were extremely friendly and went above and beyond. We had an open bar, and the bartender was very patient and did a good job tending to our group, even the drunk ones! The food came in 4 courses, the small appetizers, shared appetizers, entree and dessert. One of the favorites of the night was their bacon wrapped dates, you must try it. Their Dr. Pepper beef and fried chicken was also delicious. Most of the people from my family were from overseas and had never had Southern food before, but were raving about the food by the end of the night. 

At the end, the staff got us taxis and helped us figure out where to go for those who wanted to stay out later. They were very friendly throughout the night and interacted with the group to make sure everyone was happy without being intrusive. The restaurant itself was cozy, and even though we were sitting on different tables, we were able to utilize the space to walk around and socialize throughout the night. I would recommend this place to anyone and everyone, not just those looking to have a private event!
author: Beverly L.

description: The fried chicken is to die for!  It's great with lots of flavor and very different than KFC obviously!  The wait for order to-go is less than 30min so it's not bad at all!
author: Wailun Eugene W.

description: So delicious! Blue cheese and bacon burger was best I've ever had! Wanted to try fried chicken but opted for arugula salad and Mac and cheese instead! Very yum and friendly service. Loved the decor especially the water bottles!
author: Monica L.

description: Fried Chicken, Fried Pickles, Fried Dates Wrapped in Bacon, Baked Mac & Cheese, Shrimp Etouffe Fries, Hot Ass Margaritas, Pecan Pie, chill atmosphere, ALL GET A++++ from me!. Go with great company, and I guarantee you will come back.
author: Sabina And Pete V.

description: Excellent atmosphere, excellent service, EXCELLENT FOOD! Any bad review that you might see was written by a fascist! My GF and I found out about it on The Food Network's show Diners Drive-ins and Dives. We had the alligator nuggets, spicy shrimp and grits, Dr. Pepper braised short ribs and the pretzel crust butterscotch cheese cake. The restaurant has a very rustic and dark feel that contributes to the classic old Louisiana feel, which tops the whole experience off! This is now one of my favorite restaurants!
author: Terence M.

description:
Did someone say fried chicken? A friend tipped me off that The Front Porch fries up some crack fried chicken, so like a fried chicken fiend that I am I was there. 

I tried the gumbo and had to a get a bucket of fried chicken. The bucket comes in a popcorn bucket with 9 pieces and sides of mashed potatoes and collard greens. The mashed potatoes was fluffy and oh so buttery but I didn't mind the collard greens so much but I've never been a fan. 

The chicken was everything I expect good fried chicken to be. Moist, juicy, tender meat. And the kicker for it all was their house-made habanero hot sauce. A couple drops and you're good but anymore and you'll be grabbing for that milk. I evened the habanero sauce with their milder house-made hot sauce. It made it a perfect combination with the chicken. 

On the down side though, the gumbo had a burnt taste and the popcorn that came with the bucket of chicken was stale. Either way, I'd be down for the fried chicken any day.
author: Eric L.

description: One of the best fried chicken I ever had ! We ordered the bucket of 10 pieces fried chicken, fried pickle, mac and cheese, beef short ribs. The chicken was juice inside and crispy outside with perfect seasoning. Mac and cheese was great. The waitress was very attentive. The only thing I didn't like about this place was that the light was too dim..
author: grace k.

description: This place is okay. I thought it would of been yummier due to the reviews I read but unfortunately I was mehhh. They took around 30-40 mins to give us our food. It was my boyfriend and I only. I got the fried chicken plate with mash potatoes and collard greens. When we got our food my mash potatoes was cold which was upsetting:( and the chicken had a bitter taste:(. I really thought this place was going to be good but it wasn't:/. The only thing that was good was the mac & cheese, but that took around 30 mins to get:(.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Heard raves about the fried chicken at this place so went to check it out.  But to sum it up, the food at this place was just meh.  A very pricy meh in fact.  Is the fried chicken better than your local kfc?  Probably a lil better.  The one dish I really like and would go back for is the spicy shrimp and grits.  

This place itself is very well decorated with a front porch seating area.  Ideal for a group of friends to just sit and chill.  It is not a place for people watching though as the part of 29th this place is on is not busy at all.
author: Vito L.

description: This is a busy little spot south of Cesar Chavez Blvd, a block off Mission Street.  It's a younger crowd and it's a bit noisy and crowded (usually).  The fried chicken is excellent and they make their own hot sauces, so you'll find it to have a mildly spicy quality.  Hushpuppies are good...fried okra is excellent...the servers are all young, but professional and friendly.
author: Lamont C.

description:
Alabama Arkansas
I do love my ma and pa's 
But not the way I do love yours
Well holy moly me oh my
Front Porch the apple of my eye
Southern food so perfect and so true

Well hot an heavy pumpkin pie,
Chocolate cake and Jesus Christ
Ain't nothin' please me more than
YOUR FRIED CHICKEN

And also your hush puppies. And also your po' boys. And also your shrimp and grits. And also your biscuits. I used to live in the South, and when I come to you I'm back home. Makes me wanna sing the Edward Sharpe song to you.
author: Ali M.

description: Great brunch place- loved the food, the service was good, and the decor was cute. Definitely coming back!
author: Jim P.

description: The Front Porch helped me host a lovely bachelorette dinner for my best friend. They accomodated 9 people very well and we had a great time eating a bucket of fried chicken. Great for groups!
author: Emily M.

description:
I felt at home here.  There is something about the set-up of this place, the lighting, and the dark wood tables that just made me feel really good.  After a long week at work I hit this place up with a buddy for a bro-date.  We gave the server leeway on our first round of drinks and were not disappointed.  Thinking that this was a good omen we dove into a a delicious bowl of mac n' cheese, collard greens and a bucket of fried chicken.  Everything was cooked well.  The chicken was juicy, succulent, and might I say just-greasy enough.    

The servers were super helpful and knowledgeable.  They made an effort to explain the dishes to us and make sure we got just enough food.  Atmosphere-wise, they had some pretty low-key music on punctuated by the appearance of a mariachi singer - random, but it's SF.  

This place isn't cheap, even though it gives off that rustic vibe.  Our bill came out to around $80 bucks/ 2 people.  I'd go back, but save it for a low-key date.
author: Aasim K.

description:
Since I didn't get the chance to actually try to food here, I can't comment on how authentic/tasty/awful it is, which is a shame, considering I'm an actual Southerner (gasp!). My partner and I arrived here, without reservation, at about 6:30ish on a weekday night. We found the place packed, which is usually a good sign. Cue the dramatic music.

We had to flag down a waitress to ask about wait-time. Obviously flustered and spaced-out, she answered, "Uh. I don't know. Let me look." Um, okay? So she flitted around the restaurant, dropping things and grumbling for a while, until she finally quoted us at 20 minutes. We decide to wait, but 20 minutes passed and no dice. A table of three that arrived after us has been seated already. We asked again. She took our name on the back of a customer's receipt, hands us a drink menu, and 
disappeared. Uh. Okay. Southern hospitality, this ain't.

The final straw was when a girl who had reservations for two showed up with three extra people and they still got seated by pulling tables together that we could have sat at, easily. The waitress was so disorganized, she didn't even notice us still standing, waiting, 30 minutes later. We left and went to a different restaurant.

I did get a chance to glance at the menu before I left, though, and all I can say is that at least where I come from, we'd call paying $6 for two biscuits plain ol' fashioned bullshit, even if they're blessed by Paula Deen herself.
author: Reagan T.

description: The mash potatoes is beautifully made. I just had to say that. Went here for dinner and got the bucket of fried chicken, mash potatoes and grits, and mac and cheese. The bucket of chicken was more than enough and was delicious was ketchup and hot sauce. The mac and cheese was meh. Nothing really special; it was very bland. I really encourage you to get the potatoes and grits. You'll probably need a mint though!
author: Mags C.

description:
In the Pretenders' classic song Back to Ohio, Chrissie Hynde sings of her disillusionment as she visits the wasteland that has become of her old Akron home...."I stood on front porch; there was nobody home."

I had pretty much the same sensation here at The Front Porch, but it was newfound disillusionment rather than a bittersweet return home. 

Lookie, all my friends said this was a place to get great fried chicken and southern cooking.

Really? Tough, stringy chicken, overfried, greasy, harshly spiced? Honey, that is Northern Fried Chicken.  You could get run clean out of the south serving this stuff.

Sweet Tea that was allowed to go sour?  That's amateur-hour Yankee crap.  We make better sweet iced tea in Northern Ohio, for cripe's sake.

Tough collards, underseasoned everything, and the cardinal sin:

TOUGH, COLD BISCUITS.

I'll give two stars for the mashed potatoes and the macaroni and cheese, both of which needed copious salt and pepper but otherwise were well prepared.

The rest of this meal was a disaster.  The leftovers from our ill-advised bucket serving of chicken reeked of harsh spices and grease for a couple of hours after our meal, stinking away in a paper bag, like a bad memory, which is what we have to show for our 80 dollar meal at The Front Porch.
author: Kevin S.

description: Not the best spot for vegetarians or those wanting a light, healthy meal!
author: Jill C.

description: I love this place! The service were great and hosts are friendly.  We ordered corn as appetizer and fried chicken for main course.  The front porch sauces are spicy, and I love the green bottle one(forget the name)!
author: Jessie C.

description:
Love their fried chicken! Get the bucket, get the bucket!
The fried okra was delicious. Nice and crispy.
The pecan crusted flounder is very flavorful. The flounder is nice and flaky. 
I love their biscuits as well. This should definitely be ordered with the fried chicken.
author: Mustansir M.

description:
Dined there last night..

Great service

Appetizers: 
dates wrapped in bacon-awesome
Corn bread muffins-very good
Deep fried pickles-excellent

Entree:
3 buckets of chicken,mashed potatoes and collard greens(for 6 people) wonderful. Non greasy very flavorful.


Dessert:
Chocolate creme broule
Binays-HOT_BURNING HOT butvery good once they cooled down.
Muld Wine-amazing

Great energy, fun crowd. 4 stars-took one star off for wine bottle  that was not kept cold through dinner, did not ask for a bucket to keep it cool, but do I have to ask? Otherwise VERY GOOD-would go back!
author: J. B.

description: From the photos and reviews the food looks great.  The point of the crawl was to introduce up to their restaurant with hopes we would return.  I think I will try them since I didn't experience them on the crawl.  Will all the great menu choices, we were served dry biscuit sandwiches, really.  They could have at least gave us the sweet potato fries.
author: MyShawn C.

description: Bit pricey for what you get. Fried chicken is exactly what you want it to be -- scrumptious, delicious, and guilt-provoking. Mac and cheese was a good side. Overall, enjoyed the food but I left thinking I paid way too much for the kind of meal we got.
author: Rohan W.

description:
Had high expectations for this place.  Results....some good / some bad.  Good things were the place was very cutely decorated.  Staff was super nice and friendly. Fried pickles, cornbread, fried green tomatoes, mac n cheese, and the bucket of fried chicken were amongst the favorites.  

Bad things were the place is super small and we were cramped into a booth table. Highly disappointed with the fried okra (dry batter and no flavor), shrimp and grits (came out cold and no flavor), and beignets with chocolate sauce (wasnt light and fluffy but more dense, not typical).
author: Gina S.

description:
Been to the Front Porch a few times now, and it is a fun, eclectic sort of place.  The drinks are reasonably imaginative, and though you will pay more than you are accustomed to for things like mac and cheese and fried chicken, at least they don't break the bank.  

They had a drink there called the SuperBerg, which was basically several small bottles of Underberg mixed with (I think) rootbeer.  It was delicious and fairly priced, considering they used to put 2-3 bottles of Underberg into each one.  I think that they scaled that back last time I was there.  Fun place, but there are better culinary choices in the area.
author: Dave N.

description: Chicken and Jalapeno bacon waffles. Need I say more. This is a great find. I've only been there for brunch, but I will be back.
author: Danny R.

description: Most people that know me, know I am pretty cheap so for me to return to an expensive restaurant means a lot. The food is great. I have had every thing from collard greens, fried chicken, mac n cheese, bbq ribs with mashers, cole slaw, corn bread with sweet butter, garlic mashers, smoked salmon, fried crab cakes, and crawfish hush puppies. Everything I tasted was really good and the service is excellent. I would definitely recommend eating here if you have not yet.
author: Melinda M.

description: Good food and quick service. I also was able to sit out front and have my dog with me. We had a great time
author: Kelly T.

description: Ate here on Sunday afternoon.... Having been born and raised in the South we went based on a recommendation from a local I met on the street. My husband ordered red beans and rice - it was good, but a little over spiced--- hot does not make it Cajun!  I had the hangover helper, it was also way too spicy. The sandwiches and french fries were very good though. Service was pretty slow, but it's the only place we went to that offered sweet tea!!!
author: Vicki C.

description:
Food: Excellent. Portions: big! Service: distracted.

Had a great time, but I wish the servers would pay a little more attention. Might have been an off night. I'll still be back. The fried chicken and mac n cheeze are so epic that I'll wait a day and a night, but for the price I would rather not.
author: Tenkai K.

description:
I'm tempted to give only four stars simply because I can't really afford this place, but it's really a great spot.  I also very rarely eat such hearty foods, but Kevin and his staff, especially the kitchen guys, do a kick-ass job swaying me from my typical dietary constraints.  

All of my health-conscious eating habits go out the window as soon as I breathe in the aromatic breeze that fills this homey little joint.

There are a couple very specific things I could say about what I notice when I peak into the exhibition-style kitchen here that would sound odd to someone who has never worked in a professional kitchen, but it should suffice to say I am impressed by the management here.

Their sustainable fish with jambalaya andouille sausage and hushpuppy is an amazing piece of hella-fresh farmer's market fish pan-seared to a crisp on one side and finished off nicely to just over medium for a delicious, tender and moist texture throughout.  Their "pickle jar" is totally rad for fans of pickled veggies, it often features everything from baby corn to jalapenos to eggplant all pickled with just enough spice and sweetness.  Their fried chicken is a total sensory indulgence, accompanied by savory, tangy collard greens and garlicky mashed potatoes.  Other highlights include the cast-iron-served mac-n-cheese, the fried okra and their complimentary corncakes which come with a delicately flavored butter.

Classic comfort food meets modern ideas and service.  Cask-conditioned ales and other tasty libations, friendly environs and comfortable, cozy, though probably too noisy for some, atmosphere make for a nice night out.

ON A SIDE NOTE: let me mention that this is the only place in my 31 years on Earth where I've seen grown human beings consuming a bucket of fried chicken with a knife a fork.  This is of *zero* relevance to the place itself but rather certain clientele it might attract... the knife and fork kind, I suppose?  Not sure, but it was hilarious.  My mother (from Arkansas) and father (from Louisiana) were laughing their asses off... then we got back to the awesome viddles.
author: Blake C.

description: We had been looking forward to going here ever since we saw them reviewed on Check Please. The service was good, and we got lucky in that the night we went was one of those rare warm nights in SF and we sat outside, but the food was, meh. I lived in the south for a number of years, and had looked forward to having an authentic southern experience but that was not to be. While the menu items are southern in concept, execution was lacking. We started with Fried Okra and the Deviled Eggs, and my husband the Fried Chicken as his entree. The fried foods tasted as if they had been fried earlier in the day and then flash fried to order, making the exterior hard and the center barely warm. My entree was so unmemorable that even with looking at the menu again I can't be sure, was it the Steak and Frites? We're glad we went, it's ticked off now and we don't have to keep wondering. While the Deviled Eggs with Bacon Bourbon Jam were the tastiest part of the meal, it wasn't enough to make us want to come back again.
author: DJ S.

description: Boiled peanuts and bacon wrapped dates! Need I say more... Great Fried chicken with plenty of other options. Cozy atmosphere for your Southern needs.
author: Nick h.

description:
Imagine if they built a "Southern" restaurant at Disney's Epcot Center.

Wife and I where in Bernal Heights with nothing better to do, so we decided to get something to eat.  Some gal recommended Front Porch.

What a mistake!

Off we go.  

What's up with the decor.? It looks like  a mix of "Hee Haw" and the porch from "Deliverance".

The host start talking in what he must think is a southern accent.  Every third word is "y'all"

I wouldn't have been surprised if some "hillbillies" came out and started playing.

Anyways.  Let's talk about the food. 

I ordered fried chicken.  Wife had the mac and cheese.  Spilt fried pickles and biscuits.  Standard Southern fare.

There is only one word to describe it.....BLAND!

Southern food isn't known for its lack of flavor but this stuff sure was.  I'll give them credit I've never ever tasted a bland pickle, but they sure made one here.

Honestly the food at Popeyes is 10x better and 1/3 cheaper then what we got here.

........

This place isn't about Southern cooking.  No this is all about the "experience".  

You know like Disneyland Epcot isn't about what other countries are really like but they give you the "experience".
author: Richard W.

description:
The other day my friend was telling me about his trip to North Carolina where he walked into an all you can keep Kentucky Fried Chicken. First of all that is frickin' crazy! All you can eat KFC is crazy.

Well, as gross as that sounds, I was now motivated to go find me some fried chicken. 

So here I am...well, here I was (excuse the poor English).

Went with the better half and her friend. Reservations were a breeze for a Friday night....shocking. But as usual, we had early reservations at 6:30.

This place has a crazy number of reviews, so I won't bore you with too many details, other than the following:

Swamp Cabbage - Get it. it is delicious. For three people if you're hungry, get two.
Mac n cheese - you know it's good when you feel your mouth start salivating before the first spoon touches your lips. DON'T GET MORE THAN ONE. YOU WILL REGRET IT.....I DID.
Rice and Beans - surprisingly good and not healthy. This is not a healthy choice. It is healthier, but don't fool yourself.
Chicken bucket (ala KFC) - about 8 pieces served in a popcorn bucket with popcorn. Now I can eat a lot of chicken, but three pieces were more than enough. Lots of juicy flavor and better than Hard Knox (which used to be my favorite in the area).
Beignets - Okay, don't bother. Eat more chicken
Cobbler - Get the Beignets before getting this, but again, see previous note.

So all that alone warrants the 5 stars, but what really pushed me to a solid 5 was the cask beer. For those of old English descent or enamored with the UK, cask beer is beer that is stored in cellar temperature - basically about 50 degrees.

I was excited to see the beer on the menu and gave it a go. The first gulp was fantastic. Full flavored and lots of umph!, but the subsequent ones were just too warm. I had to switch for round two, but this was still a good beer. Definitely something to have once if you have never had cask beer before.

This place rocks. Rocks even more given the recent SFGate daily deal where $10 got you $20 of food. Yes!
author: Andrew C.

description: We started with fried pickles, delish! My 8 year old ordered a cheese burger from the kids menu.  She ate at least half of her burger and ate some of our food too.  The short ribs is fork tender and very tasty, the kids loved it, my 4 year-old son devoured half of the short ribs.  The shrimp and grits was ok, not spicy at all.  The fried chicken is delish, both of my kids devoured the chicken down to the bones.  The beignet was so good, kids ate them all.  Overall there is nothing bad about this place, just a little dark.  Def would come back again!
author: L L.

description:
Fried okra appetizer was delicious.  The fried chicken is extra crispy and quite good. Comes with mashed potatoes and gravy with collard greens.  They were ok.  Mac and cheese was comfortingly hot, gooey and with crispy cheese caked on the sides which I managed to scrape off and devour.  It's simple and delicious. Unfortunately it is ridiculously priced for chicken.  $34 for a bucket of 9 pieces (2legs, 2 thighs, 2 wings, 3 breasts?? )   The only other option was a 3 piece meal for half that price. If someone else is buying, and I am in the mood for a super heavy southern meal, I'd go back. But, when I can buy a really delicious whole rotisserie chicken for $5 at costco...nnnnnrrrr.... $34 for chicken?  damn, that bird better give me a back rub too.
4 stars for the flavor...2 for price.  p.s. Great wait staff.
author: B B.

description:
I can't stay away! 
I've only been for brunch but I sure as hell will be back to try some dinner.
Lazy Sundays lounging in a rocking chair or a dimly lit booth waiting on my chicken and waffles or baked eggs and grits or anything else on the menu for that matter is what I call a perfect sunday! 
Need your nails done or some ice cream after both sunrise nails and Mitchells are just a block away! Luv it
author: Stephany M.

description:
Still loving on Front Porch. This time for a large work dinner. We got a prix fixe menu and for $30 that got us family style apps of:
bbq shrimp on french bread (yummy but heads on? EW)     
gumbo chicken & andouille sausage with fried okra  (super yum)
field salad (best chickpeas ever, were they carmelized?)
 
and a choice of entree. I had miss clara's fried chicken with garlic mashed potatos which was totally amazing. Perfectly crispy but not over-breaded.  Husband had the brown sugar brined grilled pork chop which was also delicious!

For dessert we all got our own bread pudding with bourbon hard sauce and yam ice cream...yummy, but I was so full I didn't need it. For drinks, I enjoyed the ramblin' rose, the champagne cocktail, and discovered that the orange marmalade drink was actually delicious even when you hate marmalade!

The waitstaff was great and attentive, impressive with a large group.
author: Nikki M.

description:
A cute, unique, garage-turned-restaurant...that's way too expensive.

I don't mind paying $30+ for a great steak, but, I have no idea why a bucket of chicken would be $30+? Is there something special about the chicken that I don't know about?
author: Juliette R.

description:
pissed ... was here on a sunday a couple weeks ago. had made reservations for 6 for my birthday lunch. I have been here about 3 times before & wrote a positive yelp review a month before and I was excited to bring some friends here.

worst . time . ever 

the service was HORRIBLE. mind you, it was about 1:30 pm, not busy. probably about 4 tables full at this point. 

I'm sorry, but my friend literally asked for a side of mayonnaise 4 times until the redhead behind the bar (who took our initial order) finally walked her sorry ass to the kitchen to get it herself which took only about 5 seconds. it was bullshit.

also, when they brought all our food, we reminded them we had one more dish coming. the guy who brought our food asked the gal who took our order (redhead again) where it was. she said she guessed she forgot to put the order in. their conversation was about 2 feet away from our table and we could hear everything they said but they did not acknowledge us or tell us 'sorry' or 'it'll be a minute' ... nothing. if they had said something to us we would have canceled the order. 

so anyway, that dish finally came and it was the worst. it was the shrimp & grits (which I have had before) and the grits were hard and the sauce was watery. 

not only was that forgotten & rushed dish NOT comped, or apologized for either, we also had to pay the check with gratuity included since we were a table of 6. which was infuriating ... if the tip had not been included, we would have not tipped anything. 

in fact, it took them so long to come get our check we considered walking out without paying. I have never in my life ever considered doing such a thing.

what a terrible disappointment, and on my birthday. I felt so bad for my friends too - worst of all I looked like a freaking chump for actually liking the front porch. thanks a lot.
author: Leslie S.

description: SO so yummy! From the rocking chair seats to the copious amount of flavor, Front Porch made me feel like I was eating back home in Georgia! Best southern-like food I've had yet in San Francisco [and yes, I've been to Brenda's... twice]. I went for brunch and had the baked eggs/grits/bacon combo which was amazinglicious. I'll definitely be back for dinner!!!
author: Ally B.

description:
I loved the atmosphere at this place, but the food left much to be desired. There was only one vegetarian entree on the vaguely descriptive menu. I had to ask our waitress what the dish consisted of and hope for the best. She told me the dish was comprised mainly of root vegetables, but when I received my plate is was mainly roasted squash, maybe a few sweet potato bits and a celery purée; all of which was overly salted. 
The party I was with split the fried chicken and were about as pleased with their choice of entree as I was. Overall I would say this is way too overpriced for salty "comfort food." The saving grace might have to be the whiskey and bourbon selection, but I feel like that is not hard to come by in the city. Underwhelmed, Front Porch. Sorry 'bout it.
author: Lauren Gayle S.

description: This place is so tasty and fun.  I went with 5 other people and decided to eat family style.  We ordered almost every entree not named "meat loaf".  And that's only because we thought it was just absurd to order any more.  We had the bucket of chicken, shrimp and grits, flounder, and ham entrees.  We ordered the mac n' cheese on the side. The chicken is really good, and the grits are amazing.  But we didn't expect the flounder to be the most flavorful out of the bunch! I've been here before and ordered the burger, which is my opinion is one of the best in SF.  Of course we ordered the frickels, which are also the best in SF, and the deviled eggs (yes, please!). For dessert, we ordered the cheesecake (too much chocolate for my taste), the bread pudding and the pecan pie.  The break pudding and pecan pie were absolutely delicious.  And this is coming from someone who typically likes neither of those.
author: Matthew S.

description: Very oily, food is not seasoned enough. The pork chop has so much fat that it was almost unedible. Wish there was some redeeming dish, but did not find any.
author: Balu V.

description: First time at The Front Porch for brunch with friends. Poor lighting made it difficult to read the menu. The only vegan option was okay, drinks were good and food service was very slow. My friends ate non-vegan options such a fried chicken and waffles, fried chicken steak and thought it was okay.
author: June S.

description:
10+ STARS! My friend brought us to her little favorite spot where apparently they have amazing fried chicken. Well, I am not one for fried chicken.. Gotta keep slim which is impossible to do when you are in a city yielding so many great restaurants.   

CAUTION YOU WILL LEAVE IN A FOOD COMA AND FEEL LIKE A FAT ASS AFTER..

So, we started out with appetizers Shrimp and grits. The waitress brought out comp. brussel sprouts which were the best.. My friends here enough so she gets the preferital treatment! Brussel  sprouts made with Molasses and butter.. Try them they are amazing..  I also had for the very first time mulled wine! FELL IN LOVE.. Two glasses and I was feeling tipsy.. As my entree I went with a burger.. Couldn't finish it.  I was full from the wine and our appetizers.. I love this place.. 

Super crowded so you may have a wait..
author: Christina S.

description:
At the end of the day it's got to be about the food and the food at Front Porch was just A-ok. 

Aside from that there's many things to like about this place. The vibe is casual and homey. It's in the mission so packed with the usual suspects: hipsters and urbanites. The menu is full of comfort food faves (so maybe there is hope for a 4 star review) and delectable cocktails. Seating is plentiful and that night there was a Mariachi band making their way through the restaurant. 

Prices and portions were definitely reasonable and service was prompt. 

I wanted to sample a little bit of everything so for starters we chose the Fried Green tomatoes and fried pickles. They also provide complimentary cornbread and these were addicting. Not the consistency of typical cornbread but definitely full of flavor and extra moist and buttery. 

The fried green tomatoes were forgettable but the fried pickles were a surprising stand-out. They were breaded ever so lightly allowing you to taste the tartness of the pickle while still providing a nice crunch, and the dipping sauce rounded out it out perfectly. 

We also ordered the biscuits which were a bit disappointing. I'd say Pillsbury has them beat. Southern cuisine is all about the staples and biscuits are as basic to Southern food as it gets. Theirs were more doughy than flaky and pretty bland. Although the pepper jelly helped the cause with its smooth sweet taste and slight kick. 

For my entree I went with a classic: fried chicken mash and gravy and greens with bacon. The entire meal was a disappointment. I'm no chef but I can cook this same meal with more love and have it taste a whole heck of a lot better.

 My biggest gripe was their chicken. Overbreaded and way too crunchy (didn't even know this could be a bad thing). The batter was just an overly crunchy mess and while the chicken was juicy it just plain lacked flavor. The greens had way too much bite (sour) and were soggy. I hardly tasted the bacon at all. The mashed and gravy were the only saving grace. Potatoes were nice and light and the gravy was nice and thick. 

We had filled up so didn't get to sample the dessert but I had tasted enough to make up my mind.  

Southern cuisine is at the top of my list and while Front Porch has plenty of charm their food lacks the flavor that's at the soul of Southern cooking.
author: Dorothy F.

description:
This place is great!

The friend chicken was delicious! It was moist and tender, and when eating it, it didn't feel like my mouth was covered with shortening like these other fried chicken joints.  

The Jalapeno hush puppies were really good but the porch fries is the winning side dish, it is salty, spicy, and crunchy goodness. My mouth couldnt get enough of the fries seriously UUUUHHHMAAAAZING.

OH and before I forget, they let this Mexican Guitar player come in and serenade all of us; it dont get nothing better. I felt a little ashamed when he came around asking for tips because I only had a dollar in cash; but if I had a five I would have given him that in an instant.
author: Luigi B.

description:
I have been to Front Porch many times and really like the food and atmosphere. As I've told many friends, they usually only have one veg entree -- some sort of vegan vegetable-based melange -- but it's always been good. Imagine my disappointment when I brought some friends here recently for the first time and they were not only out of their ONLY veg entree, but our server was completely unapologetic, telling us to just order a bunch of sides. The entree is described generically as "fresh veggies cooked up with love," so I don't quite understand how they could be completely out of ALL VEGETABLES (hello -- send someone to Whole Foods!) and could not improvise something. The fact that this is their ONLY veg entree makes their responsibility much higher in this regard.

That attitude made me sorry I'd sold my friends on coming here. Past positive experiences still get it 3 stars, but I'll revisit that if I come back.
author: Gaelen X.

description:
Just not impressed...and clearly way over hyped. Lemme start by noting I'm a native Nashvillian, so I know my southern food.

Decor and ambiance was nice. Server was super friendly.

Started off with bacon wrapped dates...tasty..hard to screw up anything wrapped in bacon.

I had the fried chicken. Kcf makes better tasting chicken...which is sad. The technique they use is good...crunchy and juicy...just no flavor. Not marinated in any thing (I assume) and the flour they used desperately needed seasoning, most notably salt. Mashed potatoes and greens were pretty good.

Husband had the Dr Pepper braised short ribs.  Pretty sure that wasn't a short rib but a chuck roast...it was tender so good there...just wasn't any short rib I've ever seen. Celery purée and the sauce went well with it though.

Last...we both had sweet tea...cause omg how we miss that! Not sure how they messed up Lipton...but I think they used to many tea bags to water ratio...still was sweet tea so there's that.

Overall not impressed..especially for the price.
author: Joe H.

description: Crunchy and full of flavor. Simple and good. The greens were too vinegary for me but the potatoes were heavenly...scared to know how much cream and butter went into that side. Ask for extra gravy..it just complements the potatoes. The mac and cheese was pretty good. They found a nice middle ground between baked and creamy mac and cheese.
author: Eve C.

description:
I don't even like brussel sprouts but these brussel sprouts are bomb! The decor is really adorable: really quirky, down-home and fun. The fried chicken was good, as was the fried okra, burger, catfish with sweet potato fries. Oh! And the seats in the back are made of van seats. Way cute.

Will definitely be back.
author: Hanan H.

description: Another great example of san francisco sophisticated style blended with something traditional. The food I had was well done and tasted amazing. Cocktail bar. Sweet tea and great desert menu. Regular menu looked great as well, can't wait to come back.
author: Will D.

description:
Are you kidding me?!?! The front porch knocked my panties off!!!

1. The place is so cute. Rocking chairs in the front!! Inside it feels like a cozy home, with interesting art on  the walls. The light is super low, giving it that whole sexy bayou feel. It's a little cramped in there, but i guess that adds to the appeal.

2. The fooooooood OMG the fooooooooood. First and foremost, get the fried chicken. It comes in a bucket with popcorn (why? I have no frickn' clue- but who cares?) SO INCREDIBLY GOOD. You'll be smacking your fingers all the way home. You'll want to lick the bowl the mashed potatoes come, and the green- Good Lord Almighty- they will turn you into a southern belle.

3. The service was pretty friendly- I mean they were busy, but they kept up the nice attitude.

So why not five stars, Nnekay? Well the wait... good grief the wait was insane- AND we had reservations. If you make reservations you shouldn't have to wait....

but aside form that the food was INSANE.
author: Nnekay F.

description: Always wanted to come here to try their famous fried chicken and bacon waffle and finally did. I did like it - it was really good and juicy, the waffle was great as well. We came in late Sunday after 1pm the crowd definitely died down but boy the service was too slow and we ordered something they didn't even brought to the table oh wells. The place is also really dark and more like a pub scene.
author: Joiera C.

description: Great gazpacho, cornbread (comes before the meal), and apps; entree (holy shit burger) was intense (deep fried bacon, pulled pork, homemade American cheese)- definitely couldn't even finish half of it. Each individual part was delicious but all together a bit overwhelming. Great vibe and super nice servers.
author: Kristen B.

description: I love the atmosphere - wish more restaurants had such huge, beautiful artwork on the walls. And I'm thankful for any southern/cajun food I can find. And I love how it's fancy it feels, but yet still located in a former garage. But the portions - at least the ones we ordered were all very small. I definitely have to try the shrimp n' grits next time.
author: Jules F.

description: I took my wife to the front porch for Sunday brunch the service was spotty the food was not good at all my wife she had the grits and sausage it was not good at all I had a Bloody Mary a half shrimp poor boy and I ate half the macaroni and cheese 2 hours later I was sick as a dog I got food poisoning from the food that I ate at this restaurant on that day which was Sunday that would fit to for a dog I will never go there again I would never recommended anyone closer to service was spotty the food was greezy and I'm sick as hell I haven't ate anything since it is now Monday evening at 6 o'clock I'm just now getting over it I do not know if it was the Bloody Mary it taste kind of kind of bad I did not even finish the the drink I did half of the shrimp po boy and half of the macaroni and cheese the reason why my wife did not get sick she ate very little she had a bite of the grits a bit of the biscuit and and lemonade the reason why she's not sick she did not consume the same food that I I brought the leftovers home for my son but two hours after I came home I got sick I told my son to throw the food in the trash can I thought about calling the restaurant and complaining but why do that when I could write a review to let other people know my express at this restaurant
author: Norman W.

description: One of the best Mac & Cheeses I have ever eaten!  Cool little spot in the outer Mission.
author: Brian S.

description:
YUMMY!!! i've been wanting to try a southern restaurant for awhile so when my friend suggested this place we jumped at the chance to try it. we had resies at 9:00pm, showed up a little bit early and were seated promptly. 

everything on the menu looked sooooo good. we started with a few appetizers...fried pickles and fried green tomatoes. we also got fried okra on the house because our waitress had put the order in wrong. sweet! the pickles were super vinegary and delicious. the okra was a little bit on the slimy side but still good. the fried green tomatoes came with a crazy shrimp mayo sauce which was super tasty. for entrees, i ordered the spicy shrimp and grits. the shrimp was seasoned to perfection and the grits were simply creamy goodness. my friends got the sustainable fish entree which featured halibut that night and the risotto special. everything was soooooo flavorful and comforting. it was a bit of a heavy meal but definitely worth it and the service was great!
author: Linda N.

description:
When I showed up to Front Porch with no reservation for myself, the staff here were more than willing to find me a seat in the VERY BUSY restaurant and they were even CHEERY about it. 
The waitress and I ended up sharing some biscuits as I didn't want two to myself and we had a grand 'ol time. 
I had their specialty - fried chicken. Great flavor, spice and salt ratios. The fried okra wasn't quite as great as the chicken, but it's just nice to see okra on the menu!
A great experience!
author: Melody M.

description:
I'm disappointed on the food.  Stale popcorn, tasteless jambalaya, super burnt burger.  no buenos

Service was awesome though.

one dish that was yummy, can't quite remember the name but it was a seafood dish with rice.  Very rich and flavorful.
author: Anna W.

description:
This place seems really popular, and I think the volume of high scores of reviews on Yelp set my expectations too high. Overall, the food was just mediocre, the wait too long, and the price did not justify the quality.  I don't think I will return.
By the way, I absolutely love Cajun and Creole food, and have had some of the best in New Orleans, which may contribute to unfair expectations.   

The food took a very long time to come out, and I kept thinking the wait must be worth it because the food will be so good... but I felt disappointed after a couple of bites.   I tried 2 of their best-selling dishes, and a side of mac n cheese:

Fried chicken single 4 piece for $18 with mashed potatoes, collard greens with hamhock (or bacon?) - Chicken was not as juicy and flavorful as I would like, some pieces were bland.  I'm sad to say I've had better chicken at Popeye's.  Mashed potatoes very standard.  Collard greens were just not good at all, my boyfriend took one bite and refused to eat the rest.

Dr. Pepper braised short ribs with parsnip puree and mustard greens for $24 - beef was tender, well marinated.  Parsnip puree was smooth and velvety and the broth was good, complimented well with the beef.  Mustard greens added a nice taste and texture. Much better than the fried chicken dish.

Mac n Cheese $7 - decent but nothing to write home about.  Needed just a touch more salt.

Lemonade - refreshing, and had just the right amount of sourness to sweetness ratio.

Sweet tea - just right, not too sweet like some other places.

Service was very friendly.  Good happy crowd and atmosphere.
author: M B.

description:
So... I ordered take out... and... the chicken gumbo was terrible.  Fried pickles, pretty good.  Side of green beans, fantastic.

Why still the four stars, when the gumbo was terrible?  Because the first meal I had there was divine.  Maybe it was my mistake for ordering chicken gumbo?

I'm a smörgåsbord eater, I like to try a bunch of things, or share stuff, and not be confined to just one dish.  Please, please, please bring back the small plate shrimp and grits... puh-leeeeeease (I'm begging).  It's the perfect portion for someone who wants shrimp and grits and something else...  

And if you don't... I'll just order the big portion, and be sad that I can't be a smörgåsbord eater but happy to have the grown-up size shrimp and grits (because they are soooooooooooooo good).
author: Lani N.

description:
Not impressed! AT ALL by The Front Porch other than for the bill.
I decided to give it a try but h onestly, not too much to say... Ill keep it short:

Pros:
1. Neighborhood vibe, casual and "cool"
2. Next door from Bernal Heights Collective
3. Awesome Mussles, OMG Giant ones and pretty yummi!!

Cons:
1. Very expensive for the overall dining experience you get
2. Main courses were "whatever" - raw meat in the burger and the pork chop was dry (not to be the worst but I cook better pork at home)
3. They took forever to serve the food... FOREVER! 

That said, I can only think of Emmys Spaghetti Shack. Best value in Bernal :)
author: Anaheli D.

description:
I have been known to imbibe on occasion. Well, let's not play. I am a wino, and also a lush. And anywhere there is sangria, you might find me doing a little dance, singing along with Barry White and making my companions slightly uncomfortable.

Actually, on the real tip, "Can't Get Enough of Your Love" is one of my favorite things in life. Whenever I hear it, I muster what small bits of funk and soul live deep down in this bland white girl (I would not go so far as to say I have an Oakland Booty, but perhaps a Berkeley Booty, or more appropriately, a Potrero Hill Booty, which is where the funk resides) and proceed to pantomime Mr. White's timeless monologue. 

"I've heard people sayin'... too much of anything is not good for ya, babe...But... I don't know about that... as many times as we've loved and shared love and made love... it just doesn't seem to me like it's enough... it's just not enough..."

And here's the thing: I've heard that song maybe 5,341 times to date. I hear it in my sleep I know it so well. But no person has ever made me feel like singing that song to them; I've been plagued by the song's meaning because... who am I singing for? This ode of odes, this decadent song of devotion? Will I never feel these feelings??

And then I met The Front Porch. Cue crescendo of 70's fabulousness.

"MY DARLING I... CAN'T GET ENOUGH OF YOUR LOVE, BABE..."

I went on a Thursday night, which is prime for dining so you must make a reservation. Which they take. And you best not be so gauche as to assume they will seat you without your whole party present. Have you seen this place?? It is SMALL. 
But much like Newman-O's, and the iPod nano, and Dunzo S., petite packages can pack a serious dose of awesome. And the Front Porch is awesome.

Inevitable comparisons will be made with Farmerbrown, for obvious reasons. (Like novelty cornbread and a strangely similar coating on the fried chicken. Oh, and also the san franciscanized soul food concept.) But I am well acquainted with Farmerbrown's precipitous decline of late (RIP, good food and service), and you should not judge the son for the sins of the father. (Um, I am in no way implying a parental relationship between the two restaurants. I have no firsthand knowledge of any relationship beyond some creepy similarities.)

Anyway, Front Porch is like your badass little sister who got a bunch of tattoos and slept around in high school, but has matured into a pot smoking antique dealer with really fucking good food. Like delicious fried chicken, black eyed peas and greens, plantain chips with a tuna poke type thing, fried plantains (FRIED PLANTAINS ARE MY FAVORITE THING IN LIFE, AS YOU MAY KNOW), a thoughtful vegan entree, smoky soups and gratuitous avocado. Oh, and a bowl of grits that you stir in some chili oil and make a magical bowl of creamydeliciousness.

Cue the mellow sounds of Barry:

"IT'S LIKE THE MORE YOU GIVE, THE MORE I WANT IT... BABY, THAT'S NO LIE..."

I would probably have done a better job describing the menu if we weren't busying ourselves sucking down peachy sangria and pinot grigio out of juiceboxes, lunchbox style. Yes, really. My baby is all class.

In fact, I don't even remember dessert. But I do remember that they made an attempt at tin ceilings, which were frighteningly inauthentic, but a sweet gesture. Um, if you are actually interested in the merits of the interior from an architectural historian's perspective, I will say that the bathroom is where it's at. 

In sum, great environment, nice owner, fantastic place to take a date or four bitches you're trying to ply with cheap wine and delicious foods.

And so, Front Porch, I grab the (fake) mike and say to you:

"Baby, it may take all of my life...to find you... but you can believe it's going to take the rest of my life... to keep you... oh Oh OH DARLING I... CAN'T GET ENOUGH OF YOUR LOVE, BABE!!"
author: Megan W.

description: Came here for dinner last week with a friend and we loved everything we had, and we has a a lot of food! We started with the mixed green salad and fried pickles which we amazing, probably the best I've ever had. She had a burger and I had friend green tomatoes and gumbo as a main dish. Gumbo was really good, nice and flavorful but on too spicy (how I like it). I'm telling you we left this place feeling stuffed and happy! Wanna come back to try their brunch soon.
author: Alexis W.

description: OMG! I went here with my besties for my birthday and the food was awesome we had the shrimp and grits and the Mac and cheese and the fried chicken! All was sooo good! Drinks are good to ;)
author: Davis B.

description:
The funny thing about expectations is that it can sometime skew a moment in a good or bad way.

With that in mind, some of the higher rated restaurants on Yelp may have fallen victim to the exaggerated assumptions I derived from their reviews and subsequently have only garnered three stars from yours truly.
Sorry.

It's really too bad because if I just adhered to ignorance being bliss, maybe some of the same places may have gotten four or five stars instead.
Sucks.

The thing is when a review is right and a restaurant impresses, my gastronomic leap of faith is rewarded with good eats, and my faith in my fellow Yelper is renewed.
Hallelujah.

The Front Porch lived-up to expectations and then some.

Although, there was some trepidation when I first saw the fried chicken.  It looked burnt.  But what I mistakenly thought to be overcook was merely the deep fried color of (I'm assuming) the cornmeal coating: crispy with a little spice and hints of lemon.  What I liked most about the coating was how succulent it kept the chicken inside.

And the two sides really complimented and completed the meal.
Grits were firm and sweet and really took nicely to being lightly drizzled with chilly oil on top.
The black eye peas were mixed with greens, coconut milk, and also had some heat to it.

Overall, the restaurant is inviting and loud and in a part of the City I would have never expected to find a sit down place that served comfort food of this quality.

Good Stuff.
author: Dan B.

description:
What do you get when you take an Emmy's Spaghetti Shack, remove the Italian influence, and replace it with southern comfort cooking? Well you get The Front Porch! 

Like "The Shack" you get a quirky / cool interior (my date sat on a re-purposed van bench), a relatively bargain-priced gourmet meal, a ton of in-the-know hipster types, and a painful wait (about 1 hr on Friday night) with no reservations taken.

I started with a roast quail salad (the special), which was decent and the birdie had some serious kick. For our main we split the bucket of fried chicken. The fries were diverse (lots of different potato types in there) and the slaw was okay (a bit too mayo-ed for me). Also borrowed from Emmy's: homemade ketchup, which smelled and tasted great.

Overall good value, a bit too much hype, and a brutal wait.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
You're food is good, great waitress. 

HOWEVER, the LONG BLONDE HAIRED hostess was absolutely horrific. There were at least 3 tables open. She seated us right by the stairs while my date and I were looking for a more intimate experience. Before we were seated, she was already gone. We waited for her to come back for a good 5 minutes STANDING UP next to the tabe, she was no where to be found. So we took the liberty to move to the back empty table by the bathroom. 

She finally shows up again, looking at the empty table and says (What the fuck. Where did they go?) We're about 3 tables away and WE can hear it. We then waved her down to let her know that we moved. She then says, "WHY CAN'T YOU JUST SIT WHERE I SEAT YOU!" 


Conclusion: We're not in the boonies. There are way too many good restaurants in SF to put up with a narcissistic, ill-mannered HOSTESS.
author: Michelle Y.

description: I finally made it to The Front Porch in time for lunch. I Love this place! :-) Filé gumbo is delicious!
author: Carl W.

description: Probably my favorite "date night" place in the city. Really small location in the outer mission/bernal heights area with great atmosphere and lighting. The shrimp and grits are my favorite thing on the menu and I often get the fried okra and a side of carrots.
author: Katie U.

description:
This place is a small, modest little spot in the outer mission. The decor gives it a southern feel, and you can smell the fried chicken from down the block. 
I had the Shrimp and Grits, which was amazing. the gravy really made the plate wonderful. 
My boyfriend had the fried chicken and mashed potatoes and collard greens. I got to try the greens, which were also very good.

I would definitely come here again, and I would also tell others to come here as well. 
Very nice!
author: Sami B.

description: Alright, so I finally made it to the Front Porch and let me tell you. I was really excited to try out their fried chicken, since I've read good reviews about it. So we started with a few starters like the jalapeños bacon deviled eggs which I give em 4 for being creative. The fried okras were also 4, loved the dip. Also got biscuits & baked Mac & cheese which were a big 5. The biscuit very fluffy & tasty but the baked Mac & cheese were out of this world. So finally to their fried chicken, so sorry to disappoint anyone but I sure definitely was disappointed. Gotta give the chicken a 2.5. Don't get me wrong the chicken it self was real tender & juicy but it really didn't have no flavorly taste. Oh yeah the service was real real great. Wish I would of gave em a 4 but in my opinion this place is not all the hype it should be.
author: Edward M.

description:
Loved the Fried Chicken here. Also when they say fucket-get-a-bucket 10 pieces for $30, those are some pretty large 10 pieces!

Have some really nice drink options too and am definitely looking forward to coming back soon!
author: Aggie Z.

description:
The food was really good.... but the place was hot inside near the bathroom.... not to much option in the bar.... 

the food was so good....
author: Florence C.

description: We continue to frequent Front Porch and have had nothing but great experiences - some of the best cocktails, consistently good and interesting food, and great service.  Feel like they've earned the 5th star!
author: Neil M.

description:
I can understand why this place has majority 4 star reviews.

It's just a hair shy of being totally kick ass.

For my boyfriend and I, it was the pork and beans appetizer dish that was just not super amazing. I love pork belly.  But the kitchen seared it and added something to the skin piece that made each bite get stuck in every crevasse of each tooth in my mouth and we were at the table picking seared pork belly out of our teeth before the main courses came. 

That said, the rest of our meal was kind of amazing. I had the fried chicken meal. Superb! Three pieces of chicken perfectly fried, collard greens, mashed potatoes and gravy. My bf had the shrimp and grits meal portion and enjoyed it very much. The grits were perfectly made. The sous and head chef are both from the south so their grits better be amazing!

Overall, ambiance and quality of food was very on point and we had a fantastic experience here and would definitely go back. 

For drinks, we each had Lilet and a Sweet Iced Tea. Amazing!

One appetizer, two entrees, 4 drinks, happy bellies = $72 (w/ tip) total bill. Not bad, yo.

Go check it out.
author: Matthew M.

description: Dinner was great - easy to get a table for two on opentable for a Saturday night the week of. Great fried chicken (4 pieces - thigh, leg, 2 breast halves) - succulent and crispy. The root beer braised short rib entree was smaller than expected, but really tasty. Biscuits are solid. BBQ shrimp starter had this awesome spicy creole sauce that I wished I had more baguette to sop it up! The Porch Swing cocktail was a major win. The apple cobbler and butterscoth pudding were HUGE portions and yummy. I was enamored with the mini cornbread muffins that are brought in lieu of a bread basket... the compound butter was to die for.
author: Kristen K.

description:
This review is solely on the dinner service at The Front Porch. I have heard better things about the brunch service at TFP but I have YET to try.

A friend of mine suggested we give this place a try since we were both craving some good ole southern comfort food. Be sure to keep your eyes pealed since this place can be quite hidden around night time and you can drive by this place and miss it. We had a reservation at 7:30pm and we were promptly seated. This ambiance of TFP  featured dim lighting and intimate setting with a nice hum/chatter/laughter of the patrons. The waitress came over and dropped about three different kinds of menus (a prefix, drink, and food). We took a quick look at the prefix which featured items we weren't too interested in so we passed on that. We then proceeded to browse the drink menu and decided on two cocktails (don't remember the name but one was mojito based and super tasty)

Our drinks came promptly and the waitress came and took our order. We decided on their infamous Fried Chicken Bucket. We considered getting a side dish but opted out of getting one when our waitress told us that the side dishes (Collard Greens & Mashed Potatoes) that came with the bucket should be more than enough food for two people.

There was a wait time of around 25 minutes so stated in the menu for them to prepare the chicken. The chicken came out pipping hot in a large movie theater popcorn bucket with a handful of popcorn mixed with the chicken. We dug in the skin was crisp and the meat was tender and moist. DELICIOUS! The flavor was a little lacking since it was just white meat so a little hot sauce did the trick.

The mashed potatoes and collard greens were good but forgettable. Like the waitress said, we ended our meal with one remaining piece of fried chicken with 4 a piece. 

During our meal two different mariachi bands came into TFP and gave a performance for tips. It was pretty fun and entertaining the first time but by the second time it got a little annoying. 

Parking can be a challenge but not impossible. 

Overall I had a great experience at TFP and would definitely come back again!
author: Myron J.

description:
Prison Work Experiment

I ordered the medium-rare tri-tip here. When it arrived it was thin over-cooked and rubbery. The waitress gladly took it back to have a new one prepared.

The new one was seared and bright pink in the middle but at least it had a little flavor. There was a lot of gristle. The waitress saw it, laughed, and told me it was the end-piece. She offered to take it back again when she saw the pink but we both new it wouldn't be worth it.

When I walked to the back of the restaurant I saw two large women in hair-nets in the exposed kitchen that reminded me of Switchblade Sisters prison scenes. Participating in prison-work experiments is noble but I think I'll wait until I'm in the central coast before ordering my next tri-tip.

The waittress was nice enough to reduce our bar tab by a small amount.
author: Pepé H.

description:
Everything was overpriced and tasteless and more yet the waitress spilled most of an alcoholic drink on me! She proceeded to be sarcastic about the spill while we asked --- What about refilling our spilled drink? BAD BAD customer service. However, the WORST part is I realized on my receipt that the Front Porch, or the waitress, added themselves a LARGER tip than I had put in! 

Reasons to avoid this place!

1- They inflate their tips by adding more after you have left.
2- The food is tasteless and overpriced.

The first reason is ENOUGH they are dishonest. Everyone, check your receipts!
author: Darrel H.

description:
Interesting decor in the restaurant, service wasn't too bad.  I liked how they kept the menu simple.  Prix fixe with choice of 3 choices of appetizers, a few choices of entrees and 2 choices of desserts.

Mac n cheese is definitely one of the BEST mac n cheeses I have ever had.  Gooey thick layer of baked cheese on top over creamy, flavorful mac n cheese served in a cast iron skillet was amazing.

Fried chicken and waffles were good, but I still prefer Lil Skillet's.  The chicken was moist and the breading was just the right amount but not crazy memorable.

The beignets were good.  They definitely gave you a lot so but after the huge mac n cheese and fried chicken, I was too stuffed to finish it.

If I get a mac n cheese craving and I'm near the area, I will be back!
author: Yun W.

description: Went here for brunch the other day. Shrimp and grits was amazing; chicken and waffle wasn't as good unfortunately. Will be back to try some of the other brunch items. What's amazing is that it's possible to simply walk in at a reasonable hour on the weekend and have a fairly nice brunch without waiting for 3 hours in line :)
author: Gleb P.

description: The food is too rich for my taste.  Best part is fried chicken which is well seasoned.  Overall, I would give it two stars based on how heavy the food is and not a good value.  Think I spent about 75 bucks on a bucket of fried chicken, appetizer and a few sides.
author: Annie W.

description:
Heard about the Front Porch from a friend and I'm a big fan of soul food, so we decided to give this place a try. 

They really go all out in trying to make you feel like you're in a totally different place. It doesn't even look like a restaurant from the outside. It's sandwiched between 2 residential homes and you wouldn't be able to tell that it's a restaurant if you didn't know about it.

We walked in and it was so dark in there. The staff was pretty laid back and friendly. We sat in one of the booths and it took a while for us to decide what to eat. The way my bf & I work is we usually try to order different stuff, so this way we get to experience more of what the restaurant has to offer. But, this time, we couldn't decide. We both wanted the chicken and waffles. I was so determined to get it and he was too. Nothing else looked appetizing to us. So, we did. 

It took probably 20-25 minutes for our food to come out and when it did...man, did it look super good.  I ate my chicken wings with the ghost hot sauce. I believe it was the hottest one they had and I was kind of disappointed because it wasn't hot enough for me, but I still enjoyed it.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Made reservations with OpenTable (probably didn't need them) and checked out The Front Porch today.  My wife is into fried up southern things so this seemed like a good spot.  We met up with a friend and split a few things.
* Fried Okra - really tasty and done perfectly.  No slime or yuck, just tasty friedness.  The okra came with a nice mayo and also bottles of the house made medium and habanero hot sauce.  I like the habanero, everybody did the medium.
* Complementary corn bread (sticks or lady finger cookies of cornbread?  Some unusual configuration) - These were good with a rich spiced butter.
* 6$ made to order biscuits - two small biscuits.  Not at all sure what the fuss of the price was for.
* Fried chicken - Nom nom nom.  Order fried chicken.  Don't be stupid.
* Something vegetarian - Whatever... did I mention fried chicken?

They had a few beers on tap, a few less common.  My beer was not too tasty, the wife's was much better.  Next week they'll open a full bar here - the permitting is in place.

Overall, we'll be back to sample some of the other greasy treats with some cocktails.
author: Ivan L.

description: For sure my favorite brunch place in the city. Service is fast, the staff is nice, and the food is consistently delicious. They have some awesome drinks too.
author: Melissa H.

description:
5/5 stars on the Wing Scale... (rounded up for impeccable service!)

- Quality of product: 2.5 of 3 stars
- Quality of service: 1 of 1 star
- General feelings of happiness: 1 of 1 star 

On a friend's recommendation, hubby, sis-in-law and I set out for The Front Porch. By the grace of the parking gods, we found a spot close to the restaurant relatively quickly. 

FOOD:
For appetizers, we split the fried okra and gumbo. The okra could have been seasoned a bit more. However, it was well-fried and not slimy like I expected. The gumbo was packed with flavor. I should also add the free corn bread was not too shabby, either!

For our main course, we shared the famous bucket o' chicken. The chicken came in a paper popcorn bucket with some popcorn. Our theory is that the popcorn keeps the chicken crispy and is not actually for consumption. The batter was tasty, and the chicken tender. 

I wasn't such a fan of the mashed potato and collard greens that came with the dish... the texture of the potatoes was a bit unusual (runny?) and the veggies too sour for my taste. However, we all enjoyed the mac-and-cheese and biscuits a lot. 

Hubby also loved their homemade habanero sauce while I preferred their milder cayenne pepper hot sauce. You can also bring that stuff home with you for a small price!

SERVICE: 
To echo most other Yelpers, the service was friendly and attentive. Despite the crowd on a Friday night, our waitress kept our glasses full and answered all our questions about the menu. 

GOOD-TO-KNOW INFO:
- Tab was reasonable (less than $25/person) for the amount of food we ordered.
