- Reservations are a safe bet for anything after 7pm on a Friday night. 

- The surrounding neighborhood is typical Mission/ Bernal Heights... be prepared to meet some colorful characters at night. 

- If you're like me and still crave sweets after a big, fat Southern meal, mosey over to Mitchell's Ice Cream down the street for dessert. :)
author: Wing Y.

description:
Alright sorry to rain on this parade.  I love the idea of this place - but the chicken - ain't that good.  Instead of ripping on it more - I'm going to teach you (yes you) how to make great fried chicken right at home...

What you need:
1) Chicken thighs and legs (dark meat better than white meat)
2) Lawry's seasoned salt
3) All purpose flour 
4) A big thing of canola oil 
5) Pan/Pot with sides that are 3 inches high or more 
6) A ziplock bag or big brown paper bag 
7) Pepper 
8) Natural cooking instinct or a cooking thermometer 
9) Paper towels 

What you should do:
1) Sit the chicken out for an hour (its needs to come to room temp) 
2) Fill pan/pot with 3 inches of oil and put on high heat 
3) Create a mix of 10% Lawry's, 90% flour and taste it (yes - lick your finger - dip it in and taste it) it should taste salty and garlicy - if it doesn't - add more Lawry's.  
4) Add pepper to the mix 
5) Test to see if your is ready by putting a pinch of flour mixture in it - it should immediately fry up 
6) When you are ready to fry (oil is hot, chicken is at room temp, mix is good) add 2-4 pieces of chicken and the mix to a ziplock bag or brown paper bag and give it a good shake - as you remove pieces from the bag - dust off the excess flour and add to the oil (if you are a pro - use your hands - if not - use tongs)
7) Keep an eye on the oil level of the pan - don't add too much chicken!!!
8) Make sure when you add each piece of chicken it bubbles (this confirms the oil is still hot)
9) After frying for the first 10 minutes you can adjust the heat down to medium high 
10) Fry the chicken for about 15 minutes and then check it with the thermometer - you are looking for a temp of 170 degrees - keep in the mind that the legs will cook faster
11) When the chicken is cooked - drain on paper towels for a couple minutes and then you can keep it warm in an oven set at 200 degrees 

Boom - there you have it - epic fried chicken at home. 

Peace!
author: Michael S.

description:
Fried Chicken. Mac and Cheese. Collard Greens with Black Eyed Peas. 

The black eyed peas were a disappointment, as they did not sing or dance as promised by their many albums. They did, however, get it started in here, which was yummers. 

Yes, even better than ma used to make, back where they really know how to make fried chicken...Alaska. Okay, so they suck at fried chicken in Alaska, but they make some mean fried halibut! really...we have a lot of fish up there...

okay, I'm gonna go mumble to myself in a corner now. But before I do, Eet was Goooooood and I is Fuuuuuullllllllllll.

Nuf said.
author: Danielle L.

description:
The Front Porch is just what the doctor ordered on a rainy saturday night. Good food, colorful people, notably helpful staff, a long wait, not a wait at all because I made the block like 5 times looking for a place to park. 

The spicy shrimp and grits were wonderful minus the bacon. I don't think bacon can make a dish taste better. I consider the use of bacon as a cop out but thats just me, but I have never had a better grit. The grits were nice and creamy. I would go back soon to ensure I have that the shrimp again before they change their menu.

The chicken was a little peppery and just right for me. I really enjoyed the bucket  the chicken came in with the few cornels of popcorn. 

The Mash potatoes and greens were pretty good. I say pretty good because I'm not a fan of greens. The mash potatoes though were awesome.  I also enjoyed the hush puppies, they came out hot and crispy with a nice tender inside. Is tender the right word? Well at least it wasn't gooey. 

Oh and have the Rozay Sangria. I'm not saying Rozay because I hear Rick Ross say it so much; it because I now like saying Rozay and forgot how to spell it right. Forgive me 

This is also a cool spot for a 3rd or 4th date because the place is cozy and cute.
author: Karim R.

description:
Two things that rock about this place:

1)  They have really yummy Southern food.
2)  They deliver so I've had the privilege of enjoying their food in bed.

So here is a rundown:

1) The chicken is tasty and moist.  And the chicken sandwich is delicious too!
2) The oyster po'boy is also very good.  (I've had this a few times.)
3)  I'm not a huge fried okra fan but theirs is pretty good with their hot sauce (which coupled with the actual temperature of the okra nearly burned a hole in my throat).
4) The cole slaw is good and it's creamier than most out here.
5) The grits are delicious!  Better than the mac-and-cheese which is a little too rich for my taste.
6) The staff is very friendly.

Downside:  I tend to over-order here because there are so many things that I want so by the end of the meal, I can hardly move.  Thus delivery to my bed is perfect.  It is a good place to go with folks and share.
author: James S.

description:
UPDATE:
The waldorf salad is a great appetizer to start off. I love the mix of celery, apples, walnuts, raisins and some spicy dressing to give the salad some kick.
The yellow cake with chocolate frosting for dessert is ok -- I wish the cake was more moist.

Truly delicious southern comfort food! 
I loved the dungeness crab and sweet white corn grit porridge.
The special of the day was grilled salmon which was also excellent.
Great food at really affordable prices. I'll be back for sure!
author: Helen Y.

description: We came here after seeing a food network show. We ordered spicy shrimp and grits and Dr pepper short ribs just like we saw on  the TV. Both were delicious and definite recommendation to try. The place is small/cozy and has good vibe.
author: Albina G.

description:
I have been here 3 times for brunch and have mixed experiences.

The first time : arrived art 10:30 on a Saturday and no gravy, not a good start, but the biscuit sandwich was solid. The egg was prepared over hard, but had it have been over medium I would have given 4 stars even with the gravy gaff, but 3 stars for this trip....

The second time: Was an awesome brunch.  The chicken rocked (even with soggy waffles) and the BnG was excellent.  This was a 4 star experience.

The third time:  The service was very slow the chicken fried steak was meh and the gravy was not ready for primetime. Probably a two star effort.

I guess over all I had a 3 star average, but with a bit more consistency with food and service it could easily be a 4-5 star contender.
author: G A.

description: GREAT FOOD!! GREAT ATMOSPHERE!! HUGE portions!  Our eyes were bigger than our stomachs, 2 appetizers filled us enough that we had to take home our entrees.  My fiancee spent a year in New Orleans and felt the cuisine lived up to good southern cooking.  The jambalya was delectable, the alligator was spicy and tasty.  The fried chicken, greens and mashed potatoes were as good as homemade.   Definitely taking my parents to brunch there when they visit.  Its a Bernal Heights gem without question!!!
author: Jessica M.

description: Been wanting to go here for a long time, and finally got there last night on a rare night out with our kids for a little dinner date. Great atmosphere - pleasant people and place. Quaint, relaxed, legit down-home vibe... slightly but not too hipsterish. We enjoyed our meal: started with a pair of appetizers - the deviled eggs with bacon bourbon jam ($6.66 - clever, right?) and the fried okra with jalapeño aioli. The deviled eggs were more out of curiosity... and they were cute and tasty but I don't know if I would order them again: they were good, not great. The fried okra was delicious and I would go back for it, but the jalapeño aioli was a miss -- as in missing not only heat but even on flavor... rather bland really. My wife had the Farmer's Vegan and enjoyed it - great presentation. I had the special of the day which was fried catfish with onion rings and cole slaw. Fantastic, really. The catfish was up there with some of the best I've ever had -- really great with their hot sauce -- and the onion rings were a cut above. The cole slaw was absolutely wonderful... nice and light, not too much or too little on the citrus/vinegary-flavored dressing and very very fresh. We are looking forward to heading back for Sunday Brunch to try out their chicken and waffles and bacon bloody's!
author: Brian S.

description: Front Porch is my go-to place for meeting friends in the City.  Everyone I've taken here has loved it.  Delicious hearty comfort food, really excellent brunch, and full bar.  I like to order the special waffle without the fried chicken.  The bacon is always fried perfectly here.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I was stoked to try this place out after reading the reviews. And in my eyes, I think people gave this place too much praise. But my friend that I went with would probably say the opposite so this review will have both good & not so good in it.

-Fried OKRA: very good. (It would be sad if a place messed up fried okra)
-Fried CHICKEN, garlic mashers & gravy, collard greens: I didn't really like it.. I wasn't feeling the breading that they used.. I felt like they over did it and it was a bit overpowering. But my friend took a bite of my meal and he had the opposite reaction and really liked it. But at the least, I could say the mashed potatoes were really good
-CATFISH, sweet potato fries, coleslaw and hushpuppies: The catfish was not bad at all. I probably would prefer it over the chicken.

Portions are a great size and could leave you with some to take home.

Very cute restaurant. Great place to go to with a date or with a group of friends.
author: Krystle A.

description:
ok, I've been here about a dozen times now over the years and it is quite good. I love the atmosphere. It is dark and cozy with low ceilings that make you feel like you're on a date no matter who you're with. The food is excellent, and has a decent range for people who have dietary restrictions (vegans, gluten-free, low-carbers) and all of it is good. I've even had the vegan plate of grilled veggies which was incredibly flavorful -- and I am a hardcore meat-eater. The desserts are great, if you can stuff them down your gullet after eating the main course. I have never tried the fried chicken so I have no idea if it is good or not. The burgers are good, the salads are interesting and tasty, and the red beans and rice is flavorful, particularly with pork. Of course, what is not made better by pork fat? Nothing, that's what.
Oh yeah, drinks are good so sit at the bar if you can't get a table. And it gets crowded fast so make a reservation. The last time I was there it sounded as if they had my iTunes collection on shuffle, so if you also like My Bloody Valentine, the Pixies, early Adam and the Ants, and mid-90s brit pop, this should be your new go-to place for comfort food and a homey vibe.
author: Kely G.

description:
Definitely make a reservation for a weekend visit.
Definitely get the spicy shrimp and grits, either as an app or a main dish - holy, holy!  So good! Can't leave without trying this!
Burger was solid, fried chicken - juicy and not overly greasy and HALLELUJAH.....buttery mashed potatoes and collard greens!

Restaurant was small, clean and casual and the waitstaff was friendly.
I will definitely be back!
author: S K.

description: My second trip to The Front Porch really left me wondering what was so amazing about the first trip.  The chicken was just okay...the mashed potatoes weren't seasoned correctly...and there was no sparkle in the sparkling lemonade.  Perhaps it really depends upon which cook is making your food...but I ordered the EXACT same thing only a few weeks after my first visit and was sorely disappointed.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Maybe it's just because I'm from the midwest, but omg I wanted to try EVERYTHING on the menu when we sat down. Here's what we ordered:

Okra: I was SO excited to find a place that had fried okra... up till now I've been trying to make it at home. Not the same. But their okra was just ok. The breading is mostly the flavor and the sauce that came with was just alright. 

Chicken, mashed potatoes, and collard greens: THIS dish is why I'm giving them four stars. It was AMAZING. And, they use rosie's chicken, major bonus. Like another poster said, I usually do not eat the skin.. but this was amazing. Crispy, flavorful, moist chicken... mmmm. 

Hubby had the fish and rice with andouille sausage. He said it was awful. He won't go past that comment, and has nothing more to say than "do not order". So. 

The biscuits were good, I really liked the jalapeno jelly dip. 

Overall, this place is hipster heaven, we had good service, and I wouldn't say it's really cajun like a lot of other people are saying... I'd say it's just southern. Sure, they serve some spicy things, but it's not really a place I'd run to for jambalaya- but I would come back for more chicken.
author: Mia S.

description: Went there with my wife on a Sunday last week. Food was "ok", the bacon was inconsistent. Some was underdone and some was overdone. The eggs were perfect. Reason for the one star review was that we were seated by the kitchen and the big guy cooking (heavy set fellow) kept touching his hair, sending texts and stuffing his face with food. There was hardly a time when he wasn't chewing! Cell phones have more germs than toilet seats and this guy didn't once wash his hands.
author: Jm C.

description:
"It's finger licken, finger licken good y'all
Finger licken, finger licken good y'all"

The Beastie Boys must have been singing about the fried chicken at the Front Porch because that shit is amazing!! 

I don't know about you, but I loves me some fried chicken... BUCKETS of it.  The only downside I see to fried chicken is that sometimes you encounter chicken skin that is so greasy, rubbery and tissue-like that it snaps off the chicken, lands on your chin and reminds you that you're eating the flesh of a disgusting fowl and have to stop before your feast has even begun (no offense to chicken lovers ... I just happen to think that birds are creepy when they are alive and poopy and glaring at your with their beady eyes). 

Somehow, the Front Porch manages to crisp the skin to such a light yet crunchy consistency that it crackles then melts into your mouth like that was its destiny. Each piece steams seductively from the bucket yet retains its moist succulence after you've snatched it up, torn it to bite-sized pieces and devoured it voraciously like the barbarian that you've always known you were.  

WARNING: don't let the size of the bucket excite you too much.  It's a large popcorn bucket, but it's only half filled with eight to ten pieces of chicken (which is plenty for two to three hungry people or one hungry Jenny).  Guard your chicken from scavengers and eat each piece sparingly lest your daydreams of cold chicken for breakfast to be dashed!!

Apparently, there was other food on the menu at the Front Porch, but everything that I tasted was pretty forgettable and/or overpriced.  The spiced West Indian Chips were an interesting snack to munch on while waiting for the chicken, but everything else (beet salad, Plantain cakes and the side dishes (greens, potato salad, black eyed peas)) were tapas sized, cost too much for the quantity, and really didn't impress me as far as taste goes.

The restaurant is completely adorable.  From the open air front porch to the tin-lined ceiling, the dark wood bar to the eucalyptus scented bathrooms, this place was cute as a button.  It was just loaded to the gills with sweaty, hungry people and swampy as a Missourians armpits during an August heatwave.  

Our group was lucky enough to get a next-day reservation and to be accommodated when we had last minute additions to the reservation, but it was a tight fit for eight of us in the booth area.  My left hamhock was hanging off the bench during the entire meal, and my body teetered on its ass crack until we finished eating and spilled out onto 29th Street.  

MINOR GRIPE:
*  They could stand to hire additional servers and bussers as it appears there were only two or three for the entire restaurant.  They were totally pleasant and hard-working (and I'm sure that they were doing the best that they could), but they deserve more help and the patrons deserve more water and corncob-shaped cornbread ;P
author: Jenny K.

description:
Good Service
Tasty dessert
Fried chicken crust a little over cooked but would order again.

Plan to visit the Front Porch again.
author: alison g.

description:
Chicken and waffles in the morning with fried okra. Oooh. The coffee needs a bit more love and they should add their corn bread to the brunch menu, but I can wait for these improvements. 

So Smitten. I ate all 3 pieces of chicken. 

Good think I walked up to Bernal Hill afterward.
author: Judy L.

description:
I have to give them props for their response to the birthday boy without me even reminding them about it -- it was super sweet!  And, the atmosphere is incredibly charming.  

I brought my Italian friend here to introduce him to southern food.  He is an omnivore, and he really liked it.

My experience, being a pescatarian, was a little different.  Unfortunately, they only had one fish entree - catfish with fried sides.  Last time I was here, I had an amazing grilled fish dish with chanterelle mushrooms.  Alas, it wasn't on the menu this time.  

The options for vegetarians are just as few and unsatisfying as in Alabama.  I loved the fried okra, crab fritters, and his mashed potatoes.  But, I have to say, my vegan plate was almost inedible.  All of the veggies were coated with some sort of oil that had a bad flavor and masked their natural taste.  I might have sent it back on another day, but I didn't want to cause trouble during the b'day boy's night out.

I'm sure it's obvious, this being a southern/creole/soul food place, but I thought I would mention that this place is risky if you don't eat meat and can't stomach every single item you eat being fried or full of oil/butter.  

I would up my stars to four or five if they added even just a couple of things to the menu that are slightly less fried / rich.
author: Grasshopper R.

description:
Apparently I should've ordered the fried chicken. 

Went there with my husband on a weekend night, and was hoping for a taste of home (Georgia). I had the fried pickles & catfish (with hush puppies and cole slaw)... Lots of fried goodness. Husband had pork something-or-other. While the fried pickles were recommendable, both entrees left a lot to be desired. My catfish was over-salted, the cole slaw had red peppers in it (blech!), and the hush puppies were dense as rocks. The pork my husband ordered was bland and boring. Drinks and service were good, but we left disappointed.
author: Lindsey P.

description: My fiance and I went to the front porch the night we got engaged. The atmosphere was wonderful and the food was great! The fried chicken was delicious! They also had an awesome staff. The owner even popped over and thanked us for celebrating such an important night with them. Excellent all around!
author: Nicki H.

description:
I love the concept of this place, very "I'm eating in my friends garage," feel. I've been in the day for brunch & at night for dinner so I will summarize for both & give an overall review.
For brunch I joined friends and had the Flounder which was ok, not spectacular, not the worst...just ok. The mimosas were the highlight that day, oh and the fries w/ the aioli sauce on the side, off of my friends plate. Those were nice & crispy w/ the right amount of salt! Service that time was great and food ok.
Now fast forward to date night w/ my honey. Granted we arrived at night & were informed the kitchen was closing in 15 minutes, but being that it's also a bar, we figured no biggie, I think that's where WE were mistaken. 
We were rushed to order, but we were hungry so in this case it was ok. My boyfriend ordered a burger medium well w/ a side of fries. I ordered the warm spinach salad asked for no bacon & requested shrimp instead. 
When the order came, my sweetie's burger was well done, not to his medium well request and my salad had the shrimp I requested AND the bacon that I asked not be in there! Needless to say we were disappointed. It was late etc., etc., but we also wanted our meals as ordered....again the drinks saved the day! My boyfriend had his Prohibition Ale and I had my Sauvignon Blanc & we moved on in the world after our overpriced incorrectly served meals...
author: Jasmine A.

description:
When I got there, the group had already ordered a bunch of stuff to share.  I was expecting a big family style meal to appear.  Instead they brought out each thing as it was ready, as if it were a small plates meal, instead of family style.   The sides come out one at a time - we all attacked and there was never enough.  The problem is that the sides are not sized to share.  

Finally the fried chicken came out, the sides were gone and it didn't feel like a meal.  Tasty food, sort of crappy service - they seemed annoyed when we kept asking for more food or asked to clear away empty plates. I don't mean to slam this place but my advice is that either its better for pick up or ask the kitchen to bring out everything at once.
author: Erin K.

description: Great southern food minus the grease and heaviness. The people are super chill and match the vibe of this hidden gem. Plenty of parking (try the Safeway lot) and away from the now-trendy part of the Mission district. So far, only real foodies know about this special space. Dinnertime is great for a date and I'm looking forward to trying their brunch and actually sitting on the porch! Good times.
author: E D.

description: Fried chicken, Porch chop, Short rib, Gator and fried okra is what our table ordered and all but the short rib what amazing and flavorful! Must go back for more!!
author: Punkster S.

description: The fried chicken is seriously awesome. It's all about the batter. Get the bucket, save mula and take some home. It's also a nice cozy atmosphere. Very relaxed. -1 star for overpriced cocktails that are undersized and for blowing our reservation time by over 30 minutes.
author: S B.

description:
4.5 stars

For all the great places to eat in the city that I say I'll come back to, I actually mean it for the Front Porch.  LOVED everything about the food, decor and service.

- Bendy straws for wine in a juice box (don't knock it till you try it)
- biodynamic cider 
- salt cod and sweet pepper fritters snack - (next time you get your own plate)
- Ahi tuna starter 

Though they had me at *drool* with the cornbread with spicy butter.

E. had some vegan soup and I had the ribeye steak.  I would have complained that my meat wasn't cooked medium rare (it looked well done) if it weren't for the fact that it was still super tender.
author: Kathleen W.

description: Loved it!  I went because I heard such great things about the fried chicken.  We were early on a Sunday, first guests in the place, and we started with chicory coffee and beignets and went on to fried chicken with waffles.  Yeah, maybe more expensive than NOLA but I was in the City.  What the heck.  Fantastic food, moderate service.  I'll go back again!
author: Dave P.

description:
super eclectic and homely! this was a great little spot and appropriately named.

we came for breakfast and i got my go-to: chicken & waffles. i remember there was once a time i thought the combination was too unique for me, but i have come to love this brunch staple. the waffles were made with sweet potatoes, which were slightly denser than the usual waffle, but still fluffy enough. the added sweetness was mild, but delicious. the chicken was fried and seasoned well and it was juicy. i kind of wish they had the crystal hot sauce (i put that sh*t on everything)!

all in all, this place is a great mission addition. i'd probably come back.
author: Marjie T.

description:
I know my review won't make a difference, but the food is bomb. 

Went here on Mardi Gras for the Shrimp Boil... It was out of this world! As was the fried chicken... the biscuits... King's cake.... and the cornbread. 

DELICIOUS! I'm so glad you exist, Front Porch!
author: Alisa G.

description:
I've been on a fried chicken binge and heard this place was good.

The chicken lacked seasoning, it was bland.
author: David L.

description: Grabbed some fried chicken the other day and it was a mixed bag. The skin was extra crispy and the meat was juicy. But it lacked a lot of real chicken flavor.
author: Lando H.

description:
There are very few foods that can warm my soul.

The first is bacon. It really brings out the best in me. The second is any food item from The Front Porch in SF. I came here with my brother and cousins my cousin's birthday. Needless to say, it was a good choice.

I personally ordered the Oxtail stew. And I must say, it was a VERY generous portion. In fact, I remember not breathing very well when I was done with the meal (because I was very full, not because of the quality). The meat itself was very tender, the stew had the perfect texture, and the vegetables were very good.

As for the fried chicken...it is divine. It's as if a higher power fried chicken for themselves in the heavens...and accidentally dropped it down to Earth. Order it and see for yourself.

The staff they have here is awesome, too. Every single person from their staff that passed by was helpful, and each one of them had a smile. What more could you really ask for from a restaurant staff (other than complimentary items)?

If you're ever in the area, please do yourself a favor and go here. And when you're done, pat yourself on the back.
author: Daniel M.

description:
Front Porch, I used to love you.

But the last few times I've been the food has been uninspired. The decor is still comfy, the fried chicken delicious. Other items on the menu just don't hold up.

I'm hoping that the kitchen will get back on track and the formerly fantastic food will make a comeback.
author: Mason C.

description:
I was dissapointed. Well the place is cute, staff was nice, free cornbread was yummy, then the dishes came flying out, here we go..
Fried Okra- I think it was a cornmeal batter, it was not good.
Fried Pickles- These were popular at the table for all the pickle lovers. I think it was a beer batter, it was good, wished the okra was fried in the same batter.
Shrimp and Grits- Not good at all, the dish came out luke warm, half way done it was cold and lumpy. 
Shrimp Poor boy- the bread was burnt and soggy. It was just grilled shrimp with some lettuce and mayo on top of this bread, Not good.
Fried Green Tomatoes- One of the best things I had, real good sauce for it!
Bucket of Fried Chicken- Thigh was delicious and juicy, white meat was just ok. The batter was flavorful and it wasn't soaked in grease. It was good but it was not Farmer Brown Chicken.
Mac and Cheese- It was very cheesy, it was good but I wish they added a kick of something.
Collard Green- too much Vinegar for my taste, but my friends liked it.
Beignets with Chocolate sauce- (This was kindly given to us for the cold shrimp and grits issue) i was bummed, they were not light and fluffy like the beignets in new orleans. These tasted exactly like Chinese sweet donuts, you Chinese folks know what I'm talking about! 

I think if I was around and my friends really wanted to go then I wouldn't mind going back for chicken and fried green tomatoes.
author: Karen T.

description:
I came here with my hub a few weeks ago. Ever since they opened I have always wanted to try it, and whenever I go to Mitchell's I always think, I really need to go. We were craving fried chicken and while hard knox was on the top of the list, I like to try new places, plus we were able to get a reso through open table and they have a liquor license now!!
So we went, and the place really has some character and cute. Super loud yet cozy.

The food was ok, we had the autumn salad, cornbread and fried chicken, and the mussels.  And dessert of course!

Salad= yum
Mussels = I felt the portion was small for the price point 
cornbread= they could have been fluffier for me, but the jalapeño jelly or butter sauce was on hit!
Chicken= it was ok, it had a nice crisp and was moist but it need a little more flavor, there was a slight bitterness that really stood out.

Dessert was on point! We had the pumpkin creme brûlée and it was so good. It made me realize that I may like pumpkin! It was served with a brittle, really good!

Actually, all the desserts looked really good.
I may go back, maybe for brunch or just  dessert, to be determined at a later date...
author: Debbie M.

description:
MMMMMMMMMMMMMM Chicken!!!!!!  The fried chicken is scrumptious, delightful, yummy goodness on a plate.  Its battered with cornbread and fried to perfection.  The mashed potatoes were paired wonderfully and the beans were enjoyable.  I tear up thinking about their chicken.

Now the pork ribs, wow.  When I asked about them and the waiter started to describe the dish we seriously started salivating, MOUTH-WATERING.  And boy did they live up to their reputation.  A small warning, its 50% fat, so if you don't like pork fat order the rack instead.

We wanted to order dessert but it wasn't happening, we were way too full, plus a party of 7, I mean 8, I mean 9 tried to squeeze into a table of 4.  Thankfully they were downgraded to 6, I couldn't understand how a large man was going to try and eat when he didn't have any table space in front of him.  I guess he's that hard-core about Front Porch, willing to eat with a plate on his lap.  

Its rightfully named, they have a cute little, you guessed it, front porch, that you can hang out in while waiting for your table, and yes you will wait, and wait, or you can order a drink, bring it out and rock your little heart out, literally.  Ok its a city front porch, no wood but its got the chairs and the front porch vibe.  If I could I would go sit there at least once a week and relax with a plate of chicken.

The only reason I give it 4 stars is the disappointment I felt when i bit into a piece of cornbread, stick, lady finger, madeleine cookie like object.  It was boring, lackluster its missing something and they need to figure that out to get my 5th star.
author: Kristin Marie S.

description: the first time i went to the front porch i went with my girlfriend and we ordered the spicy shrimp n gritz and the fried chicken. They were both amazing. chicken came out crunchy on the outside and juicy on the inside and went well with all 3 of there homemade sauces they had at the time(harbanero was my favorite). I happend to leave my phone at the restaurant but when i called they assured me they had it and would hold on to it until i was able to come in again. when i went in about 3 days later Josie assisted me and was friendly caring and passionate. Thank you for helping me Joise. the food and service was great.
author: Enrique D.

description:
Low ceilings - don't bring a tall person here to eat.
Very dark - from the outside, thought it was closed. From the inside, it was hard to see anything.  Could've had a fly in my food without me seeing it (slight exaggeration).
[Funny how someone mentioned it looked like a tomb, very accurate description]
Decor was a random assortment of things, did not feel like it had a central theme.

Service was quick and friendly.
Chicken needed seasoning; it was the most tasteless chicken I've ever had. But the mashed potatoes were alright. Fried okra was alright as well.  Jambalaya was decent, nothing special.

Overall, would not recommend this place or try it again.  Food was average, but for the price and the tomb-like atmosphere, I'd rather go someplace else.
author: B M.

description:
SOUTHERN COMFORT!
Cool people, great wine, delicious food, awesome atmos. What else could you ask for?!
author: Lisa C.

description: It was good. Not great. It seemed to me like the food was trying too hard -  I had the fried chicken and waffles, but instead of doing a simple thing really well, they tried to add twists and it ended up mediocre. The waffles had jalepenos and spices mixed in the batter and the fried chicken was overly spiced. The beignets were decent though, and my husband country style steak was pretty good.  I will say one thing, the shandy here is excellent!
author: Amber W.

description: Overrated and pricy unfortunately. Was really looking forward to checking it out on Father's Day. Chicken crust too thick and not crispy just hard. Collard greens overdone and limp. Flounder overdone as well. Étouffée was good but that's about it. Not an outstanding example of Southern cooking by any stretch. Will not return, especially not worth a drive into the city solely for.
author: Cooper C.

description:
I've gone here a couple of time, and each time was always a great experience. The hubby and I are very pickers, and know when there are too many choices to choose from, default to the front porch. 

Not only is their food delicious, but the service is very knowledgeable of the additional local products that are featured in the menu, so when you want to know where to get that beer, veggies, or even the meat on your plate, they're ready with answers.

I only have one suggestion. BRING BACK THE PICKLES!!!!!!!
author: Roma G.

description: Good southern restaurant and since my dinning companion is from the south and he loves their mash potatoes and fried chicken. I love the fried okra. The place is a little small and dark. Great service! The price is reasonable though not cheap. We would return.
author: Tracy L.

description:
We had a party of 2.

3 piece chicken is $17
9 piece chicken is $34

We really only wanted 4 pieces because of all the hype about their fried chicken, but that option wasn't available so we ordered the 9 piece and sweet potato fries with it.

I thought the chicken was really tasty and juicy...it was really crispy and had a hint of garlic in the batter. I typically don't eat chicken breast b/c it's always dry but this was moist.  I have to say the chicken was good, but I have to admit not $34 good. I could've easily gotten a bucket of Popeye's and enjoyed it just as much for a much lesser price. I wouldn't have minded to pay $12 for 3 pieces though...

The service was excellent. They were attentive and very nice.
The decor was really dark southern like. It wasn't a bad experience, I just wouldn't go back there just for their fried chicken.
author: aaron t.

description:
I wanted to love this place, looked forward to it for so long then was sorely disappointed.

Here's a quick run down:
Server was very nice/friendly
Iced tea was good. 
But....
Corn bread was bland.
Burnt crab corn fritters.
Gumbo needed lots of salt.
Chicken tasted like it was fried in burnt oil.
Potatoes were watery.
Corn was cold when it came to the table.
Dinner for two $70+-ouch.

Honestly???
author: Jennifer G.

description:
It might have been the day i went but the food was not good. I will stick to brenda's from now on.
chef was having a bad day or something
author: Nicoline B.

description:
CHICKEN AND WAFFLES.
+
RED WINE SANGRIA THAT TASTES LIKE POM JUICE.
+
CHRISTMAS LIGHTS.
=
A perfect evening at Front Porch with good company, hearty food, and a warm ambiance.
author: Lauren S.

description:
The food was delicous here! You'll definitely need a reservation

I'm a big fan of the fried okra (best I've had ever), and the fried catfish and the mac and cheese!! I love that the mac and cheese is cooked in a mini cast iron skillet and it comes out to you fresh out the oven.  My friend ordered the gumbo, which was fantastic. Pretty much everything that was ordered at our table was very tasty.

This restuarant is a little quirkier than I'm used to be the taste of the food was able to override all my initial doubts.

Bryn-our waitress was great and I would definitely want her to wait on us again. 

The downside-it's a restuarant that sells southern food but halfway into our meal, we have this "live entertainment" which consisted of a mariachi guitar player, which was very conflicting to the type of food that was served. And after his performance he went around and collected money in a paper bag, I didn't like this at all, he totally interrupted our meal and I found a crumbled up dollar bill for the guy, only because I felt bad he had to make his money that way. So this is the reason I only gave 4 stars instead of 5.  If I wanted entertainment I'd go to a concert, not to a restuarant. Okay, that's all...
author: Brandi W.

description: Nice place; pork chop is for real.
author: Matt L.

description: First time in Tallahasee , first time in Front Porch. Me and my wife didn't have idea where to have dinner but when we saw the front porch we decided to stop A kind receptionist accompanied us to a table in the front porch Very professional and friendly service, fantastic food and atmosphere Good price.
author: Donald W.

description:
I think there is a lack of creole/southern food, so this is a great deviant from the norm. I've only been here for dinner, but am definitely a fan. 

I lean towards their fried chicken often, when I feel like being unhealthy. The bucket is a great buy if you have a couple friends who are also looking for some fried chicken with fixins. 

Otherwise, i've had some of their other dishes and they are quite delicious! (But you do end up feeling like a fatty) After reading some reviews, I really want to try this place for lunch/brunch.

Overall, I think this is one of the gems of the city :)
author: Angela H.

description: If you're looking for San Francisco style southern food, then you've found your spot but if you are interested in a real southern meal think again.  The food is okay but over-priced.  As for service, the waiters/waitresses are not very attentive, and usually have an attitude.
author: Emily P.

description:
Hands down the best fried chicken in the city---never oily, deliciously crispy, and even better, often served in a popcorn bucket with said popcorn. The ambiance is the consummate, mom-and-pop-meets-decadent-hole-in-the-wall that makes SF restaurants great. 

But it doesn't end with the chicken. The free lady fingers-like cornbread, light and fluffy biscuits and Mac and cheese are unsung, yet essential contributors to this soulful menu.

Bonus points---it's a mere block away from Mitchell's ice cream!
author: Brian D.

description: The fried okra is the star dish here!  Wow!  Reminds me of my southern roots.  My group greatly enjoyed the fried chicken, while I opted for the mac and cheese.  If you are deciding between the mac and cheese and another side, I'd go with the "other" side as the mac and cheese just didn't have a 5 star taste.  To be honest, I could only take 4 little bites as it was too rich for my tastes. Luckily, I filled up on sweet tea and cornbread so was all set, despite my disappointment in the mac and cheese.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Fried chicken + beer out of a cask = heaven

Have been here many a time and never been let down. OK, there was that one time I ordered the cheeseburger and they left the plastic wrapper on the cheese, but they made up for it by replacing it and giving me a free drink. The service here has always been top notch and the food is always great.

Great soul food and a cool bohemian atmosphere. Great place to go out on a date. Be sure and check out the 3300 club down the street for some drinks afterward.
author: Mathew S.

description:
So this was my second visit. I came with 3 friends on a sunday night for dinner. 

For starters, we had the fried okra and mussels. The fried okra was absolutely yummy! Loved it. The batter wasn't super thick and the flavor was just delicious. The mussels were good. Nice size and the broth had great flavor. 

Entree's.....well the two guys shared a bucket of chicken. We also had the shrimp & grits and the pork chop.

For some reason, not long after 6'ish, they dimmed the lights. The mood was already set when we walked in, but I guess it wasn't "moody" enough. I found the darkness to be a major problem in eating my nice thick pork chop. Ugh. It was so dark I couldn't tell the fat from the meat. I don't mind eating a bit of fat with my chop, but MAN...it was so gross to think I had cut a decent yummy chunk of chop and find out it's nothing but fat once I start chewing. It was the most frustrating chop I've ever eaten. Too bad because the chop was cooked well -- meaning not dry. 

The sides that came with the chop were weird. One was a weird potato/apple cake thingy. And the greens....they only tasted like butter. 

My friend said the shrimp and grits were worcestershire-y. 

The hi-light of the meal was definitely the chicken. Not the best I've had, but it was pretty good. Nice and crispy and juicy. 

The service was good. Waitress was helpful in offering suggestions for wine and beer. Not sure if I'll be back though.....
author: Malisha J.

description: Very cute small restaurant with a bar inside. We had the Mac n cheese, bucket of 9 fried chicken, shrimp something dish and the fried okra. Everything was really tasty.
author: Wendy H.

description: The folks here were super helpful with our reservation for 15 folks (1/2 of them kids) even though the place is small, we were able to work out something for our group.  The food was very good, we all liked everything we tried and a few of us had things we had never had before.  If you are coming here, bring your appetite, especially if you're getting the chicken & waffles as it's a lot of food but sooooooo yummy!  Chicken was perfectly crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside.  I could eat it again and again and again!  The only downfall is parking on a weekend is very scarce but worth it!
author: Candy R.

description: Love, Love, love this place. The 5th star is missing because of the lack of service the last few times I've visited but I have to tell you that the food is great every time I've been.  if you love Farmer Brown and good 'ole fashioned Southern style cookin' then this is the place to be.  You can sit outside on the "front porch" in rocking chairs while enjoying your cocktail and bucket o' chicken or you can eat inside with the rest of the family and scarf down the rest of your meal.  The fried okra and Gumbo are also my favorites but I don't think you can go wrong with anything on this menu.
author: Kevin J.

description:
I've been here a few times, originally with my aunt & uncle. I also came with Stephannie N. on Mardi Gras. Considering the new orleans style cuisine & atmosphere it was the perfect location for the occasion.
Sadly, I haven't tried the fried chicken. I just don't like fried chicken and no amount of grease can change that. I always order the shrimp and grits. I've tried the blackened catfish but I won't stray from my grits. The fried okra is pretty dang good too. They have a great beer list with seasonal and sometimes hard to find microbrews on it.
author: Sara P.

description: The food was good. The atmosphere was really lively and fun. It's a great place to hang out with friends and have brunch. It's priced right with interesting and basic food options. I will go back.
author: Jill T.

description:
We wanted some southern comfort so we came here for our date on a Friday night.  Parking is not easy to find on a Friday night and neither is a table easy to come by at Front Porch but we finally found a great parking spot after circling for more than half an hour and with a total wait time of about an hour for our table.

We ordered some sweet teas, fried chicken, shrimp and grits, crab cakes, and mac and cheese.  Surprisingly the food came out really quickly. We were seated next to the open kitchen so we could see all the action that was going on. The food was good and we were probably really hungry by then so everything tasted good.  We finished off our meal with the bread pudding (delicious) and were stuffed we couldn't even get ice cream at Mitchell's across the street.

The service is really good. Our waitress checked up on us a few times and they cleared our table relatively quickly.  You can tell this is the kind of restaurant that has lots of regulars as they treat their customers well.
author: Betty C.

description:
Not bad.  Not great.

They do have a charming little "front porch" where you can dine or enjoy pre-dinner cocktails, while sitting in a rocking chair.  What would make this front porch area even better is if they had heat lamps!  We had to wait here for about an hour last night in the cold.  

The food is nothing too special.  We ordered the mac n cheese, brussel sprouts, rice and beans, and fried okra.  I consider myself a bit of a mac n cheese connoisseur and was very excited to try this one, based on pictures and reviews.  It was very bland!!  We agreed that we've had much better.  Everything else was just okay.  The dipping sauce for the fried okra was not very flavorful.  I'd say the brussel sprouts were the best dish out of them all.
author: Suzie M.

description:
Went for brunch with some sidekicks, and left still looking for a real good cajun vibe in this city (SF, maybe we should just quit on a few things: pizza [little star is your only gem], laksa, and shrimp etouffe?).  All in all we'd def go back because the vibe is funky, but food was either reallly good or reallly off.  

The goods: I got the crab benedict, but it came with NO sides!...come on throw some taters on that plate!  It was really tasty with a flavorful sauce, but kinda pricey and still hungry after that one.  The sweet potato waffles were simply amazing.  We also got the chicken friend steak and that was a hit.  

The bads: the grits were absolute crap.  The beingets were ok, but a bit on the dry and thick/heavy side.  

Will give it a shot for dinner cuz I love po'boys.  Fingers crossed.
author: A A.

description:
Came here with a good friend of mine on a (somewhat) late night and didn't have to wait to get seated.

We started with the deviled eggs, I got the shrimp and grits and my friend got the burger.

Deviled Eggs: Nice and creamy and the jalapeno added a nice crunch but there wasn't any serious heat (which is good). The bacon didn't seem to add anything to the eggs but it did give it a bit of a chew so maybe that's a good thing?

Shrimp and Grits: The grits were very creamy, almost like a mash potato type of creamy. The shrimp were huge but I'm one of those people who really don't see the point in having the tails on shrimps and these came with them, it just made it a bit harder to eat; they were cooked perfectly though and they were big enough that I could overlook the tails =). The one issue I had with this dish was the sausage; they tasted way overcooked, they were hard and felt dry. The sausage added the heat to the dish which I could have done without but some may like it. All in all, I felt like this dish would have been perfect if it wasn't for the sausage.

Burger: My friend's burger came with the standard accompaniments of veggies and it came with fries. I stole a couple of fries from my friend and they were done well, they were well seasoned so they didn't taste plain.

Our waitress was attentive and the place had nice taste in music. I definitely see myself coming back at one point or another. I know a lot of people say to get the fried chicken but I really dislike having to use my hands to eat, particularly greasy things. So if you're anything like me, the shrimp and grits is a pretty good choice.
author: Richard C.

description:
Wow!  They have fried stuff!  

Having grown up in the south, I love me some fried okra - and there it is on the menu!  This restaurant serves up all kinds of old favorites.  I have to say that I was really drawn in by all the sides: green bean casserole, hush puppies, mac and cheese, corn on the cob...these are things that you don't find on menus 'round here much.

The menu has a nice well-rounded selection of entrees to choose from as well.  There is even a featured vegan entree on the menu (which I love, southern and vegetarian - strange sounding, I know).

The wine list is not extensive but it has a really well-put-together mix of wines to choose from.  They also serve up beer.

The service was friendly and responsive.  The ambience was eclectic and there was a steady drone of rock-n-roll/alternative playing on the music system in the background.  

The front porch has rocking chairs on it.  I wish it had been warmer so I could sit out there and "rock" for a while.

Nonetheless, I have to say that I had a great meal here and I think people that like their food fried up real nice should check it out.
author: Dennis H.

description:
Not a huge fan of fried chicken but oh my god were the shrimp po boys and fried green tomatoes yummy. 

downside: looong wait if you don't have a reservation.
author: Cecilia D.

description:
I heard a lot about this place, so when I saw a deal on groupon I snatched one up. I made an opentable reservation, because Me and a companion were heading to Cobb's for a show and wanted to stop off to The Front Porch for a bite to eat. 


We arrived early and talked to the hostess, who said we could start at the bar and be moved to our table. This was thoughtful, since even though the place wasn't that busy, we were told that the house was booked. Other guests arrived without reservations wanting to be seated. This is where our BAD experience at TFP began. 

The Front of the House: 

Other non-reservation guests were seated in the back of the house, where there was more room and less cramped, while we sat at the bar and eventually were moved into small quarters. We confronted the hostess asking why we weren't seated before the guest without reservations. We were told that the guest said they were not going to stay long and would eat and leave (we beat them to the door). She was apologetic, that she had not offered us the same service first, but it still did not excuse the fact that others were seated before us. If I didn't have a groupon I would have just walked out.  

I really wanted to like this place, but the start was not promising. We tried our best to get past it and ordered the Sweet potato fries with aioli , Three (3) piece fried chicken with mash potatoes and gravy, collard greens with bacon and baked mac and cheese. Ginger beer and sweet tea cooled our heated tempers but, the food was far from pleasing. 

The Meal:
Complimentary corn bread was much appreciated. The sweet potato fries and chicken were burnt and it tasted like the grease needed to be changed. The mac & cheese was just okay along with the potatoes & gravy. The collard greens missed the mark, where vinegar was soaked into them. 

Overall: 
The hostess committed a major mistake in customer service. The food lacks that soul food taste advertised. The service was good from the waitress. Later on that night the food made both me and my dinner companion sick, we luckily made it in and out of the comedy event we attended. I will not be returning here or would recommend eating here.
author: Dennis S.

description:
This place is a really good find....


Their cornbread was cute and tasty, but I think I'm still in favor of the cornbread at Hard Knox.
But...
they had good ass fried chicken. I could totally taste some garlicky flavors infused in the crispy fried skin! (and the meat was juicy as hell too)
Mashed potates and collard greens are always a comfort.
Spicy shrimp were a perfect combo with the grits for people like my friend who's sensitive to spicy food (really not that spicy, but she's a wuss. haha).
The mac-n-cheese coulda been a little bit more cheesier because it was a little dry.
The muffins were warm, fresh, and oooooooo so buttery! (and the name is awesome- "biscuit for boobies" because the profits go to the breast cancer awareness!)
I think the grilled corn on the cob was the hit of the night. All of us loved it with the chili butter!
Their draft beers were winners.-easy to drink, hence the merry buzz.
author: Emy s.

description:
I would give this place a four stars for their entree...but after all was eaten and done I decided a three is enough.

Came here with my bf on a Friday night. Wasn't too bad for me when I tried to look for parking in that area and it was about 8:30pm. 

My bf was already there, and the wait for him was about 30 minutes, but they probably would have sat us down earlier if I was also there with him.

Service was good, very friendly waiters. 

Dinner comes with complimentary corn bread: they were yummy with the sauce that they provided with it. =)

We ordered:

Gumbo with andouille sausage and okra with seafood...$17---1 star, 
So I've tried gumbo in Texas once, and didn't like it, but I thought I'd give it another try. My first impression with my first bite was "uh, yea still not a fan of gumbo." But after a few more spoons of it, the taste kind of grew on me. But once I moved on to the hush puppies and came back to the gumbo, it had the same effect of leaving a weird taste in my mouth. The gumbo was especially thick and creamy, had a good texture but the taste just wasn't there for me.

Jalapeno hush puppies with remoulade...$5---3 stars, Good starter, I liked it. The remoulade was very creamy and tasty. The hush puppies were yummy. 

Fried chicken: 3 piece single garlic mashers and gravy with collard greens...$17---4 stars (except for the collard greens) The mash potatoes were awesome. The fried chicken was flavored perfectly and had a good crispiness to it. The meat, both the breast and the thigh was so tender and juicy! I was amazed at how juicy the meat was! Of course way better than KFC, but $17 bucks for chicken? A little pricey.

Braised short ribs with garlic mashers and baby carrots...$19---5 stars, This had to be my favorite dish of the night. The braised short ribs was also very tender and had the right amount of sauce. Finger lickin' good. Mashers were good we killed it all on both plates. Carrots were also good, very sweet and was lightly seasoned and looked like they were roasted.

Also ordered a glass of wine...total came out to be ~$75-80.

Great atmosphere, but the place is small. Do not recommend coming with more than 5 or so people. But I do believe they take reservations.  They have a bar. Noise level is high, I was sitting across from my bf and by the end of the night I felt like I have been screaming on top of my lungs.

I give three stars because I felt like for the experience and type of food it was a bit pricey. Plus the gumbo was disappointing. =/
author: Amy L.

description: For the $ you spend there, I would rather go to Hard Knox on 3rd ST. A little too hipster for me.  But the fried chicken was good.  Didn't haven any cocktails, which I guess they are famous for.
author: Susie M.

description: Good. But not great. Blue Plate, around the corner, or Foreign Cinema on Mission have much better fried chicken
author: Daniel Z.

description:
Delicious. Sustainable. Fried. Goodness.

Go with a group of friends, order the bucket of fried chicken (which comes with Collard Greens & Mashed Taters) an extra side of mac & cheese, fries and of course the biscuits for boobies (order a pair and donations go to fight Breast Cancer) and get ready for a night straight from the south!!

Seriously Colonel Sanders has nothing on the Fried Chicken at The Front Porch - Crispy, not overly breaded on the outside. Moist & Flavorful within. OH and the hot sauces!! From mild, medium to caliente, they all go great with everything here.
author: Rana A.

description:
Quaint, old-time decor with dark lighting.  Front porch design outside with lap blankets and heaters.  
Beignets were a little too bread-like and not puffy enough, but delicious.
Jambalaya Risotto Balls - Damn good!  Chunks of crawfish and sausage with risotto in a lightly crispy ball.  Hell yeah!
Gumbo - great flavors, true to the original, but could have been a little more substantial in quantity.
Jalapeno + Bacon Deviled Eggs - Spicy! And delicious!
Bucket o' Chicken - Juicy fried chicken.  Plain and simple.
Country Captain - Fail.  This dish was out of place and had more of a Mediterranean flavor to it.  More tomato, less spice.  Not a fan.
Pumpkin Bread Pudding - good, needs more texture.
author: Monica S.

description: OMDOG GOOD!!! I had a bucket of fried chicken and a bucket of shrimp (with Andouille sausage, corn on the cob and taters) to share with my Mardi Gras krewe! $60 well spent!!!!! BRAVO!
author: Jim S.

description:
I was there during beer week. They had a prix fixe menu. It was pretty interesting. I like the place. It is a little too loud in there though... 

Food was good. The company I had was even better. 
I would come back.
author: cyril l.

description:
We just came home from The Front Porch for the first time - Josie was our server.  
I would like to say, that the longer you spend outside The Front Porch, the more obtuse your life becomes.  This spot was outstanding.  I had fried chicken and I would have punched an old lady in the neck for a second serving.  We had a bottle of Malbec and Josie picked a Key Lime Pie for us at random to finish.. and the crust on that thing was as good as about 12 months of masturbation in a 4 minute sitting.
EL - gave this place 2 starts - and thats why you haven't returned her calls.

Way to go Front Porch.
Please kick out our neighbors and put Front Porch II in the spot next door.

werd.
author: David L.

description: Front Porch is an excellent place for comfort food. The date with goat cheese and bacon is sooooo good! MUST TRY! Parking around the neighborhood is hard.. but ALL WORTH IT!!!! :)
author: Doro C.

description: The night I went to The Front Porch, we had a happy hour at work, but I avoided all snacks because I was aiming for the infamous fried chicken! I wanted to make sure I did not miss out. We were a group of 11 and the space it tight. It is also very dim in there and lively (aka loud). The food looked and tasted great! Since we were a group of 11, I was able to see a variety of plates. The deep fried okra and pickles were great.  Portion was enough for the table. The fried chicken plate comes with 4 pieces and two sides. Standard is mashers and collard greens. I replaced mashed potatoes with red beans and rice for a minimal upgrade in price. The wait staff helps each other out, so no issues there. Pricing is decent, but not affordable if you are on a tight budget. Parking can be challenging, I was able to find a spot two blocks away. It is also very close to Mitchell's Ice Cream for an after dinner dessert. Only complaint, the cornbread was not the best I ever had. But the chicken, amazing! If you love biting into a drumstick and have juices dribble down your chin, it is the perfect order.
author: Neville B.

description: The food was great, the atmosphere was nice too! We left in a food coma- fried chicken, short ribs and shrimp and grits are all hella good! The dessert was hella good!
author: Danyelly F.

description:
FREAKIN LOVE THE FRONT PORCH

Best damn fried pickles around :)

The Shrimp & Grits is my absolute favorite. Fried Chicken is off the hook amazing...

Great beer selection....great service...love this place!
author: Angela G.

description: Seriously? 4 pieces of friend chicken for $18? And you have to eat in someone else garage. Not to mention how small, dark, smelly and cramped this "garage" restaurant. A friend told me about this place, I gave it a try and promise myself I'll never return. This place is such a ripoff.
author: May M.

description:
Alright, so I went back.  I know I swore I wouldn't go, but it was an friend's event and I couldn't boycott any longer.
And, I'm glad I actually got a chance to eat here.  The chicken fried steak was excellent.  It was exactly what I wanted.  The fried chicken was good, but just good.  Also, they tell you a bucket only serves 2-3 people, don't listen--it's a huge amount of food!  We also had the fried okra, which rocked and the shrimp and grits, which were good.
Service was hit or miss and we were all scrunched into a tiny seating area, despite it being a very large party.
I'm still convinced there are better options to check out...
author: Jessica L.

description:
Decided to check out The Front Porch after work on a busy friday night.  I approached the hostess area and was greeted by Josie who informed me there would be an hour in a helf wait for two people.  I put my name down and asked her about the bar area since I was famish, wanted to sit and rub elbows with locals.  Not even five minutes has past, and she informed me that a bar seats would be available.  I thanked her and was then greeted by a nice looking bartender name Matt who recommended what mixed drink to order and I am glad I did.

When it came down to ordering I decided on the fried chicken and I was glad I did.  The chicken pieces were moist, juicy and crispy.  Mi amigo decided on the fried catfish and he didn't leave not even a crumb on the plate.  

I am wanting to come on the weekend to try their other menu items since everything looks appealing.
author: Isis L.

description:
Finally, good, great yummie fried chicken... this was more nuevo style southern food. grits. collareds and white beans. Great corn bread. We arrived too early and went to 3300 to wait and so glad to be the first seated that night because by the time we finished they could have used the front porch to seat people.
the food is good and the fried chicken is awesome. a bucket will set you back $30 but if that is what you want, it is worth it.
author: Lawrence T.

description:
I've always wanted a front porch. Except that on my front porch, I've dragged an old comfy couch onto it and I sit there with my beer and heckle the people walking by. 

I guess it's a good thing this isn't my front porch. This Front Porch has excellent service, delicious food, and interesting decor. Good southern food is somewhat hard to find in SF, so I'm glad I'd stumbled into this place a few times. The servers have always been wonderful. There's also a chandelier constructed out of old silverware. 

The food is rich as so much of the southern food is. The collared greens are cooked with the bits of ham (bacon?) and served in a mound of deep green leafy tenderness. The fried chicken is some of the best I've had in the city. I thought it was better than Hard Knox, Farmer Brown's, Little Skillet, and KFC. Nice and crispy skin outside, tender, flavorful and juicy inside. The shrimp with spicy grits was ok, as was the jambalaya. The red beans and rice with andouille sausage was a shade too smokey for my tastes. The crab flavor really shone through on the crab fritters. Their in-house hot sauces are WHOOOO!!!! 

They feature a full bar with plenty of interesting beer options, including a Speakeasy cask Prohibition Ale, recently. 

Still have things on the menu to try, so see you next time.
author: Saunders C.

description:
My friend had spent a night out in SF and were looking for a breakfast place that would nurse the hangover and fill our belly with good hearty food! This place was awesome. The food was flavorful, filling and the staff were nice. I love the southern flavors.  It was a perfect fit for my pallete. 
 I had the country fried steak and eggs and its was amazing. It was perfectly seasoned and had  a very crunchy batter yet the steak was cooked to perfection. I ordered a Bloody Mary and that was decent too! There was a little bit of a wait, but nothing to fret about. Overall, I'd come back to this place in a heart beat. The only reason why I didn't give it 5  is because the server took a long time to get to u.
author: Nadia G.

description: Cozy little place. You must visit it for fried chicken and fried okra.
author: Vrushali P.

description:
How is it that I have not yet written a review for my favorite restaurant in the city?  Front Porch serves up comfort food with friendly service. I'm a fan of the shrimp and grits, fried chicken, chicken fried steak, and fried okra with a bottle of Abita root beer, which is brewed in Louisianna!  

Parking can be rough.  Be sure to leave a little room for time and patience when it comes to finding parking in the neighborhood, or take J-Church out to the area.
author: Jenny K.

description: Unreal food, amazing service, and stellar drinks. We will be back. Try the chicken and waffles or the stoner stack, can't go wrong.
author: Luke L.

description:
Don't let the meat-centric menu fool you, vegetarian options are here for you as well! The atmosphere is adorable, especially if you reserve for one of the few outside, "front porch," tables during one of our lovely city's few and special warm, late evenings.

Situated between Mitchell's and various amazing dive bars, The Front Porch provides a refuge from the fast-paced Mission and is more reminiscent of visiting Southern relatives, even if only for a few minutes.

A major plus is that if you pay with a registered credit card, you get extra airline miles through the AAdvantage Dining Program as they are a member restaurant!
author: Tracy B.

description: SO GOOD YOU GUYS. Get the fried okra. Get the chicken. Get the everything. Brunch is great. Drinks are great. The place is super small so make a reservation early. Felt like the dirty south got Californiafied.
author: Aaron H.

description:
I had a sazerac  for the first time.  It seemed like all alcohol.  I thought by having this southern drink it would be different.....it was.  I then thought I would switch it up with a mint julep.  Wrong !   It tasted just like a sazerac in a different shaped glass.  I'll pass on these southern drinks at this establishment.  

It's hard finding decent fried chicken nowadays.  This was pretty good though.  It was moist inside.  I'd recommend the bucket of chicken.  With a hardy appetite this hits the spot.

The mac and cheese was fine.  The collard greens and mashed potatoes were alright too.

The beignets didn't strike my fancy.

Four stars is pushing it .....if anyone has any fried chicken restaurant recommendations let me know.  I heard a long time ago Ad Hoc in Yountville has excellent chicken but I've heard mixed results.
author: Robert C.

description:
Ah, Front Porch. Hipsters be dammed. You are my go-to neighborhood restaurant, when I can get a table that is. One day I will learn to make a reservation, until then I will rely on my lucky timing (showing up at 6:55 on Tuesdays helps). I probably would only like you 3 stars if you weren't so close to home though.

I love the new version of your grits and shrimp (adding bacon made it better, huh, go figure), and your other dishes are often good (though not always). Please stop catering to the unadventurous crowd - there's no reason to have a boring steak and a more boring burger on your menu.

You're 60% Cajun/Creole, I'd like you better at 100%.
author: Lauren G.

description: They found a way to seat eight of us together. The waitress (reminded me of Danielle on American Pickers) was phenomenal.  We consumed the fried chicken, mash potatoes, corn bread, biscuits, green beans, Brunswick Stew etc., then banana bread pudding and beignets.   All delicious to the last bite.  Faneffintastic!    Never thought a restaurant could make homestyle food as good as that.    Great job Front Porch, great job.
author: Joe C.

description:
Fried Chicken = really good with a thin and flavorful crust. Side of mashed potatoes were some of the best I've ever had - so creamy with delicious gravy.  Only downside, the crust of the fried chicken seemed to get soggy pretty fast.

Shrimp & Grits = this was not what I was expecting and would not order this dish again. The grits were too liquidy with a sauce that just didn't have a good taste.  The chicken dish made up for it though.

Recommendation - split a bucket of fried chicken and a side of mashed potatoes
author: Jessica P.

description:
Dirty feeling place. 
Chicken waffles 2/5
Chicken fried steak 1/5
Iced tea, they never come and refill it.
Fried okra 5/5
Eggs Benedict's are super small 2/5
Beignets 2/5
author: Cindy L.

description: Everything we tried was delicious: Bengits, fried okra, baked grits (w egg), sweet potato hash with pork. I'm a southern transplant and I give it an A+!
author: Erin S.

description:
Quaint little place that I have walked by a million times and finally decided to try for dinner.  Inside it looks more like a bar than a restaurant, however, don't let this fool you into thinking that you will be served bar food.

The gumbo was terrific--very rich flavor, not too brothy, and just the right amount of spicy kick.  The shrimp and grits was also scrumptious.

The service was friendly and FAST. Our meal came out within five minutes!  We did come early--around 6pm--on a Monday night so it wasn't very crowded yet, but it definitely filled up by 7pm so I would recommend making reservations if you plan on dining during peak hours.

I can't wait to come back to try their brunch on the weekends!
author: Natalia K.

description: Brunches are sinfully delicious. Better than morning sex, really.
author: Pepe W.

description:
Awful.
Mac & cheese flavorless.
Brussel sprouts, pure sugar.
Pork chop nothing but fat.

Server was good and helpful though!
author: Susan M.

description:
Lets talk about fried chicken. Yes it is delicious, but I didn't know it could be this delicious. When you slather a piece of that fried chicken with the mash potatoes, that is finger lickin g-o-o-d!

Things to note:
- the chicken takes ~30mins to arrives
- this place is not inexpensive
author: Claire B.

description: I like this place, but I don't love it.  It seems to be a little inconsistent.  I've been 3 or 4 times now and the last two times we went, it didn't seem up to par.  We always order the bucket of chicken with the two sides of mashed potatoes and collard greens.  The first time we went, I was blown away with how tasty the fried chicken was.  I absolutely love the collard greens, but I found the chicken to be mediocre this last time.  Service is ok, but sometimes the servers are a little strange.  I agree with Cindy L. that it does have a little dirty feeling to it.  I would give it a 3.5 stars if I could.
author: Stacy M.

description:
This is my favorite "date night" restaurant!

My boyfriend and I have been on several occasions and we each get the same entrees: I get the vegan plate and he gets the cajun catfish. The vegan plate is different everyday and my favorite has been a carrot-puree based vegetable concoction. He just adores the catfish, which comes with delicious sides of sweet potato fries and coleslaw (even though I'm not generally a cole slaw lover!). Other friends have loved the burger and the fried chicken though as a vegetarian I can't vouch for them. 

I would likely give the restaurant four stars on the food alone; however, the atmosphere warrants the fifth star. The decorating is perfect - hip but not pretentious. The lighting is great for a group of friends or a date.

The drinks (only beer/wine) are standard to good. My favorite has been a local IPA that they serve on tap. 

Prices are on the expensive side but reasonable for the quality of the food. I like to save it for special occasions.

I recommend that you make a reservation if you can - it gets busy!
author: Maggie J.

description: Cute interior with dim ambient lighting, and awesome old school Goth music. Unfortunately everyone in my party of three, found our meals to be bland, and the service very unhelpful. I ordered the vegan jambalaya, and it was basically two flavorless portable patties on rice with BBQ sauce slopped on it. No real sauce - horrible. The fried okra and dip had no flavor too. My friend's fish did was boring, and my other friend's mac n'cheese was simple, but required salt. The butterscotch cheesecake was too sweet to eat. The waitress kept asking if we were OK, and when we would try to respond, she would keep walking. It was apparent that she was going through the motions, but it didn't really matter if we were OK. The food was way overpriced for what we got.
author: Daniella C.

description:
Unique restaurant!
-cute random decor, i.e. the use of an old van bench as seating
-the restaurant is also cozy and small, with dim lighting.
-the fried chicken is great!
-house salad is great!
-the service is good and prompt 

The food is great, but a suggestion is to sit closer towards the entrance, and NOT the back.  The back of the restaurant is right next to the kitchen and it got way too hot when I sat there!
author: Linda C.

description:
Loveeeeeeeeee the fried chickennn. The mashed potatoes were creamy and delicious. I also tried the white sangria and it was fantastic.
 
Interesting atmosphere... a little funky but in a good way. Its a great place to go have an intimate dinner with a few friends and indulge in some home cooking.
author: Ashley Vivian A.

description:
INTRO

I haven't been here since 2008. All I want to know is why? I went here last night and had the butter lettuce with green garlic dressing and the spicy shrimp with grits as an entree and I was so so woowed. 

FOOD

Green Garlic Salad with tangerines - It wasn't just the amazingly heavy yet incredibly delicious garlic dressing. It was the thick bundles of freshy butter lettuce, and the hyper flavorful blue cheese that can knock ya off your feet. 

Spicy shrimp and grits - Spicy yes, but creamy also..and such a fantastic blend of the two. 

Macoroni and cheese - The best I've ever had. I have no idea what cheese they used, but Jesusss. I had to add a little salt and pepper, but that usually goes without saying. 

DECOR

I love the decor, too. I've never been to New Orleans so my closest comparison was Austin. Quirky, colorful, and unpretentious. I think the low ceilings add to the more intimate feel of the place (by intimate I don't mean quiet, though, as this place is pretty loud). 

SERVICE

The service was good. I was so engrossed with the food that I wasn't necessarily that attentitive to them. I was having foodgasms at a pretty constant rate....

CONCLUSION

This place is one of the most underrated in the city!
author: Alexandra M.

description:
Good but not great food that's a bit overpriced. 

We arrived five minutes to 9 for our reservation. My buddy called to make the reservations for four the day before, got a confirmation but when we got there there was nothing on the books at all. The hostess was nice enough but I could have gone without the condescending "love" she tacked on to every sentence. 

We popped up the block for a quick beer at a bar that smelled like broken dreams and came back around 9:40 for a table that was waiting for us. The waitress was nice, knowledgeable and attentive - so that's good. 

While browsing the menu earlier in the day, I had my heart set on the pecan-crusted catfish. My son of a snake pal Jamie ordered before I could and I'll be god damned if I wanted two of the same dishes at the same table, so I switched to the fried chicken. Thank. God. 

Appetizers included the fried green tomatoes and fried okra and both were happy in my belly. 

We got the pork chop (solid), the aforementioned catfish ("I wouldn't order it again," Jamie said in his sheepish Canadian tone), blackened catfish that was slightly undercooked and my fried chicken. 

The fried chicken kicked all sorts of ass. It managed to be very crisp on the outside and moist inside. The best part was that it wasn't as greasy as you'd expect fried chicken to be. Just clean and wonderful.  

We had a few drinks with the meal which probably why the bill was a bit more than I expected. It wasn't outrageous but know that you'll be paying a little more for the cool ambiance and booshie presentations. 

It's too far from where I live to really make it worth going but that chicken will haunt my dreams.
author: Marin P.

description:
Do NOT eat here if you have a shellfish allergy!  

I went to The Front Porch tonight with a friend who is allergic to shellfish.  There was no indication or warning on the menu that non-shellfish dishes might be exposed to shellfish.   Allergic reactions to shellfish can be deadly which is why most restaurants state clearly if dishes include or might be exposed to shellfish.

We ordered fried okra as an appetizer never considering that it might be exposed to shellfish.  My friend had two bites of okra and started to feel like he was having a shellfish reaction.  We asked the staff immediately if the okra was exposed to shellfish.  The floor staff told us that the dish should not include any shellfish but agreed to check with the kitchen.  After checking, the staff returned shocked to find out that every fried item (except the chicken) was exposed to shellfish since the same oil was used for everything except the chicken.    

The management/chef never came out to talk to us or check on my friend.  The floor staff was very nice but seemed unconcerned even when my friend was outside throwing up.   They never offered any assistance of any kind. 

I will be reporting this incident to the SF Department of Public Health tomorrow. It turns out that my complaint will not be the first.  The Front Porch received 3 official health violations in February.
author: Erin D.

description: This place makes my mouth water. Slightly over prices but the food is really good. I would have to say that it was more mild than I was expecting the first time I went there for cajun food but someone there know how to cook. You gotta check this spot out.
author: Bantu Z.

description: In as few words as possible, everything here was amazing. The chicken was mouth wateringly good, the mashed potatoes were heavenly, even the hot peanuts were delicious. The staff was friendly and very helpful. They made some great cocktails and made sure everything was just right.
author: Sam H.

description:
Our friends liked this place a lot but for us so/so....will not be back on our own.  More of a neighborhood place. If it was not for the fun company that night this would be a 2-star review.

Context: group of seven for dinner on a Sunday night at 6:30

Atmosphere: front porch, despite its name, might better be called basement. It's in this cave like, almost windowless space but it does have a few outside tables.  It also smells a bit like a basement, musty and airless. It's very small with maybe seven or eight tables and a long bar. It's also very dark. We had a table at the front that required some maneuvering to fit seven and moving around to let people in and put. It was right by the cash register and i was regularly bumped as staff passed including knocking my purse on the floor enough i decided to hold it. They were steady but not packed

Service: we were seated promptly upon arrival and they were fairly patient with our dithering and indecisiveness.  Wen we finally ordered, food and drinks came kind of willy nilly.  The server returned repeatedly to see if we needed anything.

Food: I would call this kind of creoleish comfort food- fried chicken, gumbo. Mac and cheese, fried catfish, red beans and rice, etc. we ordered quite an array of choices. 

The menu is medium sized but not very friendly for those looking for something light.  We started with fried pickles with an aioli and crawfish étouffée French fries.
