The servings are medium sized but the two rich dishes were plenty for the seven of us. The pickles are like good fried food but they feel greasy, maybe because pickles are moisture filled? The étouffée was just way too rich for my tastes with a pile of fries, smothered in a creole tomato sauce and tiny little shrimp. For mains, we had the fried chicken, the fried fish, some dish with shrimp, pork belly sandwich, red beans and rice with andouille, a salad, and gumbo. Fried chicken was moist and flavorful with a spicy taste to the chicken itself and not greasy. The fried fish was too mushy for my tastes. The shrimp dish was served on grits and was mildly tasty. The pork belly was like eating little chunks of flat fat on a big bun. I had one bite and couldn't eat anymore. It came with fries. The red beans and rice were tasty but not stand out. Salad was fine. Gumbo was a bit slimy with okra and not particularly flavorful, though not bad. Overall, I came away with the impression that the food did not have much flavor, which is weird given its creole-like foundation. They do give you two hot sauces, one of which is very hot, to heat things up which I generally poured on everything after trying it and finding it so blah. The chicken I think was the best dish.

Drinks: beer, wine and cocktails are offered. Cocktails tend to be new orleanish including a sazerac. I had a cream style dark beer but didn't find it very creamy. The server described it as a thicker dark beer,  which was certainly not the case. But it was good.
author: Vivek V.

description:
I have been wanting to check out this place for a while now and finally, it happened!
..had the popcorn chicken, fried okra (omg, excellent!), collard greens, mash potatoes and mac n cheese.. yes, too much food haha.but oh so yummy! Mac and cheese was a heart attack waiting to happen! No, seriously. It was really good but really really bad for you.

My friend also recommended pork chops and tea cocktail ..hmm.. maybe next time!=)

The place is small, dark, good looking cozy bar and it is unpretentious..just the way i like it. if i lived closer, i'd show up there for a beer and some fried something=)!!

You have to try out this place. Food, atmosphere and serive , ambiance, look..all good.
author: C A.

description:
I've been here a few times--I live in the neighborhood and like to support local places. 

The reason for the one-star review: when a website problem resulted in my reservation being lost, the hostess was extremely rude. She told me that if I had a problem, I should take it up with OpenTable. No apology for ruined plans, just a condescending attitude. This is generally how the hipster hosts and servers at Front Porch are--too cool to be nice. 

The food at Front Porch is fine, but it is ultimately not worth the price. And if you've been there once, no need to go again--the menu is limited and doesn't seem to change. Given how bad the service is, I certainly won't be going back.
author: B G.

description:
Twelve years ago I went on a business trip to Salt Lake City. Our company was located next to the mall, and I decided to get some lunch at the Chinese place at the food court. I went with the combo, which included Kung Pao chicken, Mongolian beef, steamed rice and mashed potatoes. Yep, mashed potatoes. Presenting, Chinese food, Utah-fied. 

I think Front Porch is the epitome of Southern cuisine, San Francisco-fied It's a little too apparent that they tried to make the restaurant into what San Franciscans think Southern restaurants look like. Instead, if they had tried to make it look and feel like a true Southern restaurant, it would have been more authentic and a bit less contrived. Also, hipster waiters, really? How is THAT Southern? 

I was a big fan of the patio with a couple of rocking chairs, but guess what? You're still in the Mission, watching people try to cram their Smart cars into "motorcycles only" spots. Although if you did sit in one of those chairs, you would have seen my car in its amazing parking spot right across the street. Yup, I got very lucky. The interior of the restaurant is dark but cute. The chandelier made out of old kitchen utensils was my favorite, the faux clay ceiling (read: plastic ceiling) was not. 

Our waiter appeared out of nowhere and told us a little bit about the menu. He also brought us two tiny pieces of cornbread; each piece was the size of a biscotti. The cornbread was good, I think, but who can tell when it's gone in two bites??? When I asked for iced tea, he, true to the Southern tradition, asked me whether I wanted "sweet or un-sweet." While sweet tea is one of my favorite things in the world, I had to give it up a long time ago. It's just too much sugar. If you don't believe me, check this out: http://www.grits.com/tea.htm. Yep, 2 parts water, 1 part sugar. Shrug. 

We ordered 3 appetizers to share: hush puppies, fried okra and yard clippins (a salad). The hush puppies were amazing, some of the best I've had this side of Mississippi. The fried okra was quite good, although anything deep fried is tasty. I think I liked it because I couldn't taste the okra, which I detest. The salad was organic and crispy, but the dressing that tasted like prune juice was absolutely horrible. I guess I am too old to drink sweet tea, but not old enough to drink prune juice. Hmmm. 

For my entree, I went with the pork chop with andouille sausage cornbread stuffing. I liked the stuffing a lot more than the pork chop itself. The meat was overcooked and extra stringy. And no, it wasn't country-fried, so don't tell me "that's how it was supposed to taste." My friend opted for the vegan plate, which was actually very good. I would have totally ordered it . . . as a side to my steak. 

As we were driving back, I kept think about those hush puppies, the delicious deep fried cornballs. YUM. It would totally be worth it to get scalded by the Bluth Company Cornballer every once in a while, if I could only make those hush puppies at home. (If you are not an Arrested Development fan, please ignore the last paragraph).
author: Yan G.

description: Collard greens were...good? Chicken was dried out. It was almost closing so maybe that's why the guy helping us looked impatient. I'll order the spicy shrimp and grits next time. Maybe I'll like that. (Hipster Hangout Alert). Lol.
author: Leilani I.

description: If you're going to include allyl isothiocyanate (horseradish, dijon mustard, etc.) in your deviled eggs and meatloaf, you should warn people on the menu.  I ordered both and hate, hate allyl isothiocyanate.  So disappointing.  On the plus side, my date's fried chicken was delicious, as were the mashed potatoes and the bread pudding.
author: J B.

description:
After so many mentions my friends, I came here last night for dinner. Here is recap of the night.

Fried okra- yummy, sliced length-wise which was different
Fried Chicken- juicy, tender, and no salt on the skin
Chicken Gumbo- darker color than I am used to but no salt it seems like
Halibut over seafood jambalaya- large fresh prawns which were yummy, jambalaya was without salt, fish was grilled and good, again, no salt

I kept on remembering that the food was tasteless and I had to put salt on everything. This place is A-ok to me because the flavor of the food was decent... just needed some salt.
author: Eva Y.

description: What a hidden little gem - drove past it twice!!!  Overall great service, good food, pleasent decor, and very worthy of 4 stars!!  Started with gumbo, which was good, but not outstanding (corn, shrimp chowder at Guissies was outstanding!!) - then moved to new item which was the biscuit, fried chix, gravy "sandwich" - good flavor all around - chicken was nice and moist while crispy exterior - side potatoes needed to be better crisped (a bit soggy) - will be back!!
author: Richard D.

description:
Enjoyed 2 scrumptious lunches here already and looking forward to the dinner menu. The service is always friendly and informative but it is really all about the food!

Shrimp and Grits knocked me over, tangy and spice with a rich wine flavor. Fried okra was good, the batter was wonderfully light, but could have used a little more seasoning. But the best are the beginets, not at all what I expected!
author: Katie A.

description:
What a disappointment. My partner and I decided to take a very good friend here for her birthday, she absolutely loves southern food. We've been here before and had a reasonable experience. I lived in New Orleans for many years so can appreciate good southern food as well.
This time was a completely different experience. The service was horrendous, slow beyond belief and then when she finally did acknowledge us, she was cold and rushed us thru the ordering process then had to check back to confirm a selection. Having waited tables for years, I looked around to see if they were under staffed or extra busy but the restaurant was only about 1/3 full. The food was reasonably good but the bread, drinks, appetizers and entrees all arrived at the same time. Overall it was a subpar dinner and we will not likely recommend The Front Porch again.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Burnt horrible coffee, undercooked & bland veggies with flank steak which was pretty good itself. Biscuts for boobies biscuts were the worst, at least for three dollars a biscut it was for a good cause. I'm not really sure what would get me back here.

wasn't this bad on previous visits, but it was fairly lame last night.
author: diction d.

description:
Any cajun place with decent reviews deserves a try. But after been there twice, I am a little torn. Don't get me wrong, it is worth repeated visits but I am really wavering between the star ratings.

First of all, the atomsphere was great. Clearly a hipster hangout place, I always felt like the un-hippest people there. 

It was loud and fun, not good for talking with your brunch buddies but there was live band once! The decor was very interesting, a hodge-podge of random things, looking like a hoarding grandmother's living room. The small plates were not the standard-issued white, but all mismatched china with floral paints, as if they were hand-me downs and along the way, every family broke a few from each collection. Downside was that it was a little too dimly lit in the back. Service was good.

As for food, the po boys were good and the price was decent. I didn't really like the fried okras, on the greasier side, even for fried food. The shrimp and grit had a very nice sauce, slowly cooked so all the flavours mellowed together, nothing overpowering but complexed with depth. The portion was small tho and the grit was quite thin that I was hungry soon after.
author: Cindy B.

description:
The Front Porch is yummy home-style, soul-food. 

My favorites are the Pork Chop, Spicy Shrimp and Grits, and the Fried Chicken. The Fish and Chips are also very good with a crunchy, crusted layer instead of oily, thick batter. I have tried most of the things on their menu, and you can't wrong with any of them. The meats are cooked with flavor and always juicy. =]

The waiters/waitresses are always friendly. And the atmosphere has a darkened mood lighting and can be a little cramped at times, but the food makes up for it.
author: Chris C.

description:
I'm almost at the point where I don't even want to try a new restaurant. My friend saw this restaurant featured on checks please so off we went (reluctantly on my half).

The following is listed in the order of my liking
mac & cheese: this was the best thing we ordered today and rated a 6 on a scale of 1-10
fried chicken: meat was moist, coating was crispy but no flavor but salty, rated a 5
fried okra: great for those with an oral fixation. again no flavor but will keep your mouth moving till the food arrives, rated a 3
red beans & rice with sausage: this was the worse shit I've ever eaten, the rice was hard from either being nuked or it was the bottom of the pot. can I stress AGAIN, no flavor. rated a 1

I would never return even if someone else was picking up the bill. I see there are a lot of great reviews so either I came on a bad day or these poor souls have never had real food so they thought this was great. OR they've had some drinks to make the food seem good like how ugly people look good too after a few drinks. As for southern food...really? would that be south of the border in Mexico because that would have to be the case.
author: May G.

description:
After passing by this place and noticing all the cute rocking chairs, I finally decided to go in and try it for dinner. Ordered a strawberry lager at the bar while they set up the table for us. Service was friendly and nice, but lagged a lil probably because they were about to close. The decor was dim and intimate, with a old fashion cashier sitting on the bar area and t-shirts on the wall saying "fucket get a bucket" 

Ordered the spicy shrimp with grtiz and the chicken gumbo.  The chicken gumbo arrived fasst but maybe too fast. It lacked in the flavor savor department and the sausages werent the greatest. The spicy shrimp with gritz was good in the sense that it was creamy but again not much flavor or spice there. I've heard good reviews about the fry chicken, and the goat cheese ice cream, so im pretty sure im goin to return with a thirst for beer and battered goods!
author: Shirley L.

description:
After a walk in the Presidio with the puppy my hubby and I were starved and decided to treat ourselves to a little fried chicken, we'd walked up a hill after all! The hubby wanted Hard Knox but I've been wanting to try Front Porch for quite a while, so many friends have told me this is THE place for fried chicken, plus FP has hush puppies so I convinced hubby we should try it out. 

The place is small and decorated with that rockabilly country vibe but a bit too dark really, we both had a hard time reading the menu not that we need to review anything but the drinks since we were there for the fried chicken. We ordered the jalapeno hush puppies to start and of course two three piece fried chicken plates that come with garlics mashed potatoes and collard greens. I prefer having something crisp and fresh but you don't get a choice of what comes with it. The Hubby detests garlic and they did let him substitute french fries for the garlic mash but for a $2 fee which was odd to me I mean he was swapping potatoes for potatoes. 

The jalapeno hush puppies were light and fluffy but a bit bland. I saw one tiny piece of jalapeno in mine and could not taste or feel any spice. The dipping sauce that came with it was OK, some sort of mayonnaise based sauce, personally I think a jalapeno jelly would have complimented better. 

We were also given a side of corn bread which was probably one of the best things on the table. It was very fluffy and moist with the sweetness of the corn coming though in every bite. 

After the corn bread out came the fried chicken. It was beautifully fried but the pieces were cut so they were not whole pieces of fried chicken and they were overly seasoned. Poor hubby said it was garlic seasoned and had to pull off the batter and just eat the chicken which defeats the purpose of going for fried chicken. I didn't taste garlic ,more like some sort of off the shelf seasoning salt (Lawry's perhaps??) and WAY too much of it. It was like eating a fried salt lick, which was really too bad because the texture of the chicken was perfect, if only I could have tasted it instead of the salt. 

To cut the salt I tried to rotate chicken with bites of mashed potatoes and collard greens but the potatoes were also overly salted and the greens too vinegary. I had to cut the salt with 2 glasses of cava which the waitresses kept trying to take away before I'd finished, probably because it is so f*cking dark in there!! 

I really don't see how this place has so many great reviews. Maybe some people like over priced tiny pieces of salty chicken, have only eaten KFC or don't know what greens or hush puppies are supposed to taste like. More power to them, they can stay here, I'll be going to Hard Knox.
author: Pilar B.

description:
I really enjoyed this place but that could be partially influenced to the company I was keeping at the time and that I had gotten a drink prior to coming to the restaurant.

This place is nice because they ALWAYS HAVE A VEGAN SPECIAL!

The jar of pickled things was rather tasty and there lawn clippings salad ruled. 

It's not cheap but it's not expensive. Just not some place you'd go every night for a quick bite to eat, but lovely for a nice night out.

Overall I'd come here again for sure
author: Bc L.

description: A quaint spot with a neighborhood feel, we found The Front Porch to be comfortable and inviting from the moment we walked in. We started with gumbo and fried okra both were uniquely prepared but big on flavor and big enough to share. I had the most amazing shrimp and grits (seriously, amazing!) I've had probably ever. The grits were truly creamy and delicious all by themselves. Hubby had the 4 piece chicken with collards and mac n cheese. WOW! We couldn't believe how tender, juicy and flavorful it was. Dessert was the apple crumble and pecan pie both were out of this world! Overall our meal was OUTSTANDING and the service matched! Kenny, our waiter was friendly, knowledgeable and there when we needed him. Hats off Front Porch, keep it up!
author: Melitta W.

description:
Such a cute place!!! Wasnt thrilled about the inside, but the actual porch is amazing.

Food was good, but i was sad to see the menu was different than the one online. Portions were big, and we got a lot to go after, which I love!

A minus was the 50min wait for our food!! I think they forgot us, but waiter was nice enough and apologized. Thankfully i had great company and it was a nice night for swinging on our chairs :)
author: Martie K.

description:
As I try to cross off the list 100 food/drinks I must try before I die, the list brought me to the Front Porch for the Crab and Grits... A little disappointed I was to find out the chef that made that NO LONGER works there and took the recipe with him... Booo!!!!! But nonetheless, we sat down and continued with our experience. 

We started off with the Fried Okra with Jalapeno Aioli and Fried Catfish Sliders. The fried okra were addicting! I just keep popping them into my mouth like popcorn!  The catfish sliders were not too bad.. not enough fish though.. =T For our main entree, we had the Fried Chicken, Shrimp and Grits, and the Lower Ninth Ward BBQ Shrimp. They were all effin' awesome! The shrimp and grits and bbq shrimp were both on the spicy side, but I love spicy food, so it was deelish for me. the fried chicken was juicy and not overly battered. PERFECT! =) 

We got there a little past 6, and there were plenty of seats left. But by the time we left, around 8:30... the place was packed with a wait.. on a Wednesday night! Recession's over!!
author: My C.

description:
The other half was craving for fried chicken..so after doing a little research and reading through the reviews, we finally decided to try out The Front Porch...

Love the space..a little speak-easy vibe..

Service was very attentive and on top of  things.. we started with the spicy shrip and grits and deviled crabs. both were tasty but not memorable. The mac n cheese was so-so. and then the bucket for fried chicken came...we were in heaven! perfectly golden brown and juicy tender meat. yummy!
author: Mich Q.

description:
If you order anything, get the fried chicken and macaroni and cheese.  And a beer.

Here's my impression of everything else:
picked  vegetables - too sour 
oxtail stew - too tough, stew kind of sour from tomatoes but it's tasty from the meat
fried okra- so/so.  it's good if u like okra
gumbo - don't do it.  tastes burned 


service was great.
author: Alias A.

description: The best fried chicken ever!! their mac and cheese is great too!
author: Steve P.

description:
I've been here three times, and I'm still not impressed.  Their food is really rich in creams and oils and perfectly cooked, but the seasoning I woudl expect from cajun food just isn't there.

The service is amazing.  Drinks are strong. They also have some creative dishes - for example sweet potato waffles.

My friend absolutely loves their chicken, so I'll go back if he wants to go.  I probably wouldn't go back on my own.
author: Hester B.

description:
on sundays i like to do waspy shit like roast a whole chicken.  this is because it makes the whole house smell good and i get to wear an apron.  this sunday mama was workin' all day and didn't have time to roast daddy a fucking chicken.  i remembered that the front porch sells their amazing fried chicken by the bucket with sides for about thirty bucks- HELL YES.  do i need to tell you that when i was pregnant i got a craving and went to KFC for the first time in like 10 years and somehow spent $28.00 there for two people- it was terrible.  this shit however is incredible, thirty bucks (will feed two very hungry people) and is available for take-out before 7:30.  they made my night!

(i did however have a "precious" moment runnin' my ass up that hill to the safeway parking lot with my bucket of chicken PRAYING my car wasn't towed...)
author: Jessie J.

description: Not sure what the fuss is all about. The food is pretty simple,  not anything to write home about. I think my favorite part of our dinner was the corn muffins. The customer service is alright. Not great. I guess I was expecting more from all the rave reviews....
author: Yana B.

description: Man this place is good. Had shrimp and grits were awesome and the bite I had of the pork chop was juicy, tender and flavorful. Deviled eggs have a different spin with the jalapeño and bacon on top. Crawfish hush puppies were good as well. Ordered it over at Rock bar. Would do that again for sure!
author: Marc L.

description:
THE BEST FRIED CHICKEN ?!?!

I'm not trying to attack the masses who say that in their reviews but I really hope I came on an off day ... please tell me I did. True the chicken was juicy but definitely not flavorful. Maybe they forgot to salt and spice the batter? I mean when you say best fried chicken you have to be talking about flavor and not just texture or consistency right? Mac n Cheese, collared greens, mashed potatoes were decent at best.

I know some of my favorite food joints tend to be off kilter at times so a second visit is in the works. I want redemption sucka.
author: Steve H.

description:
I have eaten at the front porch maybe 10x.  The food is pretty good and the service is hit and miss,

Tonight the service was so bad I will not be returning.

Ambivalent, can not be bothered, hipsters (code for a dude in skinny jeans- YUCK)  should not wait tables.  

Clearly waiting tables is WAY beneath the gentleman hipster who waited on us tonight.

So the food tastiness does not outweigh the bad service...won't go back - ever.
author: jennifer t.

description: As someone who grew up in the south I definitely believe I'm a connoisseur when it comes to the perfect friend chicken. This place doesn't disappoint! Friend chicken is crunchy, moist, full or flavor, and doesn't have an inch of batter you have to bite through before you get to the meet. Definitely try an order of biscuits! Rosemary butter is to die for! Mulled wine was delicious and the perfect compliment to the food and the cold night!
author: Michael M.

description: The shrimp and grits were amazing, as well as the "hangover helper" (mac n' cheese + chili beef). I only ding this place one star because one of our servers was less than friendly.
author: Rich L.

description:
Going here feels like an escape to New Orleans, moody, boisterous and vibrant. People's eyes crinkle, it's warm, everything moves a little slower, but with purpose. Dates feel like you're stealing time, food feels like you're packing on calories. And you are.

Don't tell me you don't get those fried hankerings where it doesn't matter what the thing is except battered and greasy! I see you, lipid lover! I'm happy to say that TFP has set the benchmark for crispy fried goodness. They also excel in more ambitious culinary exploits: the shrimp and grits, yard clippin' salad and chicken fried steak work out real nice like. And the portions are large enough to feed the army of ants that parade around my compost pile. That's commendable.

Soul food's got my ideal flavor profile: salty, sour, spicy, in that order, and these folks play up the sour. That leaves many fine options for paired tippling. Though the bar lacks a full license, its got swagger and creativity, so don't hesitate, just swig and enjoy.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
Overpriced home cookin.

This place is good, but honestly I would be equally satisfied going to KFC and getting a dinner plate there.  We got the crab cakes, mac n cheese, and then someone also got the shrimp n grits.  The mac n cheese was totally good.  Otherwise, it was hard to eat too many other things because it had pork, bacon, etc.  Warning to those who don't eat meat, selection here is limited.
author: Nadiyah S.

description: The bucket of chicken and popcorn was really good.  We also had the mac and cheese, it was good, but not great.  Everything was fresh and hot and the service was attentive and friendly.
author: Hillery G.

description: The most amazing chicken I have ever eaten!  Everything was great.  Do yourself a favor and have dinner at the Front Porch.
author: Toni E.

description: I had the holy sh!t burger, whilst my girlfriend had the mac n cheese and a ranch salad. All of it was excellent. Dropped a star as it could have been marginally cheaper given the area. Would go again.
author: Tom K.

description:
Being from the South and from New Orleans to  be exact, I am often on the lookout for hometown food. I guess I will keep looking. It started off right, the decor, with the patterned ceilings and casual  chic decor. They even had Sazeracs and Abita beer on the bar menu. I had a glass of white wine because Sazeracs are too strong for me and I wasn't in a beer mood (need piles of boiled crawfish and  crabs to go with that ). I glanced at the dinner menu and became instantly suspicious. Too many California-ized dishes with so-called 'health conscious' ingredients mixed in with standard fried and sauteed in butter fare. It just seemed that the cook may have studied Southern cooking, but didn't really understand it. I ordered the flounder, as it is one of my favorite fish. It was too salty! I had really wanted to shrimp grits, but it wasn't on the menu that day. The jambalaya had peas in it--peas??? That would be paella maybe, but not jambalaya. The hush puppies were pretty good, with a nice kick and fried just right. Other customers were snarfing down the fried chicken, maybe that was the thing to order. Tried the beignets, but was disappointed. They were too cakey and they shook them in powdered sugar, rather than dumping a pile of it atop freshly fried dough (which New Orleans style beignets basically are--similar to Indian fry bread, but the shape and toppings are different). When you eat beignets, you are supposed to get a face full of powdered sugar!

But if you want a place with a cozy atmosphere and are not focusing much on the food, this is a nice place. Very lively with a homey feel. I happened to be there when a large group of blonde Southern women were busy celebrating a friend's birthday. It reminded me of a scene out of Steel Magnolias.
author: 和子

description:
I came to the Front Porch after a friend suggested we try getting some take out. I could not wait to sink my teeth into some crispy fried chicken!
 The place looked very cozy with garden-like seating out front. A full service bar just inside. . 
I ordered a bucket of chicken to go. I sat sipping my drink at the bar noticing the decor. Inside was very cozy almost like being in a honky-tonk somewhere in the south. I saw families and couples on dates. Everyone looking very satisfied.
Twenty minutes later, my order came. When I tore into it at home I had a popcorn bucket with fried chicken and mashed potatoes with gravy, collard greens and cornbread!
When I bit into the chicken, the skin was crispy the chicken juicy and tender. The mashed potatoes were lightly seasoned. I could not stop slopping up the greens! I was pleasantly surprised!
I will definitely eat here again, next time I will be dining in!
author: Cyn B.

description:
I had heard about this place when my friends and I went to Mitchell's, which is a block away. Both friends raved about this place. Days later, I came here with another set of friends who have never been here. We ordered fried okra and fries as our appetizers, then shared a bucket of fried chicken and short ribs with side order of mashed potatoes, collard greens, and mac n' cheese. Also, we had sangria, which you are given a choice of rose or red wine as the base. A lot of dishes lacked flavor - okra (but had dipping sauce with it), mashed potatoes, mac n' cheese, and even the fried chicken. I had to season them with salt and I had sprinkled hot sauce on the chicken (maybe that's the intention to go light on the flavor?). The sangria also seemed to lack sufficient flavor, seemed a little watered down (different from the sangria from Cha Cha Cha). 

On the other hand...the chicken was tender and of higher quality meat, than your KFC. The mashed potatoes had a nice, creamy texture. Our waitress was super-sweet and cool. Also, I liked the ambiance inside - dark, hip cool. You have cushioned seats with seatbelts and armrests and super-realist art on the wall of cds and cassette images.
author: Audrey L.

description:
I enjoyed, but was not wowed by the food. I think that it's a can't go wrong place to go to, but not one that has me feeling a need to go back. 

The rest of this review is superfluous.

The biscuits (I love biscuits. I would even say I luv 'em, I heart them, and I loooove them. I'd even say it with Isaac Haye's bedroom voice) are meh. Tiny and uninspired. 

The service bordered on attitude and negligent. I'll allow that was perhaps because it was the end of the brunch period on a Sunday. And I went alone ['A lone brunch eater? There's probably something wrong with him. Better keep our distance.' Yes. It's the cross I bear. And I've not kept up with the SF hipster look, which doesn't help ingratiate me with the locals. So I don't fault them per se; again it just doesn't inspire me to return. 

Seating seemed pretty good, with some outdoor spots, too. There's a full bar.
author: A D.

description:
They do not take reservations for lunch and brunch.  

I came here on a Saturday morning.  We ordered the chicken and waffles (25 min wait time) and the crab cake benedict. We had the server bring the crab cake benedict out first so we could share that while we wait for the chicken and waffles.

Crab cake benedict: Very disappointing.  It was floury, mushy, and not too much of a taste.  You do get a lot of crab, but just very poor in flavor.

Chicken and Waffles: This was the money maker right here.  I really enjoyed the batter, and the chicken was so moist.  The waffles went very well with the chicken.  I was a happy camper!

Our bill, please double triple quadruple check your bill.  That was how many times they had to fix our bill.  They accidently kept charging us extra!

Service was good, despite the check incident.

I parked a block away, 2 hour parking!
author: Joanne H.

description: I ordered the mac and cheese and Brussels sprouts! it was like my the taste buds were busting a move! like a dance party in my mouth!
author: Dida A.

description:
The best thing about this place is when they provide their carefully controlled filteration of water served in a pristine 40oz. Old English Glauss Bottle.

...
author: Romes K.

description: They do it right!  I had the Dr. Pepper Rib it was execellent! the wife had the fried chicken it was also excellent!  We will be back!!
author: Phil B.

description:
I'm a big fan of The Front Porch!  I've been here a few times, and each time, the experience has been memorable, service pleasant, and food delicious.  There's not much use in describing my dishes, as the menu changes seasonally, and vegan/fish dishes change daily or weekly.  

----- The Location -----
In the heart of the Mission district, parking can be tough, and the area can seem seedy.  The restaurant is designed to be somewhat divey on the outside, the inside is quite nice.

----- The Food -----
I'm by no means a vegan (eating a sausage at the airport, waiting for a delayed flight), but any chance I can dine on some well done vegetarian/vegan food, I'm always down!  The first trip, I had the plantain risotto with mushrooms.  How can you go wrong?  The second time, I tried the fried chicken.  Though the chicken was good, it was just... fried chicken.  I'd prefer the Korean fried chicken style (less breading, more natural skin flavors), but good nonetheless.  The best part was the sides.  Brussel sprouts, grits, and fried okra.  I could see how some people might think the grits were too plain, but it was just as I like 'em.

A note on the hot sauce.  They have an amazing habanero hot sauce.  It's like a habanera puree, so be careful!  I was putting this on everything.  Probably went through 3 tablespoons of it.

----- The Booze -----
My coworker ordered a white wine from Chablis.  Very clean, very good!  Not overly dry, and paired perfectly with the food (except the brussel sprouts, which had a caramelized, sweet flavor).  I don't know much about white wines, but this one was very drinkable.  As my coworker says, this is what water should taste like!  Not that the wine is watered down, but drinking water should be replaced with drinking a Chablis.  Ooook, alkey (though I agree).

----- The Dessert -----
Ok, so we had bread pudding and some other desserts, but we drank our dessert.  2006 Sauterne dessert wine.  It came in a miniature bell glass to allow proper aeration and maximum aromas (or, it just looked cute).

Why the four stars instead of five?  The second time I tried to getting the vegan dish, it had coconut.  Not only do I not like coconut, I'm somewhat allergic.  Not that this is their fault, but the fact that beyond the fun of the random vegan dish, there isn't really a lot of other options that pique my interest.  For that, 4 stars.
author: Steve A.

description: Im sorry Tyler Florence, but my favorite friend chicken no longer comes from Wayfare Tavern; The Front Porch is probably the best fried chicken of my existence, and I dont say things like that lightly. I enjoyed everything about this place, the ambience, the cocktails, the food.. the only major hang up I had was the size of the table.. too small for drinks, water and plates of food.. Also try ROCK bar across the street, its owned by the same people and they specialize in mixology.
author: Evan O.

description: I seem to be on an unintentional fried chicken kick lately and happily added The Front Porch's to my list, along with a few other tasty dishes and drinks of theirs. All was good except the bland cornbread - a bit hard to forgive for a southern place, but the rest was good enough. Aside from the food, the place is cozy and has some fun tableware, like water out of a 40 and fried chicken served on a cafeteria tray.
author: Brett B.

description:
Thanks MIranda! 

I had a great time with my boyfriend here this week. We ordered a corn on the cob and the blackened catfish (we were not super hungry). While we waited, treats of cornbread and bruschetta just showed up at our table! Yum! 

I just wish there were more items on the menu that seemed, well, healthy. I can't really get down with that much fried food!

I did really enjoy my glass of Cava, and I do have to compliment the service, everyone there was super on point and seemed like they were enjoying themselves! 

Thanks, we'll be back!
author: Molly G.

description:
I was truly excited to come here and enjoy some quality southrrn food with my hubby.  Being from the south, I miss having my soul food. Believe me, i know food...especially southern food.  Unfortunately, we were disappointed in a few things on the menu. Staff was pleasant and ambiance was what I had hoped it would be like.   Just wish the food was better.

Gumbo...very thick and the rue was not quite right.  Def not freshly made.
Fried okra...we enjoyed
Jambalaya...was decent but not worth 20 plus dollars
Fried chicken...best thing they have going for them.
Dessert...pumpkin brûlée ....should have skipped it

The food is not worth the price you pay.  Sorry guys....I was really rooting for you.
author: Jenny G.

description:
Two words: Fried Chicken.

First time I was here, I had the bucket of fried chicken.  Perfectly crispy on the outside but super moist and tender inside.  One of the best in the city (along with 1300 on Fillmore and Little Skillet).  

Last night, I returned for a group dinner and in addition to the requisite chicken, we stuffed ourselves silly with so much more.

Having to wait about 45 minutes after our reservation, they gave us some fried okra and pickled veggies on the house.  The okra was nicely battered and fried and accompanied with a chili aioli.  One of my favorite dishes of the night.  The pickled veggies are also quite nice.

For appetizers, we had the beet salad (really good, especially accompanied by with the sweet pluots and peppery arugula), the fried green tomatoes (very fresh-tasting) and the blue crab and corn fritters (ok; too fried; lost a little flavor)

For my main, had the entree size of the spicy shrimp and grits, which were amazing!  The grits provided a nice creamy base for the shrimp, bacon and mushroom.  By far the best dish of the night.  Had a bite of the new york steak, which was pretty fatty and not too impressive.  

Overall, great neighborhood place.  Be prepared to wait (even with reservations).  It's always jam-packed but that's just a testament to how good the food is here.
author: F. P.

description:
I'm torn. The place, the food, the staff are all great. It's about 25-30% higher than it should be in terms of what you are getting - $21 for shrimp and grits which is great but expensive. Also the Pork chop is great but really, we only go there a couple times a year due to the price of a dinner for the two of us was $90 plus tip and we didnt' have that much food or drink. The Donkey D Hot Ass Margarita is spicy and yummy. But the weird thing was, on a Saturday evening they played heavy metal music the whole time which is not relaxing, not Southern, not conducive to conversation or feeling good. 
I figured the boss was away and it's also a way to get people in and OUT the door asap. Go there, everything is super good. A bit expensive and not super relaxing but still 4 stars. It needs $$$ rather than $$.
author: Kit M.

description:
This is a great little hole-in-the-wall place. It's super rustic, and I literally felt like I was in NO for the evening. I guess it probably did help that I came in on Mardi Gras!

Food was tasty -- no complaints here. But what really made this place was the music, the drinks, the dark lighting, the artwork, even the location lent itself to the backwoods ambiance. 

I would recommend to all who enjoy southern style livin'.
author: Stephannie N.

description:
From soft hushpuppies to spicy fries to sweet cole slaw to perfect catfish. The front porch is a winner!

Can't give 5 stars though, kinda not cool when a "musician" comes callin for a tip, while I am in the midst of my meal!
author: Sumit G.

description:
TOOK A LONG TIME TO SIT DOWN

Overall: C+
Return Again: IDK, probably not

Showed up and was told the wait would be 10 minutes.  Ended up being 30 minutes.  The staff was way understaffed and was rushing to help people but it wasn't enough.  It took a long time to order our food and even longer to wait for the food.  The food itself was fantastic.  Based on taste alone the place gets a passing grade.  Good job chefs!
author: Chris H.

description: This restaurant is a nice little restaurant tucked within a residential row of homes. The staff is very friendly and the host was more than accommodating. I ordered the baked Mac and cheese which was freshly made, a bit greasy, but expected from a southern food place. I had a delicious spring salad as well. A common practice in SF is to serve canned soda, which I find annoying but manageable. The main dishes were steeply priced with fried chicken coming in at $18 for a 3 piece and a side. Overall a cozy, clean and well managed place that gets top dollar.
author: Ryan M.

description:
MEH... i like farmerbrown better.

drinks were watered down. 

Fn no parking.

no thanks.
author: T V.

description: We eat at this restaurant because we like to try new experiences, to begin ordered the cesar salad was fine, then fried chicken thinking it would be cool but it really was not and finally some shrimp and grits Wow who knew well were satisfied !!! The best of the night was that was available is a table outside with this rich climate of today do not ask for more ...
author: Miguel G.

description: Beignets had way too much sugar and tastes like they use the same oil for fried fish. Unfortunate. The texture was perfect though. I got the chicken and waffles. The chicken was great. The waffle was quite brown but a little soggy. The flavor was fantastic though. Like french toast with some cinnamon. I will be back because they are in my hood but will likely steer clear of the beignets. Service is good but not great today. Other times has been stellar.  Cheers!
author: Raelinn D.

description: The Front Porch is always a treat.  It's a neighborhood fave, and great for small groups (be sure to make a reservation).  We've taken lots of friends there and they've always loved it.  The fried chicken and the shrimp and grits are wonderful (the crab and grits is my favorite, but it's seasonal and wasn't on the menu).  The fried green tomatoes and grilled asparagus were great starters.  The 4 of us shared a bottle of Albarino and a carafe of a domestic Syrah/Grenache blend, and both were tasty.  The banana pudding with Vanilla Wafers was a perfect ending.
author: Robert W.

description: Best fried chicken this side of the bay! Hands down! Phucket get a bucket logo is poignantly placed at the bar to remind you to order a full bucket of chicken. Whoever is cooking this food......slams hard. Cornbread could have been more plentiful but I'm understanding.
author: Betty B.

description: I've been to Front Porch before and enjoyed it, but this time they missed the mark. I got the pulled pork sliders and mac and cheese. The mac and cheese was pretty standard, but without a delicious crust on top or anything. The sliders were cold and the slaw on top of them overpowered the pork. I feel like I spent too much money in proportion to the quality of the food I got.
author: Beth D.

description:
Yes - definitely the best fried chicken I have had, but everything else was really disappointing.

Fried Okra: no taste and somewhat soggy

Gumbo: this was described as a 'sausage fest' by our server (her words, not mine).  I did not find one little piece of sausage anywhere.  Also, it had a really smokey taste....so smoky in fact that it tasted burned.

Fried Chicken:  great.  Collard greens were sandy and disgusting.  They tasted like they had been grown on Ocean Beach and just thrown into a pot without being washed.

Pork Chop: Pork chop was ok.  Sausage Cornbread muffin - grossy McGrosserson. Turnip greens - again with the no washing!!

The service was great, but 95% of the food was regrettable.  If I ever come back, it was strictly be for the chicken.
author: Megan H.

description:
I came here cor chicken and waffles....well I had to wait over an hour because their fryer broke. So at the half hour mark I decide it is time to ask our waitress why our food is taking so long, and she tells us the fryer is broken...OK can I order something else? The answer is no because they are already making it... 
When I finally received my food, the chicken was bland and the waffles terribly funky.
I will only ever come back for their beignets. They were the best thing I had that day.
author: Jen E.

description: OK so this place was all around GREAT!!!!!  I mean from great service when you first walk into the door to great food and great drinks!  It's a little hole in the wall place and not in the best of neighborhoods, but once you get over that, you're good to go!  The portions are a nice size amount (especially for the price), and it's all tasty!  The mac-n-cheese was rich and cheesy, the fish was seasoned and fried to perfection, and the hushpuppies were delectable.  As I said, the staff is super friendly, and the decor is perfectly themed for a down home, front porch feel!  I will definitely be returning!
author: Iman Taliah H.

description: Loved the atmosphere at the Front Porch from the moment I walked in. It just is a place with a good vibe, that makes you feel like you're sitting in someone's home (even though you are clearly not). I was not a big fan of the fried pickles or collard greens, but everything else we tasted (fried chicken, crab & grits, salad) was delicious. The entree portions are not enormous, but we were more than satisfied when we left. Next time I have to leave room for dessert.
author: Katelyn M.

description: I'm sad that some of my fellow reviewers haven't had the same excellent experiences as I have had here. I have dined at The Front Porch more than a dozen times for both dinner and brunch over the last 18 months. I have never had a bad meal here! My husband and I come for the fried chicken, fried okra, bacon-wrapped dates, and (in my opinion) one of the best hamburgers in SF. We've also tried the flounder and short ribs, which are also great. We usually eat at the bar, where the bartender makes a mean sazerac and old fashioned. We've also gotten a warm welcome and excellent service at the tables, too. This is one of our top go-to places in SF for taking out-of-town guests.
author: N K.

description:
neat little place. came here on a saturday afternoon for lunch and there was no wait for a table which we like.

the gumbo was pretty good. we came here to try the fried chicken and it was fried nicely. it was juicy inside which means it was cooked perfectly. the waffle tasted like really good and had yam and cinnamon flavors but isnt the crispy style waffle. 
the pork and hash with eggs was good but the portion was on the smaller side.

the atmosphere is pretty fun since its in a basement/garage.

unfortunately they only serve the corn bread in the evening.
author: Alex H.

description:
The place is in the booneys within a residential area. When we got off the cab I thought I was entering someone's house. Anyway, we walked in and the restaurant was super cozy with a full bar and many tables of friends chatting, and drinking the night away. 

We ordered the mandarin orange salad - it was good but I don't like blue cheese so I can't say that I liked the salad a lot. We also ordered jalapeno hush puppies - the focus was not really the hush puppy itself but rather the touch of spicy aeoli sauce that was used to pair it. We ordered a bucket of fried chicken (of course), it was super cripsy and tender and it came with popcorn! The mash potato was really good. The mac and cheese was average. My friend got the pork belly - good but way too greasy for me. But the top was baked to perfection - crispy. We ended the meal with a rootbeer float - nothing too special about the making of it but definitely hit the spot.
author: Keara C.

description:
So, this is the cutest little neighborhood place in town.  The owners work the floor, the door and the bar. The food is tasty and comforting. The low tin ceiling and dark ambiance, very cozy and warm.

The wine list is well thought out and accessible, both in content and price. 

Vinnie says four stars! Check it out!
author: Statin Island V.

description: Make a reservation because this place seems pretty busy and they're on a tight schedule. Fun menu options. Loved the little gem salad. Fried pickles are waaaaaay better than they sound, just fyi.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Greasy and generally unhealthy food?  Check.  Heart working doubly hard to laboriously pump blood through my body?  Absolutely.  Deliciousness from almost every dish?  You bet your ass.

We ordered about half of the menu, and no, this is not an exaggeration.  In the blizzard of food that graced our table, some of the big standouts were the gumbo, shrimp & grits, and of course, the fried chicken.  And just when I thought I couldn't ram another ounce of food down my gullet, here came the dessert menu.  Bourbon pecan pie?  Yes please!

The only negative of this place is that our planned big night out in the Mission turned into one drink and done, thanks to my uncomfortably full stomach.  But if that's the only bad thing I can say about the restaurant, then it obviously kicked mucho ass.  Well done, Front Porch!
author: Norm U.

description:
I was disappointed by Front Porch. 

The goat cheese and bacon wrapped dates had too much goat cheese, which dominated the flavor and the texture.

I didn't like the seasoning of the fried chicken, but that could be a personal thing.
author: Michael M.

description:
Back in May we had reservations for a friend's birthday (FYI-they only take reservations for parties of five or more).  The only complaint I had was that it was really, really loud.  I could barely hear the person across the table from me.  But honestly, you will be so busy stuffing your face, there will be no talking so it really doesn't matter.

The food was delicious!  There were five of us and we ordered the conch and sweet pepper fritters (yummy!), bucket of chicken (OMG, SO GOOD!), trio of fries (spicy!), black eyed peas with collared greens (didn't know what to expect, but really good), and the jerk bbq of the day which was skirt steak (so tender and full of flavor) with a side of potato salad (surprisingly really spicy but awesome).  If you are offered the hot sauce with the fried chicken, go ahead and accept but be very careful!  It's made with scotch bonnet peppers, which means you will sweat profusely and your mouth will be numb.  But it hurts so good!  

We ordered the box of wine, and we were a bit leery, but it was great.  Our cute waiter informed us that having wine in the box is cheaper to package and holds more than a bottle would.  I'm sold!  They also have certain wines available in juice boxes which unfortunately, we didn't try.  The birthday girl did get two King Cobra 40s!  She keeps it classy.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Something about getting the very last table by the bathroom, that doesn't exactly scream Front Porch. Especially when you are two feet away from the kitchen on a busy Friday night.

A little disappointing since we actually made reservations for 8pm. Hard to believe there wasn't a better table, but we were with friends and decided to roll with it.

I had been here before and convinced my boyfriend to come back for the chicken, something so decadent about the chicken juices all over the popcorn...wait....popcorn...I knew there was something missing. :( This time there was so little popcorn in the bucket it was hardly worth mentioning.

The apps were delicious so I wouldn't complain about that or any of the other food, but the service was a bit iffy. Especially around the drinks. Call me kooky, but most diners  want their drinks shortly after they order them, and we had already finished dessert by the time the brandy showed up.

I like the Front Porch, I would even recommend it, but maybe not on a Friday night.
author: Kelly W.

description:
If you are a fried chicken whore like I am, then I HIGHLY recommend this place! Their chicken is fucking good, man! No seriously. Of all the fried chicken joints I've been to (check out my fried chicken list), this is one of my favorites. 

My friend and I shared a bucket. Yes, we're a bunch of fat asses and we ate it all! Just kidding. I was full after 2 pieces. I believe it came with 8 or 9 pieces. It also came with a side of mashed potatoes and green beans. For around $33, it was totally worth it. Damn man, that was one juicy ass piece of fried chicken! I had one piece left over that I was planning to eat for breakfast. (Omg, that would have been an awesome breakfast!) But I forgot to stick it in the fridge so my bf threw it away! WaAaAaaaaAah! Yes, I was very sad and I almost cried.  =(

I also tried to make last minute reservations. Too bad they were full. We only waited about 15-20 minutes for a table. It was first come first serve and our names were on a list. Good thing we were able to drink beers outside. They had rocking chairs and tables. All they need are heat lamps. I'm definitely coming back here for their awesome happy hour.
author: B B.

description:
YUM!  Enjoyed the fried chicken dinner, another time loved the spicy shrimp and grits.
Liked the biscuits.  Liked the cornbread. My husband thinks they have one of the best burgers in SF.  When you want some comfort food, this is the place.
author: Monte C.

description:
I had herd about Front Porch for a while and so I finally got an opportunity to have dinner with my friend. I'm really glad I made reservations and at kind of an early time (6:30) because when we were done with our food there was a large group of people waiting by the door! And this was on a  Wed night!

Our food was good, not amazing but good. I had the short ribs, I did like the portion of my dinner, it was just the right amount of food! My friend had the fried chicken, it was kind of too much food for her but I tried the chicken and it was good! I wish the drink menu was a little bit more....interesting but the drink I ordered was good!

I would for sure come back again!
author: T C.

description:
3.5 stars.

I really wanted to be ecstatic about this place. I mean, shrimp and grits? Cornbread? Mac and cheese? fried chicken? That's fatty deliciousness in a box right there. How could any of it go wrong?

I wouldn't say that anything was wrong, exactly - but I will say that I felt slightly underwhelmed at times, with the exception of the fried chicken and the green bean casserole. Let's start there.

The fried chicken was probably the best I've ever tasted - moist (and I really hate that word) and crispy at the same time without that KFC greasiness. This was REAL fried chicken.

The green bean casserole also stole the show. Wouldn't advise it if you have high blood pressure, but this cheesy goodness made my night.

Onto the mediocre...

I had heard amazing things about the mac and cheese, but I was a little disappointed in how bland this dish was - the pasta also seemed slightly overcooked. And there was the cornbread. Girl, please. Cornbread is supposed to be warm, buttery, dense, with that mix of sweet and salty  that makes me want to eat until I can use my stomach as a plate. This cornbread was cold and airy. Not really sweet or salty, just eh.

Overall, the atmosphere is really fun and the service is great - you really do feel like you're sitting in a rocking chair in the deep south waiting for grandma's okra.
author: Genevieve W.

description:
*On our quest to try 52 new places in 52 weeks.* 

We had been chatting about coming here since we were in law school (eek!) and  finally made the "N-Judah-to the J-Church-walk a few blocks" trek out to Bernal Flats.  We treated it like a holiday dinner  and went out with our favorite married couple. Everyone ordered a round of drinks and then had the Bacon Wrapped Fried Dates as an appetizers. HOLY. SHIT. These things were incredible. They had some sort of balsamic-port reduction that I want to drizzle on every single thing I ever eat again. We then ordered the bucket of fried chicken (when in Rome...) and some sides. The chicken lived up to our expectations- it was delicious. $29 for a bucket of 10 pieces- if I lived near here I would come by all the time for this. We finished the night with some dessert and more drinks and were completely satiated. Had we not ordered drinks, our bill would have been dirt cheap for the four of us. Between the cheap eats, campy decor, and drink options aplenty, I'm sure we'll be back.
author: Melissa N.

description:
Gotta have the crab grits!!! What a combo. I've been here twice ( in the same week) and passed on the chicken only because chicken can only be fried so many ways...and I'm sure at 32 I've tasted it. The cornbread appetizer with the seasoned butter is also a winner. I'm gonna do my best to try a new dish on my next visit.
Let me not forget to mention the great service by the entire staff. I heard the wait for a table can be on lengthy side so get here right before everyone else.
author: Wild Style G.

description:
Man!  I'm a big fan of this place!  Granted I've only been here once, but that was enough to make me a fan.  I here there is always a wait when coming here without reservations.  Luckily I came here during a Giants playoff game, so the place was half empty.

I started off with a half order of the spicy shrimp and grits.  I love the shrimp and grits.  Tasty!  I've had the shrimp and grits at Brenda's, and while it was good, it was really greasy.  Then I had the fried chicken with garlic mashers and gravy with collard greens.  I mean, if you're going to a restaurant for the first time, you should get what they are known for.  I have to say, the chicken definitely didn't disappoint.  The garlic mashers was good.  The collard greens were a bit bland for me.  I like them a little more salty.  We also ordered the mac and cheese.  I did like them, but they didn't seem too special to me.  My wife had the N.Y. steak and fries, and she was kind enough to give me a little taste.  The steak was tasty.  Don't get me wrong.  If I'm looking for steak, I would probably go somewhere else, but it was good.  The sweet potato fries with chili aioli was great!  I especially loved the aioli.

If you're looking for soul food, I would definitely give this place a shot.  There are a lot of items to choose from on the menu.  I wanted to try more, but it was just too much food.  I'll definitely be back for more.
author: Jesus R.

description: Took myself out for my birthday and couldn't have been happier. Great, great fried chicken -- some of the best I've ever had -- and I've tried it all over the country. Great service, great drinks, great sides. I can't say enough good things about the place. I'll definitely be back.
author: Dave S.

description:
This place is three stars plus four for the company and ambiance and ease. 

Food: upscale soul food - had the burger and the pickles, Ty had the shrimps and grits which I normally do not like and it was DAMN addictive!!! Tricked his girlfriend into ordering a second round of it.

Drinks: nice wines and beers and ginger beer for those who are abstaining. They were awesome to bring out wine samples so I could choose a killer Zin with my burger. Friend had a yummer fried chicken. Not the best fried chicken I've ever had but good.

Ambiance: it's simple inside, navigable, small and intimate, and AH SAY GODDAMN....they were playing Joy Division. Why don't you just make a perfection sauce and drizzle it all over my naked body?  There is a bar inside that I feel like I could easily belly up to.

Service: Did I already tell you about the wine samples? Everyone here is cool and nonpretentious and they strike my fave balance - attentive yet unobtrusive. 

Front porch is not a destination but definitely head there with one or two close friends for a damn great meal.
author: Andrea S.

description:
Had been wanting to go here for a while after finding it while searching for a nice restaurant to go to for my husband and my anniversary last year. Decided to make a group thing out of it and had 2 other couples come with us in August 2012. We were highly anticipating it because the menu looked really good and we love Cajun/Creole food. I also previously worked at a Creole restaurant for a year as a cook and fell in love with the cuisine.

We arrived and the place was tiny, which is ok but we had 2 babies with us so it was a little awkward on placing the strollers and our seats without being in the way. Also one of the couples was a bit late, and so when they did show up the server seemed to be rushing us a bit to order. We ordered the Oysters Rockefeller, Hushpuppies and Fried Pickles. The Hushpuppies were good but I did not taste the supposed pork that was in it. They make their own BBQ sauce so that was cool but I didn't really care for it. The sauce that came with the pickles was awesome and who doesn't like Fried Pickles? :) I didn't have the Oysters because I don't like them, I think everyone enjoyed them but it was not something memorable. 

I also ordered a bowl of the Gumbo and I really did not like it, it was bland...just lacking flavor. 3 of us shared a bucket of Fried Chicken, which was fantastic, really moist and good flavor. The potatoes were good too but the collard greens were not so good, it seemed like they weren't seasoned or whatever they were seasoned with did not compliment it's flavor. One ordered the Shrimp and Grits dish and said it was really good and the other 2 ordered the Holy Shit Burger which they thought was AWESOME! 

Me and one other person finished with Bread pudding, that was good but again not really memorable. 

What we do remember however, is that one ordered coffee and the cream they brought with the coffee was lumpy and curdled...It is pretty normal for restaurants to pre pour cream into whatever they serve it to the table the day of service so that it is ready to go and saves time, but because this one was bad and there was a ring around the inside of the container, it told us that this cream had been sitting in the container for QUITE SOME TIME and no one was checking them to make sure if they were still good before serving to customers. That pretty much ruined the experience right there. It made me think if they don't check the cream for their coffee, what else is sitting in their fridge/walk in that goes unchecked and for how long, etc.

I wouldn't come back, and I don't think I'd recommend it to anyone either.
author: M H.

description:
Juicy but not super flavorful fried chicken. 
Tasteless Okra

In the on-going quest for awesome fried chicken in the City, I was advised by several sources that Front Porch was IT- great southern fried food, especially fried chicken. 

My verdict: It was pretty good, but definitely Not Great. 

- Fried Okra: tasteless batter, gummy okra. Pasty, absolutely tasteless aioli. waste of stomach space. Don't waste time or money on this dish. Disgusting 
- Bucketful of Fried Chicken (requested dark meat only. $6 extra): The chicken was juicy, but the batter was a little soggy and frankly, not that tasty. The chicken itself was pretty good, but I really wanted the skin/ batter to be much tastier and it just wasn't. 
- Mashed potatoes: Yummy 
- Collard Greens: Yummy

We made reservations for 7p and were seated around 7.45p; they (very nicely) offered free Glogg for us at the bar

Not sure I'd venture all the way back here again. The (seasonal) fried chicken @ Firefly was WAY better and even Townhall's sometimes too-salty-and-not-flexible-on-dark-meat-only-fried chicken was better. 
I was disappointed.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Overall a good experience. I went there for lunch and we got a nice sunny spot outside with some rocking chairs :)

I got the blue crab fritter Benedict dish. My boyfriend got the sweet potato waffles....O to the M to the G...those waffles were GOOD. My dish was tasty but those waffles were what really stuck in my mind. Order them!

We also tried the biscuits and gravy. Good, but I could have done with a little less gravy personally.
author: Shirin M.

description:
Was all excited based on all the yelp reviews. The place seemed interesting and the menu looked promising. Ordered the fried chicken as it seemed best to start with their specialty. Asked the waitress (cute!) if we needed sides. She said no but that the chicken takes 25 mins so we ordered the butter lettuce salad with deep fried bacon. Sounded great.

The salad arrives and it's yummy. We're thinking this starting well. but then...the chicken arrived. It looked delicious but sadly it was about the blandest chicken I've ever had. It tasted like they had just taken plain chicken, rolled in flour and deep fried it. Nothing else what so ever. Even salt would have made it better but I would have expected something more too it.

We finished, left and only then confirmed with each other that we had both had the same bland chicken. Did we miss something? Was it an off night? I probably won't go back but maybe when I just can't think of anything else I'll give it another try. This time I won't order the chicken though.
author: Gregg T.

description:
Chicken so good makes me wanna slap yo mamma!  Ok maybe not that good but it was pretty friggin fantasmic.  Seasoned and fried to crispy golden brown perfection, yet still moist on the inside, one bite and you'll definitely be hooked.  The funny thing is that I usually don't care for fried chicken. 
  We also ordered the fried catfish which was served with slaw, sweet potato fries, and hush puppies.  The catfish turned out pretty nice but was a bit on the bland side.  The sides were a bit of a disappointment :(
author: Phil Y.

description:
Front Porch + Groupon=  Must try.
My GF procured the Groupon for this resto a while back, so of course we were going to try it.

We arrived right when they opened so we pretty much chose our own seats in one of the maybe 5 booths. Kinda cramped, but enough space. The decor was interesting, kinda dark, but not too bad. A lot of window shutters on the wall. Knick knacks and trinkets as well. We sat under a silverwear chandelier. If they were trying to capture that "down south" look, I think they pulled it off. Overall it felt clean which was good. The bar is along the left side of the dining room, and kitchen along the left side of the back dining room area. Didn't get too noisey at all.

The food. We ordered the mac and cheese of course based off the raving on here, which I must say... was very much worth it! So good and creamy. Piping hot out of the oven. The melted cheese on top was perfect and light, but had the stringy quality that we all loved as kids. Perfect flavor and the consistancy of the mac was perfect. Not too hard, not soppy soft. Add a dash of their home made hot sauce to spice it up. So good. I ordered the pork chop, and damn! It was way bigger than I thought it would be! I was nervous about it maybe being too dry, but it was just right. Not chalky dry at all. Really juicy, loads of flavor, and the potatoes it came with and greens, made it PERFECT. I don't eat pork chops a lot at all, but this re-ignited my tastebuds from being in pork chop hibernation all this time. Again, I used the home made hot sauces and it just enhanced the already flavor it had. Trust me, by the time i was finished with it, I was STUFFED! My girlfriend ordered the three piece fried chicken entree. I forgot what it came with but that too was really good. Personally I don't like to eat too many things fried, but the chicken wasn't greasy at all. Almost like a broaster style but with way more flavor. The chicken was a liiiitle dry, but it wasn't bad at all. The spices made up for that so much. Very good and tastey.

Price was kind of steep for the things we ordered. I think it came out to be around $60 for the three things we ordered, but to me it was worth it. How often do we eat southern food really? 

Would we come back? Maybe. After some debate, my GF would come back for the Mac and Cheese alone, I would also, but I wouldn't mind trying something else on the menu as well.
author: Jay V.

description:
We arrived at The Front Porch after going to two other restaurants that were on the verge of closing for the day. The front of the restaurant looks like a "front Porch" and inside looks just as a cozy. 

We got seated and we ordered:

cornbread - looks like madeline and a bit on the dry side

mac & cheese - just your regular mac&cheese 

Blackened Catfish w/ sweet potato fries, hush puppies - the size of the fish was a bit smaller then I expected, the fries were a bit soggy, and the hush puppies were ok. 

Fried chicken w/ collard greens and mashed potatoes - pretty good 

this place is okay but I dont know if I would come back here again. However, the waitresses are super nice and the service was good.
author: Sophie S.

description:
Pull up a rockin' chair, and tell Aunt Dee to retire her skillet. She has cooked her whole life, and now she can enjoy the fruits of other people's labors. 

I'm a soul food girl to the core, and I have the hips and thighs to prove it, but it is a nice alternative to see american corner stone food given a kick and a twist. Last night, I had the Fried Chicken (which is "Friend" minus the "N") which was oh-so-nice...a little lemon flavor helped cut the grease; my leftovers were even crispy when I inhaled them for lunch today...when does THAT happen with Friend Chicken? I dabbled a couple people's plates, and can raise my hand high and Yelp a Hallaleujah for the Hush Puppies, Pickle Jar, Mac n' Cheese, Roast of the Day and a very special Amen for the Brussel Sprouts (which had capers...mmmm).

Desserts, while more French than Creole, were on point - Creme Brulee...I will always order you as you have yet to betray me; Apple Tartlette - oh carmel sauce, please be my secret lover. **WARNING** The Red Velvet Cake is no longer on the menu. So. Sad.

All the drinks were great, and I love that the bartender made them and delivered them...it was a nice touch...felt more personal. 

The place has a great vibe, and is a nice spot to start or end your night.
author: Chia C.

description:
We went to The Front Porch tonight to celebrate my friends birthday. I know she loves southern cuisine, and I wanted a place that produced good, flavorful dishes. TFP delivered in this department. 3 of our group split a bucket, a dish of greens, biscuits and gravy, hamhock collards, beans and rice with andouille sausage. our other two members tried the hamburgers. While I didn't taste the burgers, the chicken was amazing - fresh, flavorful, and juicy, without being in the least greasy. The collard greens were the best I have every eaten, not cooked into mush. We ate outside and were perfectly comfortable with the heat lamps. 
The best part was that they provided friendly polite service even when we asked to change tables and actually got more comfortable seating outside. Food was prompt and service was good without being intrusive. 
Altogether I was very happy with my experience here and would recommend them to others.
author: Lisa B.

description:
They've replaced their "Shrimp n Grits" with "Crab n Grits" and holy cow, do you get a ton of crab!  The plate arrived with a massive dungeness crab atop a generous plate of grits with gravy.  Sweet and delicious.  And even when totally full I could smell the fried chicken at the next table and wanted a piece (it's that good).

And now with a full bar, might go back tonight.
author: Mike I.

description:
Oh, it pains me to write this.
The food used to be soooooo good here.  Then, I guess they switched chefs and the food took a HUGE dive.  

The Shrimp and Grits, which used to be my favorite, went from being light and delicate and spicy, to heavy and salty and just nasty.

The Brussels Sprouts, which used to be awesome, and now greasy and mushy and foul.  

They have added more deep fried things to the menu... but they all taste the same... 

The only thing that doesn't suck now is the fried chicken dinner, but that's not enough to get me to come back.

I'm sad Front Porch... I used to be your biggest fan, but you really let me down.
author: Liz A.

description:
My first experience was a forgettable one at The Front Porch, 5 years ago. Thankfully they've improved since then. 

Ordered: 

Mac N'Cheese: Unbelievably creamy.

Fried Okra: Crispy, crunchy, and fried to perfection.

Fried Green Tomato's: First time in my life I had this dish. The diced sour pickles on top of the fried tomato's didn't mesh well but I brushed them off w/ my fork. Sauce on the plate was yummy too.

Fried Chicken and Waffles: My first time eating this dish as well. Waffles weren't crunchy, they were soft. But I think the fried goodness of the chicken more than made up for it.

Complimentary Cornbread w/ Strawberry butter: Delish.

Unfortunately we didn't have room for the Cherry Cola Pie. It sounded interesting enough, and I'll go back to try it. 

In the battle for Southern Comfort food The Front Porch beats out The Elite Cafe, Town Hall, and Farmerbrown's. Best days to go Mon-Wed. Otherwise there's a long wait. You have to write your name down when you show up; they don't take reservations.
author: Maria A.

description: Food and service was excellent, as well as the drinks. I had the Spicy Crab and Grits which was great. The atmosphere is laid back and has a bit of "dive" bar feel in a good way.
author: Matt F.

description:
Cute, quaint, hipsterville. Good for dates and a small group of friends. 

From the outside, the place looks like a regular front porch with an open door. When you walk in, the place turns into a small dive bar in the Mission. Bar is right next to the door and it's pretty small and very dim inside. We sat at the area of tables in the back that were surrounded by blue leather van seats. Cool touch. 

The freebie madeline cornbread to start off was to die for. A spicey butter spread complimented it very well. I ordered the chicken fried steak and mash potatoes...and what? I get to order beer from tap, too? (point!) The chicken fried steak had a apple pie/cinnamon-y after taste, which I thought was freakin' AWESOME. Although, the quail looked delectable, the chicken fried steak will be my "default" here just for that after taste. 

The portions were just right. We skipped dessert and walked across the street to Mitchell's for ice-cream. 

Overall, winner!
author: Kat M.

description:
In the Outer Mission, down a sketchy side street next to a large dumpster, resides a delightful (and belated) culinary find: I've lived in SF for over eight years, and have never heard of Front Porch. Glad I have now.

The ambiance? I'd describe it as the sort of place the modern, stylish, yet slightly rag-tag cast of "Rent" would hang out: Funky, dark, eclectic, and resolutely welcoming to one and all. Our waitress didn't put on airs. 

Neither did the menu. It doesn't feature soul food of the southern "grits 'n hush puppies" variety, but rather, funky, Caribbean-accented comfort food to nourish the soul. 

My two friends and I were prompted to order the oft-praised cod fritters as an appetizer. As promised, one order wasn't enough for three people, so we'd gotten two. They were good, although not as orgasmic as some reviewers would lead you to believe; the accompanying sauce was deemed too salty by my tablemates. 

For an entree, I ordered the again-oft-praised Miss Ollie's fried chicken plate, which came with black eyed peas with ham hocks, and mac n' cheese. Not a disappointment, exactly, since it all tasted good enough; But not transcendent, either. The chicken wasn't particularly hot when it arrived, the batter was a little too crispy for my liking, and the meat was a little on the dry side. The mac n' cheese was also kind of cold and a little rubbery. Still, it all tasted good, and the sheer warm-and-fuzzy nature of what I was eating made up for a lack of refinement. 

My two friends both ordered the same main course, which may have been the crab n' grits. They liked it well enough. 

Because restaurants with this much soul are a rarity, even in food-packed San Francisco, I do recommend Front Porch for a casual meal with friends.
author: Suzie Q.

description: I went here for brunch with 3 other people on a Saturday for brunch. Out of the 4 of us, 2 of us really enjoyed our dishes while the other 2 did not. The chicken and waffles (a friend ordered this) looked and I was told were amazing! The stoner stack which my gf had was also right in the money, bacon cheddar friend chicken on a biscuit. I ordered the sweet potato and pulled pork hash which unfortunately was more of a bell pepper and onion salad with about 3 pieces of pork. Unfortunately I was pretty disappointed with this particular selection as I was expecting a decent amount of pork and for it to be chopped up a bit more like a real hash. My other friend ordered the grits and they just went a bit too hard on the butter. Not sure if it was the brunch rush, but we put in some side orders and they forgot to put them in 2x along with one of my friends pieces of chicken being dropped. To their credit they got us another piece and gave us a discount on his order. The cocktails were all very well done. Overall it's a good place but they could definitely use some tightening up on the service and a few of the dishes
author: Cavendish C.

description: Meh. Fun to sit outside on rocking chairs on the front porch and the fried chicken's good (not good enough to warrant a trip just to eat here though) but rest of the food we had was quite unmemorable. I would have the fried pickles again but not the frito lay chilli. The mashed potatoes were quite tasteless and the mustard greens were slightly bitter -- both came with the chicken.
author: Audrey T.

description:
Crazy good southern food 4 blocks from my house?  There is no better news for a Virginia boy living in SF.

Front Porch rocks.  You sit on old car seats, listen to whatever music the bartender happens to play (everything from jazz to indie rock), sip on some beer and enjoy fried chicken, collards and mashed potatoes.  It's like visiting your drunk uncle's house while your sweet aunt feeds you the best soul food of your life.

I highly recommend the fried okra as an appetizer.  SO good.  The only thing that would make this place better is a full bar (so I can have mint juleps).
author: Tim C.

description: What a great spot for breakfast!  Service was friendly and attentive.  The beignets are fresh, hot and light.  I ordered the chicken and waffles...it was good, not great.  The coating on the chicken was flavorful, but the bacon waffle was a little disappointing (flat).  My friend ordered The Stack w/ side of cheesy grits.  OUTSTANDING!!!  A fresh homemade biscuit split and topped with sausage gravy, boneless fried chicken, cheese, bacon and a fried egg.  Breakfast heaven on a plate!
author: Lod K.

description:
I have to say I was let down.  I was expecting a lot more from the peeps that brought us Emmys.

I LUV southern food, I mean I got a semi just thinking about deep fried pickles (does that make me gay?), fried chicken livers, gumbo, and deep fried gumbo (I made that up).

But the food at the Front Porch was not up to my standards.  We shared the fried chicken (with grits and mashed potatoes), chicken gumbo, and a side of mac-n-cheese.  Nothing was really great.  I mean everything was edible but nothing I would serve guests.

If you're looking for a southern food fix in the area try Baby Blues BBQ just up the street on Mission.
author: Jason S.

description:
I've always heard about this place from my coworker that lives near by.  So I went there with a few friends to try it.  That popcorn bucket fried chicken is one of the best I tasted.
