We had that, the grits and spicy prawns, that was really good too.  The gumbo was good, not outstanding, but we wanted to try it any way.  We also had the fried ocra, which to me a an acquired taste.  
Service in that place was great!  
You have to go there and go across the street to Mitchell's Ice Cream for desert.
author: Peter L.

description:
Ambiance? Check

Food? Check

Eclectic Decorations? Check

This place has so much personality in its presentation, its food, staff, everything. I love the bar, the silver ceiling, the overstuffed booths, the rocking chairs outside, everything. The southern comfort food is the best part - served piping hot and inexpensive!

Four girls consumed:

Bucket of fried chicken with garlic mashed potatoes and collared greens - the chicken was so moist, the mashed potatoes were creamy and delicious, and the collared greens a welcome healthy contrast to all the other creaminess.

Plate of pickles - super tangy, not for the faint of heart!

Burger and fries - Didn't try the burger, but the fries were crispy on the outside and perfectly seasoned

Pork and beans - Perfectly junky with giant beans and thick pieces of fatty pork belly

Spicy grits - I didn't try this, but my meal companions loved it

Fried okra - So good! Lightly deep fried, not oily, and firm okra inside

Such a great place, can't wait to come back
author: Katherine P.

description:
Charming ambience - obviously they tried to make it Southern but the hipster wait staff and bustling urban vibe give away the restaurant's San Francisco location. 

The fried okra was slimey, and the catfish was bland (though covered in a lovely crunchy, cornbready fried batter). I think my favorite dish of the evening was the gumbo we ordered as an appetizer - meaty and thick, with just the right amount of salt. 

All in all, a positive experience with friends, but nothing worth writing home about.
author: Jen L.

description: Slightly expensive but very good. I recommend the fried okra, tri tips, the shrimp and grits and the mac and cheese.  Servers were friendly.  Limited seating so make a reservation with opentable.
author: Adam B.

description: Fucket get a bucket was exactly what I did. The fried chicken was done perfectly and arrived hot, fresh and juicy. Also got a shrimp po boy which wasn't that great, mostly bread and too little shrimp. Came here for lunch and will probably go back during dinner so I can try out the garlic mash potatoes, which is a dinner item only.
author: Tony Y.

description:
Ok, so I'll admit, I barely have any experience eating Southern food and I could definitely tell that this was a San Francisco spin on Southern, but either way I loved Front Porch.

I love the atmosphere, super chill, they give you the appetizer menu, which is taped to a tin box of dominos and a bottle of water that looks like a recycled 40 bottle.

Complimentary cornbread was disappointing, very small and did not have a very good texture.

We started off with the fried okra, hush puppies and a salad ("yard clippings", I love the name). The fried okra was served with a jalapeno aioli and it was delicious (better than the fried okra at Farmer Brown). The hush puppies were really good, but I had never had them before so nothing to compare them to. The yard clippings salad had some sort of prune dressing, which was really weird, not really a fan of that.

For the main course, I ordered the vegan special of the day and it was freaking delicious! I don't even remember what all the vegetables were in it, but it was absolutely delicious and had a ton of flavor! My friend ordered the pork chops, which I did not try, but the cornbread stuffing that it was served with was good. The macaroni and cheese was awesome! (I loved how the edges were crispy)

For dessert we got the bread pudding, which was served with ice cream and caramel. It was not the best bread pudding I have ever tasted, but I love desserts and enjoyed it very much!

Overall great restaurant & I want to go back and try the fried chicken!
author: Elaine S.

description:
Do you LOVE fried chicken, or spicy shrimp with grits? How about ordering a 24oz Tecate with dinner? Do you dig the Mission hipster vibe, but still consider yourself a foody with a delicate pallet? If so, then this is the place for you.

My girlfriend Stina raaaves about this place all the time. She calls it comfort food with a hefty price tag, and that's for sure. When my ex called to take me out to dinner, you know I was all about it. He suggested FP, I enthusiastically agreed.

We shared the fries (nothing special) and the cornbread (also unspecial). I had the shrimp and grits (soooooo good, sooo heavy), and he had the famous fried chicken, which he claimed tasted better in the past. I liked that it didn't really taste like "fried chicken" and actually had nice lemon taste.

We were too full for dessert...so the portions are good for the price.
author: Misha F.

description:
Yum! Went here on a Sunday night around 8:30 and had our choice of seating. One of the best salads ever with persimmon, squash, pommegranates, and candied walnuts. We were hungry but we literally INHALED the salad it was so fresh, flavorful and crispy.

Fried chicken is hearty, pork chop was also pretty tasty. I loved the sides (mashed potatoes, collards, stuffing) as much as the mains. Oh, and there IS a vegan plate so you can bring the entire family!

Really good stouts, had the cream ale stout that was really smooth and cut through the flavors. And I gotta shout out for their home made hot sauce! Next time I am there I am going to ask if I can buy a bottle to take home it is so incredibly good.

Major fan, and with my new move this is now walking distance so I am officially done for.
author: Allegra F.

description:
Ok. First I will review a DINNER here. Easily four stars, really cute. 

Setting: Super cute, quaint, theoretically a great idea. I always seem to sit in the round booth at the front, no matter how many people I'm with. The ladies room is pretty.

Service: One time I had a really nervous female server, otherwise easy going and casual.

Food: Highly recommend the Spicy Shrimp and Grits-sauteed shrimp, bacon, mushrooms and garlic over grits. $11 or 18 you can't go wrong with this one.
Roasted Beet Salad-typical salad with arugula, candied walnuts and goat cheese. $8, though there was no goat cheese when it arrived so we awkwardly had to ask for it.
Vegan Plate-super cute! Can't remember what was in it, but it looked like there was a flower growing out of it. $17 A little expensive for what it was.
_________________________________________________________

Then there was BRUNCH. Honestly, I think it will get better with more practice and time, but for now it was a small disaster. Sadly, two stars.

Setting: Once again, I sat at the round booth, only this time it was super dark, the lighting was really off. I was blinded by the open door and bright outside, and my eyes had a hard time adjusting at my friends in the booth.

Service:  I had a bend-over-backwards sweet guy, who also is the bartender.

Food: A sorry brunch. The menu isn't online so i have no reference for what we ate. We were so excited about it too.

We ate a sort of mish mash of eggs, goat cheese, spinach and "bacon crack" (which takes extra long to cook) It all sounded good, and was tasty, but in the end i felt a little cheated and dissatisfied.

My friend ordered the Eggs Benedict, she said it wasn't very good and barely touched it. She also ordered cheese and grits which was very plain.

Beignets-best part of the meal.

Bloody Marys- they were Soju cocktails, aka no liquor license, a disappointment.

We got average potatoes for the table, and this is where serious disaster struck. The kind server was explaining the different hot sauces. In his words, "Hot, Really Hot, and Super Fucking Really Hot." Feeling frisky and daring we decided to try the latter. My friend slightly shook it up and when she opened it, the ghost pepper hot sauce exploded like beer that's been on Seabiscuit's back. It shot all over her lap, the table, the booth, etc. First it was so shocking that we started laughing...and then the fumes wafted up towards our eyes and nose and a cacophony of gags, burps, sweat and tears broke lose at our table. Not so funny. But still funny, kind of.
Our super sweet server immediately picked up on this and gave us a free cocktail to share amongst the table.

Better luck next time, make sure to grab the candy bracelets and  cool matches on the way out.
author: ariana t.

description:
This is such a cozy and fun place that I didn't really expect the food to be anything special.  I was wrong!  The food was fabulous.  We had fried chicken and collard greens that were the best I've ever had.  
Wish I lived in San Francisco...I'd be visiting often!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Me and my boyfriend finally used our gift certificate from our birthdays and ate dinner here. Lagged 3 months but oh well. We went at 6 to beat the dinner crowd and got seated right away. Didn't know they had happy hour so it was great to find out that our appetizers were like $5 each. We ordered deep fried okra, oysters and hush puppies and for our entrees I had the spicy shrimp and grits and he had the chicken fried steak and to wash it all down sweet tea. Yummy! The food was so good!!!! The shrimp and grits had mushrooms and bacon which were so yummy I swear I wanted to order another plate but was so full from everything else we ordered. LOL! 

I read good reviews about the chicken so next time we go I will order that.

Good service and great food. 

Can't wait to go back.

Minus one star for parking.
author: Vanessa C.

description: I am giving this place another star.  I tried it again.  This time the drinks were tasty.  The fried pickles were excellent, and the veggie dish was much more flavorful.  I am still not super excited about the Front Porch, but they did a good enough job that I will probably give them another chance.
author: Tia B.

description:
So a month after going to the Front Porch, I still find myself talking about how great the fried chicken is.  It's awesome.  Best. Fried. Chicken. Ever.

The rest of the food we had was ok, not the best I've had.  We tried the okra (good), gumbo (good), the fish of the day (questionable), and the porkchop (overcooked).  

But to end on a high note, our waitress was really nice and I had a great time.  And I'm glad we made reservations, cuz it was hopping on a cold Wednesday night.
author: Yeeman N.

description: I had never eaten at this place before but was invited to have dinner with two friends.  The ambiance was cool but the food.. the food was awesome ESPECIALLY the fried chicken! Seriously, I've been thinking about their fried chicken ever since that dinner and am now spreading the word to people I know (although that may only add to the congestion and cramped seating situation.  I only gave this place 4 stats because the it is a little tight with seating but hey, this is San Francisco!
author: SF M.

description: This place is always awesome, I have been here a few times for brunch and dinner.  Just recently went and had the crab fritters... amazing!  The fried chicken and the mission chiliechiles ( how ever its spelled--brunch item) are a must.  The cocktails are great too, we had hot kick ass margarita (actually part of the name! lol) with jalapenos in it.
author: Loretta M.

description:
This place is trendy and that's all it is, TRENDY. This restaurant was on my list of restaurants to try and luckily I found a Bloomspot voucher. The boyfriend and I made reservations for a Friday night. 

Parking: Make sure to arrive at least 30 minutes earlier because parking is a real bitch out there. If you do arrive early, the bar across the street has a very decent selection. Cash Only. 

Dinner:

Bacon wrapped fried dates- The reduction was too sweet for my taste and the amount of cheese ended up overpowering the entire dish. In a bacon dish, it would be nice to taste more bacon, since it's awesome.

Pulled pork sliders- These three little sandwiches were the perfect size. It's pretty hard to mess up pulled pork. These are decent.

Single order of Fried Chicken- The presentation for this was very cute. The mash potatoes are definitely the highlight of the plate. The chicken was nice and crispy on the outside, but lacked a lot of flavor. It was just... fried chicken. 

Fried okra with jalapeno aioli- This came out super well done! I love crunchy things but as soon as I would take my first bite, the batter would crumble and fall apart on my plate. At the end of the day, you can't mess up fried okra that badly so this was decent as well.

Roasted brussel sprouts with apples and bacon- They cut the brussel sprouts in half for this dish. I personally can't fit the half into my mouth so I have to cut them up more. This dish tastes exactly as you would expect, so not much to say. We definitely ordered it for the health factor. :)

Baked mac & cheese-  I really believe KFCs mac and cheese tastes better. I thought maybe they would have a good blend of cheeses, but it's just plain ol' mac and cheese. Nothing special and I wish I didn't waste money on it.

Conclusion: They included an 18% gratuity on our bill, with a party of 2 people! You're better off spending your time and money at Farmer Browns or Hard Knox where you will find good tasting quality food. If you're looking for a night out at a trendy spot in a gentrified neighborhood, then this place is for you!
author: Lilimae S.

description:
I wanted it to be good. The staff was great and, as my dinner companion observed, the decor was "cute"--she said while sitting on a car bench seat. It was not to be. I've seen reviews that commented on changes in management/kitchen staff; maybe that explains it.

The spicy shrimp & grits was fine. No complexity at all to the sauce, which is to be expected if it's really spicy, but this wasn't. In this case, the grits basically served as a sauce delivery mechanism, which is a bit unfortunate: buttered grits are essential soul food, but I only got any flavor of that when I found an edge of the dish that the sauce had sloshed away from. The mushrooms and shrimp were cooked satisfactorily. Satisfactory... good word for this place. Also an apt description of the complimentary cornbread.

For our entrees we ordered the chicken fried steak (with corn and mashed potatoes/gravy) and the fried chicken (with green beans and mashed potatoes/gravy). To their credit, the presentations of the two dishes were reasonably distinctive and appropriate, even though the mash+protein+vegetable format was the same.

While I'm giving credit, the fried chicken was decent. As my companion put it, it was "suspiciously juicy"--surely brined, but I'm not prepared to call obvious brining a bad thing. There were some crust adhesion issues but the flavor was good, although I was turned off when I encountered some undercooking in a particularly thick piece.

The mashed potatoes and the gravy were fine. If half-stars were available, they'd get one for the complimentary bites that were brought to the table: blue cheese and, I believe, walnut, on crostini with microgreens. Downside: it was just a bite. We had some thoughts on that, too, but since it was tasty and reasonably well-done, I'll leave the nitpicks aside.

The chicken fried steak, on the other hand, was a mess. First of all: no reasonable interpretation of the dish can involve a too-thick, too-tough cut of meat. The whole point of the thing is to pound the crap out of such a tough cut and then cook it until fork-tender. I needed my steak knife.

But even if you imagine that to be a quirk of interpretation, the breading situation was so bad that I couldn't help but joke that they'd come up with a deconstructed chicken fried steak, with the breading served on the side. It might have even been plausible had the whole thing not been hidden underneath a mess of average gravy. I honestly thought there was twice as much steak as there ended up being, just because of the amount of breading spread over the plate like shrapnel. There was one place where it wasn't to be found, though: on the meat.

So, I've got to give it a star for ambiance and a star for service, but I can get equal or better food at too many places to give real credit on that front. Maybe it was an off night; I'm not planning to increase my sample size, though.
author: Mike M.

description:
So Valentines, my Valentine....
Went here on Valentines and it was golden...
The appetisers came out really fast (we had the picked salad stuff) and was given a shot of the soup of the day (asparagus and BEAUT) and some corn bread.
Took a long time for the mains to come, but it was Valentines
The bar tender was really helpful and the home made Mulled Wine was gold.
Oh and HUGE news for Aussies.... They have BUNDABERG GINGER BEER! This alone is worth going to The Front Porch...
We had the Lamb, small but cooked to perfection.

So all in all, food was impressive
The decor was golden
The staff were warm and friendly....

All in all Golden

PS You CAN book now.... and it is best to book
author: Nathan H.

description: Went to Front Porch based on Yelp reviews.  It was great to be able to make reservations, seated right away on a Friday night.  However, our meal was just ok.  We ordered the mac & cheese and fried chicken.  Nothing really blew us away....
author: Jennifer B.

description: This time I came back for brunch. BFF ordered the Fried catfish Po'boy sandwich with fries. I ordered the hang town fry: fried oyster, bacon, scallion omelette on ciabatta bread. I loved the fried oyster because it added something different to the omelette. The catfish on the sandwich was very flavorful and I loved the fries! I will definitely be back again to try more items. Love.
author: Mel P.

description: It was a nice warm sunny day and going into the restaurant it was pretty dark.  Maybe they were trying to conserve energy since it was still pretty bright outside for 6PM?  The waitress was very nice.  Started off with comp cornbread that came with a chili honey butter.  We indulged ourselves with lots of fried goodies...hush puppies, fried okra (cut in half) and fried pickles.  The fried chicken was nice and crispy on the outside but the meat was still moist and juicy.  They had such a small serving of mash and collard greens that came with the 9pc bucket.  The Mac&Cheese was delish.  The jambalaya was ok with lots of shrimp, chicken and sausage.  The only downer was that I requested/noted that the dinner was for a birthday and when we ordered dessert-beignets there was no HBD.
author: she q.

description:
teammate R. and I decided to check out this place, 2 hours ago.

a hip(ster) place, full of non-sloppy young people looking unruffled, casual, yet put-together on this cold and gray saturday afternoon. love the interior, pretty artwork and window panes/frames tacked on to the walls, comfortably dim lighting, the decor is unique without trying too hard. mentioning this because the feel of the place itself contributes to the dining experience, and so The Front Porch would be a cute place to bring out-of-towners and that man or lady you've been wanting to ask out.

started off with the beignets...delicious way to calm a rumbling tummy while waiting for the chicken and waffles (a 25-minute wait). The beignets were pillowy yet substantial, came out hot but not oily at all. mmmm. the sugar wasn't too much or too sweet, so it was not at all cloying and heavy and didn't make me feel fat before my main meal. thumbs up.

chicken and waffles has been my top craving these past few days, and i am now satisfied. chicken pieces were not as big as i was expecting them to be - but then again, i'm too much of a glutton for anyone's good - but the dish comes with three pieces, and so it does fill up a normal human being's appetite. hot and juicy on the inside, with crispy skin that stayed crisp even after i drench it all in syrup and hot sauce. DELISHUZZ. the waffle was okay, not the best i've had,  but i appreciated the natural sweetness of it (a hint of vanilla in the batter?) and it excellently soaked up my syrup+butter+hot sauce pool. DELISHUZZ.

R. had the country ham with red eye gravy, that came with two eggs whichever way you like them, and homefries. she finished up her food, so i take it that she enjoyed her meal as much as i did. had a couple of pieces of her potatoes, and they were just okay in my books.

the iced coffee was pretty weak in itself, but refills are free and it goes refreshingly well with the heavy meal. don't expect the robustness of that cup of blue bottle you usually get with your sweet morning pastry is all.

will come back again for other goodies and to relish in the interior of the place. must remember to look effortlessly hip the next time, instead of rolling in with eating pants and unplucked eyebrows.
author: Eliza D.

description:
I have been wanting to come here since I found out about it and I finally got a chance to last night.  It was one of my friends friend birthday so of course we got wasted, on a Monday night....We started off with a round of 24oz. King Cobras.  That's pretty awesome when a restaurant serves those.

We then moved on to Duvel which is a great Belgium beer and 7oz. Miller High-Life's.  

Brynn (spelling?) our waitress was amazing, she has a great sense of humor and kept the mood fun and I even convinced her to shotgun a High-life with us, I mean that is freakin awesome!! 

Food: they give you some cornbread with a spicy-butter spread which was amazing...we then ordered the Shrimp and Grits for an appetizer.  Grits were cooked to perfection with the gravy and the shrimp was superb.  We then had Fried Okra, God! what a creation, best thing ever.

As an entree I ordered the Shrimp Po'Boy which came on a roll with tomatoes and some slaw (unbelievable!)

I could go on and on about this place...I'll definitely be back!!
author: Dustin K.

description:
It makes me sorry to knock off all the stars from my original review but it must be done. 

Management at FP: I hope that you actually read this review and makes some changes.

Let me preface this by saying that I have been to FP about 5 times and loved each visit before last night.

First, since the chef has changed from the Barbados to the Lousianna style, the fried chicken is NOT AS GOOD. The textures are still perfect but there is no flavor in the batter or in the meat. It used to be salty spicy and delicious. Please consider changing the recipe or at least offering a more flavorful variation. The fried green tomatoes were very stiff, not at the the tender and juicy flesh of a properly ripe and cooked green tomato.

And the service, dear lord, the service... It has gone way down hill. I know that there are off nights, but I have noticed a slow, steady spiral downward in service here. Last night we were told 30-45 minutes, off by about 20 minutes more. There was no concern shown about our hunger or patience. No "thanks for waiting," or "Sorry about the extra wait." I have worked in restaurants and bars for years and find this unacceptable. But, I was hungry and hopeful, so I let it go. I had also raved about this place to my dining companions and wanted it to live up to its reputation.

The restaurant was not extra busy and yet we waited and waited and waited. We did not order drinks, appetizers or dessert and yet we sat there for 2 hours, only 30 minutes of which was actually eating. Again, there was no explanation for the long waits for our food, for our check, for our change. There was no apology, no effort to check in with us, nothing. 
At one point, our server brought by an amuse bouche (about 45 minutes after we had been waiting seated at the table) after the cornbread and with no explanation about why we were getting it. 

Despite our incredible patience, at the end of our meal there was no exit greeting, "Thank you for being patient" or "Thanks for coming in" or "I hope you enjoyed your meal." The service was sloppy, very sloppy, and confusing. I'm not sure there was a manager on site since everyone working there seemed to be sauntering around, chatting with themselves and other customers.

I am sad to say that the Southern hospitality I could count on that made the Front Porch stand out among its competitors is gone.
author: G Z.

description:
Luscious and moist chicken, until...I got some uncooked batter with my serving - plus it took 40 mins for us to get our food and it's pricey for what you get. All that means minus 2 stars.

Love the decor and ambience, and in it's favor there was pretty good service.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
It's been a while where I've been able to go to a restaurant and enjoy every dish that I ordered... this has broken that bad streak. I thought everything was scrumptious! :D

We had the Shrimp and Grits- Delish! I never had the chance to try the famous Crab and Grits.. but if its anything like the Shrimp one. I'd be a happy camper!

We had the bucket of chicken: Super crispy the way I like, if there was a downside.. it was perhaps the batter wasn't tasty enough... but I'd still order it next time

The Mac N Cheese-- comes out bubbling and oozing with butter.. so good. 

Don't come here on a diet.. :D 

Way better than Hard Knox. Not as great as Angeline's in Berkeley (for the chicken).. but I will come here for the grits.. OVER and OVER.. Good Job peeps!
author: Kristina L.

description:
We came here on Halloween! They sure know how to dress up the place what with its already-dim-dark-deep restaurant decor and Southern feel. The service was attentive. The food was yummy! The menu is on the gently-overpriced side but worth it if you're not strapped for cash. It's not enough for me to make the trip back though for a repeat meal but I wouldn't complain if a friend organized a meeting meal there. We ordered, as usual, WAY TOO MUCH! But it gave me a good feel for the food they served. 

They started off with a little cute cup of butternut squashy pumpkin soup. The soup was smooth and the veggies had a very savory flavor. It was very nice. And complimentary! I'm not sure if it was a Halloween treat or if they do this as a norm.

Then we got the cornbread. WOW! We loved it! I just wish we had more. The cornbread came in cute little long cookie-style packages. It wasn't your usual slice a square of cornbread thing. It was as if they baked the cornbread in those fancy metal cookie pans. Very cute! Very tasty! OH SO YUMMY! And it came with this savory butter sauce too!

We got the fried clam coleslaw roll. Not too bad. Too much bread and too little clam. But the clams that was there were full-bellied and crisp and delicious! The bread was good too. 

The baked mac and cheese was a crowd-pleaser! We LOVED! They piled on tons of high-quality cheese in a piping hot clay bowl. The waiter kindly warned us that the plate was HOT. AND IT WAS HOT! It was still steaming a good 10 minutes after. I like that the clay pot kept our mac toasty! VERY RICH though! Whew!

We got a bucket of fried chicken. Now, I love fried chicken like nobody's business but I have to say that their fried chicken wasn't what I expected. It had a lemony essence going on there in their chicken. I love lemon. I love fried chicken. I'm not 100% sure that I love them together. I'm more into the savory spicy thick glazy fried chicken stuff. The fried chicken at Farmer Brown, for instance, rocks my socks. It's different here though. Judging from others, it looks like the fried chicken here rocked their socks. So I guess it's a personal preference of how you like your chicken fried. If you're into lemon, you'll probably love this! Kudos to the chef for not OVER-frying it. It was crispy to perfection with just enough flavor from the oil to sink into the meat. They do know their technique! 

We had the collard greens and mashed potato with gravy. YUMMY YUMMY!  The desserts looked scrumptious but we couldn't order. Stuffed to the brim! Next time though if I find myself at The Front Porch again.  :)
author: Pamela L.

description:
This place is delicious. They get five stars mainly because they make the best Mac N Cheese I have ever tasted. I have tried, and failed, multiple times to replicate it. It is so creamy and cheesy, you know it can't be good for you.

The atmosphere is really unique, it's dark and kind of New Orleans during prohibition. Every time you look around, you'll notice something new. This would be a great fun date, or dinner with good friends. The staff is young and upbeat and very accommodating. 

Also, if it's your thing, try the mulled wine. It would be awesome on a colder night and the spices are just strong enough without being over powering.
author: Katrina G.

description: Amazing food and staff!  The fried chicken is the best ever, the Holy Sh@t burger is a God sent miracle to burger lovers......and the bacon covered dates were better than any other appetizer in this world!  The staff from the minute we walked in the door, was a friendly, helpful group.  The chef even came out and met with us!!  What a wonderful place to go when we come in town!!  Love it, Love it, Love it!!
author: Jennifer K.

description: This Place is Great! Yummy Fried Chicken Great Buiscut Sando I try to go on weekdays as on weekends tend to get a lil funkdified.... 4 stars up w a yummy cheese gits
author: Adrienne G.

description:
This has been on my to-try list forever! 15-minute wait on a Saturday night- not bad, I actually expected worse. 

The girls shared a bucket of fried chicken (with chicken-flavored popcorn) which came with a side of creamy mashed potatoes and crisp green beans. Yeah, $33 is steep for fried chicken (especially when Popeyes has 99¢ Tuesdays!) but this was the real deal. The chicken was sooo juicy, flavorful, and fingerlickin'good! The homemade sauce complemented the flavor nicely (though it can definitely hold its own).The bucket is probably good for 3 people if you're not big eaters. The boys had the roasted quail, and shrimp po'boy with sweet potato fries (sold out that night), which they both seemed to enjoy. 

The rocking chairs outside in the front (where we waited for our table) and the "car seats" we sat in during dinner were a nice touch! It gets kinda loud here so don't expect an intimate dinner. Overall, I had a jolly good time and I'll have to come back for happy hour.
author: Zell C.

description:
This was my first experience with soul food and when I first saw the menu I didn't really know what to order. Luckily I was with people who had been there before so I got to try a nice variety of dishes. 

First let me say, they have the best fried chicken I have ever had far!! The girts were also amazing!! We also tried their mac and cheese, fried okra, collard greens with bacon; all were very good. 

The place is very small and casual but everyone was very friendly and attentive. This is not a good place to over eat because the food is on the heavy side, but it's hard to stop eating that chicken. 

If your interested in trying soul food for the first time or you just love fried chicken this is the place for you!
author: Thomas A.

description:
The Front Porch has a cute, easy-going feel with a laid back staff.  My guy and I both ordered the fried chicken.  A single order is 3 pieces and the bucket (the price of two entrees) is 9 pieces.  We got two single orders since we both wanted separate sides; they claimed their would be an upcharge for doing so, but it wasn't on our bill.

The fried chicken is exactly what it should be but it wasn't my highlight.  That honor goes to their mac and cheese with HOMEMADE ketchup.  The "side" of mac and cheese is large enough to be a dinner on its own and comes bubblingly hot.  It is a must get.  

Love the fact they have sweet tea (although it is normal tea with simple syrup added to it rather than the sugar being boiled in.)  Also love they didn't rush us out at all - we had a very long (2+ hour) dinner and they refilled our ice teas and were super nice about it.

Corkage fee is $10.   Takes American Express.  $52 with tip for two people (with no booze.)

Highly recommended for dates; it has that hard to find mix of cute, quiet, and unpretentious that makes comfortable talking possible.
author: Dee B.

description:
So I broke my no pork rule for this place. Bad Jew!

We started with their complimentary corn bread and butter and some tasty cocktails. Then some steak fries with and their smoked paprika aioli. I love fries, but I don't like the thickness of steak cut, so that's my bad. Then Brussels sprouts. Yum, very tasty and brown buttery. For entrees we split the fried chicken and shrimp and grits. The shrimp and grits were amazing, a must have. The bacon (yes bacon!) and mushrooms worked perfectly in the yummy dish. The chicken was really good. It was moist and seasoned well, although I prefer Angeline's in Berkeley for excellent fried chicken. For dessert we shared the chocolate pecan chess pie and it was scrumptious. Overall a great meal.
author: Stacy R.

description: Yum yum YUM!!! The fried chicken is the main event but there are other stars here! The fried pickles were amazingly delicious. The gumbo had a nice taste. The mashed potatoes were fluffy and rich with the robust essence of garlic! Finish off the meal with the beignets which may be some of the best I have had outside of Nawlins! The coffee deserve mention as well. Get the bucket of chicken and call it a day...a real good day!!
author: Joaquin G.

description:
Appetizers.. 
The cornbread was good, but the spread is to die for!  The jalapeno hushpuppies were just okay, kinda boring.

Entrees.. 
Tender and nicely seasoned fried chicken (but pricey for fried chicken).  Spicy oxtail that falls off the bone!  

Small place, long wait.. even on a weekday.  Despite being so busy.. the service is still pretty good.

Would definitely be 4 Stars if i got more bang for my buck.
author: Ryan C.

description:
A fiver!  How long has it been?    

My Front Porch experience left little to be desired.  Our waitress was casual yet quick and knowledgeable, the happy hours tapas/appetizers ranged between good and amazing, and the decor and general atmosphere were, if a bit hip, quite comfortable and classy.  

Something to keep in mind is that this is not a soul food or southern restaurant as reviews led me to believe.  It's more southern-meets-world fusion.  Plantains reside next to okra resides next to aioli.  The pulled pork (I'm going to see how much pork I can eat this week!) was amazing, a combination of Mexican spicy and sour that I've never had anywhere else.  

If you're not looking for traditional preparations, but rather want to try something new, check it out.  Bring your special lady or your fuckin' lady friend though, not your good drinkin' buddy or a small child.  Because my drinking buddy will teach your small child to say all kinds of really inappropriate things.
author: Jared L.

description: We had, simply, a wonderful meal and wonderful service. It was. Monday evening, not too crowded, and everyone couldn't have been more attentive or helpful. My marguerita was great, and the appetizers were delicious: crab cakes, fried pickles with aioli, chickory salad. I had the vegan main course: corn bread (made with soy milk) with sauteed greens over a butternut squash puree, and my wife had the "hambrosia" which was grilled citrus and ham over salad greens. We also tried a side of rice, beans, and Andouille sausage (which is made locally and fresh each day). Everything was just bursting with flavor. For my vegan desert we had a trio of sorbets, and my wife had the oreo cookie cake with vanilla ice cream, all great. We will definitely be coming back next time we are in San Francisco.
author: Larry B.

description:
The Shrimp & Grits are amazing.  They're a must order.  It's probably the best dish on the menu.

The fried chicken, on the other hand, was really disappointing.  Totally flavorless and bland.  For a southern restaurant, I was really expecting better.  I've been on a fried chicken hunt the last 6-12 months, and have ordered it just about everywhere.  I recommend the fried chicken at Blue Plate (around the corner) or at Fish & Farm in the Tenderloin.
author: Tony F.

description:
I'm not completely sold on the new fried chicken craze.  Not that I don't like my fried chicken...I just think my neighborhood mom and pop's diner can do just as good and for twice as cheap. That goes with everything else on Front Porch's southern food menu.

That said, the food is rather tasty.  But if i'm going to pay fine dining prices for southern food, i'd rather check out Wexler's where there's a deliberate attempt that manipulating southern food in creative ways.
author: Allen L.

description: This place has amazing baked mac and cheese. the asparagus is very good too. I will have to go back sometime soon.
author: Carl N.

description:
They took the crab n grits off the menu.. Sorry that's a star right there.. please see previous review regarding the crab n grits

Your other stars will remain since the food was still delicious.. I had the gumbo, and mashed potatoes -- apparently these go reallly well together. Otherwise, the gumbo was a tad salty. I took a bite of burger as well. It came with a dipping sauce which also was necessary since the burger was also a little salty.  I'm slightly distraught over the crab n grits still.. 

but.. I was hiding under your porch because i love you.. :(
author: Donna H.

description:
The fried chicken was delicious.  The collard greens were really good.  The mashed potatoes were tasty, but really smooth, so if you like 'em kind of thick and chunky, the potatoes won't be that impressive.  

Why only three stars?  It has nothing to do with the mashed potatoes.  It has to do with the delicious chicken..the last of the four pieces of chicken was not cooked entirely through.  Now I totally understand there my be some pink, and I'm perfectly fine with that,  but there was some actual blood and lots of pink on this piece of chicken!  I brought this to the attention of the waitress, and she said that there would be some pink...then I showed the bone to her...she totally agreed with me and said that it shouldn't be that red and bloody.  

At least I knew I wasn't over reacting.  Well, that is until the chef said that it was supposed to be that way and that it was cooked thoroughly and I wouldn't get sick from that.  Okay.  I suppose all these years of eating fried chicken and not seeing any blood has been a coincidence.  

In any case, they were nice enough to offer a dessert or another round for me and my wife.  

We also had the blue crab fritters.  Yummy.  

I had a really hoppy cask IPA to drink.  Really good and it was a Front Porch brew.  Nice.

Super cute place.  Tucked away and hidden.  My wife and I really enjoyed our time there.  Would've been 4 or even a 5 star review, but that bloody chicken drops it.  If I get salmonella, this is going down to a zero star...
author: Chris S.

description: Service was awesome, fried chicken was great.  The mac in the mac and cheese was overcooked but still ok. The menu was sort of limited, specially if you want to skip the deep frying and the bacon, but I'll come back for the fried chicken at any time.
author: R X.

description:
Delicious fried chicken & fixins, or a great atmosphere to grab a drink. Dark, quiet, relaxed.

Skip the wine- and beer-based "mixed drinks"
author: Steve S.

description:
I grew up in the south, where fried chicken was a weekly dinner item and jambalaya recipe differences can cause fist-fights -- so I was very excited to try out FP with some friends on a Saturday night.

First impressions?

Score one for the crowd and drinks at this Bernal Heights joint.  It's hard to find a good restaurant scene when 9 o'clock rolls around in SF, but tucked away on 29th street is this lively gem.

Score another point for the sides.  A little on the small side for Southern standards, but the baked mac& cheese, fried okra, collared greens and corn 'bread' works.  I dare say, with the local ingredients here, it can give a bunch of places in Louisiana a run for the money.

Unfortunately, the main courses failed.  Popeye's has better fried chicken, which isn't saying much.  I miss good ol' Southern buttermilk fried chicken, where the meat sticks to the skin and all that flavor in the fat mixed with the spices makes your belly remember the meal for months.  The fried chicken here was ok, but not worth the $20.  The po boy was a 'wet' one -- perhaps it originated from a part of the South that I'm not used to. It was a good sandwich -- just not a New Orleans po boy.  It was more like stir fried shrimp slathered onto a loaf of bread.

My biggest pet peeve?  The gumbo.  I tasted salt.  I really wanted to like the gumbo, but this one lacked the subtlety of good (or even average) gumbo.  Not enough rice, no zing and some shriveled sausage medallions.  It was watery, and I don't know what the roux consisted of, but it sure wasn't anything I recognized.

The desserts were a saving grace -- but they can't really mess up root beer floats and bread pudding -- especially when they got your ice cream down the block from Mitchell's.

A definite missed opportunity for the Bay.  Want to pay something crazy for Southern food? Go to southwest.com.
author: Josh N.

description: ....Here I go again...if this place was in Oakland or on 3rd St it would be twice as good at half the price....the newly monied Chucky Cheese crowd think its heaven...
author: jim b.

description:
I love me some southern food, and Front Porch kills it. Last time I went in, every course was fried. yum. They also sport a decent beer selection. 
I'm a girl that loves to rock, so the wait out front with a beer in one hand and a rocker under my tush is nothin but good times. Love the ambiance, the food, and the friendliness. Doesn't hurt that it's close to the homestead either.
author: Brooke B.

description:
The service here can be hit or miss.  I've had great and really bad servers.  I think the worst thing is that they let a mariachi band come in and play a few songs during dinner.  This place is super small, usually packed, and it's already really loud, so when you add obnoxious music it can be impossible to have a conversation.  Plus the musicians hit you up for tips afterwards which is a really tacky thing for the restaurant to let them do.  I understand that the musicians are trying to make a living, but hey, the music doesn't match the atmosphere and I didn't ask for it.

The food here is ok.  I've been several times and it always seems to be over-salted.  It can also be on the greasy side--even for fried food.  On the other hand, there just aren't that many places to get fried okra in San Francisco, and I'm pretty much in love with fried okra, so I make it back every couple months for a hit.  They also do excellent jalapeño poppers, hush puppies, cornbread, and have a decent beer/wine list.  Overall, I would say that this is a place for a snack or happy hour, not dinner.
author: Steve B.

description: I am very glad we had a reservation for 6 and at an early hour 5:45pm. The service was attentive and non-distracted. We each ordered entrees as well as sharing a bucket of chicken and had a few sides. I had leftovers to say the least.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
I got the poppers which were amazing. The fried chicken is one of the best I've had. Tastes like the chicken was marinated before hand? So good!  The stuffed pork chop was also good. A little spicy. The drinks are superb as well. They take typical drinks you might has w liquor and make them w wine or beer but they are SO good. Service is also great. 
Had a reservation at 7, got there around 6:30 and sat down right away. By 7, the entire place was packed and this is on a Monday night. Def recommend reservation and an early one at that.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
Great southern comfort food.  We had the crab and grits, and the fried chicken.  We had the bacon wrapped dates and the gumbo as sides.  The dates were a bit too sweet for my taste, but the rest of the food was amazing.  Lots of flavor in all the dishes.

The staff was great too.  They were always checking on us, and we had a wonderful experience.
author: Jon S.

description:
"Mission Southern Hospitality" Embrace it! This is the second time I've been to the Front Porch and both times have been great. I heard about this place from a coworker when he told me they serve fried chicken and 40's, but the food was great. We got there a little before they opened and the woman in the front told us that if we came back right at opening, we could probably get a table, but that they were booked for the night. This place is pretty small, so a reservation is essential.

Both times my boyfriend and I went, we ordered the Bucket O' Chicken, with sides of baked mac and cheese and biscuits. GET THE BISCUITS. They do give you little cornbread style muffins with spicy butter which are good, but these biscuits are fantastic. They're served with rosemary butter and a cranberry jam, and the second time we ordered a second round.  The mac and cheese is also great. Cooked and served in a small cast iron skillet, it came to the table still bubbling. I'm pretty picky about my mac and cheese, I much prefer it with a smooth cheesyness (not that grainy texture homemade mac and cheese often has) and this one has a little of both, but it's definitely more on the smooth side.  Now the fried chicken. They serve it in an actual KFC style bucket, filled with popcorn on the bottom. It is super crispy and unmistakably juicy. I would definitely recommend it.  All of the food we have had is so well made. We had an ordering dilemma this time, thinking we should try something else on the menu, but decided we like the place so much that we'll just come back and definitely try something different next time.

As for the drinks, well the first time we got the 40s of King Cobra, of course. For such a cute and trendy restaurant, there is something so fun about eating fried chicken out of a bucket and drinking on a 40.  The second time we decided to class it up a bit. The boyfriend got the blonde bock beer. Their draft beer selection is very small, but they chose local and strong. I got the Porch Swing because you shouldn't be hanging out in the south without some bourbon in your hand. It is bourbon and cointreau with fresh orange and lime juice and a sugar rim.  It was strong enough to taste the bourbon, but not so overpowering to make it difficult to drink.

The two deciding factors on what makes a great restaurant for me are 1. I can't wait to come back and 2. I trust the chef with any item on the menu.  The Front Porch meets both of these criteria.
author: Heather B.

description:
I still love you Front Porch, but I must admit that the new chef is not killing it the way your old one did.  

The burger was not as stellar, and why-oh-why are the crab grits gone??  Shrimp grits? Not the same. Bring back the crab grits!

Fear not, I'll be back. I'm a big fan of second and third chances. Especially when the food is so good that I want to go back for senconds and thirds!
author: J Liberty S.

description:
This is some damn good fried chicken. Tender, juicy meat that was seasoned well, even before the batter went on. It had a slight lemon/citrus taste which was really nice and helped to balance out the heavier, saltier spices that were added to the perfectly battered fried skin. 

The sides of mashed potatoes and green beans were great as well. The green beans were cooked just right, crunchy but not under done. Whatever they used to season them were fantastic, I kept reaching over to serve myself more. The potatoes were good but not necessarily rave worthy. Since my friends and I were so retardedly hungry, we also ordered a side of fried okra and mac'n'cheese. The okra was only okay, they were cut too small and the batter was the type you find on fried Twinkies at county fairs. The mac was also only okay, as it needed an extra kick of something...it mostly tasted like cream and noodles. 

Again with the waiting though. When we arrived close to 10 pm, there were still a good amount of people waiting to be seated. Upon the suggestion of the manager, we put our name down and then walked down the block to a little sports-themed dive bar to have a drink while we waited. However, the wait was much quicker than anticipated, as we were just served our drinks and we received a call that our table was ready. 

And here's where I learned something new while in the bay, the concept of a "roadie". Basically, a to-go cup for your booze. The really awesome older gentleman who was our bartender sent us along to the restaurant with roadies, since we didn't want to down our beers in a minute. Haha!
author: Karen T.

description: Very cool Southern/Cajun/Creole style food... And alot of it for the money. A very "SF" restaurant, this place had solid fried chicken and mashed potatoes, Mac n cheese, & spicy shrimp and grits, among a few other things.
author: Raza M.

description:
Great quality food served piping hot! I had the mac and cheese, chicken, and jambalaya. Great atmosphere, great service. We did have to wait about 45 min for a table. You can't make reservations unless you're a party of 6 or more. It would be great for a date, but not the first.

This is the kind of place that makes you proud to be a local.
author: Halley B.

description:
the yelp reviews brought me to this restaurant..and after a long day of day after thanksgivig shopping...some good ol' Fried Chicken was going to hit the spot for me!  

So two disclaimers that you should know up front:
1.  this joint is pricey.  A bucket of chicken (9 pieces) was about $35 , but this does come with collard greens & mash potatoes with gravy.  Everything else was the same...small portions (think tapas) and not so small prices.
2.  this joint is small.  This means that reservations are a must!

The food was yummmy.  To date..this is the best fried chicken in SF!  The ambiance of the restaurant was so cool with local art on the walls (for sale...also very hefty prices), live music, and a full bar with very fun cocktails.  I could do without the dim lighting though..I like to see my food!  

Okay, back to the food.  There were four adults and one three year old in our group.  We had the mac n cheese (this is a must try!...yumm..) It's the kind of mac n cheese where the cheese is stringing off of your fork as you pick it up. 

We also had the fried okras.  I usually don't like okra because of the texture, but this was yummy.  The three year old hates veggies, and he loved these okras!  

We had the fried pickles...not a fan.  It tastes just as you would imagine it.  salty and tangy, but not in the yummy salt & vinegar chips kind of way!

We had the sweet potato fries...the fries weren't as crispy as I'd like them to be, but they were yummy anyway.  I am bias though because I love french fries (in any shape and form!)

And we had the corn dog.  HUGE corn dog, but the batter tasted burnt. I wouldn't do this again. 

Go here.  It's worth the price, worth the wait, and oh! try some cocktails.  The champagne cocktail was deeeelicious!
author: irene u.

description:
Don't you hate it when the night before you move from San Francisco, you finally discover yet another cool restaurant and think to yourself--why hadn't I done this before?!?

Ah well, it happened with The Front Porch.  I went with my hubby, and our 2 friends (one, also hailing from the South originally), and we had a great time. Don't let the location dissuade you--just a short trip down the J, and ultimately across from Mitchell's--can you go wrong?

Anyway, the atmosphere was fun and lively, service was great, and loved the menu.  I enjoyed my po'boy (it changes nightly), but couldn't get enough of the sweet potato fries on the side.  We also ordered the special app (fried mushrooms...mmm) and I had to try the mac & cheese, which was tasty.

Carrie got the fried chicken--yum for her--and a huge portion.

I wish we could've done dessert, but man were we full.

Just a really fun night--it's a bit loud / lively, so if you need to have an intimate conversation, you may want to find another venue.
author: Lori G.

description:
Maybe it had something to do with the beers consumed early in the evening. Perhaps the influence of tequila at the International Club across the street played a role. Whatever it may have been, my dining experience at The Front Porch was divine.

As usual, boyfriend and I ordered too much food. It is easy to get anxious about trying all the classics and quickly realizing you've ordered enough for a small army. But there are just some things you *have* to try in a place like this. For me, having grown up around Southerners and my grandma's cheesy grits, it was imperative that I try things like Gumbo, hush-puppies and grits. Plus throw in some fried chicken and the vegan special - oh, and more wine.

Everything was delicious. The Gumbo was a surprising HIT in my mouth. Gumbo is hard to get right, really hard and these guys nailed it. The portion was HUGE though, so beware.

Hush Puppies - oh yeh, I love me some fried dough. Basically a rounded beignet with savory remoulade.

Spicy shrimp grits: holy f**k. A delectable dish, my favorite of the evening.

By this point I was FULL and could not consume much more. A couple of bites of fried chicken just to taste, which was juicy, crunchy and spiced just right, as well as the exceptional and shockingly good vegan special. I am not adverse to eating simple vegetables, as a matter of fact I love them, but I tend to shy away from vegan menu items because people are always trying to *fake* other ingredients and flavors. Not this time - this was a true celebration of onion, tomato, fava beans and black eyed peas. Really nice dish.
 
The chicken proved to be a really great walking-home-drizzunk-at-2am-after-Dovre kind of treat, so definitely take some left-overs home.

Can't wait to go back. I also can't wait to go back to the International Club across the street - what an amazing people watching joint.
author: Zara E.

description:
In this day of rising prices, shrinking portions, and depleted bank accounts, it's a wonderful night that you can plop your butt down on a chair at The Front Porch, and realize that not only are all the prices wildly reasonable, but the portions are still.....well, they are still huge. And the food continues to be marvelous.

Spanky & I put our names on the list, and started off at the bar, with a carafe of a lovely Chinon. Our table was ready in about 10 minutes, and we sauntered over, glass in hand, and were immediately taken under the wing of our friendly and competent server.  Spanky admired the decor; I admired Spanky. So far, so good.

The Meal

After much debate, we settled on getting far too much, in order to taste all we wanted. A starter of steak tartare with quail egg, mustard, caperberries, radish and arugula (unctuous, full of textured silkiness, lovely) and a plate of asparagus with fried prosciutto, poached egg, and a light hollandaise (really lovely combination of textures and flavors), and then moved onto mains -- although at this point we were already starting to feel a bit full.

Our glasses being empty, we hailed back to the bar. Spanky replenished her Chinon with a remarkably healthy pour from the bartender (perhaps he overheard her commenting on his attractive demeanor), and for me a cask conditioned, whiskey-barrel aged porter. And these went exceptionally well with our choices of the fried chicken (still stellar) and the rabbit with morels (the rabbit light, the mushrooms almost overwhelmingly decadent), with sides of plantain and fried okra.

Holy cow, how did we think we could eat this much????

So we closed out with a digestif --- a lovely root beer float (I know, I know) and coffee. And then we rolled home.

The Front Porch remains a solid and comfortable choice in hard times.

Four filling stars!
author: sascha b.

description:
I wanted to like this place a lot, with its dim New Orleans style decor. But I felt it was unnecessarily overpriced since the food wasn't that tasty. Nothing too amazing your missing here. 

Parking was difficult too. Not sure why it made the 7x7 magazine must eat list.
author: Ash T.

description:
I LOVE fried chicken. After hearing so much about Front Porch's fried chicken for so long, I was very excited to come here and try it out. The restaurant is small, but very cozy and decorated like some loving southern grandma's house. Their wine/drink list is very good, pretty well priced and really delivers. The mac and cheese is absolutely, sinfully delicious, albeit somewhat oily from the amount of yummy, yummy cheese it has. 

However, I was pretty underwhelmed by the chicken itself. It appeared to be over-fried on purpose so it was almost unappealingly crispy and, in my humble opinion, over-seasoned too.  The texture of the meat was good though and I actually enjoyed that more than the skin, which is kind of sad. Also, the mashed potatoes and greens were just aight for me - not really that flavorful.

What I'm really looking for in a fried chicken joint is better fried chicken than I can make myself - because it's a good amount of messy work and I'd gladly pay to have it done for me. Front Porch didn't really live up to mine so I'll probably only come back for drinks and dessert and/or mac & cheese.
author: Kristina A.

description: Fried Chicken, greens, and biscuits were great. Try the fried green tomatoes. Small neighborhood place that was great. We will be back.
author: Lorna J.

description:
I went there for dinner last night with a friend.  I had heard good things about the place, and I love Cajun food, so I was really looking forward to it.  Although the atmosphere was fun, and I loved being able to find a place to park, I was a little disappointed.  When I think of Cajun, I think of stewed stuff like gumbo and jambalaya, blackened catfish and loads of sauces.  They had some that on the side, but it seemed that burgers and fried chicken is more of the restaurant's forte.  Just putting hot sauce (and bacon) on something doesn't make it Cajun.  We ended up splitting a green salad and the fried chicken dinner.  The salad sounded great in the description (pears and grapefruit slices, etc), but it was kind of blah. The dressing seemed to lack something.  And, the lettuce was composed of the toughest, most bitter leaves... that's the part you give to the rabbit or the compost.  The chicken was nothing to come back for.  My friend liked it, but wouldn't go there just for that.  The sides that came with it - the collard greens, mashed potatoes and gravy were the best part for me.  Oh, they also gave us cornbread, which was a plate of easy-bake oven sized muffins - just 2.  I'm telling, you, if I ever run a restaurant, I would never skimp on the small stuff, not at the prices like they charge. I didn't order the shrimp because I was afraid I'd only get 5 prawns.  We also ordered the bread pudding, which was fabulous.  Great bourbon sauce... mmm.

The bar was a little disappointing, because they don't stock a lot of liqueurs that are necessary to make certain cocktails.  If you stick to their own bar menu or the simple stuff, you're OK.  Now the bar across the street (which the restaurant owns) is completely the opposite, well-stocked and with a knowledgeable bartender.  We had gone there first, and had a great time.  My suggestion is for the restaurant is to lose the in-house bar, put in more tables, and lower their prices because they won't need to carry the expensive full-bar expense.  But, I'm sure they won't make any changes until they aren't filling tables anymore.  The place was packed, and noisy, even for a Wed. night, so word has gotten out well for them.  The service was also really good, so no complaints there.  I just didn't think the food was all that great, and I thought other Yelp readers who enjoy good food needed to hear that.
author: Randy P.

description:
Five of us went to dinner last night to celebrate a birthday. One of the concerns is parking although a found a spot on the street about 1/4 mile away. The restaurant is small and they had a good crowd for a Sunday night. We had reservations and they seated us immediately. For a small restaurant their drink list was impressive. Good whiskey list and they had some nice tequilas as well. We ordered the gumbo, fried pickles, and salad for appetizer. These were good. We wished the gumbo was spicier, but they gave us hot sauce to heat it up (their own brand). 
For mains we ordered their burger, short ribs, blacked fish, and, of course, their fried chicken, which is why we came there. Everyone enjoyed their dishes, and the fried chicken was very good. Worth the trip. 
We shared the pecan pie and the beignets. Both very good. Only thing bad I can say, was the restaurant was a little dark so hard to read the menu, but we managed. Btw the service was excellent. I recommend.
author: andy w.

description:
I tell my clients all the time, you get one or two nights a week to go a little nutty so make it count. You got your usual suspects like pizza but  we know how iffy that is in SF so I'm all about comfort food. Better yet, I'm cool with anything that is a receptacle for butter or salt so Front Porch is like crack for me. It's good.

I go for one of two combos when I go there. Usually my GF needs help with something so I try not order too much. I'll start with the field greens and kick ass on the pork ribs starter for a main. If I had a craptastic week, I go with option two-The crab/grits starter and finish off with the fried chicken. The fried chicken is never dry. It's not your typical KFC breading so If you are a fan of cornmeal breading, you'll love it. It's beer and wine only. I did not inspect the wine menu but was pleased at the selection of Belgium ales. 

Last time I went there with a buddy who sells them wine. It was the last night Amy Jenkins worked so it was festive and we had a blast. Even though they were slammed, the service was good and they took care of us. They have a new exec chef but I do not foresee them changing the menu too radically. 

If new chef Michael Law changes things around too dramatically, I'll pounce.

go
author: Bill M.

description:
I was sorely disappointed by this place.  Went there for brunch - maybe their brunch just doesn't measure up.

It was a jarring experience going from a sunny Sunday afternoon into a place that was dark and seemed dingy.

The food itself was nothing special.  Chicken and waffles - average.  Yes, the chicken was fresh and it was not super greasy, but there was not much flavor to it.  Biscuits were ok, but I've had much, much better.  It's certainly better than KFC, but it's also like five times the price.  Seriously, what's up???

I will say that the service was super-friendly and helpful.
author: Y K.

description: Awesome, keep up the good work. I have to stop trying top find other Southern food places to go and just keep coming back here where I'm not disappointed. Your Scotch bonnet hot sauce is a staple at home btw.
author: Shad M.

description: I am from South Carolina and I must say they got the food right.  Loved the ambiance and the service.
author: Eden F.

description: Baby sitting a house this week in Bernal I decided to check out Front Porch again and go for the chicken. I love Cajun but they don't have my favorite Etoufee, but they do have great chicken and greens and an awesome deal. The Okra was also outstanding and the drink menu a lot of fun, along with my favorite bourbon Heitz. They could create some more Cajun like drinks and spice the place up a little. But I like the atmosphere, service and the neighborhood is excellent. You also must go for the poor boy of the day especially the shrimp. I thought the food was a good value for the area overall.
author: Peter A.

description:
I've heard consistently great reviews from friends about this place...so last night the manfriend and I were in the neighborhood and decided to eat there. What greeted us was what looked like the messy remainders of a tailgate party...trash everywhere, drunken people, gross smells, and all-around unpleasantness. 

WTF? We asked if they were serving tonight and got a roundabout answer about some sort of party going on (but there was no indication of a private party going on...but, yeah, it was pretty apparent that some sort of party was going on...or WAS going on and the only folks left were shutting the place down. The place was a mess!).

Anyhow, we left confused. I know the space used to be a pretty dicey bar, but what is it now?
author: Kitten W.

description: very good fried chicken. uncomfortable seating.
author: Mrs. E.

description: I love this place! Good Southern-fare is exploding in SF and this is one of the best places. The decor, service and especially the food are top notch. How could you not love a place that serves hushpuppies?
author: Dave B.

description:
We had made a reservation after seeing how popular this place is.  Sadly, on this night public transpo was being...well a b*tch.  Two of our friends made it on time because they drove from into the city, but three of us were about an hour late.  The staff was really understanding and accommodating, service definitely great.

The food.  Tasty.  It was a serious fried food feast of goodness.  Point being, in case you hadn't figured it out, the food is GOOD.  However, the food is not cheap.  With drinks and everything it was a fairly pricey meal for the five of us.  

This place definitely feels a little hipster, but I was digging the front porch theme and the dimly-lit ambiance.  I would say it's worth checking this place out at least once and deciding for yourself if you want to return.

Make a reservation.
Bring an Empty stomach.
Try one of their cocktails.
Sit on the front porch.
author: Kristine C.

description:
For some stupid reason I was really put off by the name. It sounded like it was trying too hard, or something, so I walked in to pick up my order with a chip on my shoulder. Thankfully, that all changed with my first bite of their fried chicken. 

Picture all of your friend's mothers. Then picture the one that cooks the best, and imagine how she would make fried chicken. Multiply that by 10 and you have The Front Porch's fried chicken. A lemony undertone really perfects their crunchy breading. It feels like home. HIghly recommend. 

It's also worth mentioning their beignets. Honestly, their beignets were my first, and if they get any better than that, I have a new favorite food. Expect powdered sugar and chocolate sauce everywhere. I promise it's worth it. 

It's not cheap, I'll say that. But its good enough that I won't complain.
author: Lindsay J.

description: Chicken and the mac & cheese were ok, the greens and the mash were not my type only because i know how to cook a little.  The positive thing is that the staff is friendly
author: Joseph G.

description: Crawfish hush puppies are so delicious. Crispy and flavorful and the sauce they come with is amazing. The burger is so on point too!! I'm surprised there aren't more reviews on the burger - seasoned perfectly and cooked perfectly. I'm not usually a fries person, but the fries that came with the burger are maybe the best I've ever had. Shrimp and grits were delicious! I've never had grits but OMG - the buttery cheesy goodness and texture was amazing. The shrimp were also delicious. Although, the dish was so rich I probably would never be able to eat a whole order by myself. The biscuits are SO GOOD. And the Rosemary butter they come with is crazy delicious too. I literally would only give my bf one bite of them bc they were so good! The fried chicken was good but I'm not really a fried chicken person so I'd probably stick with the burger next time. My bf loved the greens they came with and he ate all of the mashed potatoes. The Mac and cheese was also good, but very cheesy and not too many noodles. Not the best I've ever had but still good. We ordered deep fried bacon on it too, but I ended up peeling off the fried portion to put some normal bacon on my Mac and cheese - deep fried was just too much.,Was seated fast and the staff was so nice! I did get pretty hot in the back of the restaurant but that may just be a side effect of ordering the entire menu ;-)
author: Jenna L.

description: Orgasmic mac-n-cheese. Cornbread was  yummy. My friends can't stop talking about the fried pickles.
author: Taylor C.

description:
I saw the little Front Porch while driving by and wondered what it was all about. Then I saw it on Check Please Bay Area, which gave it some mixed reviews. The only downside I could tell, in agreement from one review on CBBA, is that it isn't the best spot for kids. It's small and packed. Which is a good thing for the restraunteurs. But it had a great vibe and the hostess, bartender and waitstaff were friendly and helpful. 

I went alone and sat at the bar for dinner. I wasn't too hungry, but really wanted to try the place out. I had the fried okra with jalapeno lime aioli appetizer, which was good. I didn't expect too much from it, but I think it could have used a little more salt and overall zing. I had the spicy shrimp with andouille sausage app too. The sauce it was in was hearty and delicious. It wasn't as spicy as I had imagined. When I mentioned that to the hostess, she brought out three bottles of their hot sauce with varying degrees of heat. I could easily pass on the mild sauce, but the habanero and the ghost pepper sauces were perfect! I asked for more cornbread to dip in the shrimp sauce, which was fabulous.

I saw and heard about their fried chicken and stuffed pork chop. I will definitely go back for those when I feel like having a full meal. Of course, with a Red Stripe!
author: John F.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. Wait let me rephrase that...I really wanted to love the food because I liked the place.

The restaurant has an interesting interior, kinda reminds me of a voodoo curio shop with a bar. I think this would be a fun place for drinks. Also loved all the rocking chairs on the porch. The service was friendly and attentive. I just wish I liked the food more. 

The food was decent but I think it could have been so much better. I just didn't feel like there was a lot of flavor. The chicken was cooked perfectly but I just wish there was more seasoning.

BBQ shrimp and grits were good but lumpy which threw me off.

Mac and cheese had a great consistency but didn't have enough cheese flavor...

So I guess everything was almost there. Just needed a push to be all the way there.

I'd be willing to go back for drinks but would probably eat somewhere else.
author: Lu E.

description: Had the chicken and waffles here.  Came out piping hot, was fairly tender, wasn't greasy and was flavorful.  Waffle was good consistency and tasty.  Hard to beat for $14.
author: Jerry W.

description:
Location: A little place tucked away on 29th st
Decor: Homey, Cozy
Wait Time: About 15 min for a group of 6 on a busy Thursday night
Service: Friendly, but a little slow
Eats: Bucket of friend chicken (literally a popcorn bucket of chicken w/some popcorn), sides of greens and mac n cheese. Everything was a little forgettable except for the mac n cheese which was soooooo delicious. They also served us corn bread as an appetizer. It was dry and gross.
Money Honey: about $55 for two of us
Notes: just ok in my book

Try it. Like it. Repeat
author: Jenna s.

description: I was missing southern food after moving back to the bay area from DC/Virginia a couple years ago. Tried the pace and enjoyed the food !
author: Monica R B.

description:
Fina FINALLY I get to try this place after hearing so much about it from my sister, friends, and other friends.  And that, my friends, is the life of a yelper, the mission to try new places, especially those recommended by others or in yelp terms are 4+ stars!

And to my surprise, it's actually not that far from what I originally thought.  oh the anticipation of coming up to the place where you've heard so much about, not knowing what to expect, what's it look outside, and inside.  When we got here, I think the first thing that came to mind was the restaurant reminded me of New Orleans in Disneyland....very cajun, dark, and seems like the spot to be to eat, drink, and be merry.

Although the prices are a little high, there are certainly some things worth eating and trying. We had the following:

-Fried Okra - a must.  If you know what okra is and how the awesome gooeyness of it is, then no doubt, having it fried and dipped in some cream sauce is exactly that much better.

-Brussel Sprouts with lemon juice - I know a lot of people don't like brussel sprouts, but if you had it made like this, you'd love it.  Perfect spice and lemon zest.

-Fried Yucca with garlic sauce - pretty much just another type of garlic fries, but then the yucca is funny.  You need to eat it early before it turns all hard, but overall, I can do without this one.

-Oyster Beignets - didn't know what to expect, but it was certainly good.  we were unsure what the bottom patty thing was but its a bread pudding that complimented the fried oyster really well.  Definitely deserving a redo.

-Shrimp and grits - they make the awesomest grits with this candied gravy-ish sauce topped over.  I think this is my favorite dish thus far.

-Steak Special with squash fries - steak was tender but a tad small.  I'd prefer a larger piece and less squash fries although the entire plate had everything inculding some veggies at the bottom.

Definitely would want to come back, but perhaps not indulge as much and try a dish every so often.  Fried Chicken, i want you next time.
author: Vincent K.

description: Best short ribs I've ever had. Little madeleine-shaped cornbread was fun, gumbo was smoky and soupy. The bacon-wrapped frog legs were actually better without the bacon. The grits were great. And I enjoyed the cocktail and sitting outside on a nice summery evening. I only wish we'd had time for dessert and that there had been parking less than four blocks away, but I expect I'll come back. Service was friendly and fairly fast.
author: Sam Z.

description:
Quirky is the perfect word to describe FP. I'm inclined to like any place that I can get a bucket of fried chicken.  I think more restaurants should offer a "bucket" sized entree.  

My dining companion and I split the fried green tomatoes because it just doesn't get more Southern than that. The tomatoes had a nice crunch and came with a prawn salad thing that was quite tasty. I ordered the shrimp and grits because I can never resist grits. It was decent. 

I had to order the chess pie.  What the heck is chess pie?  Well it happened to have chocolate and pecans in it.  Tasty.
author: Monica L.

description: Are you kidding me?!? Just ordered take out and ordered the Vegan plate, amongst other things. It is described as "fresh veggies from local farmers" for $17.  When I unpacked the food at home, I thought they had forgotten my food. So I called and they asked if I saw rice and chili. Yep, I thought they were complementary sides. She informed me in a completely unapologetic manner that this was tonight's vegan plate. I tried to give her the benefit of the doubt and ask if she thought I'd ordered the side of vegan beans and rice. Again, with no hint of apology, she informed me she knew exactly what I ordered. Yeah, what was I thinking ordering vegan food from a southern restaurant.  But this was very misleading, and their customer service was poor. Really, a small container of rice and chili for $17 is supposed to be fresh veggies? Straight up lies (overpriced ones).
author: Wendy M.

description: An absolute fave of my entire family, including two young boys who *love* the idea of eating (gulp) alligator!  The quality of food, balance of flavors and overall vibe will make you want to come over and over. Kevin (the owner) and the staff are always warm and inviting, which adds to the "local" flavor of the experience here.
author: Mom G.

description:
Sooo, it' still good-- A place well worth going for a hearty finger-licking feast.  After the departure of the original chef and a menu overhaul, the fried chicken is still delish, the wine/beer selection is admirable, and the atmosphere still warm and relaxed.

But... what can I say?  It just not the same...  it lacks the finesse, the curiosity, and the inventive panache it became famous for.  It's not hard to find good fried chicken or a slab of pork belly, so I don't see a reason for the fuss anymore.
author: Laura F.

description:
It wasn't the best fried chicken and waffles I'd ever had and it wasn't the best mimosa I'd ever had either.
It WAS the best service I'd had in a long time and it was someplace I would go back to just for that. The server took time to bring over a rocking chair when my daughter got fussy and gave her a cozy blanket to snuggle up in and a book to read so that Auntie Nez and I could finish our food (one at a time). I appreciated that they didn't treat us any different knowing we were paying with a Groupon (and the meal was basically free). I also noticed that other peeps with kids were there and kept coming in which is the mark of a true kid-friendly joint. It was much more relaxing knowing that I wasn't getting the stink-eye because my kidlet wasn't coping with sitting in high chair that day. 
Front Porch deserves it's name because it's really JUST as cozy and inviting as sitting on a front porch.
author: Jill D.

description:
I HEART FP! Great ambiance w/dim lighting providing a romantic feel. From start to finish we could not get enough of the food! Started with the jalapeno corn bread shaped in the form of madelines. For the starter we had the fried okra, a somewhat healthier version to calamari. It had a light & crunchy taste.
For the entree, we ordered the bucket of chicken. Came with two sides - creamy mashed potatoes and collared greens. OMG,  talk about a mouth-gasm. The chicken was all white meat and amazingly tender on the inside and crunchy in the outside. It's safe to say that this is the BEST fried chicken I've ever had. We were told that the food would taste just as good if not better the next day and our waitress was right! Not only was she informative but also very sweet.
I can't wait till my next visit =Q
author: Cheryl P.

description:
Why must all beloved restaurants eventually die? Well, not actually die, but die from my roster of go-to places. The first time I went to Front Porch I had the crab and grits and nearly fell out of the booth. It was like eating melted clouds with strands of sweet words strung throughout. My southern wife was similarly ecstatic about the fried okra. In fact, when we were there celebrating her finished dissertation or sumtin she got a little tipsy and ordered more okra for dessert. Being a naive idiot, I tried to stop her, but she belligerently demanded them. Apparently she became a bit of a cause celebre in the kitchen when she wolfed them down. We went there for her birthday not long thereafter, and I had the waitress bring her a bowl of okra with a candle in it for dessert. Anyway, you get the picture, special place.
