But apparently a new chef has taken over, and for some crazy reason replaced the liquid gold with shrimp and grits, a sad imitation of their glorious past. The rest of our meal was just adequate. The cornbread at the beginning seemed a little stale, our entrees were serviceable, and everything took a pretty long time. It's amazing the effect a chef can have on ever detail of a restaurant. 

Anyway, the search for satisfactory okra beings anew.
author: Arne J.

description:
Pretty tasty restaurant, but very small, cramped, and loud.  You usually have to wait for a little bit, but you can make your wait a bit shorter by agreeing to eat at the bar.  I've been here twice, and this is what I did both times.

Overall, I found the food to be tasty.  I've tried both the fried chicken and the burger - both were above average but didn't blow me away.  The prices are a little high but fairly reasonable, because you get pretty large portions.

A nice little out-of-the-way place that delivers a pleasant surprise.  Recommended.
author: Chad H.

description: I when there it was OK food the place is off the hook I wish their more then beer and wine.
author: Yondome C.

description:
1.17.10, 8:00pm

Needed a reservation. Parking is horrible, but that is nothing new in SF.
Love, love, love the atmosphere! Very fun; hodgepodge of garbage all over the walls! Dark with highlights of red bulbs and that sort, very vintage look even though this place has only been there for 3 years. It's so in and new to look so old. My favorite part of the atmosphere? All the facial hair in that place! Man, the side burns and handlebar mustachios on the guys that were in that restaurant were off the chart! 

+ Cornbread (complimentary)
It's in the shape of corn on the cob!!! Warm, soft, AND it had coarse kosher salt on top. Yum. It's really worth asking/begging them to bring another plate over.

- Sauteed shrimp, bacon, mushrooms and garlic over grits, $11 for app, $18 for entree
No no no no no! The shrimp was cooked well, and the grits was creamy and well done but all of it was ruined under a 1/4" layer of red grease. I thought, maybe I'm not fancy or southern enough to appreciate this dish but I had everyone else at the table try it and everyone was awkwardly silent afterward (as in, no oohs and ahhs) until Marc was basically like "dude, that's gross and greasy". When I asked the waitress, she looked confused and said that there's a sauce on it. Oh dear. Anyway, she graciously took it off the tab, which I am grateful for. 

- Fried Catfish with hush puppies, coleslaw, and sweet potato fries $16.50
Rubbery fish. Dry, stale hush puppies. Soggy sweet potato fries. :(

- Fried oyster salad $?
Someone ordered this and it was so gross. The tangy dressing did not match the oyster and the oysters tainted everything in that dish with its hotness and oiliness, leaving anything fresh in its path in a wilted, oily, lukewarm mess.

+ Fried chicken $16.75 for a couple pieces or $33.33 for 9 pcs
The batter was greasy, yet coarsely crunchy without any tasty spices. BUT the actual chicken meat was awesomely moist. The meat must have been rubbed (under the skin) with crushed processed/canned garlic because it had that fragrant bite of garlic yet a little duller than the fresh stuff. I liked it. In terms of uniqueness or value, I dunno...the fast food joints are tasty, yet definitely not the quality ingredients and natural meat as the Front Porch.

+/- Local ground beef burger, bacon, cheddar, house made pickles, porch fries. $16.75 
Your average burger. What I would expect, although the bun was soft, moist and fluffy and the fries, fried and seasoned to perfection.

+ Fried okra with jalapeno aioli $4
I really liked this. Got it as a starter for everyone to share. Not greasy at all, but fried with a tasty cornmealy batter and the aioli was smooth with just a little kick.
author: Diana D.

description: Initially, I was excited to hit up this place when I saw all the yelp reviews after a friend recommended going here.  I already knew what I was going to try out.  I thought it was somewhat pricey but I had to give it the benefit of the doubt.  Like everyone else said, this place is SUPER dark inside.  I guess it just depends if that's your kind of thing.  I personally am a vampire so I felt right at home.  I went with my bf and my friend and we ordered the gumbo, the bucket of chicken, and the mac & cheese.  They gave us complimentary cornbread which I thought was nice.  It was somewhat dry but they gave us a cheese spread to put on it to compensate I suppose.  The gumbo was satisfactory.  I asked for no okra and they told me it's already in there so I had to deal and just not eat it.  The rice was grainy and there wasn't even any seafood in it but it still cost $8.50.  Rip off.  The bucket of chicken was even more of a rip off.  $34 for 9 pieces of crunchy but SUPER-DRY chicken, with pieces of popcorn in the bucket.  I asked for gravy on the side and they charged me $1 extra.  They should be giving gravy on the side for free to make up for their UNDER-SEASONED, SUPER-DRY CHICKEN!  The only good thing about the chicken was the crispy outside.  The only good thing about this place was the mac & cheese, but still not enough to make me come back here.  I'm from SoCal so I suppose all the people who've reviewed this place 4 stars or more for their chicken must have never been to Roscoe's Chicken & Waffles!  Overall, I wish I could be refunded the $75 spent (for the 3 dishes, plus 1 coke & 1 drink).  2 stars for the place, minus 1 star for the price (especially since it's not worth it)!
author: Gem S.

description:
Winner! Winner! Chicken Dinner!

Since my former employer decided to downsize me, foregoing a goodbye luncheon, my cow orkers decided to take me to dinner at The Front Porch.

Only a small handful of them were invited. (No spies allowed!) Okay, okay! The rest of them are either family with the bosses or cheap bastids who would ruin the night anyway.

Back to being a wiener... I mean WINNER!  We scored at  The Front Porch. We had a bucket of chicken, a jerk chicken, baby back ribs, crab grits, and some kind of pumpkin squash medley.

They really know how to spice it up! It's a good thing Powell's has disappeared in to nothing more than a lunch line in the Outer Bayview...otherwise I'd have to lower their stars to 3.5.

The jerk chicken is stuffed with a cool almost sweet stuffing and a little bigger than a cornish game hen. Beware, it is effing spicy. 

In the parking hell that is 30th and Mission, we found parking with nary a problem. 

And lastly, they were celebrating President Obama's inauguration with $3 draft beers.  Beer and wine only, so you hard alky drinkers should get your drink on in the Safeway parking lot or at Playa Azul.

Winner! Winner! Chicken Dinner!
author: Kevo M.

description:
Love the crab grits...

Love the bucket of fried chicken dark meat only in the popcorn tub. (I have yet to be able to finish it with 2 people)

Love staring at the hammered tin ceilings in the soft glow of the light from the bar.

Love the old school wooden cabinet/countertop they write your bill on.

Love the sticker on the liquid soap in the bathroom.

Love how they go out of their way to make up for any shortcomings on customer service when it gets crowded in the small space.

Love how they remember their customers.

Hope to try non-fried chicken one day, as well as the desserts but hard to pass up Mitchell's across the street for that.

Can't wait to go with a big group again so I can sit in the one of the corner booths.
author: Mark Y.

description: Just want to make this review short and sweet, because there is only the BEST things to say about The Front Porch - friendly staff, fun down-home atmosphere and AWESOME food.  Get the fried chicken - so delicious and juicy! Spicy shrimp and grits just perfect  with the "bacon crack". YUM!  I just know that everyone should try it and you'll want to go get seconds.
author: Timothy W.

description:
Dear Front Porch, I just wanted to say that, with all my heart, I love you. 

We walked in very hesitant considering that the chef had changed and they no longer have spicy crab and grits (a;owifj;aoiwejfW!!!!!). INSTANT sadness and heartbreak I was sure that there was no way The Front Porch could possibly recover! Then, we were dealt another blow when our server informed us that the chef was starting with a limited menu before expanding and... there were no grits on the menu. SADNESS.

But, we continued on. We ordered (and LOVED):
-Gumbo: It had the perfect balance of flavor and texture and the andouille sausages and fried okra left me wanting more more more!! 
-Dungeness Crab Salad: The name is deceiving. Originally I did not want to order this considering it was Fat Tuesday and things with the word "salad" I believe shouldn't be eaten for Mardi Gras but it turned out to be one of the best things we ordered. I'm still not quite sure what a mirliton is but it is amazing.
-Fried Chicken: Succulent, flavorful, perfectly fried. I never understood what the fuss was about fried chicken until I tried it at The Front Porch. I can't describe it - you just have to try it!
-Seared ahi over a crawfish risotto cake: Only thing I wasn't completely impressed with. The idea of a crawfish risotto cake was intriguing but it didn't deliver on the name...
-Slow roasted pig: My favorite Main dish! Delicious and the rice and beans accompanying is was a very nice touch.

As if the food wasn't great enough, our server, Emily, came back out with a bowl of...yes, GRITS!!! That, truly, made my night but I would have been very 5 star happy without it too, and that's saying something.

Great food, great service, great ambiance...The Front Porch is stupendous!! I will be back for sure to see what else will be developed on the menu.
author: Christina L.

description:
Hubby and I just moved from NC to CA in June.  When we heard about a southern food restaurant, we had to try it. We are VERY pleased with the Front Porch and plan on going back.  The only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is because I don't remember seeing sweet tea on the menu (someone please correct me if it is there and I missed it).
We started with fried pickles, which were great!  Definitely an appetizer I'd recommend.  I had the ribs, grilled corn (YUM) and mashed potatoes.  I ate every bite on my plate and was stuffed to the max.  Hubby had the fried chicken and thought it was delicious.  Great restaurant, and a "home away from home" place for us.
author: Jenni H.

description:
The food looks and tastes like it's $10 more than it costs.

Seriously. I was happily surprised when my entree arrived. I had their fish dish (don't completely remember what it was or what the fancy ingredients were called). It was beautiful. Could have had less butter and more seasoning. The fish was perfectly cooked and it was so rich it knocked me out for the rest of the evening. But in a good way.

The wine was the best I've had in a SF restaurant so far and it was incredibly reasonable. I loved the ambiance. It fit perfectly with the southern cooking, homey theme of the restaurant. Seems like a spectacular place for small groups of friends and romantic dinners.
author: Loe L.

description:
This joint is awesome. I lived in Nashville for 3 1/2 years and developed an affection for grits (cheesy or not), biscuits, gravy, and other things that are just so bad for you...but so good.

The Front Porch delivers a reasonably authentic, slightly gentrified/sanitized version of the traditional Southern Breakfast. They have a bit of a cajun thing going on, which is good because the N.O. Beignets were flippin' awesome.

I had the country breakfast (massive, but delicious), my belle had the pulled pork hash which was as delicious as it sounds terribly wrong for anything before 6:00pm.

No wait (I think we lucked out), good service, and actually pretty freaking cheap for the quality and quantity. Can't wait to go back
author: Giacomo F.

description: Small spot , love the decor. Fried green tomatoes were amazing! I ordered the shrimp and grits, it was okay. My boyfriend ordered the fried chicken; it was amazing! Probably the best fried chicken I've had. The service was okay; they could be a little more friendly.
author: Serena L.

description:
I'm really not a fan of Southern food...i think of KFC as Southern. I went with a group of friends, and luckily some of them have been there before so, they ordered items for the table.
The place is small, was originally a garage, and is located under an active house...which is really cool. We ordered fried okra, and potato fries which are really good, not greasy, and come with special sauces. I ordered the Tri-Tip which came on a bed of ratatouille niçoise is the best way to describe it, and was actually quiet complementing to the tender meat. The mac & cheese is by no means from a box. The noodles might be pre-made, but the cheese is a mixture of different cheeses, and can be eaten as a main course. As For desert i got the freaken delicious bread pudding sadly it was really small serving, but it was an awesome dessert, the peach cobbler was also tasty, and warm.
This place has a Southern taste, but it is not overbearing to eat. I'll will have to take a true Southern friend to get his opinion.

If your looking for a unique restaurant in the Mission district that makes "home cooked" Southern food this is the place to try.
author: Nathan M.

description:
Great experience all-around. We were told to expect a 40 minute wait for 2 on a Saturday at 7 pm, but it only ended up being 15. Even so, the brought blankets out to our rocking chairs outside because it was cold. Who does that? Awesome.

We decided to share an order of their famous fried chicken, a vegan special, and baked mac and cheese. Some of the best fried chicken I have ever had, if not the best. The veggies were perfect and displayed beautifully. The Red Velvet cake also delicious.
author: David M.

description:
We split the chickemwaffle and a couple of sweet iced teas.
The teas were iced, yet not sweet.
The chickem was crunchy, but mostly bone, and also very bland.
The waffle was pumpkin and we liked it. It nice.
We waited 40 minutes for a table.
We waited 40 minutes mostly because there were a couple of people who had clearly already paid their bills and finished their drinks, and yet continued to sit and talk.
We hate it when people do that.
We highly recommend that regardless of your age, you request a children's menu and some crayons. Or bring your own crayons. Because they have an off-brand that is even worse than RoseArt.
author: Samanthatindy Z.

description: Ate there for the first time lat night, and was very impressed by the food. Everything we had was piping hot and delicious! The fried chicken was flavorful without being salty, and crispy without being over-battered. We loved it and would definitely go back!
author: M'famous O.

description: Loved it! Cute atmosphere, wonderful food (I'd say it's better than Brenda's), friendly staff, and we got seated in just a couple of minutes. I'll definitely be back. The only teeny tiny thing I'd like them to change would be to supply hand wipes - eating ribs or fried chicken or boiled peanuts can be messy!
author: Alex F.

description:
The food is great, atmosphere proper, service excellent.  Is it perfectly authentic?  No.  Is that reason to dock some points?  Hell No.  These people clearly care about their product, and their customers.

Lagniappe lives here.  Love it.
author: Mark S.

description:
4 stars for the food quality
2 stars for the price

Only in SF could someone get away with charging $16 for a Po'Boy filled with 4 shrimp and a few slices of pepper.

Price aside, the food is very delicious and the overall dining experience is pleasant.  The fried green tomatoes were excellent as was the cornbread and fried chicken.  My favorite was the donut bread pudding which is  must (although at $8.50 it's grossly overpriced)

Check it out once to get it off of your list then head to Farmer Brown where the prices are better and the food equally as good.
author: Joshua J.

description:
Three and a half stars instead of 4 or 5, because of the very aggressive mariachi they let come in and pester you until you tip him.  I admire Front Porch for trying to support the community, but they should pay the mariachi and request that he not solicit patrons for tips when you're paying $33 for a bucket of chicken.  If he were a little more gracious, that would have been okay.  But he hung out at a nearby table that was ignoring his requests for five minutes hoping they would cough up something.  We would have preferred the CD that was playing.  

Also, I asked for bread, and our server said, "we have cornbread," but still didn't bring it out.  Is there some code language I need to know to get bread?  

Anyway, the food is reasonably priced for the quantity they give you and being in SF, besides the accompaniments to the fried chicken, which were a little small.  The fried okra was really good, perfectly salted and fresh.  The lime jalapeno aioli missed the mark - it was slimy and did not seem to go with the okra.

I loved that the fried chicken is presented in a popcorn tub with some popcorn that absorbs some of the chicken fat and gets much tastier as the night goes on.  They just staple the bucket up with your leftovers, and I appreciate the minimal waste.  The fried chicken was really moist and tasted like it had been marinated in citrus for hours.  

They were out of the green beans, so it came with collard greens and mashed potatoes.   Both were good, but this portion was really stingy for a dish meant to serve more than 2 people.
author: Amy D.

description: Wow! What a disappointment! I didn't think the food was good at all! Service was very slow and our waitress didn't even check on us. We had a problem with taste on an entree, the hangover. Had to hunt someone down to replace it. After 35 mins we decided to forget it and leave. Manager insisted we stay and eat it because it was already ordered. No thank you! Not after the way we were treated. Thumbs down on this restaurant!
author: Thomas M.

description:
Being born and raised in the South, I know a thing or two about fried chicken. My tastebuds are highly critical of anything that doesn't come out of mama's kitchen, and I for sure would not expect some hotshot restaurant from San Francisco (of all places) to impress. Well, The Front Porch does just that and it may be the best fried chicken in this city.

That's what I would say if I really was from the South and actually knew what real fried chicken is supposed to taste like.

Well, I am Bay Area born and raised, and the extent of my fried chicken expertise pretty much ends with KFC's Original or Crispy. What I do know, is that the fried chicken served in a popcorn bucket (popcorn included) from The Front Porch is some of the best I've ever had. I'm very easy to please, but fried chicken must possess two distinct qualities: crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside. Anything else is just a bonus. The Front Porch does both incredibly well. The skin is perfectly seasoned and crispy, and the meat is mouth wateringly juicy and flavorful. 

I went with a group of friends, and we shared a couple buckets of chicken with mashed potatoes, collard greens, and fried yucca with aioli, which were all very good as well. We washed it down with some Rose sangria, which is made by the glass per order. Though very refreshing and fruity, I regretted not ordering an ice cold beer instead to go with my fried chicken.  Check out the full review on my blog, see profile.
author: Gene M.

description:
Food: 3
Service: 4
Overall: 3.5

Fried chicken: Good but not amazing.  The breast meat was kinda dry but the batter was yum.  Slightly disappointed it fell apart so easily when I dipped it into my masted taters.
Shrimp + grits: Very nice flavor combo, though I like my grits slightly thicker. Something I'd come back for.
Mac + cheese: Pasta was overcooked, but the crispy cheese on top was delish!
Free corn bread! The orange mayo/butter stuff was a nice touch.

The servers were patient when some of us were late and courteous when we needed an extra seat last minute.

Overall, a pretty good experience here, but nothing to go OMG about.
author: Camila L.

description:
Hidden away in the outer mission, this place will remind you of the south.   

Good food, kinda heavy though but I really enjoyed my experience at this place and I will definitely go back.
author: t s.

description:
The Front Porch manages to link together two words that would normally never be used in the same sentence: Hipster and soulfood.

Worth the trip for the crab grits. Just don't forget to wear your skinny jeans and Chuck Taylors.
author: Hunni B.

description:
yummy!!!

I went here with a couple of friends, we had a reservation but still had to wait.. a little bummed about that but hey I was a host for a bit I know how it is. The food was amazing!! So I almost forgot about not being seated for a bit..gotta get the Fried Chicken and Black Eyed peas! All in all great food, good cocktails, and a cool spot! Wish they had a location closer to me..
author: Daniel L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place since they made the 7X7 list of must try food in SF.  At 9:00pm on Friday night the place was packed and lively. 

The food: The chicken gumbo was pretty good, but a little flavorless.  The blackened catfish was incredibly bland, but wasn't terrible.  The shrimp and grits dish was my favorite. 5 large shrimp with a flavorful sauce (maybe just a tad too salty) on top of a good sized portion of grits. For dessert we had the bread pudding topped with caramel and praline ice cream.  It was good, but nothing out of the ordinary. 

I saw a lot of tables order the fried chicken, so I'm half tempted to go back and try it.
author: Nita K.

description:
This was our first meal at the front porch.  Please read the entire review. The FP is a beer and wine only establishment. We ordered 2 drinks, one was made with white port, I had the red sangria.  Her drink was great, my sangria was so so. We paid for our drinks at the bar. 

Appetizer: Blue Crab Fritters. These were very good. 

Dinner: A bucket of fried chicken, which includes mashed potatoes and greens.  We also got the biscuts.  

Dessert: pecan pie and 4 barrel coffee.

We didn't leave hungry, but both of us were miffed at how we dropped $117 dollars for 2 drinks and a fried chicken dinner.  The blue crab fritters were tasty.  The chicken was also very good, but at $33 dollars/bucket, not even close to being priced reasonably. Our biscuts were $6. You get only 2. They were tiny and dry.  The pie was terrible and at $7.00 for a micro slice also over priced. The coffee tasted burnt and was on par with Denny's. We know what chickory is...  But that wasn't it. Poor!

Overall, we were not satisfied with the quality of the food we were served. Just about everything there is over priced, and some items tasteless for what you get and are paying for. In addition, street parking is hard to come by and we almost gave up after looking for a space for over 30 min. I wish we wouldn't have found a spot after this experience. The chicken was good, but not worth the price, hassle or dining in a pub like atmosphere.  You just can't charge these type of prices for dining in a converted bar which is dimly lit to hide all of it's imperfections.
author: Rick K.

description:
Perhaps it's me and I should just admit I despise overly rich food...

...But the crab and grits (I ordered a large as my main after sharing a couple starters) was so intensely rich that I had to stop after 3 or 4 bites. When I say rich I mean there was more butter/cream than actual grits (perhaps this is accurate to tradition but not for me) and I found it very unenjoyable. Additionally, I could hardly find any crab on top. A few carrot chunks, sure, but there was literally one little blob of crab that was so over seasoned I found it unreasonable to charge so much for a couple bits of veggies on a bed of cream.

However, let me be certain to point out that the brussels sprouts were AMAZING and I still dream of those. Sweet and sour and perfectly cooked.

Loved the actual front porch though, and can't complain with the beverage selection.
author: Abby Z.

description:
#300, here it goes.

This place is truly something special. I've given it much thought, and a solid fried chicken joint is hard to come by, especially in San Francisco. I'm not looking for fast food or for a place that simply serves it, I just want a place that does it, and does it WELL.

EUREKA!

The Front Porch is a tiny bustling restaurant in Bernal Heights that probably seats no more than 50 people. We came around 8pm on a Sunday and got a table within minutes of waiting at the bar. The party of four behind us weren't as lucky. Come prepared for a wait and have a backup plan for dinner if you're impatient. As mentioned, they don't take reservations for parties under five. Ideal for couples or small parties. It's very loud, dark and has a "divey" quality to it. The staff is outfitted in the typical trendy but unique vintage Mission hipster fashion and they're very nice.

The menu is diverse, with daily seafood and vegan specials, spruced up with a fresh perspective of Southern favorites, with a nice selection of beers, local and from abroad (they even have King Cobra), and wine. The little gem salad was decent with a very bitter and strong dressing. I felt it was a little lacking and could have used some shaved parmesan or asiago on top to counteract the bite of the dressing. The Bermudian callaloo soup appetizer was hearty and loaded with lobster, greens, seedy whole pieces of okra and onions. It was the perfect cold day soup and I would definitely order it again.

Now onto the chicken. The chicken, the chicken, the fried mo'fockin' chicken. The fried exterior is thicker than your normal fried batter, clearly well peppered and spiced. Thicker as in it's more like a shell, rather than a mass of fried matter like at Popeyes nor very delicate like a tempura batter. It flakes off in small sheets, instead of crumbs. Albeit, my tastebuds were a little hindered with a cold, but I could still tell the fried shell packed a powerful punch. Not overly spicy at all. Every piece was cooked to juicy perfection; dark meat and white meat alike. Nothing was overcooked nor dried out. It doesn't need sauce, but The Front Porch will provide you with some of the spiciest orange habanero secret sauces around. It is ON FIRE. A spec had me sniffling, and a dip had me nearly chugging water straight from the bottle. It's not a joke. Less is more, people. The green onion mashed potatoes were good, as were the green beans, and I never got to the wax beans beneath the mashed potatoes, because for me it was all about the chicken. It is just so good.

Nice find.
author: Chelsea P.

description: Went with a group and we had the fried chicken, hangar steak, flounder and sides of gumbo and the chili fritto.  Chicken was moist and tender but was just average in flavor. The steak was ok but not something I'd write home about.  The gumbo was not very good but the chili fritto was really popular.  The flounder was good and moist.
author: Doug W.

description:
This place is my jam. 

The gf and I have made The Front Porch an event-meal standard. Birthdays? Anniversaries? Valentine's Day? CheckCheckCheck. 

The ambiance is humble and warm; the food is outstanding; the service is pleasant; and the drinks do not disappoint. Sitting on the porch waiting for your table to open up is a great way to burn the dying daylight. I can't say enough about this place.

I will touch on two culinary highpoints: the fried chicken and the red velvet cake. You owe it to yourself. I broke ranks on my vegetarianism for the chicken, and I have never regretted it.
author: Maple Q.

description: We are regulars here. We live nearby. Tonight the $19 hangar steak was not "a steak" but rather a few pieces of meat masked by a mountain of three (four?) onion rings and sitting in a giant pool of almost too-sweet creamed corn with some green peas on the side. I have noticed the portions getting steadily smaller over time. Here, they nearly forgot the meat what with the corn. It tasted good. But it was not very much food. I take that back. It was a lot of corn, and not much meat. It was worth maybe $12 at most. Dang, it really was a lot of corn. Sigh.
author: Chris V.

description:
The short: Stick with the fried chicken, and make sure you aren't seated next to the bathrooms

The Long:
The place was a little too loud - we were seated right next to the bathrooms - we could actually be heard from inside the bathroom.  I ordered the duck with spicy apples - and I asked how spicy it was.  I was told it wasn't at all spicy - just some cinnamon on it.  Turns out it was covered in habanero sauce.  

I hear the fried chicken is amazing, but overall, I don't think it was very good.

They don't take reservations for groups under 5 people.
author: Cameo W.

description: Ah, the Dirty South.  Why do I love thee so?  San Francisco is about as far from the Mason-Dixon line as you can get.  So why did I dip into this cozy establishment for dinner with friends?  Cuz it was damn good and I can never pass on fried chicken and BBQ.  So many of SF haunts are jammed with tourists armed with Frommers and fanny packs.  Not the FP.  It's a step down joint, dimly lit, with a mellow Mission crowd.  Loved the food and the atmosphere.  This is my new SF favorite.  Of course the Bay City has so many great spots.
author: Tony T.

description:
Not sure where to start about my experience at Front Porch.  A little
about me first, I was born and raised in the South, South Carolina to
be exact, and I am a chef, so needless to say, I had some expectations
when going to eat at Front Porch.

It smelled great when I got there.  A bit dark of an ambiance for my
taste as I usually like to clearly see what I am eating.  Tight space as the
waitress bumped into me 3 times with her rear without apology or
acknowledgement, which became annoying after the first time.

We ordered the biscuits, which were $6 for two of them!  I thought
this was exorbitant has I know what goes into biscuits, and they are
not $3 worth of ingredients each; really, there should be 4 for $6.

I ordered the mac and cheese and my friend ordered the rib plate. The
waitress returned to tell me that they were out of mac and cheese!  I
almost fell out of the chair because I do not know how a restaurant
would run out of a permanent menu item that consists of at max a total
of 8 simple ingredients that you can even find at the closest corner
store.  
I scanned the menu for something else, and ended up paying
$11.50 for a side of mashed potatoes and sautéed green beans. 

Turns
out the ribs were dry and the corn on the cob was only a half a cob
with a side of mashed potatoes for $19.

Wish they had better business sense to have what is listed on the menu
and give a bit more food. They should have offered to comp a beer or
dessert for the lack of such a simple staple menu item on a
Southern style food menu.
Won't go back here unless I am too sick to cook and I need southern
author: Melissa B.

description: We brought my southern mama here for judgement day after coming here a few times on our own. She gave her stamp of approval on the chicken, greens, porkchop, mashed potatoes. The only thing she didn't go crazy for were the fried pickles (I quite liked the slim cut take on them, but I'm a city girl) and the Mac n cheese. She fell in LOVE with the banana pudding dessert. Absolutely obsessed. Very cute. Weeknights you don't need reservations, but you are free to make them. Weekends I highly recommend opentabling it. We have totally been turned away before!
author: Andrea W.

description:
It is quite embarrassing how much I love fried chicken. I crave it and if listed on a menu, will not hesitate to order it. 

Forget the starter, I went straight for the good stuff. Apparently good is all I got. After hearing people rave about the chicken, I think I had too high of expectations because I was slightly unimpressed after finishing the first chicken piece. Although the chicken was juicy, the breading was off.. not flaky and crispy as it should be. 

I can't comment on any other dishes besides the fried chicken but will give it another shot in a couple of months.
author: Lan H.

description: I can't think of a reason not to give this place 5 stars. I moved to the city a year ago and this is one of the few restaurants that are in my rotation (it's generally my rule to try new places unless a spot is outstanding... and the Front Porch is indeed outstanding!). The folks who work there are hip, pleasant and down to earth. We've been squeezed in at the bar without a reservation and treated well without pretenses. The service gets 5 stars... the food gets 6. The fried chicken and collards are amazing, the bacon wrapped dates and fried pickles have me wanting to make them at home. Other entrees that have me salivating just writing this review are: the side of mac and cheese served in a cute cast iron skillet, the flounder (oh yes yes yes!), the burger. You can't go wrong. Go here. Oh, and, order a cocktail.
author: Cute N.

description:
Just OK. I had dinner for the second time at Front Porch on New Years Eve. I had eaten there a few years ago when they first opened and was not very impressed then either. I had always wanted to give FP another try, but I felt the exact same way again. 

Firstly, even though it was New Years Eve, a friend and I had dinner at 6pm because we were not celebrating NYE, we were just having a casual dinner in the hood. I say this because the first thing the snarky hostess said to me was, "Oh, SOMEONE didn't dress up!" Well, excuse me beatch for not living up to your expectations! 

Anyway, that didn't really put me much in a good mood. We started with a pretty good salad, but let me tell you, their fried chicken bucket is pretty crappy. My Mama was a Mississippi native who KNOWS how to make fried chicken. Get a clue. Seriously, I would rather eat at KFC. My friend had some seafood paella type of dish that she really liked, so at least she was happy.

I really want to like Front Porch, it has a great room and is around the corner from my house, but you know what? I ain't going back there to eat again.
author: Yvette K.

description: Their burger is amazing AND they deliver. Highly recommend you giving it a shot.
author: Emma C.

description:
I expected really good soul food here since I have seen this restaurant always is crowded, yelp reputation is pretty good and my friends recommended. however their food just betrayed me sadly....
Hard knox is way better taste and cost.

we took....
Roasted Beets Salad; Golded beets themself were tasty but dressing was too blank  so I needed to add a pinch of salt to them.

BBQ rib: it was the worst dish we ordered. Not juicy at all and smelled bad.

Fried Chicken: Good! I like this crispy flavorful coating and juicy chicken.

Sidedish:
   Potate salad; potate was uncooked, too hard to eat...
   Collard Greens; too sour to eat....
   Corn Bread;too dry to eat....

one star for nice service and decor, the other for fried chicken.
author: Spinof P.

description: The food here is good but I felt that the price was a wee bit too high for what we ate. Grits and fried chicken were yummy! We had a nice waitress too. Parking is bad, but it's like that pretty much all around SF, am I right?
author: Dalia M.

description:
dayum.... seriously awesome 9th ward bbq shrimp...  Fried chicken is crazy good.  Roast pig was awesome.  duck prosciutto amuse popped.

I've lived in SF for decade now, and really, I'm tired of the whole 'california-chez panisse' thing.  yes, i get it.  simple foods, don't mess with it yadda yadda.  Nopa, bar jules, zuni, all are based on this. 

Front Porch is different.  It's about connecting with something of the past.  It's about eating great food with some history.  Creole/New Orleans food is something that's developed over 100s of years, a fusion of culture and time.

This is one of first menus i've seen with  'original thought'.  It's deep, rich, flavors, layered.  Sauces where you have no idea what's behind it all?  Coffee the bbq sauce?  Molasses?  Buttermilk in the fried chicken?  Who knows, but i know it works.  But not only taste good, but has a point of view.  It had soul...  a love for life.

Add that with a non-pretentious staff.  sweet rocking chairs outside, and you got a great place that's really changing things.

note to yelp: why doesn't my post show when i sort by date...
author: suckafree c.

description:
The official motto for this joint is "The Front Porch Rocks."

I tend to agree.

My date and I enjoyed a lovely, messy meal here last night.  A frissee salad with bacon, egg and deep fried oysters (omglikeanorgasmferurmouth!)  A half a slab of tangy baby back ribs.  And, Mamma Ollie's Fried Chicken.

Add in two glasses of "jug" wine and I felt like I was back in New Orleans... delightful, really!

So the food: the salad was sublime.  Period.  The ribs reminded me of some really good ones I had in Mississippi once where they boil them all day before throwing them onto a mesquite wood grill.  The chicken - god I don't know what they do to that chicken - but, it was fried chicken which was tangy, juicy and soooo crispy.  It would have rivaled Powell's Place chicken & that's saying something.  Plus they had mashed potatoes that had something like stewed green onions in them... Uh, I might have to figure out how to make those so I can just eat a whole pot of them.  Yumtastic!

It was quite crowded for a Tuesday night, but the hostess was very prompt about getting us seated as quickly as possible.  The staff was a little over attentive (as we were on a date, trying to eat and trying to talk - didn't need to be asked how everything was twelve times - but, just this once I'm going to chalk it up to them being friendly.)  The atmosphere of The Front Porch is charming, I love the pressed tin ceilings.  And, the actual front porch is adorable.

To sum up: great food, cute atmosphere, friendly & attentive staff, clearly  a very popular place.  Can't believe I hadn't heard about it until now.  Big props to my date for being able to find a restaurant that I didn't know about and which impressed me!

I will 100% be back!
author: Kate R.

description: the flavor of the food was very bland in my opinion. we ordered the gumbo as an appetizer & it was kind of disappointing. the best thing we ate was the fried chicken & baked mac and cheese. the mashed potatoes had absolutely no flavor & the collard greens were so so. the service was alright; the waitress kind of have us attitude. we want to give her benefit of the doubt & just say that she had a long night, but even then she should have been more pleasant towards us cause we were the customer. it's worth coming in once to try the food, but I wouldn't come back here again. I can find places that serve the same kind of food for way better quality & flavor.
author: Janey H.

description:
The Bottom Line: Front Porch offers quality southern food, with a southern feel for a decent price. Great place to take friends or when you just need some comfort food.

Came here after about 3-4 years to celebrate Fat Tuesday. Great part is that its "Beer Week" in SF as well as strong beer month. I had 2 strong beers, blondes, 1 of their version of a mint julep (because they don't have a liquor license) and 1 purple haze, a raspberry Hef. Great beers, and of course they have King Cobra PREMIUM malt liquor, how can you go wrong with that? (brings me back to the high school days).

We ordered the special, Boudan Sausage Battered and Fried. It was pretty good but nothing to rave about. We then had the braised oxtail with mashed taters / wild mushroom in some sort of gravy, man the oxtail was good, but the gravy made it 10x better. We also had the gumbo, signature southern food prepared well. Mac and Cheese was great as well, top of my Blue Box list.

Bartender was understaffed but did as best he could, he wasn't standing around.
author: Steven C.

description: Tried this again, and turns out i'm insane (but my first review was accurate for the food I had that night).  Went back again and the chicken was effin delicious and so were the sides.  Giving 5 stars this time to balance out my one star from before.
author: Big Toe ..

description:
Pretty darn good!!  I've gone twice and would definitely go back.  Why I love this place:

1) You put your rezi in, and if you decide to go to Club 3300 up the street to get a beer while waiting, the guy will either call the bar OR walk up himself to say your table is ready.  How awesome is that?

2) Food is pretty good.  Last night I had the burger with fries.  Other people in our group had chicken fried steak (maybe the best I've ever had?) and someone else had fried chicken.  

3) Prices are okay.  I love that they offer $1.50 beer (I think it's Michelob).  Hey, a buck fifty is a buck fifty - good deal.

4) The cornbread they give you is a nice touch.  I wish it was warmed up though.
author: Carol S.

description:
We wanted to like this place very much but...

My husband is from the South (North Carolina) and we go to Southern or Soul Food restaurants whenever we see one.

This place, he and I both said that we probably won't dine again. 
The waitstaff was great but the food was just below OK.
Fried chicken... I make it better although mine is an oven baked fried chicken.. 
Side dishes... I make it better...

It was a huge disappointment.
author: Wakaknee J.

description: Had a group of 7 for a Saturday morning breakfast.  What a great group of individuals work at the Front Porch!!  We had the shrimp and grits, the stoner stack, chicken and waffles and the fried okra.  Every plate was delicious and almost finished - we just got too full!!  The service was wonderful; humorous and attentive without intruding.  There was not a complaint in our group and we absolutely loved the food.  Our daughter, who lives in SF, brought each of uis a cup of Phil's Coffee to try. Our wait staff didn't complain - just said "OK, you have to bring enough for everyone!".  Thoroughly enjoyable and a perfect start to our San Francisco holiday,  Thank you to Yelp for posting the reviews that were used in our selection of this fabulous establishment!!!
author: Deanna U.

description:
My various misadventures have left me a little....dottie......as well as more socially awkward. Living with dane brammage can be difficult. Strangers sometimes find me uncomfortable to be around, mostly because of the giggling. One of two things happens in these interactions, people are either annoyed or gracious when dealing with me. 

The people at The Front Porch are gracious. They went way out of their way to help me with my picnic. They even let me borrow silverware. We got the chicken bucket that came with cornbread, grits and black eyed peas. For about $40 (including tip) I fed four people. The only thing I regret is that I forgot to ask for the black eyed peas to be non-piglet, so I didn't get to try it. The people who did loved it. Everything was delicious. 

If it weren't for the crappy ass weather at Holly Park, we could have enjoyed the music and films and it would have been a perfect Saturday. Luckily, the food was so tasty we were able to ignore the freezing bitter wind bellowing through the park. 

We'll be back!
author: Mitsi M.

description:
I took My Favorite Yelp Celebrity here for fine dining.  Sadly, you Dear Reader (and for purposes of this review) just haven't earned Most Honored And Favorite Super-Yelper status, else I'd have finessed The Front Porch's high-end take on soul food  down your palette instead of hers. When I take YOU out to dinner (notice I said "when", because I'll get to you all, and that's a promise) that means that you's straight-up my Never-ending Big Balling Yelper Of Eternity. That night. But I digress.

[[SF/X: Patsy Cline, Walkin' After Midnight]]

If the Front Porch is offering some stank, skanky vegetable, all candied up and slathered in bacon, get it. Don't sleep. They turn funky old green vegetables into a donkey ride to heaven. Though they no longer offer their roasted candied brussel sprouts as a starter, I get an email alert  when they're back in season. I could eat them like bon-bons, all slick in a silk robe watching daytime soaps while part-time models serve me deliciously stinky brussel sprouts. 

They keep a 40 oz. of King Cobra on the spirits list. For the life of me I can't figure what food would go with King Cobra (too masking, even for grits and greens, though probably perfect with their corn-shaped corn bread appetizers), I opt instead for the Persephone, a bio-dynamic or whatever hard cider with pomegranite juice and fruit. Sangria style cider. Not too sweet and I think I smell newly-mown grass. "Get the part-time models back here, we've filled another tray".

Rumor has it their shake 'n' bake recipe sits safely in a locked vault in a satellite orbiting 1000s of miles above the bayou. The best shake 'n' bake I've ever had. It should be called shank 'n' bake, because it will mess you up.

Next time I come here, I hereby carve in stone that I'll try whatever the vegan special is and drink tons of their juice-box wine. Also, that while I am enjoying my vegan special I will tenaciously bum some of YOUR fried chicken. So it is written!
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Laura B & I needed to get together to discuss minion control on behalf of fellow board member Miri D., who was out saving lives. She had sent us a memo of ways we could get more people to agree with her on the Talk boards. Also on the agenda was the fact that our own personal minions had gotten out of control. Not backing us up on Talk threads or sending us enough compliments. We have no self esteem and rely on social networking sites to pick up the slack from our incompetent parents. It was imperative we meet. 

We decided meet at The Front Porch, which was the perfect backdrop to discuss the aforementioned topics and also to discuss Yelp Royalty concerns like making people add us as their fan, deleting talk threads and discussing how we were morally superior for having join dates in 2005. Not only do they serve wonderful sangria, this joint is EXTREMELY vegetarian friendly. As you know, Miss LB is a vegan nazi and has been known to chop people's heads off if they eat meat in front of her. That bitch is NUTS! I got the fish & chips but told her it was seitan so I was safe. I hope she doesn't read this.

EDIT: The fried chicken here is NOTHING like the genetically modified disgustingness that is KFC. The breading is like a fancied up Shake & Bake, all spicy and yummy. The chicken was succullent and juicy and I couldn' t get enough. I subbed the black eyed peas and collards for the corn on the cob and not only was it buttery, it also had a super delightful spiciness to it that made it much better than anything I could have made at home in a pot of boiling water. Add some wine in a box, super cute interior and awesome waitstaff (including the doting but not hovering owner) and you have my new favorite restaurant in SF. I like it better than that other trendy new southern inspired cuisine place in the TL(you know what i'm talking about, people).
author: Maria D.

description: I was so excited when I saw this place, as my husband loves Southern (grew up with an Arkansas mama!) and this place is right in our neighborhood. The fried okra was very good, but my meal (the vegetarian option, chard with veggies) was not only a mess in terms of mesh of flavors and textures, but it tasted as if there were sand in my dish, which I can only assume was from chard which was not thoroughly washed. The service was great and I loved sitting by the kitchen, but don't think I'll be returning for dinner. It seems like it'd be a nice place to grab a drink though, and would totally go back for that.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
Besides sporting one of the great restaurant names, the Front Porch delivers on some great carribean/ soul food that would send your senses into a state of delirium.

... You are now entering into a state of deep relaxation...

Creamy grits with sweet corn

... Your tummy is content...

Sweet baby back ribs appetizer.

... Your eyes are getting heavy...

Delicious fried chicken with a hint of lemon served with popcorn in a popcorn box.

... You are getting sleepy...

Excellent hamburger with cheddar and bacon with a side of fries.

... Sleep... 

Box of Wine

... Sleep... 

Red Stripe Beer

... Sleep...

You are now in the state of 'Itis. You dream of a simple life... chilling on your front porch enjoying a delicious meal on a warm lazy afternoon/evening.

... When I count to 3 and snap my fingers you will awaken feeling a lot more relaxed and joyous...

1... 2... 3.... 

*SNAP!*
author: Sam T.

description:
Front Porch Review #486: It's no wonder the wait COULD be long. If you're prepared to wait, bring an extra layer. There are some rocking chairs out front.

Estimated Arrival Time: 6:30pm on a Saturday.

Parking: Corner of San Jose Avenue and 29th, less than a block away.

Wait Time: Zero minutes, a few other tables also open. Just two of us, so even easier to get a table. I would probably only come here with five or fewer.

Drinks: I forget the name of what I ordered. MANDARIN something with kumquat. It was refreshing and tasty. D had the KIR ROYALE - black currant liquor and champagne.  We love our black currant liquor.

All food was shared between the two of us. 

Starters: CORN BREAD w/ chili butter, SPICY CRAB & GRITS with peas, scallions, and lemon butter. Fantastic. Yum. Creamy, crabby goodness. D likes neither peas nor grits, and yet she licked the dish clean. It was THAT good. PICKLED SALAD served on a Chinese soup spoon. From the kitchen, they told us - thanks!

Main Courses: MISS OLLIE'S FRIED CHICKEN with garlic potatoes [w/ something pickled] and sauteed spicy spinach [replaced the Bajan coleslaw]. Extra crispy skin, moist and tender meat on the inside. FISH CUTTER [changes daily], which happened to be a fried oyster sandwich, with fries [zesty ketchup, similar to a BBQ sauce] and macaroni pie [not very cheesy]. By the time we got to this entree, we were stuffed. We managed to finish the sandwich [fried oysters = YUM!].

Service: Friendly, speedy, accommodating, awesome. They warned us about the house-made hot sauce [habanero!]. That shit is spicy. I dare not touch it, but D can vouch for that one.

Left with: No room for dessert. One piece of fried chicken. Some garlic potatoes. A lot of macaroni pie. Some fries. A Front Porch matchbook. A Front Porch sticker.

$$: Reasonably priced for leaving ridiculously stuffed and with lunch for the next day. 

Approximate Departure Time: 7:35pm. Service was fast, and/or we chowed down like there was no tomorrow. Seriously though, we ordered. I took a quick bathroom break, and our appetizer was already on the table.

Minus 0.5 star for 5lbs gained in one sitting. You think I'm fibbing. I stepped on the scale today. I'm the heaviest that I have EVER been. NO THANKS TO YOU, FRONT PORCH!
author: Tinna H.

description:
My father is from the Charleston, SC which makes me a southern girl by birth.

Southern people know good food and they aren't ever afraid to eat it.  Why do you think everything is bigger in the south?  And I'm not talking about peaches, son.  I'm talking about thighs, cankles and spare tires.  If they aren't BIG, then you are doing something wrong, and by wrong I mean, lay off the salads and have some red beans and rice for godsake.

The Front Porch has embraced the bigger is better philosophy, and is working really hard to make me fat (fatter?).

Out to dinner with six of the hottest ladies I know, we shocked and awed the other patrons by ordering a round of tall boy Red Stripes and taking them down like it was not our job, but our god given duty.

Feeling buzzed, we then proceeded to dive into the eating portion of the event.  

Waldorf Salad (walnuts on the side -- Hi Nance), Corn and White Fish Fritters, two Buckets of Fried Chicken, Crab and Grits, Macaroni Pie, Black Eyed Peas, Collards and Mustard Greens all done up Family Style, cause the girls that share together, get nice and fat together and live together with their 7 cats later in life when no one wants them and they can eat frosting out of the can free of judgment together.

We finished everything -- save four pieces of AMAZING fried chicken.  And if you looked real hard, you could see me and my Texan friend sopping up the leftover grits with pieces of chicken skin.  

Ummm, yeah.  That's how we roll.

The price tag for added back fat was relatively moderate as well.  Back fat, if done right, can be pretty pricey.  

Not only was adding a layer for the winter cheap, but the waiter and host at my new favorite restaurant were super complimentary and told us that the booth we were sitting in had never looked better.

I have to agree.  I have never seen anything prettier than seven skinny to average girls who eat like fat girls, drink beer like frat boys and swear like sailors, either. 

It's magic.
author: Rachel G.

description:
Apparently a cute guy looked at me while I was eating at The Front Porch. I didn't see him, but my friends did and they said he was hot and he was staring at me. 

My hands were slathered in grease, there were dried bits of grits on the sides of my mouth, I was chugging a 24 oz. bottle of Red Stripe, and I was surrounded by models and women with really pretty teeth...I think the guy may have had too many sangrias, or drumsticks, or my friends were just lying to me to make me feel better for being the oldest bitch at the table (although they were laughing and sounded surprised).

Either way, the chicken was fried, the mac was cheesy (although not quite enough for my palate), and the grits and crab were dish-licking proper. 

The host kindly noted the hotness that was our table, and I kindly noted, in my head, the hotness that was our host.

Our waiters (gray splotch and Anthony Rapp) were extraordinarily helpful and didn't spit in the food of my friends who came all the way out from the Marina. I mean, the girls DID wear skinny jeans. You've got to give them some points there. I may have even seen an ironic t-shirt too.

Other then the lackage of heat-lamps on the front porch, the experience was birthday-tastic.
author: Sammy S.

description:
So I really wanted to like The Front Porch, and probably will go back for another shot, but on first attempt it just wasn't all that.

While waiting for our table at the bar (30-45 minute wait at 6:30 on a Friday night!), we had a few drinks and took in the atmosphere. There is a down home and local sort of feel, and what I liked was the surprising dearth of hipsters. Just a lot of people from the neighborhood, ourselves excluded. Our bartender was cool if a little lackadaisical, but that seemed to go fine with the laid back vibe.

When our table was ready, we were seated in a somewhat tight booth, but still pretty comfortable.Our waiter arrived, seemingly breathless, just to tell us that five other tables were also sitting down now and that it would be a bit before he got back to us. Um, what?

So this became the theme of the night: 
"You want water, no problem." It arrives fifteen minutes later.
"It's so busy, but I'll be right back. I have five tables to serve!"
"Don't try this dish, not that good, and we might be out of it."

Items arrived sporadically, and in the case of our potatoes, not at all. The corn bread was pretty good, but not salted enough. The Bucket of Fried Chicken was my favorite thing on the menu, but just not enough of a reason to frequent the place (A bucket comes with 2 sides, although for $29, this ain't no Popeyes!). Maybe I'd sit at the bar and split an order with a buddy - or try their Porch Burger -over a bottle or two of St. Peter's Ale or something...

So while the food could be improved here and there, and I'm sure they'll get into their stride (the grilled steak with roasted fresno chilies seems worth a return trip), it was our service that really brought down our experience. I hate to say it but our waiter needs to be kicked off the porch.
author: Nish N.

description:
(to be fair, I had just got back from a week in New Orleans when I ate here)

The gumbo was very good. The fried chicken...it was tasty, but for some reason just didn't do it for me. Greens where excellent

Abita turbodog was a nice treat. A solid, if not amazing Lousiana meal.
author: Stephen W.

description:
The Front Porch's biggest sin is that, like too many hip Mission places, it doesn't accept reservations for parties smaller than five, which can be a real pain if you're hungry.  In this case, however, it turned out to be a blessing in disguise, since the other two members of my party besides my wife and me arrived quite late, and the hostess, who was absolutely delightful and accommodating, made sure we were well cared for.  My wife and I had the salt cod fritters, which were hot, delicious, soft, and moist, along with a large bottle of Duvel, the combination of which quickly eased our initial annoyance at the 45-minute wait to be seated (the hostess' estimate; our actual wait would have been shorter but for our friends' tardiness).  We were able to have our appetizer and beer on the patio, which allowed us to avoid having to crowd at the bar.

The Front Porch's other sin, revealed once we were seated, was that they had allowed a mariachi player to infest the restaurant.  Mariachi is my least favorite form of music on Earth, so not everyone may find this as much of a disadvantage.  Fortunately, he only played one or two songs, asked for money (which I might have given him in order to prevent him from playing), and then left before we started eating.

My wife and I split the bucket of chicken, which was enough not only for dinner but for subsequent lunches as well.  I can't recall the wine we ordered, but it was fruity and well-suited to the nouveau soul food.  The chicken came with red beans and rice, both of which were also quite satisfying.  Our companions were in the midst of an argument, so I can't say whether they enjoyed their meals, per se, but they did get doggie bags.  We were all too full for dessert, unfortunately.

Overall, the experience was very pleasant and just the thing for a chilly night.
author: Bitter J.

description:
Fried chicken. That's pretty much all one has to say to pique my interest. Who am I kidding, fried ANYTHING and I come running. So when I heard that The Front Porch had great fried chicken it didn't take long before I was sliding my ass into one of their booths.

The menu is small and seasonal. There are always specials, be it ceviche, entree or sangria and a changing vegan entree. Mini corn-shaped corn bread is brought out with honey chili butter. If you thought butter was delicious before, try it with honey and chili. I want to put this stuff on EVERYTHING! Also, mini things in general are awesome. I like to pretend that instead of things being small, that I am actually abnormally large. What? You don't do that? Oh, OK, I'M the weirdo. Screw you guys.

The wife got the pork chop special with butternut squash puree and slaw. It was either brined or rubbed with Caribbean spices and was delicious. I would have been jealous if  I wasn't stuffing my face with fried chicken and grits. I found the dessert menu a little uninspiring but thankfully Mitchell's Ice Cream is practically right across the street...and I don't pass up Mitchell's. Overall, I really enjoyed the cool atmosphere, relaxed friendly service and solid, soulful food. I most certainly will return.

Oh, and another thing that added to the awesomeness was the fact that they were playing the entire "Money For Nothing" album by Dire Straits. Just so you know, "Sultans of Swing" has one of the sweetest guitar solos IN ALL OF ROCK HISTORY!!! OK, maybe not, but I still had to fight the urge to fly into an episode of frantic air guitaring.
author: Josua P.

description:
Crispy fried chicken served in a popcorn 'bucket,' black eyed peas, and grits.   

The chicken was oh my sweet jay-sus good!  - Juicy, crispy, great flavor,  corn meal breading, and not greasy!!! The House hot sauce is HOT!!!

If fried chicken wasn't a heart attack waiting happen  I would have this all the time!

There's like 550 plus reviews, do you really need to read anymore?!!?  Just freaking go already!
author: Jenn A.

description:
Good things come to those who wait.  

So even if they tell you it's a 45-minute wait (at 8:45pm on a Monday night, with the place hopping like it's Saturday night), exercise your patience and refrain from the temptation to go somewhere else.  It's worth it.  

Part 1:  The Wait
Managed to score a table with some rocking chairs on the "porch" section just outside the front door of the restaurant.  Ordered a bottle of cidre doux, a few beers, and some snacks to tide us over.
Rock, Talk, Munch, Drink, Rock, Talk, Munch, Drink.

Sweet & Spicy Nuts - really good, toasted nuts covered in a layer of powdered sugar and spices.

Chicken Liver & Mount Gay Rum Pate - if you like chopped liver, you will probably love this dish.  I love chopped liver.  Not crazy about the mango preserves served with it, but enjoyed all of the other flavors very much.

Part 2:  Supper
We were seated in a cozy booth along the side of the restaurant.  I liked everything about the ambiance, from the tin ceilings to the blue painted walls to the lace curtain above the kitchen area.  It feels very Deep South, in a dripping-with-Spanish moss, Low-Country way.  Think Patsy Cline on the stereo (although we heard Tom Waits, too).  But this is definitely an urban Southern experience - as the place hustles and buzzes, with plate after plate leaving the kitchen and making their way to the hungry diners.

Corn Bread - made in the cast-iron corn molds that you often see at flea markets - in the shape of corn!  Those kinds of details make me very happy.  Served with jalapeno butter.

Salt Cod with Cod Fritters- this was a special appetizer, and it was so good.  The Fritters were unlike any other I've had - light and savory.
The Salt Cod was tender with a drizzle of lemon oil for a citrusy richness.

Miss Ollie's Organic Fried Chicken - mmmm, mmmm!  We got a whole bucket to share, and it is so tender and juicy, like the buttermilk-soaked kind that your grandmama used to make (like I WISH mine had).  The seasoning is very good - salty and citrusy at the same time.  

Fish & Chips - also really good - fried in a light batter, with moist fish inside, a great homemade Tartar Sauce and EXCELLENT coleslaw.

Dungeness Crab and Sweet White Corn Grit Porridge - tasty, but extremely rich.  Very buttery.

Street Corn - grilled, blackened corn-on-the-cob.  Very good.

Grit Porridge with Scallions and Chili Oil - DELICIOUS.  I love grits to death, and this is one of the very best preparations I have ever had.  So smooth and creamy, with the bite of chili oil - a perfect food.  The waitress told us that she has a customer who comes in once a week and regularly orders 2 portions of this dish - one to eat right then, and one to take home.  I think that sounds perfectly reasonable!

The portions are large, so try to get a tight booth so that you can unbutton your pants discreetly.  Wait, did I just write that?  ;)

Service was very good and the people are nice and seem to genuinely love working there, always a bonus for me with any dining experience.

Special notes:  
Very interesting beer list.
Vegan options that sound inventive and amazing.

Must-haves for next time:  Dessert & a Juice Box of Wine with a Bendy Straw

Will definitely go back to have some more of Sarah's home-cooking and a relaxed evening with friends.  Front Porch is by far my new favorite Southern-Style restaurant in the city - rock on!
author: Liz S.

description:
I went there for the first time recently, and we really enjoyed myself. I had the fried chicken that everyone's raving about, and I agree--Really good.  Brined and fried! What WON"T taste good brined & fried!?! My wife had the pork chop dish, which unfortunately, had to be sent back, since it wasn't completely cooked. (-1 point). Also, the hushpuppies we're recommended, but they we're slightly overcooked. (I'm nitpicking, but, it was still good.) I nitpick, because I've heard so many great reviews, so my expectations were a little raised. 
The vibe reminds me of some of the kitschy groovy decorated places in Austin, TX, (Which I've just checked out recently...) Very bohemian, very fun and unpretentious. The staff was awesome, and I'd totally go back. A great place in SF that makes SF a great place!
author: Greg C.

description:
Sigh. Another place that makes me feel like "I don't get it." A feature in 7x7 several months ago, 2 Yelp ROTDs, and many more glowing Yelper reviews led me to believe that the Front Porch had reinvented fried chicken the way that XXX reinvented XXX (you can probably come up with something wittier than I can). Admittedly, the chicken wasn't BAD. The meat did have quite a punchy tang to it, though a little too much in my opinion, thus detracting from the joy of eating the crispy cornmeal (albeit overseasoned) crust/skin. It was also d-r-y, which to me is b-a-d. Moreover, I am a dark meat kind of gal and was very upset to find nary a succulent thigh in the paper bucket. $30 freakin' dollars for fried chicken and you can't give me any juicy thigh-action?!?! Eating fried chicken has never made me so sad!

The rest of the meal echoed my ambivalent sentiments of the chicken. 
- Cornbread served w/ honey chili butter: the cute ear of corn shape tricks you into liking these more than is warranted. A bit dry, but one of my friends liked them enough to get a second order - which we were not informed was an extra charge. :-/

- Conch-Habanero fritters: I had to convince my gastronomically-conservative friends to try these out by telling them that "it tastes like shrimp." Truth is that I totally forgot what they tasted like. If they taste like shrimp, I couldn't really tell because the spices that they use overpower any conch flavor. They were a little chewy, which suggests being overdone. Accompanying aoli was pretty good though and cut into the too-intense flavor of the breading.

- Jerk entree of the day was steak tips: isn't it customary to ask for how well you want steak done?  Well, we weren't asked. Luckily it came out medium done, which was acceptable to me. The potato salad served with the dish did not seem to match up with the steak in flavor or texture; too bland and undercooked potatoes.

- Sides: 
1) Fries Three Ways (home, sweet, and french): the concept induces more excitement than actually eating them. Though it was kind of fun to try and guess which was the sweet. Maybe we got a bad batch - oily and limp. Sad fries! Must say that their homemade ketchup and mayo that comes with the fries were excellent.
2) Sauteed greens: first off, we thought we had ordered the black-eyed peas with collard greens, not the sauteed mustard greens. Oh well, we ate them anyway. Bitter, as expected, and nothing special about the flavor.
3) Coconut red beans and rice: yum. Definitely a departure from traditional red beans and rice, lighter even with the use of coconut milk. This saved my tongue from falling off when I made the mistake of using the habanero (I think, it was yellow) hot-sauce on my chicken...holy crap, I almost asked for a glass of milk. Be warned!

- Libations: an  interesting, extensive drink menu. Happy that there was $3.50 Pacifico. And get this...they serve malt liquor. Some Yelpers will appreciate this more than I can.

It might sound like I didn't enjoy my meal, but that's not really the case. Perhaps that is the danger in doing too much research before eating somewhere...there is a much greater chance of disappointment. Foodwise, yeah it was a'ight. Quite a pricy meal for what I considered 3 star tastiness. In my opinion, what makes the Front Porch a destination location is more for the atmosphere of refined Southern comfort. From the wooden porch and rocking chairs out front to the comfortable booths to the gorgeous tin roof to the charming, ethereal waitstaff, I felt like I was in another city - one smaller, homier, friendlier than San Francisco. In the future, I would welcome a trip back to see if the food can match up with Front Porch's aesthetic.
author: Steph P.

description:
D and I went here on the recommendation of one of his coworkers as our prior dinner plans got cancelled at the last minute. We took Muni from my house to the Mission, getting off a little early to walk through the Twilight Zone of Noe/Bernal/Outer Mission, walking past El Rio, Mi Lindo Peru, Good Frikkin Chicken, 26 Mix and all of my former Mission haunts, getting lost, asking for directions from a really nice man off the street and finally entering the cutest little cajun restaurant this side of the Mississippi.

The Front Porch is small, quirky, intimate and fun. We seated ourselves at the counter as there was already a small wait at 6:30pm on a Friday night, with a bartender that I've seen somewhere else (and still haven't figured out where), a mariachi player playing Spanish love songs (swoon) and a hodge-podge of old Southern knick-knacks and heirlooms that would make any granny-belle jealous.

The menu displayed all the variations of comfort only a traditional belle in the kitchen could create. Fried chicken, ribs, grits, collard greens, corn, shrimp, stews, black eyed peas, etc. 

We started with some crab and corn grits. I think we almost licked the plate clean. Cornbread and pepper butter accompanied our starter; it was buttery and light and perfectly matched with the spicy butter.

Actually, everything we ordered had a little bit of kick to it. Our bucket of fried chicken came with a side of stewed black eyed peas, collard greens and pork belly, and another side of grits (this time with a smoked pepper butter). The fried chicken was the killer dish, though, with a cracker/cornmeal crust and an herbed brine, and fried to light/crispy perfection. It arrived in a popcorn bucket with bits of popped corn adorning the chicken and plate.

I wanted to stuff my face silly, but had enough self control to save some room for dessert. Blue cheese drenched in brandied cherry honey and served with little toasts.

The bartender was gracious and provided excellent suggestions. I noticed that he kept his even temper as a pompous and rude guest got unnecessarily obnoxious after he made an honest mistake in change. The bartender at the Front Porch exemplified true southern hospitality and goodwill, and never let that asswad faze him during the dinner service.
author: May T.

description:
Tonight was my second time at Front Porch.  The reason I wanted to go again was because my first time there was AWESOME.  The food was superb, service was quick and knowledgeable and the prices were just right.   THIS TIME, though, the prices and food were fine but the service was AWFUL.  We (two of us) sat at the bar for dinner.  Shayna, the bartender, was completely (or voluntarily) unaware of our existence.  We ordered two courses, and when the first course arrived, we were hesitant in asking for napkins, silverware and plates, since Shayna was busy talking to another guest about her new crush.  When our entrees arrived, the host who delivered the food was gracious enough to get us plates and whatever else we needed.

Not once during the course of service, did Shayna check back on us.  In fact, we asked for the bread that was supposed to accompany our meal and our food questions were met with, not answers, but puzzled looks and exasperated sighs.  AWESOME.  

Basically, Shayna shouldn't be working in the service industry.  We gave her 20%, simply because we work in the industry, and our consciences would not allow us to do otherwise.  However, Shayna's service was worth about a 4% tip, if that.  Sorry if we ruined your night, by wanting to pay for food and service, Shayna.  Here's a suggestion, get another job that doesn't involve making people happy.
author: Camille C.

description:
It seems that lately when I go out with a friend, we have a Plan B.  This applies to pizza, where Little Star is our backup.  Emmy's Spaghetti Shack was our Plan B to this place.

I have been here once before, and the first time, while I don't remember what I had, I DO remember it was good.  I don't know what happened between now and then.  You all know about the dark interior, and how loud it gets, so we'll skip all that.

The corn bread starter was very good, with chili butter.  My friend does not like spicy food much, and I wanted her share of the "red stuff", but she selfishly didn't give me any!  No matter ... it was still good.  And possibly the second best part of the meal?

I was intrigued by the Grilled Hearts of Romaine Salad.  We had the bacon on the side.  The dressing was an interesting combination of Avocado and Habanero.  I guess I was expecting more heat.  The lettuce was more than grilled ... it was burnt and resembled burnt paper on some parts.  I don't know if it actually TASTED like burnt paper, but it clearly resembled that.  We should have stuck with the "Doubles" of Chickpea and Butternut Squash.  

My friend had the Vegan Stew, and she says it resembled regular vegetables simmered in ketchup.  She did not find it appetizing at all, and only mustered a few bites.  For me, it was a toss up between the fried chicken, and the Bajan Bavette.  I should have chosen the former, but didn't since they have that every day.  The hanger steak, which is reported to be one of the most flavorful steak, lacked said flavor.  The thyme crust ruled that out.  The accompanying Onion Strings were a bit cold, and I never got to try the Broccoli Rabe before we decided to head out.  We did order the Corn on the cob, and it was tasty, and makes me want to grill my own ... if only I can FIND yellow corn!

The service is good, and the waiter recommended a good bottle of red wine to compliment both my friends vegetables and my steak.  We had the Sere Grenache, which was very nice ...

Like I said ... it's good to have a Plan B.
author: Michael M.

description:
I've been a fried chicken freak since I was a kid so I was looking forward to trying out Front Porch for the first time.  First, the beers on tap are great!  I had the Gator and my friend had the Big Daddy.  For dinner we ordered the fried okra, plantains, spicy shrimp and grits.  For dinner, it of course was the fried chicken and a side of mac-n-cheese.
Here are my ratings:

Fried okra: ehh...3 stars (not bad, not great)

Plantains: 3 stars (little dry, nice portions)

Spiy shrimp and grits: 4.5 stars (this was the best dish of the night)

Fried chicken: 3.5 stars (too much coating, a little over cooked but at least the insides were moist.  I still prefer Roscoes, or Glady's Knights in Atlanta, and I have to admit even the fried chicken at Whole Foods Market)

Mac-n-cheese: 4 stars (hot, bubbly, maybe two different cheeses)

Our server was Amy and she was great.  For dessert we had the Chocolate Pecan Chess Pie with a scoop of Mitchells Ice Cream and of course that was divine!

Atmosphere was cozy and very neighborly.  Overall we spent about 3 hours there enjoy the meal and company.  Definitely a place to go back to.
author: M V.

description:
I am not a huge fan of reviewing places that have over 150 reviews, but i thought in this case id put my $.02 in.

I went here with a party of 7 last night, a few of whom i didn't know before, and actually turned out to be Elite Yelpers as well.  Pretty random.

We did make reservations,  their timing on it was only off by a few minutes, and we got sat in a booth built for 7.  It might have been the only larger booth in the place, and no more people would have possibly fit.  We sat there chatting it up for a bit, but it took us a good 10 minutes to get menus.  My roommate had to ask the server for them.  This was one of the few hiccups that occurred during our evening.  I say they were merely hiccups because i had a really great time, and truly enjoyed the food, and would definitely come back here to eat again.

The corn shaped cornbread is great...my roommate and i shared a Bistro salad, the Seabass special of the day and the Pork chop.  Everyone at the table was happy with their meals, and i tried many of the other dishes, including the side of brussel sprouts which were outstanding.

So the Pork Chop arrives , and two of us have ordered it at the table.  We both look at the chop, see its served with french fries and the other sides that were listed to be served with the Rib-eye.  It looks a little dark for pork, but we cut into it and its quite delicious, but tastes an awful lot like steak as well....but its pink in the middle and that's how she said the pork was served.  Now i don't know why i was doubting my meat knowledge.  The other girl who ordered it said she hadn't had pork in 10 years, but the fact that it took me two bites, and me doubting myself enough to finally call the waitress over and tell her that we received the rib-eye and not the pork chop, disappoints me greatly.  A GIRL SHOULD KNOW HER MEAT!!  After an apology and the right meal being served, we were all happy.  

They were very nice about the whole thing, and for me that's important.  The way i looked at it after i left, was "man that pork was good, and maybe next time ill order the rib-eye because that was tasty too!"  Had they been assholes, it would have been another story.

One of the best parts of this place, aside from their signature fried chicken (another member of our party had that), is that they have a very random, fun wine list.  We got our wine in a jug, and you could have also ordered wine that comes in a juice box.  Something different to make for an enjoyable meal worth talking about.

The ambiance in this place is also great...dimly lit for a date evening, with tin ceilings, dark furniture and a newer hip, urban feel.  For music I think that they just play their ipod at a reasonable volume, which is OK by me because last night we were listening to Beck and Radiohead, two of my personal favorites.
author: Lauren F.

description:
3.5 stars.  I love fried chicken.  Not in the "I'm going to KFC for lunch" way but when the craving hits, there's no stopping me.  So when I heard about The Front Porch I just had to give it a try.  The food was pretty good-the chicken had a lot of flavor to the batter and was hot and crispy.  If you go with a large party definitely split a bucket-9 pieces w/ 2 sides for $29 compared to 2 pieces w/1 side for $11 if you order individually.  

Service was kind of scattered-our waitress was really friendly but mentioned to us a couple of times how slammed she was which I thought was weird.  We asked how many pieces came with the side of corn and were told 2.  Four of us wanted corn so we asked for 2 orders of it...when the waitress brought out the food she said she was mistaken and it was only 1 piece per order and only brought us 2 pieces.
