We went ahead and ordered 2 more pieces (because splitting corn on the cob just ain't happening) but it would have been a nice gesture on her part if she had just realized her mistake and brought out the extra 2 pieces initially.  

Also, at this point they are only taking reservations for parties of 5 or greater...since we had 5 people we were able to get a reservation but were seated at a table for 4 with a chair stuck on the end.  Not very comfy for 5 adults.

All told it was a fun night out-good food, decent prices, cool space (The Front Porch even has a cute little front porch)  I'll probably be back but I'll give them some time to work the kinks out first.
author: phil h.

description:
I originally thought Farmer Brown had the best fried chicken in San Francisco.  No, I was wrong.  The Front Porch with their cornmeal crusted, juicy, and full of flavor down to the bone chicken takes top spot in my book.  The great thing about this restaurant is the affordability factor.  It is good eating for a lot less than I expected.  

Their appetizers range from $5-10.  Highlights were the fried chicken livers served on top of gravy toast with sauteed onions and the Bistro Salad that could have used at least 2 more oysters.  Avoid the ceviche unless you like tangy and sour because the salmon pieces are placed in a cup of this sour concoction.  You almost have to bob for the fish pieces with your fork.  

Sides were also hit or miss.  We enjoyed the black eye peas with collagreens.  We didn't like the fries because they are the thick kind and the coleslaw which followed the too sour theme.  

If you order the right items, this place is well deserving of the 4 stars.  Be prepared for a wait because it can get crowded.  For the alcoholics, they only have a beer and wine license!
author: Jason A.

description:
A coupla thoughts on the Front Porch:

1) the friday dinner crowd could not by any stretch of the imagination be called hipsters. good thing or bad - you make the call.

2) the food by and large was pretty mediocre - steak grisly and underdone, potatoes in the potato salad were also underdone. the vaunted crab risotto was too smooth and the crab tasted simultaneously watery and dry. the brussels sprouts had no flavor. the okra - well, i will never like okra. HOWEVER...

3) the chicken was pretty great.

I can't recommend this restaurant at all but it's OK if you stick with the fried chicken.
author: Al B.

description:
Service, service, service - I harp on this endlessly in my reviews and I stand by my perspective that service can make or break an experience.  However - I must say that the food at Front Porch has driven service to the very back corner of my (admittedly tiny) mind.

I had the avocado, radish and salty broth appetizer - yum.  Followed by the crabmeat and sweet corn grit entree - let me just say that I have yet to experience the orgasm-by-food, but this came awfully close.  Fiends at the table had the black eyed peas (good) and the fried chicken (succulent and fabulous).  We all left fat, happy and very full.

I must call out that they lost our reservation (get on Opentable, dammit!) and we ended up seated at a booth for four with a chair on the end, which was quite awkward.  But our waitress turned down the music when asked, and was quite knowledgeable on the menu.  

Overall - great food, 'meh' service and interesting atmosphere.  I am definitely interested in returning to try more.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
Loved this place. Came here on a friday night and we were told it was going to be a forty minute wait, so we decided to get a drink at the bar. The sangria was amazingly tasty made with guava puree, rose wine and a splash of bubbles. So refreshing. Luckily what was going to be a forty minute wait ended up being just fifteen minutes. Bonus!
We started off with the gumbo. The chicken and sausage were tender and tasty, not overly cooked and just the right amount! The fried okra just made the dish perfect. For the main course we ordered the fried chicken which came with mashed taters and collard greens. The only reason this place doesn't get 5 stars is because you can't sub out the boring collard greens for extra taters or at least something with taste and not so BLAH. We also got a side of brussel sprouts which was cooked to perfection. Capers, lemon and butta, need I say more??
author: Kehaulani K.

description:
Update: We've gone twice more since the initial review -- not as fantastic but the place is still super busy and the staff is still nice. The vegan okra entree I had on our second visit was just not a good balance with tomatoes and plantains -- felt like it was just sides thrown together with no forethought. And no tasty seasoning salt in sight!  Second visit was better, although I wish server had noted that my combination of bean-ish soup with bean-ish side of black-eyed peas might be a little too, well, bean-ish as a meal (vegan entree was AGAIN okra, so I passed...). Please look into some additional veggie entrees to offer your loyal leftie customers! We want to love you Front Porch!  PS If you've read this far, here's a tip -- tell the host you'll go wait for a table at the 3300, then head down 29th for a drink. 

OK, so this is my first Yelp review and here I thought, since this place opened yesterday, I might be the first or even second reviewer -- no dice -- this site is crazy hip, apparently!  Or just really popular with my little corner of the Mission, since I also live about 30 yards away from The Front Porch.  My boyfriend and I have eagerly awaited its opening since moving here in May, and we were not disappointed with our opening night dinner.  

The atmosphere, staff, food -- the whole shebang, basically -- were all great. Walked in and, since we got there early (learned our lesson from sister hangout Emmy's, which we also adore), got seated right away at a table in back -- my spot was an old bench seat from a car, seatbelt still attached.  Dolly was crooning something when we arrived, and later we caught snippets of Robert Johnson-ish blues.  I think the music picked up the tempo a bit later in the evening. Patterned tin (?) ceiling and checkered linoleum floor were homey, and the bare walls seemed to be waiting for art. I picked up the receiver to a pay phone near our table to check for a dial tone and nope -- pay phones are now just a decorative retro-prop, a fact that makes me feel about 100 years old!

The food is unique and very tasty, and they had a solid beer and wine list and soft drinks included my favorite, ginger beer.  We opted for a jug of "Tres - something" red wine -- these jugs, once cleaned, seem to double for the water bottles, too. I love it that this place and Emmy's both leave water on your table -- how simple!  How wonderful when scarfing up garlicy and/or spicy fare not to have to desperately flag down a harried server every five minutes!  Why don't more places do this? Sorry, I digress...

Anyway, my honey had the pickled veggies with egg as an app and I had the green salad with sugary mustardy vinaigrette.  I sampled his veggies -- fresh, crunchy, delicious pickling -- don't think of a nasty old egg in a jar at Moe's bar for this fare, please!  Veggies included beets and green and wax beans -- wax beans!  Suddenly I'm five and getting a no-thank-you helping from my mom, only this time it's "more please!"
I don't do eggs but honey said it was fab.  

The veggies also came with a cute, teeny bowl of homemade seasoning salt that I promptly confiscated for my beautiful, fresh, but a little bit bland green salad -- this salt is to die for, seriously.  The hot sauce and catsup on the tables are homemade, too, we were told, and the hot sauce was H*O*T.  As noted by others, the cornbread was wonderful, crumbly but moist with a slightly crisp exterior -- and cutely shaped like baby corn, I can picture the cast-iron mold! I ate mine plain with some of that crackalicous seasoning salt while my honey enjoyed with butter.

For entrees we had the vegan squash and rice (me) and crab and grits something (him) -- both filling and delish.  I was thrilled to have a unique and labeled vegan entree to select and I hope there are more to come whenever the menu has seasonal changes.  There were two or three more things on the menu that looked to be vegan and I can't wait to try those on our next visit, which will be soon!

There were few cons and one would be understandable slowness on opening night, the salad being a wee bit bland, and once the place started jumping it was somewhat loud.  Quarters are tight between tables, at least in the back, and part of the noise was also the appealing open view to the kitchen. So, this definitely is just more of a heads-up if you're looking for a quiet, romantic evening -- get here early or just have a drink at the bar and enjoy the front porch -- yes, there really is one!
author: Karen W.

description: Wow, I can't believe how much positive reviews this place has gotten but I regrettfully will not be writing one.  We were seated promptly service was good.  They gave us corn bread which was served with sweet butter chilli spread.  It was good.  We ordered the cerviche and to my surprise it was very acidic that I couldn't taste the seafood.   We ordered the fried chicken but I was surprised how dry and how tasteless the chicken seemed to be.  I don't know if we caught them on their off day when we came in on Tuesday.   We also ordered their crab (I don't believe it was fresh crab, it tasted like canned crab) with corn grits -- it was okay - I wished the grits had more flavor.  Sorry folks.
author: pengrin ..

description: I love this place! I had driven by it so many times and I finally decided to look it up and see what it was. I went today for the first time with my mom to celebrate her birthday (we checked out their online menu and when she saw grits she decided right then this was the place). The staff was so friendly and helpful. While deciding what we wanted we asked the staff what they recommended and they were honest about their personal favorites. I ended up trying the fried chicken&waffles, and let me say it was amazing. My mom tried the spicy shrimp and grits and she cleaned her plate faster than I did. We also tried the beignets and they were delicious. Not only will I recommend this place to my friends I'll be dining there again.
author: Angee R.

description:
391 others have already talked about this, I will add my 2 cents.

My housemate has been sick the past few days and strangely craving fried chicken. Her guy friend figured out a place in Berkeley to go and they thoughtfully invited me to go with - but the Bay Bridge was a parking lot. We exited at the last possible moment and considered our option. iPhone to the rescue (not mine.... I have a cheap arse normal phone). A bit of searching and the Front Porch came up. And zip, we were on our way.

Thankfully we were there a bit before 7, so the wait was nil. To all you people complaining of the wait, eat earlier!  We were quickly informed that there were specials, but no. We were on a mission. "How much isi n the bucket?" "Oh, about 10 pieces" "Fantastic, that's what we'll have." 

I started out with a beet salad, which was good quite delicious, especially the fried onion bits. The greens were a bit stemmy, but as a gestalt, it was quite good. My "dining companions" had a Waldorf salad, which completely disappeared, so it must have been at least decent!

Next came the main course. Chicken, macaroni pie, and french fries. Wow, this stuff was remarkably freaking awesome. The chicken was moist, with crispy skin and with a wonderfully flavorful batter. The mac and cheese pie was rich and delicious. The fries were a mix of sweet and russet potatoes, along with a spicy dipping ketchup. Yum.

And then dessert. I had the pets de nonne, which I now see translates as Nun Farts. Wow, that's even better than I would have imagined. The housemate's guy had the spiced pear, which was so good he did everything but lick his bowl clean. 

Ugh, and I forgot to mention the cornbread and chili butter. So good, I almost wanted to eat the butter plain. 

So yeah, maybe it's not cheap, maybe it gets crowded (there were a lot of people waiting when we were heading out) but man is it delicious. I will indeed be going back!
author: neil c.

description:
440 reviews in their first 18 months of existence...is that a Yelp record?  And no less than 3 detailed and inspired reviews from my favorites.  So I won't bore you with more.  Besides, life (unlike the selection of trendy SF restaurants) is seeming a lot more finite all of a sudden (could it have something to do with eating here on my 26th birthday?), so I'm warming up to the virtues of the executive summary.

Suffice it to say, The Front Porch rules the uniquely San Franciscan quirky-comfort-food scene (try the Blue Plate a block up if you want more).  What's not to like?  Free cornbread?  Nice.  Fried Chicken (with sweet sweet macaroni)?  Delicious.  Inspired rotating vegan dish (in my case a risotto-stuffed bell pepper)?  Check.  Desserts to die for? Hell yes, try that pumpkin cake.  N'Awlins atmosphere?  You bet (almost made me wish it was hot & humid out).  Blatant gimmicks like the eponymous waiting area with rocking chairs or the booths made of car seats?  Natch.

Only reluctantly do I give out 5 stars to places whose entrees are over $15, but The Front Porch can take my money any day.
author: Wes M.

description:
PORK BELLY!

it's kind of what you'd expect. a sliced up chunk of pig fat! ew ew ew to the max. i took one bite and had to give the rest to lance, not because i didn't like it, but because i just couldn't get past the... pork fat. he ordered it anyway, i just didn't want to seem like a spoil sport by not trying new things.

super cute restaurant, tasty drinks, delicious food (i could dine on their succulent porch chops for the rest of my life & OMG SPICY CRAB GRITS - GIVE ME MORE) & attentive service.

go earlier to be able to have a conversation you can hear and to avoid the mad rush of people clamoring for fried chicken and fizzy guava sangria or you know, go later, if you enjoy that sort of thing.
author: Irene S.

description:
Best fried chicken ever!  Great service, fun atmosphere.  

Now that we have that out of the way, let's provide a bit more color to the experience:

Long story short, from the time we got to Front Porch to the time we paid and left was about 2.5 hours.  Actual sitting at a table (there were two of us) time was about 40 minutes.  Admittedly we showed up without reservations, but still, 2.5 hours is a long time, even if the food is excellent.  

We learned a little bit too late that they will call the 3300 Club 
http://www.yelp.com/biz/Js_bI7oepLbOfE3eADqjpQ?hrid=ks3BNCM2mh6T40q_BKZy6Q
if you tell them when you put your name in at Front Porch.  I like the 3300 Club more every time I go there.   

Parking in that part of the Mission can be crazy sometimes, but we managed to get parking within a block.  If you are adventurous, you might take a chance with parking in the Safeway parking lot.  

Great food, but you will definitely wait for it at peak times.  If we go back, we'll get there by 6.  I'm taking 1 star away for the long wait.  It sucks to be popular I guess.
author: Nelson W.

description:
Definitely get here before 7 to take advantage of the happy hour specials. Had some decent streak frites with amazing aioli, some really good churros, and decent spiced popcorn. Jalapeno cornbread was good, although I wish we got more. We split the shrimp and grits, which was absolutely delicious.

Wish it had been warmer so we could have sat outside. Just all in all a great place, nice chill vibe, good music, good decorations.
author: Mark A.

description: About as expected! Simple but well executed. Though the vegan dish, fantastic in the past, was a bit underwhelming.
author: sean m.

description:
Growing up in the South, I'm all about comfort food. Front Porch had promise, but ended up being a let down. I heard they had changed chefs which is why their popular crab and grits is no longer on the menu...seems like the rest of the food has suffered from this as well. 
[Recommendation: For a much better comfort/soul food restaurant in San Francisco, go to farmerbrown]

Baked Mac & Cheese - really oily and bland. They should have added a sharper cheese for contrast or at least something to give it some punch. Not sure how long the dish was sitting out before we got it, but the cheese was hard and congealed when they served it. I'm not picky about mac and cheese and usually love it in all forms, but this was the first bowl of mac and cheese that I did not finish (nor did even I want to).

Spicy Shrimp & Grits - it had a nice spicy flavor but the texture was all wrong. The grits were overly mushy and literally drowned in the sauce...it felt more like I was eating shrimp and mashed potato soup - the whole essence of the grits was completely lost. 

Momma Clara's Fried Chicken - finally, a good dish. The fried chicken was crispy on the outside and super juicy on the inside. I also enjoyed its citrus flavor. However, the mashed potatoes and vegetables on the side were lackluster. 

Needless to say, the food at Front Porch didn't provide much "comfort" at all. The service wasn't great either. Ironically, the best thing about the restaurant actually is their front porch - a cozy space with a rocking chair and two small tables.
author: Karin V.

description:
Something about names that brings you to your first memory of what it's referring to: FRONT PORCH... The best fried chicken I ever had- was on someone's front porch on a hot West Texan weather. It was a clandestine restaurant- the one where you get invited to by someone who knew the proprietors or were regular patrons...No formalities needed- just get a plate and pack it with the goodies on the table and comeback as many times as you want, just dont forget to leave the 10 dollar 'bill' on your way out with no tip necessary! This was Odessa, TX... where fine dining is what YOU make yourself!

I have been waiting for the right moment to go here- and well when I read today's ROTD- finally decided to give it a try...the fried chicken photo was just too tantalizing to pass up!
I figured since its a Sunday  it wouldn't be such a long wait- well 30 minutes got us our grub :-)
What we ordered from the menu:
Bucket Fried Chicken- about 10 pcs- I believe it is cornmeal/ bread crumb with spices- which fried to a dark amber color ...I thought one could have used a Pontchartrain batter mix and gotten the same effect... The bigger pieces had a tendency to be overdone-too compact and dry-  the drumsticks and wings were  juicy...I wonder if they marinated in buttermilk first? The bucket was about 30 dollars- highway robbery!  I know this is SF but I'm not dining in a 5 star restaurant either :-(
1-Taste/Flavor 8/10
2-Tenderness/Succulence 7/10
3-Crunchy factor 8.5/10
4-Overall appeal 8/10

The Green Salad was a mix of greens doused with a molasses vinaigrette dressing- too sweet for me!
The Collard greens with black-eyed peas were pleasant- wished they had real ham hocks in the brew- but diced ham was ok...
The fried liver on a bed of onion was already heavy and could have sufficed without the sweet marinade -  the bread was soggy , too oily from the butter.
We did not care for any dessert.
The service was mediocre- no Paula Dean sweetness emanating from our hosts :-( and well sadly I didn't hear "Y'all come back nahw" on our way out :-(

Best thing about this experience- I'm starting a new list- "Best Fried Chicken in town-"I'm accepting recommendations right now :-)
author: Arissa C.

description: Pulled pork and Yukon potato hash with poached eggs. Hangover cure. Add their chicory coffee and you're ready for the day
author: Echo R.

description:
No more crab and grits, my favorite.... And don't think that the shrimp and grits is any kind of a substitution, cuz it's not. I mean, it's OK, but it's not the old, soupy, creamy, delicious crab and grits.

I've been going to this place almost since it opened, and so I've eaten the food of each of the two chefs. The new chef has changed the menu quite a bit, which is kind of a shame, because the food doesn't seem as "different" or edgy anymore. I will need to get used to it.

That said, the service was amazing, and our server actually suggested I get a different salad that gave me more variety in my meal. Major bonus server action right there!

Cocktails: Mmmm, Lil Rouge Corvette!
The dungeness crab salad: delicious
Hogs headcheese turrine: My partner who loves gross things like headcheese really loved this.
Shrimp and grits: Eeew, shrimp heads, and gritty grits. Not a fan of this dish! It was sorta bland, too.
Fried chicken: good, but saltier than it used to be, says my partner.

Overall, I'm giving it 2 more tries before I write it off... and cry quietly.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
My boyfriend and I are always down for soul food!! Fried chicken, grits, shrimp gumbo, and all that Southernjazz!


I came here on a Monday night with my boyfriend and it was empty. I didn't feel that the reservations were needed, but whatevs. The restaurant was dark and casual. I can tell it was a place for hipsters from looking at our waitress and waiters. 

Booze: Thunderberg and a Champagne Cocktail

Bite:  
1. Corn bread -- complimentary starter
2. Chicken gumbo - Mm-mmmmmm. . I love a whole big pot o' gumbo served hot and bubbly. Gumbos usually overload with okra, giving the soup a very gooey texture, but this was perfect with a  blend of andouille sausages and rice. It had a bit of a smokey taste, but I loved it overall.
3. Shrimp & grits - This was the best part of my meal, as usual. I don't know how and when I got so obsessed with grits, but it has become my alternative to rice! The consistancy was great -- creamy and tasteful.
4. Mac & Cheese - My first impression was that their mac&cheese was really different than what I had. It wasn't an orange cheese they used, but rather a white cheese with a cream-cheese (sour) taste to it. I personally loved it and thought it was delicious and something new, but the boyfriend took a few bites and left it all for fatty me. :( 
5. Fried chicken - We came here specifically for this and it is probably the one thing I can do without next time eating at Front Porch. I can't seem to say I loved this bucket of fried chicken. It could be that by the time we got our order, the mashed potatoes, greens, and entire bucket was overwhelming to our full, round bellies. The battered could have been crispier and it tasted a bit burnt. *Shrug 



$97 later, our bellies were satisfied,  but the wallet wasn't.
author: Rosanne L.

description:
I got pretty drunk here on a combination of tall bottles of Red Stripe, tall cans of Budweiser, and numerous pints of beautiful Stella.  I also ate a lot food, including brussel sprouts, fries served  three different ways, and the vegan special of the night, which was, if I remember correctly, a bunch of coconut milk and fried things and other stuff.  It was better than it sounds -- not the best, mind you --  but better than how I care to describe it.  

Just having a vegan special is pretty sweet, although I always prefer more options.**  Call me selfish, but so what? A man's gotta eat! 

Everyone had a great time, and I think the beer +  the company was the best part.  The host and other employees were absolute sweethearts, making the experience way more fun. Plus, the actual establishment is pretty dang cute.  Awww.

**Actually, I sort of don't like too many options because of my Midwestern, vegetarian roots. Therefore, if there's anything more than, like, a grilled cheese, some sort of crappy pasta or a veggie burger on a menu, then I get really overwhelmed and flustered.  Hang ups, shmang ups, shut the fuck up.
author: Chloe S.

description: Great little hidden gem. Nice friendly staff. Had a beer with my BF here last Sunday. They have a great quiet cozy outside seating area. I will definitely go here again.
author: Jo A.

description:
Yeah. Mmmmmm. Uh huh.

Vegan soul food. I've been waiting for that one. 

Vegan CORN BREAD. I've been waiting for THAT one. I mean, GOOD vegan cornbread. Not that crap stuff that's just all gross and crumbly because it doesn't have any butter in it. 

I HATE when vegan food makes me miss all the stuff that ain't in it. But I didn't miss anything in my meal here. Instead, I was busy thinking about all the good stuff that WAS in it. Like the coconut in the special vegan stew that night... That subtly rich flavor mingling with the tomatoes and the okra...

Mm mm MMM!!!

My Front Porch night was one of those rare occasions where I was a totally satisfied, 100% happy, stuffed-to-the-gills dietarily challenged girl and proud of it. 

Because I had a meal as good as yours, and mine will only make me half as fat!

Score 1 for the dietarily challenged!
author: Lisa T.

description:
This place is cooler than I am.  

Which is a pretty damn hard thing to achieve...cuz I'm pretty fucking dope.   I shit you not.  If you don't know, now you know.  Recognize bitches....

We had to wait.  ON A TUESDAY!!!  It didn't matter though because they had rocking chairs outside to sit on.  Nothing says summer like sipping sparkling sangria in a rocking chair in a crazy strange warm summer night in San Francisco. (btw: when the fuck did it start being warm in SF? IN JULY?!?!) The booths are van seats!!  Seatbelts and all....crazy cool.  I dig it!

Like me the place is dark and sultry.  You can have a romantic liaison here in the low lights all the while chowing down on tasty fried chicken.  (nothing says romance like chicken wings and street corn!)

This place is all fun and sassy like me!  Upon hearing that we were celebrating my birthday the chef began to sing Happy Birthday to me!!  She had the whole kitchen and waiters singing to me....she's fucking kick ass.  

I dig this place...It totally fits my personality and the staff is great.  Some one take me here!  I'm easy!!  (well only if you're cute, tall, smart, nice and have muscles)

Minus one star for filler in the chicken bucket.  It made it seem like it was a full bucket of chicken...which at $29, it should be.
author: Jay H.

description:
My new top vote getter for best Fried Chicken in SF.  The fried is mostly corn meal, which keeps it crunchy and somewhat healthy tasting (if that's possible)...not the drippy, oily mess you'd get at other places.  And, there was actual real meat on dem bones!

I dock the joint a star as the sides and salads were kind of misses for me.  We had the frisee salad w/ oysters, eggs and bacon bits, which sounded really tasty and indulgent, but ended up being just pungent and kind of bleh.

My southern friend enjoyed the fried okra and even took them home in a doggie bag -- so if you're into that kind of thing, definitely order those suckers.

Other items had by our table were:
-- a seafood special -- so, so.
-- tuna tartar -- yum
-- some crab and grits concoction -- also yum
-- corn bread shaped like cobs of corns -- another yum

There's also a great corner table by the bar that I would imagine being a ton of fun w/ a group of 6-8 friends....
author: John R.

description: The fried chicken here is to die for! My mouth is watering just thinking about it. The smell as you wait is even torturous. The building is very comfortable and welcoming. Like someone's home. It truly is like you are sitting on the front porch eating a wonderful bucket of fried chicken. Try it!
author: Marieke V.

description: I went there for an early dinner and I sat facing the front door. The place was so dark and the front window so bright that I had to move my chair because of the glare. It's also borderline dingy. I didn't understand the decor at all. "Early Hippy" was the term that comes to mind. I could almost smell the patchouli oil. The menu was "southern bohemian". The food took a while but there was nothing noteworthy about it. Other than the portions being too small, too expensive, and bland, the food wasn't bad... but it wasn't good either. Next time I want a meal like this I'll go to my sister's house. She's a bad cook too.
author: David C.

description:
I envisioned myself somewhere in the South lounging on the front porch swinging on a wooden porch swing with the hot sun beating down on my tanned skin--with a piece of delicious fried chicken in one hand and with the other hand waving to the neighborhood kiddies playing on the street. However, my reality was just a tad different. My front porch consisted of a few tables and chairs. I had the San Francisco fog seeping into my "not so tanned anymore" skin. I had a delicious piece of fried chicken on one hand and my other hand was waving to cars speeding down 29th Ave (between San Jose and Tiffany). 

This Front Porch may not be the front porch complete with the wooden swing and rocking chair you envision, but I bet you the fried chicken they serve here would be exactly what they serve in the south. I came here on a Tuesday and the place was packed - I repeat...PACKED...on a TUESDAY! The fried chicken is awesome - perfectly crisp on the outside, moist and juicy on the inside. My friends and I ordered a bucket of fried chicken which came in a popcorn container complete with the popcorn. I ended up ordering the burger. Yes, you have read right...I ordered a burger...at a soul food restaurant. I was craving a nice juicy piece of ground up cow that day...okay? The burger was delicious--quite possibly amongst one of the best I've tasted. The meat was thick and juicy and the bun was nicely toasted. 

I came out of the Front Porch feeling rather much like a front porch myself. The food was so good I ate a tad too much that night.
author: Sue L.

description:
Just saying this would get me run out of a lot of states but I don't care: I LOVE my soul food with vegan options. 

The food is delicious, the drinks inventive and the atmosphere almost too cute for it's own good. If I had a tiny criticism, perhaps I'd say that this is the Disneyland version of a soul food joint. But then again, I love vegan soul food, so who am I to be bitching about authenticity?
author: Tamara B.

description:
Came here with friends who ordered wine. Wine and fried chicken...who woulda thunk it? I'm always open to trying new things but I probably won't do that combo again. 

This is a cool spot in the Mission. A little hard to find since it's really the front porch of a Victorian. Parking can be a bit of a pain too. 

Portions are huge and food is good. I'd still eat at Back A Yard in Menlo Park over this place though. Definitely not as nice but the food is cheaper and tastes better. If you like to east spicy food, ask for their homemade hot sauce. Holy crap that stuff is spicy. 

Friend next to me got a slab of ribs. Wow. Gigantic (That's what she said). 

Spicy crab grits were also very tasty. Doesn't look terribly appetizing but it's legit.
author: Trung V.

description:
I went to the front porch without reservations, which I highly recommend since we had to wait forever. I actually went back twice to see if they could get me in, and it was worth the wait. The decor was very kitschy but in a good way. The bar was almost a communal table for those who weren't fortunate enough to get a table. I  looked around to see what most people were eating, and the fried chicken seemed quite popular, and quirky as it was served in a tub of popcorn with popcorn bits thrown in. Hmm perhaps it was popcorn chicken, very clever ;) Unfortunately, for us herbivores, there was one vegetarian dinner option sadly, and even that was a toss up. It was a  wild card "seasonal choice of vegetables." Very vague, but apparently it was a vegetarian taco meal for like $17. I dunno about you, but I don't go to southern food restaurants for the tacos. So what we did instead, my dinner guest and I shared sides tapas style and it worked pretty well, considering we were both vegetarians. Word of warning make sure you say Vegetarian, because they can make a vegetarian roumelade, and their gravy is meat based for mashed potatoes. So we ordered fried okra, a black eyed pea salad, fried greed tomatoes, mash potatoes sans gravy, and mac and cheese. Their little complementary cornbread was a cruel tease, and I don't believe on the menu, only biscuits at a whopping $4 each. 
For dessert we had the beignets and the peach cobbler, which both left much to be desired. I have been to new orleans du monde cafe and so far only the louisiana food on shattuck in berkeley could compare. The beignets were heavy and dry. The peach cobbler was a bit bland, but I could tell they used fresh peaches.
This is definitely something to indulge in every blue moon, with all the fried decadent foods, but they were good, and since they were mostly sides, we got them delivered faster than we could finish them, which was very nice.
The service was nothing remarkable. The waitress, a southern belle with a british accent lol, didn't write our order down, and naturally we had to send back some of the sauces on our vegetable entrees, which they acted like they did us a favor. I also got the impression that some of the staff were stoned on the job: i.e. the waiter who asked my friend for the game status, as he assumed that if he was looking at his iphone he was following the game. The maitre d' who seemed distant/spacey when asking if there were any available seats. I had the impression that she didn't quite understand the question. Anyhow, she eventually got us in so no harm no foul.
I will be going back... there is a grilled corn on the cob with my name on it.
author: Onika C.

description:
I'm originally a Texas man, so I was missing some good Creole food.  Enter: The Front Porch

Nice atmosphere that's just homey enough with out being over kitschy, and the rocking chairs out front are a nice touch.

Drink selection has some hard to find Louisiana imports which is nice.

The food however, was not over the top stellar.  Well presented, yes, but authentic, no.  It feels very "Cajun inspired" while at the same time not being innovative.  No offense New Yorkers, but it feels like one of you designed this menu after browsing cheap cook books at Amazon.  I'm being harsh here, but I'm protective of my Creole.  

Here's the laundry list:

Fried Okra : GOOD!  (this was done well, nothing fancy just good food)
Redbeans and rice: Ug.  THis was just red beans over rice.  No real spice or long cooking it seemed.  Edible, but not that great.
Gumbo: This. is. not. gumbo.  Tastes ok, but not gumbo.

I sampled some other dishes.  Very tasty porkchop.  Black eyed peas were ok.  Etc.

One thing I have to point out : The staff was awesome! Very friendly and helpful (despite not knowing what File Gumbo was.)  They are the reason this gets an extra star and I will likely be back at some point.

In summary: The Front Porch is not bad food, it just isn't food that knows what it is yet.  They need to up scale the food (to match the prices) or pile a bit more Cajun/Creole love on, and get off the fence between the two.  Lots of potential, but not quite there yet.
author: Christian H.

description:
3+/4-
Cool funky vibe a la Emmy's.  Definite similarities between the two -- those aprons, grungey hip, dark lighting, cool music that makes you bop in your seat.

Cool menu with a range of interesting things. Salt cod two ways with cod fritters next to cod sashimi.  Chicken liver and Mount Gay rum pate with mango on crostinis.  Dungeness crab and corn grits soup (polenta) with scallions and chili oil.  Old school apple crisp.  They've also got the fried chicken, bacon cheddar burger, vegan green curry,  fish n chips, tartare with plantain chips, collards and black-eyed peas, etc.. 

Cool drinks, with a focus on wines that come in boxes, jugs, or other usually scary formats.  (I did have a headache this morning.)

UNcool flavor all in all.  Bummer.  Like, sounds great on the menu, but then when you eat it, it's like hmm, interesting.  It's good, but it's not wow delicious.  Maybe it just needs salt. (The crab grits was wow delicious tho.) 

They do really have a front porch, so that's cool.
author: Melanie C.

description:
The Front Porch is an adorable little spot!  And yes, it actually has a 'front porch' equipped with rocking chairs and mood lighting where you can sip your wine and wait for your table on a warm night. As a designer, I'm a sucker for atmosphere, and this place engages all the senses in all the right ways. 

I've eaten there twice now, and the first time was such a great experience that I've decided to go back for an intimate birthday dinner with close friends. My friends loved it. Our waitress was sweet enough to remember that it was my birthday and put a candle in my desert (a delicious french bread puddin' with purple yam ice cream and hard bourbon sauce - yum!) and sang Happy Birthday to me - a very sweet, unsolicited gesture. 

I ordered the grits with shrimp, and splurged on the Ramblin Rose cocktail with sparkling Rose, rose water, and rose petals. My tummy was happy. Yours will be happy too.
author: Lorraine O.

description:
The beverage menu alone is unique enough among the many delicious choices this side of the mission. 

We had a deeply satisfying meal on a cold Sunday evening with a bucket of chicken, sides of mashed potatoes and collard greens with spicy shrimp and grits (fat girl dinner, holla!)

The decor is spot on with the food, the staff are all friendly and attentive (but not in your face attentive), and while we listened to the new (and amazing) Pheonix album, the latter portion of our meal was charmingly interrupted by a small Mexican man singing and playing mariachi. 

Only one star off for the awkward bathroom wait, but overall it was a damn good dinner and I'd gladly go back for seconds.
author: Sandra H.

description:
Love the ambience, the friendly staff, the wine selection (red) ... and even the food. However, I think the food is OVERPRICED! S Chicken Fried Steak should not cost $19+, anywhere in this country .... the sauce was delicious, but the steak itself was not all that different from one at a greasy spoon.

I'll probably go back because all the positives I listed, but it may be for a couple of drinks and an appetizer.
author: Mikko G.

description:
Kitchy but cute.

Your typical Marina meets Hipster and having an affair in the dirty (well not so dirty) Mission.

The service is quick and attentive and they offer only beer and wine, which is fairly extensive and quite affordable.

They have the best ceviche deal in the city at only 5 bucks a serving (which happens to be pretty generous).  My fav ceviche aside from making it myself iS Cafe Arguello's just down the block on 24th street.

The hubby had this fried oyster and a soft egg salad, not my cup o tea, but he loved it!  

The treo of fries and the home-made ketsup were a great appeteaser.

The special fish of the day was an amazingly awesome swordfish with a gauc and severed over red beans and rice.

Come here for the chicken, deep fried and battered outside and succulent and juicy inside.  MOVE OVER finger lickin good, this is GET your MF fingers OFF that piece of chicken before I stab you, GOOD!  The black-eyed peas (not the singin kind) over collard greens were fabulous but it was the spicy crab grits that had me slidin off my bar stool!  HOLY mother of GAWD - can I get a bath-tub of that and spoon, I'll eat my way out!
author: A P.

description:
Front Porch's fried chicken is blasphemy.  

Their mistake: messing with a classic.  If you can levitate a classic to a higher plane of existence you've accomplished something truly amazing and the gods will reward you into eternity.  If you can't, the least you can do is not to bung it up.   

I hope the chef(s) at Front Porch aren't expecting 21 virgins in the afterlife.  

First, I'm pretty sure cornmeal crust goes against one of the chicken commandments, as I think most fried chicken fundamentalists would agree.  It's too heavy and ends up falling off and the flavor overpowers the delicate meat.  And speaking of overpowering! Holy herbal enema, so was the rosemary bath the poor chicken was drowned in before meeting its ignoble end in a pan ful of cornmeal.  It tasted like pine sol for god's sake.  

Anyway, I'm sure the chef thinks (s)he's very clever but (s)he's not.  Or at least theyshould just agree to leave the classics alone when trying to show the world her mad skills.
author: Jami C.

description: So dark I sometimes wonder what exactly I'm eating. Small portions -- bad for parties of 4+ who are sharing appetizers. We feel greedy. Weird seating arrangement. Sat like I was the head of the table at a booth. Mediocre fried chicken. Decent blackened codfish. Chards were too vinegary. Pushy on the alcohol. I understand the business owner came from Emmy's Spaghetti Shack, ergo notoriety and reputation.
author: Peter H.

description: Pretty disappointing.  The fish jumbalaya was overcooked, the fried chicken was overbreaded, the crab fritters overfried, and the mac and cheese was ok.  The corn bread was nothing special and I probably liked the fried okra the best- but even then I prefer okra to be cut crosswise.
author: Christine L.

description:
God I love me some fried chicken. If you love me baby, don't send me flowers, send me a fried chicken bouquet, or bucket.  Went here with Chard M, Chris R, and Donna A, which pretty much means I'm going to have a good time anyway, but the food was awesome, and the service was spectacular. They took really good care of us, even when it was clear that I did not need to hit that second jug of $25 pinot. Also, mental note to self - when the waitress asks you if you think that'll be enough food, do not reply with: "oh, if it's not we'll just stop by micky d's on the way home."

But I digress: Look, best fried chicken in the city. That's my review. What more do you need?

Oh, and they *do* take resevations. Huzza! Extra points, SIX STARS, etc.
author: Tal K.

description: Good cajun food!  The Oyster PO' Boy was the bomb!
author: Thomas M.

description:
I am a huge fan on comfort food, and so I was very excited when a friend and I settled on The Front Porch for our ritual dinner date.  The bottom line is that I love this joint; I want to throw a party here, even.

The art on the turquoise walls is eye catching.  The interior is both cozy and cool.  And, well, how can you not love a restaurant in a Bernal house with wooden rocking chairs on the front porch?

But, enough about the place; the food, the food...  We ordered the vegan special of the day, the fried catfish, the fried okra, and the key lime pie.  The vegan specialty with pea varietals and favas (which I don't have the patience to cook myself) was surprisingly delish.  And, all of the fried food was perfectly prepared--not greasy at all.  The waitress guided our every choice and she was pretty much right on.

So, why only 4 stars?  Well, the dessert was just okay...  I love sweets and I require a perfect meal--soup to nuts--for 5 stars.  But, don't ding this place too harshly for that.  After all, most restaurants with great food turn out only okay desserts, as they are not the house specialty.

So, I say: GO!  And, hit up Mitchell's or BiRite for ice cream on your way home.
author: Margo C.

description:
I sat and pondered for a while as a plate of what looked like olive oil was placed in front of me. 

What is that layer on top?  Is that butter?  Who ordered the butter soup?  Is that my grits?

OK let's calculate how long I've lived in Cali and the probability that my cardiovascular system remembers how to deal with this.  I'm a Southerner, and by God, we'd butter ice cream if we could find a way.  I should be able to handle this.

So I took a spoon and scooped up a few grits and some crab from the bottom of my bowl of butter for good measure.  Lemony.... crabby... BUTTERY....     Mmmm... glug* glug*

See?  I'm not soft.  I can do this!  Even whilst my stomach and the fried chicken livers on Texas toast were still getting acquainted, I finished that bowl of "crab and grits" and even had a piece of the vaunted fried chicken generously bequeathed by Jenny K to top it all off.

Heck, all the food was good, but Lawd have mercy, nobody from south of the Mason-Dixon Line would evah, evah, EVAH serve appetizers in such small portions.
author: Gilberto Y.

description:
I wound up going here after my girlfriend found out about the place online I believe. 

First of all, the restaurant is in what appears to be a house....HOW COOL is that!  The food was amazing. The only gripe I have is with the service and pricing. I added an extra drumstick to my chicken plate and that shot the already insane $16 price tag up to a whopping $20.50!!! You guys know how much KFC that buys? A TON! 

My other problem was with the slow as snails service. At times, I almost think they were avoiding us! 

So, give this place a try, knowing that you will spend a lot, and will probably have to fight for your server's attention.
author: Hermin L.

description:
Can I get a hell yeah?

1.  The service is fabulous.
2.  The food is damn fantastic.
3.  How cute is this place?
4.  The fried chicken makes you want to smack your momma.  It is refreshingly different.  And I am a fried chicken purist.  
5.  It is a five minute walk from my place.

Yep.  Damn near perfect.  Love this place.
author: Dottie G.

description:
Pretty good place. Ambiance is homey. The restaurant is the downstairs of someone's house, it's unbelievable, great idea! Service is amazing. Here are the things we ordered: 1. Salmon Tartar with fried salmon neck bone & fried mushrooms. This was just "eh" for me. The fried fish & mushrooms lacked flavor. The tartar was okay but also lacked flavor. Won't order that again. 2. Crab Fritters. Super yummy!!! Definitely will have again! 3. Corndog. It's not a hot dog but rather andouille sausage filled with bacon. I liked it. It's pretty huge & comes with AMAZING homemade tater tots. 4. Bucket of Fried Chicken. I've had better tasting fried chicken but this one was not bad at all. The batter was good & the chicken was juicy, not dry. Pretty standard. Cool part was that they serve it in a cardboard popcorn bucket, like the ones you get at the movie theater, plus they sprinkle a bit of popcorn on top, very cute! 5. Vegetarian Jambalaya. Very yummy!!! Would order again. Lots of tomato in it, but I like tomatoes. Some veggies, but mostly rice 6. Baked Mac & Cheese. All I can say is WOW. I've never had Mac & Cheese this amazing. This was definitely the highlight of my meal. If & when I go back, I think I'll order 10 of these!! 7. Mashed Potatoes. They perfectly flavored, smooth & silky, went well with the chicken. 8. Homemade Biscuits. Pretty standard, nothing that stood out much about them, but also not bad. Oh, and I can't forget the delicious cornbread sticks they served while we waited for our food. They were warm, buttery, and perfect. Served with Chipotle butter on the side, I'd prefer these over biscuits next time. 
FYI, they only serve beer & wine here, so don't expect to be able to order any cocktails. They do however have a list of special wine cocktails. I had a mint champagne one, forgot the name but it was really yummy, almost better than a mojito. Although it won't be my first choice on the list, I'd def return to this cool place. The ambiance is great, service is superb, and the Mac & Cheese just can't be beat.
author: Claudia M.

description:
Sooooo GOOD, even though you can easily rack up a substantial bill!

Starting with the fried okra was like this-is-bad-for-me-but-so-worth-it heaven.
Crab 'n grits is a dish I could live on alone!  
The cornbread with spicy honey butter is divine (we got a couple extra slices), heirloom tomato salad with lemon thyme oil and crispy garlic is fresh and hot at the same time & the golden raisin coleslaw (a recommendation of our server) was a joyous surprise in how flavorful it turned out to be.

I must also mention that the Lillet cocktail was a fabulous apertif-- minty, bubbly with a splash 'o lime.  deeelish.
author: Heather P.

description:
What a surprising disappointment to have such a cute place in my hood fail on me like that. Things were great until the food arrived (after an eternity). I don't understand how there are raves about the fried chicken. It was completely bland. Yes the meat was succulent, but the breading was a complete snore. Same goes for the catfish. Both just not good.  I have never had chewy hush puppies before and they were inedible.  Were they stale?  

An odd silence fell over our table as we sort of begrudgingly picked through our food, rather than an excited, mouths-full, tucking-in.  The rhubard tart was not prepared properly and although it had a nice flavor, was simply a mushy mess, even the crust. The food was simply not very good. :-(     

Kind, attentive service was the high point.  Feeling like I was in the hovel that is Emmy's Shitghetti Shack did not help.
author: Christian H.

description:
When I first went to the restaurant, it instantly felt like my kind of place. 

They are really nice there, there is an interesting and diverse crowd, and they don't take reservations for parties under five, so I don't have to plan.

I have ate at the bar and at a table, I like both. The bar is more entertaining. A visitor from out of town, who was staying with me was talking to this guy in Spanish all night and my guest doesn't speak a word of Spanish.....Go figure.

I love the food here. I don't go here for anything except the fried chicken. The chicken has wonderful spices, is crispy on the outside and moist on the inside. I like to get a bucket of it with two friends and pick my own two sides. That is what I love. My favorite sides are the macaroni and cheese and the grits. 

You might have to wait, but they have a cute waiting area outside to have a drink before dinner. I give this place a five. I need to go back soon, I am missing it as I write this review.
author: Christopher W.

description: I tried their fried chicken. Quite overpriced for a mediocre plate. The collard greens were very bitter. I would still rate Farmer Browns as the best fried chicken in the city.
author: Genaro R.

description: Fried Chicken, Spicy Shrimp and Grits, Chicken Gumbo was AMAZING!  Mac and cheese was missing some type of crunch, maybe some bacon??  The Sazerac had too much SoCo for my taste.  But I've been to this place 4 times and it's never a disappointment.  Thankful I made reservations 2 weeks before.
author: Joe H.

description:
Cultural paradoxes abound at this trendy, upscale soul food establishment (just think about that for a second).  The disparity between the prices on the menu and the decor and "funky" flourishes -- they serve King Cobra from the bar -- is not as charming as the proprietors imagine. 

One of my dining companions, prone to superlatives, hyped me up as we sat down by raving that the food was among the best he had ever had.

I had a hamburger, but I tasted many other entrées and none of them really moved me.  As for my hamburger, it was a pretty sad affair.  $12, and it was lukewarm.  There is no excuse for a cold hamburger.

Also, and this may run contrary to some tastes, I am not a fan of the flavored patty.  The menu advertises "Grass-Fed Uruguayan Beef", but the taste of the meat is imperceptible underneath the overbearing litany of Italian-style spices.  

On the positive tip, you would do well to request the habañero sauce, which was quite flavorful and spicy.

I'm sorry to be so down on this place -- the service was pretty friendly and they were playing early Heptones for most of our meal -- but I just have to tell it like it is.
author: Breezy J.

description:
I am removing one star b/c I recommended this place to a friend and she said it was one of the worst restaurant experiences shes had. She said the waitress was very un-helpful and pretty much talked her out of ordering anything on the menu. 

Minus 1 star for making me look bad!
author: Adri C.

description:
I want to get a bucket of their fried chicken and only eat the skins.  I want to fill my arteries with crispy seasoned deep-fried cornmeal covered fat.  Wash it down with a big tall glass of their Persephone.  Yum.  

Everything at the Front Porch is pretty decent.  The butter leaf salad is okay--the dressing s a little too reminiscent of sweet and sour sauce.  But their grilled asparagus/ sweet potato with curry aioli is spectacular.  I crazy love their burger; it comes with the crispiest mix of regular and sweet potato fries.  The crab grits are loaded with chunks of crab; very tasty, but I must mention I am bizarrely impressed by the peas that are mixed into the grits.  They are fresh and flavorful and perfectly cooked.  I picked them out and ate them one by one.  

No introduction necessary, of course, for the fried chicken.  The plate comes with some black-eyed peas and grits (neither of which was super great).  But the fried chicken.  It is Cracked Out.  Last time I ate until my stomache hurt.  Cause technically I had already eaten dinner and the Front Porch was supposed to be a "snack".  Or second dinner, which I'm assuming shouldn't be an even larger portion than first dinner.  Someone familiar with Hobbit culture should let me know.
author: Diana Y.

description:
I waited a long time to try this place only because i'd heard horror stories of the wait time to get seated..
Well, i toughed it out last week and i can firmly say that i'd wait another hour any night to eat here again.
The burger was one of legends, the mac and cheese was like nothing i'd seen before, even their ketchup was god-like.
Just go.
author: Kiya B.

description:
I wanted to like this place.  Really.  They did, after all, take over one of two Latin Fight Club Bars on that street, and in doing so dramatically reduced the number of drunken street fights in my neighborhood.  I'd heard good things from my roommate, and the menu looked not half bad, so I took it for a spin last weekend.

And, well, ew.

The interior of this place is dark.  Not just pleasant ambient dark, the kind where the flicker of candlelight makes everyone look better... no, this was just plain dark.  No matter.  I've seen my friend enough to recognize his silhouette, so I wasn't worried about suddenly dining with a stranger.  But it's not just dark, it's dark and... green.  So the dark plus the green lends the whole place a somewhat cavelike atmosphere.  It also makes people look a bit sickly.  The noise level went from pleasant to "HUH WHAT I CAN'T HEAR YOU!" as the restaurant filled up, so conversation over dinner was right out.

The host was quick to seat us and quick to ask for our names.  Friendly sort.  Our waiter was anything but.  He seemed bored and disintenterested, at least until he got to his next table.  There he chatted up the four diners for (we timed it) nearly 20 minutes.  Meanwhile, we have no drinks.  We pointed this out to our waiter when he disengaged himself from the foursome seated next to us and were met with a snapped "they're on their way."  

Ambience aside, the food was neither great nor awful.  The friend's appetizer arrived after our meal, after yet another reminder to our waiter.  Our orders of fried chicken arrived, all flaky weird cornmeal crust and slimy fatty skin.  The meat under this coating was indeed succulent with a lovely limey tang, though.  Kudos on their marinating.  If they could fix the outer coating, the chicken would be a winner.  A smoky soupy bowl of collards and black eyed peas went uneaten, as it was just too soupy and too smoky to be tasty.  But hey, we got moist towelettes, so we were good.  

Our check was delivered promptly; unfortunately, our waiter disappeared just as promptly.  We had to flag down the happy helpful host in order to settle our bill, though I truly believe we would have been unnoticed had we simply slipped out without paying.
author: Tracy R.

description:
The vegan coconut curry stew is insanely good. It was the vegan plate, which changes daily, so I don't know how to predict whether or not it'll be around. Before I was told the evening's vegan choice I was going to just order a couple of sides, because they don't really have anything else vegetarian. But this dish was so delicious (and I was so hungry) that I can't really objectively evaluate this place. Great sweet and sour brussels sprouts, too, which our nice waiter gave us for free because he initially forgot to put in the order.

The saloon ambiance was spot-on, and only enhanced by the entry of a traveling mariachi band that briefly interrupted the solid soundtrack of Joy Division. They did a weird rendition of the birthday song for the two large birthday parties hogging half of the restaurant. This would be a fun place for a birthday party, so maybe I'm just jealous. 

My only complaint, other than the lack of more vegetarian dishes (just one more would make me happy!) is that when there's a long wait and it's freezing and rainy outside, the leaky literal front porch isn't such a good waiting room.
author: Rachel J.

description:
Everything about this place was surprisingly great.  The decor, service, food, price and music earns the 5 stars.  The best fried chicken I've had in the city; only to admit that Popeye's is it's only competitor. 

Will most definitely come back to this establishment again and order the crab grits for myself!
author: Justin C.

description: Parking and seating gods were looking down upon us and we scored both on a midday Saturday visit.  Atmosphere very homey and friendly. Waiter adorable. We smartly ordered the fried chicken and waffles as soon as we sat down as it does take 20 minutes. We started with biegnets which were warm and fresh and served very creatively in a brown paper bag. We also ordered the gumbo which was bland in taste and had no kick. The fried chicken was moist and the waffle tender. Overall solid. Was it the best we have had? Almost. Maybe worth a second visit for dinner. A great neighborhood spot.
author: C K.

description: My boyfriend & I were looking for a new spot in the city to try , we were both craving chicken we came across this little place and let me just tell you the location is awesome the ambiance is great! We were really excited about being here we started our meal with the cone bread which was good tiny but good. We had fried pickles for appetizers absolutely amazing with the Tabasco aioli truly a great combo we both had the 4 piece chicken plate which came with mashers and gravy and some greens it was good  it was a good amount we both left one chicken since the 4th would be too much but it was good.. We ended our dinner with beignets which were good but not great I've had tried a lot of beignets in a lot of different locations and these were good. My only complaints is that the lighting  was a little too dark but still was nice inside and our server wasn't very attentive the really nice girl who sat us was more attentive . But that will not stop me from returning ! See ya soon front porch
author: Vianett E.

description:
I hate to write a less than positive review BUT
After being told the wait would be 20 minutes- I waited almost and hour and they ran out of high chairs. They were kind of "oh well" about it. So rather than eat dinner with my squirmy toddler in my lap we left. I guess it must be nice to be so popular that you don't care if potential customers are turned off by lack of organization (I had called ahead and asked about chairs and the wait time) or by poor attitudes. (I don't think they even noticed that we left) I heard the food is good but I wouldn't know.
author: Melissa B.

description:
Yeah, it's a little bit southern, a little bit Creole, plenty San Franciscan and all around rockin'. Celebratory group of 5 waited 45 minutes for our table on a packed Monday night. Friendly service had a few timing kinks to work out, nothing too serious...an extended wait for the fresh-from-the-oven cornbread sticklets and the need to flag a server a couple of times for attention - seemingly just the growing pains of a brand new, very tasty baby.

A stylish, hammered tin roof and eclecticly colorful surroundings set the interior stage. The namesake "front porch" sports charming rocking chairs of various sizes and a candlelit atmosphere perfect for a warmer evening. 

We chowed down. Appetizers included a wonderfully fresh and tangy heirloom tomato salad and a good, but not mind-blowing ceviche, easily scooped and eaten on Bajan ting "chips".

Entrees and sides were shared family style; crispy buttermilk fried chicken with just the right hit of spicy love, the novel (and I'd venture, soon to be signature) dungeness crab and sweet white corn grits - so creamy, so delicious and so quickly consumed, caraway coleslaw dressed lightly and rightly, black eyed peas smiled coyly as we woofed them down, and grilled summer corn rounding out the offerings. The only dish we really didn't favor was a vegan special of the evening, a veggie stew in a weak sauce made no stronger by the glass of pinot noir accidentally spilled in the mix. Two bottles of that fine libation served us right as we ate and caroused in the inviting, convivial space.

No room for dessert, we left happy and full. I will definitely be back to rock on The Front Porch.
author: wendella a.

description:
I already have a Subaru, all I need is a baby and a house in Bernal Heights and I'm set!  I will fit into the scene at this restaurant perfectly and will be able to eat here EVERY NIGHT!  

Honestly, this is my new favorite restaurant, yes it's that good!  We started with two individual cornbreads with honey butter, mmmm mmmm I knew I was in trouble!  We then moved on to the baked beans on toast.  I attempted to mock the dish for resembling the cafeteria food in my London Dorm during the summer of 96, but WHOAAA, it was so good that I had to apologize to the beans. 

Second course, I got the kids meal of friend chicken (yes, sir there is a baby in my purse) and the spicy crab porridge.  Don't let the name scare you, that crab was CRAZY.  

I never knew that I had a secret carribean loving baby tucked inside my tummy, but TA DA, she's out and ready to head back to this lovely, charming, local restaurant.  

Seating:  it's a first come first serve only kinda place so we arrived at 6:30 pm on a Friday night.  I know, who eats that early?  I guess dorks like us, but it was worth it cause by 7:30 pm the place was crawling and I'm guessing the wait was pushing 45 minutes a table.
author: Claire C.

description:
Wow!  Yum!  I think I'm starting to drool just thinking about the meal my friend and I had here last Friday.  We walked in at about 8, the place was packed, and were told it'd be about an hour wait.  The hostess told us to walk down the street to a bar, and she'd call the bar when our table was ready.  We were there about an hour when she called and we walked back to the restaurant.

We shared a carafe of a delicious pinot noir (two glasses each), and thoroughly enjoyed our meal of cornbread, doubles, friend plantains and fried chicken with mashed potatoes.  I've been trying to find a place like this in SF, and I am SO happy my awesome friend suggested this place, cause I loved it and will certainly be back!  We were too stuffed to consider dessert, but there were some yummy-sounding options.  Maybe next time I'll save room.  A great spot for a date, a friend date, or a group!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
My adult chidren took me there for my birthday. There were 6 people in our group and the food was either Ok or awful. My daughter and I had the fish of the day, and it was so overdone it was like fish jerkey. The only real positive was the fried okra.  
We had reservation and they were busy but we wereseated quickly, but then service went SLOW to take drink ordrs, deliver drinks, take orders. Even the wait for the check was very long.
author: Charles D.

description:
I have to give proper compliments to the staff at The Front Porch. We've been here a few times since it opened (we live in Glen Park and it's a short walk to get there). The food is always good, especially if you're familiar with delta-style cooking. If you're up the stairs in the back, you get to see the preparation goin' on in the highly efficient kitchen.

I took my family for dinner a couple of nights ago. Like most Saturdays, the place was very crowded and noisy (that's something else to consider). Each person ordered a specialty cocktail (made with beer or wine - no spirits). Then each ordered according to his or her level of adventerousness - liver, burger, gumbo, catfish and chicken (which was the winner).

To my taste (and my daughter's) the catfish had a slightly off taste (I've since read that it is pretty common among even fresh catfish, which most aficionado's don't mind at all). I mentioned it to the waitress, just by way of information, and she took it back and offered us another dish or credit! That's amazing! It was really our mistake to order it... But anyway. Just want to make this public "thank-you" and give a recommendation to a restaurant with good food and great spirit (even without a license to sell spirits)
author: Dan M.

description:
Damn good food.
Recommend the grits w/ crab and the fried chicken.
author: Peter O.

description:
Heh, been meanin' to check this place out for a long time and, finally, decided on a date for my partner and I, and another couple to check it out.  They don't take reservations for parties under 5, but said not to worry. . .half hour at the most.  As luck would have it, when the day for our meal rolled around, the Front Porch receives an excellent write up in the Chronicle.  We had no reservation.  We opted to skip for fear of the throngs surely descending on the place later that night.  Fast forward four months.  Went there on a Friday (party less than 5, no reservation) and waited about 45 for a table.  

It was worth it.

For starts, the staff was very friendly.  Brought us a complimentary appetizer (which was delicious) while we waited. The mulled wine was delish. . . and we had the time to really appreciate how cool the space is (beautiful old bar and ceiling) and how cool the crowd was . . .pretty mixed and the nice din of people enjoying their meals and company.  . .

Fast forward, the meal.  Three of us this time, and we all shared our meals since all of them were SOOOOO good.  Mine the pork, his the dungeoness crab and grits, and the other 'his' was the fried chicken.  You really should try it all too. 

My friend is a foodie.  While waiting for our meal he pointed out how good the homemade ketchup on your table is. . .ate it by the spoon and soon I was too.  He can usually figure out what's in just about anything after a taste, but he was stumped by this ketchup.  We asked the waiter what was in there, but he was sworn to secrecy.  We're thinking celery seed.  We're thinking bicarbonate of soda.  Damn, It's good.  We ordered the fries just to go with the stuff.

So, go.  Be prepared to wait, but hell, you've come with friends, right? (but 5 stars if they take a reservation for three.)
author: Mark N.

description:
What a happy, happy place.  

The fried chicken is some of the best in SF.  The jerk chicken is even better.
author: Ben A.

description:
YUMMY! This food is amazing not a drop left after dining here. We where not sure what to expect but thoroughly enjoyed the atmosphere, the very informed wait staff and the FOOD WAS AMAZING! Whether you like all veggies or you are a die hard meat eater this is the place to dine it gave my husband and I both a perfect menu to select what we liked and even share.

Highly recommend it plus if you like to have a drink I hear this is a great place for that too.
author: amy g.

description:
We hadn't been out to dinner with some good friends in far too long.  We wanted to try something fun and new for all of us.  Hmmm...  Where should we go?  Hey!  How about a new restaurant where we knew the chef's abilities and style?  Shall we say... Front Porch?!?  

We ventured toward Front Porch with great anticipation to see what great dishes were to be had.  We put in our name and sat on the porch on rocking chairs.  A nice way to relax on a warm evening before dinner with friends.  We were called about 15 minutes before our quoted wait time --- things were looking up.  We entered the dimly lit room that had pressed tin ceilings and cool blue walls, and a aged but very stylish bar.  We were seated under a speaker, the music thumping with excitement.  Music ala Emmy's.  

There were great combinations on the menu that we thought would work well together.  We yelled our orders through the din of the bass beat repeatedly to our server who was very personable, humorous and patient.  After straightening out our entree order, it wasn't long before our meals arrived.  Now... about the food.  Well, let's just say that I will have to give it another try.  Mostly, we opted for dishes that other friends and acquaintances hadn't already tried and liked.  For our entrees, we tried the vegan porridge, fish and chips, and fried chicken with a side dish of black eyed peas and collard greens.  

First the porridge, great as an entree?  No.  As an appetizer, yes, due to the size of the portions.  About 8 inches across and a half  inch deep --- think smallish pancake size.  All yours for $9.50.  Yikes!  Two portions were served so there didn't seem to be a mistake on the portioning.  We felt obligated to share our remaining food with our friends!  

Next, fish and chips.  The fish was good.  Crisp, flaky, moist fish with just the right crunch with the cornmeal coating.  Yum for me.  The chips were a little flat and cool, perhaps cooked too soon before serving and maybe from different batches since there were two different styles (cubed home fry and French fry cuts).  The coleslaw was just interesting.  Great if you like caraway flavor.  Nice light dressing but the cabbage seemed to be cut a little too thick, making it rather chewy.  Not for most at our table, but I could see that others would like it.  

Lastly, the much talked about fried chicken.  Overall, I have to agree with the minority of customers who didn't like it.  My first piece was deep fried heaven.  A perfectly fried thigh with the just the right amount of spices and crunch.  The two remaining breast pieces were plain and simply, over done.  It was difficult to eat the other pieces without the help of the busser would kept us well supplied with water in vintage wine jugs.  The collard greens and black eyed peas were very good.  I thought these were very tasty (with just a hint of coconut milk?).  Yum!

After a ho-hum meal, we thought we would brighten our spirits with the chocolate cake and the apple crisp.  We were able to try one of the two apple crisps we orderd because they ran short.  It appeared the portion was good, but the apple crisp was described as being basically chunky apple sauce without the crisp.  The chocolate cake was just okay as well.  Nothing special, just chocolate cake and a dollop of fresh whipped cream.  Each serving was small that the size of what you could make in an Easy-Bake-Oven.  The frosting was just a tad bit salty.  With no alcohol ordered, we were slapped with an $80 bill, (with tip, it wasn't the server's fault!).  We left a little deaf and somewhat hungry.  A sad ending to a place with potential.

Like I said, I will likely revisit Front Porch in a few months to see what other inspiring combinations they are offering.  To be sure, they have the talent and the taste buds.  Just not on the evening we visited.  Check them out for their other dishes!
author: Joe B.

description:
Great food!!  The fried chicken and crab porridge are excellent!
Wine in a box...hmm...not a great idea.
The beer and wine list need to be revised.
Changing up the menu once in awhile might be nice too.
author: Tasha S.

description:
Can I tell you how hard it is to live right across the street from the Front Porch? 
I love fried chicken.
This place makes rockin' fried chicken.
I always have fried chicken on my mind.
Mmmmmm....so good.  
Just like grandma's!
But with a little plus- the bartenders do a good pour!
Sancerre to rim of the larger than normal wine glass.
Makes me want it all the time.  
And another plus is the decorations, totally remind me of my gf's mother's house:)
author: Valarie A.

description:
Holy shit. I'm still full from eating here earlier tonight with two friends.  Yeah, our wait was 45 minutes, but we went over to the knockout for some $2 Hamms and watched Joe wreck shop at Ms. Pacman. But I digress... 

Yeah, they put our two appetizers, which were tiny, on those huge plates, and that's irritating, but they were still great.  (They were the plantain cakes and the conch fritters, amazing). We all shared our three main courses, the ridiculous fried chicken, the equally ridiculous pork chop, and the very good special escavaitch of blue nose cod.  

Our waiter was super friendly and after we had finished our meal tried to talk us into dessert. We told him we were stuffed, no thanks. About ten minutes later, another waitress came over and set down a bowl of apple fritters with ice cream and four spoons and told us that she just wanted us to try it for free. Fuck it, we thought, and gave it a go. Again, ridiculous. We asked her to sit down and eat some of it with us, which she did. After that, we had the host come sit down, and he killed it off for us.  

What a great night. 

After some reflection, I have to admit that the pork chop is better than the friend chicken. That means it's really good, because the fried chicken was the best friend chicken I've ever had outside of the south.
author: Josh K.

description:
Valentine's Day 2008 
Course 1:  
Butternut Squash Soup - yes
Tuna and Scallop tartare with taro chips - yes, please!

Course 2:
Lobster and crab grits - OH, YES!
Fried chicken, mashed potatoes and collard greens - HOLY JESUS, YES!

Course 3:
Red velvet cake with coconut ice cream - YES, YES, YES!  AHAHAHAH
Chocolate plate - Wha?

What kind of stoner put this together?  Fried bread (call it brioche if you must) with a smear of chocolate inside, drizzled with chocolate sauce, a doughnut (call it a pastry if you must) drizzled with chocolate sauce and a heaping spoonful of whipped cream with reeses's pieces mixed into it.  

E.T. phone HOME.  

I gotta drop a star for that while it might sound good it really wasnt.  It REALLY wasn't.  It went uneaten aside from that spoonful of cream and pieces.
author: T-Bone L.

description: I know it's a lot to ask, but can I eat well, get good service and have a nice setting for all of this as well? Gee thanks, Front Porch for making this seems so easy! Everytime I go here, I succomb to the fried chicken, though everything on he menu has always been yummers-(raided my friend's plates.) It's super cute inside and out and all of the employees, even if it's just a person you see once who clears one plate, are awesome. Also, I don't know how they make their mac n cheese so delicious, but I think it's best that I never know...faeries maybe?
author: Isabel L.

description:
I love southern food (who can resist fried okra) so I really wanted to like this cute place. 

I had the crab grits which was delicious. And our table shared a bucket of fried Chicken which was crispy on the outside and piping hot on the inside. if it were based on food alone, I would go with 3.5 stars.

However the service was terrible. Our waiter was downright RUDE. it took him 30 minutes to give us water and when he asked for drink orders, I felt liek we were imposing on his time. He basically yelled at me when i asked for hot sauce as if I asked for a grenade as a side to my chicken. Overall the guy was a douche and I will never frequent the restaurant unless it was free and my escort was johnny depp :)
author: Diep N.

description:
I really don't like cornbeef hash, but I ordered it and what do you know it was real shreded cornbeef not that ground up stuff they usually call cornbeef hash.  I really liked it.  My guest had the eggs benedict; he like that a lot.  

Again the service was great for us.

Something to keep in mind, they donate 10% of their sales on Tuesday night to support 'Meals on Wheels'. Wednesday, are their "food for thought" 10% of your check will go to benefit these Mission Graduates.
author: Naomi H.

description:
Walking in here it was *nothing* what I expected. I really thought it would be a down-home soul food - well - diner. When I stepped over the threshold on that crisp Friday night (crisp is really my poetic euphemism for freezing frickin' cold) I found it to be a cozy, romantic, hip haute-soul restaurant.

And the sounds coming from our table once our Miss Ollie's Fried Chicken hit our table were triple-x pornographic. The moaning and lip-smacking sounds emanating from our table would have made Jenna Jamison blush. Okay. Maybe not Jenna. But Linda Lovelace, definitely. When she was still alive. And not a prude. Did you see that documentary on Deep Throat?! She really took a turn.

But my point is that I am forever ruined on fried chicken because never again will any breaded and fried poultry pass my lips that comes anywhere near as good as that crack (and really, that's a damn shame, because we all need more breaded and fried poultry in our lives). And the macaroni and cheese pie? I was dying!

The server was really cool and attentive. But I must say, because the staff doesn't wear clothing of any uniformity whatsoever, as he first approached my table I was wondering why this guy was heading in my direction. But when he came back with a pint glass of Jasper Poppy beer from Morgan Hill, well, he had me at "Here's your...". That was one fine beer.

The review that brought me here said that the Front Porch has really affordable soul food. Well, she apparently eats at much more expensive restaurants than I - that and I acknowledge I am a total cheapskate. Our meal for two (including two Jasper Poppy's - shut up. Not each!) Was nearly fifty bucks. When I think "affordable soul food" I'm really thinking more in the 25 dollar range. But I guarantee you, and the trendster staff, that this will not be an "occasion restaurant" for me. The magnetic pull of that fried chicken is too strong. Much too strong.

Damn. Now I need some chicken. Miss Olliiieeeee!
author: J P.

description:
Farmer Brown, move aside. Maverick? Bitch please. 

"Hyped?" How? This place is so good I want to put up a hammock and stay, like, forever.   

 -Delicious fried chicken, grits, cornbread, corn pudding for dessert. Maybe I just like corn... but my friend's fried fish sandwich with remoulade was the real deal. More harmonious flavors than Weird Fish.  I don't know, everything tasted like somebody CARED. I'm from the South - I know what these things should taste like. 

-The service is so nice you almost don't know how to handle it. Never intrusive or obsequious, nor with an ounce of attitude, they simply go out of their way to make you feel welcome, even when it's packed (offering you a drink at the bar instead of shoving you outside in the cold. what a novel idea!). As a bonus, everyone's also really cute.

Awesome food, friendly service and surroundings and great value. What more do you need?
author: BroSauce J.
