description: The ambiance here is definitely "hipster".  Having a Southern family, I know what Southern food tastes like.  This ain't it.  We ordered shrimp & grits and the waitress came back with something looking like cold soup.  Um, no.  Their prices are also off the chain!  Nothing quite like leaving a restaurant unsatisfied and feeling like you were gouged.  Overpriced mediocrity is how I would sum this place up.
author: Mila M.

description: Loved loved loved everything! I really appreciated their nod to the vegetarians, even though I don't suppose soul food is known for being vegetarian-friendly. I also enjoyed the mariachi player who came about 20 or so minutes into our meal!
author: Lucy M.

description:
I ordered the "Poor Man's Plate," which was pretty friggin' terrible and quite honestly the worst dish I've had ever since I metamorphisized into a foodie a few years back.  On the menu it is described as their daily selection of "offal, off-cuts, and other things we love." The day I went was off-the-bone pig's feet.  Now I usually reserve pig's feet for cheapo Chinese restaurants, but since this was a southern-themed quasi-try-too-hard place, I thought they might put some nice southern touches on it.  WRONG.  The only touch, which was acceptable but not to the level of "nice," was lima beans.  The rest was not acceptable.  Pig's feet is supposed to be a mixture of fat, meat, and cartilage.  The stuff they used contanied none of the latter two.  Then they just threw that with the beans and tomatoes on a bed of instant rice.  No sort of flavoring whatsoever.  Now I don't expect pig feet at a southern restaurant to be stellar or anything, but it was like they just threw everything into a plate and didn't even try.  No words that I use can even do homage to that horribleness.  Let's face it, this dish was awful.

Even worse, they charged $16.50 for it, which was on the *slightly* higher side of average.  But pig's feet are cheap as hell.  You can get them for $0.99-$1.99/lb @ Manila World Market just down Mission (which is probably where they got them from.)  They are obviously way cheaper than entire pieces of chicken that are fried, of which someone from our party ordered for $15.95.  But considering how horrible it was, it should have been cheaper, WAY cheaper, probably even cheaper than the Vegan Shepherd's Pie.

Some of my acquaintances had better luck.  The house-smoked salmon appetizer was way too salty, but a nice attempt & at least edible.  The crab salad wasn't bad.  The brisket was pretty good.  The dungeness crab & cheese grits was perfect (and the feet were so bad that it took this spoonful of perfection, combined with a spoon or fork everything else passable, to pull this up to even two stars.)

Even though I don't take service into consideration in my ratings (unless it's extraordinarily bad or good), for those who care, they were very nice and casual-professional but we had to wait a loooooooong time, even before they came to take our order.
author: David A.

description:
Here's my plan for the next time I come here: first, I will forgo the starters.  No corn bread, none of those spicy chips.  Forget the drinks...the sangria was just OK (I've had better).  Hold the side dishes - no potato salad (it was alright, I was just a little thrown off because I was expecting that kind of mayonaise-y, fast food-type potato salad), no collard greens or black-eyed peas, no coconut red beans & rice (which were actually pretty tasty).
  
No, instead of all that, just park that big bucket of chicken in front of me and I'll be happy.  Very happy.  Really, I think that's all I will need.  That meaty, tasty fried chicken with the flavorful, flakey skin.  Yum.  There's an old Run-DMC lyric that always runs through my head when I eat chicken: "Yo, yo, is this Kentucky Fried?".  No, Run.  This is most definitely NOT Kentucky Fried!  And don't expect much in the way of conversation as I work my way through the bucket.  Do what I did and go with a group of witty, amusing friends who will keep the conversation going while you eat.  

All the other reviews have said it.  It's cozy (small).  It's noisy.  It's got a cool tin ceiling.  Seating can be a little awkward if there are more than five people in your group.  But it was good food, good company, and Johnny Cash was playing on the stereo.  It was a good night.
author: DD B.

description:
You guys have been holding out on me.

It seems like no one ever mentions The Front Porch without going on about the fried chicken and how wonderful it is. So when I found out that we were eating out there my mind was made up; I barely even looked at the menu. 

And looking back, I can't say I was completely disappointed; The chicken was moist and tender, even the breast meat. The dry crumbly batter on it was unique and kind of tasty, and I enjoyed the creamed collards and grits (no mashed potatoes that night.) I have to give them some credit for putting their own spin on a traditional dish, but my expectations were set really high and it didn't quite meet the mark. I think I prefer the orthodox fried chicken that I get at places like powells. 

AK, a front porch veteran, knew better. She ordered what turned out to be one of the best burgers I've ever been able to eat off of someone else's plate; Uruguayan beef, bacon and cheddar with perfectly done fries and some tangy, slightly spicy homemade ketchup. If you ran a restaurant would it even occur to you to make your own ketchup? Small details can go a long way. 

Which is what is bothering me. Has all the talk about the fried chicken there been some kind of misdirection? Have you all been steering the suckers towards the chicken so they don't run out of hamburger or ingredients for some other fantastic dish that's only for those in the know? I wouldn't do something like that to any of you.

Oh, and the cornbread starter with the spicy butter was as good as any cornbread I've ever had. 

I usually start off reviews with the decor and service, but I'm all out of sorts now and my review is backwards. See what you've done? I hope you're happy.

There are tile floors like you'd find in your grandparents' basement and tin stamped ceilings like you'd find in a victorian mansion. There is no carpet, no tapestries, no fabric anywhere in the dining room. So the Front Porch is NOISY. I can't recommend the place for a first date unless conversation makes you uncomfortable. The tables are basic wood squares on legs, and some of the seats in the back have been salvaged from a passenger van, complete with seatbelts and fold down armrests.  

The hipster wait staff was friendly, but a little slow. AK said the service was worse than usual so I imagine it's generally very good. 

I'll definitely come back, but I'll have the burger or something else next time, and I'll recommend that everyone have the burger or something else good because I'm unselfish and I want my friends to enjoy their meal as much as I do when I find something special. Just sayin'.
author: matthew r.

description:
First Of all this is not Bernal Heights People this is the Mission and I should know I hung out at the Chevron on 30th and mission back in the day..Used to have a 3 bedroom flat for $800.00 (hell of nice to b4 the dot -comers and Yuppies moved here and took over my city) in the back of Safeway(which is on 30th and Mission)

Anyway I had know idea that the front porch was across the street from the old Tiffanys bar which back when we were 19 and did not have and Id we could still get a drink..Back when the front porch was
a latino hang out and there would be Marachi's playing in the front and drunken old men singing along

What does that have to do with this review maybe it's that I read that it was so good I was excited to go..

I got there late my friends had already ordered so I tried a piece of there fried chicken it was okay ( I expected more) 

I ordered the steak which was good the potatoes were tasty .. the greens were pretty good as well..

I tried my friends crabcake over grits it was edible but not great...

This spot is over rated and to me not soul food which is what i expected.. 

The waitress was very nice and the service was cool on the upside
author: Kim R.

description: great date location... personally enjoyed all the dishes, except the chicken. the chicken looks perfect but has no seasoning. all other dishes have been delightful. southern food without the grease.... I don't know how they do it. highly recommend
author: Sharine d.

description:
There are not many restaurants that live up to the hype. And boy, is there a lot of hype with the Front Porch. But you know a place is good if there are 500+ reviews with most of them 4 stars or better.

Let me put it simply...
-9 pieces of cornmeal crusted chicken in a popcorn bucket - with popcorn to soak up the chicken juice
-jerk spiced half-chicken (yes, I said half of a chicken!)
-cornmeal crusted okra
-porkchop marinated in rum and molasses (you can cut it with a fork)
-habanero chutney (the waiter wasn't joking when he said that you only needed a drop!)

Seriously, how can you go wrong? This place rocks. I went here with a few of my friends to celebrate a birthday. I am so happy I finally got to the food here. Sure, there were a lot of wanna-be hipsters that went there. But the food makes you forget about all the bad dressers out there in the world - at least for a little while.
author: Jan Z.

description:
I'm jumping on the wagon and rating this place 4+ stars.

From the moment you step into this restaurant, you're just amazed! You walk into this different world inside. The place reminded me of an old school restaurant that was a hole in the wall where the famous people hung out. The best part is that the kitchen is half open so you are able to watch them work their magic.

I had the fried chicken (c'mon, of course I did) and it was quite tantalizing. Crispy, juicy, and most importantly, not greasy! This must have been the 2nd best (you know no one can do it better than mom) fried chicken I've had.
The black eyed and collards were very tasty as well!
Spicy crab and grits...no words to describe how much I enjoyed this meal. =)

Um, try it already!
author: John C.

description: Went here for the first time a few nights ago. I have to say, it was very delicious! It was really busy, but they
author: Bernadette B.

description: This is my 2nd time here. The first time the food was great, this time it was mediocre. Everything was under seasoned and the crust on the chicken was soggy in places. Overall, the food is good, but tonight  wasn't one of their best nights.  Another great point about this place is the customer service. Everyone is very nice and will bend over backwards to make sure you enjoy yourself.
author: Yohanes F.

description:
Can we say "Overrated"? I think our group waited for almost an hour for this supposed amazing place. SOOOOOOOOOOOOO disappointed. That fried chicken that people talk about? Lame. And why was mine still pink on the inside? The hostess was bitchy and the place was super cramped. Just not a fun night. Good thing the ceviche and grits were pretty good otherwise this would've gone in the "I want to give them zero stars but am forced to give at least 1" category.

Oh and I must admit I enjoyed the rocking chairs out front. Since we had to wait so long at least I got to rock away while catching up with some friends.

And when all else fails, count your losses, gather up your friends and walk down the block for a cone at good ol' Mitchells.
author: Karla G.

description:
Tasty tasty food.  Honestly left feeling very satisfied and very thick full of rib sticking delicious food.  Went here for the first time last night for dinner with friends and loved the ambiance.  The booths are a little too cozy if you're sporting a big pregnant belly but we managed.  Kudos for being able to make reservations on Opentable which is apparently a new thing for them.

We shared the shrimp and grits and the hushpuppies for apps.  They were awesome.  I ordered the fried catfish and a side of biscuits.  Biscuits were decent so was the catfish.  My husband ordered the fried chicken and it was incredible.  We all shared a rhubarb crisp with goat cheese ice cream for dessert.  I didn't like the goat cheese ice cream but the rhubarb crisp was awesome... not too sweet and just the right amount of tartness.  I drank a ginger beer from Australia which was perfect.  

I would go back again.  Especially if I'm super hungry and looking for some excellent comfort food.  I think I'll order the fried chicken next time.
author: Natalie B.

description: Nice little place, I'll definately eat here again.  The fried chicken was delicious, but portion sizes were small.
author: alex f.

description:
Came here for our Fat Tuesday feast with fellow yelpers Anne A. and Melanie V. and some other friends. 

The outside is literally like a pront porch with some rocking chairs, and tables. Cute feel and vibe.

Inside it was crackin... really dim lighting and really loud, hustle and bustle. We already knew we wanted the fried chicken with collard greens and mashers. A vegetarian friend got the sustainable fish and we were ready to go. Some of us ordered Sangria and it was okay... not your typical sangria, something I won't order again.. I shoulda had a beer instead.

Especially because this Fried Chicken is outstanding. This is not your normal KFC. This is this epitome of finger lickin' good. Aside the tasty artery clogging skin, the chicken itself is huge, juicy and tender.  Add some Crystal hot sauce to the mix and you're good to go. There were some Collard Green that I didn't care for much - maybe collard greens are too soggy for my taste? The Garlic Mashers were HELLA buttery. Like it was 1 part potato 2 parts butter. And the side of Yucca fries with Aoili was my favorite side of them all. 

This was definitely the way to splurge on Fat Tuesday. The location is great... directly across the street for Mitchell's ice cream. 

Parking was ehh.. but we kinda cheated because we parked at the Safeway! Oops..

Cheers for this place. I'll certainly come back after easter (since I gave up deep fried foods for Lent!!)
author: Alyson C.

description:
Tonight I had the vegan special, a coconut-based stew with various vegetables (like okra).  I found it kind of bland, not as rich or spicy or salty as I like. It did seem very nutritious though.  
 
My husband and my friend LOVED their fried chicken.  They said the meat was wonderfully juicy, and that it had a distinctive tang ---  apparently the meat sat in salt and lime before cooking.  The fried chicken bucket had more than enough for two. 
 
The skinny fries were delicious dipped in homemade ketchup with an interesting kick - we couldn't figure out which spice was in there, but it reminded us of BBQ-sauce. 
 
The mustard greens were good, not too soggy or soft, and they had a pleasant bitterness I liked.  They didn't have much seasoning though.
 
Our server referred to tap water as "Hetch Hetchy."  Cute.
author: angela n.

description:
I went during Beer Week last week, which was great because they had fun, inexpensive tastings. But as someone who has eaten real fried catfish and hushpuppies, this place didn't compare. If I'm going to eat fried food, I don't think I'd do it here again.

All in all, it's like southern home cooking with a bistro kick. Good stuff if you don't know any better. Fun hole-in-the-wall atmosphere as the place is really small. Rocking chairs on the front porch. Go on Thursdays so you can get their special Farmer's Market dishes.
author: Meredith W.

description:
Went here last night for an impromptu early dinner with the wifey.  Thank God Granny came to babysit - we haven't had a nice meal out together in a long time.

We came at about happy hour and sampled a number of small plates.  By the time we were done, we both hurt in that really good way.  We tried the "Lawn Clippings" mixed green salad, shrimp and grits, mac and cheese, fried black cod po' boy, gumbo, greens, and corn bread.  The Lillita - mojito but with Lillet - was ok.  The two Abita's we had were great.  We finished with chocolate chess pie and donut bread pudding.

A food spectacular for fairly cheap - at least SF-standards cheap.
author: Chris D.

description:
Lotsa reviews already, so I'll be quick.

The good:

- the cod fritters (SOOO GOOD)
- friendly service
- the fries
- the house salad
- it's a cute little restaurant

The not-so-good:

- the fried chicken -- overrated.  It's good, but nothing great.  And not worth the hefty price tag
- lobster, mango, hamachi salad thing.  just not that good.  and i was most excited about this.
- cornbread.  not really buttery enough.  and kinda chewy.  i prefer my mom's (which are made from a box, I think).  we all took 1 bite and put the rest back.
- wine and beer only

we were also interested in the cucumber salad, but then the server explained that it's literally just chopped up cucumber...

in the end, just too pricey for what it is.
author: S J.

description:
BUCKET O' CHICKEN!  Now that's some good grubbin!

Went there for a bday din din me and two friends and it was coo.  I kept thinking that we were in someone's living room, though.  That was a bit interesting.  Maybe that's the feel that the owner was going for.  Either way, their chicken is where its at and oddly enough, their soup WAS REALLY TASTY AND FILLING.  Forgot what it was but talk about SCRUMPTIOUS!    Would definately go back... or at least order take out.
author: Sas C.

description:
PROS: Close to home. Nice ambiance, décor. Close to Mitchell's Ice Cream (oops). Ease of booking reservation, smooth. Bathroom Cute.

CONS: Food not up to par, service is a hit or miss, a bit dark in the restaurant.

I came here w/J.M. and we were excited to finally try The Front Porch. The visual impression of the restaurant was cool. The décor was for sure eclectic- a mix of French Country-Art Deco-Victorian-Shabby, w/the use of darker colors. If anything, the ambiance had a chill, southern-hip vibe to it. We ordered the Porch Fries (a mix of Sweet Potato and regular fries), Mac n Cheese, and the Shrimp n Grits. We got corn on the cob shaped cornbread to munch on while we waited- 2 words: Sahara Desert. The Fries were dark and burnt, could barely even find a sweet potato fry. The shrimps tasted like they were swimming in a pool of red wine reduction. And the grits....poor grits, they were almost non-existent, lost in the sauce and the word "runny" would even be a nice way to describe it at this point. The best thing we dined on was the baked Mac n Cheese. It wasn't the best I've had, but compared to the rest of the food we ordered it was their saving grace.

You could read J.M.'s review about the service, which was another upset that's knocking a star off my rating. Maybe we caught them on a bad day, but unfortunately I don't think I'll be dining here again.

Don't...don't-don't..don't believe the hype....oooohahhhhh.... (that was my attempt at spelling out the note sung after hype, bwahaa)
author: Rho T.

description: Like have a little city of the Saints in your backyard. If you haven't tried this your missing on the taste of a culture responsible for a whole lot of what this country is now. A recent discovery of down-home that will have me coming back more than a few times.
author: Steve S.

description: Mediocre chicken (think Colonel Sanders), way over-priced and served in filthy, seedy surroundings. This place is getting away with murder.  HOLY SHIT.
author: Stephen K.

description:
The original chef moved...  :(   
They now have spicy shrimp and grits ..... Not as good.  Sniffle, Wahhh !!!
author: Mark B.

description: amazing mac and cheese, biscuits , fried okra was not the best but the jalapeno aioli is a winner , fried chicken was very moist  and batter was different than any place around ... desserts were great chocolate pudding  and pecan pie both did not disappoint ...the place is amazing and cozy and perfect for a date ....
author: NAEL K.

description: Beautiful interior, fun rocking chairs on the front porch.  The heirloom tomato salad was yummy, as were the crab grits and the fried chicken (though both were undersalted). But I think I like Emmy's best, then Farmer Brown, then Front Porch, in terms of their restaurant empire
author: Vanessa H.

description:
dim lights, cool vibe, GOOD FOOD!

fairly priced with an interesting selection. Definitely hit the southern comfort spot. Went here with the bf for a relaxed sunday night dinner, service was great and had a minimal wait. Our menu consisted of:

hushpuppies: incredible crunch, spot on spice and a flavorful dipping sauce
french fries: combo of regular and sweet potatoe, perfectly crisp, piping hot and creamy interior, paired with a creole aioli
mac and cheese: not the high light,but the creamy consistency was spot on!
fried chicken: w/ mash potatoes and collard greens, super moist and the breading was nice and fine which made a nice crunch. 
sweet tea: yum, duh
ginger beer: refreshing, unique, delicious.

ps. walking distance from mitchell's ice cream, WIN.
author: isabelle g.

description:
I came here with my girlfriends for our weekly fat friday meal. We heard that this place gets pretty crowded & that they open at 5:30 so we got there as close to 5:30 as we could. 

The atmosphere and the whole look of the restaurant is adorable and to the tee! We actually wanted to sit on their rocking chairs that they had on their front porch. (: 

When we got there they asked if we had reservations, and we didn't. But we were able to get seated if we were going to be done by 7:15, so we said yes & took the seats! I guess its good to know that reservations really do help to get a seat at this place, and they don't give away your table so they guarantee you table.

Down to the food, we weren't too hungry so we decided to only order 1 appetizer and 2 entrees for three girls. 
- Appetizer: FRIED PICKLES $6. I was extremely excited to try their fried pickles because I am a pickle lover and and fried pickle lover! But boy was it a disappointment! I don't know if it was the pickles that they used, or the batter they fried it in but it -was just not working. I would never get those again. 
- Entree #1: FRIED CHICKEN(SINGLE) $17. We got the single because it comes with 3 pieces and there were three of us! I believe the bucket ($33 1/3) comes with 8 pieces or something and that was going to be too much for us. This comes with three pieces of chicken, mashed potatoes and collard greens. Oh my, the chicken was delicious! The skin was so crispy and the chicken meat was very moist. The mashed potatoes were very creamy (which is good, because I do enjoy mashed potatoes that melt in my mouth), and I'm not a big fan of collard greens but my friend who enjoys them said that they were very good!
- Entree #2: HALF RACK BABY BACK RIBS.This comes with a half rack of baby back ribs (6 bones on the ribs), lumpy mashed potatoes (different from the mashed potatoes that come with the fried chicken), and grilled corn on a cob. Everything about this dish was good. The BBQ sauce that they provide with it is on point. 

I would come back to this place for their fried chicken and baby back ribs, but definitely not for their fried pickles!
author: Taylor C.

description:
Wow, was I surprised not to like this place! Entering the building I had a really good vibe, and the bartender was extremely kind to us. That was the last person who treated me the way I expect to be treated at a place like this. 

The wait staff was way too "in your face"; I felt hurried to place our order and constantly interrupted during the course of the meal. Music & noise levels were identical to a crowded bar, making it very difficult to conduct what I consider typical dinner conversation. 

At least one order of each course (appetizer, entree, dessert, and beverages) took forever to arrive. They did provide a couple of randomly selected dishes to fill the interminable delays, but I would have preferred their waiving the charge for late food rather than having to politely pick at nectarines in sea salt. At one point I actually had to corral our waiter and utter the sentence, "What's the status of those nuts?" which was the turning point for our waiter from in-your-face-let's-get-it-over-with to obsequious and visiting too often. 

Guess I should have ordered the fried chicken! Unfortunately, I'll never go back. If I want good chicken, Goood Frikin Chicken is down the block at Mission, and compared to the Front Porch they have ZERO attitude.
author: Dan S.

description:
Our group of 4 was seated promptly around 9:30 on a Thursday without reservations. I'm a fried chicken-holic (one of my, ahem, healthier addictions) and this was one amazing bucket of fried chicken! Had the greens and the grits with it, and washed it down with a cold one from a very, very well edited beer list.

Cool interior, hip vibe, but the service still needs a bit o' work.
author: Priya S.

description:
Before we even moved into our new condo, friends told us we were so lucky to have Front Porch in our Hood; then when we finally moved in, I looked out the front Bay window and just to the right of the Bernal Heights Pot Club was a neon sign: Front Porch. I thought, "How frickin' wonderful is that?! We need to check it out." So we did--on a couple of occassions. 

First of all, the best thing about the place for me is the Bartenders: cute and friendly; they also pour a generous glass of wine--try the Sancerre it is the best on the menu. 

During the couple of times we have eaten there, I have tried the burger, ceviche, brussel sprouts, fried okra, chicken livers, fries, and bites of my girlfriend's fried chicken when she was not looking. I am a dedicated patron and will eventually try everything on the menu, but favorites some times just get in the way! So far the dishes have been delicious, but I must say the fried okra did visit me later, but sure was good while I was chowing down on it. 

My only gripe is not the wait--go have a beer at the 3300 Club; nor the noise--turn up your hearing aid; it is that the menu does not change that much so I cannot go there as often as I like. Yes I am selfish; I want variety, but with that said, when I am in the mood for a burger, chicken, fried anything, or a glass of Sancerre, I walk across the street and get myself some. Worth the wait for sure!
author: Deborah S.

description:
Great place to go to with a group of friends to sample their tasty menu.

Bucket of fried chicken is served with some popcorn for some extra style points. Grits, grits, grits! Not a huge fan but damn was it tasty. Especially the crab grits. Dont forget to try the fried oysters with a poached egg and greens. The mac n cheese was ok but small servings.

Place can get packed so make sure you get their early. It also a nice "front porch" to hang out and have a beer while you wait. Wait staff is super nice even with my group of 8 or so people.The interior has a retro/antique vibe with southern flare.
author: Gabe H.

description:
I have eaten enough fried chicken in my lifetime to feed all of China - Basically, I consider myself a fried chicken connoisseur.  And the fried chicken was NOT tasty.  Soggy mess on my plate.  I expected much more from this place.  Wasn't even worth me taking home left overs. 

This place gets two stars because the staff was super friendly and helpful. 

If you want good fried chicken - go to Q's on Clement. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz/q-san-francisco
author: Victoria F.

description:
eh, its just all right - sorry front porch,  I REALLY wanted to like you more - great atmosphere - seems like a real nice place - the staff are awesome and the little blonde watiress that works there is hella cute, but everything we ate was really dry....  the cornbread was dry, the chicken was dry, maybe we went here on an off night.    The only thing I liked was the rib appetizer which set us back $20 by itself.  

I might try ya again but am more likely to go to Hard knox for a better tastier value.
author: Rick R.

description:
:::Heart explodes!:::

This is definitely one of my new favorite restaurants although my arteries probably hate me for inflicting The Front Porch's wrath upon them.

The space is beautiful, homey and laid back and the food is just phenomenal and by San Francisco standards, quite inexpensive. Great fried chicken, greens, brussel sprouts, and fried okra (the okra was out of this world!!!). The drinks are well mixed, tasty and reasonably priced as well. Our server was really attentive and kind and our bus boy/drink filler upper guy never let our glasses run dry. 

The only thing I took issue with was that although one can arguably never have too much butter, I definitely got way too much of it when eating their mashed potatoes. However, if my only complaint about this place is getting too much of a good thing, surely it has to be great, right?
author: Clarissa S.

description:
Good quality fried chicken and grits. Decent drinks. Long wait (1hr - arrived around 7:30pm), amount of time eating = time waiting for table. Service - eh.

The story with service, more or less merited the loss of 2 stars. Strike 1: The manager acknowledged my friend and I when we walked in. Then walked away, and upon return ended up taking down names of people who arrived after us.  Strike 2: We got drinks at the bar and caught his attention, he got us on the list then or so we thought. We realized a drink later that he never asked us for a name. Mentioned it to him and he didn't have us on the list at all! He did remember the time we walked in and promised us the next table.  We got seated 15 minutes later...

Agreed with most Yelpers that the food satisfied our craving for fried chicken and crab grits. The sides weren't spectular, but we liked the trio of fries we got on the side.  Scene is typical Mission hipster, able to have a conversation without having to shout that much.
author: Amy Y.

description:
My only complaint is that a place that serves a "poor man's plate" should definitely serve sweetbreads, but apparently they only do that once in a blue moon for some uber-special occasion. What did I say in Chicago? SF, CATCH UP PLEASE!

The "poor man's plate" last night consisted of amazingly tender pork cuts in a barely-spicy onion gravy and a-bed mashed red potatoes. I really want to know what made the potatoes so sticky, because I seriously couldn't stop eating them even way past my fullness limit. One friend had a very ample portion of the boneless short ribs which were smothered in a deliciously tangy bbq sauce. 

Two things. First, the entrees are definitely large enough to share around the table, which is the best way to taste a little bit of everything. Second, ask for things extra spicy or ask for hot sauce... because although some dishes are described as being spicy, they aren't.
author: kay v.

description:
My boyfriend Fussy Fusspot and I went to a charity event that benefited the Gay Historical Society. Since Fussy is a gay, I agreed to accompany him so he wouldn't get caught muttering to himself in a corner like a crazy person. If you ever see a guy in the back of a BART train, whispering to him self in a low voice the amount of people that get off at the Montgomery station, don't be alarmed, it's just my Fussy amusing himself. 

Anyway, so many of these kinds of events have several food stations that provide 4" plates and bites of this and bites of that; this is okay if you have already eaten. But at the dinner hour I hate this method of feeding the masses. This event had tid-bits of this cube of ham and a little squirty spread on that piece of tiny bread, tiny salads in plastic martini glasses and an array of miscellaneous food wadded up in small ball shapes.  The worst part about eating at many events is that they make you eat while standing up, I hate this too. The plus, plus, plus thing about this particular event was that they hosted a fully stocked and open bar, and it was big with minimal wait times.  This made up for the three giant bowls of potato chips with coordinating dips.

After twirling it up on the dance floor to the live music of a singing tranny in sequins and confirming we lost the raffle prizes and silent auction items we bid on, it was time to go. We threw our wine and vodka lined tummies into a cab and made our way to The Front Porch. 

The instant we walked into the restaurant we were greeted by the bartender, and we were seated by a very nice hostess within minutes. I was so much in the mood for a quirky, quaint neighborhood restaurant like this and I immediately felt good about my surroundings. It was dark and moody, and the people looked like they were all having a great time. Eclectic decor and eclectic clientele was the dining room theme. At the first table near the entrance I saw some of the dishes and the plates were big and the portions were generous. The menu was interesting and the food was good. We shared their fried chicken, and this would be reason alone for me to return. As well as having a fair price point for the caliber and style of cooking. 

A couple sat down beside us. Boris and Natashia, they were very nice without being overly chatty. They met each other while mountain biking and Boris left his phone number on Natashia's car windshield. Their first date was a bit later, and they grabbed a cup o' Joe together and have been lovingly staring into each others eyes for two years. They were a very attractive couple, which is good because I hate looking at ugo's while I eat. 

I very much liked this restaurant, and it is a place I would want to go back to with friends who are virgins to this hidden gem. This restaurant gets 5 thumbs up!
author: Blade L.

description: Great food! Recommend it, but ummm, we all dont like listening to Sex Pistols at dinner, thank you.
author: John A.

description: I love some damn good cajun food, and well here you go.  Stop on over to The Front Porch and be welcomed with some good southern hospitality.  I have friends that live here, originally from New Orleans, and they applaud this place!  That says something right there. Try their Po Boy sandwiches,mmm.   They have good lemonade or wine and beer if you want alcohol.  I am going back for brunch to have their chicken and waffles!!  I will say their cornbread is nice and sweet tasting too!
author: gayle w.

description: Best Mac and Cheese I've had in a long time!!
author: Michi M.

description:
Three words: GET THE GRITS.
and a few more words--
I have had their spicy crab grits as well as their spicy shrimp grits and I have to say -- they are both wonderful. $12 dollars is a little pricy for a bowl of grits, I have to say, but once in a while, I like to spoil myself.

Fried Chicken to die for. That's all I have to say.

Came here for Valentines Day; the place was decorated with balloons. They had a special "Valentine's Day" menu. We got the bucket of chicken for 2 that came with mashed potatoes and collard greens. 

The service was great. The food was great. It's a little pricey for southern comfort food, but great quality and atmosphere.
author: M B.

description:
As I mentioned in my review of CreoLa, I have a high standard when it comes to Southern food, being from New Orleans. I very much enjoyed my dining experience here (loved the porch outside with the rocking chairs and the back seats of cars as seating inside!), but was slightly underwhelmed when it came to the food. I opted for the small portion of the gumbo and the shrimp and grits. In the case of the gumbo, it was a bit too salty, and something about the actual soup wasn't quite right in terms of the texture of it. As for the shrimp and grits, again, I had an issue with the texture - they were too runny, and the shrimp barely had any bite to it.

However, I did enjoy my cocktail (the lil' rouge corvette, which had Lillet Rouge in it), and the complimentary cornbread with the spicy butter was quite tasty. The dessert, chocolate chess pie with caramel pecan ice cream, was quite good, too.

That said, I am intrigued by the fried chicken since some fellow Yelpers are saying it's the best they've ever had, so I'm going to have to go back to try that. In spite of being a bit disappointed in the food, I probably will go back even after my fried chicken quest, as it's the closest place to where I live to get my much-needed fix from time to time for most excellent Southern food.
author: Rachel G.

description: I love this place. The gumbo is extremely rich. The fried chicken is fantastic. (It's obviously brined, so if you don't like brined chicken, you won't like it... I love it). But, the real treat? The seafood and grits. My favorite is the crawfish and grits. My only gripe? No liquor.
author: Rich H.

description:
Was craving for some fried chicken and was recommended this place.  Started off our meal with some gumbo and fried okra, both were deeeelish.  I never I thought I'd like okra but I actually couldn't stop eating it!  Got the baked mac n cheese for my daughter (and yes by the way, it is a family friendly place as they even had a kid's menu) and that was even good, not your typical mac n cheese, it was a tasty mozzarella kind.  Hubby and I shared the bucket of chicken with mashed potatoes and it did not disappoint.

The only bad thing about this place 1) as most places you go to in SF, parking is tough, 2)  the place is small and they get pretty busy, and they wouldn't seat us right away because our whole party wasn't there.  (there was only 3 of us and my husband was looking for parking) although I saw a table with only 2 people whom the hostess approached and they said they were waiting for 2 more people.  Otherwise the service was pretty good.
author: WinnJess E.

description:
"Fucket Get The Bucket," The Front Porch sticker.  Now this is my kinda rhymin'!  I mean it.

My friends and I planned to meet at 7:30 this past Thursday and at the last minute I thought to make a reservation.  Nothing at 7:30 so I took the 8pm reservation thinking we could still meet at 7:30 and enjoy a nice drink on the front porch.  

I had a nice time chatting with one of the owners, enjoyed my drink (lil' rouge corvette - a lovely red wine and ginger beer mix), and got the chance to catch up with my friends.  But then, my hunger made an appearance...it was 8pm, great! - we'll be seated soon...8:10 still no appearance of the nice owner ready to show us to our table, however hunger was in full sight.  8:20...8:30 (I know this really isn't THAT much time passed but hunger minutes are MUCH longer than normal minutes.)  Finally, we saw a large group leave meaning our table was going to be ready soon!  yay!  It didn't exactly happen immediately, but it happened - we were seated!

I've been here two times before and I knew exactly what I was going to get!  And I did not hesitate to encourage my friends (first-timers) to join me.  Fucket get three buckets!  At 2 sides per bucket we were able to try all 6 sides.  A complete meal!  The fried chicken was perfection as usual!  The corn meal crust is the crispiest I've ever had!  The crispy full-flavored batter is wonderfully matched by the tender juicy chicken.  One more thing - the chicken was nicely complimented by their fire in the hole hot sauce!  Two sides stood out from the rest - the grilled corn on the cob which dripped of butter and the grits which were also dripping with butter!  Our dinner was fantastic and we have the clogged arteries to show for it!   

I would like to give them 5 stars because I really do love the atmosphere, the music, the vibe, and most importantly the food!  However, our waitress was unable to pull our experience together.  And it wasn't just that she was super busy, she was in fact busy - but she was definitely more attentive and friendly to our neighboring tables which made us feel singled out in a very negative way.  The guys who helped her deliver some of our food were very fun and helpful though.  I'm definitely going to return, you too should try this place, and hopefully we both have more luck with the service.
author: Nicole N.

description:
REVIEW OF TAKE OUT ONLY

We walked by a few times, and it's adorable. Cute front porch area for diners while they wait to be seated. The inside is dark but looks homey.

Last night, we decided to get take out, since we weren't in the mood for going out. Be warned - they only accept take out orders when the kitchen isn't busy, so early evening on weekdays and not at all on weekends. We called pretty late (around 9PM), and they explained their take out policy, but since they weren't swamped, agreed to take our order. 

We got the bucket of fried chicken with the trio of fries and coleslaw. I'm kind of a coleslaw snob - often the dressing is off or there's an imbalance in veggies - but the Front Porch gets it just right. In terms of the bucket, for almost $30, it was not a large bucket. But the fried chicken certainly hit the spot! I'll definitely be back to try their fried oysters. All and all, a great find in Bernal Heights.
author: kathy c.

description:
This is a great place to eat if you are in the mood for a watered down interpretation of "Soul/Carribean food", in no way shape or form is this a Caribbean Restaurant, sorry.  

The fried chicken is very good, very tender and juicy but $30 for a bucket of chicken, Really?  The cornbread was delicious, not too sweet, not too salty, just right.  

The doubles: these are not doubles and you shouldn't call them that.  I saw "Doubles" on the menu and started salivating almost did a happy dance to be honest, only to receive something else.  In an era and place where Doubles are non-existent, its just plain mean to tease people like that.  Mean.

The service was great, each person that came to our table was exceptionally warm and accommodating (and fashion forward if I do say).  If I was in the neighborhood and was hungry, I would absolutely stop in and have a meal.  If I was craving Soul food or Caribbean food, I would look elsewhere though.

$30 for a bucket of chicken?  Really, you are serious?  Wow.
author: Rosie C.

description:
I went here last night because I had the biggest craving for fried chicken and i didn't want to make it myself.  I heard that the fried chicken here was out of this world and blah blah blah....well that's exactly what it was blah.  I love fried chicken so much that I usually eat quite a few pieces during a meal.  By a few pieces i mean like 3-4 or 4-5 on a good day.  This place served two measly pieces, which were quite small and just kinda blah.  The crispy factor was there but the flavor was missing.  So i drenched it with the wonderful habanero chutney that they offer in this cute bottle and ate my 2 little pieces of chicken that cost $13.  I think that's just highway robbery for 2 pieces, even if it comes with a side of grits and black eyed peas.  

Some good things are: the ambiance, it was really well decorated with antique accents and the colors worked well together.
-the presentation of the food was lovely, too bad there wasn't much food there.
-the CHUTNEY was phenomenal!!!  It was the best part of my meal.

As far as being good Southern food, I think that the menu has a little more of a fancy twist and not enough of the actual Southern flavors or portions.  

I'd give this place another chance coz maybe there are other things that are delicious, but i will never get the fried chicken again!
author: Maria B.

description:
Pickled veggies & eggs? - Pickled, tangy and spicy hot, but in a good way.

Crab & grits? - Yes, please!

More wine? - Yep, keep the bottles coming.

Bucket of chicken? - Why is there crumpled up paper in the bottle of my bucket?  Hence minus one star.

OUCH!  Hunger pains.   Time for dinner!
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
Literally waiting on their 'front porch" for our table, the setting outside the front door was very inviting. 

seated towards the front of the restaurant, you could look into the rest of the place and see it was like being in a large house. Sweet decor with great ambiance.

I ordered Momma's country fried chicken with mac n' cheese while my friend ordered the Crab grits. The brought little appetizers like: purple potato chips and corn bread strips. the corn bread was awesome! some of the best I've ever had. 

Service was top notch for being busy, very attentive on everything. with anticipation our food arrived just before getting ancy, and I was pleased. The chicken was cooked perfectly and the cornmeal batter was tasty. I tried their super hot housemade Habanero sauce which gave everything a nice zing. The crab grits were great , I never thought grits could have so much flavor!

Definitely comin' back with a crew to try more dishes!
author: Dave S.

description: Always amazing with a great staff to compliment the great food. The owners are always there which says a lot. Since I moved here four years ago The Front Porch has always been a go to spot for me even when I moved out of the area.
author: adam c.

description:
Three words. Out. Freaking. Standing. I'm going on the record to say that was the best fried chicken I've ever had. Before last night, I was super loyal to Farmer Brown, but I can't lie...Front Porch's fried chicken bucket with housemade habenero sauce is unbeatable. There are like 4 billion other reviews of this place so I won't spend time saying what everyone else has already said, but seriously - crispy, juicy, cornmeal-crusted with a little bit of zip...I can't wait to go back...

And they serve King Cobra. That's just dope.
author: Kate S.

description:
Yes. You should go.

Ok keeping it real time. I kept hearing about this place for what seemed like forever. I was curious, however I didn't really try to make it a priority to go because...well it's outta my way (like waaayyy out) and two, I have been dissapointed by recommendations from people who swere so and so has great fried chickens/greens etc, and then you go and after the first bite your set to slap the ish outta them because apparently they fell for hipster hype and the food tastes like leftovers from Popeyes. A bad Popeyes.

Not the case with The Front Porch. The hostesses were very nice.My table of three ordered the following:

Gumbo
Bucket of Chicken (comes with mashed potatoes and collard greens)
Bisqcuits for Boobies (a plate of two)
Side order of Ear of Corn
Side of Baked Mac N Cheese

Desserts:
Peach Cobbler with Vanilla Ice Cream
Beignets
Chocolate Smores Bread Pudding with Caramel Prailine Ice Cream
Coffee

Yes, that is a sh*tload of food. 

E's gumbo was gone in no more then 10 minutes, aka very good. It was gone before we had a chance to try and sample it (greedy bastard).
The chicken was awesome! Seasoned perfectly, not greasy. Was served in a popcorn container with a lil popcorn, nice touch. Taste very well on its own, or they had two Front Porch sauces you could pair with the chicken if you like. The mashed potatoes...very creamy. Not overpowering. Very good. Greens are legit, for real. Not overpowering like a lot of places or reeking of vinegar.
Mac N Cheese- I wish they had a larger portion but I guess in the meantime you can just order two+. It was just the way I like it. Nice crusting over the top, crisp edges yet creamy at the same time. Served in a small cast iron dish. The serving however is only enough for 1-2. I recommend everyone order their own.
Biscuits- They were ok. Please note these are not like the hungry jack or pillsbury many people are usually familiar with. they were two old school rich style Biscuits. And they served them with butter and honey.

Desserts:

Ok this is the main thing you need to know about the desserts. Each dessert can be shared between 2 if not 3 people, except the beignets IMO. Or you can do like we did and order different ones and share.

The biggest winner was the Smores Bread Pudding. OMFG!!! Save room for this. I'm serious. Uh-Mazing. Chocolate sauce at the bottom of the bowl, the ice cream was a perfect match with the bread pudding, but note that it stands very well on its own. If you love chocolate or want something sweet to share, you need this in your life.

Peach Cobbler- Good and rich. Lots of peaches. Defin a dish to be shared..

Beignets- Eh. They were ok. Dusted with powered sugar and some chocolate sauce on the side of the dish. Dip em in your coffee!

Did I mention the winning dessert was the bread pudding? OMG.

Plus I thought it was funny you can also get a tall can of King Cobra here as well. I had the Champagne Cocktail, very good.

All in all, we had a great time, TONS of food...didnt eat again until 3 the next day (this dinner was around 6:30 eve). Could not even finish all the desserts, accidently left behind a couple pieces of chicken we had packed to go..was heartbroken about that.

Loved it. Great food, great people. If you don't drive (like many of us, myself included, you can take the 14 Mission, get off at 29th and walk down a block. 

So..I guess my hipster friends are one step closer to credibility. Kinda. :)
author: Patrice W.

description:
The biggest problem I think a lot of people will run into with Front Porch is that for  "down home cooking" the prices can seem a little high. However, if you have a little flexibility on price in exchange for experience I think you will have a fine time at the Front Porch. 

DO:

Do sit out on the porch and have a drink (or at least at the bar) so you can soak up the quarky atmosphere here. They have all the usual beer, wine and cocktails, but also have some fun options like tall cans, malt liquor and juice boxes of wine.

Do get the fried chicken; you kind of have to at least once. I liked it, but am not the biggest fan of the cornmeal based crust.

DONTS:

Don't come super hungry, as you will most likely have to wait at least a little.

Don't order the larger version of crab and grits, opt for the small size. This is an extremely indulgent and rich dish, the small is way more than enough and you basically just get twice the grits and the same amount of crab for twice the money if you go for the large. 

Don't expect the best fried chicken, just go and order some fried chicken and see how it turns out. 

Don't under any circumstances try to drive here! Parking is horrible around the restaurant; we looked for over half an hour and ultimately ended up many, many blocks away. Friends have told me similar stories.

I would recommend this restaurant to:

Someone who lives in SF or visits frequently who has already hit up some of the more well known mid-priced dining options and is looking for a little different dining experience.
author: Alex D.

description: Great food, good ambiance. We went with a table of 8 and just ordered a couple of buckets of chicken along with 2 sides of everything. I loved the Mac & Cheese, greens, & Chicken the most. Our waitress & service was also great. We started getting our plates within 5 minutes of being ordered.
author: Craig G.

description:
We were so excited that a new restaurant was going to be opening up down the street from us. And we couldn't be happier with how The Front Porch turned out. We went on opening night and while the wait was long, we can tell that it's going to be a great place and we'll probably go back regularly.

The cornbread with spicy butter was a unique and appropriate combination. My wife had the steak, which was a little spicy for her but I thought it was great. Her steak came with a really good potato salad and grilled corn on the cob. I had built up a hankerin' for the fried chicken after seeing it posted on their menu a few days earlier, but sadly they were out of it and I got a burger. Turns out the burger was very flavorful and cooked perfectly -- crispy on the outside and very juicy inside. 

We were as impressed by the service as we were by the food. It was opening night and things were pretty crazy, but both of the owners found time to stop and chat with us. The staff was very apologetic about the long wait (which was totally understandable -- opening night!) and made sure that we were happy.

We'll definitely go back to The Front Porch. Not just because it's about 20 steps from our house, but because we now feel like we don't need to go very far at all to get excellent food and service.
author: Scott K.

description:
Anthony and I came here tonight for my birthday, after seeing so many great reviews here on Yelp.

I absolutely enjoyed dining here, although Anthony didn't care much for it.  

The service was excellent.  Our waiter was friendly and explained items on the menu.  We started with the dungeness crab salad, which we both enjoyed.  Anthony started complaining (to me of course) that he just hates waiting a long time for his food.  Then the waiter suddenly brought us (without charging) a pureed pea pesto with chile oil.  I guess for having to wait.  Excellent I thought.  

I had the boneless ribs, very good with an excellent sauce.  Anthony had the chicken, but wasn't too impressed.  I told the waiter it was my birthday, and at the end of our meal, he brought me out a huge dish of vanilla ice cream (at no charge). Very nice.

I was impressed that they had corn pudding and donut holes for desser that were made out of grits.  This could satisfy my gluten free diet.  I didnt' order it because we had cake waiting at home...(mental note: Happy Birthday to ME!!) 

I would recommend this place.  Oh, and Anthony didn't like how dark it was.
author: Gretchen F.

description:
I got the bucket of fried chicken and it was decent.  The wait staff was pushy and nearly forced appetizers on us.  The environment is dark and retains many of the characteristics of a lifetime of being a Mexican divebar.  If you don't mind not seeing your food than this is the place for you.  If you don't mind extremely salty food and not enough water than this is the place for you.  For me, I'll go elsewhere...

To top it off, one of the staff  (if not the owner) contacted me through YELP and tried to persuade me to change my review.  Pathetic.
author: Darkie L.

description:
If you've never been here before, this place is always packed. Even with a reservation, my small group (5 of us), still waited a half hour for a very cozy table.  The service was acceptable.  Our waitress was friendly and hospitable.  
The food was okay, nothing spectacular. Maybe my taste buds are shot but after hearing about how great the fried chicken would be, I guess I expected something that was similar to southern fried chicken I had in small towns in Louisiana.  Not so.  One of my dining mates smacked his lips and thought he was eating KFC.  The grit porridge was smoother than I'm used to (I want to taste the GRIT) but the black eyed peas and collards was delicious.  The ceviche had a nice, spicy kick to it.  The good variety of beers and wine made the trip worthwhile.
author: Eileen Q.

description:
dude i heard so many good things about this place.  i was finally in this neighborhood last night and decided to give it a try.  

wasn't impressed.  had bucket of fried chicken, crab and grits, beet salad and tuna carpaccio.  the beet salad was the best.  dressing and fried onions were tasty.  tuna and persimmons were drenched in olive oil and i just remember my big lips covered with all oil and being shiny.  the tuna was nothing special.  crab and grits, not sure, i never had grits so not sure if it was good or bad.  i didn't like it personally.  fried chicken is my favorite food but not at this place.  the batter was boring and tasteless.  after a drum and thigh, my final 3rd piece i just ripped off the batter and ate the meat which was good.  it came in a popcorn bucket like an OG one from the movie theatres and had some popcorn in it too.  that was cool.  the fried chicken for $6 at sam's on broadway street SF is superior to this.

the place is very small and tight between tables.  the servers were pretty nice.  i don't go out to that neighborhood often and probably won't be back there for a while.
author: Kevin L.

description: We both thoroughly enjoyed the food.  I had the fried chicken, good but not the best.  I think Hard Knox has better fried chicken and lower in price.  The pork chop was excellent, the mashed potatoes creamy, the collard greens very tasty but the mac and cheese was so-so.  My biggest problem with this restaurant is the lighting and the pricing.  I would like to see it more well lit simply because for people with vision issues, I couldn't see the menu, the wine list, etc. I don't think I will return.
author: Sylvia E.

description:
From the reviews, I was afraid we'd have to wait an hour to get in at 7, but we waltzed right in! Unfortunately, we couldn't sit in a booth, since it was just a party of 2,and the place is teeny-tiny. The crew did a great job of the decor, and our server was laid-back and professional.

Now the food. Kids: this ain't soul food. I'll go with Caribbean. Folks in the sunny south ain't addin' coconut to collard greens. I didn't get a chance to order the famous crab porridge, but I can make that at home. However, I had the Old Speckled Hen amber ale from the UK, and we split the bucket o'fried with two sides:the charred corn on the cob and the combo of collards and black eyed peas. We also had the potato salad and red beans & rice. The potato salad was supposed to have had creole mustard, but I couldn't detect it, and the rice was flavored with coconut, too. 

The chicken is cooked to order, so it arrived at the table piping hot. And as for me, leave the stale-ass popcorn away from my chicken! As the place filled up, it was quite warm inside; I should have asked them to turn on the ceiling fan. I'd go back and try the pork chop - a nearby table ordered one and it looked great!
author: Rene D.

description:
Quaint and homey in the outer Mission. Hipster without the attitude. You can tell the people who work here love their restaurant and don't hate customers.

I loved the shrimp and grits and the fried green tomatoes. The cocktails were also original and paired perfectly with the food.

loved everything I ordered, but the fried chicken. It is not bad, it just wasn't my style.. some parts were more salty than others and it had herbs in it. I like my fried chicken simple... flour, salt... maybe buttermilk and cayenne. (my friends enjoyed the chicken)

I would definitely return to sample the rest of the menu. Great place for a first dinner date.
author: Claudia O.

description:
Best ketchup of my life.   And I don't throw around that designation lightly.

We, my southern-fried foodie father and my beau and I, filed in to this sardine of an establishment, full to the gills, with assurances that our middle-of-the-room table normally just for two was, in fact, the "rock star" table.  I took the "rock star" seat with my butt out in harm's way; so the fact that was bumped only once by a patron, not a server, is tribute to the skill of the bustling waitstaff.

Sushi had lost out to "southern Mission" tonight by decree of the 6'4" guy with a fat wallet.  So we order them to bring us every type of fish on the menu that night:  salmon ceviche, tuna tartare, the catfish, and a special swordfish entree.  Father's talked into trying the crab grits, despite fried chicken on the menu.  We decided to round out the meal with the vegan okra dish, the Brussel sprouts, and a side of pickles.

Waiting for food (and avoiding the cute corn bread because, as the help confidently reports to me, it's got wheat flour in it), I spot a steaming bucket floating past us on its way to a far table.  "That must be the fried chicken."  Father whips his head around and looks longingly at the bits of crust you can barely see hidden in the white tube.  We note that it's far from a *full* bucket of chicken.  "Oh," he says, mildly self-satisfied.

The winner was most certainly the swordfish entree.  Holy moly.  A close second was the tuna tartare.  The salmon ceviche was surprisingly bland; if I'd held my nose I might have guessed it was poached egg white.

Father *hearts* the crab grits.  Yes, Yelp, you win.  Should have avoided the strange vegan dish, which was a lot like eating some kind of canned marinara sauce.

We get a fun surprise at the end when our head waiter decided to fix me (poor digestively challenged me, with the lack of milk and wheat in my diet) a special dessert -- a huge bowl of poached pears with non-dairy caramel.  Awwww yeah.

To tell the truth, I could have just kept eating the caramelized Brussel sprouts for dessert.  Occasional dips of That Ketchup.  Oh my yes.
author: Naomi M.

description:
Do you have disposable income and tattoos? Maybe an ill-fitted hoodie and worn Chuck Taylors? Answer yes to all of these questions, and Front Porch is the eatery for you.

Not only is Front Porch bringing some much-needed variety to the Mariachi dominance of the nether reaches of Mission Street. Not only does Front Porch make me feel cooler than I really am--in a surly, insurgent Bay Guardian kind of way, rather than a effete haute coutuer 7x7 kind of way. Not only does Front Porch look cool inside with the funky low ceiling. Not only is the throng of hipsters too loud to hear the Pixies and Nas playing on the radio. Not only can you cope with the interminable wait by bellying up to the bar down the block at the 3300 Club, only to have the owner of Front Porch personally come and fetch you you're your table's ready. Not only does the waiter offer you a water choice of "Pellegrino or Hetch Hetchy." (Try the Hetch Hetchy and subvert the bottled water racket.) Not only all that and a bucket of corn bread, but the food is great.

The cod and pepper fritters. Yum. Chicken liver with onion jam. Yum. Fried oysters with pork belly. Quite frankly, doing too much. Every entre I've had there has validated and enhanced my nerd girth--fried chicken, molasses-brined pork chop, pepper pot stew with wild boar and oxtails. It's all meaty and rich and cozy. Instant food coma.

Only word of caution--the desserts haven't done it for me. They're good, and maybe I'm just worn out by all the fried goodness on the way to dessert, but they haven't excited me. My preference is to skip dessert here and head over to Mitchell's to finish my night one happy glutton.
author: Nato G.

description:
I've been trying to think of a reason to go to 5 stars for front porch, but I can't seem to push myself over there. It's amazing; don't get me wrong. I just don't get chills up my spine thinking about it the way a 5 star rating should feel. I'm thinking it's the service. The first time I was there it was pretty darn good, but it felt like we were being waited on by someone who was "stepping in" to help the main servers. That's totally cool with me, but she didn't have all of the answers that our 8 person large group needed. A few other people actually ended up helping her as well...and dude 4 star service is NOT bad at all, but it's just not 5 star. To top it off, now that I've been there a few times and have had that same server I know what to expect. She's a nice person though, so she'll keep getting 20% from me. 

The food was spectacular - maybe 4.25 stars if I were on some kind of warped 5 star version of Star Search. With 8 people I think we actually tried everything that was on the menu, and while I will agree that the fried chicken is quite awesome, the side dishes are what will drive me back down there. 

They have wine, wine coctails, beer, and regular fare for drinks and a pretty nice jug wine that you should try for $24 if that sounds like your cup of tea...um...or jug of wine...anyway..

The location actually makes me want to move away from the crappy restaurants like Magnolia and the Alembic that I live by now, which probably think they're nearly as good as The Front Porch. They are not...by a long shot.
author: Mike M.

description: Best Fried Chicken in SF!  Got a bucket  of Chicken to go and it was amazing...  Can't wait to try other items on the menu.  Great Service
author: Y B.

description:
While the space itself is a complete assault on the senses (loud and dark), the food was excellent.

May 2008 update:
Still loud and dark. The service was excellent. Food was great. We had the fired okra, which we mentioned to the bartender was too salty. He tasted one, and immediately returned it to the kitchen. And was totally cool about it. We weren't even really complaining. He was unbelievably nice. I'm not used to this niceness wave that seems to be sweeping the hipster locales. What is going on? Is it the economy? Have to be nicer since fewer people are willing to spend discretionary bucks on dinner? Anyway, it was a welcome surprise.

We had the spare rib special. Which was delicious. Too much for one person. This dish would have been better with a smaller portion of beef, a little more sauce, less potato salad, and some green veggies. But that's just me. 

Again - I'm blown away by how nice the staff was.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
The Pros: Friendly place, awesome decor!!!, some exceptional food (I'm a vegetarian so I ordered two veggie apps instead of the 1 vegan entree). The butternut squash soup was good but very standard, nothing special and is served in those annoying huge saucer bowls that take up half the table. The greens and tomatoes appetizer was very good, I loved the spicy tangy sauce and the yummy fried ricotta dumplings although the greens in the dish were overcooked/mushy.

The cons: Slow Slow Slow service.. It's slow it really is. Friendly albeit but oh my god it's slow.

This place seems like a cool place to go with a bunch of people (although there isn't a lot of space) and drink and laugh and forget you are waiting. Otherwise prepare to wait.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I wanted to update my below review.  As promised...I went back to check out the Front Porch + am SO happy I did!

The food was sooooo much better!  Great friendly service, cool scene, blocks from my house all = I will add it to be one of my regular stops! 

Here is my original review - 
Ok....I want to start off saying that anyone who knows me, knows that Emmy's is my favorite place.  And that any of the  Emmy's extended family places that have opend (Blue Jay, Farmer Brown) I have been there to support.  

So I wanted to LOVE this place A) to support Josie and 2) I would love to have a new great place in my hood.  BUT......I have to admit (literally after thinking about this all weekend) that I was not impressed with the Food at all.  The atmosphere was really cute, the waiter was great and friendly, I love that you can order a "deuce" of wine, but the food, not so good.  I got the Summer Squash Curry...which had little to no flavor.  I know...trust me, I am sad about this too.

If I did not have ties to this place...from that meal, I would actually not go back, however, I am going to think positive that 1) I was there on an off night or 2) They are still new and working on the kinks with the menu and still give it another shot........but not for a couple of months.  

Until then......I will be keeping my fingers crossed:)
author: Michelle G.

description:
This is one of my new favorite places in SF. The atmophere is warm, inviting and funky; the staff was engaged and totally cool; and the food? Dungeness Crab grits was rich and creamy. Fried chicken was some of the best I've ever had (a bucket for $29 could easily feed three people alone). But the crowning achievement was the deep fried chicken liver--a huge pile of them, actually-- all molassess-ed and worchestershir-ed up on a piece of toasted thick bread. I said God Damn! 

It's not chic and they don't take reservations. But if you feel like some delicious downhome food, down-to-earth service, without any downtown pretensiousness, Front Porch is a great pick.
author: Benny B.

description: Awesome little place to get brunch on a Sunday afternoon. I ordered their poboy sandwich and it was fantastic. It was very tasty and good. My fiancee ordered the chicken and waffles but he said my sandwich was better. The place is uniquely decorated and has outdoor seating for warm days. There is a 30 minute wait for fried chicken because it's made to order. Either than that, this place is a cool place to try.
author: Anh W.

description:
The hubs brought me here for my thirty-hhhmmphth birthday and I love loved it.  We picked it from an article we saved rating the top 100 things to eat in SF (Front Porch was ranked for its crab and grits).  Sadly, the crab was out of season but the shrimp and grits were money with a big fat M!

Service was a bit slow but every recommendation by our waitress was spot on so don't be shy about asking.

Fried chicken was crisp and tasty...but skip the green bean side (yeah, it's the only healthy thing on the plate but so what).  The corn bread starter was also nice and a l'il spicy.

My only negative comment is that - while the red velvet cake hit the spot after 2+ glasses of wine - it still tasted previously frozen or chilled way ahead of time in the fridge.  So I suggest skipping that.

Otherwise, I say go roll up the sleeves and don't hesitate to get some chicken grease dribbling down your arms!!
author: Christina K.

description:
I'm a big fan of neighborhood joints- Emmys is a favorite and Blue Plate is my eating establishment of choice. Now we get to throw the front porch in the mix and it couldn't have come at a better time. I think the waiters were getting sick of seeing me at the other two.

The first nite I went to front porch Al Gore was there. Pretty much anywhere the protector of our ozone layer eats I'm cool with eating. It is dark and homey and very crowded. Every-time I have been in I have ran into at least one person I know, if not five.  The decor, much like emmys, looks haphazard and thrown together, and it works. I love the uncoated wainscoting ceilings and find myself staring up through the meal.

As far as the menu goes...so far everything I have tried, I have liked. The Grits with crab gets a 4 star with me and I really like the nightly vegan offering. The pate is to die for! Service has been ok and always friendly.

Being a neighborhood restaurant, there are quite a few characters that lurk. Sometimes they even stop by and try to sit with you. Depending on my mood it's either very charming or I feel like I'm about to stab someone with my fork. The later it gets the more unruly the local talent becomes as well as the whole room. Just add liquor and the front porch becomes more and more like a dysfunctional family gathering, crazy aunt included, attesting to the homey feel and charm. That is if you find aunt may charming.
author: sasha w.

description:
fantastic.  I'm from the south, and this stuff is for real.  At first, I rolled my eyes at yet another place selling the south, but that was premature.  I have loved everything that I have tasted with the exception of the mac and cheese.  Some folk love it, but it's too sweet for my buds.  

I love the atmosphere, love the chicken, love the okra.
author: Emliy H.

description:
Update: 2/5/07
It's very rare that my experience of  place can change from a 2 star review to a 5 star review..however, after having dinner at the FP last night, I had to do them justice:

I took my lovely friend Jen there to celebrate her b-day. We were told that it would be a 25-35 min wait for a table for two. NP..we thought..we headed to the bar for our wine-in-a-juice box. An hour later...we were still waiting..and were slightly irritated. The manager, Kevin, was sincerely apologetic and offered us a delicious app to hold us over (and his charming smile definitely helped, too) 
Finally. after waiting for an hour..we were finally seated...right next to the front door. It was a bit drafty..but we were so hungry we didn't care. 
The two of us shared the bistro salad, pork chop, and of course the fried chicken. The fried oyster in the bistro salad was delicious...I could have had 10 of them. We finished everything on our plates..and ordered the fried Plantains for dessert. 
Despite the long wait, my experience with the service was dramatically different from my first time there. I can tell that the entire staff is making an earnest effort to improve their service. Thanks to Kevin, the FP is now my favorite place! 
***************************************************************************Update: Went back there again yesterday 1/16/07 and my experience with the service was much better. (It was an early Tue night so the tables weren't filled). I also tried different things too. The bistro salad was delicious...love the fried oysters. The salmon ceviche had a lot of flavor. 
The picked veggies and egg was interesting...My favorite was the side of grits..can't wait to go back there again!
****************************************************************************
I was more than excited to try this place especially after Tanya Z. raved about it. Friday afternoon we decided to make a trek out there for dinner. I was salivating just looking at their online menu!
We arrived around 7pm, and was told the wait would be around 30 mins. Soon after we got our drinks and some bar nuts,  the gracious and cute host/manager seated us(after a less than 10 min wait). We were off to a great start! I liked the funky decor and even the luxurious panel ceiling that looked out of place at any front porch...I had visions of a 6-star yelp review.

After scanning the menu, the three of us decided on the bucket of fried chicken with two sides and I couldn't resist the crab porridge. (I also really wanted the pickled veggie and eggs but my dining partners promptly vetoed the request :-(

All was well even up until we got our corn bread..so why the three star review??  Shitty service. Working and being in the service/retail industry, I understand that it is not easy work...but there is no excuse for a complete lack of friendly service...seriousely...it's one thing that our waitress was a bit cold...we didn't care as long as we got our food and our drinks...We pretty much had to request everything and wait a hell of a long time...The ironic thing was that there were more than one server on staff and a number of bussers helping out. 
The food was pretty decent..I enjoyed the crab porridge..but thought the fried chicken was a bit on the salty side. All that aside, I was ready for dessert. By the time the waitress finally came by our table to ask us about our dessert choices..we had long lost our patience and interest. 
What a big disappointment.. I love the concept of the place, the decor, and the food...but our experience was tainted by just bad service.  I'd definitely go back again hoping that we were there on an off night.
author: Mimi T.

description:
The Front Porch recently re-opened after a revamp and change of chef. I thought the food was even better than before (and it was great then). 

We started with the oyster beignets and gumbo.  Now, I really don't like fried oysters but my partner does. Well, with this dish I'm a convert: the beignets were light and crispy and not soggy and greasy like some fried oysters I've had before. The bread pudding base was an interesting contrast. Gumbo is one of those things that always sounds good but rarely lives up to expectations, often being stodgy, gummy, or worse. The Porch's is superb! A great mix of flavors with just enough soup, chicken and sausage and spice to satisfy. Actually, it might satisfy a little too much for an appetizer.  

For main course we had the slow roasted pork, the court bouillon and the tostanes.  I only tasted the pork but it was moist and succulent and received rave reviews from my partner. I couldn't get enough of the court bouillon "liquor" in which bathed the baby veggies and tomatoes - a few less tomatoes and a few more veggies would have been good. The fish was perfectly cooked - moist yet flakey. The tostanes were crispy plantain fritters with pickled onions and avocado. I love pickled onions! This dish was another hit.

And apart from the food, what a cool, friendly place! I love the low lighting which might not be to everyone's taste. The porch itself is great for a drink and snack, weather permitting. You need to get there early to avoid the crowds.
author: Andy C.

description:
Wonderfully relaxed atmosphere even though the place was hopping...bartender friendly during short wait...ok beer list...$10 corkage fee.  

Near our table in the back it sort of felt like the props room from a community theater (e.g. old dial telephone on top of an equally-dated payphone telephones). 

Dinner started off with a complimentary unique cucumber/jalapeno/mango aperitif...definitely cleansed the palate...not everyone loved it, but I did...all the food was fresh and delicious ...cornbread strips were just like they make them in Georgia ...jerk chicken was spicy and tender...crab salad was generous with the crabmeat...     

For dessert some sort of funky ice cream thing was shared...we apparently broke an unspoken time limit and were rushed by our server (e.g. with multiple premature attempts to clear the dessert)... this may have gone unnoticed but for the fact that it was so out of sync with the spirit of a place like this.
author: Matthew L.

description: my sister lives in bernal heights and i tried out the food here on my last visit to san francisco.  the bucket of fried chicken was the bomb!!  next time i'm trying the dr pepper braised beef short ribs. i saw on Food Channel Chef Guy's visit and saw how that dish was made.  YUM!
author: Stella A.

description:
(I would have given this place 3.5 stars ... but have to round down in this case without that option)

Given that I live right down the street from this place and had gone way too long before actually eating here, I really WANTED to love this place and make it a new neighborhood favorite. However, after finally crossing it off my list of places I've been meaning to go, I have to say it was just OK in terms of food.

I tried several of the smaller plates on the menu, including the Oyster Beignets, BBQ Shrimp, Gumbo, the Mac n Cheese, and of course, the Fried Chicken. I understand from the waitress that the chef has recently switched, so perhaps that accounts for it not being as good as the hype ... but she also mentioned that the new chef was from New Orleans (where I spent a lot of time after the hurricanes and LOVED the food), so I was hopeful.

Gumbo: Reminded me more of red beans and rice (as the dominant ingredients), a bit too thick

Oyster Beignets: Interesting ... liked the bread pudding touch ... but ultimately not overly impressive

BBQ Shrimp: Much smaller shrimp than I'm used to getting in NOLA, though the sauce was good

Mac n Cheese: Actually enjoyed this one the best of the starters/sides - just the right amount of breadcrumbs in the mix for some texture

Fried Chicken: I have to say that I think I enjoyed the fried chicken from the previous chef better (I had it once in a takeout order)

One final disappointment was the bread pudding for dessert. I've walked by this restaurant about 400 times and have heard people rave about the bread pudding, so I was anxious to compare it to what I've had around the South in the past. Unfortunately, it fell flat. The yam ice cream from Mitchell's (across the street) was a nice touch, but it came in a small casserole bowl that was warm on the outside, but not all the way through. Plus, it came out so fast that it seemed like it was just sitting somewhere warming, ready to go.
