On a positive note, I'll say that I really dig the beers they have available at this place ... from some Abita (Louisiana) beers on draft, to tall cans of Tecate, to tall bottles of red stripe (a rarity), and even King Cobra malt liquor ;-)

Overall, the food was decent, but just not what I was hoping for. Still a very cool spot, and a cool place to hang on "the front porch" when warmer outside ... but I think next time I'll just be hanging at the bar with some beers and Mac n Cheese.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Ever since my beloved Powell's Place closed down, I've been on the search for a new soul food joint.  

The crab and grits were creamy, but not quite enough for a meal.  The chicken pieces were fried well and tasty, but they were on the small side.  Honey asked if I wanted the wing, to which I replied, that's not a wing, it's a breast!!  Nuff said, pieces were small.  The benefit of small pieces is that the white meat stays juicy inside.  Mac n cheese was good, but the portion side had me feenin for moh.

No reservations.  I called and she said there was no wait.  We arrived in 20 minutes and the wait jumped from none to 45 minutes on a Sat. night.

Haven't been back, but I'd get the bucket next time.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
The South and the Caribbean are separated only in theory. There are many reasons to lump them together gastronomically, especially when you own a restaurant and can do whatever the hell you want.

I first heard of Front Porch in a discussion of "fried chicken in the city." I was skeptical, as a native Texan, that anyone in San-Fran-Cis-Co could do fried chicken right, but this was right around the time that I began to loosen my standards of who-can-cook-what, and how.

Front Porch is right on so many levels, it's hard to describe. We ate there last night, my fourth time. I've had something different every time, and it's all been amazing. I've sampled dishes my friends ordered, and same thing. Therefore, I'm gonna go ahead and guess that the entire menu is amazing.

The place is very intimate, in a hard-scrabble, Emmy's Spaghetti Shack way. It looks like a house with walls knocked out, which it very well may be. But, like Emmy's, it's tiny. So either arrive early, get a large group and make a reservation, or get ready to wait. If there are openings and it's not too cold, get a drink and sit (you guessed it) on the front porch in a rocking chair. If it's too crowded and the wait is long enough, head down to Mission to the 3300 Club.

Last night, I had a ros bubbly paired with fried chicken. Wow. Great pairing, and wow. Their chicken has a homemade-plus-awesome taste. And of course, it's so much more than "homemade," cuz if you made this at home, you'd have the mess to clean up too.

Tara R. suggested the place is romantic, and after some thought, I have to agree (see Emmy's comment, above). But it's been good for our dates as well as my birthday last year with a group of eight. I love dynamism in a restaurant.
author: Jeff H.

description: Love to go here for the food, the peeps and the food! Don't go here for your veggie only plate! That's stupid this is good ole Americana food, southern fried, grease in the eyes, eat your meat ass off grub! Oh yeah and you gone pay! But its good, good, goody!
author: Miguelito C.

description: Since I just dissed Farmerbrown's chicken I thought I would give props to the best fried chicken I have ever had. Incredible! Also, the staff is super friendly. My one complaint is that the place is too dark.
author: M K.

description:
Saturday night.  The place is crazy full, hopping with life, with this southern-esque casual, hip vibe I haven't felt since Austin, Tx.  

I met some friends there, sitting at the bar, and despite my chest cold the cute and vivacious bartender convinced me to sample the mulled wine.  This mulled wine was magic and perfect for how I was feeling.  Warm in the hand and warm in the chest, and the perfectly balanced spicing was positively therapeutic.  It's easy to screw up with the clove (I've done it lots), but I was in love with it.

It took us a while to get seated (more on that later), but once we did, we just poured over the menu.  Lots of choices--from the light to the hearty.  Ceviche-salmon that night,  to fried chicken, available in a bucket if you plan on sharing.  I ordered the special--pork rubbed with savory, spicy seasoning, with cubed grilled sweet potatoes. My friends ordered chicken livers (!) and brussel sprouts, and the vegan special with an order of the salmon ceviche to start.  

All of the food was fabulous!  The cornbread and sweet-butter while we waited for our order was fabulous on their own and inspired me to make cornbread (not as good as theirs) the next day. The ceviche was light and flavorful.   While I'm not a fan of livers or of brussel sprouts, I'd order both myself on another visit; they were flavorful, but not overpowering as these can sometimes be. The serving of pork was healthy, moist, and seasoned to accentuate the taste of the meat. The vegan special was hearty, well-balanced, and tasty. 

Overall, the food at The Front Porch lived up to its buzz.  The service however was a little subpar. My friends were on the list for a seat at 6:30, were told that the wait would be a long while.  So they stepped out for a bit, returned to the bar and waited for their names to be called.  Finally we grabbed the host to see what was up and he acted surprised that we were still there--claiming he had called our name at 7:30, which was a bold lie, since we were sitting at the bar near the door finishing our first round of drinks at that time.  And our waitress was capable, but a drone.  Man, she was positively robotic.  So, I suppose she was okay, but not very attentive, and certainly at odds with the cozy, homey vibe of the rest of the place.  But the bartender--she get's thumbs up!  I'm glad she talked me into the mulled wine.

I'll definitely go again, but plan to wait to be seated.  And really, the most important element-the food is THE reason to go.
author: Padawan T.

description:
Update, 10/2007: Wish I could knock my rating down by half a star for the terrible service my friends and I experienced during our latest visit.

Our waiter, a Latino guy with a faux-hawk of sorts, was bad. He had trouble explaining the menu, didn't refill our water, and waited way too long to get back to us at the end of the meal -- another person on staff ended up handling our check for us. The waiter's worst mistakes, though, occurred when I sent back some undercooked fish. He took it back to the kitchen but didn't know what would happen next -- would I get a replacement, and if so, when? When he finally returned, he said the kitchen was preparing a new serving for me, for which they were "overcooking" the fish, implying that my judgment about its preparation were incorrect. (I made sure to tell him at the end of the meal that the replacement fish had been cooked properly and correctly.) No comp, which might have been appropriate, given that the new fish came out at the same time as my companions were ready to order dessert.

Despite this bad service, I'll probably go back, as I still like the food. Okay, the correctly cooked fish wasn't phenomenal, but it was good enough, and I liked the pickled vegetables that came with it. Still liked the grits with crab, and the house salad with pineapple dressing is a good deal.

Update, 3/2007: Went here for the second time last night and again had a great time. We waited at the bar, where the friendly bartender served us beer and wine. Our table for two was ready sooner than we thought it would be, and we were served by a nice man named Alejandro. Great people watching, mellow and funky atmosphere, low-key despite the crowds.

The fried okra was awesome. Really. Not too greasy, tasty cornmeal batter, yummy bits of okra. We had the fried chicken, grits, and Brussels sprouts again because we'd enjoyed them so much the first time around, and the choices were again right on. Well, the sprouts were a bit too sweet/overly treated with molasses. No room for dessert, alas.

Original review: Went here last night with J., P., and R., and very much enjoyed the experience. The vibe was mellow and comfy, but it was only because we arrived before opening that we were able to get in without a wait. That's the secret.

Good food! I enjoyed the salmon ceviche, which was not particularly Southern but was particularly tasty. J. and R. has nice-looking mixed greens, and P. enjoyed soup. For the main course, J. and I shared a fried chicken plate and a crab grits porridge. Yum! The chicken was moist and tasty. I'm not so into black-eyed peas, but they were good for what they were. The crab was tastylicious. We ordered Brussels sprouts on the side, and they seem to have been sweetened with molasses, in a good way. Underwhelmed by the trio of fries -- I just wanted the regular potato kind.

Service was friendly and mostly timely, although we had to wait for our check. We'll be back.
author: Tara M.

description:
I so wanted to love this place.  It was adorable.  Filled with all kinds of garage sale gems, I sat down on one of those car seat benches instead of a booth for chrissake.  Super friendly host and server.  I literally said when I sat down "oh my gd, are we on our way to a five?"

Then, the food came.  And, everything has something that wasn't quite right.  Salad was overdressed.  Fries three ways were great.  The mac and cheese was amazing with it's bacon and breadcrumb toppings, except where was the cheese?  The crab and grits was.... interesting.  Strange, too much pepper, this sounds so terrible but it was sorta like high class prison food.  My Caribbean bbq was nice but the actual slab of beef was chewy and not very tasteful.

So sadly, it wasn't a five at all, it's a three.  Which is to say, I'll go there if someone else really wants to, but I'd rather be trying someplace new.  Bummer.
author: Jenny S.

description: Corn bread was amazing (though portion was small). Had the fried chicken and really enjoyed it. Love that they have such a wide selection of Abita (Louisiana) beers, including turbo dog on tap!!!
author: Topher G.

description:
I'd probably not go back unless someone else was footing the bill - for one entree, one app and two beers - $50! before tax n tip?!!? I'D RATHER GO TO BERETTA, GARCON OR ABSINTHE FOR THAT PRICE. 
Took at date - she was the only thing that made the experience memorable... in a good way. 
I was super pumped about this place and I ended up feeling pretty disappointed. 
Whole lotta fried, over-priced, loud, crowded, poor layout. I'm from the south and I feel like the food was good... hence 2 stars.... it wasn't great -  They WAY over cooked the cajun fish and the service was SUPER slow. 
For a Sunday evening with a reservation, it took us 10 minutes to simply get seated (our table was wide open and setup from the moment we walked in... just understaffed on hosts I guess). Then it was like the server just kept disappearing for extended periods of time when we wanted to order.
The company was great - the extraordinarily drunk group next to us at 7pm on a Sunday was pretty entertaining... and deafening. 
Concept it cool, I'll give them that much - but I wasn't impressed, maybe on a nice day outside on the sidewalk would be a better setup.
author: Jordan S.

description:
Hank Williams on the juke box. Abita on tap. Pressed tin ceilings with eclectic art. Fried fried fried menu items. And I'm not in New Orleans? Hot damn! 

Went with my mom and stepdad on our once a month "must try someplace new" adventure. And so glad we picked here!

Got there at 6, a little afraid it would be packed on a sunny afternoon. Perfect timing as we get to hit happy hour and linger before it gets packed. Started with the steak fries and aioli. Loved them. Shared the iceberg salad with my mom and that was so cool and refreshing, vinaigrette/creamy dressing combos make me happy. And bacon. How can one go wrong with bacon on a salad? 

For our mains, my mom had the poboy of the day which was crab cake, I had the fried chicken and my stepdad had the black cod perloo. Yum all around! I was supposed to share with my mom, and did but ate her half of the poboy for lunch today as I was stuffed from that amazing chicken and those sinful mashed potatoes. Poboy was STILL delightful the next day. I don't know if there is anything I can say about the fried chicken that hasn't been said before. Other than, how do they get it so damn hot? It was like an inferno when you opened it. And so delightfully crispy without being greasy. The Chron totally missed this place on its places to get great Southern food in SF they printed the other day. 

I will be going here anytime I need an Abita and fried food fix.
author: Lisa M.

description:
1 hour+ wait on a Saturday. What else is new, San Francisco? Quality makes ya wait.

The host on Saturday is a total dude. He's the perfect entry into your experience. Slackerish Polo shirt, happy guy. He kindly sat us ahead of promised time at the bar.

My favorite thing about this place is the fact that it's not in the usual kind of residential building that houses a restaurant. It seriously looks more like the Front Porch was once the garage in this place. I like the atmosphere that creates.

I got the veggie special, which came highly recommended. My compatriot got the crab dish which I vastly preferred. I'm a major brussel sprouts fiend, and theirs were good but not quite perfect -- slightly sweet, we agreed.

And like Nish, we didn't get all our dishes. Calamari just never arrived -- until it arrived on our bill. They kindly took it off when we asked.

The menus are printed with whimsical, Courier-like type that is often off-kilter and blotchy. Nice. But the restaurant's logo betrays this ironic style and looks a bit too polished.
author: Blake E.

description:
Is it bad if I have a crush on Kevin? He's so welcoming every time we come in, it's like Cheers. I'm reluctant to give 5 stars because I don't want to see any more hipsters in there, I already see waaay too many. But I happen to love The Front Porch, and not just for Kevin. 

To be honest, the food can be hit or miss. I have had dishes that lacked sparkle. Still, there is something about the atmosphere (dark, eclectic, rockin') that kind of makes me not care about that. They have a nice little menu that usually has something new to try, along with some more permanent items that are definitely worth revisiting. The pickled veggies are a good pre-starter. Watch out though, sometimes they are super-vinegarized, you might pickle your face-hole. The grits are so creamy and comforting, the burger is tasty, as are the brussels sprouts and  the bistro salad. Vegan entrees can be delicious, but they can also seem like someone cleaned out the veggie bin in the fridge. Mostly, though, find an excuse to use the house-made ketchup and hot sauce. The boy says he would eat through a mountain of babies just to get his share of those tasty condiments. 

My only real beef with TFP is that I have had some BAD service there. If you are a person who gets really bunched up about your table service, maybe go somewhere else. There is one girl in particular who just should not be waiting tables, and it seems like she is always there.

Overall, the food is good, the prices are excellent, and the atmosphere is exactly what I look for in a neighborhood joint. And the little peccadilloes are kind of irrelevant in the end because i always leave with the warm fuzzies.
author: pizzazz g.

description:
The brussel sprouts were tasty.

I had a very tasty dungeness crab on grits-- an odd combination one would think, but the grits were amazing.  Delicate and light, they didn't overpower the crab at all.

The decor here is neat; metal patterned roof and booth seats that look like they came from a very large American car from the 1950s.  We observed a pay phone sitting in the back; pay phones are such a rarity these days that we couldn't quite figure out whether it was actually there so people can use it, or as part of the decor.  Until I start carrying quarters, I guess the world will never know!
author: Fen Z.

description:
I love this place: the funky and fun ambience that feels a little bit "new orleans" - especially with the tin ceiling.. the fun waitstaff,  the smart wine and beer list, and food with pizazz and fingerspitzengefuhl. 

Yum points for the organic fried chicken, spicy crab and grits, and the usual creative specials. For appetizer  I like the jalapeno corn bread and the calamari with egg and vinegary sauce even if its a bit strong. I always make sure to throw in a side dish or two - I like the black eyed peas with pork stomach (a delicacy thats better than bacon). You really get what you pay for here too. 

This place makes a fun night out for any kind of occasion.
author: David S.

description:
I have many sins and one of them is fried chicken...  The chickening was juicy / crispy and I had no shame and used my fingers by the way... 

 So you know the tell when a restaurants is about to close for vacation or holiday- you know how they say its not a good idea to go on the last day before they go away. They say the food and service wont be good  nothing will be fresh and the staff's head is already out the door passport in hand. Well folks last Monday-night Kevin in his crew at T.F.P. delivered service and the food was spot on. I will be back next week to check out the tans...
author: swys -.

description: We live down the block and the Front Porch is a regular favorite. Grab a drink at the Rock Bar across the street while you wait. The specials are seasonal, sides are delicious (get a couple for the table), and vibe is chill.
author: Saket V.

description:
Let me just start by saying that if I could award half stars, I would be giving The Front Porch 3 1/2.  Yelp and Netflix really need to change that.

Good things:
FANTASTIC service (Brian!  Holla!)
Fun menu
Darling atmosphere
Great brussel sprout side dish
Inventive cocktail menu

Bad things:
My halibut special was WAY over-salted
The cornbread was not good or fresh and neither was the paprika butter it came with
The fried okra was eh.  Came with a jalapeno-lime dipping sauce (sounds delish, right?) that was totally boring/bland

Had my dish not been over-salted, I would have raved about it.  It was a nice piece of fish, served over a chive crepe that was filled with roasted root vegetables and sweet potatoes.  There was also a good sauce involved and some crab meat.  
My friends had the shrimp and grits and the porkchop and liked them both.  For dessert, they had the beignets with the rosemary honey and the bread pudding with the yam ice cream.  They liked them both, but weren't raving with OMGs like they usually are when something is awesome.
I had a root beer float, which was good.

I would recommend The Front Porch for people that are going to be in that part of town and are looking for a cool spot, but I'm not sure I would otherwise.
author: Jacquie M.

description:
Ditto on everyone's review of the fried chicken.  Very unique, deep fried lighter-style coating with super moist interior.  This is the best fried chicken I've tried yet.  Cute that it also comes in a bucket.  I would go back just to have this fried chicken.  

Noise however is way too loud.  I was there on a Friday but all we could hear was cackling of a blond 2 stalls down from us.  

Great local, divy, hipstery atmosphere.  I felt like I was in New Orleans or something...
author: Tom K.

description:
Decided this was a good place to try out with our friend, Andy, while he visited from L.A. 

Well, as the name goes, it is literally walking in from someones front porch. 

Overall, the staff was extremely friendly and helpful with the menu items. They even were well-versed in wine. 

Fried Chicken, Spicey Crab and Grits, and Burger and Fries. The food was good, however, Gary did get an upset stomach afterwards. I had one later in the evening. Not sure if these were related, but ya know... 

However, we did enjoy the ambiance, and it is loud and crowded on the inside, but was a good place to bring Andy to dine before hanging out during the rest of the evening. He enjoyed it very much and would like to go again when he is up in S.F.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
The space is cool, funky and eclectic, but feels homey and comfortable. Sadly the noise level is a bit much if you are sitting in the front room, we had trouble hearing eachother across the table. The food was just so so, we had the fried chicken, and what this city needs is a place with good fried chicken. It was ok, atleast it wasn't dry but we ordered a bucket to share with 4 people and there were like 6 pieces, 4 of which were something that resembled breasts, how do you get 4 breasts and no dark meat? 

When it comes down it to, it just seemed like there wasn't anyone in the kitchen who was paying attention. And our waiter was so frazzled he couldn't even keep an eye out on things that he had recommended. Nothing stood out as spectacular and the atmosphere didn't make up for the subpar food.
author: Kai H.

description:
It is a happy person who gets to live within two stumbling blocks of both Front Porch and Blue Plate. That person would be me. 

I would like to begin by doing a bit of fellow-Yelper smearing. I do not understand why there are so many reviews on here bemoaning the fact that you can not bring an enormous group of people into a small, quaint resteraunt on a weekend and feel not feel a bit squeezed. This is San Francisco people. Almost all of the good restraunts are small and not good for groups over 5, and have lines out the door on Fridays and Saturdays. Get over it, or do not frequent these places with your larger-assed friends. Also interesting is the constant bitching by Yelpers of the sides and appetizers being small. They are well within the average size of a non-entree item. Again, bring your overeating friends to the lone KFC in San Fran if they would like their fried chicken to come with a bucket of slaw and mashed potatoes. 

If, however, you and your friends would enjoy a flavorful yet crispy fried chicken, great grits, crab, and a host of other comfort food options at a reasonable price (for reasonably good food in a great setting in San Francisco), please do try Front Porch. On all of my visits the staff have been prompt and friendly.  I make a point to only go on weekdays to avoid the crowds and noise, although this is my rule for all dining in SF unless the place serves late.  The Blue Plate close by does have better food, but it is also ten to fifteen dollars more per entree, and a different culinary style.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
One of my favorite regular meals was with the sous chef at my old restaurant in Ann Arbor on Sunday evenings.  We would eat what we liked to call "fat with a side of fat" involving some combination of duck confit and/or fois gras AND/or imported Italian cheese.  It was heavenly.

It's been a while since I ate at The Front Porch - last fall in fact.  The only thing I remember was a meat appetizer with all sorts of yummy aged meat which were tender and flavorful.  I do remember an interesting wine list and friendly waiter but also can't remember my entree or much else.

Clearly not great enough to have rushed back in the past year.  I probably will be back; now that I am reminiscing about that meat plate it's sounding better and better....

to be continued...
author: laura g.

description:
I went here last night, and damn!, was it tasty!! We walked in and were able to get a seat at the bar right away...not bad for a Friday night. (The wait for a table was about 45 min though.) Our bartender/server was super friendly, and gave me 2 generous "tastes" of wine before pouring me my preference. 

We started out with the Bajan Waldorf Salad - heirloom apples, celery heart, bajan rum soaked raisins, caramelized walnuts, dressed in light creole mayo. It was a tad bit heavy on the mayo for my taste, but what do I expect? It is a waldorf salad, after all, and was probably still considered "light" by most people's standards. Otherwise, the salad was very pleasant...the rum soaked raisins were nice and plump, and the caramelized walnuts were surprisingly crunchy!

For the mains, we ordered the Crab and Grits and the Half Jerk Chicken (from the specials menu). The spicy dungeness crab and sweet corn grit porridge was absolutely divine! I admit that I did expect to see more crab on my plate when it came out, but that thought immediately dissipated from my mind once that first smooth and savory bite entered my mouth.

I hardly ever order chicken at restaurants, but just couldn't resist the sound of the jerk chicken, and I had absolutely no regrets ordering it. It was seasoned just right, with the right amount of kick, and the meat was incredibly tender and juicy. It was served with brussels sprouts, and another veggie which slips my mind at the moment.    

I admit I wasn't exactly sober for this dining experience, so I can't honestly say that all 5 of these stars are solely due to the food...but with the combination of the food, service, ambiance, my glass of wine, the pre-dinner drinks, and the company of a good friend, I couldn't have been happier. :)
author: Kristen C.

description:
Ok.  First ... I like this place in general.   Excellent food.  The pork chop and beans is just flat luscious.   Do not miss the corn pudding dessert either.  Yummy.

Now let's talk about the service.  I've never had any issue with the wait staff, however the hostess leaves much to be desired.   On a recent visit we arrived early (6pm) to get a seat in this always busy place.  Upon our arrival there were two (count them ... only two) occupied tables in the restaurant.  The hostess (and I use the term loosely) informed us we would have to wait 10-15 mins for a table and abruptly walked off.  Upon her return some five minutes later, I inquired as to why in an empty restaurant customers were made to wait.  Her response was that the kitchen required "pacing" and guests simply could not be seated in mass.   I aksed why we couldn't just be seated sip some wine and peruse the menu.  She responded we could in a "few minutes".   

Were the food here not so spectacular we would have turned heel and left.  ANY restaurant that has a ktichen that can't handle more than a couple tables at a whack as a HUGE problem.  I've never heard a more absurd excuse in my life!!

Further ... they are foolish for waisting their opprotunity to sell extra beverages (the high profit item btw) because of this stupid policy.  I'm not sure we'll be back.  We like the food, but no place is worth putting up with inane and borderline rude treatment.
author: Russell D.

description:
We came recently with a group of friends. And we ordered everything on the main course menu (except the vegan plate). 
I am more the healthy type but there were enough options on the menu. The daily fish special was amazing! And the burger was phenomenal. And the steak...mmmh.
Ok, and now to the fried chicken: I could not resist. It was marvelous. I try not to have too many fried items but this was made to perfection. 
The lighting is a little dark but that makes it even more cosy.
author: Alexandra D.

description: Had a great time here for brunch! We got there relatively early (at least for a Saturday), around 10. We were the first ones there so we had our choice of tables and the wait staff was very friendly. We all got chicken and waffles and we all loved them! It's not a dish that I normally would get but it was very good here. Spicy, salty, and sweet all at the same time. The coffee was good too, as soon as I took a sip the waiter came over to give me a refill haha
author: Andrea P.

description: This place has a laid back feel which I like, but the food was just ok. Nothing really stood out, except that the fried chicken was a bit soggier than it should have been. The brunch menu looked pretty good so I'm coming back for that.
author: Evan K.

description:
yum! love the front porch. 

tried the gumbo, shrimp grits, deviled crab, and a bucket of fried chicken! man i love fried chicken! I'd stick with the small plates with a cold brewsky. great with large groups so you can have a taste of everything.
author: Jane C.

description: The food was pretty good.  The best Mac n cheese ever!!!  The chicken batter on the fried chicken was a little too salty for my taste.  It was worth the $$
author: diana n.

description:
Didn't expect to like it. But I did.

We had a party of 6. We ordered family style. The appetizers (Ceviche, Tuna Tartar, and Cucumber/Watermelon Raddish salad) were really tasty. Then we had a jug of wine, a bucket of fried chicken, and the down-home sides to go with. Plus some fish & chips on the side just for good measure.

The quality of the food was all great. Sashimi-grade tuna in the tuna tartar, organic chicken in the bucket of fried chicken, really fresh fish for the fish & chips.  And the seasonings were just right on everything. 

Some of the portions were too small (an order of corn is half an ear? And that's one of the options with a full bucket of chicken?). But the chicken was fairly generous, and we actually didn't finish it.

The wait staff was friendly, the atmosphere warm, fun, ecclectic in that perfect San Francisco way, without the attitude that can sometimes be the downside of the perfect SF mix. I do think the server should have warned us about the small portions, given that we had 6 people & were ordering for the table. The jug of wine is a fun idea, but the wine itself was not so great. 

And for the full experience, I have to include these random parts of the evening: while waiting for a table we had drinks at the dive bar on the corner, where the blue-collar guys knocking back stiff drinks gave a thumbs up review of the front porch. One fellow told me "the chicken good; succulent & lightly battered, not too heavy". And it was true. I love that in SF you can get good food reviews from the truck-driver barfly.

Then, at the end of the night, while taking advantage of the all-night bart service (due to the bay bridge closure), we were critiquing the restaurant.  After going on a bit we discovered that the executive chef was standing right next to us. She was very gracious, asked for feedback, we gave some, she told us they're scrambling a bit 'cuz they didn't expect so much attention right away, and she invited us back for another bucket of chicken, on her. I love it. I will be going back, in a month or so, and see what they come up with to refine the concept further.
author: Jo R.

description:
This is my new favorite restaurant!!!  As a southerner and comfort food addict, I just can't get enough of this place.  

I shied away for awhile thinking sure it'll be good, standard overpriced food in the Mission.  Comfort food is comfort food. Right?  Not here. Every little detail was exceptional.   They took so many of my home cookin favorites and gave the ole california cuisine spin without compromising the flavors you crave in southern food.

From the red-eye (beer and bloody mary together at last!) to the obligatory fried chicken with coconut greens to the pork and beans (a molasses brined pork chop) with BBQ beans and slaw.  

Our server was stressed out and forgot to place our appetizer order otherwise I'm sure I'd be raving about those too.  

I know I'm just another voice blabbering on about how good this place is, but it was too good NOT to review.  That says something.
author: Krista G.

description:
Folks who say this place is southern cooking haven't been to the south. The corn bread was dry though cleverly shaped like a corn cob. The fried chicken was coated with corn meal instead of a proper batter and was flavorless and dry. The best part about good fried chicken is the crispy skin and a salty/spicy batter which this joint chooses to bypass. 

The burger was good though but for the money, it wasn't anything special. I would've rather gone to big mouth burger and save a little money or drink another beer.

However, I thought the service and presentation were good.
author: Andy L.

description:
The Mission is full of gems. Unfortunately, I am not a miner out there looking for those gems, in fact I am a big slacker when it comes to heading out to the Mission. Thankfully, a friend decided to celebrate his birthday in a gem of a restaurant in the Mission called Front Porch. 

Ambiance (4): As you walk in you are greeted by rocking chairs which reminded me of Cracker Barrel (a Southeast roadside eatery institution), except these are worn and not for sale. The inside is divey but not dirty and there is kitschy stuff on the wall. It's a tiny place but I liked it and it fit the comfort food they serve perfectly.  

Food (4): The food was great. I really wanted to give it a 5 but was not as happy with the fried chicken as I wanted to be. We had collard greens and mashed potatoes (deep South what? greens outshined the potatoes...shocking!), fried goodness: oysters, onion rings, shrimp, mushrooms, pickles (everything was juicy and the oysters...bursting with goodness, see if you can just get a basket of those bad boys by themselves), mac and cheese (all that cheese must be sinful, if they had dropped some truffle oil on that I would have eloped with it), beans and rice (really good and underappreciated), fried catfish and hush puppies (not greasy, just right), sweet potato fries (a bit too skinny or overfried), strawberry shortcake with a candle (candle was waxy but that dessert was spot on, and I am not a dessert guy and by no means a fruit guy) and finally fried chicken.  

I think a conversation about Front Porch must gravitate around fried chicken. When a restaurant serves fried chicken, they have to bring their A game. And of course if it's on the menu, diners should check it out, especially when they lure you in with someone's special/secret recipe; Momma's, Bob's, Aunt X, etc. Front Porch's chicken is served in a bucket of popcorn...why I dunno, but it was certainly not good popcorn I can tell you that. One thought I had is that it keeps the chicken from sitting in its own grease, which then makes it a novel idea, just don't eat the popcorn. The chicken is extremely juicy...even the white meat. In fact, everything they fried was pretty juicy so have at those fried items on the menu. The bucket comes with a mix of white and dark meat and unfortunately I was sitting next to a dark meat lover, so I was relegated to one chicken wing and a whole lot of half breast pieces. Despite the chicken between juicy, I was disappointed with the breading. Years of thick coated, fast food restaurant chicken trained me to prefer a substantial tasty coating or a crunchy exterior (I know it's unhealthy). Even though it had a tasty coating, it was very thin and this can be disappointing especially when dealing with the chunky breast pieces. Don't get me wrong, it's good chicken, I just have different preferences.

Oh and Front Porch bottles their own hot sauce (or get sauces with their labels on it). They have hot one and a hotter one. Amateurs need not apply to the hotter one.

Service (4): Everpresent smile, attentive with the jugs and 40s of water (you read that right), overall great service. The servers seem to fit right in and I have no complaints. Usually Service gets a 3 for standard good service, but the fact they kept those jugs of water coming is something that unfortunately you don't see at most restaurants. 

Value (5): Everything is well priced and if you go the route of family style, it's a great bargain. Just don't overorder like we did. I know the basket of fried goods is tempting but don't order 5. Corkage fee of $10 is unheard of, but so is having fine wine with Southern comfort food, so it's a perfect price point.

Overall: I loved this place. The food was right on and the service was great. I would definitely go back and you should too. To be honest my only deterrent is the deep South Mission location. Driving all the way down there and parking is a drag for me. Don't let that deter you though, you need to check out this place to get your vitamin F(ried).
author: Alvaro H.

description: Love the atmosphere and the food was fantastic. I could eat the fried okra all day, and the vegan chili was perfect. Tasty cocktails and friendly service too.
author: Tamara M.

description:
We went there last night expecting some serious sticks to your gut comfort food. The menu sounded fantastic. 
We got there and the hostess told us it would take about 30 minutes and directed us to the 3300 club down the street. I guess they have something worked out where the restaurant patrons will go the club and the hostess will call the bartender and let him know your table is ready. Really symbiotic relationship. 
Well we did just that except we were never called. After an hour of waiting we went back and the hostess had apparently mistaken another couple for us. Minus 1-star. But then she offered us free mold wine which was delicious - okay you get the star back. 

The restaurant is cozy and smell amazing. Very clean and comfortable. Really chill mood. Dim lights and a little jazz. 

Why 3-stars? I don't consider this a bad  rating. I think it means adequate but nothing fantastic. 

We had the cajun shrimp on a bed of grits. Tasted great but for $11 we only got 3 shrimp and the grits were more liquid than grits. You can go to Little Skillet and get a ton of grits with butter, andouille sausage and cheddar for $5 and it's amazing. 
The fried okra was okay. nothing really spectacular. 
He had the chicken fried steak which was very good, clean but it lacked imagination. 
The fried chicken was fried. But it lacked flavor. I was expecting something spicier and richer. The chicken itself was moist but it really left something to be desired. 

Overall, we enjoyed the atmosphere but the food lacked the creativity we were hoping for. And while the prices aren't outrageous, we expected more from them than we got.
author: Liliana A.

description: Nice ambiance and staff. But high prices for the neighborhood, a very gross mac & cheese and a skunked PBR. Too many other place to eat to go back here.
author: Kate L.

description:
Holy grits-tastic yummy deliciousness!

Hooray grits!
Hooray fried chicken!
Hooray out of this world homemade hot sauce and ketchup!

Hooray!
author: Harrison M.

description:
I am still a fan! We came back in a group of 4 the other day and had a dizzying array of choices. Our table was packed to the max. Our appetites were raving but just not enough table space. Of cos we had to havea  bucket of fried chicken and that is still sooo blardy awesome tasty. Wooweeee...the juice of the chicken drips out as you uncover the crispy skin. Absolutely loved the spicy shrimp with grits. it was sooo tasty. I think I prefer this to the crab with grits cos the shrimp is much sweeter. The flanksteak was done really well too and it was tender and yummy with all their sides. My friend was pleased with his burger. We were in love with the sides - fried okra, the maduros, and brussel sprouts...mmmmm....

It is really comfort food at its best. Be sure to make a reservation!
author: Topazskye L.

description:
Still a fan, but the chef and menu have changed. Sadly, none of my favorites are on the menu anymore, and my last trip did not create any new favorites. 
Still, great service and ambiance, great drinks and pretty good food. If they brought back the ribs, I'd be happy.  
I give it four stars because I imagine that's what it would get if I was eating there for the first time now. In reality, it feels more like 3 compared to what it was before.....
author: Jasmin S.

description:
Two vegetarians go to a southern restaurant and order:
- hush puppies (yes!)
- fried okra (hell yes!)
- mac n cheese (ooh yeah always)
- beans and rice (meh)
- brussel sprouts in molasses (erm... alright)
- biscuits (i like anything i can put honey on, but i like my biscuits softer  and more cuddly)
There were two other sides we could have ordered: sweet and regular potato fries and collard greens. Well the collards had bacon, and I don't know to what extent they could have been picked out. Anyways, you can hook it up here if you don't eat meat. I didn't specify vegan on the beans and rice so there was some ham chopped up on it. We took it home for the dog and she was PUMPED.
It is not okra season, but the okra was the best thing I ate. Maybe it is better frozen for the purpose of deep frying. The breading was the stuff. Makes me imagine how great the chicken would be.
Mac n cheese was missing the step of putting in the oven, I think. Totally fine. Creamy. They make their own hot sauce and this was a good opportunity to use it.
The hush puppies were fab. I don't really understand what a hush puppy is and I don't need to. 
No room for dessert whatsoever. Took leftovers of three of these dishes home. I wanted beignets or peach cobbler but I'll have to save space for that next time.
author: Mei G.

description: Returned after several years between first coming here, having had a really fun time there right after they opened, and looking to spend more time at spots in my neighborhood. I have to say "Meh" really summed it up for me. At $21 the flounder is the second most expensive entree, but feels pretty "home style" in a way I could recreate camping, pretty underwhelming. The jambalaya, described elaborately as "blue crab and tasso ham" sounds great! Tasted nothing special, under seasoned and had the consistency of bad risotto. Pretty dark, so I'm not sure if there was crab at all, I certainly didn't taste it. There sure was plenty of it though! The fish was a basic pan fried affair, and needed something (even a lemon wedge would have helped.) The "special" sangria was really diluted, and had more fruit rinds and pulp than actual fruit (this is the height of summer!) Service was fine, but everyone had the air they were closing soon (I think we were there with still an hour to go before they do), paying more attention to their tumblers of wine at the bar than the fact I need another knife please! I hate to review someplace so poorly, but I think they earned it this time. I'd go back, but strictly to share some fried chicken.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
thoughts from my front porch experience -- i came here on a tuesday night around 8 pm and it was packed, which i wasn't expecting. we had to wait at the bar for a table to open up (15 minutes or so). i liked the vibe in here, and a lot of the food looked delicious. i ordered a couple of sides (shoulda tried the blackened catfish!), which were honestly not that great. not bad, just not GREAT. of course, they were fairly boring as far as sides go: beans+rice and collard greens. still, i was hoping for a bit more flavor. i also tried the fried okra appetizer, which was alright. i'm not a huge okra fan, so i was biased. 

i think i need to give this place another go and try an entree this time! nice vibe, very dim lighting, and a good mix of people are all pluses, though.
author: Elle B.

description:
*Tear*

I came her for Spicy Crab and Grits (yes, it's a proper noun in my vocabulary) only to find out they have a new chef.  The food was good - nothing amazing though.

We had:
-asparagus app (best part of the meal)
-rabbit cutlets with spaetzle and peas (?? it was very German and a little bland.  The rabbit could have been pork)
-Fried chicken (good, not as good as it was before though) with garlic mashers (yum) and collard greens (too tough)
-The cornbread was good if a little too chewy

Service was great though, as usual.

I'm so sad.  This has put a damper on my week.  Fortunately, the last chef is opening a place in Oakland.  I may have to travel a little farther to get my fix, but at least my Crab and Grits will still be around.
author: Alyssa W.

description: Been here twice. First time, we had a party of 5 and the hostess said it would be a 1.5 hour wait but by then they will be closed. Could had just said that they couldn't fit us in that night. We tried a year later for one of my gf's bdays. This time we had a party of 7. We were seated  promptly and each ordered a rose sangria (super sweet and more juice-like than wine-like). We ordered two buckets of chicken which was good (tender, juicy, and not too salty kinda like Church's Chicken but way more expensive). I don't usually eat the skin of fried chicken but my friends were taking them off my plate so they have to had been pretty good. I know one thing tho; it was greasy! The mac and cheese was very good (one word: cheesy). I can't remember what else re ordered but I am guessing it wasn't too memorable anyways. Overall, I prefer Church's Chicken.
author: Christina Z.

description: I've only had the fried chicken here -- we like it so much that we get it everytime. we live in the neighborhood and get the bucket to go - it makes for a great family meal with leftovers. I highly recommend it! I hear they also deliver.
author: Laura K.

description: Very tasty!!! I came here with my wife for a light bite, but WOW!!! Everything we ordered were generous and bursting with flavor!!!  Can not wait to come back!!!
author: robert C.

description:
Ate here tonight with my tragically hip younger brother.

His first response was, "Are we on a date?" 

Cute. Really.

Classy place with great ambiance.

They gave us fried okra with molasses as a courtesy. (We didn't order it!) Sooo good.

I ordered the fried chicken, which was yelped pretty highly, and I received four(!) pieces of chicken!

Friendly service and good draft selection. I like this place alot! 

However...


I've been pretty generous with five-star ratings, but this place is not one of them. For one, it's cramped, not good for large groups.

But yeah, my bro ordered the seafood bowl which was a wee bit overpriced ($23! Yeah...)

That, and we came close to closing and our service was a bit slow. When they finally came around, the (cute) waitresses were really friendly.

And it's close to Mitchell's!!! They didn't close til 11 tonight, so we ate dessert there after.

But all in all, I love this restaurant and I'll be a regular. And when they really wow me, they'll get the final star.
author: Alexander D.

description:
I absolutely love everything about this place.  The interior.  The awesome wait-staff. The BEST fried chicken I think I've had - definitely the best of 2010 and definitely the best in SF.  This place would get 5 stars plus if there was a full bar. This place needs a full bar.  Note to FP: I know it is pretty much impossible to get a new liquor license in SF, but wow what an impact that could make!!!!
I can't take anything away stars-wise from what there IS.  But, because when you are there, everything about the food, decor, etc screams old-world SF, your mind can't help to go how great a spicy bloody mary (not the soju stuff) would go with the meal.  It's like, it would be the quintuple crown of an SF dining experience.  As in perfect food, drink, decor, service, ease of access/parking.  All dreams would be fulfilled.
Ok, back to the food.  Everything is out of control delicious.  The biscuits and gravy are out of this world.  The fried chicken, well, I had to ask and learned all about the brining in buttermilk.  The chicken has the absolute best spices and texture of any chicken I've ever had.  And I'm one chicken-eating mo-fo.  
Oh, I could go on and on.  Just go and eat it.  You won't be sorry.
author: Isa L.

description:
Drove a long way for fried chicken here and told the server. Alas, my search for yummy, crunchy fried chicken must continue. I was unfulfilled. The chicken itself was moist and cooked nicely but it was soggy and underseasoned on the outside.

The rest of the meal was pretty good. The arugula and pear salad my friend had was pretty yummy. 

The servers were very nice.
author: Scott H.

description:
This hurts me. A LOT!! Normally I would rate FP five stars! I had to take it down due to the new menu.

Front Porch used to be my #1 place to go for dinner. Whenever anyone would ask me for a recommendation for a place to get dinner in SF I would always send people here! Sadly, this may change. 

I was crushed to find that along with a new Chef there is a new menu at Front Porch. My beloved Spicy Crab Grits are gone. GONE!! WHY-IIEE!???! I know that you have to shake things up every once and awhile, but why try to fix something that's not broken? I used to live for the Cod Fritters as well... gone. Everything I loved.... gone. 

Perhaps I'm being a little dramatic here. But I really do feel like I've just been dumped. I hope after some growing pains that the Chef might consider bringing back some of the old favorites. They call it comfort food for a reason!! And now I'm in some desperate need of it.

With all that said, I still love the decor of the place. The staff is always really laid back and awesome. If you aren't a die hard lover of the old menu this place will probably still win you over with all it's charm.
author: Angel P.

description:
Fried green tomatoes - good
Fried okra - good
Blue crab fritters - good
Shrimp and grits - EXCELLENT
Jambalaya (tuesdays only) - EXCELLENT
Bucket of Fried Chicken - great 
Mac and cheese - great
Collard greens and mash - great
Green bean casserole - great

Service - excellent
parking - good
decor - cozy and funky

The jambalaya was so delicious. Can't wait to go back and get some more - Tuesday nights only!
author: Grace Y.

description: The server greeted us warmly for lunch and we were immediately pleased with the homey atmosphere of the place and the enticing list of items on the menu. We had the chicken and waffles, a shrimp poboy, an oyster poboy and beginets- all of which were excellent. To top it off I heard the server talking about ghost chillies which got me intrigued so he offered us to try the new hot sauce made with the infamous ghost chilies, used sparingly it is awesome. Can't wait to go back.
author: Ian A.

description:
This should be five stars. For years, whenever anyone asked, I've said my favorite restaurant in the whole city is Front Porch. But went there last night and they have dropped a star. I still love waiting in a rocking chair outside with a drink for a table, I still love the tin ceilings and the comfy booths. The service is still great - knowledgeable and efficient but relaxed and friendly.

But the spicy crab grits are now shrimp. Wah! So I ordered the fish instead. And hello salt! I almost sent it back but I was starving. I probably should have sent it back. But the sever was so nice. I just wasn't in the mood to cause problems at my favorite place. The sides:  maque choux was delicious. Crawfish beignet too greasy, maybe the oil was not hot enough when they fried it? A strange mistake for them, I thought. Sweet potatoes - meh. Ok. And there was a weird sort of sweet and sour sauce on the plate. It was ok but I didn't love it.

My dining companions had the fried chicken and they assured me it was delicious as usual. I couldn't try the collard greens - bacon. Mashed potatoes were nutmegy delicious.

I'll be back but please, bring back the crab grits!
author: robin b.

description: I have never had a bad meal at the Front Porch! I really enjoy the atmosphere, the staff, and of course the food! Hats off to you guys for doing a great job!
author: WildBill C.

description:
I am so bummed out about this restaurant. This used to be a very special place for me and I've had a few excellent meals here. It's kinda pricey/fancy so I have somewhat high expectations for my meal. I had the biggest let down the other day. We came in early, ordered the fried chicken bucket and it was raw. Not just undercooked, raw. We told our waitress (after taking a few unappetizing bites) and she told us it was supposed to be "pink". We showed her the very pink/red meat and she took it back to be cooked again. By that point though, we didn't really feel like eating it and were kind of scared that we might have gotten food poisoning. She mentioned that the oven was having problems the night before, seems like something they need to figure out asap.
I definitely won't be going back there again, especially not for a $35 bucket of undercooked chicken.
I thought maybe they would comp something but they just gave us our chicken to go. I was too scared to eat it later so we gave it to our neighbors and guess what, it was STILL undercooked!
author: Emily L.

description:
everything was fine.......until my special steak came...medium rare and i can hardly chew or digest it. i had to spit out most simply cos i would choke to death if i try swallowing!!!

the appertizer seemed good. i tried the fried stuff...chicken was ok....i might even prefer KFC's seasoning..though probably more fatty...and i don't even eat KFC, the last time i went was in China....many moons ago...

nice concept though, a bar turned restaurant. great atmosphere and great service. but the booth we were on were highly uncomfortable.....the way it was set up...plenty of room between our shoulders but our feet are piled on top of each other!
author: Xiu L.

description:
The promotional stickers say "Front Porch Rocks," and goddammit, it does.

After rocking (appropriately) in a rocking chair for half an hour with a juice box of wine (they're at Whole Foods, check it out) on their front porch waiting for my table, I decided I'm always amazed by how I have the best experiences at this restaurant.

Cozy and equal parts group fun, intimate dinner and delectable soul food. Me and the guy went on one of our first dates here, and it reminds me of those initial butterflies. So crowds aside, it will always feel just as intimate as a dinner at Foreign Cinema.

It fills up fast, so definitely make a reservation ahead of time. Since the place is set up in an old, Bernal Heights house, you may feel a bit squashed into your table, but just get cozy with those people/person you came with, and you'll be fine.

I think the menu changes periodically, but my suggestions include Uruguayan beef hamburger with all the fixins, Texas Toast and Pinot Grigio out of a the aforementioned juice box. A sampling of a friend's order of grits was also tasty. Yummy fried chicken is rivaled only by SPQR. Fun, courteous staff. Fun cocktails on the menu.

I'm coming back next week.
author: Tara R.

description:
Every bite of food I had was totally insanely scrumptious (sangria, sangria, sangria, conch fritters, grilled asparagus with boiled duck egg, fried chicken, jerk tri tip, homemade donuts). If I had my way, I'd fill a bathtub with their grits and eat my way out. I LOVES me them grits. Creamy and perfect. This is my pick for best place to take out of towners for San Francisco treats.  

My only complaint, and the food and atmosphere were so wonderful I'm not taking away a star, is that the service was a little inattentive. We waited at the bar for the bartender to take our order for about ten minutes and he was not too busy to do so. Once he got our order it took him another five mins to pour our beer and sangria. Perplexing. We'd downed those pretty fast and it took some waving of arms to get the attention of our server (who was very charming and friendly) to tell her we wanted to order a bottle of wine. No biggie, but as a former restaurant worker, I'm always puzzled when staff aren't jumping at the chance to add $$ to the bill. 

We went on a weeknight well after the dinner rush and didn't have to wait for a table too long. 

Front Porch, I love you.
author: Pam D.

description:
Thank you Front Porch for serving your fried chicken in a bucket.  Of course, it was half filled with paper and air, which is why you only get 4 stars.  But it was in a bucket.  As if all things served in buckets are good.

Perhaps they are?
author: Steve S.

description:
Finally tried this place last night, and was delighted!! 
Cool, kinda seedy, dark atmosphere... You can sip your drink and rock in rocking chairs on the front porch while you wait (if you don't have a rez)... It was loud in a fun way (not too loud)... Very old (cool) bar and ceiling... Made-on-the-premises tasty ketchup... Friggin GREAT Kobe burger and crispy fries... Same with the fish fritters (yum)... REALLY friendly server and great service...  

The only down side (but far from problematic) was that the "bitter" side salad I ordered was kinda blechy... as in, bleh! Why'd I order this?!

But I can't wait to go back here - such a casual, fun, divey but yummy food/drink/socialize with your friends kinda place! I hear it's great for just grabbing a drink or two at the bar, too...
author: beth l.

description:
There isn't really a whole lot to add here, since 48756347865 people have already chimed in on the Front Porch. But I WILL say this: I honestly felt like I was in a down home New Orleans joint for a few hours on Friday night (minus the dripping summer sweat & rough cajun accents).

The food was great, but the prices were adjusted for San Fran.

It is what it is, though. I don't think I'll make a special effort to eat there all the time (too far from my hood), but I'll probably be back at some point.
author: Pete J.

description:
Having spent many a meal at Emmy's I was very excited see what Josie would do with a new place.  My friend and I got a chance to dine at The Front Porch last night and we both agreed that this is one of our new favorites.  

The place is a block from Emmy's, and provides the only knock on the experience, which is parking.  Entrance is through a very cute porch area with a few seats.  The inside is homey and comfortable with the immediate smell of home cooked food, namely fried chicken.  

During a short wait for our table we spent some time at the bar where the service was friendly and fast.  My friend simply HAD to try the wine in a juice box which was a quite nice Pino Grigio from Three Thieves that was literally served in a juice box.  It's quite an experience to drink wine out of a grade schoolesque juice box.  

Once seated we started with the Pickled veggies and egg dish.  The picking was perfect.  Not too much yet enough to give the right flavor.  The veggies included green been, carrots and yellow beats.  Very tasty.

After much discussion over the menu we decided upon the fried chicken with grits on the side and a salt cod dish that was not on the menu that included a half and half of fried and pan seared cod.  We also, serendipitously, ordered the fresh crab risotto.  The best accident I have ever made.  The risotto was one of the best I have ever had.  Order this dish.  Period.  If they are out it will be because I am sitting at the bar eating your helping.  

There's a nice wine list with very affordable options.  The Three Thieves boxed Cabernet is not quite up to par but decent.  There's a decent choice of beers and the service was very friendly and fast.  

In case you haven't figured it out I amhigly recommending The Front Porch. Just don't all show up on the nights that I'm going.
author: Dean H.

description:
This place is awesome.

Good old comfort food.  Good beer.  Good Front Porch.  

Although they don't take reservations, they put our name on the list and seated us pretty quickly once we got there.

The recommendations were perfect -- although they ran out of the mac & cheese and the chef wouldn't serve a pork chop without it.  I guess sometimes they know what flavors they are trying to pull off and substituting out the m&c just wasn't going to cut it.  Damn, guess I'll have to go back.

The grits with crab was awesome, though, and had the m&c/pork chop combo been available I wouldn't of ventured that way.  So good on ya for sticking to your guns!
author: Mara H.

description:
At 417 reviews, you really don't need another mediocre one but I couldn't resist.  Especially since I waited over an hour to get into this place.  They take reservations for parties larger than five on busy nights.  Though it seems every night is busy. 

What to do while waiting?  Grab a drink at the bar if there's room or drink up at 3300 Club (just down the street) and they'll ring you when your tables are ready.  

It's Soul, Carribean food served under stamped-tin ceilings, low lighting, and quirky decor.  I loved the atmosphere and prices.  Everything else was so-so.  My champagne was flat, the fried chicken was OKAY, and almost everything on the menu is baked, fried, or slathered in gravy.  It's good grubbing if you're into artery clogging food. 

Oh...and parking is a biatch.
author: Kimmie N.

description:
We had reservations so we got seated quickly and promptly. The food was great... my favorite was their fried chicken. It's my weakness. Their cornbread was very tasty as well as the pork and ribs. 

They charged us a cake fee and corkage fee (expected)... the cake fee seemed about average... but I felt the corkage fee was slightly over average cost.

I would still go back --- can't say no to that fried chicken!
author: Haw Y.

description:
I found a pleasant surprise while perusing mission. It's easy to pass by since it's a smaller restaurant but after checking out the menu and quickly learning it'd be an interesting feast (fried green tomatoes, okra, shrimp and grits etc) we were sold. 

sat at the bar and had their sangria which was mediocre. then came the dining part. the restaurant itself is relatively small but very cozy and unique to SF. servers were very cordial and helped explain the vegan menu as well as the special po'boy of the day. 

my friend and i (we were starving) had the fried green tomatoes, plantains, fried chicken (we just had to order after looking at it being served the table over), shrimp and grits. a lot of food but each were satiating. the fried green tomatoes were good. the plantains seemed carmelized so id probably pass on that next time, the fried chicken was amazing, and the shrimp and grits were great as well!

DO NOT forget about the habanero hot sauce!!! it was so good i asked the server about it. they sold them by the bottle at the restaurant $8. bought 2 bottles and had a bunch of left over. left the restaurant feeling very much satisfied... id definitely come here again for good southern food.
author: Mary O.

description:
It's easy to miss the Front Porch if you're passing via car or bike. Luckily, I spotted it on a walk home, and it looks like it's already earned customers via Emmy's word of mouth. Love the old-lady rocking chairs.

Yum! The prices are a deal for what you get: wholly original, mostly organic, tasty home cooking with a lil Caribbean style. We had fish & chips and crab porridge with generous chunks of a crab that had probably crawled into the joint that morning. The butter on the corn bread is amazing. Rose sangria was delicious, though a little heavy on the ice. Nice & cozy, a la Leo's Lunch Room in Chicago, but with lovelier, more fun attitudes.
author: elsa m.

description:
Shared two appetizers and an entree, with glasses of wine, between two people and we were stuffed and had to take a lot of it home.

Started off with seafood gumbo and shrimp and grits, which were both wonderful.  Richly textured and flavorful, without blasting your tastebuds to oblivion with an excess of spice.  Then we had the entree of a single serving of the fried chicken (3 humongous pieces) because, well, it's a southern comfort food place, it's kinda obligatory.  My dining partner enjoyed it, but I was pretty meh about it, I preferred the stuff from Popeye's.  But the appetizer dishes are well worth it and constitute a meal on their own.
author: Jason L.

description: This place was recommended by my friend from NYC who loves it. I was early so I sat at the bar and had a glass of wine while waiting for her. The hostess and the bartender were friendly, they have an awesome wine list. Liked the ambiance, nice and dark. Had the fried green tomatoes, they were pretty good, crispy and breaded on the outside, tasted really Southern. I also had the salmon jambalaya which was ok. Not brilliant, just ok. The fish was completely blackened and a bit dry, but the sausage was tasty. I will come back for the ambiance and the wine list.
author: Pam D.

description:
After reading a review in the Chronicle we decided to check out the Front Porch with friends on a Sunday night.  Since it had recently been reviewed we figured on a wait.  After arriving at 6:30 we were told it would be a 30 min. wait and they kept to their word.  The host was very friendly and sweet.

The interior is cozy and cute but did get pretty loud with the place full.  We sat next to the bar and had I known it would take our server ages to even ask us for a drink order I would have gone up to the bar in the first place.  I have to commend them on their beer menu - some less than obvious choices with two cask brews served at room temperature the way many beers are meant to be served.  That said, the goblet of beer that finally arrived at the table was half full (or half empty depending on your perspective).  When the cask brew ran out half way through my second beer the bartender did make a visit to our table to explain and then gave me the remains plus a full draft beer to make up for it and then kindly asked if we were into the Emmylou Harris that she was playing (we were...).  Aside from our flighty server the service was quite friendly overall.

The food was so-so.  The hierloom tomato salad was tasty but nothing out of the ordinary.  There are so few places to get good grits in San Francisco that I had to order the crab and grits porridge which was very good.  My partner ordered the corned beef hash special which was basically the same as the grit porridge but with hash and greens instead of crab.  The fried chicken was good but not great and a tad pricey (the Colonel's $9.99-sized bucket but for $29).  The black eyed peas and cole slaw that came with the chicken were both just adequate.

This is one of those restaurants that I would go to again but only if I was with a group of people bent on eating there.  Otherwise there are a zillion other new, unique SF restaurants where I would much rather drop $40 a person.
author: Jon B.

description:
The Front Porch is the best "new" restaurant in San Francisco. I loved it the first time, but decided to wait to review it because you never know with a place like that. They can sometimes have beginners luck. 

So I've been twice now ... most recently for a birthday dinner for my friend, Jimmy. Born and raised in the south, i can say a few things about Sothern cooking that are totally legitimized at FP:
- you can never add too much butter to anything
- corn should never come out of a can
- grits can be eaten at any meal
- fish is best served fried
- salad is the place for expressing your creativity

I love this place. The food is great ... it's expensive, but you don't feel ripped off because you leave full and the food is unique and delicious. The wait staff are really nice (and really hot) scenester types with no detectable attitude. 

A tip of the hat to other reviewers ... it IS loud in there and yes, there is usually a line. However, we went on monday night at 7pm and only had to wait about 10 minutes for a table. The bartendress was fun and chatty and the time flew by. The meal could not have been better. 

i'm in love ... and i'd also like to ask the host out on a date. what a hottie!
author: Scott H.

description:
Wow. This place has 508 reviews (as of today - 5/29/2008).   Not much more I can write about it that someone else hasn't.    I really like the two things I ordered, Bucket of Chicken and Plate of Meat.    The service was friendly, think mid-western type of friendly and not psuedo hip Mission friendly.   

I've been there four times so far, and the food and service has been great everytime.
author: Johnny C.

description:
The best part of front porch is the atmosphere. While waiting for a table, some friends and I sat in the rocking chairs outside while ordering cocktails from the bar. We didn't mind a minute of our 25 min. wait. 

For dinner, I had the spicy crab and grits which was DELICIOUS!! We also had the fried okra which was pretty good. My other two friends shared the bucket of fried chicken. The chicken was more than enough for two people. They had to take leftovers home. 

This place is friendly with a great atmosphere. I'm not sure that all of the food was a hit. My husband thought his steak was just above average, but, as I said earlier... the crab and grits are fantastic.
author: Joan L.

description: Excellent fried chicken. Tasty mashers n mac n cheese. The blackened catfish with crawfish was on point. We had a 40 min wait on Friday but that was expected. They sent us to the 3300 Club for drinks while we wait. Good drinks for a good price! Great night!
author: Trent O.

description:
Many people have written about this place, so I won't bother reiterating what they have to say.  I will provide my own spin, however, to educate and illuminate.

Life is about moments, and to me, a fine moment is one where you get to stop talking, eating, and drinking for a minute and just look around.  When I have a moment, it's seeing a fine dinner spread out, a friend mid-laugh, a half-full drink and a mostly empty bottle, and feeling of mirth and content. 

The Front Porch for me always seems to perfectly synthesize the moment.  I've been a few times now, and had good conversations with the barkeeps, servers, and patrons.  I've made offbeat comments regarding their facial hair, and they throw it right back at me.  They smile and chuckle when we make sexy noises with phallic cornbread and slippery honey butter.  The patrons share their stories, breaking the ice with our communal love for buckets of popcorn and chicken.  And no one bats an eye.  The dark, low-slung interior perfectly captures an atmosphere of intimacy and mystery, sort of like a fog of war encouraging you to open up and explore.  

What started as a quest for fried chicken and real grits has become a small slice of southern Xanadu (a la Kublai Khan, not a la ONJ).  It feels like home.  Hell, one of the owners even has some West Virginia in him.

So take friends, take your special someone, take someone from off the street . Put your name on the list, and then wander up the corner to the bar and chat over drinks (it'll be about 45 min or longer.  Bring discussion topics).  When your table is ready, roll back down and order half the menu.  It's the perfect way to have a moment.
author: Cracker J.

description:
This place was pretty great. Of course, it was already an amazing night. Obama just won the nomination and the Mission was spinning. People were leaning out of cars and windows shouting, strangers crying and hugging, incredible. 
Anyway, we left our election party at like 10:30 to go to dinner and The Front Porch was still open late. We were the only diners in the restaurant but the whole staff was brimming over with excitement after the election. The four of us got into a cozy table and ordered...our friends got fried chicken, my boyfriend got the crab and grits. I got a burger that was maybe the best thing in the world, with shoestring fries. so fucking tasty. 
What's really great about this place is how homey it feels, very welcoming and very friendly.
author: Eve O.

description: I like it, I'm just not in love with this type of food. The asparagus is delicious. The fried chicken is good too. The little pre-mail biscuits, such a joke. Get some real tasty corn bread, like they have at Baby Blues.
author: Samantha S.

description:
I went here around 5:00 pm, my fiance and I were the second table to be seated and it wasn't busy...The setting was casual...The server we had was dressed in typical city urban clothes and it made the ambiance of the place very relaxed, great place to kick back and enjoy a delicious bucket of chicken...

We started off with the "Fried Okra" (I love the batter crunchy and crispy and the okra is not overcooked inside)...We shared a "Bucket of  Chicken with side dishes of mash / gravy and collard greens"...(The chicken had the same batter as the okra, crunchy / crispy and the seasoning is not too over powering, just the right blend...I love how the chicken is juicey on the inside and has the same blend of spices as the crispy / crunchy skin on the outside)...

The only thing I was bum about was we didn't get our complimentary cornbread right away because there was something wrong with their oven at the time...Eventually we got our cornbread towards the end of the meal and it was yummy, I wish they would have given us more than 2 pieces, I was thinking of asking for more cornbread but I didn't want to wait for so long hahah...

Overall I would come back to this place for some yummy chicken and hopefully their oven if fixed so I can get more cornbread =)
author: Precious S.

description:
I was really looking forward to trying this place and I was really disappointed. 

The catfish was like rubber - couldn't tell if it was undercooked or overcooked. Reminded me of chewing on a sock.

The hushpuppies should not be allowed to be called hushpuppies. We had a very funny moment where I tried to put my fork in one to move the puppy from the serving bowl to my plate. I could not get my fork to break through the cemented, cornmeal shell and the force of my fork made the puppy leap from the plate and shoot off the table. Luckily I caught it before it hit the ground. Then I spent 10 minutes chewing the densest cornmeal concoction ever created. Over the weekend I had fabulous hushpuppies at Mother's Bistro in Portland. Go there - or Kate's Kitchen, or the South - for hushpuppies. 

Gumbo was edible, but not very good. How could so many ingredients create so little flavor?? Nothing compared to Yat's in that bar in the mission or the good stuff served by the witchy women at the annual ho-down at El Rio. Or the stuff in New Orleans. 

Fried okra made me want to cry... in disappointment. The batter wasn't crispy and didn't have any taste! The dipping sauce tasted like plain mayo! The okra was just sad to be in such a demeaning position. 

The jar of pickles: Loved them. They were tasty and fresh. Worth $6? No, but they were the best food item consumed.

Free cornbread. THIS IS NOT GOOD CORNBREAD. I am shocked that people like this stuff. Maybe they gave me the three day old leftovers? 

The pecan pie. This was good, thank god. Not worth a trip to try it and not the best, but edible. 

But the kicker: this all cost us $80 with one beer each. I would put the tastiness of this food on par with Hard Knox cafe on 3rd street, where a big entree and two sides costs $10 and the quality of the food is questionable (although the preparation is ok). That price is about right for this food too. Next time I am craving anything Southern, I am heading to Farmer Brown or Yat's.

I am adding one star for friendly service, a nice atmosphere, and great Southern beer on tap, but I won't be returning.
author: Jammy M.

description:
We descended with a huge group to celebrate a dear friend's birthday.  They took excellent care of us (including a personalized menu!) and the food was above and beyond what I could have expected.  
The fried chicken was truly finger licking good and I don't even like chicken on a bone.  
Mac and cheese = slamming.  
Corn bread = super tasty.  
Fried dough goodies for desert = amazing.
They have a $15 corkage fee, so we brought a bunch our own wine.  
A wonderful and memorable place for a lovely birthday celebration
author: Amanda S.

description:
After my less-than-glowing review last year, I must say that Front Porch has really come around. The food is still great, the service has improved quite a bit, and the pretension which annoyed me seems to have gone away.

My wife and I really enjoy sitting at the bar: the bartender is great, and it's just got a great vibe.

For those who are new to Front Porch, I encourage you to venture beyond the always-excellent fried chicken. From this summer's menu, the jerk chicken was amazing and the pork chop was pretty damn good. Last, but not least, the vegan special is often the most delicious item on the menu - and great for regulars, as it changes every day!
author: Louis B.

description:
OK, so friend is jonesing for some fried chicken, so I scan Yelp and find this place which is within driving distance.

Scan the menu, decide on the bucket of chicken with sides, $33. Waitress sez there are 9 pieces of chicken per bucket.  Sort of stiff, but then this is SF.

We get the complimentary "corn bread," which consisted of two 2" pencil-sized slivers of what I guess is the corn bread.  Friend is mumbling that maybe this is one of those "small plate" joints, so he orders a side of mac & cheese.

Food arrives, bucket of chicken has popcorn mixed in with it.  Odd, but doesn't distract from the food.  Sides consist of smooth mashed potatoes and greens, on a serving platter about 10" long.  Doesn't look like a whole lot for two people.

OK, let's get to the food.

Friend evaluates mac & cheese and gives it a, "good."  I scoop a helping of potatoes and greens on my plate.  Greens are very good, potatoes, not so much.  Whipped into something you could pour if they were a little less stiff and coated with I guess was gravy.  I much prefer the "lumpy" style of mashed potatoes, but I guess this would pass if mashed potatoes weren't your thing.

Now the chicken.

What can I honestly say about the chicken?  I guess "Mom's" chicken would be the best description.  By that I mean, It's got a nice coating of crisp batter, nice and juicy inside, but...............  It just didn't have that much flavor.  This chicken would pass for anyone, including your grandma and the kids, but in all honesty, I just want more "kick" from my chicken!  I'm ready to duck (no pun intended) here, but I honestly think that the KFC or Popeye's does a better job when it comes to flavor.  Again, let me stress that this is not bad chicken, it just doesn't have the zip that I prefer.

Dessert, chocolate creation with syrup...meh.  Decent coffee.  Oh yeah, one more thing.......  When giving a customer a glass of wine for $10, realize that unless you're serving it in a 6" wide goblet, fill the freakin' thing beyond the 1/2 way point!  Don't give me that, "space to breath" garbage, I just want more than 1/2 a glass of wine for my money!

Parking hell in this neighborhood.  Ride your bike or walk.

Final evaluation?  Good but not great.  There's better out there, I'll keep you posted.
author: Dan S.

description:
THE BOTTOM LINE
Full of character. Friendly personal service. Hearty soul food that you don't see every day in San Fran.

(If you go, demand the mac & cheese return to the menu.)
author: christopher r.

description:
So, the food was GREAT.    I went here with my mom, who happened to be in the city today, and for some strange reason decided to bless me with her presence.  She loves cajun food, and I figured this might be great for her.

The BBQ Shrimp was that stand out fave.  We ordered one as a starter, and polished it off quickly.  6 perfectly cooked shrimp, 1 big piece of bread, and a slathering of crazy-delicious sauce made us very happy(which is probably why we ordered a second plate of it later!).  Mom ordered the gumbo, which was probably AMAZING, but since it was my mom, she said it was "good."  I got the vegan meal, which was great...some brown rice wrapped in cabbage and lots of veggies...very tasty.
