For our sides, we went with the fried okra and yucca, both quite good, though I've recently had some awesome okra, and this didn't quite compare.  

Erin, our server, was very nice!  However, service was SLOW.  She made it to our table quickly enough, but(and I blame the kitchen for this), the times between courses was unacceptably long...I think after the shrimp we ended up waiting 30-45 minutes until our main meal! The restaurant was not even that busy when we walked in, at 6 pm on a Thursday(a few tables open, etc).  As we left, there were people waiting for a table.  I can't imagine what their wait will be like.

The wait was definitely the downside.  That being said, I would definitely go here again, as the food was awesome.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I went to The Front Porch with 3 friends tonight, after the restaurant had been open for almost a month. Our experience started off well, when a 30 minute wait turned into just 10 minutes.

The interior decor is beautiful, at least as far as one can tell from the dim lighting. The other diners were having good times with friends, with much laughing and even some shouting. The very loud thumping bass of Led Zep's "Kashmir" added to the party atmosphere.

Unfortunately, the dim lighting made it difficult to read the menu, and the loud music meant that we had to shout our orders several times to the waiter before he understood us.

The food did not take long to arrive, a fact for which we were grateful because the elevated sound level made conversation difficult and had transformed the music from fun to annoying. 

The portions of our dishes were small. Two of us ordered the veggie porridge, which was very tasty. Unfortunately, the bowl in which it was served was deceptively small, holding little more than a half-cup. While flavorful, the size seemed more suited to an appetizer than a main dish with a price of $9.50. 

One of our party order the fish and chips, which he liked very much. He couldn't tell what the fish was (it changes based on the day's catch) but the chunks and the batter was interesting and pleasing.

Another friend had the fried chicken, crunchy and well-done, with a batter of unusual and intriguign batter. Tender was the first piece. However, each piece of chicken was increasingly dry, so that by the end of the basket, my friend had trouble swallowing the meat without an accompanying sip of water.

The desserts were also problematic. The apple crisp was full of apple, but had no crisp. My yellow cake slice was small, and had the consistency of a Duncan Hines mixture that had failed to rise.

Only one of us said that he would return to The Front Porch to try another dish (he would not order the fried chicken again). For myself, I would only be willing to give the restaurant another try if someone else were paying the bill.
author: Craig C.

description: Love the chicken and waffles here. I ordered the shrimp and grits and the potato salad. Potato salad was really creamy and delicious! As for their shrimp and grits, I've had better in New Orleans. Plus the outside patio is really nice for a weekend brunch! Really cool place to chill and relax. Our waiter was really friendly too!
author: Hiroyuki T.

description:
Miss Ollie's Fried Chicken Bucket.  Comes with a small side of coconut infused beans and dirty rice.  $65 with 2 IPA's, an extra side (mashed potatoes), fried plantains (yum) and tip.

5 stars for the fried chicken.  Great consistency, wonderful to bite into.  Served in a popcorn bucket with a handful of actual popcorn.  However they cook the chicken imparts a bit of popcorn essence into the first bites.  Kitschy and could do without it.  Actually, didn't care for THAT, but the juicy tenderness of the chicken + the nice crispiness of the coating made it all okay.

Minus 2 stars for the poor quality sides and the 'no substition' policy on them.  We got 2 small cob-shaped pieces of cornbread.  Served cool and was pretty dry and over-cooked.  The regular meal ($15) comes with buttered beans and mashed potatoes.  The bucket, for whatever reason, comes with coconut beans and dirty rice.  Meeeh?

The beans were awesome, liked the coconut thing going on.  The dirty rice SUCKED MAJOR ASS.  Each grain of rice was hard and crunchy, as if we got served the last of the outer crusty portion of a big buffet pan.  The flavor was overpowered by cumin and it was dry as all hell.  It was horrible.  I grew up around soul food and am often one you'd have to fight with to get any dirty rice at all.  I kept WANTING to eat it, but every bite I tried actually pissed me off.  I've had better boxed rice.  Sorry...I'm Asian.  If you serve me crunchy ass old rice...I am offended.  Learn how to cook the shit or don't offer it.  Even the Uncle Ben's rice pilaf at Circus Circus is better than this.  C'mon!!!! Hopefully for them, it was an off night and/or so busy they gave rice-making duty to the rocking chair.

Very glad that we ordered potatoes as well or I may have given a 2 star rating.

Scratching head at the different flavored beans option as well. Buttered beans for the individual serving, and coconut for the bucket?  Mashed potatoes then rice????  WTF?  Maybe the place has an identity crisis.  Fried chicken, frisee, fried plantains, and confit?  Hmmm.  One would think that a place that offered frisee AND confit would, at the very least, know how to boil rice.  Sorry, back on the rice thing.  Guess I was more traumatized than I thought.  Taste your shit before you serve it, yo.

And...Is it Caribbean or is it soul food?  Picking one and sticking with it may serve them well.  I invite you to come to Oakland and try some real soul food...or Caribbean for that matter (they won't necessarily be under the same roof, btw).  Shooot...go to Popeye's even...it'll give you a 'minimum' to shoot for on your cornbread and rice.  Sorry...had to go there. This place may do well for its clientele, but it wouldn't survive in Oakland.  Even the white-folk out here know them some soul food.  ;p

Want to love this place.  The decor is cute and chicken was DELICIOUS, so were the beans.  Will go back, coz the chicken was THAT good, will hope they'll allow a substition for their crappy-worse-than-Church's-poor-excuse-for-dirty-rice. Man, that hurt my feelings.
author: Cris C.

description:
Really enjoyed this place. Was even better because we went with my gf's roommate who sells grass fed beef to this restaurant.  He knew the owner/Head Chef.   Helped, bc we got hooked up with all the above!

I ordered the fancy fried chicken, defiantly different then your standard KFC.  It was good, but not really used to foo foo fried chick. Ha. The table of 6 I was with shared their dishes as well.  

Experience may have been different if I came here with peps that didn't know the owner.  I'd defiantly come back again just to make sure.  

Prices- medium to high.  About 20-40 bucks per/person
Ambiance- Loved it, very southern/Louisiana feel to it.  Chill and hip!
author: Chase F.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night around 730, waited 30 min for a table for two. comfy patio outside as well as a bar inside to wait with drinks for a table to open up. great service, nice and informative waiters. hostess came to check on us a few times to make sure we were all right.

complimentary chilled pea soup with jalapeno cream (?) wasn't bad, but the bbq shrimp was delicious! even the bread that soaked up all the sauce was tasty. i got fried chicken (outside was a little too salty but inside was juicy, moist and tender) with mashed potatoes and collared greens (both great), while my friend got the burger. apparently it was cooked too rare for his taste, but the parts he did eat, he said were tasty too. sangria was absolutely delicious. not usually a fan of colorful drinks, but this was refreshing, not too sweet.
author: Joyce C.

description:
Take a trip to the south. This restaurant may look like a hole in the wall with rocking chairs scattered marking the spot on 29th St, but definitely grab a seat inside for a fun dinner. 

This is not a great place for groups. They can seat a very crowded table for 10, but you will be knocking elbows with your neighbor. 

The food was great--hot corn bread with jalapenos to start the meal off. I highly recommend the fried okra side along with the flounder entree. The popcorn bucket with fried chicken was also a hit at the table. 

The drink list is really fun too. Electric marmalade and the sangria were great...although definitely lacking booze--my main critique for this restaurant. The bartender definitely needs to tip the bottle a little...show a little southern hospitality!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I'm not a native Californian, but I might as well be.  The furthest south I've gone is Rosarito -- which is certainly south of here, but not The South.  It's not the War of Northern Aggression, it's the Civil War.  I don't say y'all, and I don't have a twangy accent.  

Thus it is very unfortunate for me that I tried out the food here the other night.  Because now I have a craving for grits.  Specifically, creamy, melt-in-your-mouth, spiked-with-a-bit-of-chili-pepper grits.  Have I mentioned that I cringe at the sight of hot sauce?  That I am married to a man who literally breaks out in a sweat while eating tom ka gai soup?  All I have been able to think about, food-wise, for the past several days is GRITS.  WTF is wrong with me??  Damn all these good restaurants opening around here!  for the love of God, STOP!

p.s.  the fried chicken is delightful greasy goodness, too.
p.p.s.  why do I keep calling fried chicken delightful?
author: Nat K.

description: The fried chicken here, although a little spendy, is da bomb!!! The sides are a little less desirable. We had the garlic mashers w/ collard greens and of course mac and cheese. Come early or be prepared to wait.
author: Minh V.

description: Great shrimp and grits! Not impressed with the fried chicken or the waffles, however. But yay! Shrimp and grits!
author: Will R.

description:
Nice atmosphere some of my table mates thought it was to dark, but I found the dimmness of the place relaxing. 

The fried chiken is great and the Spicy Crab and Grits Fantastic. 

My only complaint was the dish I had The Seafood Pelau was $27 and the rice in it was WAY to spicy and for $27 not enough seafood, the 4 clams that were in it did not open, the mussels were good and the 2 shrimp in it were good, the samon was OK, the Octopus was cooked very nicely as well. If it was a bit less spicy it would have been really good for me. 

Check it out but share the portions and if you can't handle spicy food don't go, nothing on the menu is mild.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
Love this place. Whimsical but not pretentious (i.e. cornbread in the shape of corn on the cob!), attentive but low-key service, divey but somehow awesome atmosphere, fantastically delicious and generous dishes, GREAT cocktails.

We especially love: fried chicken (dare I say the best in SF?), baby back ribs (fantastic smoke flavor and sauce), the Caribbean soup, brussels sprouts, rice and beans, coleslaw. 

The only miss for me is the rice pudding, but I've always generally thought it a gross, baby-food textured mess.
author: Carolyn F.

description: Ahhh, the front porch otherwise known as the place with awesome burgers, awesome homemade ketchup, and other stuff thats good but a little pricey. I personally love their fresh burgers and sweet potato fries! The Front Porch deserves a try or two if you live in the area. Dont visit the place with the hopes of having an epiphany, but visit with the hopes of grabbing a damn decent meal without all the stupid posh yuppiness that other restaurants have fallen victim to.
author: J B.

description:
I had originally given a 4 star review below, but a day later, I realized that I was charged wrong by our waitperson.  I called the restaurant and spoke to the Manager in the few days after to get it straightened out. 

Mistakes happen and the Manager was going to correct it.  However, here it is almost 4 weeks later and I called again today because it still hasn't been reversed (the incorrect charge, overcharging me).  It stinks when you are charged incorrectly (especially after leaving a 23% tip) and then it's not corrected in a timely fashion.  
_________________________________________
Good food and great, friendly service.  

We had reservations for dinner and the hosts were super accommodating and friendly.  Our server was good and the food was very good overall.
Definitely try:
- fried chicken; the best I've had in a very long time (collard greens are yum!)
- mac and cheese; good and worth ordering
- hush puppies; nice compliment to everything
- the Cava champagne is delicious!

Tried the happy hour a few days later.  Good happy hour specials with good prices on appetizers and sangria/beers.
 
-  excellent slider cheeseburger
-  wings are so-so
-  gumbo; not a fan, tasted burned/roux was overcooked, didn't see any okra in our bowl
- jalapeno poppers with sausage were spicy and delish!

And a few days after that, BRUNCH!

- chicken fried steak was great; scrambled eggs were not very good
- biscuits and gravy were excellent

Overall the great menu items makeup for the couple of items that are not that great.  If they improve the gumbo then this would definitely be a 5 star place.  The Front Porch also participates in a lot of local charity events so kudos to them for that!
author: K V.

description:
Came here with a group of 8 and we all enjoyed dinner.

Starters: 
Fried green tomatoes - very good but could have used more than two tomatoes on the plate

Duck - very good! It's like a duck confit, southern style

Crab - excellent

Mains:
We heard so much about the chicken, that everyone wanted to try it, so we ordered two buckets. The chicken was GREAT.  We didn't need two buckets but I'm sure it will make some great leftovers or late night drunk snacking. While it was great friend chicken, it's a bit on the pricey side for chicken - Foreign Cinema has great fried chicken, too and I think it's a bit less expensive.  The other main dishes also looked good but I was too focused on the chicken to check them out.

Sides:
Mashed potatoes were very good
Vegetables were a disappointment 

We skipped dessert and went across the street to Mitchell's
author: Doug C.

description:
I really wanted to like the fried chicken.  I had been craving friend chicken and was super excited to have, what appeared from the reviews, to be some of the best in the city.
Let me start with the good points, and there were many.  They had just started using the Open Table reservations system.  That process went flawlessly.  My date and I arrived early, had a beer each at the bar and were seated early.  Also the place itself is very cool looking.  It feels great and we were both very excited to be there.
The staff was very nice.  Everyone was friendly and eager to please.  Absolutely no issues there.
We ordered Fried Pickles to start.  They were very good.  Different than I had had in the past.  A thin almost delicate coating.  They were crunchy and salty and served with a very good Aioli.  So far so good.  We were enjoying the experience and the food and were very excited for what was to come.
The rest of out meal arrived.  The Mac and Cheese was first.  It was served dangerously hot - as it should be - and was very good.  The collared greens were sweet and tender, a definite winner.  The mashed potatoes were served with a terrific gravy.  They were creamy with a bit of lumpy still in them.  Again very good.
As you can imagine, at this point I was really excited about the chicken.  It arrived in a popcorn bucket.  Very cute!  It was crunchy and juicy - cooked just perfectly.  Only one issue - it was absolutely devoid of taste.  It was enough that we sent it back explaining that we thought that they had forgotten to apply any seasoning at all.  The waitress was responsive, brought it back to the kitchen and returned with the bucket several minutes later - again the chicken was without flavor at all.  It wasn't bad tasting, it wasn't good tasting.  It is was simply "not tasting".
So I return to my search for friend chicken, sad that the Front Porch will not be my go to location.
author: Bill G.

description:
Hello dear Yelpers, 

Sooo i gave this a lot of thought and against my brother's advice HAD to write a negative review. I went to this restaurant with my boyfriend (who is from the south) and two of my friends. When i walked in, I was extremely impressed with the decor. IT was dark and had many unique decorations. The bar area and the restaurant area are not separated and some of the tables are extremely close to the bar area. We were lucky enough to get a booth and the wait was about 15 minutes on a Friday night. When we sat down I was extremely anxious to try the cornbread since the pictures show it to be a large piece of bread in the shape of corn..cute. the waitress came and she was very nice and asked if we were ready. we ordered our dishes....however.....hhhmmmmm no bread was coming. we asked her if we had to pay for it and she replied NO. yet...still no bread. finally it came. The cornbread was extremely small and DRY. How can u mess that up!!!!! My expectations were lowered right then and there. Next as an appetizer we ordered Fried Pickles... the pickles were soggy and waaaaaaaaaaaay too salty. For main dishes we had the following: I had a fried chicken steak with mashed potatoes. it was eeegh...ok nothing at spectacular. My friend ordered a pork chop with greens. The pork chop was dry and burned and she had to return the greens because they tasted as though they were not washed thoroughly and there was sand in them. My boyfriend had fried catfish and said that it quite tasty and saw were his fries. After this disappointing meal, i decided to decline desert. However my brave friend ordered Creme Brulee. UMMMMM please tell me why the entire sugary top coat got stuck to the spoon and came off as one whole piece and it was cold in the middle....did they just MICROWAVE Creme Brulee. 

SOOOOOOO ladies and gentlemen. Despite the hype, I would advise you not to go. I love GOOD food and this was not it :(
author: marina g.

description:
with the inviting scene in the front which actually looks exactly as a southern front porch might, i couldn't wait to try this place. a year and a half later i finally did!!! ha! 

on a much needed dinner date with a couple of the girls, we decided to order up a storm and get our eat on. we got the shrimp and grits, mac n cheese, brussel sprouts, pork chop, filet mignon (the special of the day), creme brulee, pumpkin bread pudding and a rootbeer float.

shrimp and grits- aaahhh the shining star! i don't even like grits but these were creamy with substance and oh so good. i thoroughly enjoyed it.
mac n cheese- meh. the cheese and mac didn't stick together and the noodles were mushy as hell.
brussel sprouts- charred with carcinogens just the way i like it! 
pork chop- tasty but nothing to write yelp about.
filet minon- for $32 i expected atleast the tenderness a cut of meat with that title almost always posesses, but i was wrong. it was tough and i regret that order. 
rootbeer float- average rootbeer float.
pumpkin bread pudding- average
bananas foster creme brulee- THE WORST CREME BRULEE I'VE EVER HAD. it was cold, there was the thinnest of thin layers of sugar coating and the custard was gritty!! it's almost as if they took their grits and mixed them with sugar. we didn't even eat 1/3 of it, it was SO TERRIBLY BAD.

damn i wanted to like this place. the only thing that was positive was the shrimp and grits. and their cute front porch i guess.
author: Regina C.

description: Great greasy fried chicken and the ambience is nice. Don't get a po' boy but do get the fried pickles.
author: Andrew  M.

description:
When I want some home
Cooked comfort food
And transiting far 
Will put me out of the mood,
I know that the grits and 
Delicious brussel sprouts will
Remind me what it's like 
to lovingly get my fill. 

And I've got a cocktail made without heavy booze 
Some fried chicken and doubles as a starter
The people are great and the cook staffs so hot
Makes me want to strip down to my garters.

It's dark and the music
May make me talk loud
But the butter has chilli 
and pork is so proud.
Oh, the hipster in me
Really comes out in force
When I'm sipping on a stout
Just outside Front Porch.

And I've got a cocktail made without heavy booze 
Some fried chicken and doubles as a starter
The people are great and the cook staff is so hot
Makes me want to strip down to my garters.
author: Jon G.

description:
Food: 3
Service: 4
Decor: 3
Atmosphere: 3

I dined with a friend at The Front Porch this past Wednesday, the second day they were open.  I wanted to love the place.  I wanted to give it 5 stars.  I wanted to want to come back right away.

Ix-nay on that.

Let's start with the food.  The ceviche appetizer has promise, but the fried plantains weren't uniformly crispy.  In fact, some were downright soggy-mushy, and that ain't right.  We also had the heirloom tomato salad which was quite good, with a spicy and somehow hearty dressing that made for a nice duo.

For the main course, we shared the fried chicken and dungeness crab over polenta (ok, they call it corn grits but it's the same thing).  Fried or baked, roasted or grilled, chicken doesn't belong on a menu unless it's really done right -- it's simply too ubiquitous.  Given the promise of a Barbados-inspired spicy delight, we had high hopes for the Front Porch's fried chicken and were mightily disappointed.  Decent, but totally uninteresting.

The dungeness crab, on the other hand, is a stellar dish.  The chili oil seasoning really brings this entree to life - the unexpected flavor combination of the crab, seasoning, and polenta is so much better than I could have imagined.  This is one of those dishes where you're left wondering, "How the hell did the chef come up with this!?  I'd never have tried putting those elements together in one dish."

Oh yeah: avoid the side salad!  Too big, too bland, wrong greens (imo), and I have no idea how it found its way onto the menu.

The service was super friendly and remarkably on top of their game for it being the second night of dinner service.  If they can maintain this attitude, the Front Porch will no doubt earn a spot as a neighborhood favorite.

We dined kinda early, so it was hard to judge the atmosphere.  We did witness one couple get in a fight, culminating in one of the two throwing her napkin across the table at her friend/partner and then storming off.  Otherwise, the patrons seemed to be in uniformly good spirits and I'd bet good money this place is super fun after 9pm.
author: Nate B.

description:
I have to concur with some of the other reviewers on this one:  fantastic ketchup!  And, I'm not just saying that because I won a bet over their ketchup. Ok, after intense cross-examination, I'll admit it: I'm just saying that because I won a bet.

Their menu is not the largest -- so, I am glad they were offering some tasty specials.  The pork chop was excellent -- not out of this world -- but, it hit the spot.  The vibe is homey and suits the comfort food.
author: Tim G.

description:
friedchickenfriedchickenfriedchicken!

It may clog your arteries, but Front Porch makes it worth the guilt (if I had food guilt, which I usually don't).  An extremely generous portion of crispy, perfectly seasoned chicken, plus a side of black eyed peas and greens which was SO good.  We also got tuna tartare and ceviche as appetizers, and while I was a bit skeptical about how good the fish would be, I was really impressed.

Oh!  And they have juice box wine!!  I think it was a pinot grigio or something similar, but how can you not enjoy yourself when you watch the bartender stick a bendy straw into your juicebox wine.  I think I enjoyed myself a little too much that night...
author: Leslie R.

description:
I heard of this place from Check Please! on KQED.  Since it was Carribean/Trinidadian inspired, we wanted to check it out.  

PARKING - Difficult! We went late at night so we were able to find street parking 1 block away

AMBIANCE- Retro.  They were playing "rock" music. I was going to suggest them to play "carribean" music since this is a soul food place!!  The interior is really dimmed. 

WAITER - He was really cordial and nice.  He has a white patch of hair on his head. 

WAITING TIME - We went around 7:45pm and it was about a 15 minute wait. 

FOOD -  We got the Miss Olle's Fried Chicken (it comes in three pieces:  dark meat, wings, drumstick and breast). The skin is layered crispy with cornmeal type of texture? The meat was still a little moist. The mac and cheese that came with it was a bit dry.   
We got the Callaoo soup:  Taro leaves, fat, crab meat, and orka. I thought the soup was slightly bland.  We also got the "Doubles" which is a chick pea mixture with curry sauce. They provide the fried bara bread in which you can scoop the chickpeas up with your hand.  Hanks Black Cherry soda was good on a warm day in SF.  

Complimentary Corn Muffin bread which was good with a really finely whipped sugary butter. 

Dessert:  I love looking at the dessert menu before going to a restaurant but the website doesnt provide it.  We got the corn custard with subsitute of strawberries and rasaberry (no cherries, they were out) and a sugar donut of some sort.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
We came here for my high school friend's birthday.   He was advised to come before 7pm whereby there will be no wait.  We got there about 6:30p and was seated at a booth immediately.  

We snacked on some sweet and spicy nuts while enjoying our drinks, kumquat soda, limeade and glass of German champagne.

Starters: dungeness crab salad with a light avocado dressing- very good and very generous with the crab,  spicy crab and grits - grits were nice and creamy and had a good kick, and finally I ordered the fried chicken liver with onion gravy over toast.  I don't know why I wanted it, as it was the heaviest dish including the entree we ordered.  It was delicious, but the fat content, I regretted.  

Entrees: My friend had the porch chop and a side of creamy grits both, yum, yum....    My other friend and I shared a bucket of fried chicken choosing the slaw and the macaroni pie for our sides.  The chicken is delicious.  It was perfectly flavored inside and out.   The breast meat was tender and not overcooked and the pieces were generous.  There were 9 pieces and we could only eat 3 each, but managed to finish the sides.  The slaw was delicious but the macaroni pie was so so... it was just macaroni salad baked with bread crumbs... i was hoping more of a mac and cheese.   

dessert:  ooooohh...   We had the sorbet flight with crazy mixes of flavors... like the meyer lemon with chili flakes, the blood orange with mint, and I can't remember what grapefruit was paired with, but after the heavy meal, this sorbet just hit the spot.   only complaint was that they were in small cups.  :D   The other item we had was the corn custard with 2 fried donut hole made from grits.  We also had a side of Mitchell's vanilla ice cream.   The corn custard was more like a corn vanilla creme brulee.  very tasty and tasted like corn.   donut holes were so so...  but I think we all liked the sorbet best...

All in all an excellent dining experience!
author: Regi K.

description:
This is one of those "2.5 stars rounding up to three stars" places for me. 

I'd done my homework; I had reviewed the menu online and skimmed through dozens of yelp reviews prior to my first dining here. A bucket of fried chicken! Fried okura! Interesting wine-based cocktails! Affordable pricing! Located in Bernal Heights! Yep, I REALLY wanted to like this place (I know it's such a yelp cliché - bear with me here). 

The minute I walked in, I *thought* I was falling in love with the place. I l love the vintage-y interior and the cozy setup (like how I love Attic). It was like meeting a hot guy for the first time and thinking to myself: "he's so fine! I am so feeling his style!" To top it off, the waiter informed us that they offer BBQ ribs every Sunday! I envisioned myself being a "regular" here (using the dating analogy, it was like the hot guy telling me that he was working on his PhD in physics. *drool*) 

Since this was my first encounter, I decided to play it safe and order the famous bucket of fried chicken with the fried okura. The Louisiana brown ale was good, I was horny, I mean, hungry, and anxiously anticipating the dream meal to unfold in front of my eyes. Soon after we ordered, the fried okura was served. I immediately took a few bites. 

......? *took another bite of okura* .....? Does this....taste like deep fried bar food from those chain restaurants, in which I would never been caught dead? OK, I wasn't going to judge a restaurant solely based on fried okura. But still...this made me suspicious.  Again, using the dating analogy, this was as if the hot guy mentioned he was temporarily living at his mom's place (wait, what?)

Then there came the bucket of fried chicken. I hurriedly took a few quick bites like a starving child, and then paused and thought:  the texture is OK. The meat is juicy and not too fat or too dry. But something is missing here? I took a big sip of the brown ale and had another bite of the chicken, this time with a little more care and attention. A few seconds of a denial ensued. Could this be?  Then I took another bite. This time, it was confirmed: the fried chicken at the Front Porch was indeed disappointing. It was completely lacking flavor. It had no magic. Eating the rest of the chicken was like a chore. I was eating it because I was still hungry and I do not like wasting food, but like a hurried office lunch of a Subway sandwich, it was rather functional and not a joyful dining experience (I am grateful that I am not starving, by the way. But since this is a restaurant review, I am not focusing on how blessed I am to have a plate full of food). 

The dining experience at the Front Porch turned out to be a very short-lived infatuation for me. Unfortunately, there was no chemistry betweeen us whatsoever. It just so turned out that he wasn't working on his PhD in physics; he was just a pot head who was once enrolled in some "graduate level" online courses titled "Connection between Ancient Eastern Philosophy and Quantum Physics." 

I mean, he was hot. I hear he's popular. But apparently, we were not compatible. Looks can be very deceiving, indeed.
author: Nana N.

description:
I've been to The Front Porch a dozen or more times since it opened and we recently had an amazing meal there. We brought our Auntie and uncle, who are not foodies AT ALL and they really enjoyed themselves. For folks who love well done steak and plain mashers - this was a stretch. I took the liberty of ordering for us and every dish we had was a hit. 
We really wanted the braised oxtail to start, but they were out- :(. 
We had Shrimp and Grits, 2 orders of cornbread muffins, a pulled greens salad to start and for the main - 
Fried, a large bucket of chicken, greens, garlic mashers and of course, mac-n-cheese. 
Now once everything started coming, the non stop talking quickly quieted to a halt. Everyone's eyes were buggin out - we were in love w/ our plates. Not one morsel of food was left. I really wanted to have that bread pudding - but I was stuffed. I love this neighborhood joint and I will definitely return again and again - yummers!
author: Erica C.

description:
The first two times we came here, I was all thumbs down.  My impression was: loud, inattentive service that came with lots of Attitude when it came at all, mediocre food, small portions.

My guy finally convinced me to give it another try.  We went last night at around 5:30pm.  Fantastic!  like a different restaurant - no waiting, all the waitstaff were both super-nice and very attentive, the food was plentiful and delicious!  what happened?  I don't know, but i'm going back.

They started us off with delicious cornbread sticks and tasty paprika butter, followed by small glasses of chilled pea soup w/ habanero cream - so yummy!  and the waitress very thoughtfully brought a glass w/o the habanero for my daughter.
I then had the halibut over a chive crepe wrapped around root veggies in watercress cream.  Amazing - the halibut was cooked perfectly, brown and crispy on top and moist and flaky inside.  My guy had the bacon burger, one of the best he's had (and belive me, he's had a lot!)
My daughter had macaroni and cheese, which was great, and which our server was kind enough to bring out early w/o even being asked!
author: J W.

description: Front Porch.  I love the down-home divey-ness and the former bar setting.  The menu offers some solid Southern classics.  My meal was really salty.  Flavorful, but damned salty.  Good beers, good service, and good selection.  Perhaps it was a fluke?  It'll be hard for me to come back.
author: Eric S.

description: This place is a neighborhood gem, truly one of the best places to find brunch or dinner in La Lengua, if not the whole city!  I highly recommend the Baked Egg & Grits on the brunch menu,  and the fried pickles and fried okra appetizers are also delicious.
author: Tod G.

description:
This place is yum & then some! I went to this place with 3 other friends. Overall, everything we had was fantastic!  Service was also really good. 

We had:
Cornbread- it was okay.
Bucket of chicken- crispy and juicy 
Mac & Cheese- I highly recommend this! cheesy and baked! 
Collard Greens- Yum, just like the pot of greens I make at home
Mashed potatoes- Amazing, a bit creamy and lumpy
chocolate pecan pie- We were so full, but had room for dessert! We were debating o strawberry shortcake or the chocolate pecan pie to share. My gfs ro-sham-bo on dessert and the chocolate pie won (i voted for the pie). The edges of the pie was crispy, with soft pecan goods inside, then topped off with a chocolate crust on top..just like heaven. The couple next to us had the strawberry shortcake and it didn't impress me. I don't like muffin looking things in my dessert -=oX
author: Dee S.

description:
I wanted to love this place, but after being told that we would get a table in 30 minutes, and after an hour were barely acknowleded, my patience was tested. We waited another 30 minutes after getting some free sangria. 

After FINALLY getting seated, the service was a mess. They're clearly under-staffed and over-worked. The waiters were running all over the place and visibly stressed.

The grits and crab dish was pretty good, but after 5 bites, it made my stomach hurt there was so much butter. The fried chicken was nothing to write home about. The breading was dry and falling off the meat. I've had better at KFC! 

I like the idea of this place - fun, good southern cooking. But they need to get more staff, better service and polish the southern cooking.
author: Kim M.

description:
Came back here on Monday night and it was super crowded. An hour wait! The hostess could not have been nicer and more helpful though. She was fabulous! This time I was able to enjoy that glass of wine on the porch and try the fried chicken. Our waiter was wonderful too. Despite the crowd, we didn't feel rushed and really enjoyed the experience.

I didn't think this experience would surpass my last, but  it did.
author: Vanessa P.

description:
Unequivocally the best fried chicken i've ever had and you know I don't joke about food!  I am not even a fan of fried chicken but this stuff was amazing.  Crispy and not at all greasy crust with tender delicious organic chicken inside.  If you are with a group deffinately order a bucket, it's a pretty good deal.  The grits here may be the best i've ever had and while i'm not crazy for black eyed peas they were fantastic!  I ate here once almost 2 years ago and I am still thinking about this legendary meal so you know it's good!
My only complaint and the reason i'm not giving 5 stars is that it's very loud here and so dark you can barely see your food.
author: Kaylee T.

description: My son wanted some deep fried chicken and found this place online.  So we checked it out online and said, "Why not give it a try?"  So glad we did.  The place is in Bernal height, underneath a flat and packed with people.  REASON:  The fried chicken is unbelievable. Not only were they good, the hush puppies, muffins, fried green tomatoes, and mashed potatoes were just as incredibly good. We were too stuffed to even look at the desert menu--but we will next time.
author: D M.

description:
Been here twice and i have not been disappointed!  Decided to come because my friend was craving their fried chicken and their crab meat and grits.  Yes, the fried chicken is divine,  but we ended up ordering something else.  We arrived a little bit before six and the front of the restaurant was already half full; mind you that it was a rainy day so we expected it to be empty.  We ask for a seat in the back because it was a bit more quiet.

We started off with shrimp and grits, which was "lick the plate if no one was looking" delicious.

I had the daily vegan special: stuff sweet bread topped with fresh cooked tomato, beans and lots of kale.  The blending texture of the bread and yam was perfect.  The tartness of the tomato blends very well with the yam and bread.  Add a little kale and swirl it around in the bean and you a heaven in your mouth!  Yummmy! The portion was huge and I took it home for lunch the next day.  

My friend has the pork chop, which was another special of the day.  I was too focus on my plate and did not try his, but he said that it was juice, tender, and cooked just right.

Note: their menu changes all the time!
author: Winny L.

description:
"Um...we're here for the early bird special," was my apologetic statement when my friend and I entered an empty Front Porch on a Monday night around 5:30pm. I usually eat later so it was freaky to catch the wait staff in the midst of their evening warm up routine before the crowds hit.

It was nice however to get some personal attention as my friend and I were in a food ordering, decisive zone. After one gander at the menu, we ordered  the chickpea appetizer and some wine. Great wine selection and the chickpea app was delicious. Spicy, savory and not too heavy. 

For entrees, my friend got the fried chicken and I went for the crab and grits. I was a little worried when it came out that it wouldn't be enough for my Fatty McFat ways but I would have been in trouble if it were any bigger. The grits were buttery, salty and the perfect consistency. On top of the grits was an incredibly seasoned mixture of crab that made for a tasty and filling treat. I even snuck a bite of chicken off the bone from my friend and it was TASTY. 

We shared the warm bread pudding with dulce de leche sauce for dessert. The dessert was just okay but we still left Front Porch in pain from pushing the limits of our gastric capacities. 

Definite recommend if you're in the hood. I actually saw Front Porch reviewed on 'Check, Please' over a year ago and it had been on my short list of places to try for some time. It was tasty, cozy and the staff was very attentive.

p.s. Despite my penchant for shuffleboard, there are no early bird specials at Front Porch.
author: Corey F.

description:
I've been walking back & forth in front of Front Porch for the last three months watching it steadily grow and anticipating having my very own front porch just a half a block from me. I was not disappointed!

To recap and summarize from the many many other reviews posted: fried chicken excellent -- crispy and greasy coating, tender & juicy chicken -- black eyed peas needed spicing up with the hot sauce. Fish and chips to die for. Little cornbread thingys -- can I have a platter, please?? The only drawback, menu-wise, was the limited number of options. I hope they expand, just a wee bit, as I plan on going back over & over and don't want to be stuck eating the same things again & again!

Our server was nothing if not enthusiastic. She was attentive, but that may have been because we arrived at 5:30 and were only the second table seated. By the time we left there were groups of people waiting at the bar for seating. Defnitely a hit in the 'hood!
author: Phoebe H.

description:
Just got back from a halloween dinner at The Front Porch.  I'd been wanting to try this place since they opened.

I have to preface this review though.  I went to The Front Porch with two friends, one of whom is friends with the chef.  While I believe I would still have given The Front Porch 5 stars if my friend didn't know the chef, her personal touch--which I believe she probably bestows on all customers in one way or another--made our experience all the more extraordinary.

So we sat down and got water right away.  The restaurant's got a great ambiance and I admired their shelves by the table with salt and pepper, candle and flower.  "Real Cute," as my friend C-Diddy would say.  

Immediately the chef, who is quite attractive--not that it matters, but she is, brought us fried okra with a great sauce.  It. Was. So. Good.  I am now an Okra fan because of Sarah!  She also brought over cocktails that had rose petals and champagne as main ingredients and those were wonderful as well.

A little later we got cornbread, in the shape of corn on the cob, with sweet butter.  Also so good, and I for one, appreciate the details.  

We ordered an Heirloom Tomato Salad and it was plated beautifully and tasted even better.  I was eating the sauce after it was all gone.  Really simple, and really friggin good.

Between the three of us we got a bucket of chicken with sweet corn and black eyed peas and collared greens as our side with an additional side of coleslaw for Les, cause he's a fan.

I    Have    Never   Had  Chicken   So   Delicious!  

She knows how to use that spice rack.  Seriously, genius with the spices.  The corn was the same deal and the black eyed peas were great too.

We didn't get dessert because it was halloween and we wanted to be home to give out candy, but they looked great too.  

I will be back for sure!

Thanks for an awesome and UNIQUE meal.  Such a special place.
author: Biggie M.

description:
i think people come on to yelp just to b*tch and whine about whatever. i think can be mostly bias because they know someone in a good or bad way. I don't know anyone at front porch nor did the hostess take an extra 5 minutes to seat us.  I gotta give front porch 5 stars simply because it was yuuuuuummmmmmmmy. 

i started with the beet salad. some people don't like beets but i love 'em. the way they were prepared with the shallots and sour cream sauce. it's making my mouth water just thinking about it. 

we also had the asparagus with the sweet potatoes. yum yum.

my man ordered the grits with crab. i ordered the fried chicken which also included grits and collard greens with black eye peas. it was perfect. a little heavy but i easily stuffed myself with every last bite because my tongue was happy with the flavors. i felt like abusive to my body because i also scarfed down a piece of corn bread that was shaped like a little piece of corn. it was cute. it came with a honey butter that had some kinda kick to it. oh my goodness. it was to die for. 

and just when i thought i couldn't fit anymore in my body, we ordered dessert. it was the special, and i don't remember what it was called. but they were these fried balls (i see you giggling over there) with this creamy sauce and drunken strawberries... if i could name it, i would call it 'fried balls of goodness'. but i'm sure that's not what it was called. 

anyway, i didn't want to make this long, because i hate reading long reviews. but i do recommend this place for sure. take your girlfriend/ boyfriend there when you are comfortable with each other because you are going to want to go again and you'll start getting that love fat that couples get... if you know what i mean.

if i wore hats i would say 'hats off to the chef'.
author: Renae C.

description:
Definitely a unique dining experience. When we got there, we were waiting for our table to be ready, which even though it was about 30 minutes after our reservation time, I didn't mind too much because of the great waiting area out front (the front porch of The Front Porch).

The bar had these huge bottles of Red Stripe which I thought was quite awesome. Some of the other drinks looked tasty, like the ones my compadres got. It would have been nice if they served liquor though; I was jonesin' for a Jack and Ginger.

We were finally seated and decided to "fucket" and get three buckets (of fried chicken). There were six sides to choose from, and two came with each bucket, so we got all six. The chicken came out and it was absolutely delicious. The breading was nice and crispy, the chicken was the juiciest I have ever tasted, and they were nice, plump pieces. I would have to say, however, that it tasted just a little too lemony, but still probably the best I have had. One thing I thought was kind of weird, though, was that they put the chicken in these huge buckets and filled the bottom with plastic bags or something. So the buckets aren't as big as they look.

The sides were great too. I especially liked the grits, corn on the cob, and black-eyed peas. All the sides should have been in larger quantities though.

One thing that was lacking was the service. It took a while to order and get our check. I wasn't too bothered by it, though, because it was a relaxed evening in good company. But I suppose if I was trying to not spend two hours eating fried chicken it would have been a little bothersome.

I'll definitely be back, but with these prices it will be a "once in a blue moon" type of outing.
author: Stu M.

description:
Due to a kitchen mix-up, my dining companions and I feasted at The Front Porch for a very moderate price.  The staff was very accommodating and apologetic, and we stuffed our faces.

We started with the salt cod and sweet pepper fritters (my favorite dish of the night) and the roasted root vegetables.  The fact that the restaurant serves cornbread shaped like little ears of corn was a cute touch.  I was really excited for the cornmeal crusted oysters, but they had run out :(

And between the three of us, we ate two orders of the fried chicken (I really liked the side of black-eyed peas and collards with pork belly) and two orders of the crab and grits (careful, it's hot!).

For dessert we had two pieces of the pumpkin pine nut cake and the spiced pear.  

I totally understand the "southern" but I'm not so sure where the "caribbean" comes in.  Nonetheless, it was GOOD.
author: Marcus C.

description:
I was blown away by the food--don't go to Farmer Brown's except for drinks. The food here is so much better. I liked the ambiance, but I was expecting a place you could spread out a bit more--no complaints though. The bartender was a super nice guy and his sangria's were fresh and delicious. The server was a cool guy too--overall it was a very unpretentious welcoming vibe. I just wish they had the rum and bourbon that would be so fitting here.

But, it's the food, really, that makes, it, and the friendly atmosphere is just the icing on the cake. The crab and grits is my new favorite dish and the fried chicken was awesome, as was the pork chop and beans. For appetizers, we had the salt cod fritter and the double dips plate or something like that--some meats, some cheese. I can't express how impressed we were with the food without doing a lot of annoying caps and exclamation points. Not only is this the best southern/Caribbean place in town, it's one of the best restaurants in San Francisco.

Yes, I'm nuts about bourbon, but it's the one thing that's holding me back from five stars here.
author: Josh K.

description:
Deep fried chicken livers
Fried chicken and macaroni and cheese
Cinnamon flavored pate
and Petites de nonne....

Stop reading this and go taste for yourself.

I suggest getting there before 7pm.
author: Tu R.

description:
A friend of mine who is originally from Tennessee suggested this restaurant.  He said it was the closest thing to home as far as southern cooking.

I was pleasantly surprised by this place.  We ordered a bucket of fried chicken, macaroni pie, and spinach.  They also served us cornbread which was shaped like little corn on the cobs.  
The food was really good. I like southern food a lot and will treat myself every once in a blue moon.  I also have dined at Farmer Brown's, but actually prefer this place.

It's affordable and good.
author: Christal C.

description: It's good. Initially thought it was great, but after going to Lois and Angeline's, I have to admit they do southern food better on the other side of the bridge. Great atmosphere, open late, great service. Great place to visit once, cute. However, not a return to place. It's really popular, but just not great.
author: Ahmed S.

description:
The other night I had dinner at Front Porch, a new-ish restaurant that bills its cuisine as "Caribbean/Southern," a distinction that I can see in their mix of dishes and ingredients. I went with a group who above all else wanted the buckets of fried chicken, so that's what we had... three buckets, with two sides per bucket (included) fed nine hungry people. The sides consisted of black-eyed peas with collard greens, grits with chili oil and scallions, and roasted Brussels sprouts doused with chili oil... I suppose the inclusion of chili oil makes this a "California-esque" rendition of The South, but I liked it. It was also commented that the grits were "too creamy; more like polenta." Whether that's bad or not I leave to your own discretion.

Everything was tasty, but I was particularly impressed by the fried chicken. The meat was moist but firm, and the breaded and fried exterior was crispy without being oily/greasy--a rarity in the fried chicken world.

On the adult beverage front, their wine list is a well thought out selection of inexpensive-to-mid-range whites and reds. I had the Verdejo, a Spanish Rueda that was both fruity and crisp, and provided a nice compliment to the deep-fried goodness and the warmth of the chili oil.

Next time, (and the fact that there will be a "next time" is significant) I want to try the Barbados Bistro Salad (a combination of fried oysters and pork belly over frisee can't be bad) and the Deep-fried Chicken Livers.
author: Chris B.

description:
This was stop number two for our recently started Fried Chicken of the Month club and it was definitely a winner.  Beth V.  insisted that we order the bucket of chicken despite the fact that we were only two.  I'll admit the huge tub was a bit daunting at first, but the chicken inside was divine and I'm sure I'll enjoy the leftovers.  The cheese grits were equally fantastic, though I'll admit the fried potato trio and the black eyed peas with collard greens left a little to be desired (but then again, I'm a purist who makes homemade black eyed peas every year on New Year's Day, so the bar is a bit high).  I'd definitely go back for the chicken bucket -- but with more than two people!

(Oh, bonus points for very friendly staff - I think its the first time in San Francisco that I've had an owner introduce himself at the door and shake my hand - nice touch!)
author: Jenny E.

description:
I so very much love the IDEA of Front Porch. Its menu is wonderfully creative as well as standard with Caribbean/American/Soul/comfort food fusion. I want to love this place, especially because I can walk there, but I simply cannot based on my three dining experiences. 

Number one: I ordered the crab n grits, and my friend the bell pepper and salt cod fritters. I had a house cocktail, and it was nice. Unfortunately the person who came to our table (twice? three times? but he came to the tables around us--someone from the kitchen and not our server) was doused in cologne. It was BIG, like the kind you can smell ten feet away and probably came from Walgreens. Anyway I don't care where it comes from, I'm allergic, so I was unable to eat the majority of my meal, due to intense nausea and headache. I had it boxed and was pleasantly surprised while enjoying it the next day. This was amazing! I fell in love with the dish; it was well balanced with some other flavors and I think some chili flake. I wasn't sure whether I'd go back due to cologne fear, but alas, visit #2:

We split an incredibly delicious and simple and light and perfect beet salad. Also the roasted root veggies, which were an insult to root veggies--bleh--but came with some very rich and flavorful goat cheese. Also the salt cod fritters. I've always theorized that if it's fried, it tastes better. And boy did these. I'm not a fan of salt cod, but all doughed up with sweet peppers and perfectly fried hush-puppy-style, mmmm, it;s good. 

On my first two visits I was so impressed with the ideas and flavors in the vegan one pot stew that i had to order it. This is a special that changes nightly and is a welcome addition to the menu for those of us eating lower (and lowest) on the food chain. I can't remember what all was in it but the tomato sauce it was bathed in was delicious. I had the crab n grits again so I could pack it up and enjoy it at home again. But about two hours after getting home I had the worst nausea/stomach ache/something, and it felt like my food was not digesting. I was awake and uncomfortable for hours.

So you can see why I SO WANT to love this place, but it has some problems.
author: Stephanie P.

description: Been here twice now. It's a cool spot, I love all the rocking chairs in the front. The first time I went I had the catfish po' boy, with a side of mac and cheese. nom nom nom! I'd never had catfish before so I was kinda underwhelmed with how mild it was to my taste buds. But I loved the mac and cheese (tho it doesn't hold a light to that at the Broken Record) and our waitress was super cute and friendly. I don't remember what drink I had that night, but they have a variety of mixed wine drinks I've never heard of before! The second time I had a super hard time picking what I wanted, and wasn't terribly hungry so I just got the mac and cheese again and some of the wine drinks. I wanna go back again, but it is a bittttttt pricey for me!
author: Lexie L.

description:
Super-yum!!

Not many vegan/vegetarian options, but the vegan stew I had was scrumptious, coconut-curry veggies... The fried okra was awesome, too!

My boyfriend loved the famous fried chicken.

Delicious beers on tap, and I had a wonderful Malbec!

But aside from the food - we loved the atmosphere - the crowd was buzzing, humming along, in the tiny, cozy space... Music playing, the totally perfect vibrant-yet-chill, comfort zone. Plus, we can walk there (definite bonus)! 

My first visit made this place instantly one of my favorite spots in the city. Loved every bit of it.
author: Andrea D.

description:
* steamed crawfish + manila clams
* steak fries w/ paprika aioli
* bucket of FRIED CHICKEN w/ collard greens and garlic mashers

A-Must-GO if you want some good ol' bucket of fried chicken! 

Everything on the menu was delicious (at least the ones I ordered). And the staff were quite entertaining and polite. 

Kudos for the interior design.

I would've loved to come here when they used to have the "old menu" that Front Porch regulars keep mentioning. I wonder why they can't bring some of the old favorites back? Spicy Crab Grits ... Cod Fritters .... mmmm sounds good to me.

Coming back soon.
author: Vincent B.

description: When you're craving fried chicken... come here!!  Order the bucket and share or take the bucket home... Also had the fried okra.... Mmmmmmm good!!
author: Cathy F.

description:
I've heard fair reviews about this place from friends. Tonight, I decided to finally have a taste of this place for myself. The place was a small dim lighted restaurant with a cozy feel. It was very intimate. It only seats about 49 max. They played good music and had extremely friendly customer service.

When we first arrived we had to wait about 30 minutes for a table. So, we took a seat at the bar and had a couple of drinks as well as an appetizer while we waited. We ordered the porch fry daddy. It consisted of fried shrimp, calamari, oysters, mushrooms, and pickles. The appetizer was okay, it wasn't the greatest fried portion of food I've had. Honestly, I could say I've had better. The batter didn't really stick and was pretty greasy. For our entree we ordered the bucket of fried chicken that came with collard greens and garlic mashers. Once again, I've had better! The only different thing about the fried chicken was that it came in a popcorn bucket with kernels of popcorn scattered around instead of being presented on a regular plate. Other than that it was your generic fried chicken. All in all we paid around $70. We could have gone to Hard Knox and had the same amount of food. No actually, scratch that. We could have had a lot more for around $30.

There wasn't anything special about this restaurant. We wanted to eat reasonable for the night and ended up spending more than what we expected to. I wouldn't recommend this place for your typical soul food place. You can go somewhere else for much cheaper with better quality food. Basically, you're paying for the atmosphere. I wouldn't come here again to eat soul food. The place is expensive. Basically, it's soul food transformed into high-end cuisine.
author: Cassie D.

description: Came here awhile back and ordered the chicken waffles. The food was excellent but I had a problem with their portion size. When I eat Southern food, I expect to gain a few pounds after the meal. This place definitely didn't do it for me. Not to mention, parking is a hassle in this area.
author: Eric L.

description:
Very solid southern/Cajun cooking.  A bit of a wait but plenty of drinks and cocktails.  Fried Chicken is one of the best, very tasty and moist throughout, possibly brined.  Well falvored, crusty but not soggy with grease.  Pork chops are generous and moist as well, again, possibly brined, which I'm a huge proponent of.  Shrimp w/grits (Low Country style) is possibly the best item on menu.

very much recomended, a bit dark for the interior.  Make sure you make reservations and give yourself enough time to park.  Very congested area so, give yourself from time.
author: Peter Z.

description:
MMMM.... HMMMM (with a southern drawl)

Now I am not one who normally like southern cookin' but I'll make exceptions for some tasty delights and a good atmosphere. On a cool SF evening one can stroll into this warmly lit place on a whim, put their name on the list (there is a tiny wait), grab a drink and unwind on the... yes you guessed it... front porch. Chat with your loved one about the week and in no time your name will be called.

When you get your table take note of the hipster vintage decor and the following menu items:

1. Juice box red wine - it was fun and not too bad of wine... make sure to drink using the straw and no giggling!
2. Corn fritters, yum!
3. Red and golden beets salad
4. Molasses brined "porch chop"

Makes me want to slow down and just enjoy my evening. I'd say that is definitely a southern kinda thing. Well done.
author: Ali K.

description:
Vegetarian and soul food is like oil and water.

That said, if you're in the mood for the latter and you're not the former, chances are you'll dig this place.  Much better quality than say...Roscoe's house of chicken and waffles.  Although, decidedly less ghetto...there's something magical about a late night dancing and getting some of that Roscoe's action.

anyway, I digress.  I liked my collard greens (sans pork), corn grits, and bigass vat of Red Stripe.  mmmm
author: Daddy O.

description:
For my money, the only way this place could get better would be to offer whiskey. I'm giving them 5 stars anyway, because they've taken what should be a very basic menu and subtly turned it into something fantastic. They make you think this is just "downhome" cooking, but the extra mile they go to make things special reveals how talented the chef and owners really are. At reasonable prices to boot.

While the fried chicken is fabulous, the crab grits are original and with the chili oil and other secret ingredients placed in there, truly a great meal.  Butternut squash soup, which is served in nigh every place in SF, is given new life with coconut milk and ricotta. Even though it can be a bit noisy, I found that, once seated, conversation was easy and I had plenty of room.  The mood is the room is fun, informal and filled with people in good moods.

Plus, their beer selection is fantastic, with a nice mix of Belgian and English, with a few American classics right in.  They even sell King Cobra malt liquor!! However, when I spilled a bit on the floor (for my dead homeys) they didn't seem to appreciate it. Still, I'll let them keep their rating, since I didn't have to mop it up.
author: Jay N.

description:
Damn was I drunk when I got there.  Damn was I full when I left...

Pretty cool atmosphere and nice decor.  Seemed like each table kind of had it's own vibe.  Nice staff, and cute.  

The place was buzzing on a Friday, our large group had to wait a while, but if that's how things shake out, then who am I to argue?  

I was into the fried chicken.  I still have some between my teeth - I'm cherishing it.   The collard greens were pretty solid, as was the crab and grits.  That's my trifecta right there, and I would go back to get some more.  

Weirdest thing:  The whole time we were there Led Zeppelin was playing.  I think some Robert Johnson would have went better with the food.  Or maybe some Lead Belly.  

No liquor license = minus one star, no matter who you are.
author: chris o.

description:
Miss Ollie's Fried Chick'n is finger lickin'
the Spicy crab grits, kickin'
Every one tummy
Left the Porch happy

OK, the straight talk...Seriously, the food we had was stunning for comfort, quality, and flavor. The fried chicken is fresh and fried to order (there's a 20 minute wait for it). The flavor of the brine really comes through and makes every bite one to savor. Honestly the BEST damn fried fowl I've ever had.

Finally, the staff running the front of the house are just nice as can be, too. The only downside is it's loud. But the 8 of us didn't notice between  the "Ummms" and "Mmmmms" that were falling out of our full mouths.

Off I go to burn 1000 calories!
author: C P.

description:
Went here for our first anniversary dinner. Friendly, efficient service, great food, great drinks. Pretty nice atmosphere. Maybe needed a bit more spice, but I'm kinda like Lister on Red Dwarf. I eat cold curry sauce for breakfast. We got pretty drunk and had a really had a nice time. I think we were there kinda late and it seemed like they got a little regular bar scene going on. The crowd seemed really interesting--a diverse, multi-racial and multi-generational crowd. Wish I lived closer so I could justify infiltrating it. 

Definitely worth the cab ride out there.
author: SheRat R.

description:
Service was good, from the hostess to the waitress to the clean-up staff.  Got there around 7:30 and we only had to wait 15 minutes.  (BTW, they don't take reservations for small groups)  Didn't mind it at all since they actually have a "porch" with rocking chairs and gas lanterns...and the weather was mild and pleasant.  Had their pomergranite based "bevie"...which was sooo good.  Like a sangria made with pomergranites.  

The fried chicken dinner looked really small at first, but after finishing the sides and the two pieces of chicken...I was stuffed.  Total bill for 2 drinks, fried chicken dinner, butternut squash soup, and green leaf salad was under $50.  Considering the ambiance and atmosphere...well worth it!  There was still a line at 9:30ish to get seated...on a Tuesday night!
author: Mark D.

description:
Unassuming, a little rickety, but that was part of the charm.  The server was excellent...so much so that I suspected he might have been responsible for this joint: owner? partner? He had all the answers, guided us through the menu and made some pretty good suggestions, and he was totally cool and unpretentious.

But the clincher?  Fried chicken and all the fixins!  It is really hard to nail that in the head....have you ever tried to make this at home?  Unless you enjoy greasy, smelly, residue hanging around for a couple days and trying to dispose of all that oil (and don't forget about the burnt stuff, 'cause you WILL burn the first few tries of chicken bits), then DO try this at home....go out to have fried chicken and have it HERE!  You can do the single serving size or heck a bucket always hits the spot when you're absolutely craving the stuff.
The only greasy residue will be on your fingers or your face, clothes, lap, if you eat like a caveman...
Oh yeah, don't forget about the corn bread (shaped like corn) and the grits, and the collard greens, and....
author: Jaena G.

description: Excellent food (the shrimp and grits with gravy was delish!) and excellent service.  A bit pricey (I think the bill was $120 for four of us) but worth it.
author: Benjamin D.

description:
Updated review:

I have to dock this place a star (well 1/2 a star if I could) from my recent experience. I came with a party of 5, which understandably is one or two people too big for this place, but the service seemed so rushed. Like I could see the thought bubble over the servers "hurry up and get out of here". 

We were wrapping up dessert and my dinnermates were still eating from their cheese plate w/cherries and toast (looked yummy btw), while out of the corner of my eye I could see the bearded server hoovering around us, then finally swooping in, pointing to the cheese plate (only half eaten) and asking "would you like me to wrap that up for you?" Um... hello?! We're still eating it for godsake. It was pretty uncomfortable for a moment, like what he really meant was, let me passive-aggressively interrupt the 3 seconds between bites and suggest wrapping up your food (without checking the plate) so your party can get out of here. 

The art of working in food service, or customer service for that matter, is knowing how to read people. Although the servers at our table were nice enough, they need to learn this skill.

Lastly, the callaloo soup, which I recommend (taro leaves with seafood), was delicious, but the ridiculously large bowl it's served in --- you know the kinds with a 4-inch rim around it -- is cumbersome and silly. It felt like my arm did a mile stretch from the middle of the bowl to my mouth. Just awkward, you know?

Fried chicken, crab grits, greens and everything else was the bomb.

----------------------------------
Original review:

You've got to get here early for dindin, but I assure you the dungeness crab grits are worth it. 

This place gets packed! The first time I attempted to eat here -- at the late hour of 7:30 no less -- diners were packed into any nook & cranny they could fit into. Having eaten at Emmy's Spaghetti Shack, when the owner/chef cooked there, made me want to get into this super cozy joint even more.

Had a wonderful meal with friends/co-workers, and the crab grits truly made my taste buds sob with joy. Hello?! They're the bomb!
author: Antoi C.

description:
Super cute.
very loud.
good service.
didn't like the drinks, tho they all sounded good.
food was nice and fresh but not as good as I expected and the portions were small.
author: carleigh r.

description:
I avoided this place for the LONGEST time.  Having been out of the South for a collective 9 years at this point, I don't want to get my heart broken whenever a restaurant claiming to serve soul food is advertised north of the Mason-Dixon and especially west of the Mississippi.  Isn't it enough I have to sweeten my own damn iced tea wherever I go?  

But a friend was in town and she wanted to try the crab and grits she heard about.  Plus earlier that day it rained so much that mass transit was shot to hell, and we didn't want to trudge to god knows where for dinner.  So it was with great trepidation I approached The Front Porch to at least try it.

With fears firmly in place, I ordered the one dish that would determine whether or not I would set foot in here ever again: Miss Ollie's Fried Chicken with black eyed peas, collard greens and mac and cheese.  The quintessential southern/soul food plate.  Because you can't get that right, then we're going to have problems.

But beforehand, we had the fried okra as an appetizer.  It was crispy, warm, pleasant.  Okay, started to relax a bit.  Thought maybe it wouldn't be so bad.  Then our main dishes arrived. The chicken looked nice, smelled good.  The peas and collards were mixed together, which is a new twist, but ok.  The mac and cheese was actually a pie.  Looked alright.  Then I bit into the chicken.

I cannot tell you how freakin' relieved I was to have such a nice blend of tender, juicy meat with the spices and flavorings of the batter used to fry it.   The rest of the meal was excellent as well.  We ended the meal with a lovely pear desert and I with a renewed sense of hope that maybe, just maybe, I can have a taste of home without actually leaving home. 

Thank you Front Porch!
author: Charlotte M.

description: This place is a great example of what's great about SF: Great food, relaxed room, professional but cool servers, excellent beverages. Perfect place to relax and enjoy some killer chicken, mac and cheese, and yes, try the fried okra. Full bar now with some fun cocktails and good wines by the glass. (Always a measure of how much the management cares about the whole package) Worth the trip to Bernal / Outer Mission.
author: Chris E.

description:
Very cool place..reminds me of an old southern roadhouse, but the exception being that the food is edible!
I had the black bean and avocado soup..very good..beware of possible aftershocks though! Ride home with the windows down.
Also had the salt cod..not my favorite but it was tasty. The corn bread to start is a nice touch and damn good. My friend had the crab porridge..a delightful, yet sinful, dish. That was damn good too. Can i get a "hell yah" on this place?? HELL YAH!!!
author: Not M.

description:
Lying sons of bitches! Nobody gets between me and fried chicken. And my friends know that, so they called to find out the optimum time to get to Front Porch on a Wednesday night, which apparently is the new Friday night. The 'helpful' hostess said get there before 7pm and there would be no problem getting a seat. 

LIES! There is no good time to get to Front Porch and not wait in line. Luckily I am easily pacified with booze cuz the stare down I was having with that table full of twatty foo foo girls, probably having a stupid ass bachelorette party and lingering around well after dinner was over, was about to turn into a weave snatching slap down.

The chicken is kick ass! A bucket served three of us, two of us being full grown guys. Black peas and greens were yum, cornbread is tasty, but I would have loved some mashed potatoes and gravy. 

Stars off because the cookies and milk dessert needs work. Lots of work. The cookies were not fat, warm chocolate chip cookies. The milk tasted like Christmas but weird, because it wasn't milk but chocolate nog. What the hell!?
author: Krismet C.

description:
If you don't like fried chicken, I'm not sure we could ever be friends.  Chef Sarah makes out of this world brussel sprouts - I have been trying for months now to copy her recipe.  My boyfriend is not a fan of brussel sprouts (this poor vegetable gets no love!) - but when he tried them here, he had to admit they were pretty good.

The best thing Chef Sarah did was leave Emmy's Spaghetti Shack because she's got mad skills in the kitchen.  

If you like southern food w/ a bit of a twist - you will love this place.  

We always are remembered by one of the bartenders when we go there - that's always welcoming.
author: Freckles D.

description:
Oh front porch, I want to love you...

But I don't.

The concept and look are great, the execution and product not so much.

NOT that its bad, its just not good.

And a 45 minute wait, me no like.
author: Ken p.

description:
We kicked off with some of the awesome corn bread and the cod fritters which were out of this world, but I have to say that I wanted to order every single starter on the menu.  This went double for the main course.

Although the fried chicken was clearly the crowd pleaser (served in a popcorn container, which was pretty cool), I decided to go with the stew of duck, wild boar and other miscellaneous yummy meats which was absolutely fantastic.  Mixed in with some bits of potato and brussel sprouts, it was a flavor explosion.    They pretty much sealed the deal with the bottle of jabanero vinegar that they dropped off as extra seasoning.  

I would go here again in a heartbeat.
author: Adam M.

description:
YeeeHaw!  What a superb place. Homey environment, great service and quality home-style cooked meals. The menu was just the right size. The prices were very affordable ($50 for two) and the atmosphere was southern enough for me and my family is from the South.

Room for Improvement: Service could have been a bit more professional.
author: ELiOT S.

description:
I really love this place.

Complaints:
1. they serve their delicious mulled wine only in the winter, even though sf obviously rebels against mainstream weather expectations

2. the fried chicken is good, and the popcorn bucket is great, but it's not thaaaaaat good. 

Noncomplaints:
1. The vegan dish is always amazing. Al. Ways.
2. The grits are v. good. 
3. The beer selection is great.
4. The service is ALWAYS WONDERFUL. 
5. They have rocking chairs.
6. mac&cheese
author: Lillie C.

description:
I showed up here with Loretta around 9pm on a Tuesday, waited an hour for a table -- no big deal because we could hang out and drink outside on rocking chairs -- and then had a great meal. Nobody brought menus to us, so Loretta got up and grabbed one from the front; not realizing the clipboard was wooden, she tossed it to me and it slammed onto the table loudly. From then on, the staff was gracious, apologetic, and swift. They even comped us our appetizer.

The app was tuna tartar served with plaintain chips. I questioned the pairing because the plaintains overwhelmed the fish, which was very fresh. I learned quickly to alternate the plaintains and the tuna rather than pile the tuna onto the chips. A good start.

Not hugely hungry, we split the special entree, which was a pork chop propped on some of the best brussels sprouts I've ever tasted, and topped with cole slaw. Comfort food, to be sure, but not the greasy kind that makes you apologize to your stomach afterward. The pork was heavily salted (and peppered) and tender. You wonder if a new restaurant is going to try a pork special and serve you a tough slab; not so here -- the chef knows her pork. Still the pork took a back seat on this plate to the brussels sprouts, which were perfectly cooked through, not mushy, and were kind of carmelized on the outside. As Loretta put it, "The best are these super fucked-up burnt leaves."

We had the yellow cake for dessert and were pleased with the chocolate frosting, which wasn't overly sweet, like maybe there was some sour cream in it.

The joint is hipster-ish but not oppressively so. Be prepared to wait but expect a solid meal served by friendly people. Also, the music they played was fun. I'd like to shake the hand of the person who followed Man Man with Christopher Cross.
author: Greg W.

description:
I think I have to go back again to give The Front Porch another shake.  The 30 minute wait outside wasn't as bad as it could have been since i got to sit in a dollhouse rocking chair while sipping on a wine-in-a-juice-box. the blah of it was that it was a typical chilly night in sf with no seats available at the bar. Note to self: show up EARLY.

Once seated the server was gleeful and pleasant.  No, really, he was such a happy fellah.  Fellow chomping buddy, Sherms, had never had chicken livers - he's a convert. :)  He had the fried chicken and I had the dungeness crab grits. We enjoyed both. The wine soaked peaches were a great finish.

Nice beer selection and fun wine list.

I'll definitely try again!
author: iGab C.

description: Had a chicken and waffles brunch. Very nice. Love the vibe here too, especially the poster of a unicorn vomiting a rainbow.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
You have never failed me!!

Your service rocks! your food rocks! your drinks rock! your ambiance rocks!

best money i keep on spending. and i love that the owner is always polite and personable with your patrons. i can tell you folks care and are humbled.
thanks for filling my tummy with amazing food: crab and grits, the pork chop, etc . etc.
author: .Strapped ..

description:
I will start with the bad - which should be mentioned....you wait a good amount of time for your food.

On to the good - its delicious - I mean I havent had fried chicken like this ever - and the only version better was my Mom's.....yumm. 

Since we waited we ordered that addictive corn bread - which is paired with the unbelievably sweet and delicious butter - you cannot stop eating it....which can be bad since you get soooo full by meals end that its not right.

The salad dressing is light and sweet and once again delicious - simple salad but great flavor.

But back to the chicken - from beginning to end its perfect, crispy where it should be and tender inside....I cannot tell you how difficult it was to share this with others....I was so pleased!!!

I dont remember the name of the dessert we had but something with ice cream, chocolate, butterscotch - some cookie thing too - I mean come on - its almost too good - cos you cant stop eating it.

And finally the service - I think they are all great - from the moment we walk in to the moment we leave totally pleasant and accomodating but not in that annoying way!

Go here now - if you dont care about calories of fat this is the mothership calling you home.
author: Deanna H.

description:
I have to give it to the restaurant for getting us seated fast without a reservation for 7 people on a weekend night. The service was okay, nothing spectalur, I would rate the service a 2, but the food was GOOD! Iike food and this was GRUB'N! 
Portions were great, so you weren't too stuffed. The decor was cute, edgy, and very mission. I would recommend it. 
Good drinks too!
author: Kim K.

description:
Ambience:  I was expecting more of a diner-y feel to the place, but I really liked what it was...more of an intimate funky bar feel.  Dark wood, tin-panel ceiling, rich colors.

Service:  All the people who waited on us, the hostess, waitress, busboy, were exceptionally nice and attentive. When a place is funky and cool, the staff can be a little snooty.  But not here. Down to earth and helpful.

My husband and I started off with a few drinks:

He:  Puppy Jasper Beer
Me:  Rose Sangria

Both excellent. Beer is amber and full bodied.  Rose Sangria is lighter than most sangrias I've tried. And I liked it that way.

Starters:

Complimentary cornbread in the shape of a corncob.
He:  Chicken Livers with grilled oninon gravy
Me:  Octopus ceviche w/sweet potato crisps
