All very good.  The chicken livers were warm and very rich, so take that into consideration if you're ordering a heavy/rich entree.  Octopus ceviche was light, spicy and tasty.  Excellent start.

Main Entree:
He:  Wild Boar Pot Stew
Me:  Fried Chicken w/macaroni and cheese and w/pinto beans

Both dishes were solid, but my husband thought the stew could have used a little heat (which he ended up adding their homemade habanero hot sauce himself), and it was more of a braised meat shank melange than a true stew. My chicken was crispy and tasty, but again, thought it could have used some heat.  The crusted macaroni and cheese was excellent. That was gone in a flash.  The pinto beans were good, but between the three large pieces of chicken and the macaroni, I thought the added side was not needed.  (What, did I actually complain about receiving too much food?)

Overall, we'd definitely go back.  Atmosphere was fun, food was solid, drinks were great, and staff was outstanding -- welcoming and efficient.

Total bill for food and three drinks (total) was $68.
author: Jeannie W.

description: This place is awesome, had the bucket of fried chicken, fried okra, hush puppies, cornbread, and gumbo.  Every piece of chicken was fried to perfection, even the white meat was juicy.  They had a nice selection of beers.  And a nice selection of desserts.  Can't wait for the next visit.
author: Andrea D.

description:
I love this place! I love this place! I love this place! Everyone here rocks! I feel like the place reminds me of a pirates gallows! Quality, Quality Quality! I would suggest the Crap with grits or the chicken with black eyed peas!  Great Stuff... and please have the yellow cake! Don't leave I promise without the Yellow Cake in your belly! It's homemade and made with luv!

Keep Rockin and I'll Keep coming!
author: Dave H.

description:
The food was pretty good, but i was disappointed that i could not get any liquor. 

 I role into this seemingly trendy place am greeted by a cute, funny, hipster waitress. When I say "seemingly trendy", I mean very trendy. I was hoping more for a greasy spoon style restaurant than a hip san francisco cookie cutter type. The light was low and the music was loud so it was comfortable but the corn bread could have been better, it was too much like cake. I may go again but dont really see why I would.
author: howard h.

description: Not sure what all the hype is about. I'm from the south and this isn't the best representation of anything I tried.
author: Alaina I.

description: Had a great midweek dinner here with a group of 6.  I had the flounder which was excellent.  Other folks at the table had the fried chicken and loved it.  Cocktails were good and reasonably priced.  Am glad to have discovered this place.
author: Daniel N.

description:
this is an amazingly cute restaurant. we were immediately seated by a friendly hostess. she was very attentive and gave a helpful explanation on the changes of the menu. 
the food was really good ( totally recommend the pork chop or the fried chicken plate. yay for juicy and tender meat! perfectly cooked!) i have been to the south several times and the food less than healthy....but still delicious. the food here is still just as  tasty but doesn't make you feel like you are sweating out lard from your pores once you've finished a plate.
author: Katie C.

description: Awesome southern food. The mac and cheese is to die for -- but only if they crisp the top!
author: Jack K.

description: When I walked into The Front Porch I thought to myself this place is quite interesting. The ambience is very unique and laid back. They gave us corn bread with a flavorful butter. They were very good and I wish they would have given us more than just one per person. I got the fried chicken with mashed potatoes and collard greens. The fried chicken was delicious. Very juicy and flavorful. The potatoes were fantastic and the collard greens were pretty good too. This place is a bit pricey especially for just fried chicken but overall I would definitely recommend trying this place out.
author: Thania M.

description: For sure one the best meals I have had in a long time. I have to agree with everyone on the fried chicken, its amazing. The servers are sweet, the sweet tea cocktail is tasty. I had the warm spinach salad, two cocktails, and fried chicken, $50 and worth every penny. When your soul needs chicken, go here.
author: Spoke K.

description:
Great fried chicken.   Good mashed potatoes.  I think we got an app that was good.

The fish was ordered by someone else at my table and he definitely did not like it.  So as several other reviewers recommend - STAY AWAY FROM THE FISH!   

Get the chicken and you will be good.
author: Jason H.

description: We come here when we have a hankering for some good solid southern style cuisine.  Very relaxed dining with attentive staff who seem to really enjoy serving up generous portions of fried chicken, okra, collard greens and the likes.  At the top of my restaurant rotation list!!!
author: franklin p.

description: I am coming back for the grits. And maybe some fried chicken.
author: Angie C.

description: Good food and ambiance and decent service. They lose 2 points because they wipe down the tables around you with a really nasty scented solution while you're eating. Not cool.
author: zoe b.

description: I love their burger, but there's always one thing wrong with whatever else we get (gumbo burnt, breading doesn't stick to the chicken, something overcooked, etc.). A shame, since it's right around the corner.  Service is often spotty as well. An example: called for take-out this evening. Whoever answered the phone asked me to hold for a second. 5 minutes went by. I hung up and called back. Busy signal, which I assume means they just left the phone off the hook. Pizza it is, then!
author: Sam B.

description: Really great Southern food (San Fran style, that is) and excellend ambiance. My friends and I ordered the fried okra (excellent), porch fries (ok, but save your fried food appetite for other things here), shrimp and grits (awesome, spicy, order it) and fried chicken with mashed potatoes/greens (don't have to tell you to order it, you probably will and won't be sorry!)
author: Kristen R.

description:
We were all anticipating to go here base on one of our co-workers recommendation. He has been here 3x and raved about it. So as a bunch of chefs we were excited. Service was fine, the ambience was nice and cozy. How ever it stopped after that.

We were a bit disappointed with the food. 2/3 of us had the fried chicken and while the seasoning was tasty the chicken was over cooked. Too dark and crispy. I had to pluck all the crust off to get to the meat. The mashers was delish and I have to say the green beans was the best dish of the night. Wonderfully saute, seasoned, and my favorite garnished with fried garlic chips. We had housemade pickles and deep fried brandade which was ok. The salt was all over the place. Some were under and some were over.

My friend ordered the gumbo and sadly to say he didnt finished it. We asked why and he said it was a bit off. I tasted it and it was WAYYYY too salty. Another person tasted it and said the same thing. The third friend, our sous chef, was like "whoa, you need to send it back." Our friend didn't want to "complain" and was adamant about not saying anything. I told him, "if you don't say anything they will continue to serve this over salted food to other patrons." So we told one of the runner who picked it up that it was too salty. She said ok and took the plate. Never asked if he wanted something else. Then afterwards he told our waitress that. She acknowledge that.

When the bill came we were shocked that they left the gumbo on! We have worked at least in half a dozen restaurants each and we know this is not how you run a business. Just shocked.

I think the food here is going in the right direction. They just need to fine tune their food and maybe taste it more often before sending it out. Service was slow but friendly. But to produce a bad dish at the restaurant's fault, serve it then charge it to a customer was a bad judgement.

We agree we will not be coming back. Too bad, it had such good reviews.
author: Kent K.

description:
I've been here twice: the first time shortly after it opened, the second time was last week. Both times were excellent...

For my last visit, we arrived there early enough on a weekday night to have nabbed a booth, and this was around 6:15pm-ish.

I had ordered the vegan dish with a side of grits,  which was quite tasty. My friend ordered the pork chops and he loved it. We also ordered the trio of fries just so that we could have it with their delicious homemade ketchup.

During the later part of our meal the place started getting crowded and  louder. There was an older couple behind us that just got seated, I wondered how they fared in the noisy environment.

Service was good and consistent, even when the place filled up.
author: Sean G.

description:
I went to the Front Porch Saturday night for a hot date. I called in advance and was told they don't take reservations for small parties, but that's it's generally easy to get a table. The wait upon arrival was around 40 minutes, which is manageable. We were able to enjoy a couple of drinks at the bar with complimentary free spicy peanuts for our wait and even score on actually sitting in some bar stools while we waited. About 20 minutes in, they offered to let us dine at the bar. I could have cared less since food is food and the bartended was quite nice (they also seemed very appreciative). The whole experience was delightful. Great dinner surrounded by great dcor and great patrons.

The bartender, despite pouring the entire restaurant's drinks, was very attentive and provided great service. She also gave us the mulled wine I had secretly been wanting to try for free with our desert (its either 'tis the season or she was a mind reader...your call). The pickled veggies (okra and carrots oh my!) to start were amazing. I also tried my first pickled egg and though I was extremely skeptical, it was pretty darn tasty. I went with the glazed pork tenderloin which ordered medium rare turned out to be a tad overdone. My partner went with the fried chicken with mac and cheese, and though terribly awful for my heart, it ranks up as one of the better things I have had the pleasure to taste in quite some time. 

Extra, extra stars for the amazing staff!
author: Alicia J.

description: Hello Southern Charm and Hospitality..It was an awesome meal and at the bar no less...Okay we walked in on the busy Holiday weekend and a lovely lady said we could take the 2 seats that had just vacated at the bar or wait 30 minutes we took them and proceeded to eat drink and be merry with a delicious repetoire of food..The fried green tomatoes the best I have had in a long time the Fried Chicken and home made biscuits delish and my gumbo was so smokey and good made me want more.  Be back for the Bucket o Chicken next visit.
author: Anastacia L.

description:
After trying the mediocre Hard Knox Cafe, I had just about given up on SF soul food. I had accepted the fact that I was never going to experience a delicious bucket of fried chicken in SF. I had started to believe that the only way I'd be able to find good fried chicken in the Bay Area is to either: (1) skip work on a Monday and make a journey to Thomas Keller's Ad Hoc for its famous fried chicken, or (2) put my life on the line and sneak into the warzone ghetto of Oakland (where I would assume there would be good soul food). But a trip to Napa is too much of a celebratory event and I also don't want to be the next murder victim on the Oakland evening news, so I wish there were some good soul food in SF.

Hallelujah for The Front Porch.

In my opinion, the Front Porch has the best soul food I've ever tasted. And although against the will of my arteries, I've definitely had my share of soul food. I loved every aspect of the restaurant from the hometown feel and the cheerful waitresses to the vast drink selection and PHENOMENAL food.

Went with a group of 3 and we got seated immediately around 6:30pm on Thursday. Once it gets to around 7-7:30pm though, the place gets packed, so definitely try to make reservations if you can. 

We ordered the bucket of fried chicken w/ mashed potatoes & green beans, the chicken fried steak on top of mashed potatoes & sweet corn, the fried chicken liver on a cheese biscuit with habanero jelly, side of the baked mac and cheese, and the red velvet cake for dessert. The fried chicken was probably one of the best, if not the best, I've ever had -- perfectly crispy on the outside and moist as hell on the inside. 9 pieces of chicken will set you back $33, but lemme tell you, every bite was worth it. Douse that sucker with tons of their Louisiana Crystal hot sauce and you're good to go. The chicken fried steak was also great -- crazy heavy, but the mixture of the steak and the mashed potatoes was awesome. I usually don't like chicken liver, but their fried chicken liver was really good. The baked mac & cheese was insanely good. And the red velvet cake was a great way to end a "I'm probably going to have a heart attack after this" dinner.

Now, just FYI, this may be soul food, but it's soul food for those who have wealthy souls. If you're used to a bucket of chicken being $10 for a family meal, this isn't the place for you. It's nowhere near as cheap as Hard Knox Cafe or most soul food joints for that matter, but for the top-quality food and service, The Front Porch is worth every penny. For the 3 of us, we spent $120 after tip for a ton of food and drinks all around. Not TOO bad.

Definitely one of my absolute favorite restaurants in SF.

I wish I was black just so I could say: "Ah, this fried chicken is just like how Big Mama used to make it." Maybe in another life.
author: Roy C.

description:
3 stars or 4?  The service was great- 4 stars.  I loved the fact that we made a reservation and they honored it.  We walked right in and got seated at this C-shaped corner booth, which was uncomfortable because the 6 of us couldn't converse in a group over the din and distance of the table.   The server didn't get pissy about repeating the specials (I must have asked at least two times since one person arrived late), we got our drinks. refills, etc. at a decent pace.   

Honestly, don't we all dine out for the food, though?  I know this place is wicked hip but I was underwhelmed by the dishes (with the exception of the delicious fried chicken).  I found the appetizers to be smallish, the crab porridge uncomfortably spicy and the crab tasted pickled.  I ordered the seafood special (shrimp and grits finished with a chive or garlic oil) which was just like the crab porridge, minus the crab.   Didn't have dessert (yay, Mitchell's!) so I can't form an opinion.   I wasn't impressed or too terribly disappointed so I'd give the food portion of this review 3 stars.
author: Laura P.

description:
I love front porch. I just finished eating my leftovers for lunch and was moved to write a review. I think Front Porch beats out all other southern style places in the city that I've been so far. I thought it was way better than Blue Jay, and also better than Farmer Brown. 

It has a homey atmosphere, and the food is rich and comforting. I also felt like they used fresh, quality ingredients. 

For Apps:

The Plantain cakes were fabulous. The mango salad was also good. Two of my friends tried the pickled plate--some things were good, others not. 

Entrees:

The Crab porridge was the best...it was amazing. It enough for two and goes really well with a side of collard greens which, by the way, were cooked just right, rather than to death like most places.

The Burger came in second...one of the best burgers in town

The fired chicken also looked really good. 

They also have a vegan and a fish special every day, both of which sounded great, but no one at my table ordered them. 

The don't take reservations unless you are with a party of five or more. It was very reasonably priced--I was with six people, we ordered 3 starters, 6 entrees, 1 dessert, and 3 jugs of wine--it came out to $30 each including 20% tip.
author: Amanda D.

description: Reasonably priced and really good. Burgers are always excellent and I even liked their fried pickles.  A really good neighborhood place to go eat. Tends to be busy so you wait an hour or so without a reservation on a weekend. Just head across street and get a drink and wait. Never had a meal that I didn't like here.
author: Ben L.

description: Great place that offers quality southern comfort food. Steak was superb! I loved the mac and cheese. Not much to rave about the complimentary corn bread. Maybe I'm weak but the jumbo was too spicy for me...it was great but I couldn't hang after a few mouthfuls. I wish I had ordered the fried chicken because it's served in a bucket (reminds me of KFC). What a great presentation gimmick! Will definitely need to try that next time. Be careful that this place gets packed for dinner. So be sure to make reservations!
author: Wendy L.

description: The service here is awful. In short, our server was beyond rude. If you are in this area, try Emma's or the Mexican place around the corner.
author: Aaron R.

description:
I came in early on a Sunday night just before 7 and walked in and got a small table fast, the place was about 70% full. Within 15 minutes the crowd was waiting outside in the rain to get in.

The service was a little slow, but it was my first time there and i needed the extra time. Some very decent beers on tap and the wine list looked good although I was drinking beer and did not make a deep study of it.

FRIED CHICKEN  is maybe my favorite meal and there isn't much in this city. So when I hear the chicken is good, I need to try it. So the chicken - 3 pieces - was very good, not greasy so cooked hot and the resulting bird was cooked inside but not dry; and the skin is crispy - not oily. If you like greasy, nasty chicken you might think this dry, but its just  the way it should be. Its good bird, as good as I have had in the west ... the rest of the meal was interesting, the greens for a side and fried potatos (yams, regular and sweet I think) were really good and flavorful.

The service after the initial wait was good and friendly. The place was just getting crowded so service might slow down a bit as the dinner crush is in full force. but I'd give a good mark for sure, better than most outside the high end.

So on the closing topic, value... the food was very good, I originally thought $25 for 3 pieces of chicken, some greens, fries and a beer was a little higher than I was thinking it should be. It not outrageous at all since you'd pay $10 for the "same" at KFC or Churches. So its a good value in my mind, and its a cool place with friendly people and of course, good fried chicken. 

Its worth a trip, especially if you like chicken deep fried, go early on the weekends or don't be in a hurry.
author: JX C.

description:
amazingly cozy, great food, delicious drinks. it just makes for warm fuzzies. Much like the rite spot in vibe but with delicious food and less focus on the drinking (although the bar is really quite beautiful). The service was super friendly but they did forget a dish and a drink- I really couldn't care less. This isn't the type of place you come for a 30 minute meal. The wait alone is at least 30 minutes. 

The crab grits were superstar good. I had a cocktail with underberg- it comes in teensy german glass bottles that look like post-war antibiotics. Also had a lovely champagne cocktail with a sugar cube soaked in bitters. mmmmm.

oh yes and ch ch ch cheap. great value for the money.
author: Sita B.

description:
I like free food. 

Apparently the folks I went with the night in question were regulars as the various restaurant staff came by repeatedly offering us complimentary plates of this and that each more delicious than the next. Upon asking my dining companions they conceded they had been there a few times but were far from regulars. Thus my conclusion, show your face a couple times, be polite and engaging, enjoy free plantain cakes. 

Food was fantastic. The fried chicken in particular was enough to give Farmerbrown a run for their money, which I thought would be impossible. Sweet and spicy nuts (insert joke here and my dining companions most assuredly did) and grit porridge made great appetizers. 

I'd go again.
author: Geoff W.

description:
The atmosphere was cool.  People were pretty friendly. The food was just good but not what I expected from the reviews.  I expected it to be better but maybe my expectations are too high cause I did live in New Orleans for a few years.  

We started out with the fries which were really yummy.  The fried chicken was tasty....juicy & crispy.  The ribs were good....the piece I had was a little fatty.  The black eyed peas & collard greens were just ok.  My favorite had to be the crab and grits...they were really rich which I like.  They have a kick ass mango mojito...I give that a 2 thumbs up.
author: Natacha M.

description:
This place was cool. It's a very chill, relaxed, funny environment. Our waiter was really chill, helpful, and funny. They have free stickers there that say things like "fucket get a bucket" and "I heart jugs." Just sitting in the front porch rocking back and forth on a rocking chair was great, great way to unwind. Onto the food.

They give you each a long, finger like shaped piece of cornbread with special butter spread. It was so good we ordered more with dinner - 50 cents extra each but it was good! Then we had the starter portion of spicey crab grits which were also good. I wanted to eat the whole thing. The heirloom tomatoes were also a hit with the table. So simply prepared yet packed with flavor and good for you!

Already feeling kinda full, but had to toughen up for the main courses. I got the fried chicken, came with 3 pieces and some mashed potatoes. They have this crazy orange colored hot ass homemade sauce in a glass maple syrup bottle which was hella hot but good. My friend got the mahi mahi which was good, light, but I went there for the chicken. My other friend got the jerk chicken which was spicy and looked complicated hidden under layers and layers of spicy goodness. I liked the simplicity of the fried chicken better.

Too full for dessert but if I got one, I would have gotten the lemon pound cake with pinenut icing or something. That sounded unique, different, and very good. 

With a few drinks included, the bill for 4 came out to about $140. Seemed a little steep but I don't go daily so it was ok to splurge. Now back to the gym to work off the grits and fried chicken . . .
author: Vivian L.

description:
If I could give 4.5 stars, I would. The service is great, and I love the atmosphere. Laid back yet still semi-classy.

This place reminds me a little of St. Louis tucked away in SF. How can it get any better than mini corn bread rolls served in the shape of corn? There's definitely a southern flare to the menu.

My favorite entree is the crab and corn grits. Super creamy, super delicious. The touch of lemon really puts this dish over the top. I also recommend the "vegan stew" when it's not actually a stew. Two nights ago, it was stuffed peppers with risotto and plantains with a side house salad. Just ask for the specials.

Minus one star (or .5?) because of the wine list. We've had better luck with the whites than the reds.

The cheese plate features a nice blue, but could use a bit more honey. Also, the raisin toast is delicious but a bit crunchy.
author: Monica C.

description:
This place is awesome!  I called to get reservations and whie they only do them for 5+ people - the guy I talked to told me that our best bet was to walk in the door before 7:15. We walked in at 7:10 and sat right down.

Service - awesome!  nice balance for friendly and attentive. Our waitress handled us well and food moved along nicly.  Good pacing.

Drinks - we each had 2 rounds of dirnks.  They don't have a full liquor license  but the "soft stuff" based drinks were totally tasty, creative and inexpensive.

Apps - We had 3: Pumpkin/Chickpea Doubles, Duck Confit and the Frisee.  ALL of them were amazing, The salad was well dressed with perfectly done fried oysters, the doubles were tasty and the cuke salad on the side spicy but refreshing.

Crab and Grits were freakin' AWESOME!  so good that I though one of us was going to start licking the dish - seriously.

We got the bocket o' chicken - amazing!  not greasy, flavorful, moist!  The side were only OK (rice and beans)  but maybe they just paled in comparision to the chicken, you know.

Desserts!  The chocolate Bread Pudding was so tasty. great blance of crusty and pudding-y, nice chunks of chocoloate and great ducle de leche whipped cream.  My Rice pudding was the BEST  rice pudding I've ever had.  It wasn't just milky mush - the rice was cooked but had a nice bit to it and the warm berry compote-y like thing on top was great!

2 thing to be aware of:  lighting is low-ish and it can get loud.  This is not a place for older folks with eyesight or hearing issues.
author: Tracy Y.

description:
The Front Porch typifies good, casual, home-style dining. It seems like a true local's restaurant where you can walk in on a weeknight wearing whatever (I myself arrived in gym shorts and running shoes) and be treated to a hearty meal of some of the better soul food in the Bay Area. The Porch goes lighter on chicness and decor and heavier on the stick-to-your-ribs grub than, say, Farmer Brown. I put it this way: Farmer Brown is known for its artisan cocktails, the Porch for its finely curated beer list. That I think says something about the differences between them. 

Anyway, here's what can't be missed: the fried chicken, which has an exceptional dark crust (cornmeal?) and moist, tender white meat (pairs well with the house-made hot sauce). The coconut red beans, which mix a memory of Caribbean and Indian cooking into an otherwise Southern-style dish. The bread pudding is, no exaggeration, the best I've ever had. Terrific corn bread. The grits with crab is thick and creamy like a good chowder. 

What I'd do differently: No side dishes of collard greens? Come on! Also, the rice pudding was pretty poor: lacked the consistency of a true pudding, tasted more like rice floating in warm milk. 

But all in all, since we shared dishes and relied on the sides as much as the entrees, it was $20-$25 per person including tip! A great deal and a great restaurant.
author: Andrew K.

description: Hip, laid-back ambiance. Chill servers and wait staff. Amazing fried chicken and garlic mashers. OK green beans.
author: Sally M.

description: we came here after a night of romping through the castro looking at lady-boys the weekend before halloween.  i opted for the country fried steak which was an actual piece of steak and not ground beef.  but upon eating it, i was a bit disappointed as it was dry.  we also ordered the fried okra and bloody mary which we thought were delicious!  we'll be back to try their dinner menu next.  hopefully i can upgrade my rating :)
author: Vic S.

description:
I LOVE this place. 

Ambiance: colorful, vintage, homey, quirky.. Love the grandma curtains near the bathroom and old car seat benches; very kitchy. Always crouded, always bustling, but fun. There was a mariachi last time we were there, he was great! 

Drink: Unusual and great selection of beer. Had an awesome blonde. 

Food: first time I went I had a seafood risotto. Second time had to get the fried chicken. Both were delish, but the chicken is to die for. My mom even loved it, and she's a harsh critic of fried chicken. Comes with mash and collard greens. 

There is usually a wait, but you can go to the bar on the corner and they'll call down when your table is ready. 

Great place. 5 stars!
author: Brady W.

description: Good food, great service, and one the best desserts I've had in a long time! Started with Sangria and the cornbread, yum! Then the mac and chz side order delish! Then the fried chix plate with mash potatoes with gravy and collard greens. Very good! Then the finale warm Pumpkin bread pudding, toped with Mitchelle's ice cream and a caramel swirl. Heavenly! Very fun place, with satisfying, good food, and many friendly faces. The server was great and had much knowledge of the menu and very friendly. I shall return with more friends =)
author: Ladyreyes R.

description: Everything was delicious - from the cornbread to the burgers to the fried chicken.  Great cocktails - and sat on the front proch of Front Porch - staff was also fantastic!
author: Kate H.

description:
BEST VALENTINE'S DAY EVER!!!!
I was more than excited to get to eat here for this special day with my special someone. I had called only a few days before and got the last  reservation for the two of us!! Totally stoked.
The service was amazing and the food outstanding!!!
I ordered the special, the biggest most delicious porkchop of my life accompanied by some sweet potatoes and corn. I cleaned my plate!!
If you not sure about eating here trust me you will love it!!!
author: Amy S.

description:
Pros: the dim lighting, southern decor, and relaxed atmosphere are lovely.  Our main waitress was sassy and hilarious.  The fried green tomatoes and okra were excellent.

Cons: overpriced for what it is, and seemed understaffed -- the waitstaff messed up my drink order twice and the drink I didn't order and sent back still appeared on the bill.  The mac & cheese was good, but not as fabulous as the hype suggests.

Sidenote: Yelp my darling, this restaurant is in the Mission, not Bernal Heights.  See http://maps.google.com/maps/ms?gl=us&ie=UTF8&oe=UTF8&msa=0&msid=101736359319930165363.00045c2a66d756ac5e226
author: Sarah B.

description:
A unique place which means you should try it. Good restaurant to have a casual, hanging out spinning the yarn, meal with friends. Laid back atmosphere, cool friendly staff, good (fatty) food and of course the front porch which is kitchy and comfortable. This combined with El Rio makes for a fantastic time on a warm Sunday afternoon. Just remember the rest of the world probably has the same idea.

Tasty, quirky menu with some pretty interesting drink concoctions. I had the fresh crab and grits which was delicious. It had a bit too much butter but that is just the Californian in me coming out. Someone from the South wouldn't have batted an eye about it.
author: James H.

description:
This place is soon to be a regular for us. The atmosphere was hip, but not overly self-possessed. The service very friendly, but not in your face. We ordered pickled veggies to start, and were not disappointed in the least. They gave us complimentary corn bread with a chili butter, and some soups to taste. Very fun. 

We also ordered their ginger beer, which was wonderfully gingery without a lot of sweetness (an Australian brand I haven't heard of before). It went well with our fried fishes. (Monday is fish 'n chips. Yay!) We had mustard greens as well, which were a tasty side. Oh, and we also had a seared fish on top of coconut rice and beans. Very tasty and very, very filling. So much so that we didn't get dessert. Very good for all the wonderful stuff we got. We're definitely returning, but going with a couple sides and one entree so we can get some dessert too.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
I've heard mixed things from folks I trust, but I had to try it myself. Thank goodness because I had an excellent meal.

Fried chicken was great. Deep fried chicken livers were killer. Mac & Cheese was great. Roasted root veggies with goat cheese had a really great goat cheese but half of the veggies were too dry. I wouldn't order the cod fritters again. Free cornbread with spicy butter was excellent.

Overall, a great experience. Host was friendly, Waitress was great. 

Beware of the hot sauce - it is super hot but with great flavors. Next time I go, I'm going to bring some Smoky Joe's ketchup with me because it would be amazing with this food.
author: Marina N.

description:
C.h.a.r.a.c.t.e.r. This place has it. 

Didn't expect the decor at all.
First impression: Charming, swanky, dark and funky...love the ceilings 

Was prepared to be grossed out by whatever hole in the wall fried chicken place I was headed to. I'm picky and easily disgusted, so I was resigned to just get some corn. I often just get some corn...

Then I met the Front Porch.

Downsides: 
-The wait sucked, and I think they forgot us
-The waitress totally forgot we were her table
-They don't take reservations, unless there are more than 5 of you


The reason all of this would ever be OK: 

Upsides:
-THE FOOD was awesome, kind of comfort food heaven with a Caribbean twist
-Fried Chicken was great- VERY crunchy and tasty. CRISPY!!
(comes in a bucket!!)
-Mac n' cheese was yummy, and it's hard to please me with this one 
-Jasper Poppy beer from Morgan Hill, try it
-No airs- no highbrow behavior.
-Hostess meant well, and worked to fix the forgetfulness
-We were totally taken care of by the family of workers, so lack of our own waitress wasn't v. painful
-Front porch area is a great wait spot- gives you a chance to eye what I believe to be the brothel across the street!
author: Rhubarb M.

description:
If you're looking for a place where you can chill out with some good friends and truly ENJOY a meal, then look no further than the Front Porch.  The waitstaff is friendly, and laid-back, but helpful, the atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming, and of course- the food is fantastic.

This is one of my new favorite places to eat in the city: from the welcoming 'front porch' in front of the restaurant to a menu that delivers a new level of comfort food...put it this way- if you don't really vibe on this type of dining experience, I probably don't want to know you anyway.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
nice atmosphere, nice people ,decent food and very over priced!
Three of us went there for dinner, spent $110.00( not including tips) and was slill hungry. Portions are very small so if your're gonna share make sure you order extra.

p.s. if you order the Island stew make sure you like all the meat cause it comes out pitch black so you don't know what your're eating.
author: thuy m.

description:
Classy joint. Impressed with the free cornbread and baby rocking chair that keeps you occupied for the good halfn hour you have to wait for a table.  Gotta admit i wish i knew they were going to limit me to beer and wine so i couldve packed accordingly.  I really did feel like a southern gentleman as i gallantly pulled out my own chair and began dining. The food was a blast from a southern kitchens past and left me pondering why no one has yet to capitalize on this genre of food in a fast food arena?! it only makes sense to get the same feeling of the dirty south without being hit with the buzz kill of 40 even 60 dollar bill for solo diner! 
what kinda of shmuck am i to not have seen this sooner!
author: Kyle B.

description:
I had high expectations for this place given the reviews and what some of our friends have been saying. All the food was good, but not great. There were three of us and here's what we ordered-

Bucket of fried chicken with coleslaw and mac n cheese
Grits with Crab
Beet salad
A profiterole dessert (can't remember the name)

The fried chicken being served in a bucket of popcorn was original so they get points for presentation. The chicken meat was tender, but the batter was almost fried too deeply.  Both the slaw and mac were disappointing as sides. The cabbage in the slaw was minced so finely it was mushy and the mac was pretty dry. The crab and grits and beet salad were good, but not really that memorable. Overall, the place has a cool atmosphere and we got there around 6pm on a weeknight so there wasn't much of a wait.
author: A and K W.

description:
I had some finger licking good chicken here! 
Best so far for me in the city.
author: Shawn P.

description:
How do they do it? Crispy fried chicken and so freakin moist in the inside? I am no cook by any means,  so I started to speculate if they inject every piece of chicken with chicken broth? Like basting a turkey but way more effective. No? Well, what do I know. 

1 star for the chicken 
1 star for the VERY cool staff
1 star for the crazy hot sauce
1 star for the shiny silver ceiling
-1 star for the Mac- N- Cheese. Not enough cheese.
author: Cin H.

description:
Pork chops, okra, grits
All of it heavy goodness
Even vegan stew
author: Mel H.

description:
See, I am a soul food eater at heart. Give me grits and corn bread and I am as happy as a pig in a poke. 

Bonus points for the rum cocktails. People here just do not drink enough rum. 

The crab and grits were creamy and rich. The pork chop was big enough to take home and it made a tasty leftover. The corn bread was sublime. The dessert--the beignet (get the side of ice cream) was a great end to a delicious meal.
author: Akasha A.

description:
They don't take reservations.  So we waited for at least 2 hours on Friday night for a table, and finally got a seats at the bar.  We put our names down around 8:30pm,  and I think the three of us were the only Asians in the restaurant for the entire time that we were waiting to eat and when we were finally eating.  But that's irrelevant.

I'd say the fried chicken they serve was worth the wait.  Not sure I'd choose it over the fried chicken at Foreign Cinema for my last meal on Earth, but I'd venture out to Front Porch and wait an hour for it again.

Also, the crab grits were heavenly.  Everything else we ordered was good as well.  Better than I expected.  (I didn't know what to expect since I hadn't read any reviews or heard about the restaurant prior to going.)  

Oh, and we were given a free appetizer for having waited so long to get our seats at the bar.  :)
author: Jennie Y.

description:
Brussel sprouts as a starter - excellent!
I had the shrimp with grits.  It was good but the other dishes Pork Chops and Chicken was so good, I will have to order that next time.  For dessert, bread pudding - very good.  
The waitress and service was excellent.  I only gave it 4 stars because my dish wasn't as amazing as I wanted it to be.
author: Grace L.

description: Fried chicken was great as expected.  Mac n Cheese is also a must as well as the cornbread.  Small place so be sure to make a reservation on fri/sat night, unless you want to wait.
author: Michael R.

description:
Went here for a buddies birthday dinner last night. I love southern food and am thankful to have tried this place so I can go back. All in all this place is a 3 on yelp but more like a 2.5 for what I used to for southern grubbin. Cool area of town too bars right up the street, its practically in the mission. We had a few different things.

The Fried Green Tomatoes were solid, and would order again. The Blue Crab fritters were too doughy for me being a maryland man. The Catfish wasn't at all what expected and prefer good ole fried catfish myself. The roux on the creole was 100% burned, our server told us that dark roux's can taste that way but I'm no moron that shit was burnt. I've been eating southern food in the south for over a decade and it was certainly burnt. The chicken was nice and moist inside with crispy skin but the meat just a little salty. Probably a salt heavy brine would be my guess. The collards were good and not pork fatty at all which was a pleasant surprise. I liked the mac and cheese others at the table didn't. Sweet potato fries and mashed potatoes were both good. My one friend had the burger and said it was "fire," it looked awesome A couple others had the steak and said it was "aight," meaning to me it was probably not all that good. 

I'd be more inclined to return for lunch instead of dinner and check those dishes out and still be able to get the things I liked. I would also still like to try the grilled fish of the day cause i think the preparation on it sounds delicious and the pork chop, I have a feeling its brined too ;)
author: Michael B.

description: I'll keep it short... great fried chicken, sides, and mac'n'cheese.
author: David S.

description:
Was trying to go up to SF to do some Beer Week festivities and unfortunately was not able to get everyone together to do a whole day's trip up. So we drove up after Super Bowl last night. 

A friend had tried this place out prior to us visiting last night and mentioned how good the fried chicken was. So we decided this would be the place to hang out for a little while.

We arrived at the restaurant around 8:30 - 9 pm-ish and got seated. Right off the bat, I noticed how attentive and friendly the waitress was. She dropped off the drink menu and kindly mentioned that if we wanted to order food, we'd have to do it quickly as the kitchen was closing in 3 minutes. My little group was a bit hesitant to get food so late but I  convinced them to order a bucket of chicken. Seeing as we're hardly in the city, I wanted to try or lord knows when I'll get another chance anytime soon.

We flagged down our waitress and she came by and took our drink order. I liked how she tried to recommend what she thought was good. We mentioned we wanted to order food and she looked at the clock and said that the kitchen closed a minute ago, but she'll get our order in. Most other places, we would have been shut out. 

We got our beer order and I want to comment on one beer in particular that was served for Beer Week... Firestone bourbon barrel-aged Velvet Merkin oatmeal stout. The stout was amazingly yummy. It had a very pleasant taste (reminiscent of coffee) and unlike most stout, was not as hearty or thick. But I liked it none the less. Tasty! A bit disappointed the Triple Daddy was not available.. Oh well.

They brought out our place settings, water, and two hot sauces. The waitress quickly pointed out the yellow one and said "be careful, that one is habanero.. use sparingly". Well three of the five of us perked up. Interest was piqued. I quickly shook up the bottle and pour a smidge onto my plate for tasty... Oh yum! Nice spicy, vinegar-y, garlicky flavor. Most definitely pouring some of this on the chicken. The other hot sauce was ok.. nothing special. Habanero FTW!

Next came out some cornbread with chili butter. Nice kick. Cornbread was a little dry.. but had a nice flavor. Then came the star of the show, a bucket of fried chicken! Loved the presentation. Came in a popcorn bucket that had the chicken AND popcorn. Oh yah! I love popcorn. My friend mentioned that the popcorn was amazing AFTER eating the chicken.. let the grease (I did say it was fried.. what did you expect?) soak into the popcorn. I quickly dug in and grabbed a leg and poured (carefully) the habanero hot sauce onto my plate. I took a bite of chicken to get the flavor before dipping into the hot sauce. I wanted to taste it in it's original form. Oh My Goodness. Juicy and flavorful. Everything fried chicken should be. Tasted just as great with the hot sauce. The real test was the white meat, and it blew my taste buds when it was just as juicy and tender as the dark meat. I was hooked. What turned out to be "oh we can't eat the whole bucket.. blah blah blah" ended up being a empty bucket of nothingness (oh, the popcorn afterwards was super tasty.. and dipped in the habanero hot sauce, even tastier). Because it was in our bellies! I can't comment on the sides since there was no room for that. I was too focused on chicken. My friend did say he loves the collard greens though. Should be good.

We also shared the bread pudding. That was good, too. So good that there was none left (again, most of my group did not want any.. but wasn't hard to convince once it arrived at our table).

So, my take on this place? Awesome chicken, great service, and relaxed decor and setting... what's there more to say?

Verdict: Super Winnar!
author: Shauna Y.

description: Very fun, dark and yummy place.  Unique atmosphere all around, and definitely worth a try.  We'll be back!  Especially on a warm evening when we can actually sit out front in the rockers.
author: Julia B.

description: Love the fried chicken and they have Fried Okra! You get to eat in a cool atmosphere.
author: Alan M.

description: Fried Chicken, Spicy shrimp grits, fried oyster spinach salad with corn bread. All good! Yummy! Thanks Frank V.
author: Manuel M.

description:
5 stars for the Dungeness crab grits and goooooo female chefs!  The culinary world is still so white male dominated, it's refreshing to see great examples to the contrary.  It will be nice when we get to the day when this isn't exciting because it will be the norm.  

Seriously, the grits were the best I've had, so flavorful and deeeeelicious without being too salty and the crab was fresh.  I could it eat it every day.  Plus the owners are super nice.

Bernal Heights?  I consider this south south Mission.  Parking was kinda tough in this area but just bring your good parking karma.
author: Chris P.

description:
Great stuff!  I totally dig the dungeness crab grits.  Went there on a Sunday night with five picky southern boys and they bestowed their seal of approval. They said they loved the fried chicken.

Would have given it five stars, but the place needs a full bar.  Make my mint julip dream a reality baby!
author: SaraMitra P.

description:
This place is very cute,  with great atmosphere and the friendliest waiter.
He was great.
The fried chicken was pretty good. 
Still not as juicy and tender as Whole Foods' (my favorite chicken in the city) but good.

Brussel sprouts were excellent.
They're as good as Emmy's sprouts but different.
author: Trixie R.

description:
The chicken is the bomb! But unfortunately that's it. The colesaw was boring and the salads are ok. We also had the ceviche. . .eh I'll pass next time. Good assortment of beers. The atmosphere is really cool. I like the vibe, very loud but sometimes I like that. 

Make sure you where layers. When i was there, I almost stripped down to my scivies cause the ventilation in there was bad. 

But its a good place. I'd go back again.
author: Cat B.

description:
Brussel sprouts + molasses + red chilies = my new favorite candy.  Brussel sprouts?  Seriously?  Yup.  Trust me.  

And the red velvet cake is not to be sneezed at, either.
author: Sheila W.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised at my meal here on a Friday night.

First we only waited 30 minutes for a table and the last 2 bar seats opened right away.  Second we were delighted by our fired okra and plantain cakes with smoked salmon.  And by the brioche chocolate sandwhich with sweet cream and berries for desert.

My pork chop was done just right.  The grits were good (not great) and the staff was friendly and easy on the eyes.

It was delightful!
author: Kim N.

description:
This review does not cover the normal menu at Front Porch, but rather the crazy memorial-day BBQ and birthday party thrown for a waitress that we happened to walk in on.  It was awesome.  I don't know if there is that level of camaraderie on non-BBQ days but we all had a blast.

One of these stars really belongs to Tartine, because one of the customers brought a lemon-meringue cake for everyone to share AND IT WAS DELICIOUS.
author: Anony M.

description:
The food was very good. The surf and turf was a little expensive and was delivered short one of the promised 2 massive prawns. Steak was perfect.

Service on the other hand needs work. 40 minutes waiting for a table turned into 1 hour 10 min when the hostess gave away our table while we  were waiting. 

Since they are new and the food is good, I will give them another chance.
author: k g.

description:
This place is in the genre of 'The Mission' chic - reminiscent of the Blue Plate. The decor feels kinda like I am eating in the living room in a house of young artists. It just has that gritty-artistic feel that the entire neighborhood seems to invoke. That is part of the allure.

The menu is original in that it is has traditional soul-food type dishes. Normally these types of dishes would not cost as much as they do at Front Porch, but I noticed care and attention in preparation as well as fresh ingredients. So call this upscale soul-food I guess?

The specialty of the house is for sure the Fried Chicken. I don't eat friend chicken on a regular basis - in fact, rarely. However, this is the place to order it. I've seen traditional Fried Chicken recipes and it is a complex dish to make - it's not done KFC style where you dump the chicken into a deep fryer and wait 5 mins. The dish is good to order as something for the whole table though, it could be much for one persona (especially since it comes with 2 sides). For sides - the mac/cheese is outstanding. There's been a renaissance for mac & cheese lately, and Front Porch's version ranks up there w/ the best of 'em.

For my meal I ordered the crab & grits. I was not thoroughly impressed, wish I ordered something else. My dining partner's however seemed to have great meals. Crab & Grits is just a tad too rich, and a tad too short on the crab.

Overall a great dining experience with great traditional soul-food done fancy. Order a cask ale from speakeasy if one is available. Cost? $40/person with drinks & tip.
author: Craig G.

description:
This is a quaint little joint.  Overall the meal was good.  Would i come back?  Definitely cuz there were other items on the menu that I wanted to try!  Here's the breakdown....

Best part of the meal:  The bread shaped as corn and the skin of the fried chicken.  YUM.
Cocktails:  They were just ok... slightly disappointed cuz they were creative cocktails!
Wine:  Malbec:  For a $28, it was pretty good wine... kinda smokey...
Infamous Chicken Bucket:  Others loved it.  But if you're a simpleton like me who is easily pleased by Popeyes, you may want to skip the $30 chicken bucket.
Grits:  If you like grits, you'll love this.  It was creamy, buttery and heavy.  Yum.  but only for a spoonful or two...

another plus?  it's down the street from mitchells, so you can scurry on over for ice cream dessert!
author: Nutmeg Y.

description:
In the immortal words of Aretha Franklin (in Blues Brothers): "Best damned chicken in the state."

Oh and is it.

We first came a year ago with a large group.  I walked away thinking it was the best fried chicken I'd ever had.  For a year I tried to find anything better...no luck.  I went back last night fearful that the memory of the chicken was better than the actual chicken.  What if I tried it and it was only so-so?  Nonetheless, I sat with my friends and mandated that we would order two buckets of fried chicken.  They could order around that.

Fried Plantains - good and fairly standard.
Spicy Crab and Grits - very good...and I'm not a huge fan of grits.

And then the chicken - So juicy.  So crispy.  So wonderful.  Even the red beans and dirty rice sides were amazing.  

My memory did not fail me.  Neither did The Front Porch.  I will be back...
author: Todd S.

description: Greens, fish of the day, and jug of wine please.  Great staff and food.  I leave wishing I could eat like this every night.
author: Aileen B.

description:
If you like small dark,cramped and loud places then this is a great place for you, if not then don't waste your time or money on this place.So this my story on why i'am giving this place 1 star, i would give it 0 stars but that isn't an option. 

So my fiance and i found this place on yelp and seen that it had 4 stars and pretty good reviews and decided to try it. The first thing we noticed when walking in is the curtains that you have to walk through right behind the front door. Then the place looked like an old, dark as hell run down ghetto bar. I was surprised to see that allot of people were sitting down eating, and the more nicer tables where reserved. Speaking of the tables, if you like cramped listening to someone else's full on convo. while bumping elbows and there butts brushing up against your table when they walk by, then this is totally the place for you. Next was the  hard to read menus, i mean its already dark as is,but the menus being typed up by the worlds first typewriter wasn't doing it any justice at all, and being only one page made the experience even more gloomy. Lets talk about the service, before getting to our seat we waited at the door for almost five minutes before someone would seat us, on our pre-reserved table. Then the waiter brings us a 40 ounce bottle of there own bottled water that said on it "Fucket buy a bucket", how tacky is that! The drinks since we drove there we wanted to have a soda and they only had 3 types, coke, diet coke, and sprite. Dude wtf? The food, we had fried okra with the jalapeno sauce which was good, but the trouble came when we got our main dish. I had the 4-piece fried chicken with garlic mashed potatoes and collard greens with bacon for 18 dollars. He had spicy shrimp and grits bowl for 22 dollars. For such a high price we thought the food would be really good, but we were VERY WRONG! So the fried chicken was good it has nice seasoning and very well cooked, the collard greens tasted like CRAP,they were way over cooked, very greasy, and lacked flavor. My potatoes where good only up to the point where i FOUND A LARGE PIECE OF PAPER IN MY MOUTH, i showed the waiter the piece of paper sitting on my plate, and he at first reached towards my plate, about to pick the paper off with his bare hands. I had picked it up and gave it to him, only to hear him and the cooks saying, " O WOW THERE WAS A PIECE OF PAPER IN THE MASHED POTATOES", and the waiter returning asking me if i WANTED SOME MORE FREAKING MASHED POTATOES! what kind of SHIT is that? My fiance's food.... shrimp wasn't spicy the scallops were black and he thought they were mushrooms, and they were very over cooked, and tasted rubbery. SO PLEASE DON'T WASTE  YOUR TIME NOR MONEY ON THE FOOD HERE!!!!

YELP...your good reviews on this restaurant were wrong and really let us down!!!
author: Kayla H.

description:
Love the space... came here to check off the spicy crab and grits and man was I really disappointed when they told me they no longer had that on their menu... New Chef... 

I have to say he is certainly a new chef... the shrimp and grits just did not go together...  the fried chicken was okay... brussel sprouts fabulous .. the menu needs to be refined... I am really bummed that the food was not what I had read all about... I'll try it again sometime this year and hope the new chef gets everything broken in... 

Waiters were great, good beer selection.. nice neighborhood place
author: J R.

description:
I went to school in Atlanta and have really missed good Southern and Carribean cooking which is almost impossible to find in San Francsco - The Front Porch being one of the exceptions.

My wife and I stumbled on this place by a recommendation from a patron sitting outside the restaurant as we walked by - with an explicit recommendation for the spicy crab and grits so we spontaneously popped in after checking out their menu. 

The place is funky - small and cozy - and dimly lit.  We ordered the red bean and rice as a starter (although typically a side dish).  Prior to our order they brought out sweet potato chips and cornbread.  The corn bread was just OK and came out lukewarm so it was nothing special (one of the few things as everything else was far above expectation).

The red beans and rice (we chose with pork) was fantastic.  It was just a little spicy with a slight sweetness from coconut and the pork was tender.

My wife had the spicy crab and grits which was also wonderful.  I had the jerk poussin with collard greens and turnips and cornbread stuffing.  I asked whether it was spicy and was told it was more sweet (bc of cinammon and cardamom).  I was a little disappointed as I really like spicy jerk chicken. 

However, I was surprised to find that it was sufficiently spicy (made my nose run slightly), but you could also taste the sweet spices - it is some of the best jerk chicken I've had since a recent trip to Belize...SO GOOD!  And the collard greens, turnips and cornbread stuffing were also EXCELLENT!

We would have loved to try dessert, but the two entrees and starters were very filling.  However, I'm very interested in trying the chocolate bread pudding on another visit to see if it is as good as my friend's mother's version - she's from Western South Carolina.  Also, can't wait to come back and try the fried chicken!

Forgot to mention that the service was excellent and very attentive - from the hostess, table busser to our server.  We never found our water glasses less than 1/2 full, the server was sincere and helped with suggestions and our food came out very timely.

All in all, a wonderful find in our neighborhood and we'll definitely be back and give it a really high recommendation!
author: Stephen L.

description: I've been eating at Front Porch since the week they opened (and several times in between). Over time its been consistent. Last night we stopped in for the bake out - all you can eat Craw Fish etc. I opted for the exceptional fried chicken. Shared 4 breasts with a friend and stole sides from our counterparts who chowed down on craw, corn and taters. tasty salads, good beers (minimal selection, but perfect). Everything is fresh and tasty.
author: Adam X.

description:
UPDATE 2/27/2009

o woe is me...woe is me!!!  where for art thou sarah????

forgive me front porch, i know i shouldnt, but i must give you 2 stars.  

so the last visit, i fear, was this past tuesday.  knowing it was a new chef, my bd n i still were enticed by the "shrimp boil" advertised -cept we partook in just ordering from the NEW menu from the NEW chef (the menu looked interesting, had to admit).

here goes:
boo on the watery gumbo (is gumbo spous to be watery?  i dont know, i have yet to experience authenticity).  bd still liked it.
boo on the jalapeno cheddar biscuits w/ cold as rock butter 
boo on the vinegary hot sauce (confusing nuoc nam/i dont know what but it aint hot "hot sauce")

i know, im being unfair... but heres some 2 snaps:
dungeoness crab salad -  a must.  
red beans n rice w/ hamhock --good, not as thick n soupy as id had b4, kinda on the lighter side, if you can say that about red beans n rice
yucca w/ garlic--omg this was like an upgrade to garlic fries!  although beware, youll be tasting garlic 4 ever!
ahi seared tuna --yeah, i didnt know tuna was a new orleans type of dish, but this was actually ok.  bd liked it so he finished it.

sadness still prevails.  everything that which was sarah's front porch is gone.  no more hot sauce (thank god i bought a bottle), no more of the salt cod fritters i crave, no jerk anything!  its like a remake of your old favorite song...just not the same.  

forgive me sarah for taking advantage, for being selfish and only dining quarterly, for denying my impulse to order take out at least once a week.. please come back... please!  (or at least keep me posted when you open up a new restaurant)




12/17/2008
cant..cant go wrong w/ this place!  this is my fave restaurant and it has been for the longest.  i dont know why i kept denying them the 5th star.  
so went back w/ my other last week n they had a few new things on the menu.  my most fave starter (salt cod fritters) was taken off but i asked for it anyways.  whoooohoo!  i did receive.  

this time i tried the pork ribs w/ pickled okra.  oh oh okra, i loved it.  the pork ribs were good also, but the sauce reminded me of peking sauce.  weird, but still good.  other tried the jerk poussin.  loved it as usual.  theyres somethin bout their jerk sauce that makes everything so good matter what they put it on (whats that mean?  i dont know).  the brussel sprouts...carmelized!  can that be healthy?

so there.  i had to give them the 5th star.  they havent failed me yet!
author: Lady K.

description: Price brings it down from 5 stars. Food and ambiance are perfect for me. Great beers and The Best Fried Chicken I've ever had.
author: seth c.

description:
Wine from the box is clever and constitutes comfort food of the highest degree for me.
The fried chicken is delicious..the chicken juicy, the fry crispy
and I got a whole lotta chicken for my servin..
What I walked away lovin most was the black eye beans and rice as well as the ceiling (ceilings are important too people).
author: Jen L.

description:
Good stuff from the former chef at Emily's Spag Shack. 

1) The cerviche is awesome. 
2) The fried chicken bucket is good, not great. But can feed four.
3) The porridge is a bit oily
4) Good wine list or BYO w/ corkage fee
author: hunter w.

description:
UBER YUMMY.

I am giving it 5 *'s due to the fact I ate the best pork chop there EVER. It was a special. Been there twice now- everything about this place ROCKS.
author: sarah d.

description:
After two failed attempts, I finally go to eat at the FP!

Went with a group of 6 last week, and I'd wished we were a smaller party only because the tables don't accommodate 6 comfortably.  5, yes, but 6, not really.  How can you have a triangular table and only use two sides for a party of 6?!  I guess its proximity to the bar did not allow for the hypotenuse to be inhabited, so we were all squeezed in to the booth areas on the sides.  Anyhow, that was about my only complaint, as every dish was really interesting and for the most part good to great.   The service was also perfectly chill and attentive at the same time.  Always a plus.

Having six folks there certainly afforded me the opportunity to try several dishes, including three of my own - the crab and mango salad, which was killer, the jerk flank steak and potato salad, again killer, and the de-constructed cherry jelly donut dessert, very cool but not quite killer.  I was told they do a mean jerk quail, and have a rotating offering in the jerk category.  This is grounds for serious excitement, as my jerk flank steak, though slightly underdone - more like bleu than medium rare - was one of the best meat/spice/texture combo's I've had in a while.

I was also able to sample the conch fritters, which I would order again and was so sad to get only 3/4 of one, the fried chicken, which was moist and very flavorful, the salmon and plantains, which didn't really work for me (though I love both ingredients on their own!), the pork chop, which was solid, and the grass-fed burger (way to go) which was superb.  

Most menu items come fried, or with something fried, so be prepared for this aspect.  For me that means comfort food, and along those lines I think that FP could just be the best around.  Add to it the creative Caribbean-esque twist and you've got a winner.  I'm actually itching to go back.

4.5 stars, going on 5...  but I need a few more visits...
author: Pedro, aka Burgundy M.

description:
Oh come on, its not that loud inside. I just read a few of the reviews and luckily for me, I've been to the Front Porch 3 times and never had an issue with the noise.

My only gripe is that I can't stop from ordering that delicious fried chicken. I'd like to try something else but I'm addicted.

one of the two ladies who run the joint is from Barbados. My dinner companion (and best bud) is from Trinidad, a rival island. The last thing he wants to do is give a beijin (sp?) a compliment, but he was in heaven after having callilou soup, a giant pork chop, and great service.

Mitchell Bros is around the corner so go there for dessert.
author: Sylvie L.

description:
I went on a Thursday and had a 45 minute wait for a party of two. Had the an appetizer and a drink. i'm bad with names, but it was some fried fish fritter...none the less it was good. The drink I had  was skimpy on liquor, but mintly refreshing.

We got a booth lit by candles and the interior was pretty cool. The purpose of our dinner was to talk about some life changing events that are coming up, and this place set that mood. Music wasn't too loud, tables we're too close together, and everyone was in thier own conversations.  

I was starved and went for the Fried Chicken, and my party went for the Crab and Grits. The chicken was large and we could have shared it. It had some coconut flavor that was foreign to me, yet satisfing. The mashed potatoes were sweet and creamy, just how I like them. My girlfriends Crab and grits had more grits than Crab an was low on flavor. 

Would I return? Yes. i would. My overall experience was good. You can call in parties larger than 6, but it should be everyone. The atmosphere was good and the people were friendly.
author: Young Urban Minority P.

description:
The Front Porch gets 39 of 50 Fussy Fusspot Points... and a very respectable 4 stars

---

Blade is hot.  He is also hungry.  After standing around a Fundraiser for a few hours eating little bites of food it is time for a real dinner.  Front Porch - here we come.

Clean server?  Yes.  5 of 5 points.  Funky Groovy Mission District Clean Servers.

Clean table and dishes?  Yes.  5 of 5 points.

Clean bathroom?  Clean but not spotless.  4 of 5 points.

Subtotal = 14 of 15 Fussy Points on the Clean Scale.

Service - 4 of 5 points.  It's after 9pm on Thursday night when we arrive.  We wait only a few minutes and are seated quickly.  Very pleasant service all through the evening.  Funky Groovy Mission District Pleasant Service.

Ambiance - 4 of 5 points.  Quirky and Cool and Just Plain F-U-N.

Price/Food ratio - 4 of 5 points.

Friends from Finland Practical Scale - 3 of 5 points.  Convenient and easy to find but a little small and the tables are quite close together. 

Food - 7 of 10 points.  Yes, we had the Fried Chicken and it was GOOD. 

Bonus points - 3 of 5.  Great vibe = 1 bonus.  Art work and decor = 1 bonus.  We chatted with the cool straight couple at the table next to us = 1 bonus.  A restaurant that encourages people to break down their barriers and talk to strangers get bonus points!

Total:  39 Fussy Points.
author: Fussy F.

description:
Get the bucket, that's all I can say, get the bucket of fried chicken.  It is soo good.  Everything we had was great.  It is a really fun place to take friend from out of town or just to meet up with friends.  You can't go wrong.

Only one complaint, the service was a bit slow, and that was on a quiet night.
author: Becky A.

description:
What I LOVED about the Front Porch: Bucket of friend chicken with great Mac 'n cheese, crab grits, wine either in a juice box or from an equally interesting normal wine list, tin punch ceiling, and awesome service. 

What I didn't LOVE: the bar across the street. I think it's actually the front for a brothel. Notice the all male crowd save for the madame standing under the red light. 

I'll go back soon and have dessert there instead of a night cap at the redlight bar.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Craving Caribbean comfort food?  Yup, right here in SF!  The place is small, ahem, initimate.  But it can be a little bit of a wait sometimes.  If you're not starving, why not?   Emmy's Spaghetti Shack's wait isn't any shorter.  

Fried chicken is fantastic.  Talk a friend into sharing the WHOLE fried chicken.  It comes in a popcorn container.  Cute.  Black beans and collard greens are cooked in pork fat, you can totally taste it.   My friend had the crab cakes, and loved it.  Because of allergies, I could only look at it longingly, and not sample.

The menu changes seasonally with specials.  Easy place to kick back a few with a few pals.  

Then, it's off to Mitchell's for ice cream after dinner.  You only have to walk a block, no need to find parking again, yay!
author: Lily C.

description:
so we went yesterday during the downpour and there was absolutely no wait. We ordered: pot roast with carrots and sweet potatoes (yum!), crab & grits (mmmmm), vegan stew /curry(not so great..), and a side of mac pie (dry, and i've had way better). Although most of the food was very good and VERY filling, i have absolutely no desire to go back. I actually woke up feeling really disgusted this morning and slightly nauseated at the thought of last night's dinner. 
If it were yesterday, i would give front porch 4 stars. However, sleeping on it took my rating down to 2.5. perplexing!
author: eve l.

description:
Inaugural First Friday Dinners w/friends.

-- Sangria:  fruity...not traditional red wine
-- Cornbread:  delicious, and it was shaped like a corn....and the butter was soooo good.  First cornbread I'd ever liked
-- Fried Chicken in a bucket:  not bad, but some pieces were too lemonny
Sides included Grits and Black-eyed peas
-- Black-eyed peas:   ah, they're okay
-- Grits, first time I had grits, and they're DAMN GOOD!  I can't believe how I lived without 'em

I'd go back for the cornbread and grits, and try their mac and cheese!
author: Jen C.

description:
Best fried chicken ever!

Yep it's that good.  deserves 5 stars on just that dish alone.

Crispy, crunchy, mouth watering, crust, perfectly cooked juicy meat with a hidden tang that keeps you coming back for more.  It's seriously addictive. corn bread is off the hook!

My recommendation is order a bucket, side of grits, side of greens/black eyed peas and take the leftovers home.  It's cheaper than ordering two individual plates and I do this even when I eat by myself.  When you are craving later on, (which you will be)you'll be glad you got the bucket.

That's not to say the jerk chicken or molasses flavored pork chop isn't good, either.  In fact, everything here is good-even the soups/salads and sides.

The menu is limited, but EVERYTHING is good.  It's like your favorite flavors of Jamaica, California, and soul food all in one.   I believe the recipes are designed by this really nice lady from Jamaica, who is always at the restaurant and you can tell her how much you love her fried chicken.  

It's a cozy little place, people love it so it's always full, only open for dinner after 5.  You can get take out.  There is a patio with couches and chairs to sip on wine before or after your meal.

If you don't like waiting like me, just seat yourself at the bar and eat right there on the counter.  the bar is only beer and wine, but the bartenders know some good choices of wines and beers you never even heard of, including a wonderfully sweet wine/liquor I had for desert.  Yes, they have bubbly.
author: Mark K.

description:
Two questions.

1) How have I lived near this place for like two years and never been there...poor me.
2)  How many times can you eat pork belly in a week before your doctor pitches a fit?  

To the second question, my waitress at FP said 7 (daily)...I'm not sure I agree with that...but, the pork belly at FP was so good I almost went back that many times.

I'll be going back.

I'm also going to get my cholesterol checked.

There are many other healthier options there.

N
author: Nate G.

description:
Although I've already written a yelp review for Front Porch, I feel compelled to update it, if only to rebut somebody's prior comments about the "Porch Pork entree".

I was personally thrilled with the pork dish.  It's right out of a Caribbean market -- shredded pork (think carnitas) that was slow-roasted for over 4 hours, in a sweet dark sauce, with chunks of roasted plaintain and taro on the side.  They use the full pig, which means yes, you may get slices of pork belly (only we Americans seem to be afraid of tripe).  The plantain and taro offer a good starchy base to offset the rich pork and its sauce.  To provide a little extra flavor, the chef adds what appeared to be a pesto made from mint, garlic and some other ingredients I couldn't decipher.

To my boyfriend, who is the ultimate food critic -- and who is sure to make his opinion known when the "flavors" have not met his exceedingly high standards -- the pork entree passed with flying colors.  And for me, Mr. Frugal, I was more than pleased to have ordered the most expensive item on the menu.

I'll agree that Front Porch can occasionally be a mixed bag (I had a pork chop entree last year that left me underwhelmed), but this place to me represents the best of what San Francisco has to offer.  The chef takes risks, keeps things fresh by updating the menu every season, and has unique items/dishes that are not easily found elsewhere.  Plus, the location and decor are the biggest highlights.  In LA, a restaurant of this caliber would be high-profile and posh; in San Francisco, it's tucked away in a basement next to the on-ramp for the Lower Mission Safeway.  It's exceedingly rare, and I'll concede cliched, to say that a restaurant can deliver a life-changing experience but somehow, Front Porch has achieved that impossible task -- and all the more remarkable that it's only a 3-block walk away from my front door.
author: Mervyn H.

description:
first off, i want to say my friends and I went here because of the awesome yelp reviews we read online.
let's just say, all four of us were very, VERY disappointed.
maybe it's just not our thing, but none of us were satisfied with the food. the fried catfish was terribly bland and watery tasting (meaning it tasted like water). their burger were just mediocre, and their appetizer of fried assortments (i forgot what it was called) was not appetizing at all.
we wanted to try the crab and grits because of everyone's ravings, but it wasn't even on the menu anymore.
overall, the food was extremely overpriced and definitely not up to par in terms of quality.
the atmosphere was pretty cute and warm though, and gave off a southern feeling, but that was about the best thing in the restaurant.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I just found my favorite place.  I can sit on the front porch rocking my day off, drinking a delicious ginger beer  cocktail, knowing that a fantastic cozy meal is soon to come.  This place feels like the chef is cooking up his favorite food for people he likes. 

 Loved the Hostess... as a former I've gotta give my shout outs.  Very accommodating and on top of our mission: a great slow night.  
We started out with several apps.  Crab grits were tasty, corn bread made my heart happy, fried plantain mmmmm, and this take on a curry something that I can't remember the name of but really enjoyed.

Chicken, as everyone else has already praised, was great.  I am the kind of girl who makes fired chicken for loved ones and this stood up to the overnight butter milk bath chicken I love.  Not as much spice as I like, but great crunch.  The sides were great too: the brussel sprouts made me dream dirty dirty things for a few days afterward.

Great ambiance, solid food, wonderful service, and rocking chairs. The Front Porch, YOU WIN.
author: Sidrah G.

description: A little pricey but worth the money.  Chicken and waffles, fried okra, begneits...What else could you ask for.  I will never be skinny as long as places like this exist.
author: Sheriff D.

description: Fun atmosphere, tasty cocktails, friendly staff and AMAZINGLY GOOD FOOD.  I rarely yelp, but this place rocks.  I will be going back as often as possible.  Try the boiled peanuts, bacon-wrapped fried oysters, and the fresh crab over grits (as in a whole crab that you eat with your hands).
author: Jaime M.

description:
It took me a little while to reach the center of delicousness here. My partner-in-crime loved Front Porch from the start, and meal after meal he would be freaking out over the taste explosion while I shifted food around the plate with my fork, bored. Finally I must have ordered the right thing, and I haven't turned back. The owner is a complete sweetheart. I want to have babies with the cod fritters. Crab and grits is amazing, and so is a lot else. Fried chicken is fried chicken - go out on a limb, dudes.

The night I went at they played Pearl Jam I thought I was in heaven. Also, you get to hang out on the front porch in a rocking porch swing with a delicious cocktail while waiting for a table. Awesome.
author: Sarah G.

description:
i wanted to like it.... i wanted to LOVE it .... deep down in my southern deep fried soul. they have abita beer for god's sake. I had very very high hopes.

as anyone who knows me will tell you, i love chicken, i am a fiend when it comes to yardbird, especially fried. the space was great on the inside, there was no wait and we had great service. the chicken however was not that great. it was way too dry on the outside which made it virtually impossible to eat the meat without all of the skin / crust falling off.  the cornmeal crust was ok but seemed better suited for the outside of some catfish.

also when i requested hot sauce they produced their own house made habanero sauce which was good but any self respecting southern place would ask.. just ask if I wanted something like crystal or louisiana hot. maybe i am picky... but i am a stickler for good chicken. the sides were ho hum. my friend had the crab and grits which she said were "ok" but not that flavorful.

when you need your chicken fix and only the best will do - nelly's in oakland is the place to go.
author: Ashley T.

description:
this place makes me feel good.
The atmosphere and plating is endearing...very homey and comfortable feeling.
It feels like having my mom cook for me (and my mom is a dang good cook).
I've loved everything I've ever had, and I always get the chicken.
I wish it was closer to me.
author: miranda caroligne ..

description:
I had my birthday here.  
I invited a bunch of people.  
They wrote my name on the top of our very own menu.  
The service was fantastic, attentive yet not annoying. 
The food was SO GOOD.  
So were the drinks...had a sweet sangria sorta thing
It certainly is not a place you would come if you were trying to do any sort of restrictive diet.  
Everything, and I mean everything (note we had three courses) I had was fried.  
Ok, the mac n' cheese probably wasn't fried but who knows?  
But it all was divine, truly enjoyable.  
I encourage everyone to come check out the fried chicken.  
Worth the price of admission.
author: Sierra D.

description:
Food was great. Im from out of town and it was the highlight of my visit.
The staff was casual yet professional and very attentive even though they were super busy that night. Im looking forward to my next visit.
author: CYNTHIA C.

description:
This place is unique...cool hipster interior, tasty food that is not overpriced, good beer list, inventive cocktails - put it all together and there is not much like it...especially in the city.

We had salt-cod fritters to start - not on the menu but our friend knew a friend who knew the owner, so we were hooked up...and if I go back, I will not let the lack of listing on the menu set me back - I will demand some again with a spicy tarter that is out of this world.

Chicken must have been good because I was supposed to split it with my super healthy husband but he actually at it all while I was eating half a burger and some insanely tasty jerk chicken off of my friend's plate.

The food and ambience would have been 4 stars but they get an extra gold star for their service.  It would appear that they held open auditions and picked the coolest, funkiest, friendliest and actually capable servers to match the rest of their theme and we loved it!
author: Miley M.

description: Really, really good fried chicken. Shrimp and grits were good, too.  Stick with those and you're good.
author: Lucky L.

description: Oh Front Porch, how do i compare thee to a dope southern fried chicken spot?  I don't, because this place IS the epitome of a great southern style food.
