Although we had a super long wait... around 45 mins to an hour, we sidled up to the bar and hung out like it was at our grandmas house, got some electric marmalade and lilliet - their signature drinks, and next thing you know, we got our table. Between five of us, we split 2 buckets of fried chicken (18 pieces total, 9 per bucket) and sides mac and cheese, which is to die for, collard greens with bacon, and a side of plantains.  Eat here.  Its yummo.
author: Jenn B.

description:
loved the mac n cheese & fried okra. will try the lime-ade next time.

naughty girls need love, too.
author: vincent m.

description: Great fried chicken. Awesome presentation. Definitely a place to take out of towners. The drinks were good too. Very original and tasty. What more can I say? Less is more.
author: Nidia R.

description: Really off night - gumbo had a burned aftertaste.  Had to send back the shrimp over grits.  Mac n cheese was pasty and flavorless.  sadness.
author: Joshua S.

description: I could live in a tent in the corner of this place.  Sure, I'm a vegetarian and most of the menu consists of meat (specifically, fried chicken and burgers), but they have a great drink selection, fantastic setting, and even better staff.  AND every weeknight is dominoes night.  Doesn't get better.
author: Christine M.

description: Hooray for the liquor license!  Just when we thought it couldn't get any better, whiskey cocktails to go with the fried chicken!
author: Julia H.

description: I don't think know if real Southerners would care too much for the Front Porch.  Things just taste a little different than what I had when I made a trip down there.  But with that said, the food is really, really good.  I'm a big fan of the fried chicken, and will split the bucket with anyone at anytime!  The mashed potatoes were a little runny though.
author: Ernest S.

description:
just not impressed. the place is very cute and the staff is very nice, but that's where the praises stop.

catfish: I read it on the review that someone had the catfish and it was good, so I tried it when someone ordered it in our group. it was just ok. the breading was good, but the fish is not that tasty.

porch chop: very well done thick pork chop, but the collard green on the side was sandy. ewww...

fried chicken: I only had one piece even though my friend and I shared a bucket. the collard green that came with this entree was not sandy, but still not so tasty. the breading of the chicken was not crunchy as I expected, they either fried it and left it out for a while or the frying oil is not hot enough and the breading absorbed all the oil.

the oyster and spinach salad: the oyster is tasty, I think it's actually pretty fresh. however I don't think it really goes with the spinach salad and dressing, maybe it's just me. 

then it came the tap, which was quite a bit for the mediocre food. group of over 6 is charged over 18% tips which is charged over tax and health insurance fee, so we paid more than doubled the tax for tips.
author: Cicie W.

description: this is now one of my favorate places for southern food! absolutly authentic and delicious! i can't wait to go back!
author: Chizzy T.

description: Awesome place! Love the vibe and the food, will definitely go back there again and that's saying a lot because I'm not one to go back to a spot often.
author: c m.

description:
Just plain good eats!

Went here tonight to check this new spot out and I must say I shall return.

Super friendly staff front and back of the house.  It would have been nice to hear about the nights specials before we had picked out what we wanted, but no big deal.

The ceveche appitizer which came with what I believe were fried apple chips came out pretty fast and was delicious. The rest of the food took quite a while to come out and when it did my girlfriends crab topped porridge (awesomely spicy) came out about 10 minutes before my fried chicken, but everyone was very apologetic and the chef did send out a salmon carpaccio to tide me over until it came out.  I am sure the time issue is just a product of only having been open for a month now.  As far as drinks go the sangria was decent, a full bar would be nice, but I know liquor licenses are hard to come by in the city.  I would like to see a bit larger menu in the future as well.

As far as decor goes, loved it, I felt very comfortable in here, just like I was in my grandmothers house.
author: Josh V.

description:
After reading good reviews we took a large group to the Front Porch.  They will take reservations for a large group, so we got the great party table in the corner.  Others seem to be lined up wating for a table.  But hey!  You can sit in on the front porch in a rocking chari while you wait.
  
People are right about the fried chicken!  It's fantastic.  We ordered a bucket and then ordered another.  But the grits with crab were an unexpected surprise -- creamy porridge with big chunks of crab on top -- yummm!   Finally, they had brussel sprouts with a sweet sauce which was wonderful.

The only problem was an incredibly long wait for our food.  The kitchen seemed overwhelmed by a Saturday night crowd.
author: Erwin B.

description:
This place was YUMMY!!!  really cute califorinian/carribean cusine.  Very casual atmosphere but great service and surprisingly a really good wine list.  They also will serve most of their wines in a half carafe!  Try the  homemade fried chicken.   I made lots of ooooo  and ahhh noises while eating it.  heehee

Enjoy!
author: Genna A.

description:
AMAZING. I stopped by here Sunday night for dinner with a few friends. We didn't have reservations so we had to wait. Best part about waiting for a table.... the rocking chairs and blankets out front. Seriously. 

Pros: incredible food (jerk chicken special), nice atmosphere, friendly staff, complimentary appetizers from the kitchen (I'm still salivating over the corn bread with chili butter). Cons: be prepared to wait if you don't have a reservation, a little on the pricey side, not good for parties over 4 or 5.
author: Kari B.

description:
This restaurant was a pleasant surprise.  The decor is super cozy from the detailed tin ceiling on down.  The food sits at the bottom of your belly in a warm, comforting way but the portions are just right so you do not feel overstuffed.  I ordered the delicious ceviche with flash-fried sweet potato crisps and the scrumptious one-pot vegan stew. Only in San Francisco can I have a vegan dish at a comfort food restaurant.  My dining partner enjoyed ribs that "melt in your mouth."  Price was a little bit high for comfort food, but nothing outrageous.    Highly recommended.  

(one point of amusement: they serve a bucket of fried chicken for 30$. . . but hey, maybe its worth it?)
author: erin h.

description:
I must confess...I do not eat meat...I eat seafood, but not meat.  The Front Porch makes me want to eat meat again and I have not eaten meat since 1985.

Meanwhile, the spicy crab over grits with english peas rock with the devil.
author: Laura F.

description:
I really enjoyed my dinner here, although it's kind of in a weird location, for which it gets dinged one star.

The fried chicken was very, very good.  Not too greasy but full of flavor.  The crab and grits was also excellent.  The grits clearly have a lot of butter, so best to go for a special occasion when you want to pig out and not feel guilty.

Service was good.  I could see it getting a bit cramped in there if you went during a busy hour on a busy night, but we went early so it was very comfortable and fast.  

Unfortunately we didn't have room for dessert on this trip, so I'll have to go back!
author: Gami G.

description: This place rocks.  I've been there about 8 times now over the past couple of years and it's always fun, drinks eclectically great, and food hearty and tasty in a down-home yet gourmet way. I love the warm "speakeasy" feel and really genuine kindness and helpfulness of the staff. They're not perfect -- once my game hen came out undercooked and still pink inside  (they were fast to fix it) -- but the food and folks at Front Porch are on my A-List.
author: Kris A.

description: I had a great meal at Front Porch. We ordered the collard greens, fried catfish, and spicy shrimp and grits. The collard greens were flavorful and fresh. The spicy shrimp and grits consisted of creamy grits with a delicious tomato based sauce. The fried catfish was juicy and flaky. The sweet potato fries that it came with were warm and crispy, though not hot. The hush puppies were bland and chewy. Not my favorite.
author: Jin I.

description: This was our first time at The Front Porch.  Love that they take reservations, but come early because parking is tough in that neighborhood!  We brought our 16 month old and 8 year old for a 6:00 Sat. night reservation.  They have a kids menu with all the stuff kids eat like fried shrimp and chicken tenders, and it's not the frozen stuff either.  It's made there.  Service was excellent, food was prompt.  We started with fried pickles and crawfish beignets which were good but nothing special.  My bf ordered the shrimp and grits which we both thought was excellent and would definitely recommend.  I ordered the sautéed flounder which came with delicious baby carrots and liked it very much.  The bf indulged himself an awesome root beer float and I had an Irish coffee which was about 95% alcohol.  Overall, thought the food was good but there are better choices for the true lover of Cajun/Creole food.
author: Kara V.

description:
I joined Yelp just to write this review! Was here last week and the fried chicken absolutely lived up to it's reputation - it was fantastic. I'd drive back into the city just to have it again.
Don't know how we made room but the chicken was so good we had to try dessert - the bread pudding was just as good as the chicken - worth saving room for!
Only downside were the beans that came with the chicken - very undercooked and not a lot of flavor. Otherwise it would have been 5 stars.
author: Barbara H.

description:
Craving some fried chicken, we arrived at 10pm, 30 minutes before closing. The joint was busy, but not packed by any means (there were, at the least, two empty seats at the bar.)

We were greeted by a server, we asked for a a table for dinner, then were told that the list was closed. How can your list be closed if you aren't closing for another 30 minutes, AND there is available seating? This makes me think that they're more interested in going home at closing time rather than make money and serve another table. We ended up going to Pizzeria Delfina, where we got a seat immediately, so it all worked out.

I haven't had any problems with Front Porch in the past, but this was pretty lame and, really, unacceptable.
author: Alexis C.

description: Dined at TFP prior to the McCartney show and it did not disappoint..  Literally sat outside on the front porch and enjoyed the beautiful weather and lively neighborhood ambiance.  Started with two delicious and fresh salads, (Arugala and watermelon and one other) both terrific, the jalapeno and bacon deviled eggs - delicious, and the fried green tomatoes (average).  The two standouts that will really have me coming back are the fried chicken and the brown bagged beignets.  I don't have much of reference point for fried chicken,  but this version is legit.  Hot, crispy, juicy inside, and tons of flavor.  The beignets were also nice and hot, covered in powdered sugar, and just the right size so you don't feel like a complete glutton.  One minor mishap, we ordered the coillard greens which frankly don't have much hope regardless of how they're prepared.  Service is solid, I dropped my knife once, and they brought before I could ask.  Will be back, but not too often since you can't get out of there without taken in at least 1,500 cals.
author: Brian C.

description:
So it turns out that they just changed chefs which means that the crab grits I was really looking forward to are no longer on the menu. That makes me a sad panda. I overheard a waitress telling another table that their old chef was from Barbados (hence the Caribbean twist to the menu) and the new chef is from New Orleans. I'll be interested to see how the menu changes. Po boys and crawfish boils maybe?
6 of us came to splurge on Mardi Gras with fried chicken and buttery mashed potatoes. It took a little while for our food to come out, but I suspect it's because they fry the chicken fresh to order. It came out piping hot, crispy and juicy. Each bucket contains 9 pieces of chicken and comes with a side of greens and mashed potatoes. We ordered 2 buckets to split between 5 people and left with enough leftovers for  2 or 3 meals. The only thing I wasn't terribly fond of was the sangria. Firstly, they don't do pitchers because each one is made to order. That doesn't really make sense to me because the best thing about sangria is the fruit that's been soaking up all that alcohol. Also, it's made with a rose and the only fruit is citrus, so it tastes more like a wine spritzer with grapefruit juice. It's not bad, it's just not exactly sangria.
As a super bonus though, Mitchell's Ice Cream is a block away. I think I might end up being a regular here. YUM!
author: Melanie V.

description:
one of my favorite places to go WHEN they are busy. this seems to be a point of contention with some of the whinier diners out there. see, here's the thing, they have a *gasp* front porch where you can chill while waiting for your table. also, if the *gasp* front porch is crowded, you can meander up the street to the 3300 club and knock back some cocktails while you wait for them to call the bar to let you know your table is ready. good times! 

when you do get your coveted table and sit down you can expect friendly service (unless you're a whiny socially awkward retard, then you get what you give...see how that works?), great starters like the mac and cheese and amazing entrees.i've gone with the steak a few times now and, i have to say, it has almost surpassed my love for the fried chicken....almost. 

i have always waddled away from this place with a smile and a happy belly.
author: willie l.

description:
Living in the Mission, there are a lot of places to eat.  Some how, every time I tell someone where I live, they mention the Front Porch.  I had to try it. 

It was great!!

The place is small and sometimes there is a wait, but it's well worth it.  The servers are great, they have an excellent selection of beer and the food is outstanding.  Great flavors and intersting and unique options.  

I had perhaps the best jerk steak I've ever had.  

Get the surf and turf special, it's always great.
author: Andrew L.

description:
Nothing fancy about this place just FOOD.  
highly satisfying and worth the wait.  
Fried chicken is MOIST FLAVORFUL INSIDE AND OUT. Great cornmeal crust.  Some would say friend chicken isnt worth the $30 price tag for a bucket, but these buckets are filled with a whole chicken of goodness. A whole chicken with each wing, thigh, breast, even the bones are permiated with the flavorful juices. 
Its in the breading, the batter whatever you call it. Its the crust that makes the chicken, and the chefs wonderful crusty flavor ridden cornmeal crust is pretty nice.
The callaloo soup was light brothy, full of greens, and smoked ham with bits of potatoes.  The mac and cheese pie could be a little bit more moist, and all the sides can fend for themselves.

Nice polite service, great dessert, lovely and talented chef.  
Well im a creature of habit, I would definitely need to try more of the dishes in order to give it a 5 star. so far so good.
author: Tina d.

description:
What a great place! A perfect and unique neighborhood restaurant that makes you feel all warm and fuzzy about living in a cool town like SF. The whole experince from decor to music to service to the comfy van seats for my tush was just a lot of fun.

And now, to the food. Um, YUM! First the crab salad. There were these little crunchy, spicy taste exposions that went so well with the cool lettuce and sweet crab. Upon viewing the menu, I found that they were little strips of fried chili. Genius.

This was followed by the fried chicken that everyone is raving about. Everyone is right. A little  bit of a twist on some of the fried chicken I am used to. This has a stronger blend of herbs and spices - a nod to the Carribean. It really works. And, the chicken beneath the glorius crust is juicy and delicious! Not at all dried out - another common fried chicken blunder. Dessert was the jewel in this crown, corn pudding with a ball of delightful, sugary fried goodness on the side. I would have ordered another (perhaps two) just for me if the kitchen wasn't closing.
author: Aron S.

description:
Crab & grits? Yum!!

Enjoyable neighborhood spot, with outdoor seating.

We ordered a bottle of wine at the bar while we waited for our table.
It wasn't cold, so the bartender offered tastes of options.
Eventually, they found a bucket, that was tucked away in storage, to ice our bottle table-side..overall, great service. Th e owner was very personable.

I'll be back to taste the rest of the menu...I saw a few things that I wanted to try.
author: sabrina e.

description:
The service is good, but really, come on folks, it is fried chicken, beans, and rice.  $31 for fried chicken?  I guess I don't think it is that much better than KFC to justify the price.  

Grass fed URUGUAYAN beef for $11?  What kind of grass was it?  What is wrong with the Ecuadorian beef?  Come on.
author: David N.

description: We tried to have dinner there tonight. We left the waiting list of Emmy's Spaghetti Shack to walk over to the Front Porch because when I called the host said we could get in right away or in about 10 minutes. When we got there, we got a beer while we waited. We waited 40 minutes and still no table. We had to go to a show so we left, hungry. Poor service before we even tried the food. I won't go back.
author: Foodie F.

description: This place was incredible!  I came here for a graduation dinner and was so impressed.  The party that was sitting at the table we had reserved ended up taking a while to leave, but the staff was so nice and made it up to us with some free appetizers and samples of the amazing soup.  I don't know if I've encountered a nicer overall staff in San Francisco... and then there was the food!  Everything was so tasty- we tried almost all of the appetizers (including a bucket of fried chicken) and then i ended up ordering the spicy shrimp and grits.  It was one of the best meals I've ever had, and the atmosphere was perfect.  Can't wait to go back :)
author: Erin D.

description:
I have been on two really bad dates here- what made up for it is that I was at this amazing restaurant with delicious comfort food.  I suggest all awkward first dates come here, so that when things don't work out you can wallow in your fried chicken and mac n' cheese. I'm not really this pathetic! 
Things I have tried:
1.Yard Clippins- good to start with salad when you know everything else you eat is gonna be cloggin' the arteries! 
2.Porch Pickle Jar- I love pickles. But all the veggies had the same flavor- I think it would be fun if they got more creative with the pickling spices and the pickles were more surprising!
3.Fried Chicken - yum! who doesn't love mashed potatoes?
4.Fried catfish with hush puppies- really good too.  Could have used more zing in the sauce. Sweet potato fries are my favorite.
5. Hangar steak- with peppercorn Madeira sauce.  Really really great- better than I expected, bigger than I expected, cooked perfectly, seasoned perfectly. Perfection. 
6. Creamed Spinach- my only disappointment. Bland, watery, blech.
I have never made it to dessert.  Either too full or too tempted by the proximity to Mitchell's ice cream.
Last words- they only have beer and wine.  Stick to beer or wine.  The mixed drinks they try to make are not good.
author: Kimmy C.

description: I took my boyfriend here for dinner, and it was great.  He had an enormous hamburger, and he liked it.  I had the fried chicken... it was really tasty.  I'm just a picky m-fer when it comes to soul food.  The mac n' cheese was really tasty after a little more salt.  The fried chicken was well fried, with the right amount of seasonings.  The greens were decent - could have used a little more smokiness.  The wait staff were attentive and friendly.  I will be back for sure!
author: Lea R.

description:
It took me a few days to write this review...I had to digest 1st (nice play on words, huh?) before I could be completely honest. 

Ok - overall, thumbs up. My friend & I went on a Sunday night & it was packed...around 8pm. Almost a 45 min wait list but thankfully a small 2-top opened just in time & we didn't wait more than 10 min. Wished I could have sat outside on the front porch rocking chairs, but I'll save that for next time!

The food - here's my caveat...I spent 4.5 yrs in Charleston, SC. So I've eaten my share of Southern food - real Southern food. For a Southerner - you won't be overly impressed. For a person not from/not visited the Southeast, you'll like it. Here's my breakdown:

-They were out of the house jug wine so we ended up w/ the Beajuloius (yes, I can't spell that!). Not bad & affordably-priced.
-Fried Okra: yummy...we ate it all & it could have worked as a 4-person appetizer. The dipping sauce was OK, not sure what it was though
-Fried Chix - how do they get it so dang moist but fried at the same time? For 1 serving you get a breast, leg & thigh. More than enough for 1 person. The "bucket" comes out in a large movie-style popcorn tub! Enough for 4-6ppl in my opinion. The crust had no flavor though - pretty sure it was only panko-style bread crumbs. If it was Southern it would have had spice. I had hushpuppies substituted for the garlic mashers (an extra $2. Seriously? For 3 hushpuppies?) NOT worth it...the hushpuppies have herbs in them instead of jalapeno or other Southern spices. The dipping sauce (which they forgot & we had to ask for) was bland but made the 'puppies better. The collards were good. 
-The sustainable fish (I think it was "True Cod" that night? Or something like that) was good but when it was put over rice in a brown-sauce w/ shrimp, the fish lost all flavor. The sauce didn't have too much taste but when combined w/ the shrimp & rice it tasted better. 
-pecan pie. Good but would have been better if I didn't have to force my knife thru the crust. Maybe they didn' t let it defrost enough when they took it out of the freezer? 

Splitting the bill, with tip ended up around $55-60 for the 2 of us. Lots of food though - portions are good sized. 

Ambiance was great - it's super cute inside & the wait-staff was knowledgeable. Our waitress seemed a bit aloof & we had to ask other staff for forgotten items but it was fun & overall worth it. I wouldn't take my Southern friends here but I'd take out-of-towners here for something a little different. 

They position themselves as "Southern" but I'd call them more "California Southern".
author: Marissa H.

description:
OK,
I'm on my EYEphone at the table looking hip and a hip guy in jeans and T shirt (it's not casual anymore, jeans and a T shirt is pure hipster as of 06). So anywho, he walks by on his way to something drastically kooler than anything in here, or maybe just to clear the messy plates off of the next table, which by the way is also super hip if you work in a place that has any type of wait and by the way did I mention he's wearing jeans and a T shirt (hipster) and was nice to folks and smiled while taking orders and probably has a day job or goes to school, and does not have the time to really make it out to many kool parties so this is really it for him...
So anyway, not to get distracted, like I said I'm on my EYEphone and he comes by and is all "you better be updating your status to AWESOME!" and I'm like "hell yeah, cause The Porch rocks!" and immediately updated my status to ROCKIN! Only later to find out they have a FaceBook page, I am so a FAN, you should become one too...

Click below to become a FAN!
http://www.facebook.com/pages/edit/?id=49462771543#/pages/San-Francisco-CA/The-Front-Porch/49462771543
author: Ifton S.

description:
I ate here on a recent Saturday night with my husband, a good friend, and my 1 year old daughter.  My fried chicken was to die for - grits and black eyed peas were lovely.  I could have eaten two servings (I am a nursing mother - the servings were not particularly small, I don't think).  The other entrees (both the fish special - some sort of very overcooked looking swordfish over chickpeas that reportedly were flavored "like baked beans") elicited comments like, "nice try, chef" and "i'm going to stop for a slice of pizza on the way home."  But the ceviche, cornbread (with yummy chile butter), and waldorf salad were all very solid to excellent.  Oh, and there was nothing I wanted on the dessert menu, which is both a rarity and a bit of a tragedy, but Mitchell's is, fortunately, just around the corner.

So, despite the very lackluster performance of the catch o' the day, I'm giving this place four stars.  They have valet stroller parking (!), it's loud (which sometimes drives me nuts, but sometimes I like it), the cocktail menu is interesting, and it's well-decorated.  Favorite thing about the Front Porch?  It was a fun place for us to be avec bebe, AND it's a place I would have frequented before she was born.  The two aren't always one in the same.
author: jennifer b.

description:
One of the nicest hole-in-the wall places around.  I used to live nearby so I went there a bunch and the food, although not very fancy, is consistent. 
Obviously, the fried chicken is the specialty but I recommend the Crab and Grits.
author: Jackie G.

description:
I know I shouldn't go to a soul food joint and have the burger, but good lord, that was the finest hamburger I have ever eaten! I had sworn off all burgers after feeling completely ill after a Burger Joint meal, figuring that if Niman Ranch was the best I was going to get, I'd rather say aloha to my burger habit entirely. But the Uruguayan grassfed burger was cooked perfectly, seasoned brilliantly, and served on a bun that was in itself a party for my tongue. And the fries? Shut my mouth. ReeDICulously awesome.

I have to say that the woman managing seating was a breath of fresh air for us. We arrived with 5 people and no reservation and she was polite, accommodating, and efficient - not to mention totally charming and funny. The night prior I had taken a party of 4 (my parents, godmother, and self) to Beretta, and left after waiting 90 minutes after being told we'd be seated in 10. Even so, the service here wasn't just good by comparison, it was just good.

Only complaint, halfway through the meal, upon the arrival of said burger from heaven, I ordered a beer. I had finished my burger when the waiter finally returned to inform me they were out of that variety.

Also, just a note to people, if you don't like cramped spaces or loud restaurants, this might not be for you. My dad has some hearing loss and could not really participate in the conversation.

OH YEAH! the grilled romaine with avocado horseradish dressing and hunks of bacon was genius - almost as good as the near-identical salad at Blue Plate down the street.
author: Brooke B.

description:
A nice spot for good ol' southern cooking in the south end of the Mission.

We enjoyed the cozy interior and the warmth and friendliness of the staff. We wish the music was a little less loud, however -- a bit much for this sort of intimate, neighborhood venue.

Three of the starters/sides (mac and cheese, shrimp and grits, gumbo) were marvelous-- richly seasoned and well-prepared. The fried okra was supposed to be spiced with pepper, but we couldn't detect it, and the bland breading smothered the delicate okra flavor.

Two of us had the fried chicken. While the smaller pieces were juicy and tender, both of the big pieces were not fully cooked (still red).  Beef can be rare but not chicken.The burger was fine, however.

I'd go back.
author: John L.

description:
Despite the sign across the street that says "Good Frick'n Chick'n", I would defend to the end the Front Porch's frick'n chick'n...until last night. 

Friends in town gave my partner and I reason to splurge.  We power-walked across Guerrero and got there to see there wasn't a wait, that there were some tables, a booth even, open. Yessss, we've never had the booth before! Yay for us. Maybe the look of excitement on our faces was mistaken for something else because without a hello or good evening or a yo or a hay, the hipster host wisked us away to the back of the joint where our table bordered the kitchen and the toilets. "But...those...tables, those up front..." as I blocked the light of the kitchen from my face. I've hosted, I've waited, I've cooked...I get the restaurant thing and not slamming a server, so I let it go. Anyway, it was all about the chicken. Wow, such a great ambiance. Kitchen, there's a kitchen? I didn't even remember that it was three feet behind me. "The bucket of chicken takes a little longer..." said the always friendly server.  "Not a problem AT ALL," we smiled. They held us over with a finger-sized pieces of cornbread portioned perfectly for our table. Ah ha! The bucket has arrived, along with the 5 sides we ordered to go with it. Wait. No. This isn't right. This isn't the good frick'n chick'n I'M used to paying $33 for. This is Safeway worthy at best. Sog City.  Green beans and mashed potatoes? Was I at KFC? Come to find out they come with the bucket. "&*^$! I wish they'd stop yelling at each other in the kitchen, they're messing with my ambiance!" We tasted and moved on to the pay as you go delectables: the mac and cheese, hello lover! The collards, deliciously average. Red beans and rice, one of my favorites. Each side dish screamed independence but went together so well, it felt like a Thanksgiving fest...and mom messed up the turkey. Life goes on. We'll be back again and again and pray the chicken is reincarnated to yesteryear. We figured why we were seated in the back as they began to clean the front room that was near empty. Next time, I'll make the request for a better table. Maybe I won't be able to see how soggy the chicken is in the darkness.
author: Penne P.

description: The fried chicken here is worth traveling from any part of town, but the rest of the menu...eh. Last time I ventured in the place was packed, on a thursday night. We said we'd sit at the bar, which had a couple different groups waiting for tables - at the time there was not a seat to be had anywhere. We wanted to wait there (couple people with checks looming) but the hostess asked us go to the corner bar where she promised to call us as soon as someone got up from the bar... 10 minutes after we arrived down the street my date went back to check at The Front Porch and nearly the entire bar area had turned over - with no call. So for the limited menu and the bad experience, Im taking it down to 3 stars.
author: Kasi B.

description:
I reviewed so many of the ads on here before checking out Front Porch and almost everyone said that the fried chicken was to die for! So needless to say, I was super stoked to be taking my lover there for his birthday.

Unfortunately the experience more left me wanting to die, than being worth it to die for. 

We were ushered in right when they opened and were the third table to sit down. The two of us were seated in the back of the restaurant right in front of the kitchen. About 3 minutes later, in walks a family of 6, 3 of whom are children under the age of  8. The hostess managed to seat that family right next to us and didn't offer to move us to one of the open booths or tables in the front of the restaurant. When we asked to move, they rolled their eyes, but obliged.

Looking at the wine list, there was not a great selection under $40 and so we asked the waitress to bring us a bottle of her favorite red under $40. It was delicious, however when we received the check at the end of the meal, the wine had been $55. That was seriously sneaky. 

As an appetizer we ordered the crab grits, and just like everyone says, they were DELICIOUS! The only amazing part of the meal.

For entrees, I ordered the fried chicken and my love ordered the cheeseburger. The burger was pretty much a burger, an above average one, but still, nothing special. The chicken however.... AWFUL! Absolutely god forsakenly AWFUL!!!! The fried skin tasted, literally, like cardboard. And my standards for chicken aren't that high so to do THIS bad, especially when everyone says how good it was, wow. So disappointed. The meat itself was nice and moist, so my boyfriend and I just pulled off the fried part, but come on, that's the whole point of fried chicken. Now, in all fairness to Front Porch, maybe that night something was wrong with their recipe. Maybe they ran out of some sort of spice. I definitely did here the table in front of us commenting on how strange the chicken tasted, and I heard the table next to us a little while later talking about how it had barely any taste either. So maybe I went on an off night. But with the reputation this place has, having an off night is completely unacceptable. 

By the time the bill had come, we had spent almost $100, half because of that expensive bottle of wine the waitress snuck in.  but the other $50 was a cheeseburger, fried chicken and an appetizer. That's crazy. I could have made at home for that for half as much. Front Porch is just really ridiculously overpriced.

I can say that I will not dine in at this restaurant again. I would definitely pick up the crab and grits to go, and that's why this place gets two stars instead of one, but other than that, Front Porch is on my sh!tl!st.
author: Elly S.

description: I was disappointed by this place; Front Porch averages 4 stars so I had high hopes. We ordered the $32 chicken bucket.... the chicken was disgusting - terrible gamey taste and fatty, gross meat. Not sure why we didn't just go to KFC. Do most people really prefer dark, fatty, gross chicken over lean, white meat? After being disgusted at dinner, my girlfriend and I had a gross taste in our mouths for an hour or so after leaving. The macaroni and cheese was mediocre: just cheese and pasta and nothing special like most of the other expensive and small (but tasty) mac & cheeses that are available in the city. Very weak flavor. The collared greens were good but had been doused in vinegar.  Will not go back to spend a lot of money for bland or gross food.
author: Skal Z.

description: I used to be a huge fan, but its not the same.  Loved the fried Okra and the cornbread is lovely, but the rest of the food is just a little off the mark for the wait and the money.
author: Kelley F.

description:
When I was told my recent dinner party was shifted our eating grounds to The Front Porch, I looked them up online and got excited. Excited because I love Creole/Cajon food, and there is a dearth of it in San Francisco.

Arriving at Front Porch, you realize the name itself is kind of a misnomer. It's really more of an In Law, or maybe even a Garage. Those are far less appetizing monikers, so I can certainly understand the artistic licensed used. We were greeted by friendly enough people, who when informed there were six in the party, asked if we had reservations. We were told no reservations would be necessary, so it was a little odd to be asked, especially considering the restaurant was completely empty. Also, it should be noted, the entire staff was wearing fake mustaches - I saw this as a good thing. I can appreciate a fun atmosphere.

I ordered the shrimp with grits, appetizer portion, and a side of macaroni and cheese. I found the portion a fair size - in fact, it didn't really look any smaller than the full plate one of my friends got. Sucks for her, I guess. The shrimp were cooked very well, the grits nice and creamy, with chunks of smoked bacon swimming among the flotsam.  All good. The problem was in the sauce, which was a reduction of shrimp stock. I love shrimp. Damn this was shrimpy. A completely unbalanced dish, lacking any kind of expert touch. But I really like shrimp, so I ate it just fine.

My macaroni and cheese was very, very average. I like creamy macaroni & cheese, not the dry and crumbly. But alas, macaroni and cheese is comfort food. The worst I ever had (as long as they don't screw around and put asparagus or artichokes in it) was perfectly edible. This is not a ringing endorsement.

My friends weren't so lucky. They all ordered full entrees.

My wife and another ordered the shrimp Po-Boy. It came with  sweet peppers and shoestring sweet potatoes. That sounds awesome. What they got got a section of baguette, with the middle hollowed out. Four or five pieces of shrimp inside with at most three (my friend got two) slices of pepper inside with them. This was drenched in a sauce that soaked the bottom of the bread, rendering it only edible by fork and knife. Po Boys are SANDWICHES! They are meant to be picked up and eaten. If you are going to force the customer to eat them with a fork, you need to make the bread soft enough so this isn't a pain in the ass. And the sandwich was buried under a mound of 25% burnt sweet potato fries. For around $15. BOO!

Another friend got the vegan option for the evening, the stuffed tomato. This was a very average size heirloom tomato filled with quinoa and baked. That's it. No sauce. Nothing with the quinoa. A fucking tomato with a cup of quinoa was supposed to be an entree. $15. 

The final diner got the perloo. It kept getting referred to as jambalaya, but it was nothing of the sort. I assume it was supposed to be pilau, a spicy chicken and rice dish of African origin sometimes seen in the Southeast US. Jambalaya, on the other hand, should have something that crawls, something that flies, and something that swims to qualify it as such. Whatever it was, my friend had no major complaints, except that it wasn't "really that great."

Salads were also gotten. The girl that also ordered the tomato complained that she made a better salad for lunch. $8.

When the group went their separate ways, almost immediately a round of texts and phone calls ensued, complaining about our meal. 

Each of the dishes we ordered were indefensible failures, both in concept and execution.

If you look for solid value, a lack of pretentiousness, and decent southern comfort food, look elsewhere.

By the way, I don't give bad reviews lightly - please see my other reviews.

If you're looking for another trendy place you can tell all your hipster friends was great, but don't actually care what the food is like, this just might be your joint.
author: Chuck N.

description:
It's OFFICIAL:  I. AM. OLD.

When some friends of mine suggested trying The Front Porch I, of course, went running to Yelp to find out the scoop.  Things that popped out at me were this:  fried chicken (yes!), sangria (yes, please!), small (oh.), noisy (ah, hell no) and crowded (dammit!).

As soon as I came upon The Front Porch. . .it reminded me of the song Love Shack from the B'52's. . .except I was inserting "The Front Porch" into the lyrics.  

sing it with me:
. . ."The Front Porch is a little old place where we can get together". . . 

and we did. . .a table for five. . .which ends up being four people stuffed into the booth and one stuck out at the end in a chair that keeps getting kicked ALL NIGHT.  I got the dunce chair. . .it was that or it would have been a table for seven what with my boobs sitting on the table. . .it's tight.  I am not petite.  'nuff said.   At least I wasn't the guy in the big booth at the entrance. . he managed to eat an entire meal with one butt cheek hanging off the bench. . .he must take yoga.

. . . "glitter on The Front Porch" . . . 

it's really cute in there. . .kitschy decor abounds and the waitstaff is fun to look at as is the clientele. . .it's an interesting mix of folks.

. . ."you're what???? Tiiiiiiiiiiiiin roof. . ..Rusted!!!". . .

did I mention the ceiling is covered with what looks like pounded tin?  Tin = din.  As in I might have agreed to have a surrogate baby for my friends as I could not hear them at all . . . I just sat at the end of the table nodding at anything they said.  I got tired of shouting "What?"  "Huh?"

. . ."Folks linin' up outside just to get down" . . . 

It was packed at Prime Time Saturday night. . .we placed our order and waited.  And waited.  Kitchen (which is teeny tiny) was working at maximum speed. . .man, I can't imagine working that line!  We ordered a mix of appetizers.  The appetizers come in these huge negative space bowls. . .what that means is. . . HUGE bowl, small amount of food.  When you're packed five to this table it makes for some interesting juggling.   The fried chicken livers over brioche was the clear winner for the evening - and it filled with bowl.  The disparity between the sizes of the appetizers was weird. . .the chicken livers could have almost been a main course. . .my friend's Waldorf salad was teeny tiny (but delicious), my boyfriend's ceviche was all chips, very little ceviche (he kept asking me where the rest was), my collard greens with tomatoes and cornmeal ricotta fritters was truly delicious. .but again tiny amount in the negative space bowls. .. the fritters were incredibly good. . .but the tiny amount of greens was kind of a bummer.   The whole reason we were here was for the fried chicken . . .or at least that's why I was there.  We ordered a bucket for the table and it was fantastic.  The chef took something that everyone has a different recipe for and made it uniquely her own.  Quite wonderful - crispy, juicy and tender.  The sides were spicy and sweet Brussels sprouts which are some of the best I've ever had and grits that made you want to cry from happiness.   There was a glitch and one of the entrees we ordered came out almost ten minutes later than the rest of the food.  The front of the house guy (who I overheard telling someone was the chef's partner . . .these days it's unclear if that's strictly business partner or partner as in life partner) is the man. . . we were late and he handled that with aplomb and didn't make us feel like lepers and when our entree didn't arrive in a timely manner, he apologized profusely . . even though we weren't even really worried about it. . .whatever kind of partner he is, I hope they keep him around because he is great.

. . . "I can't hear you"  . . .

My boyfriend leans over and puts his head on my shoulder. . .awww. .. how sweet. . then he shouts in my ear "Rub my leg, honey, I've got a Charley horse and it's killing me!"  As I reached down to rub his leg I noticed how stuffed into the booth he was but he wanted dessert. . . the dessert menu is VERY simple with just a couple of items.  My friends order the layer cake and my honey ordered ice cream.  The ice cream is from Mitchell's and we all swear the cake was from a mix. .. which just can't be. . .there is too much love put into the rest of the food for that to be true. . .but that's what it tasted like.  The desserts were comped to make up for the late entree. . nice!

as we gathered ourselves to leave I thought about how I'd like to come back. . .maybe on a Monday or Tuesday night at 5:30 when it might be mellow and quiet. .. sort of an early bird (mmm chicken) special if you will . . Then I thought. . .I might as well just retire and move to frickin' Florida. . .I. Am. Old.


. . . "Just a funky old shack and I gotta get back". . .
author: Lainie L.

description: I happened across this place the other day on my way to Mitchells. Tucked into a side street next to Safeway, the restaurant seems very unassuming and almost more like a side bar you'd encounter on a stroll through the neighborhood. But the inside ambiance is great--it has a very comforting feel, low lights, music and mellow crowd sipping wine or beer. They keep their fare simple and have a limited bar (no fancies). No cappuccinos either folks, serving only plain coffee, but it is good, with flavors strong and nutty. they have delicious, home food style entrees like quail, catfish and po'boys, and sides like "porch fries with spicy aioli " and baked mac n' cheese. And they have delicious desserts... we had the chocolate chess cake with praline ice cream. They are open until about 10:30, so its a nice place to unwind after work or for a first (or hundredth) date.
author: Heleena H.

description: I can't say it's bad but I can't say there was anything that stood out to me in the two times I've noshed here...except the friend chicken, 2 out of three times that was super noms. Generally the food is sometimes really good and sometimes meh.
author: Juliann B.

description: The fried chicken is off the chain good. Not greasy or dry. It is one juicy piece of perfection. I'd recommend ordering the bucket for two if you're dining with a friend. My only qualm would be that it comes with garlic mashed potatoes and collared greens which were a bit underwhelming. The arugula salad was very tasty and a great appetizer to start since the chicken does take 25 minutes to make. (Worth the wait). I'd also recommend the burger, it was pretty damn tasty. The bun wasn't amazing, but the burger itself was yummy. My recommendation for FP is to may be have a little bit brighter lighting in here though, since it was very dark in the far corner where we were seated. May be next time I'll request to not be shoved in the back corner. All in all, a pleasant dining experience.
author: Kristy H.

description: The front porch is a homestyle Cajun place with a nice palette of flavors.  I came here with some co-workers a while back and enjoyed the small, cozy ambiance. Their bucket of Chicken was pretty good, and they don't spare the oil in much of their cooking [so don't count on anything being too healthy here]. They also have a tasty hot sauce that they bottle and sell--I need to go back to get some more as mine is finished. If you want stuff spicy, they aren't afraid to spice it up to the max, just ask for it. Service was standard and parking was a bit hard, but it's a good place to visit if you want some Creole food.
author: Neha T.

description:
sugary drinks featuring the likes of guava juice? check.

an interesting veggie option? check.

delicious french fries to balance previously mentioned? check

a place that you would eat at just because its so charming? yes.

yet also delicious so double the reasons? yes.

southern flair with collard greens and chicory salads? mmmmmm
author: Liz S.

description:
situated in a garage, looking more of an "in-law apartment" with rocking chairs and table in their so-called "FRONT PORCH" is this place where they serve good-tasting soul/caribbean dishes.

we were seated by a host in his best demeanor at the back room, with the view of the kitchen and an emanation of an disinfectant from the restroom...though this scent dissapated quickly.

the chair that are against the wall are long bench seat from some truck with seat belts still intact...nice touch!

a complimentary sweet cornbread with chili butter and two super petite toast with sour cream and hot sauce on top was offered while waiting for our meal. 
these items were amusingly delicious and i was tempted to ask for more, but i controlled myself....so, i considered that a little nudge of this to my stomach was all i need.

our main plates came smelling heavenly and piping hot to our table.

the "miss ollie's fried chicken" was satisfactory. they used corn meal to coat the 3 pieces of chicken, the mashed potatoes that seems liked mixed with sweet potato was divine, as well as the creamed collard greens with a right amount of coconut milk.

the "porch chop with beans" was stunning. the size of that pork was colossal..it was thickedly cut..no wonder the waitress suggested to have it cooked medium-rare which i agreed. 
the beans was rightly baked, the slaw had a smoked taste to it...interestingly tasty and the plantain was nicely fried with butter and pureed cilantro sparingly spread on top.

we ate without talking, for we can do that later. we just savored this wonderful foods and picking at each other dishes without asking permission.

dinner last night was one of the best i had.
author: Nelle A.

description:
i like fried chicken

maybe not as much as my african brother pdub or my mini brother eze

their fried chicken is probably the best ive ever had, like woah good

other stuff is pretty solid also, but like seriously if you come here you shouldnt really be thinking about other stuff

pretty trnedy venue
author: Cristopher K.

description:
this is THE place to go in the bernal/mission area...there are a lot of hipsters milling about...who sit at my reserved table and are totally absorbed with each other's hipness and delay my seating for almost an hour...but hey, hipsters are too hip to notice me glaring at them from the bar.  i've never seen this done before at a dining establishment but the owner actually asked the hipsters to vacate the table - now, i thought that was really hip!  it would've been hipper if he'd done it an hour earlier...but well whatever.

anyway, i have to agree with the hipsters in one respect, this place is kind of romantic and a good place to go on a date.  there are some cushy booths and candles and gooey chocolatey desserts that will make you and your date melt into each other in the hippest hip way possible.  yeah.
author: Tabatha Y.

description:
Overall, The Front Porch is a great dining experience. Quality food, decadent flavors, tasty libations and southern hospitality.

Corn bread - awesome, moist, flavorful and a little spicy.
Rose sangria - interesting, fruity and served with a bendy straw. I felt like a kid and almost forgot I was drinking sangria.
Fried chicken - the chicken actually had flavor. Most fried chicken is only flavored on the outside, but this chicken was moist and the meat itself was flavorful. It was a little tangy, which I loved.
Baked Mac & Cheese - rich, decadent and very good. I couldn't eat too much of it because it was very rich. 
Vegan options - I know, I just raved about the fried chicken, so why would I complain about vegan options? I'm a part time vegan with a weakness for fried chicken. There, I said it. While they had a few vegan options, I think they could be more adventurous. There are many cajun/southern/soul food options that can made vegan. I make a mean vegan jambalaya. 
They also gave us a little amus bouche before our dinner. It was a cream of broccolini soup topped with some Mexican cheese. It was delicious and a very nice touch to the meal. 
Priced well considering the quality of ingredients. It's not cheap, but I wouldn't say it was overpriced. Everything here is hearty and filling.

The ambiance was very comfortable and relaxed. You feel like your in someones house. Well technically you are. The Front Porch is basically a garage and basement of a house. 

The decor is funky, quirky and soulful. The music fit the ambiance very well. I swear over the period of our dinner I heard some indie folk rock (think The Dirty Projectors) and even some Gucci Mane! Now that's my kind of place!!

My only two minor complaints are that they didn't have soy milk or a non dairy creamer for coffee. C'mon, you have a vegan plate but no soy milk. (I know someone reading this is saying: "But you just ate fried chicken and mac & cheese!!" True, but I prefer not to have cream in my coffee, but I did, and I'll probably suffer, but it was worth it) Also, they charged us $2.50 per person for cakeage. We brought our own cake for my friend's birthday. There were seven of us, so we ended up paying $17.50 for cakeage, which probably cost more than the cake itself!!
author: Joshua C.

description:
So to sum up right up front, Front Porch is too busy for its own good.  

Now to start at the beginning: I had been looking forward to fried chicken all week as Front Porch was the Friday night plan for date night.  We arrived at 8pm prepared for good ole southern comfort food.  Now I am not a naive person -- I knew that we would have to wait.  And with King Cobra and their Sweet Tea and Basil cocktail, I thought my date and I were well equipped for the 30 minute wait we were given after putting our names down...

As it turns out, however, we were in for a good hour and a half wait before we would be seated.  The hostess was obviously overwhelmed by her list of names and people trying to pack inside (it was cold to be out on the porch) but such an inaccurate time table is pretty dangerous when you have hungry people awaiting.  I know things move slower in the South, and we would have been absolutely fine with an hour and a half wait if we knew to expect it.  You know, some mac & cheese at the bar, or maybe some fritters.  I mean we could have just eaten at the bar but when you think at any given point in time you could be called and sat, it just keeps you antsy.  And when we asked the hostess about the status on the wait, there were always two hypothetical groups in front of us, despite the fact that groups were being seated intermittently.  It looked as if she was seating groups of three or four who arrived after us at four-tops and keeping us on the wait list until a two-top opened.  Not a way to win diner's hearts.

So by 9:30 when we did finally get to sit, we got the corner table in back by the bathrooms and open kitchen.  It was cozy sitting next to each other on the old car style bench seats, and being able to see inside the kitchen gave us plenty to talk about.

As for the food, they were out of their fried okra -- one of the 4 vegetarian dishes the girlfriend was looking forward to.  The Yard Clippin' salad was a nice blend of sweet and savory.  We had the fritters that were great.  The fried chicken was good, but the mashed potatoes had the texture of the instant boxed type.  The kitchen was accommodating by making a side of their sweet potato fries that are generally only served with the po'boy. And by the end of it I was full but a little less than satisfied.

The food was good, but Farmer Brown is better.  The service was obnoxiously overwhelmed by a what sounds like a pretty medium sized crowd for the place. I was looking forward to Mitchell's ice cream afterward, but by the time we finally got out of there, that desire was killed.

I would recommend a week night visit to the front porch -- I'd hope that the service would probably manage a little better on a Tuesday...
author: Alec D.

description: Fried chicken in paper buckets, bacon and mollasses and brussel sprouts, blackened catfish, hush puppies, man this place is amazing.  The service is awesome, the atmosphere, the seating, the coffee mugs tie it all together.  I will be back here in a second.
author: Stephen R.

description:
I had dinner here last night with a large group. We made reservations which was helpful. We also have been looking forward to eating here for a couple of months. I have heard people rave about the fried chicken so I wouldn't think of ordering anything else. BIG mistake. The chicken was as bland as a piece of Wonder Bread which was probably used as the breading! It was a huge disappointment. 
The fried okra was good which is why it gets ONE star.
Oh, and our food didn't  all come  at once either. My daughter was the last to be served (it was at least 10 minutes after everyone else) and she ordered the pasta with cheese and butter off the kid's menu. Typically, the kid's plates come first.  I only know this from 12 years of dining out with my children but whatever! And how long does it really take to boil some pasta?
The waitress informed us that the chef is new. What does that mean? He was hired in off the street and he doesn't know what he's doing?! The famous Front Porch fried chicken recipe went with the previous chef? Unacceptable.
Maybe it's my bad for not eating here sooner but I'm thinking that I may have to take to calling places first to inquire about the tenure of the person preparing my food! Extreme measures for an extremely bad experience.
author: Angel B.

description: We finally decided to check this place out. We actually found parking. Wow! We ordered the fried chicken. It was good but not crazy amazing. We also had the gumbo seafood. The gumbo seafood I did not like, my boyfriend did not like it either. It was fishy an did not taste like gumbo. Maybe that is just the way they make it. Not sure if i will go back unless with a big group. Staff was nice
author: Ge I.

description:
In the process of yelping about the subpar ketchup at Slider's on Ninth, I was reminded of the out of this world ketchup at The Front Porch. I want to incorporate their ketchup into any and all future lovemaking, it's so delicious. If ketchup is your thing (it is SOOOOO my thing), you will love me for tipping you off to FP. I'm going to outline the Front Porch plan for you:
On your first trip, get the sangria while you're waiting for a table or while you're getting familiar with the brief, but widely varied menu. The sangria is pink (my fave color), tanngy, and velvety. It reminded me a little of pink lemonade. Order the sweet and spicy nuts, too (they're better than the ones at Solstice!). For your first trip, you MUST get the burger. It is some kind of super high quality cow, that you don't find in many SF restaurants (no! not kobe...something else...the bossman was telling my dining companion about it while I was getting pretty in the ladies'). Order it medium rare. Then order some red wine. That's all you- just make sure it's red. When your enormous burger comes (and bacon and cheese are included in the $11 pricetag), douse that sucker in the sexy sexy homemade spicy ketchup and dig in. But wait! There is a pile of potatoes that accompanies the burger...I swear they dust the potatoes with crack. Even Atkins couldn't keep me from wolfing those puppies down.  Douse those with ketch up too...more...more...that's right. The red wine brings the whole thing full circle and you will be too full for dessert. Order it anyway and start  your diet over again tomorrow.
I actually considered stealing the jar of ketchup from our table but my friend convinced me to leave it by promising we'd go back next week.

Other highlights: The pork chop made a pork-eater out of me and the heirloom tomato salad starter was all dressed up with pickled bits of veggies and a smooth, spicy mayo.  The crumbly cornbread comes with an addictive sweet-buttery-lardy spread that I opted to eat with my spoon...

UPDATE! Couldn't resist the urge to go back last night. Seems like the reviews in the Chronicle and other publications have paid off. The place is hopping. We waited an hour and a half for a table for two, and never complained once. The friendly waitstaff remembered us and we enjoyed that addictive sangria and spicy champagne cocktails at the bar until a table opened up. You MUST try the ceviche! It comes with homemade chips that I couldn't resist dipping in that naughty, naughty ketchup. ALSO...made a salmon lover out of me, and I have never liked fish. The luscious cornbread was served piping hot and again, I ate ALL of the butter-sugar-pepper spread that came with it. The burgers are Uruguayan beef, same as the good Argentinean beef we can't get here, apparently. Get yourself over there! The food rocks, the crowd's cool, and the staff are refreshingly friendly and familliar.
author: Autumn K.

description: Great place for a date... We ordered the bucket of fried chicken which it took a while to bring out... but the staff were so friendly and made up for it by throwing a couple of appetizers... that i didnt mind. I really like the cozy feel to it.... Diff will visit this place again.
author: Alfredo N.

description:
After I heard the magic words "fried chicken" and "sangria," I knew I had to try The Front Porch.  So, last night, Maria D and I braved the sprinkle to pig out on the famed bucket of chicken.  I had in fact skipped lunch so as to hone my hunger to a fine point, so I was in good shape.

Since we got there relatively early (~6:30), the wait was not so bad.  The owner himself took our names and told us that the wait would be short, around 20 minutes, and in fact came back once or twice to update us on our table.  It took a while to get our drinks at the bar, odd considering that the bartender only had wine and beer to pour and not much at that.  I quite liked the rose sangria, and I am not always the biggest rose fan (although I did miss the chunks of fruit in my jungle juice, but no biggie).  The bartender told us that we could eat there at the bar, and given how long it had taken just to get drinks from her, we were like, no thanks, little lady, which seemed to offend her a little.  This was an insight into the kind of dodgy server behavior tempered by the extreme niceness of the aforementioned owner that we would experience throughout the evening.

We got our table, and the owner set us up with a couple of wines in a box (think juice box, but with vino), and the waitress came to take our order.  We got the bucket of chicken with the fry trio and the collard green/black eyed peas/ham hocks as our two sides, and then decided that we'd also like an appetizer of the sweet and spiced nuts to snack on.  What followed was a bizarre conversation with our waitress:

Waitress: Since you're getting the bucket of chicken, you might want something light for your appetizer, like the salmon ceviche.
(some conference amongst ourselves)
Me: No, I think we'd like to try the spiced nuts, they sound really good.
Waitress: Yeah, but I think if you're getting the nuts and the chicken, that's too much.
Me: Well, we're hungry girls.  Spiced nuts it is.
Waitress: Would you also like to get the salmon ceviche?  It's really good.
Me: Uh, no, I think that's a bit much.
Waitress: Well, I mean, it's not like you're going to eat all the chicken.  You can take the leftovers home.
Me: We'd like to try and eat it all.
Waitress: Salmon ceviche?
In Unison: NO!  NUTS!

And by the way, the nuts are fantastic.  And in a little bowl, definitely nothing that is going to fill one up significantly more than salmon ceviche.  The trio of fries, served with mayo, especially the sweet potato fries, were really yummy, as were the collard greens/b.e.p./ham hocks.  I don't know that the fried chicken is my favorite, but a) it's served in a bucket, b) it's still tasty, and c) the cold leftovers the next day were actually good (usually cold fried chicken is a pale and clammy imitation of its warmer cousins).  Our dessert was great, too - sweet potato and plaintain fritters in warm chocolate sauce.  Mmm.  The waitress made some weird vaguely snarky comment that we would see the dessert menu and then want our check and something else to the effect that she didn't really need to show us dessert menus in the first place.  We were there for a surprisingly long time and I think she was trying to hustle us out a little, but once again, sweet owner seemed in no hurry to make us leave.  I think if it were up to her she would have booted our spiced nut loving booties out the door a lot earlier.

Odd service aside, I loved the experience.  Good food, great setting, and it was really nice to have a long, relaxing, delicious meal. 

Update: I am just going to keep updating this review, apparently, because every time I go here the service is a little different.  On my most recent visit, the wait was predictably long, but we actually got faster than normal service at the bar, and our waitress didn't avoid us per usual.  Happy day!
author: Tanya N.

description:
really southern-fabulous good. i mean, finger lickin fried chicken, buttery-sweet brussel sprouts, creamy yummy mashed potatoes. i ate way too much, and enjoyed every bite. four of us shared the bucket of chicken that arrives--quite adorably--in a retro popcorn bucket. (ps, don't try to eat the popcorn, it's not so good). along with a couple of sides. and it was more than enough food. unless you actually eat like a real southerner, you'd be fine putting 5 or 6 skinny cali bitches on this bucket. 

that chicken was really delightful. sweet and juicy on the inside, perfectly fried on the outside. and they manage to keep it moist all the way thru, even the white meat. i wanted it to have a lil more kick to it, but that's my only complaint. i'd love to try everything on this menu--it's all a fusion of southern and carribean--and will definitely be back to explore a lil more. i wasn't super crazy for the bread pudding dessert. it wasn't moist and chewy enough for me. 

the restaurant has a fun downhome, yet dark feel. it's like a creaky old house on the bayou. minus the toothless cajun with the beard. and it's so cute that they have rockers out in front for sipping beers and watching the uh...interesting?...patrons of the international club across the street. (word has it they're in the whoring bizness) which brings the authenticity of the front porch up a notch--very bourbon street. it's a bit of an effort to get here, way on the outskirts, and this is the for real mission, so if you're a girl arriving alone, that walk from mission street is a lil scary. watch out for men hanging out in doorways. 

fun music--when was the last time you went to a restaurant that played someone as fabulously nasty as missy elliot??--and their drink menu is creative and well priced. the service is fine, not super friendly,  but they were on it. and when we had a mishap of some of the bussers accidentally spilling on some of our coats, the manager was totally generous, handing over his card and telling us to send him the bill.
author: rachel p.

description:
i have a huge huge not-so-secret crush on the front porch right now.

it's charming (rocking chairs and a tin roof)

it's casual (conch fritters, plantains, fried okra)

it's smart (the persephone -- fabulous cider drink with pomegranate, a nod to my favorite high school mythology class)

it's even a little adventurous (shrimp porridge)

and sexy (everything about the cute cozy little place).
author: Lija H.

description:
I love places like these because they are better than friggin Christmas.  It is a little San Francisco gem that no tourist would ever find unless they know someone in the know. It is tiny , it is crowded and it is noisy but it feels like you are having a big crazy family dinner. However, the food is a lot more delicious  than Mom could ever make (unless your Mom comes from the Caribbean, that is.) 
We started with the heirloom tomato salad which was incredible.  I had the fried chicken and friends opted for the pork and beans and the oxtail stew.  I can't think of a single complaint about anything I tasted and I practically licked my plate.  To sooth the tummy, I of course asked the waiter if he could join me in a shot of Fernet.  He said that, lamentably, they did not serve Fernet (GASP!) but he had something even better called ....sssmsmslsosadd. Ummm ok, that wasn't the name of it, it actually started with a U and sounded German, but it came in Tabasco-like bottle and was all wrapped up fancy-like.  I don't think it topped Fernet for me, but the great intention was there.  
The evening ended perfectly as when I stepped out for a P-Funk.  The chef, Sarah, was there and I had the pleasure of sharing  some wine with her.  She is a talented chef and an intoxicating person.  Thanks for a great meal, Sarah.  I will definitely be back.
author: Jennifer s.

description:
*Not a good place for a group over four...
*Certain wait staff trained by Nazi's, and the main reason I will NEVER               
  return.
*"Prized" house special is cold, peppered crab on grits, and it's NOT good.

Save your money and go somewhere else!
author: J B.

description: Sarah Kirnon has left The Front Porch and taken her menu with her.  NOTHING is as good as it used to be.  Tragic, indeed.  However, the good news is I hear that she is starting up a new restaurant in Oakland! So, hopefully this is to be continued....
author: Jay W.

description: I'd come back for the ambiance rather than the food. Hush puppies tasted bitter, is that normal?
author: S K.

description: Well, it doesn't exactly live up to its hype, but it's okay.  It's funny that I'm paying twice (well, probably more like thrice or quadrice) as much for "southern food" as back home and it's nary even half as good.  But beggars can't be choosers.  There just ain't much good old fashioned home cooking in this town.  SO said that the fried chicken was too salty and tasted overly burnt (she has to report on the fried chicken, since i don't roll that way anymore) and SO knows fried chicken from what for, having been to the pinnacle of fried chicken perfection - Cindy Dee's in Sandy Hook, Maryland.  And I got the vegan one pot stew, which was okay, but not quite okay enough to bother finishing the leftovers the next day.  Also, crowded and dark.  Appears that the restaurant is in someone's basement.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I took a vegetarian friend to the Front Porch for dinner.  It is one of my favorite 'special occasion' restaurants.  For some reason my friend was inspired to try the ceviche I had ordered.  He took a bite and then his eyes kinda rolled back in his head and his face turned red.

"Are you okay?" I asked.

He whispered back "I just got an erection!"

If that doesn't deserve 5 stars, I don't know what does.
author: Rebekah S.

description: The fried chicken and waffles were to die for and the mimosas was a good proportion. The place is not fancy but they sure are busy. Even had a band playing in the front of the restaurant. Parking was difficult and the restaurant did not have quarters to help with parking. Remember to bring change! Meters are for an hour at a time.
author: Kalifornia S.

description:
My God. I truly wish I could remember this meal with more clarity. It was the first hot day in SF and I celebrated with one too many brewskys if you know what I mean! The Front Porch was like a glistening oasis after dancing myself into starvation mode at El Rio. We pulled up to The Front Porch-on foot of course...and well, sat down on the front porch. A smiling host brought up our drinks and we swung back and forth on the porch swing. I had to stick with what I knew: the Poppy Jasper...I had been drinking it all day and I wasn't at a place to start making crazy decisions like switching my drink.  My friend got this crazy bio-infused cider that was made on a farm or something. The point is...it was delicious. In fact, I don't need to remember the name of it because we officially re-named it, "delicious." Yep, that's the cider's new name. It was gone in about 10 minutes anyway, so I guess it doesn't matter. Did I mention they serve tall boys here? Yep. KING COBRA. If you ever got wasted as a young teenager, you know how spectacular it is to find King Cobra on a menu...they might have even had Old E...wow.

The food was awesome. I didnt' pause long enough to really enjoy it to the fullest though. I put a hurtin' on my fried chicken and collard greens. Yum. We started with the ceviche which was good, but I remember thinking it should have had more fish in it. My date had a pork chop and it was mmm-mmm good. We completed our drunken madness with a cake of some sort. I think it was birthday cake because it was really sweet and everyone around us seemed really happy....so maybe it was a birthday cake. Who knows.

I live down the street from this place. I have been dying to try it. I have. I'll want to go back another time when I can really enjoy everything in a sober sort of way.
author: Jen G.

description:
The time has come for me to admit that, when it comes to restaurants, I have a "type."  I love the glamour and poshness of the super swank, but give me a menu with some soul, kind and clever servers, and entrees between $11 and $17 and I'm sold.  Ruth Reichl and Gael Greene would laugh at my naivete, but it takes creativity and talent to create a great experience and great food for less than $20 a plate.  Don't get me wrong - I'm certainly not claiming any virtue here.  Could be that my palette is just not developed enough to appreciate finer dining experiences, so the delicate hand of Traci des Jardins is lost on me.  Could be that I'm just cheap (although other areas of my life would certainly disprove that theory).  But, as I've learned many, many times in the past few days, there are PLENTY of people to point out our weaknesses, so no reason to do it ourselves, yes?  YES.  So I will stick with the explanation that I love good food, but am also a Woman of the People.

Clearly, I digress.  The Front Porch rocks.  The food is great, original, and fun.  The staff is relaxed, charming, and (in another display of my virtue), gorgeous.  Two of us had appetizers and entrees and wine for $60.  Much like Weird Fish, there's some soul in this place.  Go.

ps: the restaurants in town that meet my [above] criteria: Weird Fish, Birite Creamery, Front Porch, Farmerbrown (I know the food is uneven, but the spirit is there), Bluejay Cafe, NOPA.
author: Pammy C.

description:
From Bill Hicks:

"I can speak for every guy in this room here tonight. Guys, if you could blow yourselves, ladies, you'd be in this room alone right now... watching an empty stage."

I didn't have a ton of friends in high school, and I was smart enough that I didn't really need to study, so I had a lot of free time. I ended up accomplishing a lot, by a certain standard: I learned to program in a few languages, wrote two short novels, recorded about an album's worth of music, and filled my bedroom walls with amateur landscapes. When I decided I wanted to do something, I would usually end up doing it, not so much because I was committed or industrious but because I just had so little else going on. So it only stands to reason that I did, at one point, put in the months and months of difficult stretching required to put that Bill Hicks quote to the test.

It was a long process. At first my efforts led to nothing, but as the lonely nights dragged on I saw some progress. I touched the tip of it with my tongue, briefly, and that was encouraging. Eventually I was even able to put my tongue on it for sustained periods of time, although the discomfort became would stop me from continuing further. I used a technique in which I would lay my head on a pillow, and roll up into a sort of ball, with my hips directly above my head, using one hand to compress my body further and the other to pull my target closer. It put a lot of stress on my neck and on my lower back, and my body would ache in the morning and sometimes through much of the day, but it was in that way that an athlete will find somehow satisfying.

When the day finally arrived that I was able to actually get enough of it in my mouth and keep it there for long enough to make anything happen, I was somewhat disappointed. What Bill Hicks did not understand is that, for a straight man, autofellatio is a double-edged sword. It is true, you have the pleasure and arousal of having a mouth stimulate your penis; however, that arousal is countered by the rather unarousing sensation of having a penis in your mouth. All things considered it was neutral experience, on par with just sitting there. Certainly not worth the effort. However, I had made it that far, so I decided I may as well see the thing through to the end. I was a teenager so it did not take long. When I finally reached that point - well, the most comparable experience I have had since then is biting into a piece of okra in the Front Porch's vegan one pot stew. There was a lot of okra in there but the waitress let us trade down for fries and we didn't get charged for the stew. The fries were delicious, so that's cool.
author: Wayne W.

description: We sat at the bar for beers and fries.  There aren't many beers on tap, but the choices are well thought out.  We thuroughly enjoyed an hour of chatting with the staff, trying beer, and oogling over everyone else's food. The atmosphere was just what we were looking for: relaxed and homey.
author: Jordan M.

description: I feel like I'm eating in someone's garage when I'm here, but the chicken in a bucket makes it worth it.
author: Ivy R.

description:
As promised, we went to The Front Porch opening night, were seated in one of the adorable red booths, but if you have a large party there's a blue booth up front.
The restaurant is lovingly adorned with cute vintage lamps, fresh flowers, a great ceiling and very homey type atmosphere.
We began with the complimentary corn shaped corn bread with habanero butter, and chose the ceviche, tuna tartar and heirloom tomato salad, which was flecked with the best pickled veggies since Maverick. All very delicious and well put together.
Two of us had the fried chicken, which comes in a little plastic basket, but you can get an order that serves 3-4 in a bucket. You can choose from sides but we both had the grits that are flavored with an excellent chili oil and fresh peppers on top, nice little kick.
The hamburger called for some of the homemade habanero chutney, which our friend didn't think was as ass kickin as the wait staff warned, but his palate can take some spice!
Lastly our friend had the dungeness crab porridge that was a nice medley of crab flavor atop creamy habanero grits. Not too spicy though.
The menu is written with a fun attitude, especially the wine list. We started with Prosecco and beers (but not the malt liquor!) then had a box, yes, a box of Pinot Grigio with the meal. The wines are all spectacular even though some may come in a juice box with a bendy straw or a jug. The Three Thieves is actually made by Charles Bieler, Joel Gott and Roger Scommegna, well known vintners.
update: Random Friday - popped in, lucky to get seated at bar. Pork chop special to die for w/caramelized Brussels sprouts (true love!)

The amazing Sarah Kirnon, chef  at Emmy's Spaghetti Shack, Kevin Cline, the GM from Bix & Josie White (whoo hoo!) manager of Emmy's opened the former home of Dominic's Club, which dates back to 1933. Menu is gastropub inspired with affordable Caribbean influenced fare.
author: Colleen B.

description:
fried chicken...  like you can't get outside of the Southeast. 
tender yummy heaven.   (even good cold the next day.) 

Also, you can't go wrong with a restaurant that proudly serves wine both 1) by the jug and 2) in a juicebox with a bendy straw.
author: lindsay f.

description:
I hope that someone from the Front Porch staff is reading YELP posts.  I sincerely regret having to write this review, but after my most recent experience there, it's a must.  

We were HUGE fans of the restaurant.  Seriously!  The burger was the last real meal I chose to eat before going into the hospital to deliver my baby, and the first after she was born.  We loved it there, raving about it to all of our friends. Unfortunately, we looked like fools having talked it up only to be let down.

It's not the fact that it took an hour and a half to seat us, but what happened afterward.  Right from the start, it was bad. The normally delicious corn bread was much too spicy.  The baked oysters and shrimp were so-so.  But the most dissappointing part was my main course.  I opted to try the rabbit, thinking, if it's anywhere as good as their burgers and chicken, I'll be in heaven.  Instead the most expensive item on the menu was so dry I nearly choked.  No kidding.
