I had to leave the restaurant to get some air and clear my throat.  

Needless to say, I only finished the accompanying fixins, and hoped the sides would fill me up.  Oops, the waitress forgot to put in the order, so they arrived much later than the main courses AND were TERRIBLE. The sprouts, which are usually delicious, were undercooked, and the mac and cheese overcooked.  At the very least, the waitress could have comped them, but alas, they were on the bill.  UGH.  Finally, the waiter who cleared the table asked me if I was done with my fish. Fish? Well, even he couldn't believe a tender piece rabbit could be mangled so badly.

A true bummer all the way around.  The worst part, however, is that our friends will probably not trust our restaurant selection again.  

It's going to take a lot of convincing to get me back to Front Porch.  Sorry Michael Law.
author: Andrea H.

description: Damn...Tal K beat me to it. I've been wanting to try Front Porch for awhile, and finally got the opportunity last night. What a great little place! Amazing food and excellent friendly service (Thanks Pamela!) at a reasonable price. We had a jug of Pinot while we waited to be seated, then a bunch of apps (Conch Fritters FTW!), a main (OMG Crab Grits!) and a bucket of chicken. I was a bit worried that we ordered too much food for the four of us, but we managed to devour a deep fried dough concoction of some kind at the end without hesitation. Right around the corner too! I'm already looking forward to heading back to try out all the other yummy looking things on the menu. Yay Front Porch!
author: Chris R.

description:
totally disappointing.

bones to pick:

1.  food should not take an hour and a half to arrive.  ever.  especially not a hamburger.  or a pulled pork (pre-cooked) sandwhich.

2.  then, when it arrives, food should be hot.  at least warmer than the surrounding air.  

3.   food, except for oatmeal should not be served in the texture known as mush.  

3,  waitrons should be able to accurately describe the night's special, the first time.  and the second time. 

4.  collard greens should not be served as a soup unless they warn you off this.  they can be "soupy" in delicious greasy porky goodness.  they should not be served as a soup.  they were.

5.  Caribbean food is more than just jerk chicken and a side of coconut rice.
author: Jesse R.

description: one of my favourite restaurants in san francisco. i dont know much about the food...i'm vegan but want to visit all the restaurants in the bay area.... there's fried chicken though, which means most people will be happy. i love the ceiling. i like when there's noise & people talking about interesting things. cute bathrooms & good cocktails and who ever decorates has good taste in music.
author: aerin w.

description: I never thought I'd be mentioning something as simple as Brussels Sprouts in a review, but these are worthy of mention.  Suffice to say, these aint yo momma's Brussels Sprouts!  And trust me: I KNOW yo' momma' (BOY, do I know her!).  And I can tell you that she aint NEVER made no Brussels Sprouts like these!  Kinda sweet, kinda spicy... They are ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS!!!  Great décor, great ambiance, great wine list, great bartenders... The Front Porch always comes through in a pinch.  And they seem to always be busy!  I guess they're not feeling the effects of the recession there.  This place is definitely worth checking out.
author: Eric H.

description: The absolute worst place I have eaten in San Francisco.  The food was something you couldn't even describe.  Please save your hard earned money.   Horrible! Horrible! Horrible!
author: Terry M.

description: Right off the bat, I give this place four stars for just having rocking chairs and  a real porch to sit out on.  Catch 'em on a nice city night and what a great way to enjoy a Stella pint and some good conversation!  Inside is cute as all get out and although we had already eaten dinner, the menu looked very...  interesting, and therefor worth returning for.  No standard pub fare here!   I will certainly return with my appetite.  Then perhaps i can upgrade to 5 stars?  Also, they can only serve booze until midnight, which sorta sucks if you are sippin' and rockin' out on the porch and then have to stop.  However, being stumbling distance from the Knockout means you don't have to end the party right away.
author: Rina A.

description: this place is awesome! great beer selection! food is excellent! shrimp and grits is my new favorite dish in sf!!!! i cried a lil when the plate was gone... seriously. ambience is chill.. oldies in the background... just a frickin' kick ass place to eat and drink.
author: D R.

description: I went to the opening for a drink and then returned a few nights later for dinner. Drinks at this wonderfully warm bar are a joy. And what else can I say for our dinner except that the staff had to add an additional table onto our two-top to accommodate all the food we ordered, and then happily ate. I love this place.
author: Jenny H.

description: Everything about my experience last week at The Front Porch was positive.  I love everything about the look and feel of the place.  There were so many great touches, such as the car seat, and the little clip-board menus.  As for the food, we had the spicy/sweet brussel sprouts, the crab dish and the vegan special.  I thought all of them were amazing.  Our server was sweet and attentive.  When I left, I was trying to figure out how I can schedule in a trip a week to this place...
author: Betsy C.

description:
I had only heard good things...

The fried chicken was chewy and tough.

The brussel's sprouts were hard as rocks. I sent them back twice but in the end they were totally inedible. First time I've ever ordered them anywhere that they simply couldn't be eaten.

Nice ambiance, friendly servers, but I won't be going back.

In their defense, most of their food looked really good, and maybe they were having an off night. Plus, decent beer selection. Whatever.
author: blimp w.

description:
So you're sitting there, in this cozy little booth under the shiny tin ceiling, and you're contemplating the table, which has only just begun to slant under the weight of five appetizers (entrees yet to come) and you have just taken a bite of spicy crab and grits, which came after a chunky little cod fritter, and before that a drenched rib, and before that a slip of cornbread, and a beefsteak tomato, and---before everything, out on the porch, a sweet, tingly glass of rose sangria.  

And you think, "Here it is.  This has Never happened before, but I, Alisun W., am going to cry at this table in front of everyone.  Seriously, I hope no one notices, especially my nice waitress who is perhaps the best and most knowledgeable service person I have ever met, because she will think I'm weird and I want to know who did her hair later because it is super cute.  But really, I'm going to cry now, in this amazingly comforting little restaurant, at this tidy little candlelit table, during one of what I can honestly say is one of the best meals of my life (minus this awkward moment of public emotion) and I've never cried for happiness before, but whatever.  I don't even care anymore.  I love everyone.  Here I am, weeping tears of joy whilst still shoveling spoonfuls of heavenly spicy crab grit goodness into my mouth like I have just won the butter lottery.  Because I have.  And everyone else can just deal.  Or come give me a hug.  Because I'm pretty sure this emotion I am having right now, of complete joy and elation and contentedness, and memory and sensation and loveliness, could potentially cure world peace.  Also, this crying and eating thing could get messy.  I hope my cornbread does not get soggy".

I do not know how to explain the emotion of crying for happiness... over food.  And... it was an appetizer.  AN APPETIZER.  We went on to  devour lemon tinged fried chicken, and mashed potatoes, and sweet corn and black eyed peas with chunks of pork belly and slivers of collard greens.  We got fat just looking at the dessert menu.  

Now, I was just visiting friends in San Francisco, I'm not from there.  So I understand all these nit-picky reviews---you natives want only the best for your beloved city.  I get it.  I do the same to the restaurants I live nearby.  Only I really need to tell you: stop.  It's a beautiful gift to your city, this restaurant: the service is sparkly and on point, the atmosphere gorgeous, and the food--- out of this world.  Enjoy it.  Get the grits.  And an extra napkin, in case you find yourself experiencing an outpouring of buttery happiness, yourself.
author: Alisun W.

description: This is the best soul food I've had in the City!  Great ambiance and really good food...the corn bread is to die for!  The only problem was that we had to wait awhile.  The place is tiny and gets crowded on the weekends...but worth the wait!
author: Nazneen A.

description:
I went here last weekend for dinner. I heard that there was usually a line, but we got there begore 6 so we were seated right away. The decor is pretty funky. Not at all what I expected for a place called "The Front Porch." (sounds a little more country). Our chair was actually a leather seat from a car or van, so that was pretty funny. There were windows hung up all over the walls, which was pretty cool and all in all it had a nice vibe. 
We started out with Red Beans and Rice and Fried Okra with a Jalapeno Aioli sauce. They were both good and perfectly sized for appetizers and priced well at $5 bucks each. There were theree of us, so they went quickly but it was enough. We also shared the bucket of chicken with garlic mashers and cornbread. It was MORE than enough and the chicken was SO good. Our service was good and the food came pretty quickly. I felt bad at the end of the night because a guy came in to play the guitar and came around after to ask for tips. We didn't have any cash or change on us because we weren't expecting that, so that made us feel weird and kind of crummy. It was a good meal. The parking is a beast and the place is small, but it would be worth it to go back again. And Mitchells Ice Cream is pretty much right across the street. =)
author: danae k.

description: The place has a lot of charm. The space is a little limited in the evenings, but the food was fantastic. I had the frog's legs appetizer, and the burger. Both of which were quite good. The burger was served with some thick tasty bacon, and steak fries. The wait staff was prompt, and charming. I have very little negative to say about the place, the only thing that was wrong, was that my drink was a little late in getting to the table. But that is nit picking.
author: Cheston L.

description: Went here on a friend's recommendation. He said it was the best fried chicken he ever had. He's never eaten my mom in law's fried chicken. This was just so-so. Service was attentive - food just okay.
author: Nancy A.

description:
Super place - we went tonight - there were 4 adults and a 2 1/2 year old.  got there around 6 - so no wait - and the waitstaff was superb.  It was a women - she is really knowledgeable, and she just got it, really really helpful.
Food was great, service great - yes it was loud, but with a 2 1/2 year old that was cool.  They have vegan dishes which was nice - you can even get vegan red beans and rice as a nice option.  New chief, but we never went prior, so have nothing to compare it to.   Gumbo - super tasty, bathrooms clean, it was a great experience all around.  Including they have a kids menu, with great mac and cheese.
author: B C.

description: This place is great! We enjoyed wine and beer while sitting in rocking chairs on the front patio area while we waited for the rest of our party (we had no reservation and the waitress was very accommodating and didn't make us feel bad at all).  Once we were sat the service was great and every single person we dealt with was super friendly. The food was delicious, two people ordered the fired chicken which was amazing! I myself had chicken gumbo and red beans and rice and i couldn't have been happier. A couple people ordered the fried yucca which was not my favorite, not a huge fried food fan. And to top it all off i had bread pudding with yam ice cream for dessert. It was fantastic. I highly recommend this place to anyone with a craving for southern food and an affinity for quirky, off beat restaurants.
author: Megs k.

description:
My dining experience at The Front Porch was decidedly uneven. We were a group of 9. For appetizers we had the salt cod, oysters, crudo, heirloom tomato salad, plantain cakes and the fries, all of which were quite good, and the ketchup yum!!  We ordered 2 different red wines and malbec and a syrah cheaper bottles and those were tasty as well. Then came the entrees. The surf and turf special was tri-tip with 2 shrimp and the spicy potato salad. 6 out of the 9 of us ordered the special and 3 of us promptly sent it back upon arrival, 2 more wished they had and 1 ate it contentedly.   The cuts of meat were terrible, extremely fatty, very flat, not that flavorful and chewy like beef jerky.  Two of us returnees changed our orders to the grits (excellent, good amount of crab, tasty, but beware immersed in butter) and the fried chicken (crisp, moist, light flavoring) the third requested another steak. The steak that came out was amazing..thick, flavorful, tender. As it should have been in the first place and worth the $22.50 - why they served those other pieces I'll never know. 

The waitress was attentive and understanding of our returned food. The chef was also apologetic.  The busing service was slow, our empty appetizer plates and rejected steaks languished on a quite crowded table. 

4 bottles of wine, some individual cocktails, appetizers and entrees = $54 per person. 

Given the overall experience, I can't say I'd return..except maybe for those grits - hangover cure!
author: Nikke G.

description: nom nom nom.  I thought this place would be pretty good, but really, the food was just unexpectedly delicious.  The fried chicken was flavored perfectly, with the flavor permeating into the meat itself.  And the shrimp & grits were truly amazing.  And even more surprisingly, great cocktails at affordable prices.  My champagne sparkler at $6 was a steal.  Maybe it was supposed to balance out the crazy $33 price tag on the fried chicken bucket - who knows.  The only disappointing part of the meal was the red velvet cake which was too dry.  Oh well, I guess I'll just stick to the chicken and grits next time ...
author: Melinda C.

description: I'm sorry, I wanted to love the place.. really. I like the people behind this restaurant, but the combination of lack luster service (the waiter continually reminding us that he was slammed with 5 tables! ) and decent food just wasn't enough for me to wait almost 45 min for a table. How much longer will mediocre food be passed off as  "comfort" food in this city? Anyone?
author: Matthew R.

description: This has been a place that i've always wanted to go. I've lived very close to this restraunt pretty much my whole life. And I love fried chicken.............well anything fried is #1, 2, 3, 4,......83 on my favorites for food, so it was surprising that I haven't eaten here. So I was nice and hungover and in the mood for fried chicken. Its a nice little decor, a couple of tables outside with regular dining or possibly even rocking chairs to dine outside. On a nice day, it would be really great. Inside it seems almost like a bar inside, with 80s rock playing. I ordered the chicken n waffles, .....fried chicken and a nice waffle, can't go wrong with that. It takes over 20 min for the order to come out (which was stated on the menu to begin with)......but it was worth it. The waffle was nice, fluffy and with a nice slight crunch and a had a hint of cinnamon flavor. For me, it was a little too sweet for a main course but still good. But it was all about the fried chicken. I'm assuming the long wait was for the chicken and it seemed perfect. The skin was crisp with great flavor, without it feeling greasy and the meat inside was juicy. They also have a sauce, probably for the chicken, i thought it was a hot sauce, but it was more like a sweet chili sauce, a little more towards the chili side, but really, the chicken didn't need the sauce, it was that good. I would like to come back, they've got some other great sounding dishes I want to try, now I've been there, I'm probably going to be coming back more, I've broken the seal......good thing I don't live in SF or i'll have a heart attack from eating their delicious food all the time.
author: Matthew N.

description: Went here with a friend and had a great time. Get here early, as they get crowded later. The sides are particularly good, especially the mac and cheese and grits. Fried green tomatoes were only all right. The service was friendly, with just the right amount of attention.
author: Krista C.

description: As i was eating - my first reaction was "mehhh", as I continued and thought about it more - I thought that "mehhh" was just because I wanted to like the meal a little, but in truth -  It was just plain bad.  The fried chicken crust just kind of fell apart, the macaroni and cheese was just dried out macaroni with bread crumbs on it (no creaminess at all), and the burger ( i split my entree and another) - was spiced in a way that made it not so good.  needless to say I will not be back - If you want good comfort food - stick with Blue Plate.  Also with all the southern food in the city - where is the cajun  - i want good cajun food!
author: Greg M.

description: I do not think "soul food" should ever be this expensive.  Although, I guess if you don't mind that it isn't really "soul food," it is good.  Fancy "soul food" is like "fancy mexican food." Would you pay $20 for some tacos? Don't let discourage you, it is tasty.
author: Rikki D.

description: First off I've got to say I'm sad about the two stars.  I was so excited about the opening of The Front Porch.  I'm a big fan of Emmy's and was happy to hear that the family is expanding.  The food however was an enormous let down.  My friend ordered a vegetable curry with coconut rice.  What arrived was something not in anyway resembling a veg curry.  Instead it was a dull plate of cooked squash over steamed white rice.  I decided to play it safe and order a cheeseburger.  I'd been craving one for a while and hoped that The Front Porch could satisfy the craving.  Let's just say I'm still craving that cheeseburger.  All in all we had a very poor meal.  I'm sad about this but I do plan to go back.  I know it sometimes takes time for restaurants to work out their kinks both in the front and back of the house.  For now, I'll stick to the bar and maybe a snack or two.
author: Anne D.

description:
I've heard good things about the Front Porch, and I love fried chicken, so it pains me to have to write this review, however.....

The best word that I can describe my experience here was "underwhelmed".  We had the pickled veggies and fried okra for an appetizer, and they got a 3/5 star review.  Nicely seasoned, a touch too salty, but generally tasty.  For the main course we had the fried chicken bucket, and it got 1/5 stars.  The chicken was juicy and well cut, however it had NO flavor.  I've had better seasoned chicken at KFC, to be honest.  And that's just sad.   I gave a total of 2/5 stars because our waitress was nice, the water was refilled often and unobtrusively, and the setting was cozy.  However the price was too high for underwhelming food, we won't be going back.  

Save your money for House of Soul in Vallejo.  Definitely worth the drive if you're in the mood for Southern fare.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Fried chicken was juicy, but I didnt think it was anything special.

Oyster beignets- interesting, dont know if I would try them again

Fried okra was good

Fried yucca- dry and tastes like cardboard!

The only thing that I really enjoyed was the brussel sprouts...

I probably would not come here again.
author: Retired B.

description:
Some say:  "Life's better on the Porch".....well, not this one.  It's more like a garage inside, and sometimes smells faintly like a zoo.  But the oddest part is that they serve sparkling wine in those cheap, wide bottomed glasses, plus they are TINY (which could be a good thing so you have less flat sparkling wine).  

The service is fine, but I didn't realize how difficult it is to make a bacon cheeseburger and follow directions of "no bun" - all the cheese was on the bun I didn't want.  In addition, the bacon was cooked unevenly - some parts were too crispy, some parts were perfect and other parts were too mushy.  The beef itself had that wonderful undercooked center but the outside was almost blackened - an amazing feat.

I was very disappointed that I braved the faint zoo odor to have dinner (another minus - no food served on the patio).

One star for a moderately interesting list of adult beverages.
author: Daisy K.

description: Wow, I decided to go here mostly because it was getting late and we wanted dinner not far from home. I found it on yelp and it was open until 10 and close and off we went.  Parking isn't bad and the neighborhood is very nice.  The front porch of the front porch provides a great walking up experience.  The inside is a surprise it looks kinda seedy bar but instead of seedy it's trendy and decorated very intriguing in a good way.  The seating is great, we got a table that had half van seats which was very comfortable and we loved the use.  Coming from the south I have a pretty high standard for most comfort southern food and fried okra seems to be one that fails constantly when I try these type restaurants.  Well, we got the okra for an app and it was great.  I've had better but not much better.  The rest of the meal just kept giving.  I got the fried chicken which came with mashed potatoes and collard greens.  The greens were cooked perfectly which means they were tender yet had just the right amount of texture left, not mushy. The potatoes were great. The chicken was, like some other reviews state, probably the best I've had in SF.  I ordered a side of molasses coated brussel sprouts simply because I just had to try them.  They were some of the best sprouts I've had and even though the portion was huge we finished them because they were so good.  He got a burger and other than mistakenly ordering it more done than he wanted it was great as well.  Another thing that was good for me was the cask beer. It was my first beer from cask and although I normally like ice cold beer the flavor of the beer was great at room temp.  The service was super. I would say they understand southern hospitality.  Also the hot sauces are pretty amazing too.  I can't wait to go back and try more stuff.  If you like southern cajun style food and understand what it truly is then this place should be on your list.  It's great quality but feels so cozy so it just feels right. :-)
author: Rodney P.

description:
The Front Porch ROCKS!

For those who've been, you know that i'm stealing their own tagline from the cute stickers they've made. 

For all you late night eaters, check their closing time. They stop serving at 9 PM on Sundays.  I think that's true for the other nights as well... but can't remember for sure. 

The service was great. The hostess squeezed us in and helped me and my 2 friends get seats at the bar. She definitely went above and beyond to help us out, which we really appreciated. The bartender who served us was also great - no complaints... all around friendly atmosphere and vibe. 

Now the food... it's not for everyone. You can't really be thinking about that bathing suit you need to squeeze into or the New Year's resolution you're about to make. Heavy on the southern fried food, and a little less gourmet than say Blue Plate. 

To start, we split the tuna tartare that was mixed w/mayo and on crispy plaintain chips -- pretty yummy. 

Two of us ordered the fried chicken for the main course -- pretty tasty and slightly spicy. I liked it fine, but my friend wished the breading was a little doughier and less crispy/burnt. 

My other friend got the crab porridge and neither she nor I were big fans of it. It was a little too oily. However, in the words of our third friend, she loved it, but she also LOVES olive oil and could drink cups of it. 

Other favorite feature... though I wanted to try the wine in a juice box, we opted for my favorite beer - Red Stripe - purely for the novelty of it coming in a big ass bottle. 

Overall, loved it and will be back again.
author: J K.

description:
I dont like to write Yelp reviews and this is my first one, but i had such a bad experience that other people might find this helpful.  

i went in last night for their blues happy hour menu at 5:30 pm and got gypted by the long, brown haired waitress.  i told her that i saw a special on the online menu that i didnt see on the actual menu.  it was a 24 ounce beer and a po boy sandwich for $11.  she was like oh we have that special.  great, i thought.  the food was okay (at most 3 stars, fried okra are slimy and not how they should be), but the overall atmosphere is very charming.  she brought out a 10" po' sandwich and i didn't think much of it because i forgot that the special online was for a 5" po sandwich.  i guess i was more fixated on the 24 ounce of beer.  then when the bill came, i noticed that she charged me the beer separately and the sandwich for 16.50.  Come on, a 10" po boy with hardly any shrimp in it is 16.50?  The beer and sandwich came out to be $20.  I asked her about this and she said that it was the special and that people just order beer to compliment their meals.  She was obviously trying to upsell me, so she could make a bigger tip.  WHO DOES THAT???!  

I should of just went to Yats, the food is much better and there aren't shady waitresses!
author: Sarah H.

description:
I'm sooooo bummed!!!

This used to be my favorite place to eat, but sadly the new chef has broken my heart.   I don't eat any meat other than seafood and they got rid of the spicy crab and grits!!  I tried for the shrimp with grits(minus the bacon)  and the shrimp still had their heads on!!!  eyeballs and antennas all over the place!!!  My date's dinner was bland as well.   Again...what a bummer.
author: joey c.

description:
i love fried chicken. it's my favorite food in the whole world. so when i heard about this place and how good their fried chicken was, i couldn't wait to see for myself. it came out and was very good, but the smallest chickens i've ever seen! i was actually still hungry after this meal. and for almost $15 for an order i expect to be stuffed. they have really good home made habanero sauce, but i can't really say i was impressed. it's a cute setting with old mini van seats as the booths that even have seat belts, but it wasn't the most comfortable for dining. 

i might go back and try something else...but i def. would not waste money on that fried chicken. go to Hard Knox Cafe in Dogpatch instead for the best fried chicken in the city for only $9.
author: Pumakat K.

description: I really love this place.  Sure, the mission hipster vibe runs a little deep in this place, but overall everyone who works there is very friendly and attentive and the food is great.  I can't remember a single bad meal I've had here - the shrimp & grits is amazing (better than anything I've ever had in the Carolinas), the fried chicken is amongst the best you'll find in SF, and I can't tell you about dessert because I've never made it that far.
author: David T.

description:
I love me some of those crazy grits. Thank God for a vegan special or I wouldn't be able to eat anything there. I love this place, and think it's getting off to a good start. Eat, Eat, Eat, soooo good. Drink, drink, drink, yum......
7/14/07 I've eaten here several times since my last review. Being a Vegetarian for 16 years I'm used to eating sides and salads and bread when I go out to eat. But!!! The last dish I had here blew my mind! Corn chowder-Vegan- with plantain, potato and okra and something else can't remember, was Absolutely amazing. The chef Sarah is truly inspired. One of the owners, Kevin, who is  a wine expert picked out the most amazing wine to go with our meal! I was so full I couldn't eat dessert! 
The room has a warm relaxing feel. And a really good vibe. 
Yeah the city is full of hipsters, is it worse or better than dot commers?...... . I'm so sick of hearing about hipsters, if you don't like the younger people around you then hang up your hat and move out of the city, we're all getting old, your just jealous, j/k.... I think all the hippies, yuppies, dot commers, families, hipsters, punks, gangsters and grandparents, will definitely love this place. And my boyfriend says geeks, elephant trainers, pussy's, porn stars and winos will love it too. Small rant sorry...
This restauraunt gets my GREEN stamp of approval, good work!
author: heather z.

description: Unassuming from the street, to say the least.  We had Miss Ollie's fried chicken and a carafe of wine - very good.  While some say it is over-priced for "home/soul food" the portions are large enough for two to share and still be full.  I would have considered 4 stars if the ventilation hadn't been so poor (is this a common theme in my dining experience in SF) and had there been just one other person in the restaurant over 40!  Gee's, where do you kids all work - Google and Genentech?  ;-)  A good place to eat if you find yourself in the Noe-Bernal-Mission Traingle.
author: V T.

description: Nice little bar/ pub place.  It reminds me of Cha Cha Cha with entrees.  The fried chicken is just ok here.  I don't agree with the yelp consensus that their chicken is awesome.  I am fat.  I eat a lot of fried chicken.  $30 for 6 pieces of cornmeal crusted, some dry some seasoned fried chicken shouldn't be on the best of yelp.  My sister's fat manatee bf ate the entire bucket himself.  Fat ass I wanted another piece.  The burger, however, was a quality burger.  This is a yelp recommendation disappointment.  I am softening the blow for you yelpers that want to make the trek to somewhere in the mission.
author: Fatty A.

description:
We waited for about 40 minutes since they don't take reservations for less than 5 people. At least the server was nice about it when we finally sat down.  

The food was okay. The fried ocra and fired pig ears had little flavor and I felt like I was just eating batter. (they recommended it, so we tried it). I had the fried chicken, which was very good.  The collard greens were included as the side, and as Mega H describes them- "grown on Ocean Beach and thrown in" is about right. I'm not sure it was worth the $18 but at least I enjoyed the chicken.   The beer was almost the best part- but that's because it was strong beer week in SF. A big "eh" for this place.
author: Alison W.

description: This place was a sweet find- very unique/ fun environment. Had the fried chicken, which was awesome! The hubs had the jerk chicken, which was just ok. If you want something out of the ordinary with some unique flair, check this place out.
author: Alison W.

description: The service was on point, and the food was 3 stars worthy.  The fried chicken was pretty juicy, and stood out flavor wise from the rest of our order.
author: David M.

description:
Some friends and I literally stumbled on the Front Porch a couple of months back right after they opened their doors. All three of us were totally impressed and made promises to ourselves that we would have to come back and get dinner. We had a couple of beers, but were a little too late to order the fried chicken, which we all were dying to try. 
HOWEVER, i made the trip back to the restaurant a week ago and was disappointed with what i'd seen and experienced. first, the food and fried chicken was awesome, but the word is out on this place. . .
what made this little hole in the wall such a find was the uniqueness of it's interior and cozy vibe the people were giving off. when i went back to have dinner, there was an hour and a half wait filled with pushy foodie types that are making this a 'destination' from other neighborhoods. i was bummed.
needless to say, the food was great and special, but the chill vibe and cooler people were gone. perhaps in six months when the dust settles on this place, it will be time to go back.
author: Gavin H.

description: After a recent trip to NOLA we are pretty obsessed with cajun/creole food so when we went to SF over NYE we made sure to find a restaurant that could cure our craving. Front Porch seemed like an upscale version of what we were looking for, so we gave it a try. We found the restaurant in an unassuming location in city. I was surprised that the interior was so shabby, but it worked for the type of food. It actually really reminded me of a bar we went to in the French Quarter. The service was good, kinda slow we weren't in a hurry so it didn't matter. We tried the Fried Okra for our appetizer. It was pretty good if you like that kind of dish. My husband had the Oyster Po Boy which he said was good, but didn't blow him away. My girlfriend and I split the Chicken and Waffles and Muffaletta. The fried chicken was exceptional. I still don't understand the big deal about eating chicken with a waffle, but it was still tasty. The muffaletta was a disappointment, but I think I am biased because of my love for Central Grocery. The bread was toasted, which made it too hard to eat. The insides were good, but there wasn't enough olive salad and some unnecessary mayo on the bread. I want to try Front Porch for their Saturday/Sunday brunch because that menu looked good. Overall, it is a good place to get a cajun fix.
author: Allison M.

description: Aside from their fantastic fried chicken, I've had the po boy specials twice (oysters and catfish) and they have both been great.  And of course, sweet potato fries are always special.  Also a phenomenal set of beers available (my wife loves the dog bite mix).  The atmosphere is quaint and a drink on the the front porch is a fine way to get the evening kicked off.  The service has always been courteous and punctual.  Appears to be enough of a hidden gem that we have been able to slip in with minimal wait, even on the weekends.
author: Matt C.

description:
Thanks to Front Porch, I enjoyed excellent fried chicken without having to shampoo fried-chicken scent out of my carpets and drapes!
I can't remember the last time I had fried chicken, but recognized the aching in my bones and the empty feeling in my heart to be the tell-tale symptoms of fried-chicken deprivation.
Boy was I satisfied...God DAMN, I said GOD DAMN...hallelujah, amen, and everything in between. 
The chicken was wonderfully juicy, the crispy skin was the perfect texture, and it was just enough to not take home any leftovers. Leftover fried chicken is akin to Harrison Ford - it doesn't age well.
I also enjoyed the accompanying pot o' comfort with black eyed peas and pork fat (insert sound-bite of Homer Simpson making that drooling sound - y'know, with head tilted, eyes rolling to the back of head, and tongue out - kinda like orgasmic gargling) and collard greens.
The little corn-shaped corn breads were tasty as well, though I had to fight the urge to pick up the little faux-cob and take it down in two bites. 
My Red-Stripe tall-boy served me well.
So why not the fifth star?
The cake. 
I know, I know, I can't go around expecting to discover a ground-breaking cake recipe every time I go to a new place. The only good thing about it was the sweet cream that covered half the plate. 
Hmmmm. Sweet cream.
Overall, a great experience and definitely worth a re-visit or ten.
author: Jessa B.

description:
Okay, so there were some definite hits and some definite misses.  Tonight, we started with the special, which included hush puppies and salt cod.  The hush puppies, although there was only three, were extremely tasty.  The salt cod reminded me of fish on the verge of being bad.  I had one small bite and advised my companion that it was NOT good.  Moved on to the cornbread with chili butter, which was complementary: TRES good.  Main entrees selected were the fried chicken with a side of chili oil grits and the fish and chips.  I had the chicken and grits.  I make my own fried chicken and I make it damn good.  There was strong flavor in the chicken, but the batter just crumbled, which I didn't like.  My date's fish and chips were bleh.  Oh, did I mention I had the sangria, which amounted to wine, a shitload of water, and a few chucks of peaches?  I wasn't a fan - especially with places like Esperpento in my culinary recollections.  

Okay, so here comes the piece de resistance: the fucking dessert!  To D-I-E.  Had the deep fried brioche with melted chocolate, fresh whipped cream and a spoonful of peanut butter.  Holy shit: this made my millenium.  Loved it.  Can you tell?

For sixty bucks, we fared well.  I thanked the chef for a good meal, and we were off.

OH, I forgot about the grits!  Buttery texture, little kernels of corn in a few bites, and the chili oil.  Nicely prepared and very good combination.
author: Tamar D.

description:
like the lakewood antiques fair in atlanta, with lower ceilings and dimmer lights.  that is, until the food comes out.  

and someone must have told you to order the fried chicken, right? you should. it's a standout meal - all TWO pieces of chicken with a shallow puddle of perfect blackeyed peas, grits and collards.  any chance the chef reads yelp reviews?  darling, (i know she's a lady because she signs her menus like an album jacket), darling you've got to know that GOIN' FANCY doesn't have to mean using those saucer-plate hybrids that hold child-size portions!

also of note: the tiny cornbread fritters (that capture the delicate relationship between sweet and salty) baked in corn cobb molds and served with honey butter are straight from food-museum-land i'm sure.

REDUCED to 2 STARS: why does everything taste like pepper? blech.
author: Kris P.

description:
Oh sweet lordy yes!! Totally what the neighborhood needed, and the owners have executed this place perfectly. Fun, cozy, warm inside, semi-open kitchen, music, bar, happy staff, right-size menu, great prices, gawdam tasty eats... exactly how I wish more spots in SF were like. Started with the heirloom tomato/pickled veggie and greens plate with spicy mayo dressing, and a couple a corn-cob shaped cornbread muffins. I licked the damn plate when I was done! Main meal was; she: the cornmeal crusted Fried chicken with a side of grits n' spicy peppers in infused oil; me: skirt steak with street-corn (grilled half cob on a stick) and 'tater salad. We polished off everything but the last couple bites of steak and potatoes---no room left in ma belly! Had a couple of beers off the small but well chosen list, and gotta try the wine and the "dry soda" next time. No room for dessert, but we'll definitely be grabbin' some of whatever they have for sweets next time. 

Opening night definitely had a few kinks (we waited about 40 minutes for our entrees!), but the food was worth it, and we're so happy to have this place in the hood we'll overlook a couple'a hiccups while they work things out.

Thanks all y'all at front porch, I'm already hankerin' for my next return!
author: Jeremy H.

description: Been there 3 times.  The atmosphere is cool but most of the food is overpriced and lacking something, usually flavor.  I had the ribs & wings last night, don't bother.  The ribs were chewy and the wings had no taste, seriously.  Cornbread is good though.  Fried chicken is ok but not as good as some people say.  I won't be back unless they change the menu and drop some prices.  Too bad cuz it is a cool place to hang out at.
author: Jason D.

description: I went back, and the chef had left, and she/he must have taken the recipes too, because I was disappointed! It was good in its own way, but nothing like the initial, foodie-heaven experience. So much for perfect grits in San Francisco.
author: Emma L.

description: Get there at 6:30 or you'll wait too long   wait will be 15 minutes or 10 minutes ordered prohibition ale she'll have a heffe-wizen  oh its been 45 minutes already sitting talking rocking  back and   forth talking about nothing   this place used to be a pool hall not our scene I guess but it would have been cool to hang out there once   i heard    grits are good fish and chips are good get the fried chicken    the pickled veggies were salty spicy drink more prohibition  get there at 6:30 or you'll wait too long fish and chips were good we shared it all    dessert?  no but it won't hurt to look at the menu chocolate sandwich sounds too good  peanut butter spoon with chocolate  yum  get there at 6:30 or you'll wait too long for your chocolate sandwich.
author: Mr. G.

description: This place kicks ass! Catfish sliders, hushpuppies, and a really mellow laid back atmosphere. I'm sure the rest of the menu is equally as amazing, and I plan on going back to find out, can't wait till summer so I can hang out on the porch with a tall PBR and more awesome Southern food!!!
author: Michou O.

description:
Ok: So, I came here for a friends birthday. It was a Friday night, and the place was PACKED. Tons of people were outside, inside, upside, downside... it was ridiculous.  
We started with the Fried Oysters and the Beet Salad. The Oysters said they came with egg and pork belly- which sounded nasty... that is, until I was told it was just bacon and not pig stomach. It had to have been one of the best things I've ever had in my life, no joke. The Beet Salad was fine, nothing to write home about... but to this day I think about the Oysters. Nearly everyone in the group (about 15 people) ordered the Fried Chicken because the Front Porch is famous for it. I kind of regret it. The Mac and Cheese that came with it was really breadcrummy and dry, the chicken was a little tasteless. I guess nothing could compete with the Fried Oysters. But needless to say, we were all picking it up with our hands and sucking the bones clean.

I heard good things about the hamburgers, and my friend had the Vegan Stew which looked and tasted yummy. All in all, even with the crazy atmosphere, it was cozy and sweet.
author: Lauren A.

description: Even though it was a Sunday night we made reservations. Glad we did because it gets busy fast. We were a 1/2 early arriving but they found us a table with no problem. The atmosphere is great and no one seemed to mind the different table configurations created to accommodate the different parties. The staff were all helpful, considerate and all very organized. The bar tender didn't just stand behind the bar but was also running drinks, bussing tables and helping in the restaurant. I read a few reviews about the prices, but the quality of food you get was worth it. From the cornbread, mussels to the deviled eggs to start the meal all the way to the thyme apple crunch pie to finish everything was awesome. The two entrees we ordered, shrimp/grits and the braised short ribs were delicious! We wanted to order the fried chicken and the Mac n cheese but couldn't eat anymore. Will definitely be back soon to work our way down the menu. Take the J train muni and walk 3 blocks so you don't have to sweat parking.
author: Michael K.

description: not impressed. food was average, water was lukewarm, and service was slooooow. i got the dungeness crab grits. it came out in a wide but shallow bowl, so the portion size was disappointingly small for a main entree. i tried my friend's fried chicken, and it was okay but kind of bland. the decor was cute, but they seated the 6 of us in a booth in the back and i felt really cramped, plus the table was like 2" in front of my chest. kind of uncomfy. don't think i'm going back.
author: Clara K.

description: It was a fun, laid back place, and I was happy with the list of drinks, cuz I like a cocktail now and then...I loved the fried chicken...at first...But it became clear that the chicken was soaked in a very salty brine, and the meat was waaaay salty....and so were the collard greens, although it was still delish.  I like salt, but this was over salted, and I don't know if it was an off night.  However I loved the mac n cheese, and my friend enjoyed her pork belly and beans very much.  I'd go back again because the food was tasty, the service was very good, and there were no problems of waiting for the food..(.but it was Mon. night!)
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Pascale and Josh went and ate here without me....jerks!!!

But then Pascale made it up to me by asking me to go this past Sunday.  She was drunk and was late meeting me, but whatevs.

The restaurant is really loud.  No hard liquor is served.  But I can deal with all of this, as long as I have champagne.

The food was pretty good.  We had the fried oysters (the vanilla ketchup dipping sauce wasn't that great), so we dipped the oysters in this wonderful habenero hot sauce (the hot sauce ended up being doused all over the rest of our dishes).  The crab and grits was amazing (def was my fav of everything we had)....buttery goodness.  The surf and turf jerk was yummy but didn't knock my socks off...it could have been more jerk, if you know what I mean.  The pork chop and beans was very tasty.  I have to say that I just had a pork chop at NOPA which was brined as well, and sorry Front Porch, NOPA's chop kicked way more ass than yours, but your chop still tickled my tastebuds.  The plantains that came with the chop were not that impressive, but I have been spoiled with amazing plantains at this Jamaican restaurant in NYC that will prob forever rule in my book as far as plantains go, so Front Porch, you never had a chance on impressing me anyways.  All in all, my Front Porch experience was above average and I will be coming back.  Pascale wants to try the conch when they have it on the menu again.
author: Christina S.

description:
If I could give six stars I would. This place just has IT. That unknown extra thing that really makes an amazing dining experience. As Carla on Top Chef would say, it shows you the love.
It's got a seriously cool vibe, no studied decor, no trendy of the minute abstract art, no snooty bitch hostess, it just feels like you walked into some backwater Southern kind of restaurant that is a mish mash of oil cloth, Bob Marley, dim lighting and just plain cool. I know I've already used cool a lot to describe this place but it's just so damn cool! I frickin love this place. For example, the whole time we sat there, every song that came on was awesome! And you could actually hear the music and converse with your partner. That's like five stars in and of itself.
Now for the food, oh honey, this is no time for Weight Watchers and counting calories, it's time to just dig in and grub because this is some serious deliciousness. And fair warning, some part of your meal will most likely be fried. They bring you out yummy corn bread (shaped like corn! How.... corny!) and to start we shared the oyster beignets. These are SO good! The beignet is at the bottom and is dense and doesn't actually taste all that fried and has a mild sweet flavor and then on top a savory, succulent, briny fried oyster that just tastes like the perfect bite of ocean and fried goodness. It was an amazing combination. My husband doesn't even like oysters and he enjoyed it so much he ate his full share of the appetizer. Which was kind of a bummer cause that meant less for me. Marriage sucks!
I then had the shrimp and grits and these were amazing as well. My grits were creamy and cheesy served with greens, bacon and mushroom and the shrimp were succulent and sweet and flavorful. I really enjoyed this dish. 
I highly recommend this place for dinner for groups of two to four, the food was good but really it was the restaurant itself that elevated everything to this whole other level. It wasn't fancy pants and it just didn't care which made it oh so cool. I plan on spending a lot more time here.
author: Cathy T.

description:
7 of us on a saturday night with no reservation? showing up at 8:30? not to worry - the awesome guy with the skeleton t-shirt working this saturday made sure everything was aces. and that we got into the blue 'gangster booth'. we hung out on the front porch - ha and drank some stellas and tall boy buds till we got in about an hour later. ta-da! they even brought out an amuse bouche to keep us happy - but seriously, the rocking chairs and well-priced beer was all we really needed. 

i can't say enough about how rad the staff was here. they were both laid back, but totally on top of their shit at the same time. 

we tried a ton of stuff - here's the rundown:

-trio of fries: must get these if only to have something to put the homemade ketchup and habenero sauces on

-brussels sprouts: holy shit! sweet and hot. pretty slutty sprouts.

-chicken livers - mostly tasted like 'fried' - but very rich and from what i hear at my table, pretty damn good if you're into that sorta thing

-cucumbers and radishes - kinda like 'southern sunomono' - vinegary bite to cleanse the palatte after such rich food

- fritters with tomatoes and greens - ehh. kinda sloppy, glorified hush puppies. but still good...

-crab and grits - perfectly hot, tangy crab atop the mild, sweet, rich corn grits. awesome pairing

-hamburger - way smaller than the bun, but bill was happy...

-fried chicken in a bucket...a popcorn bucket... - briny and butermilky...nice crunch, tender meat.

and! to top it off! we came out with plenty of drinks and even leftovers  at about $200 total for 7 peeps! woo-hoo!!!!
author: Joanna R.

description: The Front Porch exceeded my expectations! I saw this place on Check Please Bay Area and thought I would give it a try. I went with a group of 4 and we loved everything about this place. We found parking a few blocks  away, waited about 10 min for a table (which is pretty good for a Friday night in the City around 8:30pm) We enjoyed all of the food and drinks that we had, we enjoyed the wait staff and the other customers. The place just had a great vibe. We had the chicken fried steak, pork chops, mac and cheese and shrimp and grits. Everything was so great! We also had the red velvet cake and the creme brulee, both were really good. We will be going back to try the many other things on the menu that look so good!
author: Markisha G.

description: When I first spotted the place I thought the place was ghetto.  From afar, it looks like the restaurant is located in someone's garage.  Trust me, it looks completely different inside.  Let me just say, this place is WONDERFUL!  I'm a huge fan of their crab and grits and don't get me started on the cornbread with the spicy butter.  MMM.  To top it all off, the cook/owner is FIERCE!  Another thing I noticed, the waiters know their stuff.  Definitely something that really impresses me.  Especially because I'm used to waiters not knowing what wine/drinks goes with what food.  I'm telling you, major skills.  But yes, worth checking out.  -1 because I there's no A/C inside during this crazy heat-wave and the wait can be a pain...it's worth it though.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description: Best gourmet-soul food in SF. The fried chicken is awfully good. Quality ingredients and well prepared. The atmosphere is great. Sorry Hard Knox Cafe, I'm pulling up a rocking chair at The Front Porch from now on!
author: David S.

description: Wow..the chicken is fantastic. Been hear a few times and it's always a hit. Cool environment, fun people, good prices, can't go wrong
author: Dilly M.

description:
I hit The Front Porch for the second time last night.  I must admit that I liked it a lot better.  There were six of us - we ordered some fried chicken, chicken fried steak, the rock cod, and the po boy.  There was fried Okra, french fries, and the pickle jar for all to share.  

The service was unremarkable. When asking the waitress about the contents of the pickle jar she said, that's a good question and then went on to say that it was seasonal, but didn't check it out.  Beyond that she was pretty attentive.  

Most of the food was a hit.  The po boy missed the mark. Far too bready and too much mayo on the slaw.  Plus, the aoli for the sweet potato fries was pretty bland.  The plate was too small for the abundance of fries and bread.  

The rock cod was probably the star of the meal.  Pecan encrusted served over black eyed-peas and collard greens.  Excellent flavors and the fish was cooked perfectly.  

Good reviews for the chicken fried steak and gravy too.  The right about of seasoning - you could taste the pepper in the gravy, which really brought it home.  

The chicken was better the way the former chef prepared it, but still worth the calories.  

Dessert was a bust.  Bananas Foster Creme brulee -- bland and a funny texture.  

Red Velvet Cake - cake was a tad dry  - the frosting was good. 

The place is hipster with a family vibe.  A little dark so some trouble in reading the menu.  Some Mexican guys were playing loud music at the open and close of the meal and walked around with a tip jar. I get supporting the community, but felt it was out of place.

Definitely will go back and stick with the rock cod and give the salt cod fritter a whirl next time.

Oh, and we were able to make a last minute reservation so that was cool too.
author: Carson R.

description:
yum... the bucket of chicken is way yummie... too bad it wasn't my dish.  i had the meat all in a pot... which turned out to be decent.. since some of the meat had been cooked too long it came out not tender.  but i look forward to trying out the other dishes next time i go there.... 

the atmosphere is nice and cosy.  they have the van's seat as ... well.. seats.  a bit small but its all good.
author: Rosa W.

description: I made reservations for last Fri night and the only times available were 6:45 and 9:30. I took the 6:45 considering our post dinner plans. Traffic was really bad and I called to let the host know we would be late. He was so nice and accommodating, saying he'd give us an extra 15 min even though it was a busy night. Parking was also exceptionally bad and I had my bf drop me off while he circled the block. They seated me no problem, even though we weren't both present. Our waiter was extremely friendly and brought drinks asap. My boyfriend joined me 10 min later and was ecstatic to be greeted with a Sazerac and warm, humble service. We decided to order gumbo, baked mac and cheese, and we split the flounder entrée. We had to laugh at the 2 infant muffins that were brought to the table, but I knew I didn't really want to fill up on those anyway. Everything we ordered was incredible. The gumbo came out piping hot and was spicy and hearty. The mac and cheese..words fail me. Absolutely heart stopping delicious. And the flounder was surprisingly delicious considering it wasn't something I'd typically order (I opted for the fried chicken but relented to trading for my choice of sides:) and was served over jambalaya. We ordered another round of drinks and the bill was surprisingly $64. And did I mention how effing cute this place is? Seriously, such a great dining experience. We will definitely be back for tall cans and fried chicken.
author: Jessi N.

description:
So I sauntered down the street one evening and into The Front Porch, a place I'd been meaning to try, but why would I when my favorite restaurant, The Blue Plate, is around the corner? 
Well, on this particular evening, The Blue Plate, much to my initial dismay, was closed! Yes! CLOSED! It was, after all, a Sunday night, but c'mon-- us comfort-foodies need to eat too. 
And while I continue to love The Blue Plate, I must say I was rather happy to have had the forced experience of venturing into a new and yet personally unchartered territory....The Front Porch. 
The place was like an oasis, lit up with strung lights and visions of a rocking chair out front-- especially on this brisk night with hunger calling, the wind blowing, and following a day of loading and unloading a rented U-haul. (And dinner was on Henry..Cheap eats! Even better!)
When we entered inside, it was like walking into a time warp. The place was filled to capacity and mellow, a friendly vibe, especially as we slunkered up to the bar and were greeted by the bartender du jour. He offered a few pourings of vino before we decided on a bottle, and was generous in this task. He also had opinions of what was offered on the menu and guided our decision making task with gentle persuasion. We opted for the fried chicken and mash, fried okra, and a corn grits and crab app. First, crab and grits go well together. Really well together. This dish didn't last long. Cornmeal crusted fried chicken was also a real hit, served on a bed of leek mashed potatoes with half an ear of corn. The fried okra was good, but I don't know that I'll give it a second time around. Not by any fault of the okra, mind you, but more likely the result of fried-food-overkill following the fried chicken. These crispy little nuggets were also a tad hard to eat and part of me thought that whole okra pieces might fare better, go down a little easier, or at least pick up better. Tasty, but not to die for. Again, would probably fare better if not eaten tandem with fried chicken. 
The desert menu looked fantastic..(upside down pineapple cake anyone?) But seeing as how another local favorite, also within walking distance and looming just around the corner, we high-tailed it out of there and nabbed our spot in the year-round line out the door at Michell's. 
I'll definitely make it back to The Front Porch again soon....and this next time, I'm ordering the pineapple upside down a la mode!
author: collette h.

description: Loved the cocktails, the fried chicken is one of the best in town, awesome service, and love the atmosphere (neighborhood chill and coziness).  Highly recommend it and will come again!
author: Irene C.

description: The one thing that immediately stood out for me was the atmosphere and feel of the place.  It was very cozy yet felt very homey....it was sort of like visiting a relatives house somewhere in the south, which is most likely their intent and they pulled it off very well.  The place was packed and filled with energy in the tight fit room. We had a big table for our party so we did not experience any of the proximity issues that i am curious about on this visit. Everyone appeared comfortable and happy though, at least from afar as best as I could tell.  It is very different than a lot of the other places I tend to frequent, but oddly enough I really like the place.  The food was okay.  I like some items more than others, but over all the food was good.  I really like the shrimp and grits, that was probably the most memorable.  The fried chicken was lacking some flavor and not as crispy as I would have expected.  My grandmother was from the south and I was expecting some of those more zesty flavors I grew up with.  The Key lime pie, the Pecan pie and the strawberry shortcake were all delicious.  I don't personally like bread pudding, but everyone in my party seemed to like it a lot, so i will relay their experience for that item and say that it is a hit also. I will definitely make my way there again to try some additional items and try and give an update to this initial review.
author: John E.

description: I really want to love The Front Porch, I really do. I'm in the area a lot, love Emmy's, and Blue Plate down the street will always have a warm place in my heart. I've come here numerous times over the years it has been open, so I feel I've had enough experiences and food to weigh in. It's just that the food is so lackluster these days--and pricey for what you get--that it's glory days (if you can call them that) are gone. The food has never been particularly memorable-- fried chicken in a bucket is good, but not so tasty that I left really happy and licking my fingers. The brussel sprouts in molasses sound great, but aren't flavored with anything aside from the syrup, apparently (a little salt, sugar, and bacon would go a long way). The gumbo and grits are ok, but not great. That sums up about all the food on the menu--gets the job done, but not enough flavor to be memorable or warrant the (usually) $17-20 price point. And definitely lacking in comparison to true southern cooking. The menu has gone downhill over the years in my opinion-- in part I imagine due to the original executive chef moving on--and the prices have gone up. No more free jalapeno cornbread-- that'll cost you $4. Despite misgivings about the food, I have none about the staff--a really nice group that in my experiences have always tried to make everyone feel at home.
author: Sean K.

description: Bucket of fried chicken! MMM mm Goood! Great wine list, great service, awesome cornbread! Owner is super cool too. One of my favorite restaurants in town!
author: Jay H.

description:
Guys.....get your service act together! I just ate here tonight. While the spicy crab & grits starter provided the creamy, pungent snack I'd been hoping for, your inattentive, disorganized service marred the experience.

We were seated well before the place filled up, but after we got our appetizer salad, we waited FOREVER to get our main dishes! I mean, everyone who had come in later than we had plates in front of them -- and not just cornbreads, salads, and other quick-fix items. The server made a point to come over and say our plates were just about ready....and then we kept waiting. 

When the server finally delivered our plates, he did not invite us to "enjoy" our meal or anything -- he just rattled off the dish names and left. 

The host and server came back later to ask how our meals were, but they both stopped by within a five minute window. Not the best effort, considering there are so few tables to keep track of inside the restaurant, and our meal timing had already been bungled.

Finally, it irks me to not get my receipt handed to me. I may be a woman, but I also paid for the meal. There's no need to give the tab directly to the man in the party.

...Three stars, because I've seen you better than this.
author: Mia L.

description: This was probably my wife's favorite restaurant in the city--like Amy C., we agree than Front Porch followed by a trip to Mitchell's is one heck of a way to spend a summer evening.  I think the fried chicken is amazing, there are always some fantastic beers on the menu, and the rest of the menu (okra, brussels sprouts, grits) is great as well.  You may have to wait some time to get a table, but it's worth the wait.  I'd give the place 4.5 stars overall, but will round up to 5 because it's always so much fun.
author: Ty D.

description:
Went here Sunday night with the boyfriend, who is on a quest to find the best mulled wine in the City and was jonesing for some soul food. Since it was 5:30 on a Sunday, I thought "maybe we can actually get into Front Porch without waiting 45 minutes!" And, yes, in fact, we just walked right in. (By 7:00 there was one table left, and by 7:30, the hostess had started taking names.) (And no, we are not senior citizens looking for the early bird special. We'd been out running errands all day; we'd skipped lunch and we really needed to tie one on.) 

5-stars for the drinks. Interesting, strong, and something for everyone.  The mulled wine is probably not the best in the City, but it's pretty darn good. I noticed that the bar was packed even when there were tables still left in the restaurant, so obviously, I'm not the only one who would come back here just for a drink. 

5-stars for the service. The chef let the bf into the kitchen to inspect her jars of pickled stuff and then brought the pickled egg & veggie appetizer to the table herself. (I know, you're thinking "gross", which is what I was thinking, but it actually wasn't bad. I didn't try the egg though. That thing just looked disgusting.) The waitstaff was attentive without being pushy.They were particularly good with anticipating almost-empty glasses, and any place that does not expect me to sit still without a glass of alcohol in my hand will always get a decent review.  Love the decor - intimate without being too loud. (Of course "intimate" means small, which is why you usually have to wait an hour to get a table.) 

4-stars for the food. Big bonus that you can actually get veggie and vegan stuff at a soul food place. The food is flavorful, but I was expecting a little more spice in my vegan stew. The bf said the same about the jerk poussin. And the fried plantains were just bland. But, they obviously change the menu to take advantage of what's in season and I'm curious to see what other interesting things they are going to come up with.
author: Kirstin A.

description: The burger comes with two big pieces of Bacon and a slice of cheddar automatically. How rad is that? The fries and ketchup have some ineffable spiciness too. The bun could use an upgrade though, kind of greasy and lacking texture. Still, this burger rates my list and shouldn't be missed. The fried chicken is divine, but please take the garlic out of the mashed potatoes. This ain't the Claim Jumper.
author: Zac H.

description:
Called on Monday to make a reservation for Saturday night- 8pm, 4 people. 2 of those people were trekking in from almost an hour away to try this famous fried chicken. We get there promptly at 8 and the hostess can't find our reservation.
Hostess "Did you received a confirmation call, because we call everyone that day to confirm." 
Me "No"
Hostess "It's not confirmed if they don't call"
Me "We, how would I know I wasn't confirmed if I didn't get a call?" 
I whip out my phone and show her my call log from Monday and Front Porch's # is right there. 
Hostess "Sorry, but the best I can do is 45 minutes. That's the next table"
(aside- this place is big enough that a table for 4 would turn every 10 minutes or so, so this is a lie)
Me "But we made a reservation. It's not my fault you lost it"
Hostess "Some people have been waiting over an hour"
Me "That's why I made a reservation."
Hostess "Well, I might be able to get you started outside"
We walked out and consulted. Decided this place is never getting my money. Useless hostess. If she had offered us a pitcher and sent us outside to wait, it could have saved it, but no, nothing. She didn't even try to make it right. She basically said it was my fault for not knowing that I was supposed to get a confirmation call. 
Plus, the place is stinky inside- smells like rotten fish. 
We ended up open-tabling a nice Italian place in Noe and still having a nice dinner, without waiting :)
author: Vidya R.

description:
Just came back from here. Can't say I was wowed but the food was good. They get quite a crowd and take reservations for 5 or more only so be prepared to wait. We were told we'd have a 45 minute wait but a large party changed their reservation and we were able to sit almost immediately.

Wait staff was attentive but the food was only mediocre. The spice was right, it was more the texture that was off. I had shrimp and grits, the grits were a bit mushy. Another in our party had pecan crusted cod, the crust was soggy...

I'd say go once but anymore than that and you're probably wasting your money.
author: s n.

description: One of the best restaurants in San Francisco.  Food, ambiance, staff, decor, all 5 stars.  This place embodies everything that is our city.  It's imaginative and fun, while taking the menu seriously and professionally.  The 'Porch would never make Zagats top 10, nor would I want it too.  Don't bring your uncle here, it's too loud for him.  Bring your high school friends back in town for a holiday and blow their minds.  I definitely recommend the "Porch Chop" and the Red Velvet cake.
author: Lane K.

description:
Best Fried Chicken in SF? Bay Area? California? I just say that this is one of my favorite spots in the City. Place seems to be a converted house, with a small interior and intimate seating. The wait can be ugly, 45-60 minutes so I suggest you get there early, as in before 6 if possible. Service is good although when it gets busy you may have to wait between visits...also beware of private parties, one time a friend and I had a HUGE craving and were turned away. Traumatic.

Tried various dishes but again the FRIED CHICKEN is awesome...unless you are on a strict diet pass on the entre size and get the BUCKET!  I'm drooling already. Oh and they had this appetizer, brussell sprouts in some sweet sauce, that is very good also..but disappeared from menu last time we went...
author: Steve K.

description:
I've had my eye on this place for awhile because we've been looking for something a little different. I'm glad we finally made it here - the food is awesome. My only observation is that the wait staff is a tadd pretentious.  It's not quite the southern hospitality type vibe I expected, but I think I'd come back in a group so we could try more things on the menu. 

My boyfriend and I split the grits with shrimp and bacon, the fried chicken, mac and cheese and the jar of pickles. It was all delicious.  My BF had a really hard time paying $16 for Fried Chicken, but I'm kind of happy it is expensive because I'd probably eat it everyday - it was that good.
author: A T.

description:
My wife and I love this neighborhood spot .  The Caribbean/Southern-influenced food is consistently good.  It's one of our favorite spots in the city, atmosphere-wise.  

The wait can be kind of long on weekends but every time so it's probably a good idea to make reservations especially if you have a larger party.
author: Bill G.

description: Get there early.  I had the ribs...they were yummy!  We also had the ceviche....DELISH!  I has a taste of  chicken and it was also very good!
author: Adriana G.

description:
had a group of 5 and they seated us in a table fit for four. lighting was too dark, and not enough ventilation. 
would recommend the chicken but that's about it.
author: sammy l.

description:
Great things clearly come from Sarahs with an H. The Front Porch is a Big Time Favorite.  I just can't seem to get enough of this place.  I've been three times within the past week.  I love the ambiance...the bar/small dark diner feel and of course the food.  
Here is what i have had so far: The FRESH Peach Bellini, the wonderful hot bread/cornbread at dinner with spicy honey butter, fish and chips, hamburger and fries, grits porridge (mmm), Black eyed peas (yuuuuummm), ceviche with plantain chips, coleslaw, chicken livers with onions on brioche (super loved  this) , corn on the cob,and the (omg so delicious and so my favorite of all ) fried chicken.  I especially loved the housemade ketchup and the hot sauce too.   Everything has been consistently great, even on the busy night i was there. The service has always been very attentive, and Kevin who was at the bar (my favorite place to eat) was so so nice and welcoming.  
Front Porch really DOES rock...I cannot wait for the BBQ.
author: sarah C.

description: The front porch....I definitely am liking this place. The ambience is dark, soothing and very warm inside. However, the crowds may vary and it can be real loud inside. I came around 8.30 pm and finished around almost 10.00 pm. It was almost the closing time and thank god the atmosphere has toned down. The food, i must say i did not expect. They gave us an appetizer bread with some sort of butter based sauce and it was AMAZING. The bread is warm, soft, sweet and light. It was simply exquisite. We ordered the beet salad, chicken gumbo, fried chicken bucket and the crab fitters. All of them were really good. The chicken bucket is well done, although i did still see some blood in the chicken, which was quite scary so i ended up only the part that is cooked. It was juicy and tender...loved it! The fritters and gumbo were really good too! It was creamy and crunchy at the same time(fritters). However, i do suggest that when you ordered the gumbo, you order extra potatoes or rice. It just taste better then. Overall, really satisfied here. Note: Better make a reservation call if you dont want to wait 30 minutes!
author: Cavin T.

description:
a very nice off-track restaurant with a decor that makes you feel like at your grandma's old house and with very nice people attending.

we ate family style, trying several dishes and we all loved everything we had!
author: Laurent C.

description:
This review is so long it's like reading homework.

     A spur-of-the-moment Valentine's Day invite from an also-single friend led us to the Front Porch which was suggested by yet another also-single friend.  His directions were 28th Street off of Mission but we discovered 28th doesn't really hit Mission.  A quick phone call, a Google search and a "oh it's one block south... or is it north?... of Safeway" later, got us to 29th Street.  (No mean feat, as slander, not geography, has always been my strong point).  The place normally doesn't take reservations, except for special occasions (like Valentine's Day), and we had none. But it was early-ish, we waited a few minutes and were seated at the table near the window --- and front door.  As we were seated, the host told us of how they found a photograph from the early 60s which featured 2 old women dressed to the nines, drinking beers, sitting at that very same table looking out that very same window.  ("Did he just compare us to a couple of old spinsters?" asked my friend).

     It was a fixed-price meal, appetizer, entree and dessert for $35 including a saucer of champagne --- as opposed to a flute, which is appropriate considering its days-of-past decor.  The salad was great --- molasses and mustard dressing, the chicken was fab and the 2 desserts were phenomenal.

     The only thing preventing a full five star review is the cigar smoke waffling in the door from the gray, pasty-faced smokers outside, and the fact that it did become very crowded, and, as our table was near the door, we were surrounded by a crowd --- bumping our chairs-  as they waited to be seated.
author: Cary Y.

description:
It's rare these days that we venture beyond our own kitchen sink, but we have been hearing such awesome things about the Front Porch that we couldn't wait to try it out. 

I won't waste too much time adding my compliments to the throngs here on Yelp. The Front Porch really is a great place to enjoy some delicious food and drinks. The dinning room vibe really is unique, though a little bit on the dark side, and I really can't imagine anything a block south of Mission Street could be more relaxing than enjoying a beer, gliding on a rocking chair out on the front porch. 

But, in all honesty, this place is not for the weak of heart or uninitiated... 

To begin with, there appears to be some confusion regarding the reservation policy. According to the Yelp page, they do accept reservations. However, when we called, we were told that they don't take reservations, but did have a wait list. Then, once we were there and on the wait list, we over heard two people mention that they did have a reservation! But, we had plenty of time to consider this reservation paradox as we waited a heart-staggering hour and fifteen minutes! The hostess did her best to placate us all, but at that point she was getting nearly mobbed every time she called anyone's name. To make matters slightly worse, she kept calling our party by different names - first we were Larry, party of 2...and then we morphed into Tom, party of 2...I'm not even sure she remembered our name, (Eric, party of 2) when she seated us. But, it's hard to blame someone dealing with forty hungry people and her only weapon is a tiny clipboard and pen.

Once we finally had the chance to sit down and order, we sampled and smacked our way across the delicious menu. Out of all of the things we tried, we enjoyed the Louisianan frog legs the best. They were unique but simply prepared and the perfect snacking size, though a bit on the expensive side ($11). The fried okra ($5) we also had was tasty and basic and that "jalapeno lime aioli" was totally ranch dressing. While probably very traditional and certainly yummy, it was a bit insulting not to have that described on the menu.

I was excited to see a vegan special plate ($15) on the menu, but disappointed that the amazingly wonderful sweet potato pancakes and black eyed peas were accompanied by some burnt kale and undercooked leeks. While I'm not a vegan proper, I do love me some veggies and these were just not good veggies. The good lookin' guy with me, had the rabbit special ($20) and was likewise disappointed that there was way more sausage than rabbit in the dish. We didn't stay for dessert, but we'll probably still give this place another chance. 

The Tiffany Scale:
Impact on Wallet: 3 of 5                       Impact on Soul: 4 of 5
Impact on Stomach: 4 of 5                  Overall: 11 of 15
author: Tiffany S.

description:
So Front Porch is in my hood and we were really hoping to add it to the regular rotation. Although I had a good time there and thought that the prices were very reasonable, I can't say that I was blown away by the food. In fact, some of the dishes didn't work at all, whereas others were more successful. The bomb of the night was appetizer, I believe it was called something along the lines of southern greens with tomatoes and ricotta fritters. A fritter should be light, airy puffs of fried batter and hopefully include some kind of goody inside. The consensus at our table was that our fritters were ill conceived and leaden. They were dusted with powdered sugar which not only didn't complement the savory tomato sauce they sat in but actually clashed with it. Blah. 

Moving on, I will say that they have cheap booze which can be a blessing if you want to go out and have one of those nights. My "deuce" of Three Thieves pinot was easy drinking and $10, which was fine with me. 

We opted to order the fried chicken plate, the burger, and an order of crab grits with the idea that we would share everything. The buttery crab grits were the clear winner of the evening although the habanero and scallions appeared to be absent. No worry though, it was a tasty dish and a good value for $11.50. The burger was a tough call. The accouterments were all top notch, good pickles, a tangy, sweet home-made ketchup heavy on celery salt, and amazingly tasty bacon cooked just right. Unfortunately the patty itself was less than stellar. I knew that we should have ordered it rare, but my compatriots insisted on medium rare. Although there was a hint of pink in the center, the patty was a little dry and crumbly, not a top notch juicy burger. A small frown graced my face as I sampled the vaunted fried chicken. Perhaps you know that I make an effort to get out in the world to eat as many versions of fried poultry as one girl can. The F.P.'s version  will not be at the top of the list. It tried hard with the pepper in the batter (which I love) but appeared to be over fried as the crispy coating was quite dark. It came with sides of black-eyed peas which were also rated as merely okay and some more creamy grits.
