Service was on the spacey side and didn't seem particularly bright or polished. All were pleasant and they've done a lot with the space. I was really hoping for a more solid performance though. I'm sure I'll go back from time to time to get some grits but I hope they improve the fried chicken.
author: Candice L.

description:
It'd been on my go-to list for awhile, so when the Chronicle reviewed it last week, I had to go. I rallied the troops and booked a table. Apparently, they only take reservations for parties of 5 or more. Perfect. We were 5. 
Late in the afternoon, Big Chris called saying, and I'm paraphrasing here, something better came up. 
Shit. He was our 5th. 
Next, my brother Alex called.
"I'm still at work."
"It's Saturday! Leave!"
"Do not give me shit, Beth. I am pissed enough already."
Fair enough. I called the Front Porch. 
"Hi, I had 8:15 reservations for 5 but we've sadly dwindled to 3 and I know you don't take reservations for less than 5. I thought I should call."
"You're Beth? That's cool that you called. Thank you. Are you still planning on coming? Okay. I'm taking you off the list, but introduce yourself when you arrive and I'll do my best to seat you quickly."
Marvelous. Laura, Mike and I headed over early and grabbed drinks at the 3300 Club (now open at 8am on weekends!) for some pre-dinner drinks. I urge you to read the reviews of the 3300 Club because I'm sure I can't do it justice. Basically, the jist of the place is old alcoholics drowning their sorrows. If I have learned one thing since puberty, it is that the demographic which finds me most attractive is old alcoholics drowning their sorrows. As Laura predicted, I was a hit in the 3300 Club and one particular gentleman took quite a shine to me. So drunk was he, I couldn't understand a word out of his mouth. Not a word. Literally. 
I smiled. I nodded. 
We headed over to The Packed Front Porch and I checked in. 
"Oh, so you're Beth."
"Uh, yeah. I'm, uh, Beth."
"Okay, cool. It'll be a little bit. But I'll find you."
I looked around the small, DARK space and noted the crowd. 
Heavy on the hipsters. 
I looked around the wine menu. 
Heavy on the Jugs. 
I bought a $15 jug of Pinot Noir and found my friends on a bench outside. We waited and snacked on $2 picked eggs and veggies. It wasn't that bad. We took cheesy pictures of us on a sidewalk holding the jug. 
Pictures?
Come on! We were on a sidewalk. Holding jugs of wine! Whatever...
Finally seated, we ordered the wonderful tomato salad and another jug. Let me tell you something, Yelpers. I said NO to the second jug. A jug, it seems, is way more than a bottle and the last thing these particular three people needed was more booze. Alas, I was outnumbered. 
We then ordered the obvious: a bucket of fried chicken. 
You get two sides with the chicken and we selected the corn and the cole slaw. 
The corn? Eh. It was dry and on the cob. 
The slaw? Eh. Not good. Not bad. 
The chicken? Okay, okay. I give in. It was good. It was good in a way that probably took a year off my life. The chicken must be dipped in some batter with cornmeal in it before it's deep, deep fried, and it's crunchy and oily and moist and glorious. 
Alex showed up, finally done with work. 
So we ordered cake. You've got to love a place that offers yellow cake with chocolate frosting on the dessert menu. I'm ghetto fabulous. I had to have it. 
But once it arrived, my beloved friends were so trashed on their jugs of wine and buckets of chicken that they ceased to be fun. "Pay the bill!" I screamed. "I need to go home. You bitches made me full and tired and drunk and I can't move." 
The car barely screeched to a halt before I was shoved out of the vehicle. Off they went to the Beauty Bar and off I went to bed, drunk, full and sick of these freaks I call my in-crowd. 
But the Front Porch? Well, they have $2 pickeled food. So, uh...nuff said.
author: Beth S.

description:
Charming, quaint and delicious but a bit pricey. Every experience I've had at The Front Porch has been delightful. The Fried chicken is to die for, honestly the best I've ever had. The spicy shrimp and grits is also amazing. The ambiance is welcoming and it definitely has that New Orleans vibe. I will go back many more times.

My two complaints, its a bit pricey especially on my budget and considering how pricey and swanky it is they should serve hard alcohol. All and All, a great restaurant experience.
author: K B.

description: I've never had anything but their fried chicken. Every time I go there, I can't help but order it! I always get the chicken for two, served in the popcorn container, with the side of beans and dirty rice. The chicken is perfectly crispy with a cornmeal crust, and not greasy. The beans are ok, but I'm not really a bean person, and the dirty rice is great.. I even find myself craving it from time to time ;) The best thing about this place is their ketchup! I don't know about you, but I eat my fried chicken with ketchup, and their home made ketchup has a little zing to it that is kicks up the chicken another notch!
author: Aly O.

description: Wow.. I am not sure where I have been not to hear about this place. There was about a 5 minute wait, which was cool. The bartenderess was great and prompt. Good wine selection, as well as the booze.  For dinner I tried the beet salad. Very fresh ingredients and the vinaigrette was great. Now down to the nitty gritty... For the main course I had the Island Pepper Pot Stew. One word.. AWESOME! It reminded me of the time I lived on St. Thomas in the USVI. A great mix of spices, and make sure you try the spicy vinaigrette they serve with it. The staff was very helpful. There when you wanted them with all sorts of knowledge of the menu. Don't miss out on this place. It's GREAT!
author: John R.

description:
I cannot stop thinking about Front Porch!  I have now found my favorite meal in SF!
Superb service-every single person was great, from the bartender, to the waiter, to the guy that brought out our food.  Seriously best service ever!
Delectable food-my friend and I split Ellie's fried chicken which is 3 pieces (all white!) with mashed potatoes and corn on the cob.  We also got the fried okra and the coleslaw (the best coleslaw that has every crossed my lips!).  We were completely stuffed and even had to take a piece of chicken home.  Total of the bill was around $29 with tax.  They even brought out a spoonful (the wonton kind) full of  gazpacho, compliments of the chef.  Love it!
The only downside was-no full bar, wine and beer only.  I got a cocktail made with fresh peaches and mosacto di asti.  While good, not worth $7.  Definitely stick to the beer.  $5.50 for a Hef and the glass is HUGE!
I will definitely be back!
author: Sarah M.

description: They recently got a new chef here and sadly I have to take away a star as painful as it is for me.  The last chef had a bit more of a Caribbean influence that showed up in the food as a jerky zest that sent the taste buds popping off the tongue.  The new chef is a little more traditional but a not as creative.  Over all I am keeping the Front Porch in my fave five for the shear backyard Louisiana meets Mission emo vibe they got happenin.  Its bizarre and they pull it off.
author: Cameron Y.

description: Overall, a great experience. The fried chicken was terrific... much better than Farmer Brown in my opinion, and a close second to some of the fried chicken yumminess I experienced in Houston earlier the same week. Although I don't frequent Bernal Heights too often, I'd definitely go back. They lose a star for having no record of my reservation request. How fuckin hard is it to write my damn name in a book? Just another reason why I prefer OpenTable.
author: Chris B.

description:
the restaurant is very cozy and intimate.  you get the feel of someones cabin down in the south...  the walls are painted a light/warm blue, which was very inviting and soothing.

the servers/waitstaff were very personable and kind.  they maneuvered the crowd w/such ease, and were very accommodating and patient.

we started off w/the roasted root vegetable salad, which was real tasty!  the goat cheese put together the veggies coated w/a light dressing.  the waldorf salad was just as good!  my favorite appetizer was the doubles: curried chickpeas and butternut squash between baras bread, with cucumber salad.  i took a double take because i thought it was meat at first -- it's that good!

the complimentary cornbread shaped as corn cobs were too cute!

my girls had the bucket of fried chicken.  they said that the chicken was quite juicy and tender.  their sides included coleslaw, which they enjoyed, and mac 'n cheese, which was to die for!  the breadcrumbs drizzled w/butter made the side!  we also had the fries [potatoes and sweet potatoes], which complemented the meal real well!

i got the vegan one pot stew, and it was too much to my likings.  it was a stew of root veggies in coconut milk.  the sauce was a bit too thick for me; i felt it should have been cut w/something else.  and the veggies were starchy ones that were too heavy.  i had to return the order, and opted for black eyed peas w/collard greens [sans the pork belly].

our dessert was beignettes drizzled with chocolate and vanilla ice cream!  ...always have to have room for dessert!
author: Sheri N.

description: Definitely a cute,laid back place, love the the rocking chairs they've got outside.  Food is so good-  had the bucket of fried chicken,coconut rice, collard greens, ribs... alll good, good, good, even had leftovers amongst the three of us. Ordered a glass of the pinot grigio--  and it came in a cute juice box and flexi straw--  never had wine served that way before!  We sat in the back where our seats looked like they were made out of old car seats, pretty unique.  Didn't try the dessert here unfortunately, cause I had a craving for the ice cream down the street... will try the desserts next time... definitely get there early or make reservations cause this place fills up!
author: Vickie Y.

description: Wow, our highlight was Spicy Shrimp & Grits...creamy, rich and well, mouth-watering in our opinion! Fried chicken was great too - and we each had sangria to wash it all down. Nice small cozy spot, kitchen in viewing distance, staff all nice...and no line to get in when we went early!
author: SF N.

description: Wow!  What a fantastic meal.  We started with the Caribbean charcuterie which was amazing, deep delicious flavors of liver, rilette and pork belly-yum, with perfectly grilled bread. Then we shared the fried chicken-crispy, hot and just as good as expected, but the winner was the jerk special of the night, which was a skirt steak- perfection. All the veggie sides were really good too, we had a side of grilled corn on the cob, which was charred from the grill, some fried potatoes with homemade ketchup-wow!  AND they make their own hot sauce- great meal with great flavors!!  Cannot wait to go back.  Tip: Go early, we got there around 5:30 and within 20 minutes it was packed...
author: James S.

description: Really enjoyed my meal last night at the Front Porch.  Great food.  Excellent service.  And they serve a number of their wines in two glass portion carafe's that they call a "deuce."   Handy for having a little white and then transitioning to red.  They also were very accomodating of our group with three young kids and even had a kid's menu with a coloring book page with Mr. T on the opposite side.  As for the food, I tried the fried chicken which was very good, and the fresh fish option, the spicy crab and carribean jerk chicken were excellent as well.  The burger was a little over-salted and the fish and chips were a little spicy.  All in all, a very good meal in a fun atmosphere with excellent service and reasonable prices.
author: Zac A.

description: A very calming, yet energetic place - almost Lone Palm-esque in its decor... glamorous, but not pretentious.  I loved the antique cash register behind the bar and the tin ceiling.  The mismatched diner tables were great as well.   The cornbread was delicious, the grits were tasty, and the macaroni and cheese - it weren't no Kraft!  Everyone was happy to be there, including the servers, me, and my dining companions.  Way better than Farmer Brown... plus it's not in the Tenderloin.  Win win.
author: Alissa K.

description: Appetizers are wonderful, especially the cod fritters. Entrees are consistently mediocre at best which is unfortunate as this is a quaint restaurant and we are huge fans of the owner.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description:
i really wanted to like this place. it is such a tasty conceptual idea...
but it fell sort of what i imagined. 
i ate the fish out of the over battered and soggy shell (the fish was good). i also felt shruggish about the bitter radicchio coleslaw and potato wedges it came with.
the wait staff was great  and there was some yummy moments at the table.
but with so many people raving about front porch... i expected a bit more.
author: miss m.

description:
i love this place. surprisingly good cocktails.  great fried chicken - even if it takes about 10 minutes too long. but you can't really complain since it's made to order. 

food is good. great little place with great food.   friendly staff. and the woman in the kitchen is no joke.  take a peak back there, say thanks and smile. 

just a decent, genuinely decent place, which is saying so much these days.   

still haven't been to good frickin' chicken across the street,  which has been tempting me since the beginning with a name like that, i'm embarassed i've not yet been.  but soon, i promise, very very soon.
author: Nikki F.

description: No doubt this is a funky neighborhood spot. I personally like to drink beer at the bar and order a few sides. My favs were the corn bread and the black-eyed peas. Although now that the menu has been revamped I'm not sure what sides are good. Seems like the cornbread and the bean dish are now different...hmm. I tried to go there the other night to check the situation out but it was jammed packed at 7PM. The wait was like 45 minutes and the bar was a no go. Guess I'll have to try out the new menu items sometime when it's less busy.
author: Shara H.

description: 2 (maybe 2.5) stars for the food; 4 for the friendly waiters and bussers.  My sister-in-law raved about the crab and grits, which I ordered on her recommendation.  It only fainlty tasted only faintly of crab, and predominantly of black pepper and scallions.  The rest of my family raved about the bucket of chicken.  The sweet & spicy brussel sprouts were (surpisingly) the hit dish of the evening.  Don't know that I'd go back, but this is a moot point since I'm from out of town.
author: Something Like a Phenomenon S.

description:
Who should eat here:  Could be one of the most trendy new hipster joints.  Similar to Blue Plate around the corner in food style, but its interior provides for a little more "edge".  Looking for a good crowd and comfort food in the Mission, give The Front Porch some serious consideration. 

1 Star - Lacking/Turn Off
2 Stars - Needs Work, But fixable
3 Stars - Adequate
4 Stars - Near perfect, rough edge here or there
5 Stars - Can't get much Better

Ambiance/Atmosphere: 3.5 stars.  Think dive bar feel, cushy booths, alternative fun young crowd.  I would have thought it would be hard for someone to make a dive-like diner cool, but the folks at Front Porch have done it.  The restaurant can get a little noisy as the long line of patrons waiting for a table huddle around the bar and slowly start consuming portions of the dining area.  I thought this provided a good jive, but if you are looking for more quiet time I could see how this could be an annoyance.  There is also a little porch out in front (hence the name) where you can chill, and I believe there could be food service out there, but not sure??  Advice, try to get a seat in the back portion of the dining room.

Service: 3.5 stars.  I found the service staff at the Front Porch delightful.  They were helpful with the menu and provided some value added insights into the dishes.  I think the level of service could be only better for a place like this if they could provide you with a tiny bit more of attention.     The problem was that 2 or 3 waitresses were trying to cover too much ground.  Although they did a really solid job, it was just impossible for them to really get involved in the dining experience.  Overall though everyone was super cool, and provided good insights into the food and beverage.  I was pleasantly surprised.

Food: 3.5 stars.  We started with a sashimi type dish, which consisted of Hamachi.  This seemed very out of place for their style of comfort food menu, but we were looking to start off with something really light.  It was tasty, and the fish was of very high quality and the cut was good.  I would expect something of this caliber in a higher end sushi joint.  Next we moved onto the pork chop and skate for our two entrees.  Both were very, very good.  The skate was a bit salty, but they made up for it with preparation.  I think Skate is one of the toughest fishes to cook well, and I was surprised of how good a job they did with it.  One less pinch of salt and they have a huge winner.  The pork chop was excellent; tender and juicy.  My only compliant is that this dish I find is getting a little overdone, so it didn't stand out so much for me.  We ordered a side of brussel sprouts (yes I like them), which if you are a fan you have to order them.  The best I have ever had.  We skipped the desert, because we were so full.  

Wine: 3 stars.   I have to say this was one of the more surprising aspects of the meal for me.  I was expecting  a horrible wine selection.  They have put together a nice little list that really has something to offer for everyone.  The other thing I like about the list is that you can order a lot of wines in 500ml size.  We ordered a Spanish white and a French Burgundy, both in the 500ml size.  Both were very good, and matched pretty well with the food we ordered.  Our waitress also had a good grasp on the list, which at a lot of places recently has been absent.  I think it would be interesting for them to shift their list to more of a domestic orientation, matching American comfort food with American Comfort wines.  All and all though, really well done.  They also have a great beer selection, but no cocktails.

Overall: 3.5 stars.  Well done!!! A really fun night out.  We went here on a Wednesday night and the place was hopping.  Be prepared for a bit of a wait if you arrive past 7pm, especially on Fri and Sat night.
author: Scott P.

description: front porch is the bomb ! anyone who gave them less then 5 stars was just sad they had to pay the bill, yes , i will admit i am a boss , so while most people will tell u that the front porch is pricey and it might be i dont care, i enjoy my spreckled hen beer, my cornbread, the company of whoevre im dining with and i devour whatevr dish i oredrd up at frotn porch. front porch rocks ! i eat ther all the time and if the meals cost double what they do now id still be goin there
author: frank a.

description: I give this place four stars only because of the food.  The wait was long so come there with someone you can talk to all night. The portions are a tad bit small, however all the food was comforting.  The decor of the place was pretty cute as well.
author: Kim N.

description: I've been here a handful of times. Once you have a table, it's generally an enjoyable evening.  I do like the food,  they have a nice drink selection, the place is cute and it's a fun enviornment.  The service can be a  little dodgy, but I understand how that can happen on a weekend night in a busy place like this.  However, last weekend a group of us (4 people) waited an hour and 20 mins., 45 mins longer than their estimate.  We could have dealt if we saw that the end was near, but the host pretty much ignored us and it really appeared like she could care less if we stayed or left. So we left and got thai food down the street.  My 3 stars is an average of 4 stars during the week and 2 stars on the weekend.
author: JB S.

description:
At a certain point, after 231 other people have reviewed a destination within a period of a few months, you wonder what the hell is it all worth any more.  Can I be witty?  Can I be insightful?  Can I spell correctly?  Do I have a song I can sing?

You also wonder how, when you were once young and hip, had never heard of a restaurant that 231 people have reviewed in Yelp.  We went with a friend who read the review in Patricia Untermann's newsletter.  

The review:
* I had some nice fried chicken.  Tangy (Terri says too tangy), moist, well salted, well fried (but the breading comes off the chicken too easily).  We got the bucket but we didn't get any thigh pieces, which was a disappointment.  The bucket was a good presentation vehicle BUT - the pieces of chicken at the bottom of the pile got soggy.  Secondly, the bucket also made it difficult to see the side dishes on the other side of the bucket.
* The mango/crab salad was nice - the habanero gave it a nice sustained heat while both the mango and crab's sweetness still came through.  Very well done.
* Potato salad was hyped extensively by the waitress but it's probably something the Yelp population can whip up themselves any given night.
* Sauteed Greens was good - garlicky, slightly too oily
* the dessert special was a beignet made with petit choux with a mascerated strawberry sauce and sweet cream.  The beignet + hot choco in Andalu is much better

The big pluses were the prices (reviewed ad nauseum by other reviewers) and the service.  Our waitress Pam was engaging, smart, obvioulsy liked the food (not surprising), and attentive.  

However, it's sad when we rave about restaurants who serve a bucket of fried chicken for $30 bucks as a GREAT DEAL.  It's sad to rave about service when, quite frankly, the place had people who kinda cared and liked the food.  Are we really that desensitized by the crappy high priced food and snobby attitude?

This is not to dis Front Porch at all - God bless for them for creating a lovely restaurant with excellent food, reasonable price, - I'll come back for sure.  BUT, if you are reading this 232nd review on your restaurant... we'd love a bucket of chicken for $20 (very happy to pay $20 for non-organic chicken).
author: Hanson L.

description:
it's dark and loud. the menu is not that deep, but the food is delicious.

beware, prices are all over the place (from $11 to $29) so a bit hard to decide between plates if price is a concern. 

i had the fried chicken. my date had the pulled pork special. both were delicious. go for it. no reason NOT to go to this place, honestly.
author: Adam S.

description: Justr got back from a great experience here. I went with a buddy of mine and we sat at the bar. Which had a nice local pub feel.  It was a bit early (6ish) so the place was uncrowded (thankfully, as I was hungry). We even got pole position parking. The bartender was very friendly and welcoming and the decor made me very comfortable as well. The menu was a bit more eclectic than I expected, but it all sounded good. I had the special (a shrimp stew with plantains) and a decent glass of Malbec ($7 - nice wine and beer list, by the way - glad to see someone other than me and Zeitgeist selling St. Peter's English Ale). The free cornbread with honeybutter was a good sub for a basket of bread. All in all, it was a great meal and I'll be back...
author: H. Joseph E.

description: SO good.  less one star for the prices, but when my parents come into town to take me out, we go to the front porch.
author: mission girl g.

description:
i had higher expectations for this place.  went last night with a bunch of people, and we were really looking forward to the fried chicken, which we'd heard so much about.  we ordered that, and a bunch of sides (fried okra, mac and cheese, red beans and rice).  the fried chicken was good; it was nice, basic, fried chicken, no spice in the batter; the meat was juicy.  but it didn't blow me away.  someone actually mentioned they like popeye's better.  i prefer hard knox cafe fried chicken- now that's really tasty.

now a bucket cost 32 bucks!  for like eight pieces.  that's a lot of mullah for eight pieces of fried chicken (4 bucks a piece).  is it worth that?  not really.  again, someone mentioned we shoulda just gone to popeyes.

the sides are alright, nothing special.  now everyone loved the jalapeno corn bread sticks that were free.  we got like four servings of that.

the space is funky; it's dark, and the ceilings are low.  used to be a garage is why.

i'll go back and try other things on the menu, but it's not a place that i'll be running back to.
author: Ramon C.

description: All I have to say is a shared bottle of champagne and bucket of fried chicken with all the fixin's is heaven. Eating at the Front Porch is reason enough to celebrate.
author: Kami S.

description: Yes, the space is comfortably delightful, but it is the frendliness of the staff that is the very best take away from ESS. Unfortunately the salt and pepper was left in the kitchen back at old faithful. No doubt with the people involved, we'll have some flavor moving up the hill soon.
author: Maureen M.

description: This place is amazing!  We lived in Noe for many years and loved walking to this special place.  In fact we loved it so much we convinced them to host a private lunch for us, not once, but twice, in celebration of our son's baptisms.  How cool is that!  They were amazing both times and all are guests loved the food, ambiance and chillness of the place.  Kevin, Josie and the whole Front Porch crew truly made these celebrations unique, special and memorable.  We cannot say enough about how awesome this  place is!
author: Sarah C.

description: The fried chicken was alright... Super juicy and moist, but not really flavorul. Very pricey too. I would recommend the Mac n cheese and the shrimp and grits ( get as a entree and not an appetizer).
author: krystina ann r.

description: Their spicy shrimp and grits was out of this world.  The chicken is really good too.  It's got that nice crunch when you bite into it and with the creamy mash potatoes it makes it the perfect combination.
author: Beliza G.

description: I am eating my leftovers right now from The Front Porch and loving them every bit as much as I loved them last night at the restaurant. I am a Southerner, and naturally a bit skeptical every time i see a Southern restaurant out West. But oh my god this place blew me away. Kudos to The Front Porch for offering a vegan plate that holds its own against the more typical meaty dishes so popular in the South. As a vegetarian, I usually have to deal with the boring, flavorless "4 veggie plate" at most restaurants. But this vegan plate was just fantastic in every way - delicious, inventive, unique. I ordered way too much and way overate just so i could try a lot of the dishes. Favorites: Biscuits, mac and cheese, okra and my perfect vegan plate. The people will me loved the gumbo and the fry daddy bowl, which had a ton of random fried stuff mixed together. Only negative: No cocktails. I could see this place coming up with some really interesting cocktails. Maybe someday :)
author: Erin R.

description: Any place that has the best (and butteriest) grits, and where you can drink wine out of a juice box with a straw, rocks.  We had a great time.  Fun atmosphere.  Try the fried chicken that comes in a bucket.
author: Kim M.

description: Long wait at 9:15. Scattered hostess. Took more than an hour to get seated--estimate was 30 minutes. Meal kicked off with a nice salad, but the vegan coconut stew was not so good. My friend enjoyed his grilled romaine salad and fish entree. We finished with a so-so brownie. Not what I was hoping for, but I'll give it another shot down the road. We did have a very nice waiter.
author: Bob N.

description: this place got such good reviews I had to try it.  wasn't that good, I hate to say i enjoyed the fried chicken at popeyes more... but I did.
author: Wayne L.

description:
We started with drinks on the porch until our table was ready. Last night was gorgeous so we were pretty excited about being able to relax on a rocking chair - we got the electric marmalade (mmm fruity and flowery tasting sweetness) and the Lana Lee tea (tea with basil and congac-y sweet liquor). 

After our drinks we headed in - the cornbread was delicious, but small and not replenished. The fried green tomatoes with which we ordered becasue they were a larger portion than the crab (said our very friendly waitress) were ok.. lots of fried, some shrimp, a pretty strong cream sauce - three slices of tomato and three shirmp. 

Entrees were the seafood perloo (black cod was the featured fish) - I had a bite.. the sauce was a bouliubaisse-y and the fried chicken. The fried chicken was a drumstick, wing, and some other white meaty piece  - chicken was super juicy and crispy and tasty. The mashed potatoes tasted more like cream, and less like potatoes, the beans were meh. The food was good, but was it worth 19 bucks? Ive had some gourmet mashed potatoes and fried chicken in atlanta - and those potatoes were amazing, came with more sides, and the entire portion was larger. Dont get me wrong, the chicken portion was pretty big (the seafood not big enough and we got some plaintains - but they were a little bland)

All in all - 

atmosphere inside and outside - casual, cozy, fabulous
service - friendly
food - ok, not good enough for the price. My main problem may be a lack of love for the overly cream/fried/oil style of food... *though I could eat motzerella sticks all night long.. so who knows!
author: Nors P.

description: Af-Front-al Porch.   Went here for a burger after the game.  The fried pickle appetizer tasted like a dirty fryer.  For $6+, one might expect a little more than 5-6 pickle slices.  On that note, the $16 burger was overcooked, dry and tasteless.  The fries weren't much better.  Indeed, I had to inspect both the fries and burger closely to make sure they were not from Costco.  A total disappoinment!
author: Seth S.

description: I don't understand how anyone could give less than 5 stars to this place.  The food is AMAZING.Our waitress was so nice and attentive.  The atmosphere is so cosy and cool.  Also considering the caliber of ingredients, taste and variety the food was very reasonably priced.  Now I just have to fight the desire to eat fried chicken here every night.
author: Cork C.

description: Very unique. i would highly recommend. Make sure you make a reservation. Their 'po-boy' was delicious.
author: M M.

description: What a great San francisco restaurant! The atmosphere is great from the copper ceiling to the throwback school bus bench seats. I had an incredible ceviche to start and the crab and grits as my main course. So good. The tall boys of red stripe just put the icing on the cake. It's one of my go to restaurants for bring out of town guests that  I want to have a cool San Francisco dining experience.
author: Ariana B.

description:
haikus for the porch

oh alejandro
our crazy cuban waiter
say "baybeee" once more

fried chicken galore
wine boxes and king cobra
soul food heart attack
author: Genevieve R.

description: The Front Porch was done right! From the menu, the seating, the decor, the staff, the lighting, ambiance and most important--the wine list. When selecting a dish with varied flavors and spice, you need the right grape to compliment and complete the meal. Bravo! to the wine buyer--- even the folky music agrees with the whole concept. If you have to wait a little while for a table, it's worth it. Especially on a Saturday nite! I will rock on the front porch again--
author: Michael M.

description: Originally we had planned to some southern food.  We had the mixed veggie kabob vegan plate and hamburger instead.  As requested, they cooked the cattle medium-well - perfectly.  The sides were fresh and not stock Cisco boring pickles or lettuce.  The veggies were crunchy and had an excellent sauce.  The small starter of corn bread strips clearly demonstrates their command of the southern arts.  Service was prompt, refilling our water consistently and not stuffy.  Easy quick commute from SoMa on the 14L.
author: Matt P.

description:
Amazing southern home cooking!  First, while you're waiting for your table you should get a Duval beer with some hot and sweet nuts!  They're awesome.  They're coated in powdered sugar and cayenne pepper.  You have to try them.  
Now, I believe they take reservations if you can actually get through.  And if you have a party of more than 4 I think this would be a good idea.  We waited for two hours!  They were very nice about it and luckily we didn't have anywhere else to be so weren't in a huge hurry.  This is also why I enjoyed those nuts so much. 
Once you finally get your table you have to get the fried chicken and the dungeness crab grits.  I'm not kidding, those grits are freakin amazing!  DO NOT miss out on them!  
The price is amazing too!  I think it was something like $20 per person at a table of 6 people.  And we were all full!  I love this place.  And if it wasn't so unbelieveably far from my house, I'm sure I'd be there all the time.  And I'm sure I'd be getting rounder by every piece of fried chicken.
author: Lauren M.

description: I like this place! It's not out of this world but it's pretty good. The fried chicken is very good, at least compared to what we have in this city. I like the ambiance, non-pretentious, down to earth, dive-like atmosphere. The service is very friendly too. I would have given it 4 stars if it wasn't for the chicken livers that were cooked "rare"! They were so apologetic that it hurts me to write about it.
author: Reza E.

description:
i've been pining to go to front porch for ages, so last night (without reservations in tow because the restaurant has been having issues with their phone system), my foodie friends and i ventured out there for a fine night out.

sure, we had to wait almost an hour to get a table, but they had a great system worked out with the local dive bar, the 3300 club, so that you could wait for your table there and the restaurant will give you a ring when your table's ready. ingenious! they also had plenty of seating on their porch, complete with blankets to keep you warm on a cold winter day.

and the food here was EXCELLENT! yes, we got the bucket o'chicken with a side of black eyed peas and macaroni, and the portions were big enough for 3! the star of the night had to be the molasses brined porch chop though, with a HUGE pork chop just beckoning you to big into. ask the waiters about the "brining process" that makes it okay to eat the raw-looking middle. we believed them, and haven't gotten sick so far. other entrees included a peppery skirt steak for their nightly butcher's special, the island pepper pot stew (which looked and tasted unusually similar to chinese clay pot rice... it even comes out in a chinese clay pot), and the tasty callaloo soup. the wine and cocktails here are also delish.

all in all a great night, and we'd definitely go back for that porch chop and butcher's special.
author: Andrey C.

description: Mmmmmm... a definite must try!! I've been hankering for some soul food.. island style, and this hideout fits the bill! Relaxed atmostphere, dim lighting, vittles with a whole lotta love :-P ..Its been a month since my visit, and I am drooling over the thought of the fried oyster sandwich.. soo yummy!
author: Vicky P.

description: This hip and popular little spot is seriously hit or miss, leaning hard toward the miss the night we tried it. Being a lover of New Orleans cuisine I ordered the staples - some gumbo and some red beans and rice. The gumbo was really thick and heavily seasoned, no flavor from the ingredients make it through the mess. Barely detected the one oyster I could recognize. As it cooled to lukewarm it was honestly inedible. Nobody at the table wanted it, we made it through about half of it. I would guess they spilled the spice jar into the red beans. They were just a total disaster, even while still warm. Noticeable powdery taste, and (EEEK!) even a little undercooked! We didn't even eat a third of it. No amount of rice could bury the weird flavor here, but the sausage was reaaallly good. So I didn't strike out entirely, especially with bites of what my buddies ordered. One got the fish of the day with jambalaya, and it was good. The fish was tasty but unfortunately overcooked. Jambalaya was good. And ONE hush puppy. ONE. Why? Other friend got Shrimp and Grits. This was the win! Really delicious gravy, nice juicy shrimps, flavorful grits. This saved the deal for all three of us, and the tasty fried pickles helped. We also got fried green tomatoes with shrimp remoulade - Green tomatoes were good but needed help from some sauce, and the shrimp remoulade wasn't it. Pretty bland for a remoulade, more like a shrimp salad. They get props for a cool atmosphere, good drinks, and a few friendly servers (though ours was pretty snobby and slow). The verdict: I ain't going back. If you're in this neighborhood and in the mood for American food go to the Blue Plate, or get in the car and go to Queen's down in the Portola for real New Orleans food done proper with no wait.
author: Tyler H.

description:
the front porch was truly a find. except i didn't find it--i ended up there because of a last-minute invitation from some friends. the four of us were wowed by the carefully crafted southern flavors. from the buttery bliss of the dungeness crab porridge to the juicy, organic friend chicken, the soul food here was pretty darn spectacular. the black-eyed peas and collards made me feel like i was back in my dad's kitchen. 

the atmosphere is great, the staff is friendly, and the concept fills a key niche... what could be better than the patio outside with circles of rocking chairs? this place exudes genuine southern hospitality.
author: Marla W.

description: My husband ordered the fried chicken, as did my other friend. Our other friend ordered the fish. I ordered grits with spicy crab. My intention was to eat half of my dish then swap with my husband's, so that we try a little bit of everything, but my dish was soooo good that I polished it off by myself.  The grit was creamy, a little rich but not too rich. It provided a nice balance to the spicy crab. My husband's fried chicken was good too. It was nice and crispy. Not greasy whatsoever. Afterwards we walked over to Mitchell's for ice cream. Burp.
author: unhei k.

description: It was Sunday and it felt like vacation as we passed by the Front Porch...I was out for a walk with a girlfriend and we had been considering a stop...we ended up walking back, sitting on the literal front porch in rocking chairs and eating fried green tomatoes, house pickled vegetables (EXCELLENT BATCH!!!), pecan encrusted catfish and peach cobbler.  Not only were we able to while away the last of the afternoon sun and watch the fog roll in but we were able to order rose by the half carafe.  We ended up ordering 3 half-carafes and both felt it was an absolute pleasure to be able to order wine in this fashion.  I will definitely be back.
author: Ananda N.

description: What a great little spot - so different. It literally seemed like someone's front porch. It seemed like it was in such a random place off the main street, smack dab in the middle of a somewhat quiet street from Mission and San Jose, with its neon lights. We waited for our table on the front porch. When we were inside, it kind of felt like we were ostill utside, like on the front porch :-), with a tent above us - well, at least that was how I felt. The food was excellent. I especially loved the corn bread that was shaped like little corn on the cob. I had the pork chop with brussel sprouts and jicama slaw. YUMO! I would have finished it if I had not snarfed both my and my boyfriend's cornbread. Oh...and the price is soooo reasonable! I will be back to try to fried chicken and fish&chips!
author: Jen R.

description: So up my alley this might as well just be my alley. This former Nicaraguan cocaine fight club bar has been transformed into a cute Southern themed space with a tin ceiling and Dolly Parton playing in the background. The bar is solid and affordable, the staff (especially the host) are some of the friendliest people in San Francisco, and the food is solid Southern fare (the deep-fried chicken livers on brioche was great) at almost too reasonable of a price. It's not the best nor the fanciest, but it's definitely my kind of place. Love it. LOVE IT.
author: Cory G.

description: This place has great food and great service.  They put a great twist on traditional fried chicken which I think is one of the best in the city, the jerk steak was fab, I've never really liked grits but the way they made it I have to admit it was good, we had the the tomato salad and some kind of crab cake.  I could not say anything bad about this place the waitress reccomened two great bottles of wine and was sweet the whole time.
author: Michele G.

description:
Lets start a timeline:

1894-present: I am born with a freakish deformity - instead of a sweet tooth, I am born with a fried chicken tooth.

July 28: 7:30 pm. Ive got a toothache. I have also been drinking since 3. I am also reminiscing about my younger days when we lived in a climate that had actual summers. We are in the mission. Front Porch sounds like the perfect thing. We're seated right away. The service is great (with the exception of me asking for any side but greens and receiving greens anyways). The conch fritters are EFFING FANTASTIC. The chicken breaks my heart, because while it is interesting, its not what I wanted it to be -  like so many failed love affairs in my past. It falls apart easily (while passing it to a friend for a bite, an entire slab of crust fell into one of our drinks... it was painful to watch and I havent told anyone about it til now. It still hurts so much). Its sour like limes, but herby like rosemary. Its too much for my drunken palate to cope with. So I smother it all in yam mash. I actually cannot remember what anyone else had because I feel I was hovering over my own plate, deep in a vortex of thought on fried-chicken-theory. I eat, I leave, mama's happy and not hungover the next day.
author: Miss K.

description: Dressed up southern food for people who've never really eaten southern food and don't know what real southern food is. That being said, the crab and grits dish is tasty and the wine list is decent.
author: LeeAnn G.

description: This is one of those places that make you happy to be a San Franciscan.  Simple menu .. no frills.  Take a friend that you've had for years and enjoy yourselves.
author: Susan K.

description: Great atmosphere in a local pocket neighborhood. Sit in the sun on a myriad of rocking chairs on the front porch of the "Front Porch" and watch the parade of urbanity while sipping sangria. Get there early, around 4pm Happy Hour if you want a leisurely meal, because this place fills up. Great for sunny stints - a little crowded and loud for rainy days.
author: Gwenyth K.

description: I always enjoy a trip to the Front Porch. Very inventive and tasty food! I love the Rose Sangria. If you go on the weekends, there can be quite a wait (2 hours)...but if you wander to the bar on the corner, they will call you or even come get you when your table is ready.  There is a great vibe inside and always a buzz. Cute waiters too. :)
author: Valerie D.

description: The chicken was definitely better the second time back (moist and tasty),  BUT I still prefer Farmer Browns for fried chicken.  Maybe the third time back will be a charm and I will be converted?
author: Tammy S.

description: Well it was the worst food I ever had. It tasted like it was spoiled and the lemon masked the bad flavor and smell. I was afraid to get the food poisoning. I would never go back if you pay me.
author: James K.

description:
Southern comfort fare
With a Caribbean flare
Grab a rocking chair
author: HaikuReview X.

description: Hooray for Front Porch -- nice staff, delicious food at reasonable (heck - cheap!) prices.  Plus, well-selected music (Neko to Hank).  We've been back more than a few times already and have yet to be disappointed.  Fish & Chips, Fried Chicken, Crab Grits (!) and good beer on tap. Great new addition to the neighborhood.
author: michele K.

description: Fried chicken anyone? Wow!! Went to The Front Porch lastnight on a date...mind you GREAT place for a date!!  Small and intimate and the service was great! The wait was 40 minutes but there is a great little coffee house across the street..grab some hot tea and play some chess while you wait!! I can't wait to go back!!
author: Cara- Jude S.

description: The burger and fries was one of the better I've had in the city.  The homemade sauce (some sort of barbecue/ ketchup tangy combination) blew everyone away.  The fried plantains were good enough that we ended up ordering a second round for dessert.  Although a bit dark, the restaurant had a  relaxing / casual feeling.
author: Morgen N.

description:
Just went there with my friends without reservation last night.  We waited for two hours to get a table but it was a worth wait.  Making reservation is highly recommended if you have more than three in your party. 
They had some interesting cocktails on the first page of the drink menu.  The food was great.  Fried chicken was wonderful and so was my shrimp with grits.  The Tri-tip steak came with heirloom tomatoes and they were awesome.  Portion size was pretty generous especially the Bucket of the chicken.  Atmosphere was very cozy : )
author: apple p.

description: Three weeks ago I woke up as a woman. I had painted cuticles, opinions on fine outdoor wear, and a neat little pooch with mustard hair. This story involves a bonafide gentleman taking my hand and waltzing my hide to some southern dine. "We're gonna get you fed real good, Mary-Lou." Words that send my notions of husbandry to regions of delight, "You're a good man, Tommy-Lee." I'd gush and guffaw at his every bite, big mammoth chews that chaffed my very insides. In them there moments I found myself sitting back and thinking futures and kids and all things nice, that it was just my luck to find me a double-barreled man with both manners and height.
author: Marc M.

description: One of my favorites in the city.  Food is always good, service is friendly, and the beer selection is awesome.  On my last visit I finally tried the fried chicken, which was excellent, though my only gripe is portion size - their 'breast' piece looks like they cut a normal breast in half.  So it's good, but I would rate Hard Knox higher because they give you more meat for $6 less.  My sister and gf had the Uruguayan beef burger and let me tell you after I had a bite I made them each give me almost half of theirs.  It was that good.  Had a great soup and who doesn't like that cornbread they bring out?  Overall I've had at least 7-8 great meals here, my only gripe would be that it's pricey for what you get, but these days what isn't?
author: Al K.

description:
The Front Porch is a caribbean Soul food restaurant deep in the Mission District.  The space is cute and remindes me of a restaurant I might see in Silver lake...it is small and usually busy.  The staff is  attentive and very approachable.  
I was craving Jerk chicken but I ordered a burger.  The reason is ...because, I only really like the breast and it is a half of a chicken and I new most of it would go wasted.  The burger was excellent served on a beautiful Brioche bun.  Aimee ordered the special "Fish & Chips"  they were very doughy.  Also, they were supposed to be served with cole slaw but instead came with Fried okra, she was dissappointed because her plate consisted of all fried food.  In all fairness we did order the cole slaw after the fact and the waiter did take it off our bill.  We both tried  a drink called the "electric marmalade" and both liked it, however, it did go down really easy for 8 bucks a pop.  Aimee switched over to a beer on tap that she found to be warm...I don't know what it is about this place... maybe its the overall cuteness of the mission hot spot or maybe its  the comfort style food, but I will definitley return....warm beer and all!
author: Michele K.

description: I love this place, it's so cute! The food was awesome! I came her for my bday with my bf. Their dinner days vary and so does their menu upon seasons. We had their tuna tartar which was very good. I got their fried chicken and he got their pork tenderloin. Both were very good and the chicken was still crispy after warming it up the next day! Too bad their menu doesn't stay the same, hopefully the next time around we'll have the same thing or something better!
author: Annie D.

description: Best comfort food in San Francisco.  Rivals some of the comfort food in my hometown (Houston, TX).  Quick and friendly service, too.  Not once left wondering "where's the server?".  Or "why is it taking an hour to get our food?"  And the food was delicious.
author: Benjy E.

description: I really enjoyed both the service and food at the Front Porch.  I'm glad to see fried chicken served the way it should...in buckets.  Good wine selections, awesome sides, and great hot (i mean really hot) sauce selections.  Be prepared to wait in the evenings, best to make reservations in advance, especially for a larger group.
author: Adrian N.

description: Front Porch is my new city Fav!  I started again with a trendy Pomegranate Cosmo and had Frise salad which I loved.  Then on to the Fried Chicken!  I'm not a fan of free range chicken but this fried chicken was light, golden brown and comes in a bucket.  The atmosphere had a grungy, classy feel to make any hipster love the place.
author: Rossi C.

description: Rockin good fried chicken - as boy with southern roots I also a love the grits - but what I REALLY loved was how friendly and accommodating the service was....especially since we had our 10 month old in tow with us the two visit - true that the service was on the slow side but - as to be expected for a new restaurant that hasn't found their sea legs yet.  The only real bummer is that they don't do take-out on the weekend - which for a working parent kinda sucks. Thumbs up - check it out.
author: Carlos F.

description: I give this place 4 stars for atmosphere.  It is really cute and cozy inside.  Its real dark and loud so good for an easy night out.  The menu I give a  3.  It is a fairly limited, however, the fried chicken is fantastic.  It is really that good.  I liked the corn bread at the beginning with the butter with the kick, but the burger was just alright and the crab and grits was just OK too.  Good beer list.
author: Jaime C.

description:
tall boys of duvel - one star
rocking chair - one star
grits + crabmeat - one star
low lit ambiance - one star
the never ending wait in that rocking chair - no stars
author: Amelia L.

description:
I'd like to give the Front Porch a glorious 5 stars for their lovely intentions, but I have some reservations. But let me say up front that the ambiance is perfect - it's clear that a lot of work has gone into creating the fantastic southern-hipster atmosphere. 

That being said, I feel obligated to subtract 1 star for the service and another for the food. They don't take reservations for parties under 5, so we waited 30 minutes for a table, which was surprising since we were first on the list. The reasons for our wait became clear once we sat down.... SLOW turnover, and slow service. I was initially thrilled by the menu, which is pretty eclectic for soul food. Unfortunately the fried chicken was just kinda dry and average, as were the potatoes. The crab and grits came swimming in butter, which should normally be a good thing, but really was excessive. Maybe I'm biased, but I grew up on fried chicken, crab cakes, and grits and I wouldn't come back here for any of those. Too bad. I will say, however, that the corn bread (shaped like corn cobs!) was great, and I was VERY impressed by the collard greens cooked in coconut milk. I would go back, but maybe try the Caribbean goodies.
author: Emily B.

description: I finally made it out to the Front Porch last night. With all the reviews on yelp, my [vegetarian] expectation was high.  I had the vegan stew which was a very bland potato and vegetable stew in a terribly heavy cream sauce.  The portion was generous.  The ambiance and the service were great.  But the food was disappointing.  Maybe I didn't know what to order? Bummer.  I really wanted to like this place.  In retrospect, Blue Plate (http://www.yelp.com/biz/rxY7canIJeXtICb6lprUcQ#hrid:gVjD27zDI08VhzuRJoE_ow), down the street, is much better vegetarian alternative.
author: Tiffany L.

description: I find the whole soul/southern/caribbean food thing to be oppressively trendy.  Maybe I'm just mean-spirited, but it gets on my nerves.  I guess I feel that fried chicken is fried chicken, and it's ridiculous to pay a lot of money and attention to it.  Front Porch didn't particularly disprove my opinion.  They did have some wine in a box, slightly larger than the size of a bottle of wine.  This was a slightly endearing touch, and most of the rest of our food was fairly good, but it's just not my kind of spot.  I don't care who you are - this kind of food isn't supposed to be this pricey.
author: Natalie S.

description:
i really wanted to like this place. but i just don't see what the big deal was. so they serve fried chicken in a bucket, and it's "fancy" fried chicken. the decor is supposed to be charming and quaint, to give them some credit, the restaurant itself is a converted house with a front porch where you can sit and wait for your table. you'll probably be doing this as they don't take reservations and it's a small place. 

most of the items on the menu are universally appealing. burgers, salads, greasy comfort food such as fries, macaroni pie, stews, fried fish, fried chicken....i was disappointed with the chicken. too much batter, a bit overfried, and very greasy. but it was cute served in a bucket, and the fried salt cod fritters were accompanied by a delicious tarter sauce. 

not really worth another trip for me, as the wait time for a table is long, parking is difficult, and the decor doesn't really appeal to me. plus a star for being creative with drinks. no hard liqour served, but they manage to concoct a decent cocktail list using only beer and wine.
author: helen l.

description: I had dinner with a larger party here which can always be a little tricky.  Our server was great and all the food came out to everyone's liking.  We sat in that large corner booth, which is quite luxurious.  They also have jugs of house wine, which makes you feel like you are drinking moonshine.  Rad.
author: Katie M.

description: This is a small joint that gets a lot of business.  Expect to wait!  There are some rocking chairs and benches in the front for you to chill while you wait to get seated.  The food is very good.  This is the place to come for some good southern comfort.  The spicy grab over grits and doubles are two thumbs up.  The patrons here are mostly young hipsters, and they give the restaurant a very lively feeling.
author: Kev H.

description: We had the BEST experience at Front Porch.  A great neighborhood restaurant with good service, yummy sangria, and the food was all excellent.  We started with the ribs and wings.  I had the fried chicken which was the best I have had in the city (not like I have had much, but it was still the best).  Others ordered the crab and grits which was actually really good, the burger, ribs, steak, fish...everyone in the group was raving about it.
author: Lisa D.

description:
The Front Porch offers up a blend of southern-inspired foods with some "caribbean" flair thrown in for good measure, all wrapped up in a cozy atmosphere that provides understated simplicity and elegance.  But soul food it's not.

My friends and I arrived on a Friday evening, and took a look at their drink menu while waiting for our table.  Their drink menu isn't particularly extensive, though they do offer a decent selection of wines, beers, sparkling wines, and some innovative house drinks.  I ended up settling on an "Electric Marmalade," a fruity concoction of muddled peaches, muscato d'asti, and dry kumquat soda (or something like that).  It was light and refreshing, certainly sweeter than I probably originally expected, but very good.  Later in the evening, I opted for a Perseophone, a mix of biodynamic dry cider, pomegranate juice, apples, and lemons, which was certainly another smooth, easily drinkable hit.  Unfortunately on these two cocktails, the strength was a little less than good...being blessed with the wonderful genetic mishap that causes "asian glow", I was surprised that despite two drinks, one on an empty stomach, the other mid-meal, I barely felt anything, which is odd considering that even a few sips of wine will cause the glow to arise, if even for a moment.  But I digress.

The four of us opted to split a fried chicken bucket, adding on a side of mashed potatoes and corn in addition to the black eyed peas/collard greens and grits.  To start us off, we partook in the Double and Ribs and Wings.  The ribs, while tasty, were small, and certainly tougher than I was accustomed to in Atlanta.  The meat did not immediately fall off the bone, and some inevitably clung to the bone for dear life, which in my book is the sign of a rib that hasn't been cooked well.  The wings, on the other hand, were a great spicy jerk concoction that provided a fair amout of heat along with flavor.  And served alongside both of these were house-made (I'm assuming) chips, which were incredbly thin and light.  The Double is a mix of chick peas and squash, apparently, and served up a delightfully smooth, spicy, and creamy texture all in one.

Then arrived the main attraction - a bucket of fried chicken, served in a popcorn bucket with popcorn.  While the chicken was most certainly crisp and tender, I found the fry to be a little lacking in flavor.  While crunchy, nothing really jumped out at me saying "check out this flavor that is enhancing everything" or even waving meekly asking to be noticed.  I wonder if it was simply a cornmeal dredge with perhaps a drizzling of salt and pepper.  I was tempted to ask for ketchup, but decided to leave it as is.  However, it was thankfully not overly greasy, which is an easy crime to commit.

Served alongside were black eyed peas and collard greens, cooked with pork belly as appropriate.  These were tasty and thankfully did not leave any grease on the palate.  The grits are creamy, perhaps a little too creamy in texture, and drizzled with some chili oil that gave it just a little kick.  The mashed potatoes were my favorite of the sides, as The Front Porch mashes some additional vegetable in (I'm not sure what it is), providing an extra level of flavor before dousing it with gravy.  And finally, the corn was sweet and tender, though the chili peppers they sprinkled on top left my mouth on fire for a good five minutes before consumption of mashed potatoes managed to wick away the spice.

Unfortunately, none of the desserts seemed all that appealing, with all of us opting to go somewhere else instead (Mitchell's is right around the corner), so nothing can be said about their dessert selection.

Overall, the service was friendly and attentive, and very relaxed, which is fitting for the restaurant.  The portions are perhaps a little smaller than what we've become accustomed to, and perhaps split amongst four people they quickly diminish in filling power, but for an individual, two sides would be plenty.  Finally, the pricing certainly isn't too bad, especially if something like the bucket of chicken is split, along with appetizers.  Menu prices range from the high single-digits for an appetizer, with most sides falling in safely at $6, while entrees are a comfortable high-10s to mid-20s.  What's great, though, is that by splitting, and with two drinks each, the four of us only came out to just over $30/person, including tax/tip.  Not bad.

The one downside to the whole experience is the pre-spicification (chili hot) of almost everything...from the corn, to the grits, to the greens.  There are certain things that can have a little spice, but some were certainly more pungent than expected, and not always expected in the right places.

In all though, The Front Porch provides a relaxed atmosphere for anything from a (small) group of friends to a date spot.  However, beware for those going for a date...it can get a little loud, especially as more patrons begin to trickle in for the
author: Mark C.

description:
really great meal, great service, great decor/ambiance - no complaints at all.  friend chicken, pork ribs, hierloom tomatoes were all great.  

if you are reading this review, there is no reason you should not just stop looking for a restaurant for your next meal - just go here, you will enjoy.
author: James R.

description: This restaurant is pretty much a bay area version of cajun/creole cooking, but it's not bad its just not great.  I would go again if in the area.
author: ahsal a.

description: Food is good but the service is horrible.  I highly recommend the fried chicken bucket and the mac n' cheese.  The setting is great.  My only forewarning is the service - this place is always busy and i've been there several times where they are simply understaffed.   The servers are friendly but just stretched too thin and this shows up in not getting things on time, things getting screwed up, etc....
author: Ryan A.

description: I heard so many good stories about their chicken, so I decided to give a try with my boyfriend few weeks ago.  We ordered the bucket of chicken and that comes with a side order of bean.  Additionally, we ordered one more side order the spicy brussel spouts.  I love the bean with rice, and it was spicy enough to make you sweat.  If you a big fan of spicy, you should ask for the Habanero sauce.  They don't lie about their spicy sauce and it will make you suffer the next day.  The chicken is really moist but I didn't really like it.  I may go back to give a second try but definitely the spicy beans.
author: Jade P.

description:
Ok so it's been 2 years since I first ate here. The only reason why I came back is because a group of us went and soemone else made the reservation. I went in not expecting anything spectacular. I ordered the fried chicken again, just to see if anything's changed. I was surprised. It was great! It almost rivals my favorite Hard Knox and Farmer Brown. 

The other girls in my group ordered the crab grits and loved them. Actually one of them said that always she goes there thinking that she'll order something else this time but ends up always having the grits anyway. 

Giving them 4 stars now since things have improved quite a bit. No one held back on the bread either!
author: gg s.

description:
this one waitress is the worst server i've encountered in the entire city (aloof, clueless, facist) *note: NOT THE OWNER OR MALE WAITER.
thus i give it a 3-rating...

on the food alone - 4.5 
-------------------------------
i am ridiculously picky about chicken. in fact, i don't like it - unless it is in one form - fried.  i like almost every other meat in multiple styles, but chicken must be perfectly crispy fried. and the front porch has a STELLAR fried chicken. crispy, salty, generous, cooked through but juicy.  served with a side of black eyed peas and collards.  STELLAR.

in addition, small corn on the cob shaped cornbread starters came before the meal that were warm buttery gifts from heaven.   and as diners described in other yelp reviews the crab and grits dish was spectacular.  (we wished we had gotten a side of something to eat alongside this dish tho - smallish portion and no veggie) but no complaints.

the decor was charming - tin lined ceilings, cozy blue walls, old photos hanging on the walls... beautiful...the owner was seating guests, he chatted with my girlfriend and i about the place while seating us and we felt totally welcomed. 

lastly, we DID have to wait an hour for a table for 4.  we knew beforehand to anticipate this, and did.   we sat outside on rocking chairs, chatting and had a drink.  quite pleasant.  

well worth the wait, and $40 we spent for the two of us... (including beer/wine). i'm taking my mother this weekend.

GO HERE! (or don't and shorten the line for for us.)
author: Erika Y.

description: I remember this place from its previous incarnation as a rowdy mexican bar where knife fights use to occur on a regular basis. I was really excited since I had moved away from Bernal to Oakland a few years back to find this little gem appear with local friends. Sit at the refinished dark wood turn of the century bar and sip the "ramblin rose" champagne cocktail. A soothing and elegant mix of champagne, rose water and sugar cube garnished with a pink rose petal. Snack on pickle veggies, spicy Cajun ceviche with plantain chips and heavenly plates of succulent southern inspired crab on a bed of creamy gritts.The ceiling has been replaced with decorative tin which twinkles candlelight from your cozy booth or table. Friendly service, great date place, excellent ambiance, wine and beer.
author: JJ C.

description: This place was good, but not super.   The food was good, but not like knock you off your feet (or chair, what have you) good.  And the wait was horrendous.  But I figured it kind of might be.  I understand they might be doing reservations now...perhaps...the place is super cute, though.  They get stars for atmosphere, which is important.  I don't really remember the service, so it must have been good, but, again, not super.  I'd go there again, but probably wouldn't go out of my way...
author: Kerry L.

description: The fried chicken and cornbread here are fabulous. On my last visit I had the fried cod poppers which were very good as well. If you are polite to the waitstaff they will also bring little appetizer plates with concoctions the chef is working on for either current or future menu items. The staff is very friendly and helpful. I think we were helped by at least three different people throughout our meal. Parking can be an issue so I usually sneak down from the Safeway parking lot up the hill.
author: Ryan M.

description:
When cornbread is shaped like madeline cookies, you know you're in for a treat. When madeline cookie-shaped cornbread comes with dipping sauce, you know you're in a different universe altogether. Now that's some fancy cornbread. And tasty, too: buttery smooth, won't disintegrate into crumbs like most usual varieties of cornbread. Mind you, this is just the cornbread, the snack --- it's not even the starter or main dish. Though please avoid the temptation to ask for seconds because, really, it's a sin to fill up on delicious cornbread before you can get to the delicious other parts of the menu.

One star gets docked purely for the wait. I hear they take reservations, but I've come here before to wait out a table, and believe me, it's worth the wait, if only for the food and the atmosphere. Frankly, I could munch on the cornbread all evening just to be able to sit there in the lively atmosphere. 

I really wish we could do half-star ratings, because I would take off another half-star because of the service. Generally, the staff is pleasant, but there's not a consistent grace-under-fire attitude. I sometimes feel as if I'm being rushed off just so another table can be cleared. You're not supposed to make a patron feel that way, no matter how crowded it is. Though you consciously know you ought to vacate the table when you're finished, there's a reason why the server gives you the pleasantry of "take your time" when you are given the check.

I'll keep the rating at 4 stars even though the prices could go down a notch, but at least they claim to use natural ingredients and other such "alternatives". (The Argentinean hamburger beef patty certainly did taste different from your run-of-the-mill patties.) 

I haven't tried the fried chicken, which is legendary here, but my friend seemed quite enamored of it the first time I came. On my second visit, my roommate ordered some kind of stew that looked surprisingly hearty and not watered down, which I was expecting for some reason. (Stew is relatively easy to put together, yet also easy to foul up.)

Dessert choices include ice cream from Mitchell's, which is no surprise given that Mitchell's is down the street. You may want to save room for a walk to Mitchell's, but the other sweet choices are worth sticking around for, if only to sit there with your friends to eat, drink, and be merry.
author: Joseph R.

description: Just discovered the Front Porch a month or two ago.....a nice 5 min walk from my apartment.... I was never a huge fried chicken fan until I tried it here.....it's so friggin' good.... Staff is nice, food has been great my 3X there.....and the Barrel Full of Monkeys on the bar is a nice touch!
author: Mike S.

description:
cute and kitschy.

the bucket-o-fried chicken makes you start talkin' in southen' 'twang it's so dagnabbin' good.

short ribs are divine.  actually all the apps were delovely.

oh--and their lack of a liquor license is not even missed with their creative wine and beer drinks like the wine-inspired mojito.  *clink*
author: Judgey Von Judge O.

description:
The food is very good, for the most part, and the prices are reasonable, but someone needs to get a clue about the noise.  They kept turning up the music, which made everyone talk louder, and they'd turn up the music again.

The halibut was delicious as was the asparagus appetizer.  The bread pudding was pretty bad, although the yam icecream was nice.  When we complained that there was no hard sauce on the bread pudding, we were told that it was already on the dish.  We tasted it again, and had to call the waitress back again.  This time she believed us and brought it to us.

So, turn down the music folks.  We don't go to dinner with friends to scream at them.
author: Linda R.

description: Appetizers were great (Ceviche and Tuna Tartare), but the entrees were lacking in flavor and imagination. IThe e flavors were very americana (fried chicken, burger, and fish and chips on the menu and the fish of the fish and chips was pretty flavoirless). Love the location and decore (and, again, appetizers). Service was good. Will give another try to see if the entrees improve.
author: Scott M.

description:
Hipster ambiance with a bit of loco mexicana define the atmosphere but good eats are the guarantee in this outer (southern) mission social scene. The organic fried chicken is the big draw, but all the found is pretty secure in its greasy down-homity.

On the downside, the wait can be long and the service slow, so don't be in a rush.
author: Jason S.

description: The host is a sweetheart. I wonder if he is also the manager, since he was also involved with checking in as we ate. HOWEVER, the bitchy bartender (blonde woman, with the bangs) did not make eye contact even though my friend and I ate AT THE BAR. She was surly and rude....It's unfortunate because of the wait, you may end up at the bar. Which is a generally negative place to be. Food was good...but the chicken was raw, but the nice host guy sent it back and returned it cooked to perfection. I guess the place is still a bit...uneven? Over all, the food's good, BUT GET A NEW BARTENDER
author: Lala B.

description:
As soon as I walked in,  I knew I was going to like it.  Reminded me of an old favorite from my PDX days called Dot's.  Dark, mismatched furniture, Zep on the stereo, and the delicious aroma of fried goodness.

The place is now one of my regular joints, and it's become an almost weekly habit.  In fact, I may actually be addicted to the house-made ketchup and cucumber-habanero chutney.  They're both delicious on their own, but combined they form like Voltron into some kind of God-sauce.  I'd eat my own baby if it were slathered in this stuff.

Standards like the fried chicken (way better last night than the first time I had it 5 months ago), the burger, and the kickass crab 'n grits never disappoint.  Their ceviche is, if not one of the best, by far the best value in town.  Same can be said for what seems to have become a permanent app menu addition, the bistrot salad.  Nightly seafood, vegan, and entree specials always make decision time a serious pain in the ass.  Unless it's pork chop night, then it's a no-brainer.  Always gotta order the fries trio, if for nothing else to act as a vehicle for more condiment consumption.  And to quench the thirst and some of the heat from the habies, there are many tasty adult beverages to choose from.  Although I am disappointed in the fact that the red-eye has disappeared... 2/3 pint glass of spiced tomato juice and a Bud tallboy.  Trailer park bloody mary.  Sure could go for one right about, um, now.
author: Drinky C.

description:
marc, rudy, and i ended up here tonight.  when you walk in, it didnt smell too good but the hostess was really accomodating in trying to get us seated quickly. 

the food is modernized southern - collard greens and black eyed peas, fried chicken, that sort of thing.  the corn bread comes warm and shaped like corn.  

what to get:  the fried oyster/pork belly/frisee/apple cider vinaigrette salad was excellent, the fried chicken rudy ordered he said was juicy, and marc liked the brined pork chop.  i got a snapper in a carrot bouillabaise which was really good once i salted it.  

what not to get: the sangria.  they shouldn't use sprite i dont think.  and the grenache was too sweet.

the deserts looked yummy but portions are big and we were too stuffed to get dessert.  maybe next time!

it's a cute place, we'd go back.
author: X X.

description:
the fried chicken is good, but really salty - but if you get the bucket you'll be eating it for days (worth it, cuz then you can eat it with your own mashed potatoes, rice, etc). 

the brussel sprouts are DELICIOUS - spicy and savory. i might go back for that. cole slaw was really sour. 

i can say the service was really nice, and it seems like everyone knows everyone in there. but it was really really noisy, i was yelling to talk to the person i was with across the table - and that was on a wednesday night.
author: Lisa M.

description:
the good: when the cake of the day is red velvet; the host guy who is warm and friendly and seemed glad to see us even though we've never been there; the ceviche; the amazing molasses dressing on the green salad; comfy old car seats as banquet seating; cozy dark lighting

the bad: a checked-out waitress who never said hello or offered up the specials (and then we had to ask again for the dessert specials!); who cleared all our dinner dishes but never came back with the dessert menu; who never offered us another glass of wine despite walking by our empty glasses over and over; the volume of the music; overly smoked black eyed peas (did they use tobacco?)

aforementioned nice host dude essentially became our waiter, filling our wine, bringing us share plates when we split an entree and just generally looking out for us.  guess he knew we got the bum waitress.
author: Kaye K.

description: The only thing missing from Front Porch is waffles.  Their fried chicken is the best in town and everything else about this place is too good to be true.  When will they have waffles?  And bacon doughnuts?
author: Ezra Y.

description: I really did like this place, just not as much as I thought I was going to. Plus we waited close to 2 hours, got seated after 10. The greens were very good. I liked the wine in little boxes. I liked the fun and funky atmosphere....I will definitely give it another try.
author: Adrienne G.

description: After Blue Plate, this is my second favorite place in the Outer Mission.  Lots of good stuff, although I think the chicken is kind of overrated -- just too much hard cornmeal coating.  And $31 for a small bucket of the stuff that serves two. Nice atmosphere, good beers on tap, and great macaroni and cheese.
author: Adam Z.

description: The fried chicken is delicious.  The mac and cheese was great.  Their hot sauce gave me third degree burns.  My company was outstanding.  The wait... eh... it's small, we were patient, it was worth it, but it's why there isn't a fifth star.  We waited nearly an hour to be seated on a Thursday night at 7:30.
author: Erin Leigh M.

description: I was really looking forward to this restaurant after reading all the glowing reviews.  Maybe I had my expectations set too high.  The restaurant has a cool, funky vibe, which I liked.  Unfortunately, the food was a disappointment.  I am a sucker for fried chicken.  But I have to say that I was disappointed.  I think the fried chicken at Farmer Brown and Hard Knox Cafe are much better.
author: Funk G.

description:
the grits were freakin amazing. 

My husband grew up in Texas and I've never been a huge grits fan...until now. The rest of the food we ordered was equally tasty but the grits were fantastic.
author: Holly S.

description:
I think the beans had pork belly in them, which, I don't eat, but do appreciate, having grown up half in Missouri, half in Arkansas.  And, the fried chicken looked pretty good.  I'd have loved to see if their BBQ looked any good, because I'm pretty tired of arguing that Everet and Jones might be better than southern road-side shacks.  No. Way.  
The civiche was pretty good, and the fresh bean thing (the veggie option) was fair, too.  
Mostly, it was all about ambiance.  I loved it--in Brooklyn there's a place called the Queen's Hide Away, and, while this place didn't have the food beat, the atmosphere spot on...plus, little corn bread the shape of ears of corn?  Precious.
I loved craming into a dim booth with my friends and sharing a bottle of wine.   I was totally into the fun, inovative table seatings, bathroom fixtures and the cool lamp-vase holder they had in there.  This place was/is a prime example of how ambiance can totally make a place--I wouldn't write home about the food, I don't think, but I would call it an SF favorite for the cozy bar and surroundings.  I loved it.
author: Jamie H.

description:
i just got back from a three week trip to japan and hong kong mid april and decided that i missed my girls and regular old comfort food. 

i invited the girls to the front porch. it was always a restaurant we always have been wanting to try - but it was always so crowded. 
this time i made reservations.

while we were waiting for the rest of our party to arrive, we started by ordering the salt cod fritters - which were delicious

once all of us were there - we chit chatted and tried to catch up and then finally decided to order a bunch of food and share.

As we munched on the fritter, we had decided on the plate of meat with had the ribs, jerk chicken and pork belly.
also the big bucket of fried chicken with mac & cheese & coleslaw. 
the last item was the braised short ribs. 

we were super stuffed. i think we ate so much of the corn bread that was placed on the table in the beginning of dinner. it was warm and ohh so good.
