we didn't have dessert this time because were happy & content with a delicious meal and good company!! and stuffed!
author: kiko v.

description: I had a great experience and food when I first went to Front Porch. Completely opposite to the second time, the person taking care of the reservations was impolite, unfriendly and unhelpful.
author: Alex A.

description: Best friend chicken in SF...and possibly ever.  Lady & Sons (Paula Deen's restaurant) is a close tie.  What makes it great?  I believe they do a lemon-y brine, so the chicken has the slightest citrus-ness to it.  Awesome.  Fried to perfection...not too greasy or grisly.  I also have to note that their sweet tea is true to the south.  Having lived in NC, I am a bit particular about sweet tea- this is the real deal.  Great tea & sweet flavors combined.  Bonus- they also carry Bundaberg Ginger Beer!  We didn't have a reso, but we went early and they were happy to seat us.  I would go back (or send my hubby to pick up a bucket) in a heartbeat....over Farmer Brown's anyday!
author: Monica D.

description:
the front porch is all front, no porch.

i paid like 30 bucks for the chicken bucket for 2 people cuz the hot waitress said it was their specialty. 

we both said, really? don't believe the hype. save your hipster money to buy another trucker hat or some more tight jeans, don't let it go here.
author: r c.

description: I have to rave and say how impressed I was experiencing this fine neighborhood gem of a restaurant.  The front porch has so much going for it  -  the staff is right on it and knows how to treat diners, the atmosphere is intimate, warm and inviting, (in fact we came in from the pouring rain and warmed right up).  The food hits high marks and there were so many great flavors to please the palate. We all liked the added touch of the pickled vegetables as an appetizer as well as the cornbread.   I recommend the combination appetizer platter, the fried oysters, shrimp and okra were delectible.  I had to have Sunday dinner of ribs which were meaty, flavorful and satisfying.  The memory of the creamed spinach is enough to bring me back.  Others at our table raved about the fried chicken and blackened fish.   You won't believe how great the desserts are and I recommend the  pecan pie.  We came up from the Peninsula in the driving rain but loved our evening experience.
author: CC P.

description: Great food, great service, and a unique menu.  And the decore is way cute- even the bathrooms.  It's definitely different, and worth checking out.
author: Marni S.

description: Though I haven't been impressed w/ the waitstaff, I love love love the food here.  The pork loin was amazing, as were the appetizers.  minus one star, because the fried chicken is really not very good (however, sweet lordd, were the grits good)
author: suzanne g.

description: If you have been to Emmy's Spaghetti Shack, then you know what the interior is like....Small and cozy, feeling like your in someone's basement.  The place is very loud and sitting near the door proved to be draft a cool night, but what place doesn't have that problem.   We started with the Waldorf Salad, but would not recommend it.  It was nothing special and very small.  Next we got the Fried Chicken, which was great and the Duck special, which was also very good.  If you can find parking, then stop in, you'll enjoy it.
author: Pele N.

description:
This place gets it done! It has everything that you could want. The staff, friendly and knowledgeable. The food, all well prepared and made with care and attention to detail. the decor, quirky and fun. 

You see I work at the Velvet Cantina and the hostess (sorry can not remeber her name) came into my joint and got some food to go, we spoke for a min and I asked her wher she worked. and she told me about The Front Porch. The chef used to work over at Emmy's spaghetti shack (another personal fav). So even before taking a date to the FP it was off to a good start. When me and said date showed up at he FP it was busy but we got a seat at the end of the bar reviewed the wine list with the help of  the extremly nice bartender (I owe you a drink girle come to the Cantina any time to collect) that let us try the wines we could not make our minds on. Then recommended the specials that went perfectly with the wine we had chosen then let us sit and take our time and spend a great first date with an amazing woman. I will definetly be coming back. From one new little mission spot to another WELL DONE! YOU GUYS ROCK!!! 

P.S. I will be back to try the chicken witch I heard is da bomb
author: Peter S.

description:
Three stars because it is so so so noisy! Don't come here if you expect to have a quiet intimate conversation, unless you sit outside. In fact, most likely, don't come here if you want to talk at all! We asked our waiter (who was incredibly sweet and nice and cute, by the way) if it was usually this/that noisy and his reply was "Actually, this is quiet for us." Now that is scary.... 

The food was good-- I loved my grits and my sweet and sour brussel sprouts, and the collards and black-eyed peas were also great. The corn bread was yummy and my friend said her fish was really good although it was a bit of a small serving and pricey. 

But acks-- soooo noisy!
author: Michele F.

description:
I read a bunch of reviews and this place seemed to be the spot. It's pretty popular, expect to wait if you like the pop in. Now I may be at fault for not getting the fried chicken, looked quite deelish from afar. A mixed meal for me :-(

I always imagined it was super far but it's just at 29th st

The place is pretty nice, dim lights, some crazy weird brass ceiling and the antique register at the bar are cool sights. I'm not a huge fan of the small tables in the middle, any other seats by the wall are better. Hey I applaud how they converted this house

Good
- fried plantains, although they could give me more than TWO!
- Big Daddy IPA on tap

So so
- jerk steak, that jerk will kick your ass, I guess this wasn't for me
- crab porridge, pretty nice but it gets so boring after a few bites, I asked for some bread (they brought me toast which I guess is the best they could do, thx!)

No
- corn bread is quite bleh

Bonus: hot waitresses, what can I say

Extra Bonus: a short walk to Mitchell's if you like to wait 10 min for your fix


To try
- st peters stout ale
- cod
- amuse bouches
- pork chop
- corn fritters
author: xo x.

description: Oh. My.  I unknowingly ate a snail. I suppose I should've known what conch was, but as I'm not exactly known for my adventurous eating habits, I didn't. But I have to say, the conch and sweet pepper fritters at the Fronch Porch were amazingly delicious. In fact, I loved everything about this place. The corn bread was mmm mmm good. The grass-fed burger was tasty too. And loved the unique spicy flavor to the fries. This is definitely a fun, hidden spot with a cool, sexy yet low-key vibe and amazing food. (Don't even try to count the calories here!) The service was great with the exception of the unfriendly hostess who was clearly in need of a drink herself.
author: a p.

description: Went to the Front Porch a few weeks ago with friends.  The atmosphere was good, and we had a lot of fun, but the food was only so-so.  The chicken was really bland ( can't come close to Powell's) and the surf-n-turf special was closer to Teriyaki than jerk spices.  Service was good however,  our server recommend some nice wines for us.  Overall it's a fun place to go with friends, but the food isn't anything to write home about.
author: cynthia a.

description:
their wine list is fantastic, and their service is helpful, fun, and unintimidating.  their menu was the best twist on haitian inspired californian cuisine i have ever had the pleasure of tasting.  my standards are pretty high, as i have a love for haitian women and their cooking.

but the part the closed the deal:  the most delicious plate i've ever eaten in the san francisco was The Front Porch's plantain appetizer dish with the house smoked salmon and creme. 

one must go with a date or a large group and the intention to have multiple courses so that you can taste a little of everything on the menu.
author: Emmy G.

description: Let me  preface by saying that dieters beware... this is not a low-calorie friendly place.  But everyone needs to stray off the path from time to time... That said, the food here is delish.  We got fried oysters (YUM!), fried chicken (YUM!) which comes with bread-crusted home-style mac-n-cheese (YUM! YUM!), and the Tuna Carpaccio (which was just okay ... i tried a healthy option and wasn't super impressed).  I love that this place has a deal with the bar on the corner, so even if it's crowded, you can have a drink there - they will call for you there and if you aren't finished yet, you can take your drink to go.  The staff is funky and friendly and the decor is super cute.  The price is right, too (we had the above mentioned food plus a beer and it came to ~$45).  Was a great date place!
author: Simmi M.

description: Do you remember the Big Yellow House? This isn't it. It isn't Applebee's either. Yet, like both the House and bee's, it aims for instant home, only where the other two fail, The Front Porch succeeds. Yeah, yeah, 'What about the food?' you ask. Delectable. The crab and grits is extraordinary. The cornbread tasty. The fish dish with coconut milk yummy. Why only three starts? Minus one for inconsistent service and another for lack of spirits (which should change soon).
author: David D.

description:
Everyone bemoans the absence of a 3 1/2 button .  Alas . . .Anyone can tell you about chicken, so . . .

To all vegetarians in the neighborhood:  Do not  be scared away!  I have actually had one of the best vegetarian (in fact, it's actually vegan) meals at Front Porch that I've had anywhere in San Francisco:  The Vegan One Pot Stew.  It's an amazingly aromatic, coconut-milk based stew with root vegetables, plantains, and other hidden treasures.  Granted, it's the only vegetarian entree on the menu, but communists live for years without choices and I'm happy to surrender my stomach to it.  

There's also a surprisingly excellent selection of beer (e.g. St. Peter's) and tasty wine.  And I'm certain my table could have eaten a propane tank of those salt-cod fritters.  They're definitely the best appetizer.  Be sure to skip the beet "salad" - it's just a few crunchy onions.

So, I'll definitely go back from time to time, but . . .like, they actually charged my table - of four - extra on our bill because we asked for some more (teensy weensy) cornbread after we breathed in and the first batch was gone.  For real?
author: Rachael S.

description:
I am not entirely sure what happened here - but it was good. After doing friday happy hour at Speakeasy Brewery (highly recommended), we went to the Front Porch for some authentic caribbean soul food. There was a wait of course since they only take reservations for large parties. We thought it was nice that we could start with a drink up the street at the 3300 Club while we waited. And waited. The hostess wildly underestimated the wait time while we continued to drink the rum "with just a splash of coke"s that the bartender was serving us at the bar. Perhaps because we were so nice about the wait (perhaps because we were so drunk at that point) we even got free drink coupons from the Front Porch at the end of the night... Anyway, I had no idea what I ordered, but everything was fantastic. The cod fritters were too salty, but the texture was superb, maybe just a a fluke since everyone seems to like them so much. I don't know how authentic the food really was, but the laid back (and yes - slow) vibe, the good dinner, and the ambience would get me back there any time. Maybe just save the drink coupons for after dinner this time.

(and the warnings about it being dark shouldn't be taken lightly - if you have trouble reading, bring a flashlight)
author: S. M.

description: OMG, the fried chicken in a bucket is a can't miss.  This meal feeds at least 3 but possibly 4, what a deal.  And if you can handle the spice you must try the habanero hot sauce.  There are lots of good stuff on the menu so worth a couple visits.  If the wait is long, hopefully you'll be able to park yourself on the rocking chairs on the front porch and then all that's missing is Grandpa, some widdling sticks, and some moonshine.
author: Bhavesh M.

description:
vegan stew, when they make it, is absolutely delicious!

cornbread is divine.

prices are a bit high, but perhaps that says more about my financial state than you need to know..
author: leyla m.

description: I took my boyfriend here to celebrate because Front Porch is actually one of his favorite restaurants.  I've eaten there a number of times and its always been pretty good and a fun place to relax and have a good southern-ish meal.  Which is why we were so disappointed with our last visit.  Everything was cooked well but was incredibly bland. We had the fried Okra w/ chili lime aioli. The fried okra had little or no salt on it and the aioli didn't taste like anything but bland mayo.  Jalapeno Hushpuppies - bland.  Fried Chicken- no spice at all and under salted.  The mashed potatoes were tasty but soupy and the collard greens were good.  I had blackened catfish which only tasted of salt, the coleslaw was decent though also very mild sweet potato fries were fine but by that time I'd had so much bland fried foods, the fries were left mostly uneaten.  Neither of the waiters asked me how my meal was even though I barely touched my main dish. And trust me if you ask, I'll be gentle but honest. When I initially asked if there was any way they could make the aioli for the okra spicier, the guy waiter brought hot sauce which is fine but didn't make up for every bland dish after that.  Overall I felt the kitchen was skilled in technique but lazy when it came to going the extra step and adding some flavor/spices.  Really disappointing because it was our go to restaurant but this meal just killed it for us.  And then somehow they reported us to Open Table as a no show.  Urg.
author: Sarah A.

description: I bought the fried chicken to go, and I thought it wasn't worth the 20 bucks that I paid for the food. I would recommend it if it was any cheaper but I don't see anything too special about the fried food here. I got the regular mash potatoes as a side. I would try some popeyes and compare after buying the fried chicken here. =)
author: Dave Y.

description:
The short of it - 
Food: 4 - generally well-prepared and flavorful Southern/Caribbean cuisine
Service: 4 - kind, attentive and knowledgeable wait staff
Ambiance: 3 - strange (but fun!) décor and cozy feel, lively but not overwhelming
Price: 2 - waaaaay overpriced

The long of it -
Disclaimer: I'm from the South, born and raised, and I'm a bit of a skeptic whenever I find "soul food restaurants" - especially upscale ones - in a place that is not the South. Cooking for many seems to spoil things, unless you're at church with some old ladies who been cookin' their collards in their special way for 50 sum-odd years. So yes, I admit I walked into the Front Porch with a tongue that was prepared to be under whelmed.

My friend and I started with spicy crab and grits. The grits were buttery delicious, and the subtly spiced crab complimented them well. The little corncob cornbread was cute, and the maple-y butter hit the spot. We were subsequently presented with a bucket that was overflowing with fried chicken. (Shit, it BETTA be overflowing if you gonna charge me $32 dollars for seven pieces of chicken! What does it cost at Popeye's ... 'bout $10 for a bucket of 20??? But I digress.) I didn't actually like cornmeal breading. I found it dry and lacking flavor, though the chicken was extremely moist and tender. They've clearly got the frying down to a science. Red beans and rice with a side of plantains hit the spot. Our stomachs were near exploding by the time the lovely waitress handed us the dessert menus, but I'm so glad that we ordered the chocolate bread pudding! It was near perfect - by far the best part of the meal.

Other notes: 

I found the décor a little weird in an intriguing way. The ceiling tiles were crazy and reminded me of my grandmama's friend's house. As much as I like Santogold, I found that her sound somehow clashed with my meal. I would have preferred some Delta blues or at least some rhythm and blues to complement the décor and the delicacies.

People, if you are going to go to a soul food restaurant, you SHOULD NOT try to be cute by eating your fried chicken with a fork and knife! Are you out 'cho gotdamm minds? You betta grab the chicken with your fingers and attack it like you mean it, no matter how much it costs or how nicely you've got your cloth napkin folded on your lap. Get it together and end this bougie nonsense!
author: R R.

description: ugh i hated this place. it was TOO dark, you cant even see what you're eating. it was TOO loud, you cant hear the people sitting RIGHT next to you even if they yell at the top of their lungs. and the food was nasty. i had the shrimp and grits, i wouldnt eat it again if somebody paid ME to!! dont go, save your money and time and take it someplace else!!
author: Sofia M.

description: I really like this place!  We ate at the bar, it took too long for a table to open up.  Super friendly bartender, yummy glog or grog or whatever you call that mulled wine stuff he was pouring!  We had the pork chops (special of the day), brussel sprouts (yummers!!) and the yellow cake w/ Mitchell's ice cream for dessert.  All and all a great neighborhood restaurant.  We will be back!
author: Stephanie J.

description: Good food great service comfortable setting!  I loved the experience.
author: David G.

description: Could I celebrate my 30th at a better place, NO!  The ambiance is relaxed but upbeat and the table for 10 was completely ready when we got there.  Sat right down and ordered drinks and appetizers no problem.  I had the crab grits again and a juice box of wine.  The server was adorable and accomodating.  The music was just right and I even got a candle on my cake.  it was great.  Nobody makes better grits or fried chicken.  I can't say enough about it, you just have to go there and fall in love with it like I do over and over again.
author: Erica L.

description: The fried chicken is really good, moist, delisch.  The crab grits could have used more crab.  I think if you start the title of a dish off with a certain word then that word/ingredient should be prominent.  The fried okra was good and should be an app not a side.  I think I've had better Southern Food, hence the 3 stars, but would go back to try the jerk chicken.
author: e w.

description: Front Porch f I could go into negatives I'd give you - *. The place was so bloody hot I thought they were trying to cook me for dinner. That said; your food in a word was BLAND. How do you make Cajun food bland? No idea, it takes skill I would imagine. Your Grit and Shrimp were good, I'll give you that, but not good enough to make the 7X7 list. Front Porch add some spices... perhaps you can start off slow, like using salt ad pepper.
author: P J.

description: My wife and I went on a Thursday evening around 6pm.  We ordered the blue crab corn fritters and a bucket of friend chicken plus two biscuits.  The fritters had hardly any noticeable crab and they were dry.  The chicken was the saltiest chicken I've ever eaten and trust me I've eaten plenty of chicken in the last 48 years.  I will say that the crust was very light and flavorful.  The chicken would have been fantastic with less salt.  Lastly, the biscuits (2) were extremely dry and tasteless.  The waitress was very good and understood about the biscuits and credited our bill.
author: Jerry H.

description:
I'd heard good things about Front Porch and when I saw that SFGate offered a half price gift certificate, it seemed like a good time to give them a try.  The first time I went I went for dinner (no coupon) and ordered the fried chicken (house special) and a side of okra.  The okra was delicious.  When the chicken arrived, I found it interesting that it came in a theatre popcorn tub and even more interesting that they had sprinkled stale popcorn in with the chicken.  I can excuse the popcorn but the chicken was disappointing.  Although it seemed to be fresh, good quality chicken, it tasted like it had either been overcooked or more likely, cooked in oil that had been used too long.  Service was OK.  
I still had my coupon so I went back for lunch a few weeks later to try something else.  I told the server that I'd be using the coupon (probably a mistake) and ordered a Cesar salad and an order of shrimp and grits.  The salad was good.  The shrimp and grits ($14) came in a cast iron skillet with exactly four shrimp and so little grits that I at first couldn't find them in the sauce.  What little that was there was good. Service was friendly.  
I don't know if I got the "mini" portion because I was using a coupon or if this is standard service.  In any event, I think I'll head out to Hard Knox next time I crave chicken
author: Jeff Z.

description: Ate at Front Porch last night.  Party of 4 and we waited about 15 minutes for a table at 8 pm.  At 9 pm, the place was packed and the bar was 2 deep.  I thought it was everything one could hope for in a neighborhood restaurant:  vibey, funky, and quirky with a friendly if somewhat too relaxed staff, good beer on tap, nice selection of wines by the glass, a place to sit outside and enjoy your beverages while waiting for a table and really tasty food.  Flavors were great in everything we tried.  Home made hot sauce on the table was more of a souped up ketchup but I can easily look beyond that to the delcious crispy-on the-outside-moist-on-the-inside chicken,  creamy grits, savory black-eyed peas, refreshing cucumber salad and zesty cole slaw.  Everything was really good and the prices are right.   A great local restaurant and worth a drive if you live out of the hood as well.
author: Lulu L.

description: Interesting place.  Quirky space that actually works.  The cornbread with sweet/spicy butter was perfection.  Do not miss the homemade ketchup....find something on the menu to use as a vehicle for it!  We went early, so the wait was short.  Staff and service were great as well.  We've just started working our way through the menu.  The clientele was all over the place...marina to haight to noe valley.....fun mix.
author: bill k.

description: Great food, friendly service.  Even the owner is a really cool dude.  The only thing I'd like to add, is that though it only has a $$ rating, the bill really racks up quickly here.  You end up ordering so many little things here and there that you'll get a little sticker shock when you get your bill.
author: Yusing W.

description: It was a great place with a super friendly staff.  The food was unique and flavorful.  How can you discount a place with fried chicken that lives through a 3 day preparation process before it even gets to your plate!  Sending some friends there.  This restaurant was recommended to me by Francis Broome.
author: Jonathan B.

description: I was in the mood for something filling and rich and my taste buds kept on gravitating towards soul food. The Front Porch was near by and had really great reviews so I ventured here with my friend. The feel of the place is really southern, sorta witch-crafty. It's dark, low ceilings, random wall decorations. We sat in the back, the long seats have seat belts which I thought was kind of clever. Anyways, so I thought sitting in the back was cool until the kitchen got all smoky. The kitchen is open counter, literally 3 feet away from where I was sitting. I left with my hair and sweater smelling like crap, -1 star for that. Anyways, I wasn't too hungry so I got 2 starters, the mac & cheese and gumbo. Both were good and very tasty. I liked the mac & cheese best! So flavorful and... Cheesy. Haha. The gumbo was thick and filled with okra and sausage with a little spicy-ness, but I just don't care for that taste too much. My friend got the friend chicken and with his first bite, all these juices came flowing out too. Honestly, it didn't look to appealing then. It came with mashed potatoes and veggies. All in all, it was an alright dinner. Didn't dig it too much. Soul food just ain't my thing.
author: Jackie M.

description: I shared the bucket of fried chicken with my husband based off the raving yelp reviews.  The bucket has 9 pieces while the individual entree has 3 pieces (bucket is $33 vs $17 for the individual entree).  Although both of us were ravenous and are big eaters, there was no way we could finish the bucket (which also came with popcorn mixed with chicken yummy greasiness).  The fried chicken is some of the best I've had in the Bay Area.  We also shared the jalepeno poppers (happy hour special) which was delicious!  Overall, great food and attentive service!
author: Shirley J.

description:
I thought it was pricey and just alright.

I don't plan on going back.
author: Franco L.

description: I'm kicking myself for waiting so long before going to Front Porch. This place is right up my alley with good food, beer, and a little piece of the blues. I couldn't get enough of the good wholesome neighborhood vibe, with the rocking chairs, dim lighting, wonky shit all over the walls, and uber chill bartenders. My friends and I went for the crawfish boil a few weeks ago. It surprisingly wasn't busy and we had no problem grabbing a table but maybe the buffet style dining helped with the flow. The food was downright excellent. From the crawfish to the jambalaya to the corn on the cob, everything was just so succulent. (I think this is the first time I've used the word 'succulent' in a review) The deal was $20 for all-you-can-eat and $5 for bigass Red Stripes. I love the whole concept of Front Porch and I'm going to keep an eye out for any future cookouts like this one. Well worth it and so much fun!
author: Susan L.

description: Lovely food, extremely pleasant and patient service.  The poached guava was one of the tastiest and most satisfying desserts that I've had in years!  One less star than i would usually give due to the disturbing trend (especially in "down-home" theme restaurants) of giving customers cheap paper napkins when entrees are in the $15-$20 range.  It really does make that much of a difference in the dining experience!
author: Colin M.

description: I really dug this place when I went last month. The wait was very long for a table, but we managed to get one bar seat and crowd around.  Friday night, place was packed, but the staff was rockin' and excellent.  When we sat for dinner, we had a lot of fun with our wait person.  The food was great - esp. the fried chicken.  All in all, a good time.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: Front Porch already gets points for being out-of-the-way with that dated decor and comfortably tasty food. But on my last visit, it was the service--friendly efficient, knowing, and crisp--that elevated FP to a category of restaurant that I know I can rely upon to provide a very satisfying eating-time experience. A new classic, at least for the not-as-crowded Mon-Tue-Wed window (one star off for suffering an unfairly-extended wait for a table on a Friday).
author: j r.

description:
loud, dark, full of white hipsters.

the crab and grits was hella buttery and good.  

the fried chicken was ok, nothing special.

typical of mission semi-upscale comfort food.  worth trying, but probably won't go back.

um, please try no to be so loud while waiting outside for your table, we live nearby and don't need to hear your drunken conversations, thanks.
author: goosebumps g.

description:
I was a bit wary of the fried chicken going in as my dining companion explained the batter was primarily corn meal. That being said, the resulting crust was seasoned well and increased the heartiness factor substantially. Our sides of collared greens and french fries washed down with beer also made me happy for the 10 mile run I did earlier in the day.

The hostess seated us right by the door which made my friend unhappy, but I didn't mind as I could eavesdrop on the conversations of people waiting to be seated. One woman complained to her friends, "This place is too full of hipsters." Perhaps; but without hipsters, where would I go to get my daily dose of irony?
author: Dominic D.

description:
I ate here in December 07 and have been itching to go back ever since. The portions are generous and everything is YUMMY!  And to top it off the prices were very reasonable (in the $15-25 range if I recall correctly).  We had the bucked of fried chicken, the pork tenderloin, and the skirt steak special - all were equally excellent, but I have to say I enjoyed my pork the most (and it was a huge portion).  The dessert menu was fairly unimpressive so we opted to go for ice cream at Bi Rite instead.

The decor is interesting - it's reminiscient of an old-style bar or speakeasy, but I imagine the place would probably look dingy if the lights were turned fully on.  It just adds to the character of the place.  It was a bit cold when we were there, but you can hang out on the rocking chairs outside and sip on some wine while you wait for your table.  The place was packed and so noisy we had to shout across the table, so don't go here if you want to have a quiet, romantic conversation!  It's also pretty casual - the staff are friendly and laid back, and their recommendations are spot on.
author: Irene W.

description: Love and crave the crab grits!  My new favorite place!  Need I say more?
author: Dennise G.

description: holy cow, this place is delicious.  and the hostest there is gorgeous!  as if that's not enough to invite you right in.  the bartender is SO sweet and it's cozy in there with seats from an old car or something.  anyway, this place is perfect as it gets for comfort food. actually more than just for comfort food.  i'll be back and start considering myself a regular.  it's just where ya wanna be to feel super comfortable and have all your cravings taken care of.  LOVE.
author: Megan M.

description: the fried chicken might be the best i've ever had. i'm a big fan of the skin being crispy and well seasoned. every bite of every piece was just that. the gumbo had its own twist from the normal gumbo you get at most restaurants. the collared greens and garlic mash were nothing special. the waitress convinced us to get the beignets that were rice filled for dessert but it was really heavy and basically i could have done without it. i'd definitely go back though. however, it didn't seem like a mardi gras atmosphere when i went on fat tuesday. they had a mexican band playing in the background...
author: Bryant L.

description:
i had my birthday dinner here.  it was amazing.  the wine was fantastic, some Spanish white, i ordered the ceviche, then the crab and grits, and of course the yellow cake.  i'll admit that  when the crab came, i though "no way is this going to be enough", but i was stuffed.  the  crab was tender and the grits were perfect, especially with some of that homemade hot sauce.  the service was fantastic and very accommodating to my rowdy bunch.  looking forward to going back.  

i have a feeling that this flavor of the month is going to be lasting a long time.

PS.  the place feels like my home bar in Virginia.
author: suzanne e.

description:
Went there recently.  Me and my dining companion were lucky to get there when we did...around 6:30PM as we were able to get a booth.  I noticed as the night went on, it got more crowded and people were standing around waiting for an open table.  I noticed a patio out front with rocking chairs, so at least if you have to wait, there's a cool place to sit and people-watch until your table is ready .  

I had the porch chop.  It had a delicious tamarind-type glaze on it and it came with the macaroni pie and spicy spinach.  It was filling.  I also enjoyed the "doubles" appetizer.  I originally heard of "doubles" watching a show filmed in the Caribbean about Caribbean food on the Travel Channel.  Although the "doubles" were smaller than what I seen on the show, the flavor made up for it and it had just the right amount of spicyness.  

The staff at the restaurant was friendly, patient and service was excellent.  Will definetly go back again.
author: erica d.

description:
yes please! 

arugula salad w/ shaved christophine, watermelon radish, grapefruit & white balsalmic aioli & red stripe tall boys all around

next:
bucket of fried chicken with macaroni pie, crab & grits,  rice & beans, cole slaw & cornbread

next:
corn pudding with cherries

then:
booty @ the knockout.

do it.
author: tiff f.

description:
This place has fantastic cuisine and ambiance. Serious. Soul food with a nice twist....an international one. If it was just another soul food joint I'd probably smile and be thankful, but the Caribbean influence made itNOT a soul food joint, and  simply too good to pass up.  
The wait for a table at 6:30 was at first glance obscene, but then, when faced with a very pleasant 'front porch', complete with rocking chairs and la petite drink holding tables for waiting....I ceased my complaining and sat my foodie ass down with a drink menu. 
The drink menu is sublime, with more than a  little word play to make it fun, and indeed, it was. I made my way through three of their mixed drinks, most satisfied with the Lil Rouge Corvette. One can only sample so many alcoholic beverages before risking the rest of the review. 
The appetizer selection was wonderful, we had decided on the Platter of Meat prior to even sitting down. Not that we are devoted meat fanatics, but come on, it's a Platter of Meat, anyone would be just a little intrigued. There were 3 meats on the platter, all extremely good (the pork belly was very thick and very....pork bellyish)
The main menu is seasonal, the next change up being 4 days from now. Do not be fooled, this is not supposed to be down south soul food, it's soul food cuisine, it's .....California genius. It's not your mama's pork chop, it's a rum and molasses brined 2 inch thick chop. Grilled to perfection and topped with a garlicy buttery herb sauce, served with your mama's mac n cheese and (in my case) spicy sauteed spinach. It was the best pork chop I've ever laid teeth into, by far. I only mention what I ordered to emphasize the detail that the folks in the kitchen (all beautifully tattooed I might mention) put into every single entree that leaves their hands. 
The dessert menu didn't thrill me, if only because I was sated by everything that preceded it. I ordered off menu, coconut icecream with chocolate sauce, which my husband declared tasted like a frozen almond joy candy bar. And indeed, it did. The perfect end to a fabulous meal. 
The service was wonderful, despite the fact our waitress forgot to mention the specials (that's okay, we knew exactly what we wanted) and the check was a bit delayed (more time to chat with my husband). Every detail was attended to, I watched a server quickly get down eye level with the table to ensure the silverware was lined up perfectly, water was kept full, timing of courses was masterful. The place has ambiance, the ceiling is punched tin tiles, in the bathroom as well. The walls are brilliant Caribbean blue , the floor a checkerboard of black and white. The wait staff is young and very San Francisco, which translates as tattooed, pierced and interestingly coiffed, but very upscale in their delivery of service. 
This place is worth every penny and every minute you search for parking (hint; go to the Bank of America on Mission after 6pm on weekdays and anytime on weekends and holidays, $10 gets you parking about 2 blocks from the restaurant)
author: lisa s.

description:
I am very upset today.  I have heard so many great things from all my friends about this spot.  Finally, I was able to go with a crew of friends.  It was a promising start with 24oz Red Stripes.  We had a fried cod app that was amazing, but I came for some soul food and that means fried chicken.

The first bite was, I must say, was very tasty.  The chicken was juicy and full of great flavor.  My second bite was just as the first, however, it was the third bite that killed it for me.  I don't know about you, but when I bite into a piece of chicken, only to find that myself spitting it out due to the fact that the center was TOTALLY RAW!  Absolutely disgusting.  It was at this time that another in my party found the same thing.

But I guess I could get over it, but when we told the staff, they didn't seem too concerned.  They took the piece of chicken and brought it to the chef.  It was about 15 minutes later that she returned, with the single piece of chicken in a bowl.  They did not have the decency to provide us with new pieces of chicken; instead, they returned the same piece that looked like it had sat in a fryer for 3 months.  What kind of service is that?  Any it was even more annoying is to have the wait staff continue to bug us about clearing out plates when our raw chicken was still in the fryer.  Horrible.

Needless to say, I was very disappointed.  Every place can make a mistake, but it is how you handle that mistake that leaves a lasting impression.  That being said, The Front Porch has been black listed.

To add insult to injury, my stomach does not feel too great right now.
author: Patrick B.

description: i think my hopes for their famous fried chicken were just too high. the chicken is good in comparison to a lot of other places but just fell a little flat.  mac n cheese was a bit bland too.  the atmosphere is fun and i would definitely consider coming back.
author: Helen T.

description: This is the kind of place that you can come for a special occasion but is still as casual or formal as you want it to be. For us it was sadly a farewell dinner. i had reservations on a sunday night for 4 adults and one baby. (I had called ahead to make sure they could accommodate a baby.) Sure enough they did. They had our table all set and ready to go as soon as we got there. The lighting is dim which I loved and thought it added to the ambiance of the place. We were very comfortable and got started with cocktails. They were just OK. They're only able to serve beer and wine so I would recommend to keep it simple with..... beer or wine.  The blue crab and corn fritters were delicious and the fried green tomatoes were a treat. The food was fantastic overall and one of my friends exclaimed that "the ribs were the best he's had". (I guess they only have baby back ribs on sunday nights.) The fried chicken, mashed potatoes and greens were just as good as i had heard. We left pleased and satisfied. The service was tops. And I feel that dinner was worth every penny.
author: kathryn s.

description: Very authentic southern food. Delicious, but definitely need to go to the gym afterward.
author: Adie B.

description:
Walked over to the Front Porch early on a Friday evening (around 6:30pm) and we were able to score a table before the people really started arriving.

I started with the thinly sliced cucumbers and radishes and really enjoyed it.  Where I am from in the south, we use a little more vinegar in our dressing, but I still thought this was good.

Of course, I had to try the fried chicken and I thought it was great.  Excellent crust and very juicy and flavorful on the inside.

My dining companion consumed the grits with crab and loved it.  I will have to order that the next time.

We finished our meal off with the yellow cake, fudge icing and ice cream.  What a perfect end to a great meal.

My only complaint is that they don't serve hush puppies.
author: Jason S.

description: I have a huge weakness for fried chicken so I had to try it.  The fried chicken was juicy and tasty and served with delicious sides....I love the black eyed beans and the collard greens.   The atmosphere is welcoming and casual which is great.  I would go back for the chicken if I'm in that area.
author: Mary C.

description:
this is an incomplete review........and a rant...

the girlfriend and i were excited to come here on a recent saturday night. we were dreaming of the famous fried chicken in a bucket. oh, this was going to be so good... unfortunately, our dream was quickly vaporized as soon as we walked into front porch. oh my gawd! this place was loud. almost as loud as the blue angels flying over your roof loud. we had to gather ourselves. ok, this place is popular and it's saturday night. we need to deal with it. fair enough. don't you think? so we looked for the host, except that we couldn't find the host. we looked some more, but still no host. um, is there a host? yes? no? ok, is there a waiting list? yes? no? i don't know for sure, but i like to say 'no' because we couldn't find the waiting list. so for the next 20 minutes, we were standing around and looking desperate and hoping that someone will finally acknowledge us........but nothing. no acknowledgment whatsoever. we felt very insignificant... 

finally, a waiter came by and told us that there's a 2 hour wait. wow! now that's going to be a very long wait. hence we were no longer interested in dining at front porch.

in conclusion, we understand that front porch is the flavor of the month. that's fine with us. however, we felt that it was inexcusable that front porch didn't have a host or a waiting list on such a busy night. oh, and if front porch did have a host or a waiting list, we sure couldn't find them........and we are pretty competent people. anyway, due to their negligence, we lost 20 minutes. now 20 minutes may not sound like a lot, but when you're starving, it means a lot. so for now, front porch gets two stars from us, but to be fair, we shall be back soon. hopefully, there will be a nice host at the door.
author: frisco j.

description: There were four of us at our table at Front Porch. The entire group was made up of transplants from Indiana, and throughout the night we talked about how much sitting in a restaurant eating fried chicken while listening to country music reminded us of the Midwest. That is about where the similarities stopped. The grits and fried okra were far superior  than any other similar dish I had back home or while traveling through the Southeast. I really look forward to eating here on a regular basis but that won't happen til the buzz/hype for the Front Porch dies down. It took about an hour and a half for a table for 4 (we were told it would take 45 mins.) and the crowd was made up of some people dressed to the nines for a place that their main draw is a bucket of fried chicken. That is not to say the restaurant isn't nice, because it is. It is just more of a cozy laid back nice. Our service was great, and the food came out of the kitchen quick especially considering how crowded it was. We ended up getting two appetizers, the bucket of chicken, two sides, and a desert. Not one of us left the Front Porch with being anything but full and happy.
author: Bucky K.

description: Staff really sucks there. A friend and I were seated at the bar right by the entrance to the place. This was especially a bother because we'd got there before the crowd did. Then we had to deal with people coming in and out bumping on us almost the whole time. The Bar tender came off pretentious over the beer selection. Which ended up that the beer really wasn't that great. You can order your meal at the Bar which I thought was nice. The waitress sorta' defeated the effect after offering to take an order from the folks seated after and behind us. It was like we were really being avoided. As for the food? Well, the chicken didn't really "blow me away". Now I've had some chicken with some real Louisiana folk and more than my fair share of Creole style food. It's made pretty good with a decent portion for the price. The real deal breaker was that staff did not make us feel welcome at all. I'd rather go down the block to Popeye's dodging all the Drug addicts for chicken after being treated like that. Now, I gotta tell you folks that we're usually a Food Server's easy customers because I really reward effort and support my local places, but damn.  Don't let me stop you. Sometimes all three employees can have a bad day.
author: Jubei K.

description: damn i want to love this place, i really do. i love the environment, the service is great, and there are always interesting conversations going on to the right and left of me. but the food is ultimately why we go to restaurants, right? well, they got the serving sizes down very nicely. that i liked. the fried chicken was great. but the second and third time i have been here have been disappointing. the crab one one night, and then a few weeks later, the tuna special. its sort of bland and unspecial.  oh well.
author: coffeecake j.

description: I just tried this place out with a friend the other night and came home stuffed and satisfied. We did order alot of food but everything we ate was great! The food came out quickly and the service was friendly. A couple of my favorite apps/sides were the mac & cheese and asparagus. They also gave you cornbread! I love cornbread! I had the fried chicken plate which was awesome with the mashed potatoes and collard greens(which is also good leftover). We had the chocolate pecan chess pie for dessert, and although we were stuffed from dinner, we left nothing on the plate. I would love to come back and try some of the other dishes.
author: Jenna W.

description: Even after a foodie trip to the South, I can say the Southern fried chicken and baked mac 'n cheese were very tasty. I think my memory may  be slightly tainted by the fact that the wait was ridiculous, but the free cornbread muffin (on the house to make up for our wait) more than made up for it. Definitely a must-try if you're in the waaaaaay Outer Mission.
author: Michele L.

description: This is a cool place.  We really wanted to like the food.  However, the gumbo was really salty and lack of spices.  The fried chicken was crispy and moist, but really bland.  For our first time there on a busy Friday night, we were very disappointed.
author: C S.

description: Since moving to Berkeley, The Front Porch is one of my most-missed SF establishments.  The food is consistently good (probably because I almost always order the crab and grits), and the house-made habenero hot sauce is amazing.  They always have cask-conditioned ale on handpump and a well-balanced selection of beers on tap.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Jeremy M.

description:
the one thing you must know about the front porch is that they do not take reservations so you will wait.  they do if you have more than 5 people though, so my advice would be to russle up 4 friends just so that you can make a reservation!  
anyway, once we had gotten through our 45 minute wait (which we spent at the 3300 club up the street... good little system they have where you can go up there for a drink while you wait and they just call you when your table is ready), we had a great meal.  i really liked the atmosphere - dark, cozy, even mysterious.  cool tin ceiling and slow fans, candlelight.  the service was very accommodating and friendly - we asked if there were any booths available and when one opened up a few minutes after we had ordered, the hostess nicely moved us there to be more comfortable.  
we started with the cod and pepper fritters (which actually came with our entrees vs first but we didnt care!) - my favorite dish of the evening.  first of all, they are fried, which is a guaranteed win right there.  but the cod was light and had great flavor and the peppers were just a subtle touch.  i had the burger for my entree, partly just to choose something different from what other people were getting (fried chicken, crab and grits) but it was delicious.  fries were good too.  i tried my friend's crab and grits and really thought they were good.  the fried chicken got rave reviews as well.  
we didnt go with dessert, being too full and ready to hit the town after such a long dinner.  oh well - there is always next time, because i WILL be back again!  with 4 friends of course...
author: Carolyn B.

description:
solid.
solid as a rock.

front porch rocked it last night.  had a reservation for 8...which became 11.  i was REALLY worried if they could pull it off.  and they did.  got there a bit early and the table was ready.  small, but ready.  we had to squish in big time.  i wasn't sitting on the end, but those people might not have had a 5 star experience, being that half their asses were off the booth.  
our waiter was brian.  11 is a lot of people to keep happy, but half the group was from LA so that makes it even harder.  he kept the drinks going and answered all our stupid questions with a great attitude.  all this without knowing we were going to supplement his included 18 % tip.  
we ordered everything big old dysfunctional family style.
starters:
beet salad- awesome little bits a fried onions and whole beets
cornmeal crusted oysters- a bit too rich but a delicious combo
salt cod and sweet pepper fritters- waiter recommended them, and we ended up getting 3 orders
corn bread- looked like a plantain.  very moist.
main dishes:
crab and grits- my one and a half bites were awesome but i don't think i could eat just that as an entree.  it's wicked buttery.
escaveitch fresh fish- i didn't actually try the fish part, just picked out the pickled veggies, which were divine.  especially the chayote.
3 buckets of fried chicken- they lived up to their name.  delicious citrus marinade in the meat and great fry batter outside.  perfect fried chicken.
sides:
sweet and french fries- awesome with spicy ketchup
black eyed peas- good.  i make them better.
we had ordered more sides, but either they didn't come (coleslaw, extra greens) or they didn't make it around the group (the only bowl of greens).

as a last note- they have king cobra malt liquor.  and when i ordered it, the waiter high fived me.  
the front porch rocked my world.
author: Katie H.

description: I had heard so much about the place that i was dying to go. Now I hate it.  I tried to eat there friday night.  I wanted to take my 3 daughters (3-6-9) to get the fried chicken I had heard so much about.  The woman that answered the phone was polite, told me it was a kid-friendly restaurant, that there was a 40 minute wait but she kindly offered to put me on the list.  Got there in plenty of time and checked in with the hostess.  There was nowhere to wait so my daughters and I waited out front.  More than 40 minutes passed, and still no word.  Finally i asked how much longer and she told me another 40 minutes!  She did not apologize, and was not even nice about it.  This reaturant had abviously become so popular they no longer consider it necessary to be polite to customers.  This has always worked in NYC, but it is new to SF.  Dont let them get away with it.  Stay away!
author: Perro q.

description: Since there were 4 of us, I had the opportunity to try several items on the menu.  Overall, the food was mediocre.  Their fried chicken is supposed to be their specialty, but to me, it tasted like my mom's fried chicken with corn flakes used as bredding.  Their biscuits were dry, the okra got redundant very fast, and the acoustics inside the restaurant are god-awful.  Is this place a restaurant or a loud nightclub?  Want far better chicken and biscuits?  Go to KFC.  Sad to say.
author: Darren V.

description: I knew coming here I wanted the Crab Grits.  Being from the South I have this natural attraction to regional delicacies that aren't a main staple out West.  The Front Porch definitely hit the nail on the head with this one too!  Cheesy, garlicky, spicy from the jalapenos and with oodles of crab for the group.  If I could have it my way I'd get 3 orders of Crab Grits, 3 orders of Conch Fritters and a pitcher of Sweet Tea.  The grilled hearts of romaine with the bacon pieces was an excellent starter contrast to the conch fritters too.  Our group loved the duck pate' with the chutney, I just can't do it.  The fried chicken was pretty good too.  Tal K. liked it so much he ate my last piece (fatty)  Pamela, our server, was incredible!  She knew when to chat us up and knew when to leave us alone.  I wanted for nothing and looked forward to her bubbly chats and responses to our zaniness.  All in all a wonderful dining experience.
author: Chard M.

description: The price to goodness ratio is off.  The food is expensive ($15-20/entree) and the food was just not great.  The grits and crab dish was so rich it was gross, and the crab accounted for about 5% of the dish itself.  It would make a good side dish to a nice grilled piece of fish or something light like that.  The Island Pepper Pot Stew had a tasty broth, but the meat was covered in fat.  For $19 of stew meat,  it should have been better.  The escavietch fresh fish was dry and lacked flavor -- again for $19 dollars.  The fried chicken was the best thing at the table, but for less money you can go to Farmer Brown, Popeye's or Blue Jay Cafe and get more chicken with better flavor.  I hate to sound like a biotch on Yelp, so I will tell you that the ambiance is great and the service was absolutely some of the best we've had in a long time.  Plus, you can wait down the street at the 3300 Club and have a drink and they'll call the bar and tell you to come when your table is ready.  Fun!
author: S S.

description: I really really wanted to like this place.  I think the atmosphere and concept are great, but that's about where it ends.  I love me some Southern fried food, and I've given this place a couple of chances.  Unfortunately, all I really got was a couple of plates full of that chewy fat on meat that you can't swallow.  Even though everything is fried, southern food should have some great flavor, and this place missed it for me.  The drinks and service is just okay, but it's too expensive for what you get.  I would recommend going to Hard Knox.  It's infinitely better.
author: Johnny R.

description:
I don't understand why this place is getting the great reviews?
The food is average, & the wait for a table is unreal. I went there over Labor Day weekend, to take advantage of the 'burning man exodus' to get a table w/o the wait. We were told 30 minutes, but weren't seated for an hour & a half. Had we known that, my dining companion & I would have gone to one of the other 10 restaurants we like in that area, & would have been served  a meal & paying our check, before we seated at the front porch.
I'm not a chicken person. The last 2 time I've been there I ordered the crab & grits, voted "best new dish" in one of the local weekly paper's "Best of the Bay" issues. The crab & grits is good, but not worth waiting for.
I like the grungy chic look they have going on, but we thought it was so Tacky, when my boyfriend ordered a glass of wine, & at our table, they poured it for him out of what looked like a child's juice box (without the straw taped to the side).
The food is expensive, In my opinion, this place is WAY OVERRATED.
I live in the neighborhood (walking distance) so I've been in there 3 times. In other word- this review is not based on 1 bad experience.
I've given up on trying to like this place,
author: Lauren B.

description: I don't know if I would really categorize this place as a Caribbean restaurant, but Soul Food for sure.  Definitely delicious!  My date and I enjoyed ourselves thoroughly.  The atmosphere is super comfortable: hip-hop and a nice dimmed lightening.  When we showed up the place was pretty crowded, and while the hostess could have sat the two of us at a table, she brought us straight to a booth.  That speaks a lot to me.  For cocktails I had the lillita (like a mojito, which was absolutely to die for and I hate mojitos...only ordered because the waitress said it was her favorite) and the date had a very tasty thunderberg (bitters and gingerbeer = yum).  Well of course we had many!  They were so good.  Food wise we had the shrimp grits as an appetizer and then split the fried chicken and jerk poussin.  The fried chicken was probably the best I've ever had...all white meat and super moist...yummmm.  And the jerk poussin was a nice little chicken stuffed with joy.  No complaints here.  If nothing else, I would come back for the fried chicken and grits.  Yummm.
author: Justine D.

description: We made a dinner of sides: macaroni and cheese, collard greens, creamed spinach, succotash, beans and rice, fried okra, house-picked vegetables. Oh, and bourbon pecan pie.
author: Amy B.

description: i have now been to the front porch on two occasions,  and have eaten fried chicken, shrimp po'boy, burger, and the rock cod. of the four entries, enjoyed the chicken and the burger the most. if you want a good po'boy head to brenda's.  the drinks are really good though...my recommendation would be to come here with a couple friends, enjoy a bucket of chicken and try and few of the specialty  'bevies'.
author: Jaime R.

description:
five million yelpers can't be wrong...
or can they?
i really wanted to like this place, it's totally adorable.  we had nice moscato d'asti cocktails, the cornbread was light and sweet, and the service was impeccably friendly, but the menu's food was *so* hit or miss.  we had 3 different starters, and each was more vinegar-y than the next.  there was no tamarind to be tasted in my greens w/tamarind dressing, and the pickled mango in the radicchio salad- good lord.  i LOVE vinegar, and it was pretty much inedible to me.
main dishes were the opposite, super heavy and creamy.  my fried okra could have been fried anything, as it was mostly breading... and somehow, it stayed crispy as leftovers.  that is unnatural.  the crab and grits was tiny, b/c it was mostly cream, and seemed like it would be hard to eat much of w/o feeling ill afterwards.  plate sizes were so inconsistent- my salad was monstrous compared to any other appetizer.
we skipped dessert b/c we were so full, and i left slightly disappointed and feeling oddly inadequate for just not understanding the buzz about this place, foodwise.
author: Ariane R.

description: how are you supposed to read a menu in such dim candle lights??? well, you don't miss much because the selections are quite limited....my friend was not pleased with his  friend chicken (TWO pieces of small flavorless chickens cost $12.875) and I had hard time chewing my undercooked pork chop. although our waitress was helpful and attentive, i'd rather stay in my own front porch.
author: D'Andy C.

description:
the colonel continues to be my benchmark in all things fried chicken. this place was disappointing. you kind of have to work extra hard to compensate for not having a drive-thru.

chicken stats:
- battered or breaded? breaded
- dark or white meat? both (though the dark was rather dry)
- grease factor: 6/10
author: D M.

description: I like this place.  A lot.  And because of that, I took my mom there when she came into town from NYC.  I had been bragging about how much we san franciscans are true foodies.  Oops.  Ok, I understand, day before a new menu, which I know NOW, but if a dish is unserve-able...then, er, don't serve it.  I ordered the vegan option, because I've had such amazing experiences with their vegan one-pot stew in the past.  This time, however, a more apt name would have been "new menu tomorrow so let's grill whatever we've got and throw it on some rice."  This concept is ok when I am poor and will eat anything I've got at home.  But when I'm paying for a meal at a restaurant, not so much.  The server (who, as always, was super cool), described the dish as having eggplant and some other stuff over coconut scented rice with Serrano pepper.  What actually showed up in front of me was coconut scented rice with two HUGE grilled Serrano peppers, and some chunks of sweet plaintain mixed in the rice.  The main vegetables were TWO SERRANO peppers, and the eggplant was nowhere to be found.  I took a bite of the pepper thinking it was eggplant because it was so huge and prominent on the plate (and it was grilled so the color had faded).  Now I like spicy, but that was not edible.  It took twenty minutes for my throat to de numb.  That is just plain dangerous and shouldn't be served.   We mentioned it to the server, who laughed it off and we like it there a lot and definitely did not want to make it an issue and cause an awkward situation.  I didn't want to make a big deal out of it, but I was seriously displeased.   I didn't touch the rest of my meal, mostly because I couldn't swallow, and I was disappointed in the service aspect of things to not notice that and try to fix things.  Paying 14 bucks to have my throat set on fire (and I re-iterate, I love spice, I put siracha or tabasco on everything) is not my ideal of a nice night out.  I'll be back, but you guys should know - not cool.  No pun intended.
author: Esperenza T.

description: I made the mistake of watching The best thing I ever ate: fried chicken, on the food network late one night and it became incredibly vital that I get some awesome fried chicken stat. My friend found this place on yelp so we decided to try it out. We went for an early lunch and were seated with no problems. The service was good and my 2 year old got an awesome kids menu with a picture of Mr T and a unicorn to color. I ordered the chicken and waffles which I was told would take about 20 minutes to make. That was no problem. I order the kids mac and cheese for my little one and they offered to bring it out first (thank you!) When I got my chicken and waffles I immediately tore into the drumstick. It was a little rubbery like it was undercooked and the breading, while nice and crispy, lacked flavor.  I was so disappointed. all 3 pieces of chicken were the same. The waffle was, a waffle. Nothing special. I probably won't go back but if I do I will definitely order something else. At least my kid liked the mac and cheese.
author: Tish B.

description: ok, so the crew i rolled with seemed to know everyone, but i don't think that would really matter at this place. everyone seemed to be friendly - a sign of a true neighborhood joint. this place is what more refined people would call "cozy". the sous chef sent out a concoction he made of jalapeno jelly that went well on pretty much everything. i ordered the macaroni and cheese and, on the waitress' recommendation, the beef stew. i wasn't all that hungry, but i was excited to try something new and the stew was nice. huge chunks of soft meat and a very thick sauce. a friend had the crab and grits of which i tasted and wished i'd ordered. they also have huge duvels, so it's easy to get a bit toasted.
author: Jeremiah W.

description: fried chicken is fabulous.  spicy crab in goods bowl of something wonderful.  soul food.  good stuff.  little pricey is the only reason for four stars.  really good food thought so if you got the money do it.
author: seth r.

description: "Have you been to this place?" my friend asked non-chalantly, having no idea that our lives were about to change. "No, I think I heard it was good though" I responded....not wanting to admit that I hadn't gone there because they don't have a full bar and I always seem to think of going there when I want there to be a full bar. This particular night, however, it was early and we were meeting people later...I was hungry. We started with the frisee salad minus the bacon cause I don't really dig bacon much. The salad was very good. We also had a chick pea appetizer which was terrific and one more thing which I'm blanking on right now but was also good. I think it involved ahi. Having not eaten all day, we continued to order very  happily. We ordered a bucket of the yummy chicken and the spicy crab grits...the latter made me think I'd died and gone to...you know the drill. Wow!!! What an awesome invention this dish is...I will be going back to Front Porch and I will have a lot of difficulty not ordering them grits!!! Now, don't get me wrong, the chicken was good, very good but the grits....oh baby!
author: Lucy W.

description:
I went here on Mothers Day evening,  I have heard about the Front Porch on Comcast on Demand promoting their outstanding Fried Chicken and the Crab & Grits so I took a trip from San Jose to spend the day in San Fran., and have dinner at the Porch with my 2 kids and my wife.
  The service was outstanding!  We were first seated in a booth and the 4 of us seem a little confined and moments later the corner booth opened up with much more space so I inquired about us moving 2 feet to the vacant booth.  The hostess was very reluctant to move us as she was looking around the restaurant apparently looking for somebody... she reluctantly gave us permission to move.
  As we sat at our new table it was evident why she wanted us to stay at our original table..  Her friends came in and sat at our old table.  I want to say THANK YOU to her because all she had to say to me was, "I'm sorry, but the big table is reserved." and that would of been the end of it but no she would rather for us to be comfortable, again thank you.
  We had one server and she was very good and attentive, not just my server,but the whole front of the house staff took care of our table and it wasn't just my table it was the whole restaurant.
 
  We ordered the Chicken and the Crab and Grits with an order of the BBQ shrimp for an appetizer.  Our server informed us "We have a new Chef "and "we don't have the crab anymore and he will replace it with shrimp".  I heard some very good thing about the crab etc. but I said I'll give it a try anyway.
  The BBQ arrived and for $11 I was highly disappointed.  The shrimp was extremely over cooked and pasty and and the size of the shrimp were 31-40's not 16 -20's so they were very small and when over cooked it was the size of a nickle! and there was only 5.  The craw fish that came with it was just a shell no meet inside  to suck out(which is the best thing about craw fish) and no craw fish tail to mention.
  The entrees arrived along with 2 side dishes, mashed potato's and collard greens.  I come from and Irish family back east and my mother would hit me with a frying pan if I served her what I received that night.  It was very lumpy!  Don't get me wrong..  it was good and it was made from scratch and not a box, but chef needs to take his time getting rid of the lumps.  The chicken was outstanding!  I saw my step daughter devour the fried chicken!  It remained me of viewing the Discovery Channel watching the Lions in Africa eating a free buffet of Wilder Beast!  Honest to God!  I saw her sucking the bone!  I was afraid to touch her plate for her to slow down for the fear of my limb!
  My Crab and Grits(sorry shrimp), again shrimp undersized and over cooked and pasty and not much of a portion but I ate it.  The grits, I could not tell the difference between a good grit and a bad grit, I'm from the Northeast part of the country but I have had them before and it taste like any other grit but the flavor was masked behind the very good hot sauce.  The very same hot sauce served in the over priced and over cooked BBQ Shrimp.
 
  Would I go back??  Not after paying over $100 for 2 kids and 2 adults and still leaving hungry.
author: David C.

description: go early - like way before 7pm or else you'll end up waiting forever!  i love that they have tallboys on the menu so i ordered me up a giant red stripe and proceeded to chip away at some good eats: fried chicken was a tad salty (but could be a ploy to get you to drink more?) but tasty nonetheless.  black eyed peas and collards - yum!  brussel sprouts - pretty good but we make 'em at home all the time so whatever.  yellow cake with chocolate frosting - awesome and reminded me of being in elementary school.  all in all, pretty good.  worth a trip down to the lower mission area.  would be fun to actually sit on the front porch, when it's not raining of course.
author: Cyn B.

description: What a find...decided to have my 37th birthday here (what the heck else do you do for your 37th birthday but eat friend chicken) and we had a blast!  I had miss ollie's fried chicken (or something like that) and it was fabulously fried...in a sinful way!  The chicken underneath was perfectly tender so I didn't feel too fat afterwards.  Appetizer was fried squash which was great.  And the cornbread fingers were just amazing.  I could have had a basket of those alone!  Now, the service needs a little work.  Not because our server wasn't extremely friendly...but the timing of meals and overall table pacing was just so-so.  Had I been drinking I probably wouldn't have cared.  We had to wait a while for drinks because the bar was slammed (there's a social scene there that is really cool but that I am way too unhip to participate in...)  We ended up passing on dessert and going to Mitchell's ice cream instead.  But everything looked good.  Will definitely be going back.  This is a true and francisco-style, down home and hip place to eat.  Pass it on to your friends.
author: Norman P.

description: oh man, rob and i REALLY miss the crab grits and that one fish and chip special we had when we first dating, with that bad-ass lady chef.  i did however, enjoy the rose champagne cocktail.  and the service was great.
author: Kimby T.

description: Fried chicken reminiscent of Shake and Bake.  Corn fritters a little chewy.  Good atmosphere.  We need more home cooking in the city.
author: Christine N.

description: this place was wonderful, my honey took me for a nice night out, the staff was extremely nice and VERY helpful, the spicy crab and grits was yum! the deep fried plantains double yum! and the fried chicken, just like everyone else said was amazing!!! we had a wonderful bottle of pinot noir and the night was wonderful, we had a late night dinner but they never once made us feel rushed, we are def going back, for a nice dinner, or even some beers and their bucket of chicken on their front porch!!
author: Jennifer T.

description: this place has a wonderul bistro cum hipster diner vibe about it. expect a wait but once your nestled into your booth or table expect great things to arrive on your plate. the roasted root veggies and goat cheese were divine. the fried chicken is def. different, something in the batter. great date spot and for dining solo at the bar.
author: casey c.

description: This place rules. And it's really lucious and tasty for how (relatively) inexpensive it is. It's top notch quality food for middle notch prices, in my opinion. Their Red Eye (a bloody mary with beer) is delicious though it could use more spicy and some vegetables. Starters are really the most delicious thing to me here. Anything that's a fritter or fried doughy dumpling with raw fish is really wondrous here. The pork & beans is fantastic BUT the fried chicken (and let me say first that the sides were top-notch and fresher than most soul food joints) didn't live up to Oakland soul food standards. OK, but not awesome. Southern Cafe on Macarthur Blvd. in Dimond District is where I go for the best fried chicken I've found thus far in life. Uh...service is great here too. Everyone is amazingly sweet and attentive and just on it. Desert was cool cream and warm chocolate drenched pastries that were basically amazing. The docked star is so that hopefully someone at FP will remedy these easy things and ascend this place to the empyrean...
author: Alee K.

description: Solid 4, maybe 4.5 stars now.  Had the ribs.  Great sauce, but not fall off the bone, which I prefer.  (I don't hold that against Front Porch, because nobody in the Bay Area seems to know how to cook ribs.)  Finally tried the fried chicken, and it was very, very good.  The skin has so much flavor and the chicken was still juicy.  Sides were solid, but nothing spectacular.  I got to try a few bites of the burger.  Amazing.
author: Tom Z.

description: I love this place!!!  Food is awesome!  I just wish you could get the popcorn bucket of fried chicken and choose your sides.  Not everyone likes greens!  That's what deters me from getting it when I'm with a couple people--and it says no substitutions!  Hate that.  Also, it's SUPER loud in here, so if you want to have a conversation while you eat, prepare for a horse voice in the morning.  All that won't stop me from coming though!  Get a bumper sticker on your way out!
author: Jo M.

description: This place is awesome - excellent food and cool environment.  Highly recommended!
author: Molly C.

description: i really like this place, but you have to be forewarned.  it's total bad for you /comfort food.  like grits, bucket o fried chicken, all the fatty food you can eat bad for you.  we went early and put our names down for 3 hours later.  totally worked.  we were able to go home, take a nap,shower, get ready for a night out... and then only had to wait like 10 minutes!  the service is good.  really knowledable w/o being pretentious, and the atmosphere is funky laid back and fun.  we had the beet salad, charcuterie which was insane... but SO rich and fatty.  fried pork belly, yum.  fried chicken, grits (to die for), jerk special.  everything was really good, and for me a real treat.  i think you just have to make sure that you are in the mood for this type of cuisine.  also... prob isn't the best for digestion!
author: Liz C.

description: Im a hard brotha to please, with that said... imma have to give you the rundown.  Called trying to book a reservation for a special bday night on a friday... "We only do reservations for parties of 5 or more", what? ok first strike.. being that when we got there it was an hour wait.  ugggh.. and before i go further - wait is the theme to this place..  I dont mind being patient but maan, too much waiting isnt too much fun. The setup is chill, nice, i even dig the front porch part, though it doesnt remind me of a soul bros front porch.. lol.  The bar is only wine and beer, hmmm ok had to order something foofy, no cognac  :(  After about an hour and some change we got seated.  By this time we knew what we wanted to eat, so we ordered as soon as we sat down.  During that time they brought out some great cornbread, this was the highlight of the night , with some jamming , honey butter with peppers.. man that was good.  After more waiting they brought out some fried okra to tiddy us over.. my lady liked it with the spicy ketchup. Ok 25 to 30 minutes later, they brought our sides... the macaroni pie, red beans and rice.  Hmm ok where is our main dishes, 7 minutes later the main dishes... isnt that bassackwards, at least give me the main stuff first.  The chicken was good, but not even the best ive ever had, like some have claimed, actually it wasnt very seasoned, same with the fish.  Good but not great or screaming (like the homies say).  The mac and red beans and rice were ok.. but not screaming.  I can say though they were prepared a lil different, the plantains were good.  All in all the meal is nice, but all the sides stood out not the main dishes they were kinda bland to my soul food palette.
author: Wes H.

description:
minus one star for waiting for our table for 15 minutes and it being a very LOUD location.  we had a birthday party of 8, and we often could not hear conversations among the table.  otherwise, we had great service and amazing food. 
 it was one of those night where we ordered literally half the menu--and i loved everything i tried.  the ceviche, the salads, the grits were all great starters.  people had fried chicken,the short ribs, the fish, the fried oyster sandwich-- all were great.  and the sides?  heaven.  the black eyed peas, the macaroni pie, the spinach, even the french fries were amazing.  people had wine, drinks and beers.  2 of our parties were drivers, so they had one beer each.  but most people had 2 or 3 drinks.  we opted to skip dessert.  and after all that food, drink and merriment?  i was stunned to see even with treating the birthday girl, it was only $55 a person.  i left full, happy and satisfied.  yay!
author: Alisha A.

description: I was surprised to find how vegetarian friendly the place was!!  There is one vegan entree on the menu (which rocks!!). However there are a few starters and sides that are vegetarian as well and are very good. The waiter was very patient as we went through our limited choices to figure out the order. The only thing I didn't appreciate is being charged the full price for a 1/3 of a starter dish that comprised of beans and toast. The original entree included salmon, deviled eggs amongst other things. The only thing we got was a minimized beans and toast. Normally, I wouldn't complain about that, however this dish definitely didn't seem worth the full price. 4 stars for excellent food and great service.
author: Beena A.

description: dinner was fantastic! i tasted 3 entrees and thoroughly enjoyed them all: fried chicken, beef 2 ways, and suckling pig. the veggies on the side were also nice - not overcooked. 2 smalls quips - the lobster bisque was only so-so, and not being able to order the cocktail i desired was a downer (beer and wine only folks).
author: Mark B.

description: This place is so much fun.  It masks itself as kind of a dive which makes it more interesting.  All the fried items were great!  it's definitely worth checking out
author: Zach F.

description: I love the divey feel of this place - like you are going over to the neighbor's run down house.  As Daisy K noted, the glasses they serve wines in are not of the highest caliber, but while my friend is not pleased with it, my lower brow taste kind of enjoys it!  Had a great night here with two of the most fun gals; we hope the staff was amused by us as we were!  Service was great, friendly, and tolerant of our boisterousness. Ordered ribs (seriously falling off the bone, finger licking good.  Such an overused description, but there is good reason for that. try having these ribs without licking your fingers.  I just don't see it happening!) , We dove in to the bucket of fried chicken - served in a popcorn bucket with popcorn no less. Yum!  I don't generally enjoy fried chicken, but holy fried yummyness, batman.  That stuff is good! The beans, rice and plantains were also great.  Serious comfort food and a great spot.
author: Danielle R.

description: Kickin' chicken!!!  Grits with dungeoness crab!?!?!!!!!  I wake up dreaming about their stuff.  Sara pwns the kitchen and knows her stuff.  Great people own it and work there!!!
author: eiming j.

description: each time i eat here i order the fried chicken... which is really tasty.  the  crust is seasoned well and the chicken is moist. the mashed potatoes have a nice texture. the greens have a big flavor and cut to the proper size. my only complaint is, they have this perfectly fried chicken stacked on top of the potatoes and greens ... so you get soggy fried chicken!  service is good, the staff is really nice and has a great sense of humor. love the appetizers. fried okra and hush puppies are good considering no one seems to carry them on their menu? come early if you want to avoid the line.
author: melissa s.

description: This was our 2nd visit to Front Porch.  Thumbs up on the Happy Hour items...liked the fried okra and gumbo.  Beer selection is good & varied and the house wines are pleasant enough.
