Got the "legendary" fried chicken with mashed potatoes & green beans.  The sides were tasty enough but the chicken was way too salty...both the meat & the breading.  We found the chicken salty on our 1st visit while it was still Caribbean and had hopes that this was corrected.  Service was "OK" but not overly friendly.  We will only be back if Blue Plate is closed.
author: Dennis S.

description: what can i say about the front porch that hasn't already been said?  the food is very good-- perhaps at times overly complicated, but not in a bad way.   and maybe not so much really caribbean or southern, but definitely inspired by these flavors.  and inspiration is a good thing.  just don't fool yourself into thinking you are getting an "authentic" southern food experience- this is all san francisco.  quintessential san francisco.  again, not a bad thing.  i love san francisco-- that is why i live here.  and restaurants like this- down the block and in a basement- are all part of the charm.
author: Samantha W.

description: Were my expectations too high?Probably, but I'm not willing to be that objective.  We arrived at 5:00 sat down at 5:45 and didn't even meet our server until 6:15 - say WHAT?  The conch fritterswere okay.  We also ordered the trio of fries based on a yelp recommendation and low-and-behold, they ALSO came with the burger my boyfriend ordered.  Say WHAT?  Our server chose not to tell us this when we orderd - that's a crap load of french fries...  I had the crab with grits and it was okay at best.  Boyfriend loved the burger, but that did not make-up for poo service and all the other mediocre dishes.
author: Jane M.

description: too busy and backed up for what you get. the host told us we'd wait 30 minutes -- it was closer to an hour, and this was on a monday night. they get 2 stars for having the front porch itself, which is an ok place to wait. however, all this waiting didn't seem worth it for the food -- i had the fish and chips and it was decidedly mediocre.
author: omar k.

description:
i guess i shouldn't be surprised about how many people from the immediate vicinity are writing about this place... it's that kind of hood. plus it sure beats the dominic club bar and grilled, as i believe it was called. 

i also traveled almost a third of a block for dinner opening night, i guess a couple weeks ago. damn it was busy for 5:30 on a weeknight! i recently opened a new restaurant, and i feel for the employees/owners. it's so much work to start from scratch, and gets so much easier with time and familiarty. 

i liked the tin ceiling, the rest of the ambience was fine, hipster-y (this should go without saying), but not amazing. nice eclectic music. our table should not have been there. it was in the middle of the central corridor, with people squeezing by on both sides. hopefully this was a temporary situation. 

the service was very slow, taking about two hours for a three course meal. our charming waitress did apologize in advance, and informed us that we were about the second table she had served there.  i don't fault them for the delay, given the circumstances, but i thought i should mention it. i'm sure she did the best she could, she seemed skilled. 

as for food and drink: i love the beer list, with 22 oz bottles, a pint of barley wine, and king cobra?!! i got the barley wine and water  - and the jugs are cool for water. i tried some of the ginger beer as well, pretty tasty. the wine list looked trendy and decent. first we got the cornbread, delicious but nothing new. after: the salt cod plate was rad. smoked sashimi with fritters too, and some almost spicy jelly. the salad was ok, boston lettuce is my favorite, but the dressing was kind of bland, and i'd like some, like, garnishes or something. the rum/liver pate with mango chutney was totally tasty, if uninspired. and the nuts were good, but should have been free, or there should have been more. and spicier. second course: fried chicken. it wasn't perfect but it was good... i'll get it again and i bet they will have it NAILED. they were close on opening night! ditto for the collard greens and blackeyed peas (with pork belly, of course, very san francisco to give us the option). not improperly cooked, but nothing special. some forgettable soup. oh and the crab and grits thingy. i didn't get to it in time, as it was gone in about five seconds. there's always next time... oh and the crisp was good too.

so i like it. i think they will evolve into a more smoothly running machine. i'll be back.
author: fletcher s.

description: Yep, fried chicken is yummy!  Had a pork chop there that was served to me rare.  They told me it was brined and fine to serve rare but offered to give me something else and didn't charge.  I love their sides and their cornbread.  It gets real loud inside once it's filled, so best to go around 5:30-6
author: J T.

description: Some of the best service that I have experienced in the city. One reason, these guys/gals are down to earth and have a great sense of humor. Unfortunately for me, I was sporting a black eye and wearing a sweater vest. Fortunately for the bartender, she was able to notice and ask me "Did you get beat up by Mr. Rogers?".  Really funny. One of my buddies noticed that they have King Cobra on their drink menu. Who in the world has malt liquor on their drink menu? The staff noticed that they had 4 loud and rowdy guys and decided to sit us at the corner of kitchen and bathroom. Perfect seating b/c we were loud and rowdy. Our waitress had one more smart comment for me and I had to throw out the jackass comment of "i hope your not expecting a big tip." Her reply was golden. "Oh my god! wait what did you say about my big tits?"  It was alot of fun. I would give this a 5 but the chicken was overcooked and dry. Maybe we had a bad batch b/c we were one of the last tables. However the collard greens with ham was excellent. Will definitely make a return trip.
author: John S.

description: I have avoided Yelper favorites for months now after the many lousy experiences I've had at these "incredible favs" of the Yelper (morons) crowd. But I got dragged to this place the other night because I am a former French Quarter resident and LSU grad - so pals of mine always want to take me to southern/cajun/creole places. Why? I don't know why...because I always tell them that I have NEVER had good Louisiana cooking outside of Louisiana - simple as that. But I went along willingly - with an open heart and an open mind probably brought on by the fact that I was seriously Jones'n for some really good red beans and rice and a bowl of real Louisiana style gumbo. Cute place - pretty good service - cold beer - comfy booths and tables - nice crowd of people - all good so far. So we order all the really southern items on the menu - that's why we went there - who goes to a place like this and orders a burger? Yelpers do - that's who - because they are bozo's and don't know any better - then they write about it because they think they are qualified to do so and that somebody out there cares. Listen up Yelpers - they don't. If it weren't for your Mom and your "friends" that tell you how funny you are - no one would read the uninformed crap that you write. This place was such a bust it is hard to know where to begin? Where they found the recipes for some of this food is a real mystery? The food was so bad it's almost like you would have to intentionally try to cook it that poorly. If you bill yourself as a southern food joint - and you serve inedible gumbo, lousy red beans and rice, mediocre greens, OK shrimp and grits and hush puppies like none I have ever eaten before (and not in a good way) - well then you deserve to get some not so nice things said about your place. This food was not OK or mediocre or "maybe I'll try it again" kinda food - it was just bad. Really bad. Yet I felt bad when we left - I liked the way the joint felt - someone has put their heart and soul into it and created a place with a great feeling and a cool crew. But the food we had was terrible and I will never be able to return there again. So - thanks again Yelpers! You've kept your track record in tact - another highly rated Yelper joint that was just about as bad as bad can be. Congrats to all you unqualified critic wannabe Yelper clowns.
author: stephanie d.

description: this is one of my favorite places in the city. it's cozy and dark, the owners are so cool and friendly, the champagne is affordable and the grits with crab is unbelievable.
author: Lily S.

description: I heard so much about this place and it's Fried Chicken (and mind you, there's nothing better in life than good fried chicken), so I finally made the trek over to give this place a go. I called up to find out they don't take reservations so a friend and I got off work early so we can get a table before the dinner crowd. The ambiance of this place was a little confusing. The kitschy southern decor felt very out of place in the dark moody lighting. It's like this place couldn't make up it's mind on whether it's a date spot or a family friendly restaurant. So we got the menu and the fried chicken entree came as either a regular plate meal or in a bucket. Now...chicken in a bucket. That's a good sign. So I ordered the chicken of course. Maybe I was a bit too hyped up about the fried chicken and the whole buildup only lead to disappointment when I took the first few bites. First off, fried chicken needs to be greasy and that fried skin..... Oh, that fried skin NEEDS to be crunchy. The skin on this baby wasn't as juicy and succulent as it could have been. Overall, the chicken I got was only OK. It was maybe a step above KFC (and I loves my KFC). After dinner, we left the place feeling that it was good that we tried it but would we come back for the food? Probably not....
author: Richard K.

description: Love their fried chicken and their burgers. Burgers are very homestyle with housemade ketchup. Yum! One word of advice-a medium rare burger comes out really rare.
author: r e.

description: Love this place! Best Southern Food in San Francisco. No complaints. Service was great, and above all, the food makes a lasting impresssion.
author: Grace S.

description: Had dinner here for the first time last night with a fun group.  Overall a very positive experience.  HAve to agree with other reviewers that it's not really a Carribean restaurant - American Continental/Soul Food is not a bad description.  The decor is cozy and fun, not too open, not too cramped.  They have a small, but excellent beer list, including St. Peter's Cream Stout, quite possibly my favorite beer ever, and an excellent accompaniment to some competent fried chicken.  The menu is eclectic and so are the prices - some entrees are 30+, but the burger is only $11.  Personally I like that - you want gourmet food, you pay gourmet prices.  The chicken is a great deal at about $15.  Service was pretty attentive with occasional lapses.  However they put up with our ridiculous 15-minute figure-out-the-bill session with a smile so extra points there.  Overall, a very positive experience.  I'd go back.
author: Adam H.

description: loved the front porch burger and the ceviche.  the fried chicken was delicious but i was tremendously disappointed when my bucket did not contain any drumsticks.  what is fried chicken without a drumstick?  the wait for the table was pretty long which is typical for good food in SF but the service....well the owner was super nice(i think he was the owner) - but our waiter was just eh.
author: a g.

description:
new order, beatnuts, and other 80's miscellany next to 90's club rap.

wow.

it might tell you just how brave this place really is. it might also tell you how ghetto fab you can really be in sf. the chicken bests farmer brown,  but the negative is that there are no substitutions to the grits and beans that come with. I'm not a big fan of grits sans eggs+bacon, but these went well with the greasy chicken. The beans, not so much. I would have rather had a traditional fare of coleslaw alongside my fried goodness. 

oh! and if you're curious about the sweet and salty nuts, just do it. they're off the hook.
author: Daniel C.

description: I had dinner with a group of five Saturday night. There is limited seating for more than a few large parties but Kevin and staff took care of us while we waited. We called that afternoon to make a reservation but they were booked. The wait wasn't very long. The staff was very friendly and professional and kept checking in with us during the wait. The food was incredible! The fried chicken was to die for! The colesslaw and cornbread were really good too. And my other favorite was the lemon pound cake! Great wine selection also. The 10 year old daughter of a friend was with us and she really enjoyed it. Even after accidentally finding a small piece of glass buried between the seat cushions. Kevin immediately came over to clean the entire booth and made sure she was ok. He apologized then provided a few appetizers for us on the house. This wasn't necessary at all since the young lady wasn't cut and was pretty calm about the whole thing. We were really impressed. The staff was also very attentive the entire evening. I would definitely return for their brand of down-home cooking!
author: Douglas H.

description: I love this place. I love it so much that I find myself daydreaming at really odd times about how awesome it is.  The bucket of chicken....divine, mouthwatering!! The conch fritters!! Hell Yeah!! The fried frog legs...out of this fucking world. Plus the service is great!!! I went there on my birthday and I was wasted!! They were very nice to me, they should have kicked me out but they didn't!! I love them!!! Every one should experience their food!! It is divine!!!!
author: Yayne A.

description: i went to this place on a whim and was hooked! the cocktails are awesome and friend chicken delicious! its hard to find Caribbean food around here period, much less some this yummy!
author: pascale p.

description: Chickpea app, vegan stew and rose sangria. Rose sangria was out of this world. Vegan stew was OK but $15 is a lot. Chickpea app was interesting and new.  I wouldn't want to get the stew again but you never know what the one vegan entree will be. Maybe I'll be back again just for drinks or drinks plus some sides. Place has a fun atmosphere and good service.
author: Sarah J.

description: southern comfort food with an inventive carribean twist( must try item: spicy fried plantains )
author: aj s.

description: I took my boyfriend to the front porch for his birthday dinner a few weeks ago and LOVED it.  We had to wait for about 30 minutes on a Monday night, but we grabbed a couple of glasses of wine and sat out on the rocking chairs.  They've done an amazing job with the space, which used to be a sketchy bar that i only stumbled into once -- and it wasn't a good idea.  The crowd was great.  I was a big fan of the avo, cucumber and watermelon radish salad.  The veggie stew was good and my boyfriend loved the crab and grits dish.  Great spot for the price.
author: Ali H.

description: Honestly, this is the kind of place that makes you proud to be a foodie. The Front Porch is outstanding. One of the perks to dating someone who has worked in some great SF dining establishments is that you find out about all the great new places opening up! I have been there several times since its opening and each time it gets better and better. The Bucket of Fried Chicken is to die for and great for group sharing. However, the star of the show for me is the crab porridge, it is truly outrageous and leaves me wanting more! Also, if you think you don't like Brussels sprouts...think again. The chef's maple glazed sprouts will leave you a true believer. I could go on for days about everything on the menu but I will leave some for you to find out about! Just get there early because they do get slammed and if you have to wait you can sip on some wine while sitting on their front porch rocking chairs.
author: Sugey G.

description: Great food but insanely long wait if you get there after 7.  Fried chicken is heaven, and the yellow cake is to die for.  The maitre d / waiter guy is awesome and so friendly.  Great atmosphere (loud though) and very well prepared food.  One of my favorite places to eat at on a Tuesday at 6...
author: Kristi S.

description: After hearing rave reviews from friends and reading over reviews my boyfriend and I tried out The Front Porch this evening.  We were both so disappointed!  As an appetizer we ordered the cod and pepper fritters were good but salty...and I know cod can be salty but not if you cook it right.  We ordered the fried chicken and it had no flavor...extremely bland.  The corn on the cob was disgustingly salty in spots.  The staff was all friendly and helpful but overall we were really disappointed and will probably not go back
author: Angela C.

description: I had dinner here last night for a friend's birthday and tried out the fried chicken that's been talked about. At our table we started out with the doubles which was chickpeas in a curry sauce and cucumber salad with some kinda fry bread. That was pretty tasty. I ordered Miss Ollie's fried chicken which had a corn meal like crust served with mac 'n cheese and black eyed peas with collard greens. I enjoyed the food but I think there were varied opinions. The Vegan One pot stew wasn't anything special according to the vegetarians but the birthday boy loved the deep fried chicken livers. I'm not a big fan of chicken liver so it tasted like, liver. At the end of the night, they brought out a sweet potato pie with a scoop of Mitchell's coconut ice cream for the birthday boy. I could've done without the pie. It was bland in flavor and left a strange after taste which might've been the combination of coconut and sweet potato. Overall the ambiance was fun and I'd go back for the chicken.
author: Brenda K.

description: I got the pork chops for take-out.  Quite good.
author: Mike H.

description: Maybe it was all the glowing reviews I read about this place, but i was expecting more. The food was not memorable. My friend that i went with had the hamburger and they were very disappointed. The bun was stale. After his first bite the bun crumbled into pieces. My dish was OK. Nothing great. I had the vegan special.  Since this place is down the street I will probably come back in a few months to see if the food has improved.
author: Cleo I.

description: Great service & friendly staff.  Nice decor.  We waited maybe 20 minutes on a Sunday evening but it was relaxing rocking in their rockers in the sun.  The food is tasty.  I had the fried chicken (2 pieces), black-eyed peas, collard greens, and grits.  I have never been a fan of grits until now; they were sweet and hot at the same time, delicious!  The portions of the sides are on the small end but the meal was filling.  My friend had the vegan special (squash, corn, and okra) and loved it!  We shared a lemon pound cake w/ strawberries and cream for dessert, yum!  I definitely recommend this place; I just would not go on a Friday or Saturday night due to crowds.
author: Stephanie F.

description: just eat the crab grits and drink a budweiser.  it all works out.
author: Megan T.

description: This place was way beyond my expectations.  I got there with my honey on a Sun. around 6 and it was already crowded so we opted to sit at the bar.  The bartender and all of the servers were so amazingly friendly/attentive/unpretentious that we were immediately relaxed and had no regrets about not waiting for a table.  I thought that the interior was very cool and comfortable, kind of like those antiquated spots in New Orleans where you get the best soul food. So then the food started arriving: first the delicious cornbread, simple and uncomplicated. The perfect compliment to a before dinner cocktail.  Then we split the salad with watermelon turnip and grapefruit, a great combination of texture, sweet, cold = very refreshing.  I opted for the fried chicken plate for dinner and had NO regrets.  I grew up in Mississippi as a kid, then later in the Midwest, so I've had great fried chicken before.  This fried chicken was especially moist, tender, and with the crispiest batter that wasn't greasy.  Really good flavor. The potatoes and cole slaw served with it were seasoned well, I liked that they didn't compete with the delicious chicken. Oh, and we split the macaroni pie, I highly recommend!  Very moist with simple seasoning and maybe a yummy bread crumb crust? I usually never (well, rarely) have dessert, but the food was all so good and surprisingly light so I was curious how they could top it all off?  We opted to split the fried grits with corn custard and sour cherries.  It showed up, the fried grits were really dry until we realized that you have to dip the grits into the custard = wow!  Overall, an outstanding dining experience.  I will come back here often.
author: Scott I.

description: Ever since I moved here from Brooklyn, I've been on the hunt for my new favorite restaurants. Those that rival the small, delicious, festive and homespun joints I loved back East. And as of now, with 6 months of research behind me, The Front Porch takes the cake. I've recommended this place over and over again -- the warm service, the lively space, the delicious food. Now everyone I value has to face The Front Porch litmus test. If they love it like I do, I know they're good people.
author: Rebecca S.

description: 3.5, technically, but I liked the food so much it gets 4 stars. Place is a total zoo, even on a Tuesday night. Service was really sort of nonexistent, but the food was wonderful. I had the fried chicken, dining companion had the fish and chips. We split the pickled veggies and egg (I had actually never had a pickled egg before, yum) and the $5 ceviche, which was substantially better than ceviches that I have spent way more than that for. Also had a side of grits that tasted REALLY bad for you, wonderfully creamy and rich. Mild complaints with the patronage, the lady yapping at the hostess about how she had been invited to the "exclusive" pre-opening party and the Mission hipsters (I know I overuse that phrase but there are just so many of them) at the booth behind us asking if the flowers in little stem vases mounted on the wall were locally grown. But hey, that's local color, right? Plus the sangria comes with the bendy straws that I always begged my parents to buy when I was a kid. But they said the straight straws were good enough for me.
author: Liboo K.

description: i'll just keep it simple and say this is easily one of my most fave places to eat......in the WORLD!
author: kristin p.

description: Catching up on some old reviews but wanted to give Front Porch its due because I think it's the best of the Southern-inspired places that have opened in the city over the past year or two. The ceviche, fried chicken, corn bread and crab and grits were all fantastic. The sangria wasn't all that great. I wish their beer list was larger, as beer is generally easier to match with food like this. You might consider bringing a wine as the corkage is only $10 and they'll wave it if you buy a bottle. All in all this a great neighborhood restaurant and a nice use of local ingredients in a style you don't see much in SF.
author: Jonathan B.

description: I went here some time ago and it was delicious! The fried chicken was to die for, along with the homemade doughnut-like desert, every bite seriously melted in my mouth. Minus a point because my mac-and-cheese was cold, but I still ate it all, so it was good. Also minus a point because I was so stuffed I couldn't eat for two days, well actually extra point for being delicious soul food!
author: Maya L.

description: I had my early mother's day dinner here last night 5/7/08 with my daughters.  We had the grits w/crab, crab salad, jerk chicken and lamb stew.  I was great....amazing.  I cook some mean soul food myself...but I always enjoy the meals I have here.  The wait staff is wonderful and the service is.... quick draw ...fast... I have never had to wait....guess I have been lucky!!!
author: deborah w.

description: This place was rocks.  Been there twice, great service, extremely tasty, unique food and a very pleasant atmosphere.
author: J. B.

description: As a vegetarian, I was skeptical that The Front Porch would have anything I'd really like. I went on a whim with some friends who love it and I was really surprised at how good it was. The vegan plate was probably the best I've had of that sort of entree. The appetizers were great and there was a lot of variety. The servers and bartender were super friendly. The atmosphere reminded me of the now defunct 16th St. restaurant, New Dawn, that used to be a great breakfast place back in college. I will definitely recommend this to people and will be coming back.
author: Michelle M.

description: Hate to be the dissenting voice here, but I found the dining experience at The Front Porch to be poor.  The menu was extremely limited and was quite a let down.  We ordered the chicken and fish n chips, but it was hard to find much fish between all that batter; shame.  The chicken was good, but I don't know.....I've had better and I can't say it warranted the price.  I ordered a side of greens and beans, and was expecting just that; instead it was a small bowl of cooked saucy beans with some small bits of greens mixed in.  Poor!  The music was way too loud, which made trying to have any kind of a conversation impossible.  Basically, if this place was a little road side stand with outside  bench seating and the dinners were about $5 -7 bucks, you might have something.  Instead, I found the food and dining experience extremely unappealing.  Maybe we should have been drinking.
author: Tige F.

description: Disappointing considering the prices. Not sure i'd go back. Their menus is just strange. You can't get ribs unless you get it with the wings in the appetizer. The fried chicken is just okay. Lots of seasoning. The skin comes off the meat way too easily. The accompanying slaw doesn't really taste like much. The burger has good meat, but the patty is just disgustingly thick. The fries were good. Pretty crispy for steak fries. The street corn was good. But it's just corn on the cob and it's $5.  I'll seek out another fried chicken place.
author: James C.

description: Really enjoyed this place! It was walkable, the staff were friendly and accommodating-and when they told us they were out of the Vegan Pot, they offered other veggie options. When one of our party did not get the Mahi Mahi she ordered at the same time other meals were served, the staff brought her a salad on the house-great food, good service, highly recommend this place! I will go back.
author: Lisa S.

description: I went here yesterday with some coworkers of mines and the food was absolutely horrible. I am a down home southern gal and I can tell you right now that this isn't by far a soul food restaurant. We order the "famous fried chicken" and infamous it was. The chicken wasn't cruncky and it didn't have not a drop of salt or pepper and no other kind of seasoning. I was so disappointed, the okra was good and the oyster popeboy sandwich was alright. For a party of 10 we spent over $300 bucks and it wasn't worth it. On top of that at the end of our meal we told the waiter that the food was horrible and that the chicken wasn't cruncky or seasoned and she said that it was the chefs first night and thanks for telling us about the food so that we can tell the chef that he needs to season the chicken and fry it longer. As much hype as this place gets and for us to have that type of experience was a big diappointment and until the newly hired chef learns how to cook the menu I wouldn't recommend going here unless you just want okra .
author: Colara H.

description: hmmmm....i'm conflicted...it seems like whenever i go there, my dining companions have much better food than me.  maybe they don't like piggies?  one meal they burned my hamburger bun....that definitely adversely affected my dining experience that night.  my friends had some nice steaks though.  sooooo, the next time i thought i'd go steak, and ordered the blackened skirt steak.  is skirt steak supposed to be really thick...seriously, it was like a filet mignon cut?!?!?!  since it is inherently a tough cut, the thickness and preparation made it completely inedible.  i actually had to send it back...and i NEVER do that since i hate to be a trouble-maker.  my dining companion had a good pork chop at least, so i ate all of her food.  they refunded half the cost of the entree, which was half-nice of them.  anyways, i really want to like this place, but it is so inconsistent...if i go back, i'm ordering what the rest of the table is ordering....
author: Miss P.

description: BE WARNED!  BE AFRAID!  THIS REVIEW IS FOR REAL PEOPLE WHO LIKE REAL FOOD FOR THEIR REAL MONEY!!!  If you need to watch your finances and like good food but think that maybe once in a while it would be nice to eat somewhere everybody says is great do NOT go here.  For $22 I had mahimahi in the shape of baby's fist that was over cooked, absolutely tasteless, dry and tough.  It was served with a scattering of cold, flavorless, indistinguishable tasting vegetables (potatoes? parsnips? yucca? WHAT??).  Went with two friends. The fried chicken was three oh-so tiny pieces, like it came from a cornish game hen, and although considered an entree was more like a really small appetizer.  The hamburger left a very strange aftertaste.  The crab appetizer was mostly grits and came in a ramekin so small it was laughable.  Add one glass of wine.  Total, with tip was $86.00 for food that was really enough for ONE hungry person.  Give me a break!  I felt scammed, fooled, cheated, dissatisfied, disappointed, MAD!!  Oh, yeah, and the long wait, the noise and the off-putting service............ what was there to like?  This place reminds me of the children's story of the Emperor With No Clothes.  If you don't know it google it.
author: Rona M.

description:
the food here is sooooo much better than cha cha cha! came here on a thursday evening..got there @ 6:30 promptly and it was pretty empty--in a matter of 10 min. the place was packed, lots of neighborhood appeal--ppl. living nearby walking in and just filling the place up. i waited for my friend at the bar & we just ended up dining at the bar--i hate waiting and bar dining was a much more personal experience since u have the bartender to check up & entertain you.

my friend ordered the jerk chicken...that half chicken was huge! It was all black but it was sooooo damn moist and just pure yum! 
I went all out and got the bucket of fried chicken which came w/a side of grits & a splash of chili oil (i'd go back just to eat the grits...so yummy and buttery goodness) and a side of black peas (mmm...down home goodness). Now, the chicken...even tho i ordered the bucket, dont expect a KFC bucket..it came in a medium sized old school popcorn bucket filled to the brim & 3 lovely pcs. on the side of the plate--If i had to estimate, you get about 10-12 pcs. (12 pcs. if ur super lucky or if that chicken was damn small) for the bucket & those 2 sides. yea, $32 for a bucket of chicken?? crazy but it was good chicken...none of that grease-dripping, fatty pieces of chicken at the fast food joints! I detected a hint of lemony tang to every bite of chicken and thought the meat was a little too "well-seasoned" for my taste (but it wasnt unbearably salty--just very flavorful)...then i found out from the bartender that the chicken is marinated in lime & salt for a day--ah ha!! right on the money, I am a food detective!!

my friend and i had a sangria...very tasty b/c its made w/guava puree--yummers. oh but the best thing was this miraculous honey, chili flakes whipped butter that goes w/the cornbread...oh shit, that was gooooood! it's was orgasmic good--who would've thought of that combo? i'm soo gonna make that shit now to go w/my bread but u gotta use good quality honey & unsalted butter (whoops the secret's out!) 

so, 4 cocktails total ($25), a jerk chicken ($20), and a bucket of fried chicken ($32)=$97.00 for 2 ppl w/ tip & tax (and a whole bucket of fried chicken for leftovers to take home)...not bad but a bit of a splurge for a simple weeknite dinner. 

only con, hence, the -1star is parking is a PAIN here! thats the only reason why i'd come here once in a blue moon...next time, carpool--i cant even suggest a good time to come b/c parking's a bitch in this 'hood 24/7! 
thank god, i have a parking god...only took me 5 min. to find a spot waiting for me :-) but too bad for my friend..took him 20 min. to find a spot (and thats considered good around here)
author: Yolanda L.

description: nice homey food.  fried chicken is the best, opens til 10:30 usually, perfect for late nights.  ok once in awhile
author: chris y.
